title: Top Prosecutor Stands Out by Pushing Back
description: THE other day, in his office down on Wall Street, Eric T. Schneiderman owned up to an awkward truth.

title: Trying to Reverse a Guilty Plea, Blaming A.D.D.
description: They met in 1986, the setting improbable for romance. She was blond and pretty, but she was in a dentists chair, and he was pulling out her wisdom teeth.

title: Want to Join Me for a Game? Anyone?
description: APP: Sportaneous

title: Yankees-Tigers Game Suspended due to Rain
description: With the weather radar showing storms littering the area and the forecast expecting rain through the night, tonights game has been suspended due to rain. The game will be resumed Saturday night at 8:37 p.m. in the bottom of the second inning, where tonights game left off.

title: Al-Awlaki Killed in Drone Strike
description: Anwar Al-Awlaki was killed in an American drone strike on his vehicle on Friday.

title: 16-Year-Old Becomes Youngest L.P.G.A. Member
description: Lexi Thompson became the youngest member in L.P.G.A. history Friday when the tour commissioner, Mike Whan, approved her petition for full membership beginning in 2012.

title: TimesCast | Al-Awlaki Killed In Yemen
description: September 30, 2011 - An American drone attack in Yemen kills United States-born Qaeda leader and key propagandist, Anwar al-Awlaki.

title: A Dcor to Match a New Connection
description: After 25 years of earning plaudits as a high church of reverently prepared fish, as Frank Bruni, then The New York Timess restaurant critic, called it in 2005, Le Bernardin has undergone a sleek makeover. The restaurant has added a more contemporary feel, along with an extensive cocktail list and a lounge where patrons can order from a small-plate menu (no jackets required). The dining room is now dominated by a 24-foot triptych painting of waves, a design motif carried throughout in the twisted metal blades lining a few walls, a slatted teak room divider and the yellow striations of the white onyx bar.

title: TimesCast | Al-Awlaki's Influence
description: September 30, 2011 - A look at Al-Awlaki's radicalizing influence on young Muslims in the English-speaking world.

title: Another Look at the War in Libya
description: To the Editor:

title: On Facebook, Neighborhoods as They Once Were
description: WHEN she and her husband moved out in 1980, Kathy LaPolla DeStefano was not at all happy with Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Try These On. But Take Them Seriously.
description: At some point in the 1950s, artists around the globe decided they wanted to do more than just paint on canvas. Inspired in part by Jackson Pollocks dripped and poured paintings, and the idea that the process of making an artwork was as important as the final product, artists began puncturing, scorching and imprinting bodies on canvas. Franz Erhard Walther, a German artist whose work is currently on view at Dia:Beacon, took the idea a step further, creating objects out of fabric that people could manipulate to increase their awareness of time, space and the human body.

title: Icahn Locks In a Deputy With a New Contract
description: Carl C. Icahn lost one of his top deal makers last year when Keith Meister left the billionaire investors firm to start his own fund seeded by Soros Fund Management. And two weeks ago, there were reports that another top Icahn deputy, Alex Denner, might be leaving to start his own fund.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Canada: Court Saves Drug Injection Center from Shutdown
description: An effort by the Conservative government to close the only center in North America where addicts may legally inject drugs was thwarted by the countrys Supreme Court in a unanimous decision released Friday. In 2008, the government said it would not extend the centers exemption from federal narcotics laws, a position endorsed by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The Insite center in Vancouver, British Columbia, does not supply drugs, but allows addicts to inject them without fear of arrest under medical supervision on the condition that they undergo treatment. The court ruled that denying that permit and closing the clinic violated its users constitutional rights by threatening their health and indeed their lives. The justices also said that during its eight years of operation, Insite has been proven to save lives with no discernible negative impact on the public safety and health objectives of Canada.

title: A Lively Villain in the Court of King Arthur
description: In most productions of Camelot, the character of Mordred, the evil spawn of King Arthur and a sorceress who seduced him in his youth, is a footnote. Usually, hes barely remembered by theatergoers and mentioned only briefly in reviews; in the movie version, he was stripped of his two big numbers. In the stage musical, he doesnt even appear until the second act.

title: A House That Reflects an Islands History
description: THE house at Montauk Highway and Ocean Road in Bridgehampton started out as a simple farmhouse around 1824, before being transformed in 1840 by a noted portrait artist into a handsome example of Greek Revival architecture, complete with four tall columns in front. In the 1880s, it became a boardinghouse for visitors to the summer colony that had taken root in the Hamptons. By 1894, it had been altered again, this time into an elegant inn, and then reverted to a private residence in the 1950s.

title: You Love Your iPhone. Literally.
description: WITH Apple widely expected to release its iPhone 5 on Tuesday, Apple addicts across the world are getting ready for their latest fix.

title: Devoted Fans Go to the Grave With Team Spirit
description: Mildred Ryan never missed a Yankee game. She was watching when Reggie Jackson swatted three home runs in Game 6 of the 1977 World Series. She was watching as Don Mattingly toiled for years to keep his team from plunging to the bottom of the standings. She was watching when Derek Jeter  her boy, her son, Ed, said  helped return the World Series trophy to the Bronx in 1996.

title: Jack Ma Is Very Interested in Buying Yahoo
description: Jack Ma, chief executive of the Chinese e-commerce company the Alibaba Group, said on Friday that he was strongly considering buying Yahoo. It was the first public overture for the struggling Web portal.

title: Rays Continue Their Run With Rout of Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The aura surrounding the adrenaline-fueled Tampa Bay Rays shifted to wonderment Friday. Now the question is when they might come crashing back to baseball reality instead of making more history.

title: Brewers Biggest Opponent May Be Packers
description: MILWAUKEE  Naturally the question offended Milwaukee Brewers infielder Craig Counsell, who grew up a Brewers fan in Whitefish Bay, Wis., but knows what kind of pull the Green Bay Packers exert on his fellow Wisconsinites.

title: Oh, a Happy Life if Back in Moscow
description: Sarah Ruhl has a taste for and a way with the classics. In 2003 she rewrote the Orpheus myth as Eurydice, in which the heroine falls from a high-rise and arrives in hell by elevator. Last fall, Classic Stage Company in New York presented her pitch-perfect 2003 re-creation of Virginia Woolfs novel Orlando. Now she has tackled Three Sisters, Anton Chekhovs 110-year-old drama about young women in the provinces with big-city dreams. Just as soon as they move back to Moscow, they say frequently, their dreary lives will become beautiful.

title: Candidates Pursue Donations on Eve of a Fund-Raising Milestone
description: The presidential candidates sprinted toward the third-quarter fund-raising deadline on Friday night with a flurry of events and last-minute appeals for contributions, the fruits of which will help clarify the shape of the Republican field and shed light on whether President Obamas political difficulties have hurt his powerful fund-raising operation.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Stepping Right Up for Jay-Zs Carnival
description: Celebrities and other well-heeled folks dont usually deign to engage in such hoi-polloi amusements as Whac-a-Mole. But the snaking lines for games at a carnival put on by Jay-Z to raise money for his Shawn Carter Scholarship Foundation on Thursday night were easily explained: Among the rows of stuffed-tiger prizes, things like Tory Burch bags poked out, along with gleaming Gibson guitars and a basketball signed by Magic Johnson.

title: A Just Act of War
description: Santa Fe, N.M.

title: The Romance Is Fraying, but the Banter Goes On
description: Richard Dresser tends to write compact comedies that glint with a dark edge. Among his best-known works, Rounding Third (2002) studies two Little League coaches with clashing attitudes toward competition; Gun-Shy (1997) looks at divorced mates suffering through rebound romances; and Below the Belt (1995) presents a satirical saga of three corporate minions antagonizing one another at a remote industrial outpost.

title: Ahead on Emancipation
description: No politician was more determined than Senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts to ensure that secession and war resulted in emancipation. He interpreted every event through the lens of freedom. A quick end to the conflict, he feared, would leave slavery intact. Although he did not wish for it, he saw the benefit of the humiliating Union defeat at Bull Run in July 1861. He informed the abolitionist Wendell Phillips, The battle & defeat have done much for the slave. I told the Predt that our defeat was the worst event & the best event in our history; the worst, as it was the greatest present calamity & shame,  the best, as it made the extinction of Slavery inevitable.

title: Mexico: Teachers End Strike
description: Teachers in Acapulco have agreed to go back to work on Monday after more than a month on strike in protest over crime. Thousands of the citys teachers have stayed home after receiving extortion threats demanding half their salary. Leaders of the teachers signed an agreement with the state government late Thursday that lays out increased security measures around schools.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Wall Street Occupiers, Protesting Till Whenever
description: A man named Hero was here. So was Germ. There was the waitress from the dim sum restaurant in Evanston, Ill. And the liquor store worker. The Google consultant. The circus performer. The Brooklyn nanny.

title: Amid G.O.P. Din, Santorum Wages Struggle to Be Heard
description: ANDERSON, S.C.  There was little fanfare and almost no entourage when Rick Santorum, a Republican candidate for president, rolled up to the Chick-fil-A on Clemson Boulevard here the other day.

title: Adm. Michael Mullen Retires
description: After fours years of serving as the nation's highest-ranking military officer in both the Bush and Obama administrations, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Admiral Michael Mullen, retired.

title: Can You Hear Them Now?
description: Do clothes matter? Do appearances?

title: Enough With the Agony, Already
description: Every actor has had it.

title: Warm and Communal, Like a Meal in Greece
description: THE large dining hall at Mythos, one of the latest additions to Thornwoods roster of family-friendly restaurants, has the laid-back atmosphere  warm and unhurried, communal  that one might enjoy in similar neighborhood eating spots in sunny Greece, where families and other convivial groups enjoy lingering over their evening meal for hours. In fact, a large group near our table was doing just that  having a good time sharing a variety of dishes and washing them down with retsina or cloudy ouzo.

title: The Curse of the Mitt
description: Everybody is talking about the Boston Red Sox and their spectacular, disastrous end-of-season collapse. They had a nine-game lead on Sept. 3! They went 7-20 in September! Blew the final, deciding game at the bottom of the ninth!

title: Red Sox Part Ways With Francona
description: Philadelphia

title: Stokley Is Both Out and Mum
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants receiver Brandon Stokley left practice on Wednesday with what was described as a strained quadriceps, which will sideline him for at least Sundays game against the Cardinals in Arizona.

title: A Spirited Mexican Spot With a Pedigree
description: THERES a jolly fiesta atmosphere at Caracara Mexican Grill in Farmingdale. Diners entering the four-month-old restaurant on Main Street first encounter an attractive, popular bar, with a pressed-tin ceiling and Mexican tile floor. There, patrons nibble warm tortilla chips and sip the restaurants signature drink: a classic frozen margarita swirled with a pomegranate-hibiscus variation.

title: Diana Taylor, Bloombergs Girlfriend, Criticizes Obama
description: As New Yorks mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg is generally careful when discussing political leaders, measuring his words to avoid directly knocking anyone he might have to work with in representing the citys interests. But his girlfriend, Diana L. Taylor, apparently feels no such constraints.

title: The World This Week, Part 1
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Traditional Meal Ending Holy Days Becomes an Event
description: When Jill Medvedow, the director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, was growing up, she broke her fast after Yom Kippur at home, with just her family. After she married, she would go to her mother-in-laws house for the annual meal known as the break-fast. But when her mother-in-law left Boston, Ms. Medvedow and her husband became break-fast orphans.

title: Up to 22 Are Said to Face Charges in Tickets Inquiry
description: A Bronx grand jury that has heard evidence of widespread ticket-fixing by police union officials finished most of its work on Friday, after voting to charge as many as 17 police officers and 5 other people with a wide range of crimes, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: Podcast: European Debt, a Tax Plan and General Motors
description: Its been a difficult three months for the financial markets, and the global economy is weak. Unfortunately, more problems are probably on the way.

title: Improving No Child Left Behind
description: The 2002 No Child Left Behind Act focused the countrys attention on school reform as never before, but the law is far from perfect. The Obama administration is wise to address its flaws, since Congress is four years overdue in updating the law.

title: Anti-Qaddafi Fighters Are Accused of Torture
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  First there were the blindfold, the wrist-scarring handcuffs and the death threats. Then came beatings and electric shocks. In the fog of pain, the detainee, who said he had done nothing wrong, would have confessed to anything, he later recalled.

title: Lottery Numbers
New Jersey Denies Bids for Two Mandarin Schools
description: Two proposed Mandarin language immersion charter schools that have drawn fierce opposition from school officials and parents in Millburn, Livingston and nearby areas failed to win approval Friday from the New Jersey Education Department.

title: A Look Back at Mullens Tenure
description: After fours years of serving as the nations highest-ranking military officer in the administrations of Presidents Obama and George W. Bush, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, retired on Friday at a ceremony in Arlington, Va. His last day on the job also saw the death of Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born leader of Al Qaedas branch in Yemen who was killed by an American drone strike.

title: A Tour of India, Colorful and Festive
description: THERES a lot to like about Utsav Indian Cuisine, a small restaurant in Vernon. The dramatic use of color  red, purple, green, orange, gold  gives the place a bright, contemporary look that is also quintessentially Indian. The food is good, the price is right and service is exceptionally friendly and helpful.

title: Cardinals Plan to Lean on Ace Who Got Them In
description: The St. Louis Cardinals spent so long chasing the Atlanta Braves, Tony La Russa said, that their goal was simply to force a one-game playoff on Thursday. It was not until the pregame hours Wednesday that La Russa even looked ahead to the division series schedule.

title: The Nuremberg Scripts
description: In November 1945, six months after Germanys surrender to the Allies, a 24-year-old Army combat engineer named Harold Burson was handed a new assignment: to cover the upcoming Nuremberg trial for the American Forces Network. For the next five months, Burson was one of two soldiers who reported on the trial and produced a daily script, which was read over the air by the networks announcers.

title: This Sunday: Hong Kong Fish Balls, Baby
description: The fourth annual Food and Drink issue is like one of those dinner parties where you decide to make something youve never tried before. An experiment in real time, with inescapable consequences for your trusting guests. In place of the long-form narrative journalism that is our stock in trade, we concocted a completely bite-size issue made up of concise answers to a wide-ranging series of questions. Everything from How can you tell if food is genetically engineered? to How many kinds of Pringles are there? (Anyone for Hong Kong Fish Balls? Yes, thats a flavor.) The longest answer is about 600 words, or less than one-tenth the size of a typical cover story, and there are more than 50 of them. We did this because it enabled us to cover a lot of ground, and because we thought it would be fun just to change up the menu.

title: The World This Week, Part 2
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Americas Man in Damascus
description: Robert Ford, the United States ambassador in Damascus, is an exemplary and courageous diplomat. While President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his henchmen have been slaughtering their people, Mr. Ford has been traveling the country, standing with the pro-democracy opposition and bearing witness to their sacrifice.

title: Investor Fear Over Morgan Stanley Sharpens
description: It is Morgan Stanleys turn on the hot seat.

title: The Supreme Court and Health Care Reform
description: If the Supreme Court decides to take up the constitutionality of health care reform in its current term, which begins on Monday, a ruling could come by the end of June, well before the November elections. Pundits are already speculating over which party would gain the most traction from a decision that goes one way or another. The court must not let politics influence its decision.

title: Another Day Passes Without N.B.A. Deal
description: The N.B.A. did not cancel the season on Friday, but it inched ever closer to deleting games from the calendar after another day passed without a labor deal.

title: Rwanda: Two Convicted in Genocide
description: A special United Nations court convicted two men on Friday of helping mastermind the 1994 Rwandan genocide, and it acquitted two others. The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, based in Arusha, Tanzania, convicted Justin Mugenzi and Prosper Mugiraneza, the former ministers of trade and civil service, sentencing them to 30 years each. The tribunal acquitted two other senior members of Rwandas former government, Casimir Bizimungu, the former health minister, and Jerome-Clement Bicamumpaka, the former foreign minister.

title: The Heart of the Art
description: X-rays of art objects from the J. Paul Getty Museum connect the contemporary viewer to the art impulse at the core of the ancient works.

title: Lessons of the Listeria Outbreak
description: The deaths caused by listeria bacteria on cantaloupe is a warning that both the food industry and the government need to do more to protect the public. The outbreak has already sickened more than 70 people in 18 states and killed at least 15 of them, mostly elderly, in eight states. This is the deadliest outbreak of food-borne disease in the United States in more than a decade.

title: In Change, Bloomberg Backs Obstacle to Deportation
description: In a significant reversal, the Bloomberg administration said Friday that it would support a City Council bill that would hamper federal authorities ability to detain, and eventually deport, foreign-born inmates on Rikers Island who are about to be released.

title: Yanks Pick Up Where They Left Off: In Weather Delay
description: In a season that has been interrupted and elongated by incessant rain, it almost seemed fitting that the Yankees first game of the postseason was suspended Friday because of a deluge.

title: Corrections: October 1
description: NATIONAL

title: Saturday: Certain Adjustments
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Before we get to the puzzle, Id just like to pose a question to you all: How is it October already? Is it just me, or did this year absolutely fly by?

title: Obama Turns to Biden to Reassure Jewish Voters, and Get Them to Contribute, Too
description: WASHINGTON  In the middle of a meeting with 15 rabbis in Boca Raton, Fla., last week, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. took a punch meant for his boss.

title: A Career Recharged, Along With Frances Global Role
description: PARIS

title: A Pie That Tweaks the Pizza
description: A lot of pizzeria managers say their pies are different from those the other guys make. But John Ausiello, manager of Tomato Pie in Morristown, may have a better claim than most. You see one of our pies and its clear theyre pretty not-regular, Mr. Ausiello, 35, said.

title: Latin Fusion, Created by a Homegrown Chef
description: A DECADE ago, Andrew DiCataldo was as hot as caliente gets, in the vanguard of the Nuevo Latino craze that rocketed up from Miami to Manhattan. In 2001, after he succeeded Douglas Rodriguez at Patria, the restaurant earned three stars from William Grimes in The New York Times. But a lackluster review at his next venture, and a wrong turn to a restaurant in London that never opened, left him slinging fajitas at a Mexican place in Teaneck where he had worked years before. By late last year, he was cooking for the Rail House in his hometown of Rahway.

title: Remedy Is Elusive as Metallic Hips Fail at a Fast Rate
description: BOSTON  As surgeons here sliced through tissue surrounding a failed artificial hip in a 53-year-old man, they discovered what looked like a biological dead zone. There were matted strands of tissue stained gray and black; a large strip of muscle near the hip no longer contracted.

title: For a Concert That Never Was, a Good Turnout Nonetheless
description: The frenzy began at 12:18 p.m. on Friday with an e-mail blast from the organizers of the anti-Wall Street demonstrations in Lower Manhattan: Radiohead will play a surprise show for #occupywallstreet today at four in the afternoon.

title: N.J. to Repay U.S. $95 Million Over Hudson Tunnels
description: At the end of the long stare-down between the governor of New Jersey and federal officials over the money spent on tunnels that were never built, both sides blinked.

title: Hippies and Hipsters Exhale
description: Ever since the Arab Spring, many people here have been pining for an American Autumn.

title: Gains Made in Equality of Incomes in Downturn
description: The recession was bad for everyone, but women experienced at least one silver lining: Their median earnings edged a bit closer to mens.

title: 2nd American in Strike Waged Qaeda Media War
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  From his parents basement in a part of town where homes have lots of bedrooms and most children go to college, Samir Khan blogged his way into the highest circles of Al Qaeda, waging a media war he believed was as important as the battles with guns on the ground.

title: Judge Stops Floridas Plan to Privatize 29 State Prisons
description: MIAMI  A state judge ruled on Friday that it was unconstitutional for the Florida Legislature to attach a far-reaching proposal  one that would privatize 29 prisons in South Florida  to the hidden recesses of an appropriations bill.

title: Injury From Metal Debris in Artificial Hips
description: How metal debris from hip implants reacts with the body.

title: At the Stadium, a Parade of Respect
description: It is a generation now. Another Yankee epoch. Starting in 1995, the Yankees have appeared in the postseason in 16 of 17 years.

title: Protests Stir Up Voices on the Web
description: As the Occupy Wall Street protests in New York cycled through their 14th day, with a surge of attention and confusion over a Radiohead show that wasnt, an overwhelming amount of information continued to flood the Internet, from snarky Tweets to informational Web sites to blogs representing individual experiences during the economic crisis.

title: Trustee Is Sought for Records of Solyndra
description: The Department of Justice asked a federal court on Friday to appoint a trustee to oversee the bankruptcy of the solar panel maker Solyndra because its top executives asserted their Fifth Amendment right to avoid self-incrimination before a House subcommittee.

title: The Political Pulpit
description: This weekend, hundreds of pastors, including some of the nations evangelical leaders, will climb into their pulpits to preach about American politics, flouting a decades-old law that prohibits tax-exempt churches and other charities from campaigning on election issues.

title: Changes Proposed for Reporting by Teacher Education Programs
description: Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, proposing changes to the nations teacher education programs on Friday, said the Education Department would negotiate changes to the rules governing what information the nations 1,400 teachers colleges and university programs must report to Washington. The department wants them to report how many graduates fill shortage positions, like teaching math in high-poverty schools; how satisfied school principals are with their preparation; and how much the graduates help students learn once they get to the classroom, based on their students test scores. The rule-rewriting process could take many months.

title: On Free-Agent Market, Rollins and Reyes Will Be Rivals Again
description: PHILADELPHIA  Jimmy Rollins and Jose Reyes, star players for rival teams, have spent much of their careers juxtaposed with each other.

title: Roger Kennedy, Who Was Parks Chief Under Clinton, Dies at 85
description: Roger G. Kennedy, who was director of the National Park Service during the Clinton administration and an ardent preservationist of the nations cultural, historic and artistic heritage for much of his life, died on Friday at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 85.

title: Arizona Coach Baylor Is Hospitalized After Fainting
description: MILWAUKEE  Don Baylor, the Arizona Diamondbacks hitting coach, was taken to a local hospital Friday after fainting in the lunchroom of the visiting clubhouse at Miller Park.

title: Palestinian Request Sent to Experts
description: The Security Council membership committee referred the Palestinian request for full United Nations membership to its experts on Friday to evaluate whether it meets the criteria for statehood. An initial report is due by mid-October. Many ambassadors noted that before moving on the application, they wanted to see if direct talks between Israel and the Palestinians could be started within a month.

title: Rediscovering the Urban Palette
description: The images depicting the city of shadow-cloaked smokestacks and sun-drenched skyscrapers are tucked away in our minds. Manhattan streetscapes bursting with odd angles and odder people. Pastoral landscapes of misty Central Park mornings. Ragamuffins and ruffians, dandies and dowagers, all strutting across the citys stage  and all frozen in black and white.

title: Lee Davenport Dies at 95; Developed Battlefront Radar
description: Lee Davenport, a physicist who developed a radar device that helped bring Allied victories on major World War II battlefronts in Europe and the Pacific, died Friday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 95.

title: No Front-Runner This Season, but Three Who Dazzle
description: They may not be the best or even necessarily the fastest horses in the land, but they certainly have provided the most drama and entertainment through an unpredictable but satisfying 2011 thoroughbred racing season. Were talking about two boys and a girl  Stay Thirsty, Uncle Mo and Havre de Grace  all of whom are in town Saturday at Belmont Park for what is one of the sports best afternoons outside the Breeders Cup World Champions next month at Churchill Downs.

title: Unesco Director Asks Dictator to Withdraw Science Prize
description: The director of Unesco called Friday for a West African dictator to withdraw the controversial prize he has endowed for the organization. The prize in the life sciences, financed by and named for President Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo of Equatorial Guinea, would damage the prestige and credibility of Unesco, its director general, Irina Bokova, said at a meeting of the groups executive board in Paris. Human rights activists, scientists and political leaders have denounced the prize as a public-relations stunt by Mr. Obiang. The Unesco board is expected to meet again next week on the issue.

title: Britain: Kurdish Protesters Besiege Newspaper
description: A group of about a dozen Kurdish separatist protesters broke into the newsroom of The Guardian newspaper on Friday and staged a brief demonstration, demanding further coverage of Kurdish conflicts with the Turkish government, according to reports from within the newspaper. A video of the incident showed the protesters gathered on a stairway, chanting and handing out literature to newspaper staff members, many of whom appeared bemused. The protests were low-key and peaceful, said one reporter, Alexandra Topping. The invasion of The Guardian comes amid a season of Kurdish protests against a campaign of Turkish airstrikes in northern Iraq in pursuit of violent Kurdish separatists.

title: Germany Returns 20 Skulls to Africa
description: Namibian government representatives and leaders of the Herero and Nama tribes attended a ceremony at Charit Hospital in Berlin on Friday to take possession of 20 skulls brought to Germany for racial research a century ago.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 8 NEBRASKA AT NO. 7 WISCONSIN8 p.m. Eastern, ABC

title: Belarus Withdraws from European Summit Meeting
description: Belarus withdrew Friday from a diplomatic summit meeting aimed at improving ties between the European Union and its former Soviet neighbors, complaining of discrimination. Western leaders have criticized the countrys authoritarian president for jailing and harassing his opponents, and the European Union has called for people it deems political prisoners to be released before talks on financial aid and economic ties can be resumed. Belaruss Foreign Ministry said President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko had not been invited to attend the so-called Eastern Partnership summit meeting and that its delegation had been excluded from several events. Because of European Union sanctions against Belarus, Mr. Lukashenko is banned from entering the bloc.

title: Changing Forests
description: Many of the worlds forests are robust carbon sponges, but others are threatened by a warming climate.

title: Attacks on a Protective Canopy
description: Trees, which provide a crucial protection against climate change, are also under stress from some of climate changes effects.

title: Attacks on a Protective Canopy
description: Trees, which provide a crucial protection against climate change, are also under stress from some of climate changes effects.

description: Paris

title: Jean Paul Gaultier: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Cacharel: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Sonia Rykiel: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Haider Ackermann: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Viktor & Rolf: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Comme des Garons: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Wall Street Protesters Speak
description: The young and old on what they hope to accomplish by joining the Occupy Wall Street demonstration in Zuccotti Park.

title: With Deaths of Forests, a Loss of Key Climate Protectors
description: WISE RIVER, Mont.  The trees spanning many of the mountainsides of western Montana glow an earthy red, like a broadleaf forest at the beginning of autumn.

title: The Forest for the Trees
description: In Arizona, trees are cut down to save forests from fires and to combat climate change.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,778 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: An African Mermaid
description: Mami Wata at the National Museum of African Art in Washington is as rousing as a drum roll, as piquant as a samba. Holland Cotter reviews.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Himachal Pradesh: More than 250 deities will grace the annual procession at this years Kullu Dussehra celebrations in Himachal Pradesh, part of the weeklong festivities in the Kullu Valley. Two deities have been banned, though, since their devotees demanded a special place of honor in the procession (The Times of India).Jharkhand: The state plans to construct a new capital city called New Ranchi on about 27,000 acres of land (Prabhat Khabar).

title: At a Glance: Rick Santorum
description: RICHARD JOHN SANTORUM

title: Modernity and Tradition Merge in Motherhood
description: My family moved to New Jersey from New Delhi when I was 7 years old, and I have always considered myself a modern Indian American woman.

title: Forests and Climate Change: Ask the Reporter a Question
description: Justin Gillis reports on climatic threats to forests and the implications for the earths future. Please post your questions for him in the comment field below. He will respond next week on the Green blog.

title: Giants-Cardinals: Matchup to Watch
description: Giants (2-1) at Cardinals (1-2), Sunday at 4:05 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: The Weekend Word: In It  to Win It
description: Todays Times:

title: For Small Business,  Bad News on Health Care Costs Isnt as Bad
description: Theres bad news from the workplace: as The New York Times reported on Tuesday, the cost of health insurance rose sharply in 2011 after several years of relatively slow growth. According to the Kaiser Family Foundations annual survey on employer health benefits, the average premium to insure a family of four grew 9 percent, to just over $15,073. For single coverage, premiums rose 8 percent, to $5,429.

title: Styled to a T | Cristian Zuzunaga
description: The Designer

title: Pakistani Is Sentenced in Killing of Governor
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A court on Saturday sentenced to death an elite police guard who assassinated a leading secular politician he had been charged with protecting, a killing that sent shockwaves throughout Pakistan and was seen as a clear marker of growing religious intolerance and extremism in the country.

title: Out of the Box
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#714", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Unleash the Robot Dogs of War
description: In 2007 Boston Dynamics, a robotics company, posted a video online of a robot called the BigDog that could run on any type of terrain like a dog. The video quickly went viral, partly becausepeoplewere in awe of the robots agility and also because it was so scary to watch.

title: Bookshelf
description: In The Scrapbook of Frankie Pratt (Ecco, $26), Caroline Preston, a former archivist, pastes vintage postcards, Jazz Age ephemera and typewritten snippets into a sweetly beguiling novel about a New England girl who trades Vassar College for Greenwich Village on the advice of Edna St. Vincent Millay.

title: Notes from the Underground | Bubbles
description: The synth-pop duo known as Bubbles recently performed at the Agns B. flagship store in Soho. A crowd of forty or so looked on as Alain Levitt banged on his machines, and Jason P. Grisell flailed around the small stage area. Endearingly low-maintenance, the group wins hearts with their unpretentious slacks, sneakers, and baseball hats. Bubbles has played most of the better underground venues in New York, and is steadily gaining steam. And yet, while Levitts music was danceable and solidly interesting, Grisells vocals left the audience pondering whether or not we are in for a revival of that No-Wave school of Cant sing? Start a hit band!'

title: NATO Says It Caught a Haqqani Clan Leader
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO forces said Saturday that they had captured a man they described as a high-ranking member of the Haqqani network, the brutal Pakistan-based clan the United States considers one of the biggest threats to bringing stability to Afghanistan.

title: Americans Move Against Haqqani Network in Afghanistan
description: The insurgent group, based in Pakistans northwestern frontier, flows fighters into Afghanistan and has orchestrated a long campaign of guerrilla and terrorist attacks against the Afghan government and its American sponsors. It has also harbored Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups.

title: Urban Forager | Maitake Mushrooms
description: The proliferation of steady rains from August onwards has yielded a stunning crop of mushrooms this fall, both edible and otherwise. Recently, I found a lovely maitake mushroom cluster that weighed over two pounds growing at the base of a giant pin oak near where I was staying just outside New Paltz. The maitake had grown over and around a fallen branch, and there were a few acorns attached to the bottom. I took the whole thing home.

title: City Geometry, Seen From Above
description: In New York From the Air: A Story of Architecture, Yann Arthus-Bertrand transforms street-level scenes into abstract cityscapes.

title: Photos of the Moment | Nina Ricci
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#577", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Q. and A.: N.A.S.L. Commissioner David Downs
description: MIAMI  The entrance to the office of the North American Soccer Leagues commissioner is adorned with the jerseys of the leagues eight teams, which are arranged on hangers that can be moved as the standings change. The leagues six-team playoffs started Saturday.

title: Jets-Ravens: Matchup to Watch
description: Jets (2-1) at Ravens (2-1), Sunday at 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NBC

title: Frustration Is in the Forecast
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

title: In Europe, Players Profit From Team Efforts
description: The difference between the game in the United States and Europe is easy to illustrate by comparing two team competitions currently under way.

title: Runway In Review
description: Christian DiorDesigner: Bill GayttenDate and Location: Friday, Sept. 30, Muse Rodin, 77 Rue de Varenne, 7ePhotos: slide show

title: Variety: A Brilliant Cryptic
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert:  In the Sunday puzzle, there will be a notepad that reads: Ten famous people are attending a costume party in this crossword. After the grid is filled, change the two shaded letters in each theme answer to unmask a celebrity.

title: Bordeaux? Sediment? Tell It to the Judge
description: On a recent evening at Colicchio & Sons, in the Meatpacking District, the wine writer Mark Oldman attended an engagement dinner during which several bottles of 1970 Chateau Palmer were drunk. I still remember the plums-and-truffle perfume and enduringly silky, savory finish, Oldman said. He was so enamored, in fact, that before leaving, he snuck out an empty bottle with him as a souvenir. (Oenophiles, Oldman noted, refer to empties as dead soldiers.)

title: Somali Gunmen Abduct Elderly Tourist in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Somali gunmen staged another brazen attack inside Kenya on Saturday morning, snatching a French tourist from a beachside bungalow and escaping to Somalia three weeks after a similar assault.

title: Putins Eye for Power Leads Some in Russia to Ponder Life Abroad
description: MOSCOW  Time to shove off is the name of a Web site for people who are fed up with life in Russia, and it is becoming a catchphrase for those dismayed by the newly announced plans of Vladimir V. Putin to keep a grip on power for perhaps two more terms as president.

title: Dior and Galliano, After Galliano
description: Karlie Kloss closed the Dior show on Friday in a gown with a black lace top and a transparent pink skirt that revealed most of her rear end, a finale that some online commentators read as a pointed statement by its temporary designer. Bill Gaytten has been directing the studio while the label seeks a successor to John Galliano, who was fired in the spring, but Mr. Gaytten has not been seen as a likely candidate for the job since his couture collection, shown in July, was widely panned.

title: Photos of the Moment | Isabel Marant
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#377", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Small Plane Crashes Into Ride During Festival in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  A small plane smashed into a Ferris wheel at a festival north of Sydney on Saturday, trapping a pair of children on the ride and two people in the aircraft, which dangled from the top of the ride for hours.

title: Battered by Economic Crisis, Greeks Turn to Barter Networks
description: VOLOS, Greece  The first time he bought eggs, milk and jam at an outdoor market using not euros but an informal barter currency, Theodoros Mavridis, an unemployed electrician, was thrilled.

title: Competing Confucius Award Bares Discord in China
description: BEIJING  When the Nobel Prize committee announced last year that it was giving its coveted Peace Prize to Liu Xiaobo, an imprisoned Chinese dissident writer, a group of patriotic Chinese came up with a rejoinder: they would offer up their own international award, called the Confucius Peace Prize.

title: Voice of Yankees Draws High Ratings and Many Critics
description: Walking through the crowded hallway just outside the locker rooms at Yankee Stadium last week, John Sterling, unlike most everyone else, was not wearing a badge, security identification or media credential. Dressed in a crisp navy blue suit that he plucked from his closet that morning because he saw President Obama on television wearing a similar one, he merrily waved his hand as he passed attendants at various checkpoints.

title: Businesslike Quarterback Has Stirred the Bills
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  The groundwork for the predictable career on Wall Street had already been laid  the coursework in economics, the internship at a Boston hedge fund. Then Ryan Fitzpatricks college coach surprised him with a suggestion after his junior season: spend a long weekend that summer at the Manning familys passing academy in Louisiana.

title: Photos of the Moment | Christian Dior
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#649", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Jets Mason, Taught to Endure Pain, Now Shows Others the Way
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Before he could become one of the N.F.L.s most durable receivers, Derrick Mason had to stop crying. He was about 9 then, a football-loving boy in Detroit who played two-on-two games at the middle school across the street. Always he lined up against his older brother Jackie, who pushed him, bumped him, knocked him down, bringing him to tears. When Mason would get up, Jackie would push him  again and again and again.

title: Strike Reflects U.S. Shift to Drones in Terror Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The C.I.A. drone strike that killed Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born propagandist for Al Qaedas rising franchise in Yemen, was one more demonstration of what American officials describe as a cheap, safe and precise tool to eliminate enemies. It was also a sign that the decade-old American campaign against terrorism has reached a turning point.

title: Yemen Notes Its Own Role in U.S. Attack on Militant
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni officials provided more details on Saturday about their role in the tracking and killing of an American-born cleric, while a government spokesman said that the United States should show more appreciation to Yemens embattled president for his assistance in the case.

title: Showers Come and Go, Leaving Behind a Rainbow
description: When nothing happens, there is no better analyst to say pretty much nothing more eloquently than the tight-lipped Captain.

title: Photos of the Moment | Haider Ackermann
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#400", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Different Rules for Rainy Weather in Playoffs
description: Updated | 5:22 p.m. In his pregame comments, Manager Joe Girardi was asked if he would be hesitant to start the game if there was rain in the forecast for 9:30 or 10 p.m., and he said, Unfortunately, I dont get to make that decision. Thats in MLBs hands. I would highly recommend that we dont start if its going to rain half an hour, 45 minutes, an hour. But Im not making the decisions.

title: In El Paso, a Storm Over Benefits for Gay Partners
description: EL PASO  Pastor Tom Brown wants homosexuals to repent and turn to Christ. He certainly does not want them to be given taxpayer-financed health benefits.

title: Feisty Baylor Rejoins Diamondbacks
description: MILWAUKEE  The Arizona Diamondbacks hitting coach Don Baylor, who spent the night at a hospital after a fainting in the clubhouse Friday, returned to Miller Park on Saturday morning and brushed aside all concerns with one meaty arm.

title: Occupying, and Now Publishing, Too
description: Just before noon, Chelsea Potter stood on the corner of Broadway and Liberty Street holding a sheaf of newspapers and offering them to passers-by.

title: Racing Against Time and an Indelible Fear
description: Laura Arnez, a mother of five from outside Sacramento who likes to refer to her triathlon training as Mommys recess time, has long struggled with panic attacks during the most nerve-racking stage of such competitions: the open-water swim, which typically precedes a bike race and then a run.

title: Mike Heimerdinger, 58, Who Helped to Coach Super Bowl Winners, Is Dead
description: Mike Heimerdinger, who coached offensive units for the Denver Broncos, the Jets and the Tennessee Titans, helped mold players like Steve McNair, Vince Young and Jay Cutler, and continued to work while undergoing chemotherapy, died Friday while in Mexico to receive experimental cancer treatments. He was 58.

title: Revived Diamondbacks Follow Their Leaders
description: MILWAUKEE  Load everybodys statistics into a computer game, and the manager and coaches of the Arizona Diamondbacks  mostly baseball swells from the 1980s and 90s  might crush their players. Thats impressive, given that the actual playing Diamondbacks bounced back from a 97-loss season to outdistance the defending World Series champion San Francisco Giants and win the National League West.

title: Festival Starts a 3-Day Run in Asbury Park
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  All Tomorrows Parties, the festival that pays lovingly microscopic attention to olden tastes in underground pop from around the world, started its three-day run last night. It has relocated its New York-area edition to Asbury Park from the Catskills, and this was a life-affirming move. The old place, Kutshers Country Club, is a down-at-heels resort  the enclosed and remote feeling there made the event feel like a quarantined zone for those afflicted with obscure interests.

title: Khaled Abdel Nasser, Son of Egyptian Hero, Dies at 62
description: Khaled Abdel Nasser, a son of Egypts most revered leader, who captured the worlds attention in the late 1980s when he was tried and acquitted of helping to assassinate two Israeli diplomats, died Sept. 15 at a Cairo hospital. He was 62.

title: Rolle Stands Out With Punishing Hits and Pugnacious Talk
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In a little more than a year and a half with the button-down, low-key Giants, Antrel Rolle has found some measure of controversy for, among other things, criticizing Tom Coughlins coaching style; comparing Coughlin to Rex Ryan; likening football players to soldiers serving in Iraq; opining on what would happen if the Giants were to play the Washington Redskins 100 times (the Giants would win 95); and, most recently, stating that it is sometimes essential for him to take a 15-yard unnecessary-roughness penalty.

title: G.M.s Big Pile-Up
description: Key moments from the decline of General Motors.

title: On the Road to Detroits Big Pileup
description: If General Motors were any other company, it would probably be dead by now. In the summer of 2008, nearly a year before G.M. filed for bankruptcy, its executives were growing desperate. Rick Wagoner, its chief executive, secretly proposed a merger with Ford, while Bill Ford courted the future president, Barack Obama, in an attempt to safeguard his company. This article is adapted from Once Upon a Car: The Fall and Resurrection of Americas Big Three Automakers  G.M., Ford and Chrysler by Bill Vlasic, the Detroit bureau chief of The New York Times. The book, to be published Tuesday by William Morrow, reveals new details of the chaos at the Big Three. Conversations recounted in the book were based on more than 100 interviews.

title: A Tropical Technique for Maines Shallows
description: PORTLAND, Me.  I was standing in the bow of a low-riding skiff as my angling companion poled us across white sand flats, illuminated by a warm summer sun. Suddenly, several wakes appeared before the boat.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Signature Home Run Balanced by Humility
description: I sat in the rear of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan during the memorial for the sports commentator and author Dick Schaap in January 2002. The place was packed as old friends said their final goodbyes.

title: The Bank Case That Refuses to Die
description: ANGELO R. MOZILO and Kerry K. Killinger look like theyre in the clear: federal prosecutors have declined to go after them and many other masters of the mortgage disaster.

title: Live Analysis: College Football Week Five
description: Zach Hillesland and Greg Bishop will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. Join the conversation in the comments section below.

title: The Daily Shoe | Isabel Marant
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Christie Team Assessing How Fast a 2012 Campaign Could Be Mounted
description: WASHINGTON  Chris Christies political advisers are working to determine whether they could move fast enough to set up effective political operations in Iowa and New Hampshire in the wake of a relentless courtship aimed at persuading Mr. Christie, the governor of New Jersey, to plunge into the race for the Republican presidential nomination, according to operatives briefed on the preparations.

title: Profits, but No Joy, for Merrill
description: IT sounded like a crank call, the business equivalent of Do you have Prince Albert in a can?: Hello, Warren Buffett wants to talk to your boss.

title: The Weeks Business News in Photos
description: Officials searched for solutions to the European debt crisis, the United States government considered selling off assets and natural gas was flared off in North Dakota while more valuable oil was being extracted.

title: Valuing Those Who Tell You the Bitter Truth
description: This interview with  Pamela Fields, chief executive of Stetson, the hat and apparel company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Battle for Libya | October 1, 2011
description: The military mission in Libya is largely complete and NATOs involvement could begin to wrap up as soon as next week after allied leaders meet in Brussels, according to the top U.S. commander for Africa.

title: Battle for Libya | October 2011
description: Nine months of images from the fighting in Libya.

title: The Problem With No New Taxes
description: IN a debate in August, Republican presidential candidates were asked whether they would support a budget deal that bundled $10 of spending cuts for every $1 of tax increases. All said no. They rejected any deal that involved raising taxes.

title: Carpenter Works to Keep Distractions at Bay
description: Chris Carpenter, who is set to pitch for the St. Louis Cardinals against the Philadelphia Phillies on Sunday night in Game 2 of the teams National League division series, spoke at length Saturday afternoon about the way his mental approach had evolved since his days as a young player.

title: Maryland Team Wins Solar House Contest
description: A team from the University of Maryland has taken top honors at the Solar Decathlon, a competition for small, cost-effective solar-powered houses sponsored by the Department of Energy. The entries have been on view on the National Mall in Washington for over a week. A project manual and a video walk-through for the winning entry are here. Recently Joanna Foster reported in The Times on an entry from the New York area.

title: John Sterling on YouTube: The Good and the Bad
description: One need not look any further than YouTube to understand the polarizing nature of John Sterling among baseball fans.

title: When the Nurse Wants to Be Called Doctor
description: NASHVILLE  With pain in her right ear, Sue Cassidy went to a clinic. The doctor, wearing a white lab coat with a stethoscope in one pocket, introduced herself.

title: The Round and the Oval
description: THERE are a great many things that Chris Christie is indeed too fat for.

title: Cooperation in Evil
description: WASHINGTON

title: Missing the Populist Moment
description: BY rights, this should be the election when conservative populists, frequently thwarted and co-opted by the Republican Partys kingmakers, finally succeed in pushing an insurgent candidate to the top of the presidential ticket. Between the zeal of the Tea Party, the unlovability of Mitt Romney and the widespread hatred of all things Washington, theres never been a better time to run against the Republican establishment and win.

title: How Did the Robot End Up With My Job?
description: IVE done a lot of television book interviews lately, and I continue to be struck at what a difference there is in the technology in just a few years time.

title: The Bankers and the Revolutionaries
description: AFTER flying around the world this year to cover street protests from Cairo to Morocco, reporting on the latest uprising was easier: I took the subway.

title: Crosby Is Out for Penguins Opener
description: Sidney Crosby said Saturday he would not play in the Pittsburgh Penguins regular-season opener in Vancouver on Oct. 6.

title: Super People
description: James Atlas is the president of Atlas & Co., a publishing company. He is at work on a book about biography.

title: Saving the U.S.S. Bunker Hill
description: Lt. Cmdr. Joseph R. Carmichael Jr. received a Navy Cross for extraordinary heroism in keeping the U.S.S. Bunker Hill afloat after it was struck by two kamikaze planes in 1945.

title: Return of the Indispensable Man
description: Ellen Barry is the Moscow bureau chief for The New York Times.

title: Antiterror Measures at Home
description: One of the bitter lessons of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was the need for better coordination and sharing of intelligence among the nations security agencies, to flag dangerous people entering the country. But there were also well-founded concerns about how well that system was working, and whether it was being abused.

title: Joseph Carmichael Jr., a Carrier Hero, Dies at 96
description: It was midmorning on May 11, 1945, near the Japanese island of Kyushu when the Bunker Hill, an aircraft carrier with dozens of planes and vast stores of fuel and ammunition on its flight deck, was struck by two kamikaze planes in suicide attacks within minutes of each other.

title: Becoming Compassionately Numb
description: Benedict Carey is a science reporter for The New York Times.

title: Schmoozing in Whose Interest?
description: On his first day in office, President Obama struck a blow for better government with his executive order banning political appointees from accepting gifts from lobbyists. Now the administration is rightly proposing to extend the ban to all 2.6 million career federal workers.

title: Model-Morphosis | Kate King at Lanvin
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Kate King from Ford Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Approaching the Bench, in Search of Answers
description: The Supreme Court returns Monday to an overarching question: Are the federal courts the right forum for resolving societal problems? Last term, the conservative majority suggested the answer is no in closely divided cases about job discrimination, misconduct by prosecutors, fraud by mutual funds and other topics.

title: Talking About Doritos
description: Arch West, the father of Doritos, died Sept. 20 at age 97, knowing that he and his product-development team at Frito-Lay had built one of the mightiest pillars of a global snack-food empire. What many fans may not realize is that Doritos are also a mighty literary device.

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: Police Arrest More Than 700 Protesters on Brooklyn Bridge
description: Updated, 1:23 p.m. Sunday | In a tense showdown above the East River, the police arrested more than 700 demonstrators from the Occupy Wall Street protests who took to the roadway as they tried to cross the Brooklyn Bridge on Saturday afternoon.

title: Conflicts and Appearances
description: Re Tangled Relationships in Jerusalem (Sept. 25):

title: Sunday Dialogue: The Death Penalty
description: Are some crimes so abhorrent that justice demands death?

title: A New York State Law Against Bullying
description: To the Editor:

title: The Supercommittees Stark Choice
description: In August, Congressional Republicans tried to box in Democrats and the White House by demanding huge deficit cuts in exchange for preventing a government default. Then they joined in the creation of a supercommittee on deficit reduction that they hoped would take taxes off the table and focus entirely on cuts in spending.

title: How Yoga Won the West
description: Ann Louise Bardach is a writer at large for Newsweek. She is working on a biography of Vivekananda.

title: Planets in the Sky With Diamonds
description: Diane Ackerman is the author of One Hundred Names for Love and The Zookeepers Wife.

title: Can This Poet Save Mexico?
description: Enrique Krauze is the editor of the magazine Letras Libres and the author of Redeemers: Ideas and Power in Latin America. This article was translated by Hank Heifetz from the Spanish.

title: The Stuff That Wont Go Away
description: Jeffrey Eugenides is an American novelist whose book The Marriage Plot will be published this month. He won the Pulitzer Prize for Middlesex. Colm Toibin, an Irish writer, is the author of The Empty Family Stories and Brooklyn. He has been shortlisted twice for the Man Booker Prize.

title: Dangers Still Our Middle Name
description: Michael Cannell is the author of the forthcoming book The Limit: Life and Death on the 1961 Grand Prix Circuit.

title: The (Not So) Roaring 20s
description: Emily G. Owens is an assistant professor in the Department of Policy Analysis and Management at Cornell.

title: Long-Secret Fallout Shelter Was a Cold War Camelot
description: PEANUT ISLAND, Fla.  A nuclear bomb shelter was a must-have in the 1950s and 60s.

title: Speculators and the Price of Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Routes to Solving the Jobs Puzzle
description: Los Angeles

title: Who Gets to Be Called a Doctor?
description: Many nurses are going back to school to earn doctorate degrees, but does that give them the right to call themselves doctor?

title: Reading the Writing on the Envelope
description: THE Pony Express was famous for moving mail at astounding speed. Missouri to California in only 10 days! A triumph.

title: In Texas, Extending the Miseries of Hurricane Ike
description: ANAHUAC, Tex.  The hurricane that swept through this East Texas town battered Shirley Augusts house. Pieces of plywood cover the blown-out windows. Window screens, twisted by the winds, resemble abstract art. The shack in the backyard, her fathers old shoe-repair shop, appears ready to topple with one strong shove.

title: Diamondbacks Pitch to the Brewers Fielder, and He Makes Them Pay in Opener
description: MILWAUKEE  Kirk Gibson saw a lot of a young Prince Fielder when Fielders father, Cecil, and Gibson played together for the Detroit Tigers in the 1990s. The families lived about two blocks apart, and Gibson remembers a strong-for-his-age Fielder cracking batting-practice home runs at Tiger Stadium.

title: When Data Guys Triumph
description: JOSHUA MILBERG has plenty of business cred: an M.B.A. from Yale, experience in the mayors office in Chicago, a job as a vice president for an energy consulting firm.

title: On the Docket
description: The Supreme Court, which returns to the bench on Monday, has so far agreed to hear about 50 cases, including ones on criminal and copyright law, the First Amendment and foreign affairs.

title: As the West Celebrates a Clerics Death, the Mideast Shrugs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Until about two years ago, few in Yemen or the Arab world had heard of Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born propagandist for Islamic radicalism whose death President Obama celebrated as a major blow against Al Qaeda.

title: In New Term, Supreme Court Shifts Focus to Crime and First Amendment
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court, which has been focused in recent terms on the rights of corporations and on curbing big lawsuits, returns to the bench on Monday with a different agenda. Now, criminal justice is at the heart of the courts docket, along with major cases on free speech and religious freedom.

title: Perry Open to Military Intervention in Mexicos Drug War
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said on Saturday that as president, he would consider sending American troops into Mexico to help defeat drug cartels and improve border security. He indicated that any such action would be done in concert with the Mexican government.

title: This Crisis Has 17 Moving Parts
description: ON WEDNESDAY, the eyes of the financial world turned to Finland.

title: Maine City Casts Off Spurned Sculpture
description: The sculpture may have been doomed from the start.

title: Conquering My Fear of Speaking in Public
description: SPEAKING in front of groups may not be a big deal for some people, and there are those who probably sail through their careers without ever having to do so. When I was studying for my C.P.A., I was sure that Id be safe. But life isnt predictable. I ended up in a career that depends on public speaking.

title: Girardi Makes It Clear: Sabathia Wont Pitch Until Monday
description: Joe Girardi made clear Saturday afternoon that he will not allow C.C. Sabathia to persuade him that he should pitch Sunday in Game 2 instead of Game 3 on Monday in Detroit. Girardi confirmed what he said after Fridays game was suspended due to rain  Freddy Garcia will pitch Game 2 on Sunday.

title: Pay the Grace Forward
description: I WAS born in Chicago and am a middle child. My parents had 14 brothers and sisters between them, so my siblings and I grew up in a large extended family. During the summers, we spent time in Brownsville, Tenn., where my mother grew up. That grounded us in our family values  faith, family and freedom, or the ability to choose your path.

title: Sunday: Masquerade
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  After reading the Notepad for this puzzle, I jumped to what turned out to be a false conclusion. I assumed (and you should never assume) that I would find this puzzle frustrating. First, you have to figure out the theme clues and their corresponding entries, which are not necessarily in the language. Then you have to unmask the hidden celebrities in each entry. O.K., so I was wrong.

title: Suggestions for that, er, Tahrir on the Hudson?
description: My Sunday column is about the Occupy Wall Street movement  and in particular suggestions for financial reforms that the movement should take up. My Twitter comparison of the occupied park with Tahrir Square already raised eyebrows  and caused me to rush to clarify  so Id welcome comments on that, or on any specific steps you recommend to reform the financial system.

title: U.T. Making a Big Bet on the Future of Algae
description: Just off a dirt road in northwest Austin stand hundreds of 12-foot-tall tubes filled with green liquid. Nearly 15,000 gallons of algae grow inside the tubes, which are housed in a massive structure called a shadehouse. Lab workers have to climb ladders to peek inside and tend to the tiny organisms.

title: On Immigrant Tuition, Texans See It Perrys Way
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Tiny, Remote Marfa Poised to Be a Rock-Star Magnet
description: Something strange happened at last weekends Trans-Pecos Festival of Music and Love at El Cosmico in Marfa. Five hundred concertgoers  most staying in one of a hundred tents, six trailers, four safari tents and four yurts  three security guards, four sound men and one lighting specialist heard the voice of Led Zeppelin perform onstage. It seemed random and a little surreal, but somehow there was Robert Plant, live in the middle of nowhere.

title: Breakthrough for Radwanska in Tokyo
description: Agnieszka Radwanska bagged the biggest title of her young career Saturday afternoon in Tokyo, defeating Vera Zvonareva, 6-3, 6-2, to win the Toray Pan Pacific Open in Ariake Coliseum.

title: Expenses, Lender Games and Illness Added Up
description: In November 2004, Wanda Carter bought a home at 6548 South Morgan Street on the South Side and thought she got a good deal.

title: Kanye West Show, Shrouded in Silence, Creates a Scene
description: Kanye West, having absorbed enough runway shows over the last five or six years that he has been a ubiquitous presence in the front rows of Fashion Week, finally had his say as a designer tonight with his first show in Paris. It was an event that some people had been anticipating as if it were the second coming of Christian Dior.

title: Looking for Savings, Quinn Has a Good Idea
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Alderman Defends Choice of Ex-Offender to Lead Political Group
description: When Alderman Joe Moreno feuded recently with the Democratic committeeman in his First Ward constituency, he decided to form what he called an independent Democratic political organization.

title: A Fan, a Goat and Long, Painful Memories
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Seeking Taxes, Romney Went After Business
description: BOSTON  Much of the business community in Massachusetts was puzzled. Mitt Romney, a Republican with high-caliber corporate credentials, had run for governor pledging to sweep aside barriers to business and act as the states top salesman.

title: Police Arrest Hundreds of Protesters on Brooklyn Bridge

title: The Kennedy Tunnel
description: Just off Old Tunnel Road in Oakland, a stone and brass-plated marker attests to the former use of a nearby hillside. In the early 1900s, a tunnel through the hill linked Oakland and Lafayette, allowing horse-drawn and pedestrian traffic between the two growing communities. Cars used it, too. The tunnel closed in the 1940s, but a flagpole marks the entrance to this once-bustling locale.

title: Coupon Sites Are a Great Deal, but Not Always to Merchants
description: Like businesses across the land, the Madison Avenue spa Wellpath tried to drum up customers by running heavily discounted coupons on deal-of-the-day Web sites. But the Internet coupon fad is shrinking faster than fat from a weight-loss laser.

description: Robert Whitaker photographed the Beatles, Eric Clapton and Mick Jagger, and wars from Vietnam to the Middle East. He aimed his camera up Salvador Dalis nostrils in search of a surrealist effect. His pictures were displayed at Britains National Portrait Gallery.

title: The Heart of the Art
description: DURING a residency at the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles several years ago, I began to think about images that were created in the course of art preservation, where the realms of visual art and scientific research overlap. While taking photographs at the conservation department of the J. Paul Getty Museum, I became captivated by X-rays of art objects from the museums permanent collections. These ghostly images seemed to surpass the potency of the original objects of art. They were like transmissions from the distant past, conveying messages across time, and connecting the contemporary viewer to the art impulse at the core of these ancient works.

title: Wisconsins Wilson Is Living Up to His Billing

He delivered a short and simple message to his new teammates: he had come to work hard and compete. But just the simple act of introducing himself to his teammates and acknowledging that nothing would be handed to him spoke to his savvy and maturity.

title: Remembering Pete Gent, Who Wrote North Dallas Forty
description: Pete Gent was able to express in words what many players feel about pro football, both good and bad. While his writing left its mark on the game, its equally clear that the game left its mark on him. Gent died Friday from a pulmonary illness at his home in Bangor, Mich. He was 69. A few thoughts:In the early 1970s, as pro football was becoming the nations most popular spectator sport, a group of ex-players exposed, through both their words and their actions, the games seamy underside. A novel by Pete Gent, North Dallas Forty, based on his five years with the Cowboys, graphically depicted the pain and anguish the public couldnt feel or see on their television screens. Yet, despite the broken bones and sleepless nights, most of the players wished it could go on forever. Many, like Gent himself, remembered their football days as some of the best times of their lives.

title: London Film Festival Rolls in on Two Wheels
description: London did not make USA Todays 10 Great Places for City Cycling list this July. But the citys did earn a top-20 mention in a more European-focused Danish report on the best bicycle-friendly cities. Combined with local efforts to promote cycling in anticipation of the upcoming 2012 Olympics, some would argue that Londons cycling credentials are on the rise.

title: The Joy of Needless Details
description: If you have ever visited Baseball-Reference.com, you know that it is one of the greatest inventions of human history. title: New Survey Projects Higher Employee Health Premiums
description: Companies next year will push more health care costs onto their workers, who may see an increase of nearly 11 percent in what they have deducted from their paychecks for health insurance, according to a new annual study by Aon Hewitt, a large Chicago benefits consultancy.

title: The Songs of Glee Give Way to Terror
description: LOS ANGELES  Growing up, the television producer Brad Falchuk said, he practiced to see if he was prepared for a possible home invasion by wriggling on the ground, as if he were hogtied, from his bedroom to the kitchen and extracting a knife from a drawer with his mouth. Youre 8 or 9, this is what you do, Mr. Falchuk explained. Could I escape?

title: Dont Stop Screaming: The Glee Guys Introduce Their American Horror Story
description: A couple of years spent with the sunny kids of Glee could send anyone over to the dark side, and thats exactly where the Glee co-creators Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk turned for their latest television series, American Horror Story, which makes its debut on Wednesday on FX. The new show begins with a husband and wife (Dylan McDermott of The Practice and Connie Britton of Friday Night Lights) and their teenage daughter (Taissa Farmiga) moving to Los Angeles to start their lives fresh. But their new Gothic fixer-up was a steal for a reason: its haunted by a history of murder and visited by creepy neighbors, housekeepers and unwelcome guests (including Jessica Lange, Frances Conroy and Denis OHare) as well as a mysterious figure in a full-body S&M costume, whom the American Horror Story producers have affectionately dubbed Rubber Man.

title: Did the Tigers Have the Right Man at Second Base?
description: 6:48 p.m. | Updated Ryan Raburn is a useful spare part on a major league baseball club. Hes been a slightly above-average hitter over his career and plays a fine outfield. He can also fill in at second or third base, although not particularly well. According to the defensive statistics compiled from video records at Fangraphs.com, Raburns fielding has cost the Tigers 14 runs compared to an average second baseman over the 778 innings he has manned the keystone in his major league career. (He has performed even worse at third.)

title: Texas Hunting Camps Name Causes Trouble for Perry

title: Dolphin Tale Leads in Slow Weekend for Movies
description: Movie theaters were quiet over the weekend as a hold-over from last week  Dolphin Tale  overcame weak competition from several newcomers to take the No. 1 position. After 935 regular-season and 115 playoff games in the N.H.L., the 35-year-old Sykora offered some perspective.

title: Song Cycle Places One Indelible Day Along Historys Bleak Continuum
description: In a free preseason concert last month to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks Alan Gilbert conducted the New York Philharmonic in Mahlers Resurrection Symphony at Avery Fisher Hall, with the performance relayed to Lincoln Center Plaza. That great, tumultuous and, finally, exhilarating work was a fitting choice for the solemn occasion.

title: Arizona Hoping Hudson Can Keep His Cool
description: MILWAUKEE  Daniel Hudson, Arizonas Game 2 starter in the National League division series Sunday, is a one-man argument for keeping the designated hitter out of the N.L. Hudson led all N.L. pitchers with a .277 average and 14 runs batted in in 65 at-bats. Hes no slouch on the mound, either, winning 16 games after an 0-4 start in his first full season in the majors.

title: In Yemen, One Islamist Is Dead, but the Battle Goes On
description: SANA, Yemen  Despite the death of Anwar al-Awlaki, the infamous Yemeni-American cleric who was a propagandist for aspiring jihadists around the globe, Yemens battle against Al Qaeda is far from complete, as security forces fought over the weekend against Islamic militants who control large areas of territory in the countrys restive south.

title: Israel Supports Proposal to Restart Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Israel on Sunday formally accepted an international proposal to return to peace negotiations with the Palestinians, but any immediate resumption of talks appeared unlikely as the Israelis and Palestinians differed sharply over the letter and spirit of the proposal.

title: A Map of Organized Climate Change Denial
description: Oct. 3, 9:00 p.m. | Updated A chart of key components of the climate change denial machine has been produced by Riley E. Dunlap, regents professor of sociology at Oklahoma State University, and Aaron M. McCright, an associate professor of sociology at Michigan State University. The diagram below (reproduced here with permission) is from a chapter the two researchers wrote on organized opposition to efforts to curb greenhouse gases for the new Oxford Handbook of Climate Change and Society.
