title: A New Met Diva, With a Four-Legged Co-Star
description: Those mourning the slow, steady decline of the Franco Zeffirelli era at the Metropolitan Opera can take solace in the fact that a crucial element of his directorial vision remains intact: his mystifying predilection for live animals onstage. David McVicars new production of Donizettis Anna Bolena, which opened last week, for some reason included two Irish wolfhounds, and the placid donkey remains in the revival of Bartlett Shers 2006 production of Rossinis Barbiere di Siviglia that opened on Saturday afternoon.

title: A Concert, Nearly Canceled, Keeps a Rising Star Afloat
description: The beloved concert spot Bargemusic, moored near the Brooklyn Bridge in Dumbo, floats serenely, with a cozy wood-lined interior and a temperamental toilet. It is so improbable and distinctive that it seems a small miracle each time a recital there goes off successfully.

title: Fathers Who Tend to Their Flocks
description: The fourth and latest feature from the moviemaking ministry of Sherwood Pictures, a media arm of the Sherwood Baptist Church in Albany, Ga., Courageous contains enough parables, are you there, God? monologues and tearful affirmations of faith-based fatherhood to furnish a dozen megachurch services. To sweeten the sermon there is also some light gunplay.

title: An Amorous Triangle, Spiced Up by Gunplay
description: For all its flashy sunglasses and gunplay, theres a folk-tale essence in Tigmanshu Dhulias Sahib Biwi Aur Gangster, a riff on Sahib Bibi Aur Ghulam, a 1962 Hindi classic. That film concerned the chaste bond between a married noblewoman and a servant; Mr. Dhulias take offers Sahib (Jimmy Shergill), a rural mob godfather of declining fortunes, and Biwi (Mahie Gill), his neglected, hot-tempered wife. The gangster (Randeep Hooda), hired as a chauffeur, is secretly on a mission to set up Sahib for a hit. Theres nothing chaste about his designs: He covets Biwi and Sahibs status as well.

title: Stars Will Read Amazon Units New Audio Book Series
description: Would you listen to a recording of The End of the Affair that lasted hours? What if Colin Firth were reading it?

title: Neustadt Prize Awarded
description: Rohinton Mistry has been named the 2012 laureate of the $50,000 Neustadt International Prize for Literature, according to World Literature Today, a magazine of the University of Oklahoma. Mr. Mistry previously won the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for fiction and was a finalist in 1996 for the Man Booker Prize for A Fine Balance, which was also selected by Oprah Winfreys book club in 2001. The Neustadt Prize is given every two years and is sponsored by the University of Oklahoma, World Literature Today and the Neustadt family. An international jury considers the work of poets, playwrights and novelists for the honor.

title: Feisty Performance at Paper Mill Playhouse
description: Newsies the Musical may feature rambunctious youths loudly proclaiming their rebellion onstage, but the same description could have been used for a few audience members on Thursday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J. Three women and six teenage girls were removed from the theater after several patrons complained about an altercation and disruptive behavior during the performance, according to The Star-Ledger of Newark. Asked to leave by theater management during the intermission, the women reportedly refused. A uniformed officer then escorted them out. Based on the 1992 film Newsies starring Christian Bale and Bill Pullman and produced by Disney Theatrical Productions, the musical opened last week to glowing reviews under the direction of Jeff Calhoun with choreography by Christopher Gattelli and a book by Harvey Fierstein. The musical has recently drawn interest from theater owners in New York, with the intention of mounting a Broadway production.

title: Crazy Fun at Kenzo
description: PARIS  Humberto Leon and Carol Lim presented their first Kenzo collection on Sunday with a show that was every bit as fun as promised by the two founders of Opening Ceremony.

title: Theater Strike in Philadelphia
description: Members of the Philadelphia chapter of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees ended a daylong strike on Saturday, announcing that a one-week cooling-off period would go into effect to allow for renewed negotiations between the chapter and the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, according to The Associated Press. The strike began after the current chapter contract, which covers about 1,000 employees from the Kimmel Center, the Merriam Theater and the Philadelphia Academy of Music, expired on Friday. The Kimmel Center canceled all Saturday events, including a musical performance by Audra McDonald. Talks between the chapter and the Kimmel Center broke down last week after the sides failed to agree on wages, benefits, working conditions and the chapters jurisdiction.

title: Another Honor for Paul Simon
description: Paul Simon, above, was among 178 artists, scientists and institutional leaders inducted into the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on Saturday at Harvard, The Associated Press reported. Founded in 1780 by John Adams, James Bowdoin, John Hancock and others, the academy recognizes achievement in public affairs, science, education and culture. The ceremony included a performance by Mr. Simon of American Tune, from his 1973 album There Goes Rhymin Simon. Other inductees from the academys 231st class included the novelists Oscar Hijuelos and Luisa Valenzuela, the landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh and the Shakespeare scholar James Shapiro.

title: Rock in Rio Music Festival Ends
description: Chris Martin, above, the lead vocalist for the group Coldplay, practiced his spray painting on a stage wall during his bands performance at the Rock in Rio Music Festival in Rio de Janeiro on Saturday. Among the artists to appear at the annual series of concerts were Rihanna, Elton John, Metallica, Red Hot Chili Peppers and Shakira. The festival, which opened on Sept. 23, ended on Sunday.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Ballet Divas Steal Stage From Riff, if Only Briefly
description: Robert Fairchild is a natural Riff, the charismatic head of the Jets, who, in the Jerome Robbins ballet West Side Story Suite, as in the classic musical, meets a senselessly violent end. It was almost a surprise, at Friday nights New York City Ballet performance, to realize he was making his debut in the role; after that, it was just a delight.

title: Blue Shield of California Wont Cover Breast Cancer Drug
description: Blue Shield of California will no longer pay for the use of the drug Avastin to treat breast cancer, a sign that support for the widely debated and expensive treatment may be eroding among health plans.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Rapping in the Rain, All Smiles
description: Often will.i.am, the frontman and behind-the-boards maestro of the Black Eyed Peas, will appear in public wearing what seems to be a plastic mold, or sheath, covering his head, giving him the air of an Afro-futurist cybernaut or a character from a William Gibson novel. It turns out hes just planning for rain.

title: Innovator of Dance Celebrates 40 Years
description: ROCHESTER  Garth Fagan does not simply walk into a room.

title: Monday: Sob Stories
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  If youre keeping track, another one of the unwritten rules of mainstream crossword theme development is: Thou shalt not drag thy political leanings into the daily puzzle. The daily crossword is placed squarely (sorry) in the entertainment section as a respite from the rest of the days news. Today, however, Stanley Newman, editor of the Newsday crossword puzzle, hitches his vowels to our 43rd president in what appears to be a tribute to George DUBYA Bush.

description: When the Pixies, the reunited stars of 1980s alt-rock, decided recently to play a special show in Los Angeles, they wanted to make sure their biggest local followers were invited first.

title: Daytimes Talking Heads Are Now Eating, Too
description: Its hard to pinpoint the moment when chefs turned into all-purpose celebrities, but there is no question that the line between food and show business has indelibly blurred.

title: A U.S.-Backed Geothermal Plant in Nevada Struggles
description: WASHINGTON  In a remote desert spot in northern Nevada, there is a geothermal plant run by a politically connected clean energy start-up that has relied heavily on an Obama administration loan guarantee and is now facing financial turmoil.

description: As we did in Week 1, tonight well be using a Web feature from Advanced NFL Stats that charts win probability live during games.

description: The Perseus Books Group has created a distribution and marketing service that will allow authors to self-publish their own e-books, the company said on Sunday.

title: In Crossing the Border, the Risks Are More Grave
description: Veteran Mexican border crossers present an enormous challenge to American policymakers, because they continue to head north despite deterrents more severe than at any time in recent history.

description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated Gary E. Knell, who has led the nonprofit Sesame Workshop for the last 11 years, will become chief executive of NPR in December, the public radio network announced on Sunday.

title: Arrested Development Movie, and New TV Episodes, Are in the Works
description: Captain Ahab had Moby-Dick; Linus van Pelt had the Great Pumpkin; and, in the five years since Arrested Development has gone off the air, fans of that underdog Fox comedy series have spent their lives pining for a film adaptation that would further the adventures of its deeply dysfunctional Bluth clan.

description: The insurgent group, based in Pakistans northwestern frontier, flows fighters into Afghanistan and has orchestrated a long campaign of guerrilla and terrorist attacks against the Afghan government and its American sponsors. It has also harbored Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS This weeks data will include the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing index for September and construction spending for August (Monday); factory orders for August (Tuesday); ADP employment for September and the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for September (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for September, wholesale trade for August and consumer credit for August (Friday).

title: Red Mass Marks Start of Supreme Court Session
description: In 58 years, the Red Mass, held the first Sunday of October at St. Matthews Cathedral in Washington to kick off the Supreme Court session, has gone from a token ritual to a power conclave.

title: For Some, Zuccotti Park Becomes a Must-See Attraction
description: The first stop on Sharon Wheelers trip to New York City last weekend was Kleinfeld Bridal, the wedding dress emporium, where her niece, Morgan Vaught, tried on gowns.

description: MADISON AVENUE claims that the annual Advertising Week in New York is like New York Fashion Week for smart people. The fashionable set counters that Advertising Week is like Fashion Week for ugly people.

description: A view of the day in sports, with rabid fans in football and soccer and robust waves, of a sort, in Germany.

title: Syfys Halloween Events to Focus on New York City
description: As if New York were not spooky enough, the city will for the first time take part in a cable channels celebration of the 31 Days of Halloween.

title: Toil and Trouble Over the Caldron That Is Greece
description: PARIS  Europes long, halting struggle with deficits and debt can seem like the agonies of Macbeth: Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow, creeps in this petty pace from day to day, to the last syllable of recorded time.

title: Peter Gent, Football Novelist, Dies at 69
description: Peter Gent, a receiver for the Dallas Cowboys of the 1960s whose best-selling novel North Dallas Forty portrayed professional football as a dehumanizing business that drove pain-racked players to drug and alcohol abuse, died Friday in Bangor, Mich. He was 69.

title: Tours Offer Quick Access to the Sept. 11 Memorial, but at a Cost
description: A few dozen passengers on the top deck of the boat half-listened to the wind-muted voice of the guide as he noted the Empire State Building, the steamship Lilac and a group of kayakers off Chelsea Piers.

description: WINTHROP, Wash.  Kristy Longanecker smiled while her husband fell from the clear blue sky.

title: Mail-Order Pharmacies
description: To the Editor:

title: Shifting the Suburban Paradigm
description: Is there anything made in America thats less innovative than the single-family home? While we obsess over the new in terms of what we keep in our houses  the ever-increasing speed and functionality of our Smartphones, entertainment options built into refrigerators, sophisticated devices that monitor, analyze and report on our sleep cycles, even the superior technology of the running shoes we put on before heading out the flimsy fiberboard door  were incredibly undemanding of the houses themselves. These continue to be built the same way they have for over a century, and usually not as well. Walls and windows are thin, materials cheap, design (and I use the term loosely) not well-considered. The building process is a protracted affair, taking far too long and creating embarrassing amounts of building waste (over 50 percent of all waste produced in the United States, in fact).

title: Social Media News Site Gains Clout
description: Pete Cashmore acknowledged he was nervous. Only a few years ago, he was living with his parents in a small town in northeast Scotland, trying to start a technology blog. Now, at 26, he was about to interview Elie Wiesel, the 82-year-old Holocaust survivor and Nobel Peace Prize winner, onstage at the 92nd Street Y, about the future of ethics in a digitally connected world.

description: Wolfgang Munchau, on the latest euro rescue idea (using the existing stabilization fund, but leveraging it up like a collateralized debt obligation):

title: A Victory for the Taking, Almost Left on the Ground
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  It was a fumble. Of course it was a fumble. Arizona Cardinals safety Kerry Rhodes was sure. Defensive end Calais Campbell was sure. Even Eli Manning, standing 25 yards back upfield with his hands clasped to the sides of his head, was sure that Victor Cruz had just inexplicably, incomprehensibly, laid the game at the Cardinals collective feet.

title: Altering a Deal Without Blocking it
description: Blocking mergers is the bluntest tool in an antitrust watchdogs armory. That is what the Justice Department is trying with AT&Ts ambition to acquire T-Mobile USA.

title: Animated Fruit With Ambition
description: LOS ANGELES  There is little doubt that Dane Boedigheimer has created an online sensation that struck a pop cultural nerve. The Annoying Orange Web videos that hes been rolling out for the last two years have racked up more than 800 million views on You Tube, where the threshold for a runaway hit is about 50 million.

title: Obama Campaign Borrows From Bush 04 Playbook
description: WASHINGTON  The last time an incumbent president faced re-election, George W. Bush exploited social and national security issues to offset his economic vulnerabilities.

title: Oracle Convention Engulfs San Francisco With a Party Atmosphere
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Commuters driving into this city on Monday morning will discover major downtown thoroughfares closed. More than 129,000 square feet of tents will have sprouted around the citys convention center, where 4.25 miles of power cables, 300 miles of phone and Internet wires and enough beer trucks to sate 45,000 people are in place.

title: Though Not Ready to Play, Crosby Shapes the Game
description: DETROIT  It has been said that the N.H.L. season beginning on Thursday is about Sidney Crosby. But it is also about ideas, about vast changes in perception and philosophy across the league, both among the people who run the game and those who play it. And that, too, is largely about Sidney Crosby.

title: Open Up High Court to Cameras
description: Waco, Tex.

title: In Egypt, Concessions by Military on Politics
description: CAIRO  Egypts interim military rulers have apparently agreed to allow foreign election observers and to let political parties take a greater role in creating a permanent government.

title: Foreclosures Are Killing Us
description: AFTER slowing down in the first half of the year, the rate of homes entering foreclosure is rising again. First-time default notices were served on 78,000 homes in August, a 33 percent increase from July. A $1 billion federal program to help jobless and underemployed homeowners ended Friday. Foreclosure notices were filed against a record 2.9 million properties last year, and an additional 1.2 million in the first half of this year.

title: Holding China to Account
description: The dire state of the world economy reflects destructive actions on the part of many players. Still, the fact that so many have behaved badly shouldnt stop us from holding individual bad actors to account.

title: Unofficial Visits Draw Concern, Not Scrutiny
description: The report last week that an assistant football coach at Tennessee, Willie Mack Garza, paid $1,500 for a top-rated tailback, Lache Seastrunk, and his mother to fly to an unofficial visit to Tennessee sent reverberations throughout college sports.

title: For Politics in South, Race Divide Is Defining
description: PHILADELPHIA, Miss.  Ten miles south of Ronnies Steak and Grill, where Johnny DuPree was making a recent appearance before the Rotary Club, lies the lonely road where three civil rights workers were killed by the Klan one June night in 1964 for registering blacks to vote.

title: Battle for Libya | October 2, 2011
description: Fighting continued around the cities of Bani Walid and Surt.

title: Bill Requiring Higher Wages Puts Council Leader on the Spot
description: Supporters of a faltering bill that would require companies in city-subsidized projects to pay higher wages plan a new push to revive the measure, setting up an unwelcome choice for Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, who could anger either labor leaders or business interests by her action on the legislation.

title: School Layoffs About to Fall Heaviest on the Poorest and Most Struggling
description: The pink slips have gone out, and if no deal is reached by Friday, 716 of New York Citys lowest-paid workers  school aides, parent coordinators and other members of school support staffs  will lose their jobs, the latest victims of budget cuts to the public schools.

title: Ruling for Open Courts
description: The American justice system rests on open and transparent proceedings. A recent ruling by Judge James Ware of Federal District Court in San Francisco wisely upheld this principle in ordering the release of a video recording of the civil trial on the constitutionality of Proposition 8, Californias voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage.

title: Bloomberg, as Witness, May Face Prickly Questions
description: The witness was not answering the question, and Dennis C. Vacco was clearly fed up.

title: Michael J. Drake, Planetary Scientist, Dies at 65
description: Michael J. Drake, a planetary scientist, worked on many NASA space missions in his lifetime. But he remained devoted to one idea that he proposed several times in the last decade and that NASA officials rejected twice: to send a spacecraft to an asteroid, take rock samples from the surface and bring them home to study the origins of life.

title: Lottery Numbers
Social Security, New York Style

title: An Esplanade on the East River
description: For years now, New York City has been eager to fill a 22-block gap along the East River in the greenway that encircles most of Manhattan along the waters edge. And for years, the United Nations has been considering ways to increase its office space in the city.

title: All That Talent Falls Flat for Eagles and Cowboys
description: There were no damaged hands or missed calls to blame, and no punctured lung to play the hero. N.F.L. coaches like to divide the season into quarters, and they think that after the first one is over, they should have a good idea of what kind of team they have.

title: Say No to the Keystone XL
description: Unless good sense intervenes, it looks increasingly likely that the State Department will approve the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry a coarse, acidic crude oil from northern Alberta in Canada to refineries on the Gulf Coast of Texas. That would be a mistake.

title: Greeks Move to Slash State Jobs for 30,000
description: ATHENS  After marathon talks with foreign auditors, the Greek government said Sunday that it had reached a deal on how to slash its unwieldy public sector by putting 30,000 workers on a scheme that would lead to early retirement for some and dismissal for others, in a bid to meet conditions set by foreign lenders for the release of crucial emergency loans.

title: Snag for Perry: Offensive Name at Texas Camp
description: The campaign of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas found itself on the defensive on Sunday over a report that he had hunted at and taken guests to a West Texas camp with a racially charged name that his father, and later Mr. Perry, had leased.

title: Tigers Cabrera Speaks Cordially and Carries a Big Stick
description: Miguel Cabrera is a gregarious soul who, when he is not smacking hits all over the park, finds time to chat with his colleagues.

title: A Broader G.I. Bill
description: Starting this month, military veterans pursuing an education under the G.I. Bill have many more choices. The money for tuition, books and housing used to be just for study at colleges and universities, but now the G.I. Bill also covers non-degree institutions like vocational and technical schools, flight schools, and licensing and apprenticeship programs.

title: Catcher Keeps Scherzer on Target
description: In the first inning of his first career postseason start, Detroits Max Scherzer needed a compass, guidebook or GPS system to find the strike zone. The pitches that departed his hand were scattering every which way but where he wanted.

title: The Cost to Own a New York Island
description: Rat Island, a tiny lump of rock in Long Island Sound that is home to birds, mussel shells and not much else, has sold for $160,000, after about 25 minutes of bidding among a half-dozen prospective buyers, said Ozzie Crisalli, of Syracuse Realty Group, which represented the property at auction Sunday in City Island.

title: Easygoing Lee Finds a Forgiving Home
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: The University of Wherever
description: FOR more than a decade educators have been expecting the Internet to transform that bastion of tradition and authority, the university. Digital utopians have envisioned a world of virtual campuses and distributed learning. They imagine a business model in which online courses are consumer-rated like products on Amazon, tuition is set by auction services like eBay, and students are judged not by grades but by skills they have mastered, like levels of a videogame. Presumably, for the Friday kegger you go to the Genius Bar.

title: Brewers Flex Their Muscles and Push Past the Diamondbacks Again
description: MILWAUKEE  Prince Fielder started it, naturally, since every gesture and celebration by the Milwaukee Brewers seems to emanate from him. It is called beast mode. Whenever a Brewer gets a hit or makes a nice play, Fielder, the bearlike first baseman, flexes his arms forward as if trying to hug a sequoia, and the player flashes it back. Bloop or blast, it does not matter. A grunt tops it off.

description: When it comes to business, everyone on Wall Street wants a piece ofWarren E. Buffett. His presidential politics, however, appear to be another matter altogether.

title: Americans Raid Byways of Haqqani Insurgents in Afghanistan
description: CHARBARAN, Afghanistan  The first helicopter landed in the bluish gray gloom before dawn. More than 20 members of an American reconnaissance platoon and Afghan troops accompanying them jogged out through the swirling dust, moving into a forest smelling of sage and pine.

title: Incentives for Advanced Work Let Pupils and Teachers Cash In
description: WORCESTER, Mass.  Joe Nystrom, who teaches math at a low-income high school here, used to think that only a tiny group of students  the smart kids  were capable of advanced coursework.

title: Queens Lawyers Niche: Defending Abused Women Who Kill
description: Minutes before she killed her husband, Barbara Sheehan was on the computer, proofreading her sons religion paper. That same morning, she had also surfed the Web for travel bargains and read about celebrity couples  hardly the behavior of a woman in fear for her life, a prosecutor sought to show last week at Ms. Sheehans murder trial.

title: A State Grooms Its Best Students to Be Good Teachers
description: DURHAM, N.C.  When Mr. Williams means business, he is not kidding around. Hes pretty quiet, pretty serious, said Ashabur Rahman, a fifth grader at Glenn Elementary School who has him for math and science.

description: Oracle OpenWorld, the biggest convention in San Francisco, opens Sunday night with a keynote speech from Larry Ellison, the companys founder and chief executive. An hour before the doors opened, lines 400 deep formed at each main door of the Moscone Center.

title: Success Battling Terrorists, but Scant Glory for It
description: WASHINGTON  The killing of an American-born Al Qaeda leader in Yemen on Friday will probably bolster the high marks Americans give President Obama for dealing with terrorism and foreign policy. Yet his overall approval ratings are likely to remain depressed, underscoring the economys drag on his prospects for re-election.

title: New State Rules Raising Hurdles at Voting Booth
description: Since Republicans won control of many statehouses last November, more than a dozen states have passed laws requiring voters to show photo identification at polls, cutting back early voting periods or imposing new restrictions on voter registration drives.

title: Big Victory Emboldens Wisconsin
description: MADISON, Wis.  Perhaps the most notable part of Wisconsins rout of Nebraska was the reaction of its fans. The Badger faithful stormed the field last season after the upset of Ohio State, but they kept their revelry to the stands Saturday night.

title: Crossing Over, and Over
description: AGUA PRIETA, Mexico  "My wife, my son  I have to get back to them," Daniel kept telling himself, from the moment he was arrested in Seattle for driving with an expired license, all the way through the deportation proceeding that delivered him to Mexico in June.

title: Why Bismarck Loved Lincoln
description: We usually think of the Civil War as a uniquely American event, a war unlike any other fought in the Western world during the 19th century. And of course thats true, strictly speaking: no other country saw itself split in two over slavery. But thats not the only way to think of the war. Put a different way, the Civil War was just one of several wars for national unification  including fighting in Italy and Germany  on both sides of the Atlantic during the mid-19th century.

title: Brooklyn Academy Offers New Program
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has announced a professional development program designed to provide free support to Brooklyn art groups attempting to mount performances. As part of the academys 150th anniversary and in coordination with the DeVos Institute of Arts Management at the Kennedy Center in Washington, the 14-month program will offer workshops, mentoring sessions and access to academy facilities. Six spots will be available initially for nonprofit performing arts organizations, with dance being the focus for the first session.

title: Alexander Grant, Dancer With Royal Ballet, Dies at 86

description: As the Telangana region of Andhra Pradesh entered its 20th day of general strikes demanding a separate state, the Congress party still seemed unclear about its stance on the matter. K Chandrashekhar Rao, the leader of the separatist party Telangana Rashtriya Samithi, staged a sit-in at Rajghat on Gandhi Jayanti in Delhi this weekend (NDTV).
