title: The Paris Shows: Something Fishy
description: Chlo is expected today to remove the roof from the tent in the Tuileries so the audience doesnt bake (bring your shades and load up on sunblock). Paris is in the grip of Indian summer  hard to complain about clear skies, but I sometimes I feel I should head out in the mornings with a canteen.

title: Oct. 3, 1990 | East and West Germany United After 45 Years
description: On Oct. 3, 1990, West Germany and East Germany officially became one nation after 45 years of postwar division. The Oct. 3 New York Times  reported, Forty-five years after it was carved up in defeat and disgrace, Germany was reunited today in a midnight celebration of pealing bells, national hymns and the jubilant blare of good old German oom-pah-pah.

title: News Quiz | October 3, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: The White Shirts and the Protesters
description: WHO are the so-called white shirts of the New York Police Department?

title: Wait, Which Way Are the Jaguars Headed?
description: To the growing list of problems currently dogging the Jaguars (1-3)  poor play, a rookie quarterback, questionable roster moves and the specter of relocation  we can now add a new one: ridicule. But at least this time it was not Coach Jack Del Rios fault.

title: Love and Loss and the Animal Kingdom
description: There is no single word that can define Animals Are Outside Today, the photography book that Colleen Plumb has worked on for more than a decade.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 3, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Facebook as Tastemaker.

title: Five Tips for Great Black-and-White Photos
description: Vincent Versace is a purist when it comes to black-and-white photography. He is finishing his third how-to book on the subject, From Oz to Kansas: Almost Every Black and White Conversion Technique Known to Man. For black-and-white done right, he is the man to go to.

title: A Conversation With Naeem Khan
description: Its less than an hour before Naeem Khans runway show at Lincoln Center showcasing his Spring 2012 collection, and Im standing backstage with the 54 year-old designer. Photographers scurry around us shooting the clothes, which are still on hangers, while a team of stylists apply the finishing hair, makeup and nail touches on the leggy models. The mood is hectic, but Khan himself is incredibly calm.

title: Reimagined Maritime Museum in Amsterdam Opens
description: After a four-year renovation, the National Maritime Museum in Amsterdam reopened yesterday, with a renewed focus on experiencing the Netherlands seafaring history through interactive presentations, voyage simulations and life-sized seafaring replicas.

title: Class War Games
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: Offensive Line Leaves Jets Vulnerable
description: A quick recap of the Jets 34-17 loss at Baltimore:

title: The Early Word
description: In Todays Times

title: Bringing Gasoline and Matches from the Bullpen
description: You cannot improve upon perfection. So here, without commentary, is a pitch-by-pitch breakdown of Brad Zieglers relief performance for the Diamondbacks against the Brewers on Sunday.

title: Do You Keep a Diary or Journal?
description: Keeping a detailed account of ones lifewhether the writing is meant for the writers eyes only, posted on a blog for all to see, or shared with a select fewis a common practice. Do you take part in it? Do you write for an audience or just yourself? Why? Have you become moreor lessactive in chronicling your life and times as you get older?

title: Q&A: Finding Faces in Photos
description: Q.

title: Bringing Yoga to the West
description: Not too long ago, Vivekananda, a household name in his homeland, was famous here as well, as the first missionary from the East to the West, writes Ann Louise Bardach in the Sunday Review of The New York Times.

title: Back From Break, Congress Has a Full Plate
description: WASHINGTON  Congress returns on Monday after a week off, but it was the sort of recess during which it rains every day, and no one gets to play on the swings. Hanging over both chambers is the specter of yet another serious fiscal fight this week, with longer-term battles over trade, regulations and how best to stimulate the economy also on the horizon.

title: Complaint Box | Children in Restaurants
description: On a weekend excursion to Baltimore in July, I chanced upon an unusual scene in a hotel restaurant. After a toddler and his parents had finished eating and left their table, a two-person cleanup crew immediately appeared, attempting to reverse the devastation that the child had wrought on and beneath the table. Apparently the toddler had shredded every last piece of bread on the table and tossed it to the floor, along with various other breakfast items. Yet nothing in the parents expressions or words would have led one to conclude that they were aware of the mess their child had created.

title: Umenyiora Returns With a Flourish
description: A quick look back at the Giants 31-27 victory over Arizona:

title: This Week in Small Business: America for Sale!
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Amanda Knox Freed After Appeal in Italian Court
description: PERUGIA, Italy  With a rapt worldwide television audience looking on, an Italian court on Monday reversed the murder conviction of 24-year-old Amanda Knox, the American student whose sensational murder trial had reverberated on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Sharp Variations in Risks to Sea Turtles
description: A single conservation strategy for a widely distributed species works about as well as a one-size-fits-all pair of sweat pants  too loose for some people, uncomfortably tight for others.

title: Week 4 Quick Hits: In Defense of Tony Romo
description: The Falcons are still searching for an offensive identity. Did Bill Belichick find a defensive identity? And the Bills were reaquainted with a little reality. Heres a quick look at every game from Week 4:

title: TransCanada Pipeline Foes See U.S. Bias in E-Mails
description: A State Department official provided Fourth of July party invitations, subtle coaching and cheerleading, and inside information about Secretary Hillary Rodham Clintons meetings to a Washington lobbyist for a Canadian company seeking permission from the department to build a pipeline that would carry crude from the oil sands of Canada to the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Vain Glorious | Annee de Mamiel
description: Apart from switching to a richer moisturizer during the winter, most of us do not give much thought to seasonal changes and skin. But for Annee de Mamiel, there is no separating the two. Combining her training in traditional Chinese medicine, which holds that everything is seasonal, and her experience as a facialist, de Mamiel creates four limited-edition custom oils every year, each one available only during the three-month period for which it is intended.

title: Monday Reading: Flights to Europe, for a Little Less
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Mosque Set on Fire in Northern Israel
description: JERUSALEM  A mosque in an Arab village in northern Israel was set on fire early Monday in what the police called an arson attack, and an outside wall was defaced with Hebrew graffiti.

title: Exit the Curmudgeon
description: Have you ever wondered what Sundays would be like without Andy Rooney on 60 Minutes, inveighing against all manner of injustices and irritants, from the near-cosmic to the barely worth mentioning? If you have, and even if you havent, you are about to find out. On Sunday night, Mr. Rooney delivered his last philippic after 33 years as a regular contributor to the CBS newsmagazine.

title: ABC News and Yahoo News Announce Deal to Share Content
description: 10:41 p.m. | Updated

title: Did Officials Get the Victor Cruz Call Right?
description: Rule 7, Section 2, Article 1(e) An official shall declare the ball dead and the down ended when a runner is out of bounds, or declares himself down by falling to the ground, or kneeling, and making no effort to advance.

title: Two iPad Cases and a Screed
description: What could be simpler than an iPad case? A company just sent me two that raise that question and illustrate a tenet of design that hardware and software makers seem to be forgetting.

title: Fashion Bites | First Floor Paris
description: When Astan Konat, a Frenchwoman with a background in marketing and brand development, met the Cypriot designer Erotokritos Antoniadis, they bonded over their desire to mix fashion and food. Together they opened First Floor  part canteen and part boutique  in the Haut Marais in Paris.

title: Can  Jets Handle  Pressure of Being a Targeted Team?
description: Youre either getting better or youre getting worse  Joe Paterno

title: Trapped in Tijuana
description: Illegal immigrants sent from the United States back to their native Mexico end up trapped in border towns like Tijuana, desperate to return to their families in the states.

title: Bloomberg Testifies in Consultants Trial
description: The executive branch paid a visit to the judiciary on Monday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg testified for more than two hours in the trial of John F. Haggerty Jr., a Republican political consultant accused of stealing $1.1 million from Mr. Bloomberg during his 2009 re-election campaign.

title: Video and Translation of Knoxs Statement in Italian Court
description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated  As my colleague Elisabetta Povoledo reports from Perugia, Italy, Amanda Knox, the American student jailed in the killing her roommate while both were studying abroad in Italy four years ago, was freed on Monday after an Italian appeals court overturned the her conviction and that of her Italian co-defendant.

title: Buyout Firms to Buy Drug Research Company for $3.9 Billion
description: 7:02 p.m. | Updated

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Others Go, but Buffett Stays on Presidents Side | On Friday evening, Mr. Buffett was the host of a fund-raiser for President Obama at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan, typically a magnet for the whos who of finance.

title: Fight for Social Programs Looms Anew in the House
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans are laying the groundwork for another battle with President Obama over spending and domestic policy with a bill that would cut some of his favorite health and education programs, tie the hands of the National Labor Relations Board and eliminate federal grants for Planned Parenthood clinics.

title: What Were Reading
description: Bon Apptit: Were in the midst of an American boom in boutique cider-making. Andrew Knowlton selects a few of his favorites.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Sesame Workshop Names New Chief
description: 10:28 a.m. | Updated Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit group that produces Sesame Street and other educational media for children, said Monday that it had named H. Melvin Ming its chief executive, replacing Gary E. Knell, who was named the chief executive of NPR on Sunday.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Soared Nearly 10% in September, Despite Economic Gloom
description: DETROIT  Auto sales defied a downcast economy in September, climbing 9.9 percent to their highest level in five months as new models arrived at dealerships and inventory shortages eased.

title: Life Is a Wheel
description: Bruce Weber rides through the heartland.

title: Runway In Review
description: CelineDesigner: Phoebe PhiloDate and Location: Sunday, Oct. 2, Tennis Club de Paris, 84 avenue Georges Lafont, 16ePhotos: slide show

title: Nobel in Literature to Be Awarded on Thursday
description: The winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature will be named on Thursday, the Swedish Academy announced Monday.

title: Evercore Hires a Top JPMorgan Banker
description: Evercore Partners has hired Tim Main, formerly a top banker at JPMorgan Chase, as a senior adviser to the firms investment banking business.

title: Averbuch: Always Learning and Just Playing
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Every time I think Ive figured it out, Im proven wrong. I think that Ive gotten to know myself as an athlete, got a handle on my career, dissected this crazy game I play  and then I have some sort of epiphany. The more I learn, the more I realize there is left to learn.

title: One of 3 Chosen for Nobel in Medicine Died Days Ago
description: When a representative of the Nobel Foundation could not reach Dr. Ralph M. Steinman by telephone Monday to deliver the thrilling news that he had been awarded a Nobel Prize in Medicine for his breakthrough work in immunology, he sent him an e-mail about the honor.

title: South Carolina Picks Date for G.O.P. Primary
description: South Carolina will hold its Republican presidential primary on Jan. 21, the party announced on Monday morning, virtually assuring that voting in caucuses and primaries will begin just after New Years Day.

title: The Price of Running Late, Part 1
description: As I wrote last week, there are some inappropriate precedents when considering what sort of penalty might be paid by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, or other potential Republican candidates like Sarah Palin, for entering the presidential race late.

title: Your Financial Honeymoon Will Eventually End
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Numberplay: Fusing Dots
description: Youll never count the same after this weeks adventure, brought to us by Harold Reiter from the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. I met Professor Reiter at a Math Circle event over the summer and found him overflowing with curiosity and enthusiasm about anything math-related  including a number of terrific math puzzles. Fusing Dots is one of his favorites.

title: Fashion Week Casting | Giambattista Valli
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#590", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Behind the scenes at the casting and fitting for todays Giambattista Valli show at 1:30 p.m. in Paris.

title: Can Mangold Get the Jets Back on Track?
description: How will the Jets recover from another beating heading into a crucial game in New England?

title: In Football and Baseball, Instant Karmas Gonna Get You
description: Karma can be such a funny thing. We already knew it was a bit slippery, not always showing up when you think it should, but not only did it make a grand entrance into the N.F.L. and Major League Baseball games on Sunday, but it also showed such impressive two-sport range, the Yankees are now considering offering it a $400 billion contract.

title: Voting Law Changes in 2012
description: A report by the Brennan Center for Justice details the recent bills and legislation that have created restrictions on voting for 2012.

title: Advanced Placement Classes for All, and $100 for a Passing Score
description: In Mondays Times, Sam Dillon reports on the National Math and Science Initiative, a program that allows all interested students at participating high schools to enroll in Advanced Placement courses, regardless of their past academic performance.

title: Monday Motorsports: Franchitti Regains IndyCar Lead at Kentucky, While Carpenter Logs First Win
description: His famous wife may call the Bluegrass State home, but Kentucky has not been so welcoming to Dario Franchitti. Entering Sundays Indy 300 at Kentucky Speedway, the three-time IndyCar champion had not finished higher than fifth at the oval track and had wrecked spectacularly in 2007. While Franchitti did not come away with a victory on Sunday, he did leave with the overall IndyCar series lead.

title: Styled to a T | Zola Jesus
description: The Trend

title: Monday Matchup: Colts at Bucs
description: Colts (0-3) at Buccaneers (2-1), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Buccaneers by 10

title: Two Chosen Geniuses Reflect on Label
description: The MacArthur Foundation has never attached the word genius to its annual grants to exemplary scientists, scholars, researchers, writers, artists, composers and other creative Americans. The term genius award seems to have sprung up in the news media soon after the first grants were given, in 1981, and the nickname has stuck. The program simply provides a fellowship, with recipients (some 20 to 40 each year) receiving $500,000 each, no strings attached, paid in quarterly installments over five years.

title: A Slowdown in Venture-Backed I.P.O.s
description: For initial public offerings, market volatility has been poison.

title: Schools Dangle Carrot Snacks, but Its a Tough Sale
description: COMMACK, N.Y.  The new vending machine sat unnoticed as students rushed past its baby carrots, yogurt smoothies and hummus to neighbors dispensing Snapple, Doritos, Goldfish and Cheez-It. The lunch period was nearly over before a potential customer stopped to check out its offerings.

title: Risks: Alcohol Deaths and the Solo Life
description: A new study has found that living alone may raise the risk for alcohol-related death.

title: Screening: Increased Risks After Prostate Biopsy
description: A prostate biopsy more than doubles the risk of being hospitalized for infections and other medical problems within the following month, a new study reports.

title: Now Playing | Zola Jesuss Vessel
description: Directed by Jacqueline Castel

title: Sesame Street Special on Hunger Introduces New Muppet Character
description: The familiar address of Sesame Street is about to get a new visitor, one who could surely benefit from the sunny days and friendly neighbors there. For a prime-time special to raise awareness about hunger faced by American families, Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization that produces Sesame Street, has created a new Muppet character named Lily, a 7-year-old girl representing one of the 17 million American children that the Department of Agriculture estimates are food insecure, meaning their access to food is limited or uncertain.

title: Exclusive Music Video | Zola Jesus
description: The Moment blog premieres the music video for Vessel, by Zola Jesus, from her third album Conatus, out Tuesday, October 4.

title: A Report of a Hingis Returnin Mixed Doubles
description: 1:47 p.m. | Updated Charlotte James, host of the Australian Open launch webcast, reported that Martina Hingis has only committed to the legends event at the 2012 Australian Open thus far, and is not confirmed for mixed doubles.

title: Students hack The New York Times at hackNY Fall Hackathon
description: The New York Times was one of fourteen official API-providers, along with groups like Foursquare, Etsy, NYCPlatform (the City of New Yorks data site), and tumblr, (plus unofficial API-providers like Google and Twilio) at the hackNY Fall hackathon, held over the weekend at NYU.

title: Microsofts Patent Strategy Against Android
description: When Samsung Electronics blinked last week, Microsoft scored another win in its campaign to strike patent-licensing deals with the makers of smartphones and tablets using Googles Android software.

title: DealBook: Venture-Backed I.P.O.s Slow in Third Quarter
description: For initial public offerings, market volatility has been poison.

title: An Evening With the Swells
description: Last night, Tods had a cocktail party at the Italian Embassy for its new signature collection, followed by a dinner that attracted a lot of editors in chief, along with Lee Radziwill, Marisa Berenson, Rachel Zoe and assorted Casiraghis and Courtin-Clarinses. It was a little fancy for me, and I found myself going over the hits and misses of the week with Hal Rubenstein and Nina Garcia, who both liked Riccardo Tiscis strong tailoring this season for Givenchy.

title: Model-Morphosis | Zuzanna Bijoch at Givenchy
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Zuzanna Bijoch from Next Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Luigi Murenu for John Frieda. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Park Avenue Armory Will be Setting for Trip to Mars
description: Over the years the Park Avenue Armory has transformed its cavernous drill hall into everything including a science-fiction fun house and a landscape created from 30 tons of discarded clothing. For its next act the New York artist Tom Sachs will offer SPACE PROGRAM 2.0: Mars, his fictional mission to the planet. The project is a presentation of the Armory and Creative Time.

title: Lions Rebuilt Team, Psyche and Record
description: It figures that the Detroit Lions would be the first team in N.F.L. history to win consecutive games after trailing by at least 20 points in each. After all, once a team has resurrected itself from a 0-16 season, come-from-behind victories are just microcosms of a much bigger rebuilding job.

title: They Heard the Word Culture, and They Reached for Their Gun
description: Funnily enough, I was in New York when it happened. It was a short breather after several months in Kabul  a treat for my children, whom I hadnt seen for so long. Wed been out all day  MoMA, Harlem for lunch, Yankees tickets, a cruise past the Statue of Liberty. There was a reflection on the water of the development at ground zero as we steered by. Thats why youre in Kabul? my kids asked.

title: Navigating the Net Wisely in a Health Crisis
description: Andrew Schorr, a specialist in health communications, is convinced that the Internet saved his life. Now, through a book he wrote with Mary Adam Thomas, The Web-Savvy Patient, he is trying to help others facing a medical crisis use the Internet to their advantage and avoid its potential pitfalls.

title: Defending David Against Goliath
description: You may have seen a fascinating New York Times article about the lawsuit Procter & Gamble has filed against a start-up called Willa, which produces a line of cosmetics that is sold in Target and in small boutiques. It turns out that P.&G. has a line of cosmetics called Wella, a German hair care brand that the conglomerate acquired in 2003 for $7 billion. P.&G. sued Willa over the name, claiming that it was confusingly similar to Wella.

title: Libyan Rebels Clarify Steps to New Rule
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Libyas provisional leaders said Monday that they would resign once the former rebels defeat the vestiges of armed support for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in his home city of Surt, a move that would clear the way for a new interim government that would run the country until elections can be held.

title: Really? The Claim: Yawning Cools the Brain
description: THE FACTS

title: Mayor, Not Recalling Much, Testifies in Consultants Trial
description: Michael R. Bloomberg could not recall when he had decided to pursue a third term as mayor.

title: Government Deepens Investigation of Saturn Ion for Steering Problem
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is a step closer to concluding that General Motors should have recalled 384,000 Saturn Ions in 2010 as part of a larger recall that covered one million Chevrolets and Pontiacs for a steering problem.

title: Has Down Syndrome Hurt Us?
description: Of the growing genre of eloquent parents describing what it takes to raise a child with a disability, Amy Julia Becker is one of the best. She has written often for Motherlode, about how Down Syndrome means life for Penny is different, and exactly the same.

title: Red and Carnage Find New Life Well Beyond Broadway
description: The Tony Award that can reliably boost ticket sales for Broadway shows is the award for best musical: An overwhelming number of theatergoers  about 90 percent  buy tickets to see musicals rather than plays, and a Tony helps folks differentiate among the productions in the running for their ticket money.

title: On Our Radar: Gaping Hole in Arctic Ozone
description: For the first time since record-keeping began, destruction of the ozone layer over the Arctic in early 2011 was comparable to that in the Antarctic ozone hole, scientists report. [Nature]

title: Syrians Abroad Report Harassment and Intimidation
description: At first, Alaa Basatneh kept quiet after receiving a threatening e-mail to her Facebook account in mid-August, worried that it would frighten her parents.

title: Frederick Wisemans Institutional Knowledge
description: From high schools, to state legislatures to boxing gyms, the documentary filmmaker Frederick Wiseman has been exploring the institutions that make the world tick. For his latest film, Crazy Horse, the director takes a look inside the workings of a landmark French strip club that has been operating since 1951. In his survey of documentaries at the New York Film Festival, A. O. Scott called the film a study of artistic process that is itself a work of art, and, as such, a reminder of what a documentary can be. Here, Mr. Wiseman discusses what interests him in the process of making documentaries and what he hopes to convey to his audience.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Anti-Wall Street Protests Spreading to Cities Large and Small
description: A loose-knit populist campaign that started on Wall Street three weeks ago has spread to dozens of cities across the country, with protesters camped out in Los Angeles near City Hall, assembled before the Federal Reserve Bank in Chicago and marching through downtown Boston to rally against corporate greed, unemployment and the role of financial institutions in the economic crisis.

title: E-Mails Reveal Early White House Worries Over Solyndra
description: WASHINGTON  Some White House officials were so concerned last year about the financial health of Solyndra, a solar equipment manufacturer that had received federal loans, that they warned that a presidential trip to the companys California factory could prove a major embarrassment, newly disclosed e-mails show.

title: In New Campaign, a Vodka Promotes Balance
description: It seems sometimes that Madison Avenue is awash in a river of vodka  not in the offices, as in the days of Mad Men, but on the client rosters, as agencies produce more campaigns for more vodka brands.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Ashley Alsup joined TDA_Boulder, Boulder, Colo., in a new post, director for strategy and innovation. She had been group director for cultural and business insights at Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Boulder, part of MDC Partners.

title: Phil Rizzuto, Yankees Shortstop, Dies at 89
description: The sure-handed Hall of Fame shortstop, nicknamed the Scooter, went on to become a beloved broadcaster.

title: Sentence of the Week, Inanimate-Objects Edition
description: The candidates:

title: Patterns: Risks for Preemies Resurface Years Later
description: Babies born prematurely face an increased risk of death in young adulthood, a new study has found, and the more premature the birth, the greater the risk.

title: 6th Anniversary of 9/11 Attacks
description: For the first time in six years, Sept. 11 fell on a Tuesday, the same day the planes flew into the buildings and changed everything.

title: Ravens 20, Jets 13
description: The Jets lost the game but may have found, in quarterback Kellen Clemens and receiver Jerricho Cotchery, the next coming of Chad Pennington and Laveranues Coles.

title: Diggnation, Popular Web Talk Show, to End Its Run in December
description: Together, Kevin Rose and Alex Albrecht are akin to Oprah for a certain class of tech enthusiasts.

title: Citibank Adds Money-Tracking Tools to Online Banking
description: Updated at 2:40 p.m. to add Citibank comment on avoiding monthly checking account fees.

title: How She Does It in Britain
description: Weve talked about the Americanization of the film I Dont Know How She Does It, recently. But how does that shift look from the other side of the Atlantic, where the book was originally set?

title: New From Paris | Pierre Balmain
description: Balmains new diffusion line, Pierre Balmain, made its debut in Paris on Sunday and can best be described as a greatest-hits collection, but at one third of the price. All of the Balmain pieces that weve come to love  black motocross jeans, zebra-print button-down shirts and shrunken leather jackets  came styled in exactly the right model-off-duty way. The mens wear, too, was very rocker-looking, with leather bombers and silky button-down shirts neatly tucked into skinny jeans.

title: Substantial Pastries for Busy Teenagers
description: My son, an eighth grader who has grown six inches in the last year, will not eat lunch at school. Its not about the sandwiches Ive tried to pack, or the school lunches (which I wouldnt blame him for not eating). Nor is it a question of appetite: Hes always hungry. During his 30-minute lunch period he wants to play basketball. If he goes to the cafeteria he doesnt have time to get a game in.

title: Another Helping of Rattlesnake?
description: If you read Sundays Food and Drink issue, you already know what rattlesnake tastes like: sinewy, half-starved tilapia, according to Maud Newton. Check out Mauds follow-up post on her blog to find out what raw rattlesnake looks like (a garden hose made of filleted haddock) and what might be needed to cut it safely (hedge clippers), among other details.

title: A Small Fix for Hypertension: Readers Weigh In
description: Last weeks special issue, Small Fixes, dealt with low-cost health innovations that are saving lives in the developing world. Online, at nytimes.com/smallfixes, readers were invited to come up with a small fix of their own: a device for detecting high blood pressure, which, left untreated, can raise the risk of coronary artery disease, stroke, kidney damage and heart attack.

title: The Caucus | Waiting for Chris Christie
description: Oct. 3, 2011  Governor Christies deliberations as he considers whether to run for president. Also, Governor Perrys campaign faces another challenge, this one on the thorny issue of race.

title: H.I.V.: Quick Follow-Up Testing Increases Rate Seeking Antiretroviral Treatment
description: In low-income countries, as many as two-thirds of those in need of antiretroviral drugs to treat H.I.V. infection never get them. One reason is that after a positive H.I.V. test, many patients never return to the clinic for the next step  a test to determine blood levels of CD4 cells, a measure of immune function essential to deciding whether treatment is needed, and if so, what kind.

title: Caucus Video: Chris Christies Deliberations; Rick Perry and Race
description: A look at Gov. Chris Christies options as he considers whether to run for president. Also, Gov. Rick Perrys campaign faces another challenge, this one on the thorny issue of race.

title: Fourth Tibetan Monk Self-Immolates in Anti-China Protest
description: BEIJING  A young Tibetan monk set himself on fire Monday in a remote western town to protest Chinese policies, the fourth monk from Kirti Monastery to self-immolate this year, according to a Tibet advocacy group based in London.

title: Book on Strauss-Kahn Incident Planned
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn has left New York for Paris, but the story of his sexual encounter with a hotel chambermaid, and the criminal case that developed and then was dropped, is just reaching book publishers. St. Martins Press, part of Macmillan, said on Monday it had acquired a book by John Solomon, the Newsweek reporter who interviewed Nafissatou Diallo, the housekeeper who accused Mr. Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault in May. Mr. Solomons book will report the inside story of how the DSK case was transformed from a slam-dunk, five-day indictment against Strauss-Kahn to a flat-out dismissal that turned the tables on his very accuser, a statement from the publisher said. The charges against Mr. Strauss-Kahn  who called the encounter an error and a moral failure but not a criminal act  were dismissed in August after prosecutors said the accuser lacked credibility.

title: Soon, L Will Mean Less Crowded, Subway Officials Say
description: Want to find a seat on the L train? Head to the back three cars. Avoid peak hours entirely. And if its between 4 p.m. and 6 p.m. on a Saturday, forget it.

title: Riding (Slowly) Through the Heartland
description: WOOSTER, Ohio  Eighteen years ago, when I made my first cross-country bicycle journey, the ride from the Golden Gate Bridge to the George Washington Bridge took 75 days. Sunday was day 75 of my second transcontinental trip, and the distance I have yet to travel from Wooster, Ohio, to Manhattan  470 miles by car, probably another 70 or 80 on a bicyclists more meandering path  is one way to measure how Ive aged. (Another is that my knees are stiff and sore; every morning I feel little like the Tin Man from The Wizard of Oz, pleading squeakily for his oil can.)

title: Silicon Valley II?
description: The underlying assumption of Mayor Michael Bloombergs plan to subsidize a top-flight applied science campus in New York is that New York can replicate the spark that ignited Silicon Valley. Can it?

title: Addressing Some Misperceptions About Mexican Immigration
description: Reading the comments attached to my article today  looking at how todays illegal immigrants are more likely to be people who have roots and families in the United States  I was struck by something that advocates for and against expanded immigration told me while I was reporting: This is a fact-free zone.

title: Disrupters and Adapters, Continued: Will the Internet Save Newspapers?
description: The two visions of higher educations future I described in my column this week  Stanford Professor Sebastian Thruns mission of a virtual university and Stanford President John Hennessys devotion to a flesh-and-blood campus  intrigued me because of the larger context. So much of the debate about the impact of new technology tends to be polarizing. The utopians versus the skeptics, the idealists versus the realists, those who throw themselves headlong into the great mosh pit of the new, and those who cherish the familiar and time-honored.

title: Covered in White Brick, and Showing Their Age
description: Over the decades, white brick buildings  those wedding-cake-shape stalwarts of postwar living  have fallen out of favor and in again among residents, architects and preservationists. Now some of them are falling apart.

title: Airport Pat-Down for Breast Cancer Patient
description: Tightened security at airports has created new problems for medical patients, who may be subjected to embarrassing public pat-downs after imaging machines detect devices or implants related to their health.

title: A Tale of Two Cities Talking
description: On sports talk radio, the N.F.L. is king, even during the baseball playoffs, and even in baseball playoff cities. That may not be quite as true in New York: with two baseball teams, one great and one awful, there is a steady supply of simultaneous gloating and grousing, and the Yankees are perfectly capable of keeping the spotlight away from the Giants and Jets. But drive 90 miles south, or head out to the Midwest, and pro footballs dominance becomes clear: who cares if we won the World Series yesterday, I am calling to demand that we give the backup quarterback a shot!

title: Rescue Aid to Greece Delayed as Pressure Rises for Reforms
description: LUXEMBOURG  Finance ministers from the 17-nation euro zone piled more pressure on Greece early Tuesday by postponing moves to release the next installment of aid and suggesting that more austerity measures were needed.

title: Miracle of Miracles: Sunrise, Sunset Gets a Gay Makeover
description: 12:21 p.m. | Updated  Besides the Chicken Dance and the Electric Slide, one of the songs Most Likely to Be Played at a Wedding, at least for theater fans, is Sunrise, Sunset, a ballad from the 1964 musical Fiddler on the Roof. Sung by Tevye and Golde during their daughter Tzeitels wedding to the tailor Motel, the song is a melancholy look back at how time flies:

title: Artifacts | The Stand-Up, Button-Down Suit
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#963", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: An Addiction Vaccine, Tantalizingly Close
description: SAN DIEGO  Imagine a vaccine against smoking: People trying to quit would light up a cigarette and feel nothing. Or a vaccine against cocaine, one that would prevent addicts from enjoying the drugs high.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.3
description: A view of the day in sports, with indoor baseball and a race by the Egyptian Pyramids.

title: Registration Begins for 9/11 Health Compensation Fund
description: The federal governments September 11th Victim Compensation Fund began taking registrations Monday from people who believe they were physically harmed by the terrorist attacks and who are seeking financial compensation.

title: Article vs. Charticle': Comparing Coverage of a Qaeda Operatives Killing
description: Open any days print edition of The New York Times, and you will see not only various types of news and opinion articles, but also creative ways of presenting content, like infographics. And the Web version enables multimedia and interactive features.

title: Rock Stars Wont Play for Putin
description: MOSCOW  Two popular Russian rock musicians, disillusioned with the presidency of Dmitri A. Medvedev, have said they will not appear at concerts celebrating the presidential election next March, though they performed at a similar event nearly four years ago.

title: Dozens of Arrests Are Reported as Syrian Troops Retake Town
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government said Monday that it had arrested dozens of people in a central Syrian region that has become a flash point in fighting between defectors and security forces waging a brutal crackdown on a six-month uprising.

title: The revenge of the slime molds, readers take a global health challenge and we take a look at pathological altruism.
description: The revenge of the slime molds, readers take a global health challenge and we take a look at pathological altruism.

title: The Roller Coaster Ride Continues for Madoff Investors
description: Investors in the Ponzi scheme perpetrated by Bernard L. Madoff have endured more twists and turns than the Cyclone on Coney Island. Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan delivered an abrupt change in course when he limited the claims that Irving S. Picard, the trustee appointed to oversee the investor claims, could pursue against Saul Katz and Fred Wilpon, the owners of the New York Mets, from their accounts with Mr. Madoffs firm.

title: Drawing Dance: Preparing to Say Farewell
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 14th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Berlin.

title: With Off-Lease Cars, Firm Sees Increase in Odometer Tampering
description: AIM Mobile Inspections, an evaluator of new and used vehicles, said that the incidence of odometer rollback for the purpose of misrepresenting the mileage of off-lease used vehicles had increased by 30 percent since the beginning of this year.

title: Kerry Adviser Becomes a Lobbyist
description: The revolving door between Capitol Hill and K Street swept up another influential name on Monday, as the top foreign policy adviser to Senator John F. Kerry joined Tony Podestas lobbying shop.

title: Dying Forests: How Bad Is It, Really?
description: A year ago, I was sitting in a room overlooking the Pacific Ocean with a man named Ralph Keeling. The son of Charles David Keeling, who had discovered the trend of rising carbon dioxide in the atmosphere in the 1950s, Ralph Keeling had become a famous climate scientist in his own right.

title: Parents and Kids Say They Appreciated Autism-Friendly Lion King Matinee
description: When someone leaves in the middle of a Broadway show, its usually not with smile on their face. But there was Maria Omieh, standing with her children, Joshua, 6, and Shekinah, 5, outside the 1,600-seat Minskoff Theater on Sunday. Ms. Omieh had taken them to a sold-out performance of the musical The Lion King that had been modified for children with autism and their families. She decided to leave during intermission, as did a few other families, but with no regrets.

title: London Underground | Food Market Dining
description: Two recent restaurant projects  one with a life span of just a month, the other a more permanent venture  offer vivid illustrations of the liveliness of Londons current food market scene.

title: Metro Pucks: Ranking the Top Offensive Forwards Among the Rangers, Islanders and Devils
description: There are now nine elite scoring forwards among New York and New Jerseys hockey teams. Two years ago, list-makers would find it challenging to nominate more than one each from the Rangers, Islanders and Devils. Now its an embarrassment of Richards and Tavares and Kovalchuk.

title: A Vaccine for All (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Second-Class Singles (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Tuning Out the Noise (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Circumcision and H.I.V. (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Diamondback Beset With Redemptions, Summer Losses
description: Ever since federal agents stormed into its office late last year, Diamondback Capital Management has been working to stay afloat.

title: Rhapsody to Acquire Napster in Deal With Best Buy
description: Rhapsody, the subscription digital music service, said on Monday that it had signed an agreement to acquire Napster from Best Buy, uniting two cloud music players amid escalating competition in a growing market.

title: On Subsidies, Fish and Fishing
description: A report examining the roughly $8 billion in subsidies that have flowed from the European Union or Spanish taxpayers to Spains fishing fleet since 2000 was published over the weekend by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists.

title: Billy Elliot to Close in January
description: Time to hang up the ballet shoes. The Broadway musical Billy Elliot, the winner of 10 Tony Awards in 2009 and a hot ticket for much of its run, will close on Jan. 8, 2012, after 3 years and 3 months of performances, the producers announced on Monday. The decision to close Billy Elliot came after a somewhat precipitous decline in ticket sales that accelerated through the late spring and summer amid competition from new musicals like The Book of Mormon and Priscilla Queen of the Desert, hit revivals like Anything Goes and How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, and Memphis, the durable recipient of the 2010 Tony for best musical.

title: Talk Therapy Lifts Severe Schizophrenics
description: People with severe schizophrenia who have been isolated, withdrawn and considered beyond help can learn to become more active, social and employable by engaging in a type of talk therapy that was invented to treat depression, scientists reported on Monday.

title: Study Cites Increase in Cancers From HPV
description: Throat cancers caused by a virus transmitted during oral sex have increased significantly in the United States in recent years, researchers reported on Monday.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Stella McCartney
description: Its a bit of a battle, said Pat McGrath backstage at Stella McCartney of making sure that models tan bodies match their often paler faces. Were warming up with the foundation. There wasnt much else required in the way of makeup, save for Covergirls Lushberry creme blush, Lash Perfect mascara and some lip balm. Fresh, beautiful, gorgeous, glowing, young and alive, is how McGrath sees the Stella girl. Spontaneous and real, was Eugene Souleimans description of the designer, which he translated as a bun slicked back at the sides with texture on top. To create this look, he separated a horseshoe of hair all around the head, pulling it back tightly into a ponytail polished with a makeup brush coated in Wella hair spray. The crown was then roughed up with a little of Wellas Refined Texture product. Souleiman explained that sometimes its more difficult to come up with a simple look than, say, one that is high concept. That wasnt an issue today. With Stella, it just kind of happens, he said. Youre never trying too hard.

title: With Furtive Steps, Bloomberg Made His Way to Court
description: All along the sidewalk at the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse and lining the hallways outside the 11th-floor courtroom, the news media horde stood waiting: cameras rolling, flashes poised to pop, shoutable questions on the tips of tongues.

title: N.F.L. Carries NBC in Sunday Night Ratings
description: For one night of the week at least, NBC has little to worry about regarding its broadcast schedule: the National Football League continues to save the network from what has so far been a dismal fall season. The Baltimore Ravens defeated the Jets, 34-17, on Sunday Night Football to give NBC a ratings win in all viewership categories. Final audience numbers were not available on Monday afternoon. CBS finished second over all with new episodes of The Amazing Race and The Good Wife, though the numbers were skewed higher because of N.F.L. coverage overruns across the country. On ABC, Pan Am quickly lost altitude; it averaged 7.75 million total viewers in its second week, down more than 3 million from the series premiere.

title: The Pathological Altruist Gives Till Someone Hurts
description: Some years ago, Dr. Robert A. Burton was the neurologist on call at a San Francisco hospital when a high-profile colleague from the oncology department asked him to perform a spinal tap on an elderly patient with advanced metastatic cancer. The patient had seemed a little fuzzy-headed that morning, and the oncologist wanted to check for meningitis or another infection that might be treatable with antibiotics.

title: Yahoo Has a Crowd, Wants a Voice
description: One company dominates online news, sports and finance. It has more visitors to its news site than the runner-up in the category, CNN, more in sports than ESPN and more in finance than Dow Jones, owner of The Wall Street Journal.

title: How to Steer Toward the Path of Least Treatment
description: The first doctor Lynn Munroe consulted about her hyperactive thyroid gland recommended radioactive iodine treatment to destroy the gland, followed by a lifelong regimen of thyroid hormone replacement pills.

title: Full Tilt Pokers Acquirer Shows His Cards
description: Online poker is not legal in the United States. But it sure is popular.

title: Trading With The Enemy
description: Suppose you were going to write a political-thriller potboiler. You might invent something like this: a family of billionaires who support right-wing causes and pose as super-patriots, while actually using their political influence to cover for wrongdoing on multiple fronts  not just endangering workers and the environment, but even making deals with foreign regimes that are actively anti-United States and sponsor terrorists.

title: Free Trade Standoff Is Resolved
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration moved Monday to complete free trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama, submitting the deals for Congressional approval after resolving a standoff of months with Republicans over the details of a package both sides said they favored.

title: Can Answers to Evolution Be Found in Slime?
description: Most of the aliens that come out of Hollywood dont really look alien at all. They may have pizza-size eyes or roachlike antennae, but their oddities are draped on a familiar humanoid frame.

title: Beauty and the Blob
description: Photographs of the strangely beautiful plasmodial slime molds called myxomycetes.

title: The Daily Shoe | Yves Saint Laurent
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Dictyostelium, Connected and Unconnected
description: Two groups of Dictyostelium are colored red and green. On the left, they share the same Velcro-like hooks and merge into the same slug. On the right, they have different ones and sort themselves out.

title: Wall Street Goes to Sefcon II on Swaps
description: The title of the lead-off panel on Monday at the Sefcon conference, a Wall Street gathering devoted to the relatively obscure world of the swap execution facility, asked a question that most people outside the financial industry would appreciate: What is a S.E.F. and what is it good for?

title: My Three Favorite Musicals
description: My three favorite musicals are not Cabaret or South Pacific or Phantom of the Opera. But instead: Cowgirls, Hedwig and the Angry Inch and Into the Woods. Of the musicals Ive seen over the last two decades, close to 100, these 3 stood out. I saw each show more than once, bought the cast albums and proceeded to play them over and over and over. Hedwig and the Angry Inch and Cowgirls each had a lengthy Off Broadway run but never transferred to Broadway. Into the Woods won Tony Awards when it was first produced in 1988 and when it was revived in 2002. To get a taste of each show, read about them on the Web sites Musical Heaven and The Guide to Musical Theatre and check out the clips below.

title: Hoping to Crack Alzheimers, Together as a Family
description: For the Betancur family, it was a kind of pilgrimage, an act of faith in science.

title: Suspect in Post Office Robbery Is Arrested
description: A man wanted in connection with a post office robbery four years ago fired two gunshots Monday morning at deputy United States marshals who had tracked him down to a house in Jamaica, Queens, a spokesman for the United States Marshals Service said.

title: Autopsies Waning, Except on Television
description: Autopsies are far more common on television than in real life. According to the National Center for Health Statistics, fewer than one in 10 deaths were followed by an autopsy in 2007, compared with one in five in 1972.

title: Yield Of Dreams (Or Rather Delusions)
description: One principle I like to emphasize is that in times of radical change and stress, analytical economics is more rather than less useful than usual. (Or it is if the economist doing it is really trying to make sense of events rather than fitting everything into his ideological preconceptions.) Why? Because in unusual and stressful situations, experience  the kind of experience business people gather over years in the market ceases to be a helpful guide, whereas models and deep historical knowledge have at least a hope of getting at whats really going on.

title: One Point Seven Six
description: The invisible bond vigilantes continue to lure us into their invisible trap.

title: For Beckham, Family and Health Are No. 1 and 1A
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  David Beckham may be 36 years old and nearing the end of a storied professional soccer career, but his often intangible appeal is still strong enough to attract interest from Europe.

title: At Soldier Field, the Faithful Salute Payton
description: At Sundays Bears-Panthers game, there were probably more fans wearing 34s on their backs at Soldier Field than at any point since the mid-80s, wrote Dan Pompei of The Chicago Tribune. The faithful were making a show of support for Walter Payton, enshrined in the Hall of Fame in 1993, dead of a rare liver disease in 1999 and described as a Vicodin-popping, laughing-gas-inhaling adulterer in a book excerpt published last week.

title: Photos of the Moment | Stella McCartney
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#179", 592, 500, true, chameleonData);Sonny Vandeveldes Paris fashion week photo diary.

title: Wall Street's Long History of Protests
description: If there is a physical place that represents the intersection of democracy and capitalism in America, it is Wall Street. Protest movements have been drawn to it since the founding of the country.

title: Wall Streets Long History of Protests
description: If there is a physical place that represents the intersection of democracy and capitalism in America, it is probably in Lower Manhattan at the corner of Wall and Broad. Protest movements have been drawn to Wall Street  both the physical location and the abstract idea  since the founding of the country.

title: Researchers Devise a Method to Meet the Beetles
description: Ambrosia beetles are hard workers. They spend their lives cultivating their food source, fungi, deep inside trees. But the beetles are just as vigilant about their privacy, which has kept their work and social habits largely a mystery to scientists.

title: Anatomy of a Diet (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Over Earthquake in Italy Puts Focus on Probability and Panic
description: The manslaughter trial of six seismologists and a government official in the central Italian city of LAquila, stemming from what the authorities say was a failure to warn the population before a deadly 2009 earthquake, has outraged many scientists. Thousands have signed petitions protesting the prosecution as anti-science.

title: An Infection That Produces a Glazed Look
description: Mark Bowdens Worm is about the potentially diabolical piece of computer malware known as Conficker and the efforts of cybersecurity experts to hunt it down. This book is also about its authors efforts to tell the Conficker story in both technical terms and common parlance. The hype is easy: Worm can toss around alarmist terms like Cybarmageddon and digital Pearl Harbor to convey a sufficient sense of catastrophic threat. But Worm also needs chapters with titles like MS08-067 and Remote Thread Injection to explain what the Conficker scare has really been about.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Greece, California and South Africa

title: Natural Selection Leaves Fresh Footprints on a Canadian Island
description: From parish records in a French-Canadian island, researchers have uncovered what may be the most recent known instance of human evolution in response to natural selection.

title: Frequent Fliers
description: Q. I know fruit doesnt actually generate fruit flies, but how do they find out about a piece of fruit on the counter so quickly?

title: For Giants, the Long View Looks Challenging
description: For as much as players talk about taking it one day at a time, they are (generally) not robots. They know which games are when, same as the fans, and even if they dont mark down the expected wins and losses on a pocket schedule, there is still an awareness of when the team is entering a critical stretch.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Greece, California and South Africa.

description: Just when you start to despair about the art of storytelling, along come Jane Austen and F. Scott Fitzgerald.

description: BAGHDAD  Violence erupted yet again in restive Anbar Province on Monday, as suicide bombers and gunmen disguised as security officers attacked two police headquarters and took hostages.

title: Critics Picks: Man With a Movie Camera
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Dziga Vertovs 1929 film.

title: An Emotional Volcano With a Cool Exterior
description: Every singer, when confronting the songs of Stephen Sondheim, tends to gravitate toward a particular character, song or mood from the composers complex psychological checkerboard. Elaine Stritch pretty much owns The Ladies Who Lunch, that sophisticated blast of rage from Company. In Buddys Eyes, from Follies, more or less defines Barbara Cooks wistful, empathetic warmth. And Move On, from Sunday in the Park With George, distills Bernadette Peterss vulnerable sweetness.

description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#755", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Sonny Vandeveldes Paris fashion week photo diary.

title: Deal Could Mean the End for a Storied Name
description: 9:26 a.m. | Updated A decade ago Napster was the most notorious word in the music business. Now, after nearly a decade attached to a legitimate but struggling service, the name is about to disappear.

title: After Mysterious Delay, Mysterious Approval of Kurdish Advocates Visa
description: Nearly a year ago, Kerim Yildiz, a prominent advocate for Kurdish rights, applied for a business visa to visit the United States. Then he waited. And then he waited some more.

title: All Tomorrows Parties in Asbury Park
description: The local edition of the music festival took place in Asbury Park, N.J., last weekend.

title: McGraw-Hill to Sell Broadcasting Unit to Scripps for $212 Million
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its broadcasting group to E.W. Scripps for $212 million in cash, the latest effort by the conglomerate to reshape itself.

title: Surprise! Lets Dance!
description: At college campuses nationwide, outbursts of seemingly impromptu dance numbers  known as flash mobs  are breaking out.

title: Lessons From the Amanda Knox Case
description: The tragic junior year abroad is over, at long last, for Amanda Knox. And for that, we have to thank an Italian legal system that essentially gives every convicted criminal a do-over  more formally, an appeal before fresh eyes. Bravo for Italy.

title: H.P. Completes Acquisition of Autonomy
TimesCast | October 3, 2011
description: Newly released e-mails show early White House support for a failing solar company; Amanda Knox is freed after her appeal; and Alabama's stringent immigration law causes many Latinos to flee.

description: DUM DUM GIRLS

title: College Flash Mobs Become Pep Rallies Made for YouTube
description: Three steps to starting college: Meet roommate. Unpack in dorm room. Then, sometime during orientation, hear music, see a student start dancing, watch as more dancers join in, and join the campus flash mob. (Or if you miss the actual event, watch it over and over on YouTube, to see how many people you recognize.)

title: A Free-Form Festival, Wide Open to Outsiders
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  All Tomorrows Parties, the music festival that wrapped up its annual local edition here on Sunday night, is built on avoidance. Its a utopian operation; its organizers know the problems with most other music festivals and try to avoid them on principle.

title: As Justices Get Back to Business, Old Pro Reveals Tricks of the Trade
description: WASHINGTON  Justice John Paul Stevens was always courtly, but he could be a little terse and wary in interviews while he was on the Supreme Court. Since his retirement last year, he has shed some of that reticence, and he was in an expansive and reflective mood the other day as he greeted a visitor to his chambers.

title: Lens: Tyler Hicks in Afghanistan
description: Lens: Tyler Hicks in Afghanistan

title: Bengali Spoken Here
description: GOOD Bangladeshi cooking is hard to come by in New York. Though Bangladesh is stamped on many menus, too often these are passports to food from other parts of the subcontinent. The longtime touchstone, Spicy Mina, in Woodside, Queens, went dark last year, supplanted by a Nepali spot that also turns out pizza.

title: American Airlines Bankruptcy Fears Drive Down Stock
description: Shares in American Airlines parent company tumbled 33 percent on Monday on fears that the airline could be forced into bankruptcy as a slowing economy reduced demand for seats on its planes.

title: Getting Through the Security Check With a Gun, Sort Of
description: FLYING is just part of everyday life with me. Im a friendly person, and seatmates seem to like talking to me. Maybe its my Southern accent, but sometimes I think its because they think I have the greatest job in the world.

title: A Choreographer Does One Last Swoop in New York
description: When her teacher in Germany recommended that Isabel Gotzkowsky study at Dance Space Center  now called Dance New Amsterdam  she never thought she would end up staying for 23 years. Before becoming a teacher and choreographer, she was one of the organizations first work-study students. (Her duties included cleaning toilets  a dancers life is seldom glamorous.)

title: Isabel Gotzkowskys New York Finale
description: Ms. Gotzkowsky, who is leaving Dance New Amsterdam after 23 years, presents three works including the premieres of B-Sides and Kafkas Cotillion and the restaging of Bound.

title: Contraceptive Used in Africa May Double Risk of H.I.V.
description: The most popular contraceptive for women in eastern and southern Africa, a hormone shot given every three months, appears to double the risk the women will become infected with H.I.V., according to a large study published Monday. And when it is used by H.I.V.-positive women, their male partners are twice as likely to become infected than if the women had used no contraception.

title: Heroic Tale of Holocaust, With a Twist
description: PARIS  The stories of the Holocaust have been documented, distorted, clarified and filtered through memory. Yet new stories keep coming, occasionally altering the grand, incomplete mosaic of Holocaust history.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Pierre Balmain
description: This latest video by Inez and Vinoodh highlights Pierre Balmain's women's collection, featuring Abbey Lee and her band Our Mountain.

title: Last Week in Food
description: From the With Friends Like These, Who Needs  Department: Heres a look inside the American Dietetic Associations nutrition conference/expo, where youll hear all about how processed foods are an important source of nutrients. Argh. And: In an attempt to undermine the Food and Drug Administrations current efforts to rationalize front-of-package labeling, industry groups have devised a new campaign: change nutrition keys to facts up front. And: Julia Moskin on the new United States Farmers and Ranchers Alliance, a well-funded Big Ag group that is  incredibly  trying to position itself as an underdog in the current food climate. (Apparently it doesnt like the term Big Ag, but when you have $11 million to spend on public relations, and your members include the American Egg Board, the National Milk Producers Federation and the National Pork Board, thats what you are.)

title: Obama Says Hes the Underdog in 2012
description: He aint nothin but an underdog, he says.

title: American Students Supporters in Seattle Cheer Ruling in Italy
description: SEATTLE  In a suite at the Fairmont Olympic Hotel here, a dozen supporters screamed and cried out with joy as they watched an Italian appellate court judge announce that Amanda Knoxs homicide conviction was overturned.

title: Amanda Knox Freed From Jail
description: A court in Italy overturned the convictions of Amanda Knox and a co-defendant on Monday and ordered them freed.

title: A Potential Suitor for Hewlett-Packard
description: Investors unimpressed by Hewlett-Packards dysfunctional governance have sold off shares, leaving the tech company vulnerable to a bid. And Larry Ellisons acquisitive Oracle is a credible potential suitor. A Breakingviews analysis suggests that even while paying a big premium, Oracle could reap a hefty return.

title: TimesCast | Amanda Knox Decision
description: October 3, 2011 - American Amanda Knox is freed after her murder conviction in Italy is overturned.

title: Keep Your Tech Friends Close, but Keep Your Enemies Closer
description: If you are in business, you probably do not spend resources praising your competitor. But then, youre probably also not the chief executive of a large tech company that is competing with the Oracle Corporation.

description: Hewlett-Packard said on Monday that it had gained control of the British software maker Autonomy.

title: Trial to Start in Attempt to Use Bomb Aboard Jet
description: DETROIT  The trial of Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, accused of trying to blow up an airplane in 2009 with a bomb hidden in his underwear, has not yet started, but Mr. Abdulmutallab has already left an impression in the federal courthouse here.

title: U.S. Senate Backs Tough China Trade Moves
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate, seizing on the argument that the American jobs crisis is partly Chinas fault, voted Monday to move forward with tough trade legislation that would impose tariffs on some Chinese goods to punish Beijing for keeping its currency artificially depressed.

description: The Portuguese Finance Ministry has ordered an investigation of Madeiras accounts after unearthing what it called a grave irregularity.

description: October 3, 2011 - Newly revealed e-mails show White House concern for Solyndra's financial health before President Obama's visit.

description: PARIS

title: Parenting From 35,000 Feet Up
description: Working moms and dads, great news from American Airlines: you can go on your next business trip without sacrificing child care! You dont need to be there for your kids in person. You just need a comfy seat on a plane with an Internet connection.

title: N.F.L. Plans Broader Concussion Research
description: WASHINGTON  The N.F.Ls first attempt at a long-range study on the effects of concussions was riddled with problems from the manner in which data was collected to conflicts of interest for those overseeing it. After criticism from outside experts and even members of Congress, the study was shut down by the league in late 2009.

title: The iPhone Could Finally Get Its Personal Assistant
description: In the late 1980s Apple created a mock-up video of a product called the Knowledge Navigator. The Navigator envisioned a future in which tabletlike computers would come with personalassistants that could help people navigate a number of mundane daily tasks.

title: Time for Tebow
description: With the Denver Broncos struggling early in the season, William C. Rhoden has a message for coach John Fox: Start Tim Tebow.

description: Bill Craigshead points us to John Maynard Keynes, celebrating the end of the gold standard:

title: Video: Time for Tebow
description: With the Denver Broncos struggling early in the season, William C. Rhoden has a message for coach John Fox: start Tim Tebow.

title: More On China And Jobs
description: Rob Johnson of INET sends me to an interesting paper by Autor, Dorn and Hanson (pdf) that uses regional data to estimate the impact of China imports on manufacturing employment. The idea is to exploit the major differences among US metro areas in industrial specialization: some areas produce a mix of goods that is in effect in Chinas path, while others dont. The results suggest, as I have been arguing, that its wrong to dismiss Chinese exports as not really being in competition with US production.

title: A Leaders Death Exposes Disarray in the Afghan Peace Process
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the two weeks since the leader of Afghanistans peace process was assassinated, an intense power struggle has opened among the nations ethnic groups  and within them  as well as among other powerful factions here, laying bare a crisis that is buffeting President Hamid Karzai from every side.

title: More Bachmann Staff Members Depart
description: Two more important players are leaving Representative Michele Bachmanns campaign, on top of earlier high-profile departures, adding to the impression of drip-drip-drip troubles facing her candidacy.

title: Airborne, Again
description: And the long haul back to the US tomorrow, or actually today already in Tokyo. Yes, this is what my life is like sometimes. If I post tomorrow  or is it today?  thats because Im a crazy person. (Stop right there).

title: Bloggingheads: Is Herman Cain for Real?
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of the Independent Women's Forum debate Herman Cain's presidential candidacy.

title: Analysis: Tigers 5, Yankees 4, A.L.D.S. Game 3
description: The Yankees season is now in the hands of A.J. Burnett.

title: For Justices First Day Back, a Knotty Case Involving Medicaid Cutbacks
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court started its new term on Monday with arguments in a difficult and consequential case over Californias attempt to cut Medicaid payment rates.

title: Upbeat Projections, With Caveats, for Ad Spending
description: THE attendees of Advertising Week 2011 are being told that despite the woeful economy, there will still be advertising in 2012  and 2013.

title: The Killing of a Qaeda Leader in Yemen
description: To the Editor:

title: American Hotels Embrace Chinese Business Travelers
description: Earlier this year, some 14,000 members of Amway China arrived in waves of 2,800 each for a series of meetings in Anaheim, Calif.  just one example, travel industry professionals say, of a growing number of Chinese business travelers flocking to the United States to meet with potential customers, study American business practices and attend conferences and trade shows.

title: A Significant Ozone Hole Is Reported Over the Arctic
description: Intense cold in the upper atmosphere of the Arctic last winter activated ozone-depleting chemicals and produced the first significant ozone hole ever recorded over the high northern regions, scientists reported on Monday in the journal Nature.

title: Pining for the Days of Airborne Glamour
description: LAST week, after watching the first episode of the much-publicized new television show Pan Am, I called my friend Rene Foss to inquire about her exciting life on the job.

title: Former Yukos Lawyer Dies
description: MOSCOW  Vasily G. Aleksanyan, 38, a Yukos executive and lawyer who was swept up in the politically tinged prosecution of the Yukos oil empire, died at his home in Moscow on Monday after a long illness, Russian news outlets reported.

title: Companies Get New Tools for Calculating Emissions
description: The creators of influential measures of greenhouse gas emissions plan to announce two new tools for corporations on Tuesday.

title: The Kicking Queen
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  In his 18 years at Pinckney Community High School, Jim Darga, the principal, said, the homecoming queen had always been crowned at halftime of the schools football game. Never before, though, had she had to be summoned from the teams locker room.

title: Debate Poses First Big Test for Newcomer in Senate Bid
description: BOSTON  Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard professor who splashed into the Massachusetts Senate race last month after her stint in Washington as a consumer rights advocate, will face off against her lesser-known Democratic opponents Tuesday in a debate that will be an important early test of her skills as a candidate.

title: Ralph M. Steinman, a Nobel Recipient for Research on Immunology, Dies at 68
description: Dr. Ralph M. Steinman, a cell biologist who was named one of three winners of the Nobel Prize in Medicine on Monday for his work on the human immune response, died Friday in Manhattan, a fact unknown to the prize committee when it made its announcement. He was 68.

title: Postseason Pressure a Pleasure to La Russa
description: ST. LOUIS  In the last few days, Tony La Russa, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, has repeatedly invoked the word fun to describe the happenings around his team during its unlikely run to the playoffs.

title: On Wall Street, a Protest Matures
description: I think a good deal of the bankers should be in jail.

title: Before Latest Phone Debut, Apple Has Harsher Competition
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As soon as Apple unveils its highly anticipated new version of the iPhone on Tuesday, millions of people are likely to start plotting how to be among the first to buy it. But millions more may be considering a competitor  an Android phone.

title: The Cronyism Behind a Pipeline for Crude
description: Middlebury, Vt.

title: Confident Burnett Puts Uneven Year Behind Him
description: DETROIT  This may not bring much comfort to the segment of Yankees fandom that covers its eyes whenever A. J. Burnett walks to the mound. On Monday, before a 5-4 loss in Game 3 put the Yankees on the brink of elimination, Burnett summarized his task as the starter for Game 4:

title: When Harry Should Avoid Meeting Sally
description: A philosopher I know told me that once, when he was explaining his views on a contested matter to a group of his peers, he was met with this objection: But that sounds like Stanley Fish. I would bet that no one else in the room had ever met me and that few if any had ever read me. It is just that for many in his corner of the discipline, Stanley Fish is a placeholder for ideas you dont want to be associated with. Saying of someone that he sounds like Stanley Fish is a quick and easy way of refuting him. You might say that it takes the place of an argument or, perhaps, that it is an argument all by itself and one that can be conveniently made in shorthand. (Its not quite ad hominem; its ad hominem backed up by reasons that dont even have to be given.)

title: Report on Medicare Cites Prescription Drug Abuse
description: WASHINGTON  Medicare is subsidizing drug abuse by thousands of beneficiaries who shop around for doctors and fill prescriptions for huge quantities of painkillers and other narcotics far exceeding what any patient could safely use, Congressional investigators say in a new report.

title: Gibson Has One Game to Put End to Two Slumps
description: PHOENIX  Kirk Gibsons gimpy trot and slow-motion arm pump as he circled the bases in the 1988 World Series lives as a memorable highlight. As Gibson spoke in defiant tones Monday about the Arizona Diamondbacks being on the brink of elimination, he created a flashback of sorts to when he shook off injury and delivered that theatrical game-winning home run.

title: Football Beats Baseball in New York and Milwaukee
description: For more than two hours Sunday, viewers in the New York market could choose between watching Game 2 of the Yankees-Tigers league division series and the Giants-Cardinals football game.

title: Judge Allows Trial on Terrorists Challenge to Prison Rules
description: A convicted terrorists First Amendment challenge to rules barring him from almost all communications with outsiders has been allowed to proceed to trial, in a ruling that appears to be a rare setback to the government in cases involving the treatment of high-security inmates.

title: Always Starting, or Ending, Something
description: DETROIT  Detroit Tigers closer Jose Valverde loves to entertain, and is rarely shy about his theatrics on or off the mound.

title: Questions Over Yahoos Value as Buyers Weigh Bids
description: The chief executive of the Chinese Internet company Alibaba, Jack Ma, has breathed new life into the potential bidding for Yahoo, telling a Stanford University audience that he was very interested in the company.

title: Primary Date of Jan. 21 Adds Urgency for Christie
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is under even more pressure to make a decision about running for president after South Carolinas move Monday to schedule its Republican primary for Jan. 21.

title: Momentum Swings Against the Rays
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Three hours before the first pitch Monday, Evan Longoria knelt on the turf near third base at Tropicana Field. It was a prayerful pose, appropriate for the Tampa Bay Rays, who needed a September miracle to make it to the postseason stage.

title: Molycorp Set to Announce a Rare Earth Rediscovery
description: An all-but-forgotten rocky outcropping in Southern California contains ore that could help break the countrys dependence on China for certain types of rare earth metals, according to the only American producer of rare earths.

title: Belgian Minister Tries to Calm Fears Over Financial Group
description: LUXEMBOURG  Belgiums finance minister, Didier Reynders, on Monday sought to calm fears about the fate of the Franco-Belgian financial group Dexia amid concerns over its exposure to Greek debt and reports that the bank could be broken up.

title: Paramount in Court Over a Costly Error
description: LOS ANGELES  If a sloppy deal by Paramount Pictures handed Tommy Lee Jones some extra aces, should movie investors get stung for the jackpot? That question, or something like it, was being debated before Los Angeles County Superior Court judge Mark V. Mooney on Monday, in a case called Marathon Funding vs. Paramount.

title: In West Texas, Wagons Circle Around Perry
description: PAINT CREEK, Tex.  Millions of large rocks litter the hills and the country roads surrounding a hunting and fishing lodge on a sprawling ranch 17 miles outside this tiny West Texas town. But only one of them required a kind of protective custody on Monday.

title: Into the Dark Maze of Election Spending
description: In the end, Mayor Unflappable walked away unflapped.

title: Universities in Scotland to Charge Other Britons
description: EDINBURGH  When Britain decided last December to impose a steep increase in university tuition, Scotland, proud and independent as usual, flatly rejected the idea. Instead, it held firm to its long tradition of virtually free university education.

title: In the Motor City, Success on the Field and Hope Off It
description: DETROIT

title: Ready to Meet, With Start of N.B.A. Regular Season at Stake
description: On the day when training camps were supposed to open, N.B.A. players and owners will gather instead at a Manhattan hotel and try one last time to save the start of the 2011-12 season. There will be more desperation than optimism, and only one point of universal agreement:

title: Offbeat Corporate Giving: A Park Inspired by Peanuts
description: New York City parks come in idiosyncratic shapes and sizes these days, like the High Line, a narrow ribbon of green that unfurls above 10th Avenue, and the future Freshkills Park, with its four monumental mounds.

title: Plea Deal in PTA Theft Case Stalls Over Terms of Restitution
description: A Brooklyn judge refused on Monday to revise a plea offer to a former PTA treasurer accused of embezzling $82,000 from her daughters school, putting her one step closer to going to trial.

title: Fannie Mae Knew Early of Abuses, Report Says
description: Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance giant, learned as early as 2003 of extensive foreclosure abuses among the law firms it had hired to remove troubled borrowers from their homes. But the company did little to correct the firms practices, according to a report issued Tuesday.

title: Battle for Libya | October 3, 2011
description: Libyas transitional leaders named a new cabinet on Monday and vowed to step down after the country is secured.

title: Rodriguez Is Seeking Better Results
description: DETROIT  After the success he had two years ago leading the Yankees to the World Series title, Alex Rodriguez may have thought he had heard his final boos at Yankee Stadium.

title: Justice in Pakistan
