description: There is a rare glimmer of hope from Pakistan. A court on Saturday found Malik Mumtaz Qadri guilty of the assassination of Salman Taseer, the courageous and outspoken governor of Pakistans Punjab Province who was gunned down in January.

title: A Growing Movement to Save Sharks
description: Jaws, an ode to humans fear of the sea, is still a cultural icon. Yet, slowly but surely, cultural attitudes toward sharks are changing, and changing thanks to a genuinely ecological view of their role in the ocean.

title: Losses Turn Up Heat Under Ryans Collar
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When the Jets look around their complex  the locker room, the field house  they are reminded of their duty. They are reminded to play like a Jet, whatever that even means anymore. Their season-opening four-game stretch, dominated by offensive breakdowns and defensive volatility, has muddled the definition, creating a crisis of identity and personality.

title: Tuesday: The Champ Turns the Tables
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  If you have ever been to the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament or seen the documentary Wordplay, you know that the stress level and the tension surrounding the finalists going into the championship rounds is almost unbearable. One little mistake, one square left blank, and the battle is lost. You wouldnt think that a race to finish a crossword puzzle could engender that kind of drama, but it does. And every year, its absolutely riveting.

title: At a Dinner, Exotic Fare and Foul Play
description: Wild goose is on the menu in Dreams of Flying Dreams of Falling, the new play by Adam Rapp that opened on Monday night at the Classic Stage Company, where the Atlantic Theater Company is in temporary residence.

title: Foreign Aid Set to Take a Hit in U.S. Budget Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  Americas budget crisis at home is forcing the first significant cuts in overseas aid in nearly two decades, a retrenchment that officials and advocates say reflects the countrys diminishing ability to influence the world.

title: Turnovers Down, Confidence Up as Giants Put Coughlins Words to Test
description: Finish. Finish. Finish. And do not turn the ball over.

title: Wall Street Protests Spread
description: Protests against Wall Street spread across the country on Monday as demonstrators marched on Federal Reserve banks and camped out in parks from Los Angeles to Chicago to Boston, in a show of anger over the weak economy and perceived corporate greed.

title: Judge Is Asked to Allow Review of Police Dept. Monitoring of Muslim Communities
description: Lawyers in a federal lawsuit that has governed how the New York Police Department investigates political and religious groups for more than 25 years asked a judge on Monday to let them collect information to see if the department had violated his orders in how they monitor Muslim communities.

title: Hooray for Federal Loans!
description: In the firestorm over Solyndra, three main criticisms have emerged.

title: Alabamas Shame
description: Only about 3.5 percent of Alabamas population is foreign-born, according to the Census Bureau. Undocumented immigrants made up roughly 4.2 percent of its work force in 2010, according to the Pew Hispanic Center. But the drafters of Alabamas harsh immigration law wanted to turn their state into the countrys most hostile territory for illegal immigrants. They are succeeding, as many of Alabamas most vulnerable residents can attest.

title: Your Soaring Insurance Premiums
description: Annual premiums for employer-sponsored health coverage soared by 9 percent for families and 8 percent for individuals this year from 2010, far faster than wages or inflation. Republicans, predictably, blamed health care reform for contributing to the rise. In fact, the reforms accounted for only 1.5 percentage points of the increase this year. The value to millions of Americans who are already getting expanded coverage and benefits is undeniable.

title: U.S. Foreign Aid Since 1977
description: As lawmakers trim the national debt, Congress has proposed cutting financing for the State Department and its related aid agencies.

title: In Defense of Romney
description: Over the past several months, Mitt Romney has been an excellent presidential candidate. He has performed superbly in the debates. He has outorganized his rivals. He has relentlessly stayed on his core theme of putting Americans back to work. He has taken Rick Perry apart with a cold ruthlessness that is a wonder to behold.

title: Interim Tunisian Leader With Ties to Old Ruler Defends a Gradual Path
description: TUNIS  As the country that kicked off the Arab Spring prepares for its first free election this month, Tunisias transitional prime minister, Beji Caid Essebsi, has some advice for his counterparts in Egypt, Libya or other former Arab autocracies dealing with impatient public demands unleashed by the revolutions.

title: The Twisting Route Back to Romney
description: This just in: the Iowa caucuses have been moved up significantly, lest the state jeopardize its status as the nations Capital of Disproportionate Political Influence.

title: The Hague: Court Will Investigate War Crimes in Ivory Coast Violence
description: Judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague have given the prosecutor the go-ahead to investigate war crimes in Ivory Coast after the countrys disputed presidential elections last year. The prosecutor has said that both sides in the conflict, the forces backing the ousted leader Laurent Gbagbo and those backing his successor, Alassane Ouattara, had killed civilians and committed other crimes, including rape. Less than a week ago, the new government also formed a Truth and Reconciliation Commission to help establish peace, after the killing of an estimated 3,000 people and the destruction of vast numbers of homes.

title: Whats Your Economic Outlook?
description: Readers shared their expectations about their job status, the future of the economy and the prospects for the next generation.

title: Mexico: Severed Heads Found in Capital
description: Two severed heads were found on a busy highway near the Defense Ministry in Mexico City on Monday, a reminder that the capital has not entirely escaped the violence sweeping large parts of the country. One head was found on the hood of a sport utility vehicle and the other near it on a sidewalk, along with a message from a criminal gang known as the Hand With Eyes, claiming Mexico City as its territory. It was unclear whether the heads were intended to send a message to the military, which has been deployed to fight the drug cartels. Very little cartel-related mayhem has been reported in Mexico City, but a decapitated body was found in another part of the city in August.

title: Lawyer Is Barred From Leaving Iran
description: The Iranian lawyer for two American hikers who were released in September and repatriated after spending more than two years in a Tehran prison on charges of espionage and trespassing has been barred from leaving Iran, he confirmed in a text message. The lawyer, Masoud Shafiei, said authorities had prevented him from boarding an international flight without explanation. His destination was unclear, but the Iranian Student News Agency said he had intended to go to the United States. Last week, security forces raided his home and interrogated him about the Americans, Joshua F. Fattal and Shane M. Bauer, who denounced Iran after they left the country.

title: After Ruling, Hispanics Flee an Alabama Town
description: ALBERTVILLE, Ala.  The vanishing began Wednesday night, the most frightened families packing up their cars as soon as they heard the news.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: October 4
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Rangers Glad They Got Their Man
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

title: Everett Ellin Dies at 82; Helped Computerize Art Catalogs
description: Until the mid-20th century, the worlds greatest artworks were cataloged in shoeboxes. Then along came the computer, and for the first time, museums had a more efficient way to organize their holdings than the boxfuls of dog-eared index cards that had served them for generations.

title: Emanuel Litvinoff, Poet and Detractor of T. S. Eliot, Dies at 96
description: Emanuel Litvinoff, an English-born Jewish poet known for his scathing verse indictment of T. S. Eliots anti-Semitism  and for reading it before an audience that happened to include Eliot  died on Sept. 24 at his home in London. He was 96.

title: California: Governor Signs Law to Protect Circumcision
description: Male circumcision will remain legal throughout California, after Gov. Jerry Brown signed a bill on Sunday that prevents local governments from banning the practice. The measure was drafted in response to efforts in San Francisco and Santa Monica to outlaw circumcision for any males under 18 years old. In San Francisco, supporters of the ban gathered enough signatures to get an initiative on the ballot in November. In July, a Superior Court judge struck the initiative from the ballot, citing state law concerning medical procedures. Supporters of the Santa Monica circumcision ban failed to get the measure on the ballot. Two State Assembly members introduced legislation to prevent any potential circumcision bans  which Jews and Muslims argued violated their free expression of religion  in any other municipalities.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,469 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,783 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Alexander McQueen: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Chanel: Spring 2012 RTW
description: Paris

title: Flat Prices but More Manhattan Home Sales
description: The Manhattan real estate market remained resilient in the last three months, with prices holding steady and sales volume going up, despite the wild gyrations of the stock market over the summer and continued fears of global economic crisis.

title: Proposal Would Create New Accounting Standard-Setter for Private Companies
description: The parent organization of the Financial Accounting Standards Board will propose on Tuesday that a new body be set up to modify accounting rules for private companies, some of which have complained that existing rules are too complicated and costly.

title: Word of the Day | memorialize
description: memorialize \m-mr-e--liz\ verb

title: Season Starting to Slip Away
description: DETROIT  Justin Verlander had done his job, pitching well enough to put his team in a position for a pivotal victory, but the final outcome was still in doubt. It was the ninth inning and Verlander, the Detroit Tigers ace, was out of the game and the closer Jose Valverde was on the mound, pitching to Derek Jeter with runners on first and second in a one-run game.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
description: The leader of the movement to carve a separate state out of Andhra Pradesh rejected Prime Minister Manmohan Singhs plea on Monday to end the ongoing agitation and provide more time to resolve the issue. (The Hindu) K. Chandrasekhar Rao, who had previously gone on a hunger strike in 2009, threatened again to fast to death unless the center came out with a clear-cut announcement mentioning a time frame within which the state of Telangana would be formed. People are dying every day for the cause of Telangana, Rao said.Jammu and Kashmir Chief Minister Omar Abdullah on Monday threatened to sue opposition leader Mehbooba Mufti for claiming he was involved in the death of a party worker (Hindustan Times). In a blistering statement during a swiftly convened news conference, Abdullah said he was ready to appear before the panel probing the matter. The Jammu and Kashmir Assembly adjourned Monday after members swapped abuses (Indian Express).

title: NYT Front Page for 10/04/11
description: NYT Front Page for 10/04/11

title: A Conversation With: Anna Hazare
description: When we arrived in Anna Hazares village, the famous Ralegan Siddhi in rural Maharashtra, late last week, an aide had a curt message for us. Anna-ji, he said icily, was recovering from a long journey the previous day and would not be receiving any visitors.

title: Tigers Verlander Rides His Fastball Past the Yankees
description: DETROIT  Out of the 205 starts Justin Verlander has made in his major league career, he could not remember throwing as hard, or under as much duress, as he did against the Yankees on Monday night.

title: Yankees-Tigers Replay
description: A look back at Game 3 of an American League division series as the Tigers edged the Yankees, 5-3, in Detroit.

title: TimesCast | Crackdown On Immigrants
description: October 3, 2011  Latinos vacate Alabama schools and farms as the states tough new immigration law goes into effect.

title: UBS Expects Modest Profit Despite Trading Scandal
description: The embattled Swiss bank UBS said on Tuesday that it would post a third-quarter profit despite a $2.3 billion loss from unauthorized trades discovered last month.

title: Gunmen Attack Shiites on Bus in Southwest Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Gunmen opened fire on a bus in southwestern Pakistan on Tuesday, killing at least 13 Shiite Muslims and wounding seven, officials said.

title: Group Urges Research Into Aggressive Efforts to Fight Climate Change
description: With political action on curbing greenhouse gases stalled, a bipartisan panel of scientists, former government officials and national security experts is recommending that the government begin researching a radical fix: directly manipulating the Earths climate to lower the temperature.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 4, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, Maine City Casts Off Spurned Sculpture.

title: Greeces Economic Turmoil
description: WHO comprises the troika that has kept Greeces economy afloat?

title: News Quiz | October 4, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Tyler Hicks: A Decade in Afghanistan
description: OBSERVATION POST TWINS, Afghanistan  There are places and times where the politics that drive wars fade and then fade more, becoming abstractions to the people who fight or who are in a fights way. And there are moments when politics entirely disappear, and more elemental actions and emotions replace them.

title: Should Schools Offer Cash Bonuses for Good Test Scores?
description: As part of the National Math and Science Initiative, some high schools have opened up their Advanced Placement courses to all students, and those who score a 3 or higher on the A.P. exam earn a $100 reward, as do their teachers. What do you think of financial incentives to perform well in school? Would you study harder if there were a cash bonus attached to a good grade?

title: As Amanda Knox Heads Home, the Debate Is Just Getting Started
description: ROME  At least one thing was clear Tuesday as Amanda Knox headed home to the United States after an Italian court threw out the convictions of Ms. Knox and Raffaele Sollecito, a former boyfriend, in the 2007 murder of her housemate in Perugia. The case had lost none of its power to polarize.

title: Prague Synagogue Hosts Show on the Citys Jewish Community
description: A new permanent exhibition chronicling the elusive history of Pragues Jewish community, from the end of World War II until now, recently opened in an appropriate venue: the citys ornate Jubilee Synagogue (Jeruzalemska 7).

title: The Early Word: Waning
description: Todays Times

title: Misrepresentations, Regulations and Jobs
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

title: In Massachusetts, a Hoarder With Discriminating Tastes
description: For last weekends Auto Ego article, Charles Gould, a lawyer in Newton, Mass., gave me a tour of his collection of more than 100 cars, trucks and motorcycles.

title: Q&A: Sorting Subscriptions in Facebook
description: Q.

title: Looking for the Big Taste of Bengal
description: Sleepy, slow Kolkata comes to life in the 10 days of Durga Puja, or simply Pujo, the festival celebrating the Hindu goddess Durgas slaying of the demon Mahishasur, which started this year on Sept. 27.

title: Dalai Lamas Visa Request Is Denied by South Africa
description: NEW DELHI  The Dalai Lama, Tibets exiled spiritual leader, scrapped plans on Tuesday to attend the 80th birthday celebration of a fellow Nobel laureate, Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa, after the host government did not grant his visa request.

title: High School Entrepreneurs Promise to Save Millions for Schools
description: Founded in January, TruantToday is a messaging service that alerts parents instantly via text and e-mail message when students cut class. The goal? Reducing truancy and restoring state and federal financing to school districts, which can lose as much as $50 each day that a student is missing.

title: France and Belgium to Guarantee Dexia
description: PARIS  France and Belgium moved on Tuesday to shore up Dexia as fears increased that the banks exposure to Greek sovereign debt could lead to its collapse.

title: An Interview With Clare Waight Keller
description: Suzy Menkes, fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune, speaks with the designer Clare Waight Keller about important inspirations in her first collection for Chlo.

title: A New Standard for Carbon Footprints
description: In an article in Tuesdays Times, I write about new protocols that have been developed to help companies measure their greenhouse gas emissions. The goal is to guide them in tallying emissions across the entire life cycle of a product and the value chain of a corporation. (Thats company-speak for the emissions resulting from gathering the raw materials for the product, using the product and eventually disposing of it.)

title: Truck Bomb Kills Dozens in Somalias Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  This particular area of Mogadishu was supposed to be safe, a highly fortified government compound in one of the few neighborhoods that Somalias transitional government actually controls.

title: Deutsche Bank to Miss Profit Goal
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank, Germanys biggest lender, joined a growing list of banks buffeted by the sovereign debt crisis on Tuesday, saying it would not meet its 2011 profit target owing to investor uncertainty and a loss from its Greek bond holdings.

title: Slain Students Family Hopes Facts Will Emerge
description: PERUGIA, Italy  One day after an Italian appeals court overturned the conviction of Amanda Knox, one of three people convicted in the 2007 murder of 21-year-old Meredith Kercher, members of Ms. Kerchers family said on Tuesday that they still hoped that the facts about her death would emerge.

title: In Deal With Ford, Union Wins Wage Increases and Additional Jobs
description: DETROIT  After winning promises of thousands of new jobs and bonuses for active workers at the Ford Motor Company, the United Automobile Workers union now turns to Chrysler to wrap up its epic contract talks with Detroits major automakers.

title: Christie Faces Conservative Criticism as He Decides on Run
description: As Chris Christie makes up his mind about whether to run for president, he is no doubt listening to the effusive praise from donors and activists and leading Republicans.

title: Different but Brilliant: Wes Welker and Calvin Johnson
description: There may not be two more distinctly different players in the league, but somehow, they play the same position.

title: Back at Home, a Marine Must Battle His Injuries
description: Unlike earlier generations of injured veterans, American soldiers who have been wounded in Iraq or Afghanistan have received quite a bit of attention. In print and on television the accounts of their attempts to recover from lost limbs and head trauma have been told and retold, accompanied by images that were startling at first but are less so now. Even Dolphin Tale, a film aimed at young children, has a subplot involving wartime injuries.

title: Yves Saint Laurent: Being a Spectator
description: In all of Stefano Pilatis collections for Yves Saint Laurent there are characters who, in ruffles and Belle de Jour uptightness, come close to representing the YSL woman, yet never quite nail her. Mr. Pilati has done some interesting collections, one or two genuinely weird ones, and some that qualified as modern. Thats not such a bad track record in seven years, but unfortunately Mr. Pilati is stuck with a label that in public perception is somewhere between a tasty bonbon and a hallowed shrine.

title: Cooling Problem Shuts Nuclear Reactor in Japan
description: TOKYO  In a fresh blow to public confidence, a reactor in southern Japan went into automatic shutdown on Tuesday because of problems with its cooling system, clouding the outlook for an imminent restart of the countrys idled nuclear plants.

title: Immigrants Play Key Role as City Entrepreneurs, Study Finds
description: Any taxi-riding, bodega-shopping, laundromat-using New Yorker knows that immigrants own many of the businesses that make New York tick. Now a new study shows that while immigrants constitute just over a third of the citys population, they make up nearly half of the citys small-business owners.

title: Studies of Universes Expansion Win Physics Nobel
description: Three astronomers won the Nobel Prize in Physics on Tuesday for discovering that the universe is apparently being blown apart by a mysterious force that cosmologists now call dark energy, a finding that has thrown the fate of the universe and indeed the nature of physics into doubt.

title: Romney Plans Foreign Policy Speech
description: Mitt Romney will deliver a foreign policy speech on Friday in Charleston, S.C., he announced Monday afternoon on Sean Hannitys radio show.

title: Like Putin, Like Bloomberg
description: Political ploys under way in Russia could almost serve as an instruction manual for the leadership at either end of New Yorks City Hall. You have to slap your forehead in wonder that the New Yorkers didnt think up comparable high jinks for themselves.

title: Why Atheists Need Fundamentalists
description: Ive written before about the interesting symbiosis that exists between militant atheism and religious fundamentalism  the way the Richard Dawkinses of the world are always eager to insist that a cartoonish figure like Pat Robertson represents the truest form of Christian faith, and that any believer who disagrees with Robertsons pronouncements on Haiti or Hurricane Katrina obviously doesnt understand his own religion.

title: Promoting More Visits Between Korea and New York
description: Hoping to increase the number of visitors to New York City during the usually slow period after the December holidays, the citys tourism agency announced a partnership with the city of Seoul and Korean Air on Tuesday.

title: Thailand in Technicolor
description: Officially, the designer Thakoon Panichgul (above left), of Thakoon, is an adviser to Thailands ministry of commerce. But this summer he put business aside and spent two weeks looking for inspiration in the countrys northern mountain villages near Chiang Mai. He found it in the bright, hand-woven and embroidered silk and cotton ikats of the Karen and Lua tribes  a vibrant palette similar to the saturated red, turquoise, mustard and pink yarns in his recent spring collection. There is something so special about these communities of grandmothers, Panichgul says. Its really a dying art. Each tribes ikat pattern is based on memory.

title: Geoengineering? Time to Wake Up, Panel Warns
description: With political action on curbing greenhouse gases stalled in Congress, Cornelia Dean reports that a panel is recommending that the government begin researching the possibility of directly manipulating the Earths climate to lower the temperature. The Bipartisan Policy Center, which created the panel, plans a webcast discussion on the idea at 10 E.D.T. on Tuesday.

title: This Just In: Study Shows Songs About Sex Are Hot Sellers
description: Psychologists sometimes have a way of proving what you always suspected was true. A recent study of popular song lyrics done at the State University of New York in Albany shows not only that messages about sexual relationships dominate the songs at the top of the charts, but also that songs about sex sell better than other songs.

title: Tuesday Reading: Using the Net Wisely in a Health Crisis
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Stocks Rally After Report Europe Might Recapitalize Banks
description: A late frenzy on Wall Street led stocks to a sharp increase on Tuesday, even as fears over a major banking crisis in Europe mounted along with expectations that Greece could soon default on its debt.

title: Christie to Make 1 P.M. Announcement
description: Chris Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, has scheduled a 1 p.m. news conference for Tuesday afternoon in Trenton to announce his decision about a possible presidential run.

title: From Hibbing, Minn., a Plea for Planes to Keep Flying
description: Delta Airlines recently announced that it would probably drop or reduce commercial air service to 24 smaller cities in the United States because the flights are often half-full  or even less  and lose millions of dollars a year. Delta, under an agreement with the federal government, is the only carrier to serve the cities, which rely on the flights to stay connected to the rest of the country. Without the service, they fear isolation, and in some cases, economic calamity. Butte, Mont.; Muscle Shoals, Ala.; Waterloo, Iowa; Pierre, S.D.; Greenville and Tupelo, Miss.; Sault Sainte Marie, Mich.; and Hibbing, Minn., are among the cities where the flights are threatened. Residents of Hibbing, population 16,000, and the heart of Minnesotas Iron Range  where iron-ore mining is the predominant industry  are particularly concerned. The citys mayor, Rick Cannata, and Patty Shafer, a city councilor, discuss:

title: Doctors Grow Wary of Avastin for Eye Treatment
description: Dr. Robert Feig, a retina specialist in Brooklyn and the Bronx, says he wants to save patients and Medicare money by treating eye diseases with a drug that costs $50 a dose, rather than one that costs $2,000 a dose.

title: Queen of the Football Field
description: Four decades ago the federal education law called Title IX opened the door for girls to participate in high school and college athletics. But even the creators of that landmark legislation probably didnt imagine the homecoming queen kicking the winning field goal.

title: Morning T | Michel Gaubert
description: Ts Online Editor Jane Herman talks to the sound illustrator Michel Gaubert about soundtracking fashion shows, finding music to match the height of a heel and why hes always wearing sunglasses.

title: A Strange Lesson From Renaissance Learning
description: Something weird is happening in Wisconsin.

title: Q&A: An Autumn Trip to Edinburgh
description: My sister, 82, and I, 65, are visiting Edinburgh in late October to visit her granddaughter who is studying at the university. We have visited before and have seen the major sights. Can you give suggestions for off-the-beaten-track treasures and treks? We both love history and share the maiden name of Duncan  so anything that links us to the homeland is a lure. We recognize the weather will probably be challenging, but we are intrepid!

title: Oct. 4, 1957 | Soviet Union Launches Sputnik Satellite
description: On Oct. 4, 1957, the Soviet Union put the first artificial satellite, Sputnik I, into the Earths orbit, signifying the birth of the Space Age. The spherical satellite, which was about the size of a beach ball and weighed 184 pounds, was able to orbit the Earth in 98 minutes.

title: Leading Off: Panic in Yankeeland
description: For those outside the greater New York and Boston rooting areas, the past week has been an extended festival of great amusement. First, we got to watch an overflow of Red Sox panic, which is unlike any other kind of panic in its gloom and reverberating echoes of Bill Buckner, and now we get full-on Yankees panic. Just a week after they seemed to rule the universe as the Red Sox suffered through their epic collapse, the Yankees are down, two games to one, to the plucky Tigers and facing an elimination game pitched by  and heres where the real panic comes in  A.J. Burnett.

title: Model-Morphosis | Sigrid Agren at YSL
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Sigrid Agren from Ford Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: The Readers Lament
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: The Readers Lament
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: What Were Reading
description: The Gurgling Cod: The fautisanal trend in food gets a dressing down.  Julia Moskin

title: Some Loans Go Bad; Others Just Fade Away
description: As my colleague Eric Lipton and I report in Tuesdays paper, the Obama administration was divided early on over the loan guarantee to Solyndra, the solar equipment manufacturer that took $528 million in federal money before it filed for bankruptcy in September.

title: The NFL Network and Time Warner Continue to Spar
description: Karen Waldkirch, a freelance writer in Wauwatosa, Wis., owns shares in the Green Bay Packers and buys season tickets to their games at Lambeau Field.

title: Wheelies: The Fraternit Edition
description: 1:06 p.m. | Updated

title: Galaxy Visit Red Bulls Looking to Clinch Top Record
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  A flash of brilliance by Thierry Henry on Saturday night in Toronto did not save the Red Bulls season as much as preserve it for yet another must-win game.

title: Brother of Jailed Chinese Dissident Reports Prison Visit
description: BEIJING  Three brothers of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned dissident writer who was given the Nobel Peace Prize last year, were allowed to visit him in a prison in northeast China on Sept. 28, one of the brothers told Agence France-Presse on Tuesday.

title: Transcript of Bloombergs Testimony at the Haggerty Trial
description: The testimony provided by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at the trial of a political consultant, John F. Haggerty Jr..

title: Now Is Not My Time to Run, Christie Says
description: 1:30 p.m. | Updated Saying now is not my time, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey announced on Tuesday that he would not seek the Republican nomination for the presidency.

title: Morning T | Michel Gaubert
description: The sound illustrator Michel Gaubert on how he finds an apt soundtrack for fashion shows.

title: Photos of the Moment | Chlo
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Bernanke Urges Obama and Congress to Do More for Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, told a Congressional committee Tuesday that lawmakers and the Obama administration should do more to increase economic growth.

title: Reviewing Neerob
description: Lately, lovers of Bangladeshi cuisine, which hums with a vibrant undercurrent of mustard oil, have been trekking to a modest restaurant in the Parkchester neighborhood of the Bronx. Bengali is the lingua franca at Neerob, the subject of this weeks $25 and Under column, but English is a viable fallback. Its essential, though, to bring along an adventurous attitude, and it wouldnt hurt to like fish.

title: A Films Clear-Eyed Look at the War in Afghanistan
description: Hell and Back Again, a visceral documentary by Danfung Dennis about the war in Afghanistan, opens in Manhattan on Wednesday. In his review for The New York Times, Neil Genzlinger writes that the films unvarnished and ambiguous nature makes it more disturbing than some of the more prepackaged and sanitized efforts to relay the graphic realities of war.

title: In Europe, Signs of 2nd Recession With Wide Reach
description: PARIS  The European debt problems that have roiled global financial markets for the last 18 months are showing signs of turning into a far deeper challenge: Europes second recession in three years.

title: Chopping Down Trees to Save Forests
description: Jim Pitts stood on a Forest Service road near the Arizona town of Nutrioso and surveyed the damage in the valley below. It was July, and only a few weeks earlier the Wallow Fire, the largest in recorded history in Arizona, had swept through this section of steep slopes and tightly packed trees.

title: DJ Shadow Talks About His Latest Sonic Collages
description: DJ Shadow has lived for 15 years in the shadow of his own success. The San Francisco disc jockey has put out just three full-length albums since the critically acclaimed Endtroducing in 1996, which helped define the then cutting-edge genre of instrumental hip-hop: dance music with symphonic sweep built from scores of samples dug out of eclectic and often obscure recordings.

title: Runway In Review
description: ChloDesigner: Clare Waight KellerDate and Location: Monday, Oct. 3, Espace Ephemere Tuileries, Jardin Des Tuileries, 1erPhotos: slide show

title: Nick Brandts African Vistas
description: Brandts Portraits of Wildlife and Landscapes in Africa

title: Broadway State of Mind: Alicia Keys to Compose Music for Stick Fly
description: When Alicia Keys goes Broadway, she really goes Broadway. Over the summer it was announced that Ms. Keys, the pop-R&B singer and Empire State of Mind vocalist, would be a producer of the coming Broadway play of Stick Fly, Lydia R. Diamonds drama about a well-to-do black family on Marthas Vineyard.

title: Loving Your Childs Differences
description: As a new mother I somehow assumed I knew every thought my son had. Then he started to develop opinions of his own.

title: Apple Unveils iPhone 4S With Voice-Recognition Features
description: Tech journalists descended upon Apples headquarters in Cupertino, Calif., on Tuesday for some iPhone-related announcements. Our updates from the event are below, with the most recent at the top.

title: This Little Pinkie
description: Once confined to a fat cats finger, todays pinkie rings are dainty, pretty and made for a lady. See more >>

title: Open Cup Final: Seattle vs. Chicago
description: One of the oldest athletic competitions in the United States is also one of the most obscure and ignored.

title: City Agencies Are Told to Cut Costs by $2 Billion
description: Citing a grim economic outlook and dimming prospects for state and federal aid, the Bloomberg administration on Tuesday asked city agencies to pare $2 billion from their budgets over the next 18 months.

title: They Said It Had Good Bones
description: If you like the jar with the babys leg, wait until you see the jar holding the babys head. If one actress with Down syndrome doesnt provide enough Tod Browning-style otherness for you, dont worry  there are two. If the line about snorting cocaine off a high school girls nipples doesnt do it for you, maybe the scene of the sobbing naked man masturbating will.

title: Puerto Rico Prodded to Get Tough on Police
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  The discrepancies in the Puerto Rico police logs were hard to miss. Burglaries, including stolen plasma televisions and jewelry, were coded as mere breaking and entering. Large-scale thefts of telephone company cables were labeled property damage.

title: Obama Campaign Takes Jobs Fight to Twitter
description: President Obamas campaign is trying to harness the power of Twitter to put pressure on Republican lawmakers to pass his jobs bill, according to a campaign official.

title: South Bronx Rising
description: The South Bronx is being revitalized. Michael Kimmelman, the architecture critic of The New York Times, tours the area with Amanda Burden, the director of the department of city planning.

title: At Chanel, Everything but a Mermaid
description: Chanel transformed the Grand Palais on Tuesday into an all-white seafloor, with pebbles, giant stingrays, coral reefs and the singer Florence Welch emerging from a clamshell to sing us a song. But, as Karl Lagerfeld said, volubly pleased with himself, no mermaids.

title: Democrat Wins West Virginia Governors Race
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin, a Democrat, narrowly won a special election for governor on Tuesday, successfully defending himself against Republican attacks that tried to link him withPresident Obama and his health care overhaul.

title: Christie Decides Against Presidential Bid
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has decided not to seek the presidency, citing a promise he made to his states voters when he took office 20 months ago to fix a broken New Jersey. The decision ends a late flurry of indecision on the part of Mr. Christie, who had been encouraged by a growing number of Republican donors and activists who hoped he join the field of candidates vying to challenge President Obama. Read (and comment on) the full story on The Caucus.

title: Another View: Bernanke Ups the Ante
description: Mark Spitznagel is the founder and chief investment officer of Universa Investments, a hedge fund based in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Europe Raises Concerns About NYSE-Deutsche Brse Merger
description: 7:35 p.m. | Updated

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: For the Long Brothers, a Shared Passion for Wheeled Speed
description: Patrick Long, the American Le Mans Series GT2 driver, and his younger brother Kevin Long, a professional skateboarder, are elite competitors in their respective wheeled pursuits.

title: U.S. Senates Bill on Tariffs Angers China
description: China expressed strong objections on Tuesday to a bill in the United States Senate that would threaten higher tariffs on some Chinese goods in response to what the bills sponsors call Chinas policy of keeping its currency artificially depressed to give its exports a price advantage.

title: Reviewing Tertulia
description: Reviewing Tertulia

title: Hamming It Up at Chatou
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#2", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: The Frugal Traveler in Litchfield County, Conn.
description: Watching the season change in Litchfield Countys small towns doesnt have to break the bank.

title: Turkey Detains 140 in Inquiry on Kurds
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish police detained more than 140 pro-Kurdish political activists in a nationwide sweep on Tuesday, including a number of elected mayors in Turkeys predominantly Kurdish southeast.

title: The Neon Lights Are Bright on Proskauer
description: Superlatives abound at New Yorks corporate law firms.

title: Another Immigration Misconception
description: Yesterday I addressed three misconceptions swirling around immigration and the latest story in our series, Immigration Upended, but one question seems to keep arriving in my inbox and Twitter feed: Why not just go after employers? If businesses can be regulated and punished into keeping their payrolls free of illegal immigrants, wouldnt that solve the illegal immigration problem?

title: Redfin Backs Off Some Agent Home-Sales Data
description: Just days after it introduced a tool that lets users search for real-estate agents by name and view their home-selling success statistics, the Web site Redfin backed out of some markets, after getting complaints from local multiple listing services about the use of some data.

title: Litchfield County, Easy on the Wallet
description: A Js Steak and Pizza might be intimidating, I was told  kind of a bikers bar. But the burgers were cheap and good, the peanuts were free, the place was still open and it was right down the road from the room where I had just dropped my bags.

title: Bank of America Web Site Still Troubled
description: 3:01 p.m. 10/5/11 | Updated  with banks statement.

title: A Gun, Dont Look at My Face, and Then They Hit the Safe
description: Before he could react, George Bardwil had a gun pointed in his face.

title: A Threat of Recession in Europe
description: Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain are already in downturns or fighting to escape them, as high unemployment and austerity measures hit. And now, Germany and France, the Continents powerhouses, have also started to falter as banks tighten lending and business activity slows.

title: Photos of the Moment | Chlo
description: Kava Gornas Paris fashion week photo diary.

title: Milestones: Solyndras Meltdown
description: In August 2011, after receiving over $500 million in federal loan guarantees, Solyndra, a solar panel manufacturer, declared bankruptcy. The companys collapse has renewed the debate in Washington over the stimulus program and clean energy subsidies.

title: Propane Powers Patrol Cars in North Carolina
description: Thanks in part to confiscated drug money, criminals in Iredell County, N.C., may catch a ride in a patrol car powered by liquid propane.

title: National Spotlight on Christie Misses a State Full of Troubles
description: TRENTON  New Jerseys Big Man has peered into the right-wing abyss that is the Republican presidential primary and stepped away.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.4
description: A view of the day in sports includes polo on the beach and an interesting method for powering a long boat at a traditional rowing contest.

title: NBC Replaces Playboy Club with Rock Center
description: NBC, reacting quickly to the collapse of its Monday night drama, The Playboy Club, announced a series of programming moves Tuesday, led by the cancellation of that 10 p.m. show and the addition of a newsmagazine hosted by its main news anchor, Brian Williams.

title: With Christie Out, Republican Race Begins for Real
description: WASHINGTON  Memorandum to Republican activists, voters and donors: Your presidential field is set. Its time to start sizing up the candidates, learning to love at least one of them and preparing to head toward the voting booth.

title: Slow Days at Wagawaga
description: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

title: Packers? Patriots? How About Madonna as a Super Bowl Contender?
description: Madonna and the National Football League are discussing a deal under which the pop diva would perform at halftime during the Super Bowl in February, but the details have yet to be ironed out, a person familiar with the talks said.

title: Clifford Olson, Canadian Serial Killer, Is Dead at 71
description: When the Canadian police began connecting the dots in a series of child abductions and torture-murders in the summer of 1981, Clifford Olson, a career criminal with a history of sexual assaults, was placed on a list of potential suspects. It was a good hunch, as it turned out.

title: Asked & Answered | Johnny Wujek
description: Johnny Wujek is one of a new breed of stylists who are becoming as well known as their celebrity clients  in his case the pop star Katy Perry. Since the early I Kissed a Girl days, Wujek has been pulling the strings behind Perrys playful and sexually provocative image, including the cupcake bras and whipped cream bikini for the Candy Land-themed California Gurls video. Its all part of being a pop star, says Wujek when asked whether he feels Perrys look is appropriate for a younger audience. Just look at Madonna, Prince or Michael Jackson, who all have had such emblematic and often controversial styles.

title: Los Angeles Orchestra to Lead Youth Effort
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic has seized the initiative in guiding a national teaching program based on El Sistema, the Venezuelan-based movement that weds music teaching and social work. The orchestra announced on Tuesday that it would open an office, host yearly conferences and support a training program to sustain the effort.

title: Opting Out of Race, Christie Says, Now Is Not My Time
description: After a kinetic month in which some of the biggest names in American industry and Republican politics urged him to run for president, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spent a quiet weekend at home, coming to a sobering conclusion on Tuesday: Now is not my time.

title: Disappointing Songwriters, Supreme Court Rejects Music Appeal
description: In a victory for online music companies, the Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal in a case that could have resulted in increased royalties for digital music. The decision let stand a lower courts ruling that downloading a song does not constitute a public performance of it, clarifying a technical but important distinction about the way songwriters and music publishers are paid.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Human Rights Since 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Nick Brandt Redo
description: Nick Brandt Redo

title: Losing the Family Car
description: One of the more memorable posts on Motherlode was Corbyn Hanson Hightowers account of dumpster diving to feed her family. What struck so many of you were not the facts of her life  losing a six-figure job, running through her savings, supporting her family by cleaning houses and finding food where she could. What most of you talked about was her tone, her spirit, as she described that fall. She had no apologies for her missteps, and she was determined that in spite of her current straits, that she eat well. Is organic food, you wondered, an entitlement? Is it worth slogging through the trash?

title: Dispute Over Simpsons Actors Salaries Could Halt Series
description: As The Simpsons character Troy McClure once asked about that popular Fox cartoon family, Who knows what adventures theyll have between now and the time the show becomes unprofitable?

title: My Three Favorite Songs That Peaked at No. 2
description: With apologies to some classic runners-up, like Like a Rolling Stone, Dancing in the Street and Proud Mary, here are three of the best:

title: Networks Joust for Ratings Title on Mondays
description: A role reversal is taking place between ABC and CBS on Monday nights that is most certain to have some longtime industry observers doing a double take.

title: IPhone Gets Its Upgrade, All Under the Hood
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Apple introduced its long-awaited new iPhone on Tuesday. But it wasnt an iPhone 5. That will have to wait.

title: Madoff Victims Set to Get First Payments
description: 8:23 p.m. | Updated

title: Britain and European Union Agree on Regulating Derivatives Trades
description: 7:29 p.m. | Updated

title: To Spain, by Way of the World
description: SEAMUS MULLEN, a bearish young Vermont-raised chef with a sleeve of tattoos, was standing in the back of Tertulia last week, smiling damply in the heat and smoke of his open kitchen, as a wood fire crackled beside him and waiters in handsome plaid shirts dodged this way and that.

title: Rangers Waive an Agitator Who Stirred Up Opponents and Headlines
description: The latest chapter for one of New Yorks most colorful and controversial professional athletes may have ended Tuesday when the Rangers placedSean Avery on waivers.

title: Reviewing Tertulia
description: This weeks restaurant review  took me to Tertulia, the chef Seamus Mullens new Spanish gastropub in the West Village. Have you been? An acquaintance of mine compared the experience to that of a sports bar serving excellent chicken wings, and declared it useless for all those over the age of 45.

title: A Threat of Recession in Europe
description: Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain are already in downturns or fighting to escape them, as high unemployment and austerity measures hit. And now, Germany and France, the Continents powerhouses, have also started to falter as banks tighten lending and business activity slows.

title: Identity Theft Site Aims to Sort Through Hype
description: Identity theft is an anxiety-provoking topic, and one that seems to spawn a lot of hype and misinformation. To help both consumers and businesses sort out fact from fiction, the Consumer Federation of America has opened a new Web site, idtheftinfo.org.

title: The N.R.C. Goes Social
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission established a YouTube channel  last month. It has a Twitter account, @NRCgov, and since January it has had a blog. On Tuesday it took the next step: the chairman, Gregory B. Jaczko, hosted an online session with more than 50 bloggers, most of them pro-nuclear. He is supposed to do it again on Thursday, with anti-nuclear bloggers.

title: Illinois Democrat to Step Down in 2013
description: Representative Jerry F. Costello, Democrat of Illinois, announced Tuesday that he would step down at the end of his term in 2013.

title: Mets to Reduce Season-Ticket Prices for 2012
description: In the wake of another sizable drop in attendance, the Mets have announced that they were again cutting ticket prices.

title: House Approves Spending Bill Passed by Senate, and Government Shutdown Is Averted
description: WASHINGTON  With limited discussion and zero fanfare, the House on Tuesday approved and sent to President Obama a measure to keep the government operating through mid-November, ending for now the threat of any shutdown.

title: Trial Opens for 7 Kosovars in Organ-Trafficking Case
description: PRISTINA, KOSOVO  The trial of seven Kosovars accused of participating in an international organ trafficking ring opened here Tuesday.

title: Film Festival | Documentaries for Hispanic Heritage Month
La Russa Is Fined for Criticism of Umpire
description: ST. LOUIS  Cardinals Manager Tony La Russa, who was fined an undisclosed amount by Major League Baseball for criticizing an umpire during a live interview on national television, offered some words of contrition before Game 3 of the teams National League division series Tuesday.

title: How Bondholders Would Fare in a Countrywide Bankruptcy
description: Over the past weeks, it has become quite common to speculate that Bank of America might solve its Countrywide problem by putting the mortgage unit into bankruptcy to escape some liabilities and litigation losses. Bloomberg News has reported on the idea, and so has Dealbooks Deal Professor.

title: Live Blog: Woman Dies in Helicopter Crash in East River
description: A helicopter crashed into the East River off 34th Street at 3:22 p.m. on Tuesday, killing a woman passenger and injuring three other passengers, at least one of them critically, the authorities said. The pilot escaped unharmed.

title: Exit Christie
description: Though I urged the New Jersey governor to consider running for president and liked his chances if he did, I can understand why Chris Christie has decided against a bid. The hour is late, the hurdles are significant, and if his candidacy crashed and burned Christie would have probably thrown away his still-young political career  and with it, his ability to fundamentally reform a long-misgoverned state. As Reihan Salam put it the other day, New Jersey needs its governor, and a Republican Party that believes in the importance of federalism shouldnt necessarily be in the business of promoting its most successful state officials to the national level before their statehouse work has come to fruition. (See Palin, Sarah, for a cautionary tale on that front.)

title: Afghanistan Favors India and Denigrates Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Fuming over what they have called the Pakistani role in exporting terrorism across the border, Afghan officials signaled on Tuesday that they had little interest, for now, in healing a rift with Pakistan, their eastern neighbor.

title: More Disney Characters to Resurface in 3-D
description: Nemo, Sulley and Ariel are being converted into 3-D and dispatched to multiplexes as Disney seeks to squeeze new profits from its old animated films.

title: Kelly, the Tigers Mr. Fix-It, Shows his Versatility
description: DETROIT  The Detroit Tigers Don Kelly is prepared for almost anything, and everything, that could happen during a game.

title: Fiscal and Political Shifts Cloud Stadium Push
description: ARDEN HILLS, Minn.  For decades, N.F.L. teams, including those in Arizona, Ohio and Texas, have persuaded taxpayers to help them cover most of the costs of their new stadiums. The Minnesota Vikings, whose roof on their current home, the Metrodome, collapsed spectacularly last winter, are no different.

title: No Sheen, No Problem for Two and a Half Men
description: While the initial curiosity behind a Charlie Sheen-less Two and a Half Men seems to be fading, the CBS comedy was still able to reach 17.3 million viewers on Monday night, narrowly beating ABCs Dancing With the Stars (16.5 million) as the most-watched program. On Fox, Terra Nova retained 100 percent of its premiere 18-to-49-year-old audience, a fantastic sign for the expensive sci-fi program. Meanwhile, the fall season had its first network casualty on Tuesday when NBC announced that it had canceled The Playboy Club after its third episode fell to just 3.4 million viewers.

title: The Lowdown | Curtis Kulig
description: There is not a place on earth that Curtis Kulig doesnt have friends. In the darkest little dive bars in Tokyo, there is evidence that he has been there. In alleyways in Los Angeles that no one ventures down and high up above the rooftops in New York, his mark winks at you familiarly  his mark being the omnipresent two word cursive tag Love Me that litters metropolitan downtowns the world over in spray paint and endless stickers. A photographer turned graffiti artist, Kulig is SoHos most unexpected nice guy. Known as equally for his sweet demeanor as for his public cry for affection (which hes had to tone down lately), Kulig has successfully gone legit with commercial commissions like billboards for the makeup brand Bobbi Brown. This month, Kulig is trying his hand at fine art, with the opening of his first two-man show in New York, with the Los Angeles graffiti artist Skullphone.

title: Backup Catchers, a Scary Fountain, and the Story of Tony Plush
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

title: Spanning the Years in One Evening of Jazz
description: During one inspired stretch of her casually luxurious concert at the Rose Theater on Friday night, Cassandra Wilson sang material from her oldest and most recent Blue Note albums, released 17 years apart. A few of these were original songs, full of spirit talk and churning, viscous grooves. One was an adaptation of Charley Pattons Pony Blues, soulful and self-assured. There was no demarcation between old and new, no sense of shifting gears. Ms. Wilson presented the songs as points in a continuum, scenes in a story yet unfinished, and maybe unfinishable.

title: A Medical Metaphor for Climate Risk, Including the Risk of Overreaction
description: Paul C. Stern, the director of the National Research Council committee on the human dimensions of global change, has been involved in a decades-long string of studies of behavior, climate change and energy choices.

title: Another Federal Judge Takes the S.E.C. to Task
description: An unusually hostile ruling emerged from a Manhattan courtroom last week, when a federal judge lashed out at the Securities and Exchange Commission for weak oversight. It was unusual, only because its author was not Judge Jed S. Rakoff.

title: Festival of Rock Posters
description: A series of rock posters will be on display in San Francisco.

title: TimesCast | October 4, 2011
description: A truck bomb kills dozens in Somalia's capital; American astronomers win the Nobel Prize in physics; and Apple announces its latest iPhone.

title: Brooklyn Fare and Eleven Madison Park Get Three Michelin Stars
description: The tally of restaurants in New York City with three Michelin stars has risen to seven from five in the companys 2012 Guide, which goes on sale Wednesday. Chefs Table at Brooklyn Fare, which had two stars last year, and Eleven Madison Park, which had one, now have three, joining Daniel, Jean Georges, Le Bernardin, Masa and Per Se.

title: Jol Robuchon Is Stephen Hansons Japanese Consultant for Kibo
description: Jol Robuchon, the renowned French chef, is the consultant for Kibo, the first Japanese restaurant from Stephen Hansons BR Guest restaurant group. That may seem like an unusual choice, but Mr. Robuchon does have a Japanese restaurant in Monaco, Yoshi, with a Michelin star.

title: Borodin Glows in an Intimate Salon
description: One of the sunniest pieces of classical music ever written, Borodins String Quartet No. 2, which the composer dedicated to his wife of 20 years, seems to imply that all is well with the world. The third-movement Notturno, which furnished the melody of the song And This Is My Beloved in the Borodin-drenched musical Kismet, is particularly dewy.

title: Artists Painted With a Palette of Words
description: Calvin Tomkins, who has chronicled the lives of artists for The New Yorker for half a century, has somehow managed to escape the ritual of interrogation to which he has subjected everyone from Andy Warhol on down. One recent afternoon, sitting at a glass-topped table in his brightly minimalist apartment on the Upper East Side, he mentioned that he had never been profiled and is probably resistant to self-scrutiny.

title: Trisha Brown to Receive Bessie Lifetime Achievement Award
description: Trisha Brown, the modern dance choreographer, is to receive a Bessie award for lifetime achievement, the selection committee for the awards announced Tuesday. The Bessies, formally known as the New York Dance and Performance awards, and established in 1983 are named for the dance educator and mentor Bessie Schonberg.

title: Meyer Intends to Sell Eleven Madison Park to Its Chef and Manager
description: It may be the first time a foreword to a cookbook has confirmed hot restaurant news.

title: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Somalia, the Philippines, Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: The Daily Shoe | Chanel
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Romney Likens Wall Street Protests to Class Warfare
description: As anti-Wall Street protests have begun to move from Wall Street to main streets in other cities, the issue has also started to bubble up in the presidential campaign.

title: Unesco Delays Decision on Fate of Prize Sponsored by Dictator
description: PARIS  Unesco executive board members voted Tuesday to once again postpone a decision on a proposed scientific award sponsored by a West African leader with a brutal reputation, prolonging what has already been more than a year of negotiations and hand-wringing.

title: Channel Surfing: Gene Simmons Family Jewels
description: Is there nothing Gene Simmons and Shannon Tweed wont do to try to keep Gene Simmons Family Jewels, the reality show about their lives, interesting? It appears that after two children and almost three decades together, theyre even willing to take the drastic step of getting married.

title: Helicopter Plunges Into East River, Killing a Passenger; 4 People Survive
description: A helicopter with a veteran pilot at the controls, and a family of tourists he had known for years aboard, crashed in the East River on Tuesday afternoon, killing a woman despite a frantic rescue effort that involved a flotilla of police and fire vessels and dozens of emergency workers.

title: Paco Rabanne Returns With an Edge
description: If ever there was a designer-to-brand matchup that was made of perfectly complementary parts, it would be the appointment of Manish Arora as creative director at Paco Rabanne this season. Mr. Aroras flair for fantastical and theatrical designs is not that far off from what Mr. Rabanne was doing in the 1960s, when he made dresses of metal plates and squares that occasionally gave literal meaning to the term fashion victim.

title: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Somalia, the Philippines, Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: Denzel Washington Endows a Theater Professorship at Fordham
description: Denzel Washington has donated $2 million to his alma mater, Fordham University, to endow its first professorship in theater with the goal of attracting a well-known actor, director, playwright, designer or other artist to rotate into the position at the schools Lincoln Center theater program each fall, university officials announced on Tuesday.

title: Egypt Unclear on Timetable of Power Transfer, U.S. Says
description: CAIRO  Not even Egypts interim military rulers know when they plan to relinquish power to a new civilian government, the United States ambassador to Egypt, Anne W. Patterson, said Tuesday.

title: Facing Backlash, Syria Revokes Week-Old Ban on Imports of Consumer Goods
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government on Tuesday revoked a recent decision to ban imports of most consumer goods, a move that had sent prices soaring and provoked outrage among a business elite that has until now backed the leadership of President Bashar al-Assad in his nearly seven-month contest with anti-government activists.

title: Celebrating a Master of the Avant-Garde
description: Anthony Braxton sat perched on a piano bench one recent afternoon, hands folded in his lap, wearing an intent but unreadable expression. Angled away from the piano in a no-frills rehearsal space in Brooklyn, he faced the dozen or so vocalists that currently make up his Syntactical Ghost Trance Music Choir. The singers, arranged in a semicircle, were tackling Mr. Braxtons Composition No. 256, staring hard at their sheet music while trying to keep track of their conductor. It was starting to seem as if the piece, a slippery, scalar proposition, were getting the best of them.

title: As Christie Passes, Romney Campaigns On
description: THE VILLAGES, Fla.  Though Mitt Romney has always maintained a casual cool on the topic of a possible Chris Christie candidacy  Itd be fun if he got in, Mr. Romney said last week in New Hampshire, with a grin plastered on his face that seemed to say it wouldnt necessarily be that much fun at all  he seemed newly emboldened on the topic Wednesday afternoon.

title: Youth Meets Aged Master in 2 Dances, One Score
description: The Guggenheim Museums Works & Process series set a particularly difficult challenge for the young ballet choreographers Emery LeCrone and Avi Scher. Requiring them both to make a dance to the same music was not unusual; comparing and contrasting is habitual at Works & Process. The difficulty arose from the selected music: five unrelated works, atonal and rhythmically irregular compositions by the august and fearsome Elliott Carter, and none of them intended for dance.

title: Sixties Going On 30
description: The heyday of Pierre Cardin and mod fashion finds fresh inspiration in the unaffected Kirsten Dunst.

title: As Euro Crisis Deepens, Calls for Central Bank to Act
description: FRANKFURT  Jean-Claude Trichets last few weeks as president of the European Central Bank may be his most contentious.

title: Photos of the Moment | Jean Charles Castelbajac
description: Sonny Vandeveldes Paris fashion week photo diary.

title: Once Again, the Rays Come Up Short
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

title: Photos of the Moment | Jean Charles Castelbajac
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Bachmann Says Staff Changes Were Planned
description: DES MOINES, Iowa  Representative Michele Bachmann on Tuesday addressed the perception that her campaign had hit a rocky patch because of dwindling finances after the latest staff shakeup.

title: A Walk in the South Bronx With the Planning Commissioner and Our Architecture Critic
description: Following up on my review last week of Via Verde, a groundbreaking green housing project soon to be completed in the Melrose section of the South Bronx, I took a walk around that neighborhood with Amanda M. Burden, director the Department of City Planning under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. We shot some video of our tour; please watch it by clicking here.

title: Inside the Caves
description: A look at the cheeses aging in the caves at Murrays, Artisanal and the Cellars at Jasper Hill.

title: Cheese: A Coming-of-Age Story
description: ROB KAUFELT and Brian Ralph were standing in a cool underground bunker below Murrays Cheese Shop in Greenwich Village, giving a visitor a tour of five temperature-and-humidity-controlled cheese caves. The man-made chambers, they said, prevent many of the things that can go wrong with cheese when it is not handled properly.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Crackers With No Gluten but Plenty of Snap
description: Yes, these new lentil crackers are gluten-free, but even if that doesnt matter to you, they have merit as crisp snacks, for dipping and with cheese. They come in three flavors, all of them appealing: sea salt, cracked pepper and rosemary herb.

title: Spices, Sugars, Teas: A Blast for the Senses
description: Bruno Benzacken and Franois Athea are cousins from a family that has been in the spice business in Europe since 1933. They came to New York eight years ago and began selling spices and teas at street fairs. Now they have graduated to a store on the Upper West Side, colorful in its array of several dozen spices, teas and blends and just as alluring for the aromas that waft from the displays. Tall canisters hold various sugars (right), and downstairs there are more spices and teas, along with assorted salts, peppers and pepper mixtures; Provenal products, including soaps; and various gadgets for grinding spices and preparing tea. They serve tea and pastries as well.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Help the Farmers

title: Michael Dell Advises Hewlett-Packard
description: Attention Hewlett-Packard: Michael Dell thinks that you should stay in the personal computer business.

title: A Life of Guitars, Girls and Gentle Weeping
description: As three-hour-plus Martin Scorsese documentaries about 1960s musical legends go, George Harrison: Living in the Material World, showing in two parts on HBO on Wednesday and Thursday, is not the best. That would be No Direction Home: Bob Dylan, shown on PBS in 2005. (Shine a Light, about the Rolling Stones, was largely a concert film and only two hours long.)

title: Strange Ship, Stranger Crew
description: Benito Cereno has so much to say. Based on a novella by Herman Melville, the play, by the poet Robert Lowell, is keen to rail against oppression and condemn political hypocrisy. Its a pity, then, that the stagey production by the Horizon Theater Rep sometimes muffles the scripts voice.

title: Photos of the Moment | Paco Rabanne
description: Sonny Vandeveldes Paris fashion week photo diary.

title: Jesus Christ Superstar Returning to Broadway
description: Musicals with religious themes  as well as those with Andrew Lloyd Webber scores  are filling up Broadway theaters this season. The Stratford Shakespeare Festivals production of Mr. Lloyd Webbers Jesus Christ Superstar, which has been an audience and critical favorite there since May, will transfer to Broadway and begin preview performances on March 1, 2012, at the Neil Simon Theater, the producers announced on Tuesday. The revival of the 1971 rock opera, which has lyrics by Tim Rice, will first move to the La Jolla Playhouse later this year.

title: Q. and A. With Norbert Wabnig
description: This week, Jeff Gordinier writes about affinage, the practice of aging cheese until it ripens a touchy topic among fromage fanatics. Norbert Wabnig, the owner of the Cheese Store of Beverly Hills, will be answering readers questions on cheese, from the social (how do you assemble the perfect cheese plate?) to the more gustatory (when are you supposed to eat the rind?). If you would like to ask a question, post it as a comment below and he will respond in a later post.

title: Leading Christie Supporter Turns to Romney
description: Ken Langone, the billionaire Home Depot founder who in recent weeks led an intense but unsuccessful effort to draft the New Jersey governor, Christopher J. Christie, into the presidential race, has decided he will now support Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, according to two people with knowledge of the decision.

title: Adapting Julia Child for E-Readers
description: Clumsily splattering a cookbook with bacon grease is one thing. Doing it to an iPad is quite another.

title: U.S. and New York Sue Bank of New York Mellon Over Foreign Exchange Fees
description: The New York attorney general and the United States attorney in Manhattan filed separate lawsuits on Tuesday against the Bank of New York Mellon, accusing it of cheating state and other pension funds nationwide out of foreign exchange fees over the last decade.

title: Besides Burnett, Yanks Go With Same Lineup
description: DETROIT  The lineups are in for Game 4 of the Yankees-Tigers American League division series Tuesday night, and Joe Girardi is going with the same lineup he used in the first three games. Detroits Jim Leyland made two alterations with the right-hander A.J. Burnett going for the Yankees instead of the left-hander C.C. Sabathia, who started Game 3.

title: A West Virginia Forecast: High Uncertainty
description: Voters are going to the polls Tuesday in West Virginia to cast ballots in a special election for governor pitting Earl Ray Tomblin, a Democrat who was appointed governor after Joe Manchin III was elected to the Senate, against Bill Maloney, a Republican.

title: A Bonnie Glass of Highlands Gin
description: Gins from Scotland have distinctive personality. Hendricks, with its clean whisper of cucumber, is a case in point. Now there is Caorunn (pronounced ka-ROON), which offers uncommon herbal complexity, thanks to native botanicals like heather, rowan berry and dandelion, along with the more typical herbs and spices used for gin. A touch of sweetness lingers. The spirit is made in a malt distillery in the Highlands, using some equipment for treating the botanicals that dates back nearly 100 years. This gin seems to have a particular affinity for grapefruit, and a mere splash of the juice is all it needs on the rocks, though a long drink with grapefruit juice and a dash of maraschino liqueur is another winner.

title: At the Museum, Hunting Treasure and the Man Who Hid It
description: There were really two treasure hunts at the American Museum of Natural History on Monday night. City Room failed at both.

title: TimesCast | Nobel Nod to Dark Energy
description: October 4, 2011  Three Americans win the Nobel Prize in physics for discovering dark energy, a force crucial to the expansion of the universe.

title: Look of the Moment | Natalia Vodianova
description: The Look: Coquette Visage  a red lip and shoe cap a pioneeress dress with a crochet collar and hemline.

title: Saul Perlmutter on Dark Energy
description: Saul Perlmutter explains how dark energy, which makes up 70 percent of the universe, is causing our universe to expand.

title: Battle for Libya | October 4, 2011
description: Newly trained fighters attended a graduation ceremony in Tripoli as rebels fought on the front line in Bani Walid.

title: In Game 3, Arizona Will Rely on a Rookie
description: PHOENIX  Arizona Manager Kirk Gibson calls the right-hander Josh Collmenter a Ferris wheel for his unorthodox over-the-top delivery. Its a throwing motion Collmenter said he developed while throwing hatchets as a youngster growing up in Homer, Mich.

title: Calvin Klein
description: New York

title: Lets Not Speak of Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama, in Texas, Pushes Jobs Bill
description: DALLAS  President Obama on Tuesday campaigned for his jobs bill and collected political contributions in the home state of Gov. Rick Perry and the Congressional district of a Republican House leader, and he did not shy away from telling affluent donors that they and the states oil companies should pay more in taxes for the nations good.

title: Will World End Before or After Festival Does?
description: The opportunity to see two intimidating landmarks  Once Upon a Time in Anatolia and The Turin Horse  is reason enough for any filmgoer with more than a passing interest in the evolution of world cinema to be grateful for the platform of the New York Film Festival. Because the chances that either movie will soon be coming to a theater near you, as they say, are next to nil, the best time to see them may be at Alice Tully Hall in the coming week.

title: The iPhone and the Brain
description: To the Editor:

title: Lens: Photographs From a Decade in Afghanistan
description: I am a photographer working for a newspaper, and to ignore this American war, or any other war that we are involved in, would be an unfulfilling way for me to work. Tyler Hicks, a staff photographer at The New York Times, voices in a simple and understated way the reasons he keeps going back to Afghanistan after over 10 years of covering the war there. But his experiences in that time have been anything but simple or understated.

title: Two Directions for Moroccan Cuisine
description: MOURAD LAHLOU and Paula Wolfert would not seem to have much in common. He is the 43-year-old chef of Aziza in San Francisco, his arms decorated with tattoos that signify strength in Arabic, a son of Casablanca, Morocco, who works wonders with spices and preserved lemons, sous-vide and meat glue.

title: Being a Monster Doesnt Mean Being a Bully, Too
description: MONSTER HIGH, the line of fashion dolls from Mattel that features the teenage children of legendary monsters facing the awkward struggles of high school, is getting a social conscience.

title: Enjoying Cabernet of a Certain Age
description: THE wine in my glass was a pale, rusty red, browning at the edges, as youd expect in an older wine. The aroma, with its intimations of tobacco and graphite, suggested a good Pauillac, with an added touch of anise. It was lovely and graceful, tangy and deliciously fresh despite the years, and the flavors persisted in the mouth. Beautiful.

title: For 2nd Time, Adele Cancels a Tour
description: For the second time this year, Adele has been forced to cancel a sold-out tour of several American cities because of health problems affecting her voice.

title: Republican Criticizes Norquist for Paralyzing Congress
description: Who is this Grover Norquist, anyhow? To hear Representative Frank Wolf tell it, the antitax activist is a questionable character with some unsavory connections who has too much influence over the political process.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

title: A Naked Man Can Be a Difficult Problem Onstage
description: Im a Winner.

title: iPhone 4S: Revolution or Evolution?
description: Apple announced its latest iPhone, hoping to slow the explosive growth of its arch-rival Android.

title: N.B.A. Is Expected to Lose Two Weeks of Regular Season
description: A last-gasp attempt to end the N.B.A. lockout faltered Tuesday, all but ensuring that games will be lost to a labor crisis for the second time in league history.

title: More Solyndra E-mails, and Warnings
description: The Solyndra e-mails that House Democrats used to write the memo they released on Monday, in an effort to refute the idea that political favoritism was in play, are now posted on their Energy and Commerce Web site, and they have a few more nuggets about the company.

title: How to Win Friends and Influence People in the Digital Age
description: Why Carnegies Advice Still Matters

title: Photos of the Moment | Paco Rabanne
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Koreas Master Chef Prepares a Banquet at the Met
description: A pageant and banquet celebrating Korean culture and food was held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday night.

title: Cuts in Military Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily Posts Etiquette, 18th Edition
description: Chapter 1

title: House Panel Investigates FEMA
description: The House Appropriations Committee is investigating the Federal Emergency Management Agencys last-minute decision to finish the 2011 fiscal year with no additional funds, the panels chairman said on Tuesday.

title: Milestones to Lose Signature Touch
description: When Austin Romine collected his first major league hit Sept. 12 in Seattle, the ball he struck made its way from right field to the Yankees dugout and eventually into the hands of the teams chief athletic trainer, Gene Monahan.

title: A Data Center Power Solution
description: The rapid growth in data centers, some with hundreds of thousands of computer servers attending to tasks as diverse as managing complex physics problems and posting pictures to Facebook, has led to a lot of worries about power consumption. A recent census of the industry indicated electricity use will grow by 19 percent just in 2012.

title: I Am Your Nurse. Please Call Me Doctor.
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Resolution on Syria Blocked by Russia and China
description: UNITED NATIONS  Months of wrangling at the Security Council over a resolution condemning Syria collapsed on Tuesday after Russia and China vetoed a measure that contained a weak reference to the possibility of sanctions against Damascus.

title: Fox News Decides to Keep The Five
description: The Five, a talk show that was created to temporarily replace Glenn Becks show on Fox News, is being made a more permanent part of the channels weekday schedule.

title: Far From Home
description: Tens of thousands of boys under the age of 18 witnessed the brutality of the Civil War firsthand.

title: Regulator Seeks Oversight of Cheetah Traders
description: Bart Chilton, a Democratic member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, has plans to tame the cheetahs  cheetah traders on Wall Street, that is.

title: Chanel Never Breaks Stride
description: PARIS

title: The iPhone 4S Is as Much About Google as Apple
description: Tuesdays iPhone unveiling didnt have as much to do with Apple as it did with Google. And in regards to Google, Tuesdays announcement was, to quote the rapper Diddy, All about the Benjamins.

title: Make That the Mercedes-Benz Superdome
