description: Since 1975, the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans has had no other name. But on Tuesday, it officially became the Mercedes-Benz Superdome with the German luxury automakers acquisition of the naming rights to the home of the New Orleans Saints.

title: Five Years Later, a Different Outcome
description: Detroit

title: As Economies Slow, Price of Gas Falls
description: HOUSTON  The sharp slump in oil prices over the last few months is finally beginning to bring relief at the gasoline pump, with the price of a gallon of regular gasoline dropping nearly a penny a day over the last four weeks.

title: The Boys of War
description: With hopes of adventure and glory, tens of thousands of boys under the age of 18 answered the call of the Civil War, many of them rushing to join Union and Confederate troops in the earliest days of battle. Both sides had recruitment rules that barred underage men from enlisting, but that didnt stop those who wanted to be part of the action: some enlisted without their parents permission and lied about their ages or bargained with recruiters for a trial period, while others joined along with their older brothers and fathers whose partisan passions overwhelmed their parental senses. Most of the youngest boys became drummers, messengers and orderlies, but thousands of others fought alongside the men.

title: Mark Hurd Is Still Intense
description: You may have thought Oracle was a hard-charging sales organization even before Mark Hurd showed up. Turns out there was room for more.

title: Iraq Denies Legal Immunity to U.S. Troops After 2011
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs political leaders announced late Tuesday that they had agreed on the need to keep American military trainers in Iraq next year, but they declared that any remaining troops should not be granted immunity from Iraqi law, a point the United States has said would be a deal breaker.

title: Handicapping IACs Investment in Chelsea Clinton
description: Chelsea Clinton as a corporate director? Really?

title: Hanan Porat, Jewish Settlement Leader, Dies at 67
description: JERUSALEM  Hanan Porat, who helped turn Israels religious settler movement into a powerful force through the establishment of Jewish communities in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, died on Tuesday at his childhood kibbutz, which he had re-established. He was 67.

title: In a Trial, Only a Quick Nod to a Bloomberg Aides Affair
description: It was expected to be a moment of supreme awkwardness for John F. Haggerty Jr., a political consultant accused of stealing money from the mayor of New York.

title: In Florida Retirement Community, Guess What Romney Talks About?
description: THE VILLAGES, Fla.  The audience  the aging, the retired and the lively-but-starting-to-show-smile-lines men and women of Florida  could not have telegraphed Social Security concerns more clearly than Mitt Romney himself, who tried a little Social Security humor of his own Tuesday afternoon at The Villages, a retirement community about an hour north of Orlando.

title: How About a Little Danish?
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark  Well lookee here: the inevitable move toward taxing unhealthful foods to raise income and discourage damaging diets has begun. Last month, Hungary, almost unnoticed, began taxing foods with high levels of fat, salt and sugar. And earlier this week, with just a little more fanfare, Denmark instituted an excise tax on foods high in saturated fat.

title: Jury Sought for Nigerian Held in Bid to Bomb Jet
description: DETROIT  Among the scores of potential jurors for the trial of a man accused of trying to blow up an airliner with a bomb in his underwear, nearly all said they had already heard something about the case, a federal judge here said Tuesday, the first day of jury selection.

title: Hope Rising, Stores Hire for Holidays
description: Even with a turbulent economy, leading retailers say they expect to hire more, or at least as many, holiday workers as last year, when temporary hiring for Christmas grew nearly 50 percent over recession lows.

title: Taliban Using Modern Means to Add to Sway
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan  Punctually, at 8 oclock every evening, the cellphone signals disappear in this provincial capital. Under pressure from the Taliban, the major carriers turn off their signal towers, effectively severing most of the connections to the rest of the world.

title: Tenderness and Violence as Portrayed in a Murder Trial
description: On the morning she shot her husband five times with a revolver, then grabbed a second pistol and pumped six more bullets into him, Barbara Sheehan had proofread an essay on Genesis 22, written by her son for his freshman religion class.

title: Building Architects Centers to Capture Public Attention
description: In the years he has been associated with the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects, Rick Bell has witnessed some great real estate deals.

title: The Downside to a Debt Jubilee
description: Good ends do not justify bad means. That philosophical observation applies to proposals for a big American debt jubilee that are now doing the rounds. The basic idea is to slash consumer debt, which is an admirable aim for an overleveraged nation. Household debt is still 90 percent of gross domestic product, down only modestly from the 2008 peak of 100 percent. But even bank-haters should recognize that this cure might be worse than the disease.

title: An Appeal Gone Astray Catches the Supreme Courts Attention
description: WASHINGTON  Cory R. Maples, a death row inmate in Alabama, had what turned out to be the bad fortune to be represented by one of the most prominent law firms in the nation. The Supreme Court heard arguments in his case on Tuesday, and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. described where matters stood.

title: Quick Change That Lasts for the Long Term
description: On Friday I wrote about Rapid Results Initiatives, bite-sized pieces of social change that a village, government office or business will choose and try to accomplish in just 100 days. Rapid Results Initiatives have proven to be effective at various tasks: improving health, infrastructure, education  service delivery of any kind. The urgent deadline provides focus. Its no longer business as usual, plagued by the usual list of reasons why nothing gets done.

title: TimesCast | Truck Bomb in Somalia
description: October 4, 2011 - A massive truck bomb in Mogadishu kills dozens, with the Shabaab Islamic group claiming responsibility.

title: Audit Finds Citys Schools Short on Physical Education
description: Despite alarming obesity rates among school-age children and a state requirement that all students get some level of structured exercise every week, many New York City schools do not provide physical education, or do not provide it as frequently as they should, according to an audit released on Tuesday by the city comptroller.

title: Pundits Pack Meaner Punch Than Comedians Fat Jokes
description: He listened to the jokes and laughed. But he read the columns and cringed.

title: European Banks Face Huge Losses From Greek Bonds
description: Europes biggest banks may finally be forced to own up to their losses.

title: When Leaders Die, Terror Still Thrives
description: THE killing of the Yemeni-American cleric Anwar al-Awlaki on Sept. 30 is arguably the most significant attack on Al Qaeda since Osama bin Ladens death in May.

title: After Bronx Crash, a Bus Fleet Stays on the Road
description: In the months after a bus crash on Interstate 95 killed 15 people in the Bronx, federal officials were so concerned about the operation of the bus company, World Wide Travel, that they revoked its registration. But the disciplinary action seems to have had little practical effect.

title: Roots of Ballot Security: Dead Voters, Party Fears and Shadowy Tactics
description: The charge being weighed by a Manhattan jury in the case of the Republican campaign consultant John Haggerty Jr. is whether he took $1.1 million of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs money to guard against election fraud, and then spent most of it on a house instead.

title: Russia Declares It Is Close to Joining the World Trade Organization
description: MOSCOW  After high-level meetings in Washington, Russian officials said Tuesday that they were on the brink of a deal that would allow Russia to become a member of the World Trade Organization after 18 years of halting negotiations, though hostility between Georgia and Russia remains a crucial sticking point.

title: In Detroit, Young Gets New Lease in the Playoffs
description: DETROIT  In the three and a half years that Delmon Young played for the Minnesota Twins, facing the Yankees almost always guaranteed a quiet postgame clubhouse. Not only were the Twins swept in back-to-back American League division series, with many of the games close and excruciating, but they also lost 19 of 26 to the Yankees in the regular season.

title: Back to School in Libya, and Struggling to Adjust
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The classrooms at the Dawn of Freedom middle school were empty. Teachers shuffled around aimlessly outside or gossiped in the halls. A small group of bored teenagers sat in the theater and hatched a plan to coax their classmates back.

title: Will Copyright Stifle Hollywood?
description: Philadelphia

title: What Kind of Fall Am I?
description: There is no single way to measure the coming of autumn. Gardeners wait for the first hard frost, the one that blackens the basil and pulps the tomatoes still on the vine. For some, its the smell of wood smoke or the sight of leaves flaming out one tree species at a time. In New York City, there are different measures. Fall begins when street fashion slips into thermal chaos  down jackets, shawls, bermudas and flip-flops all on the same block. Fall begins, as it did this week, when the residual heat in the subway station feels strangely welcome.

title: Capital Goods Orders Rise the Most in 3 Months
description: Orders for capital equipment increased in August by the most in three months, the Commerce Department said Tuesday, a sign that business investment and exports held up in the face of growing concern over the European debt crisis.

title: At Controls of Doomed Aircraft, a Pilot With Experience
description: Five years ago, Paul Dudley was at the helm of a plane that was forced to make an emergency landing in a Brooklyn park. It was a nonevent, he said, engine trouble that he compared to getting a blowout with your car on the highway.

title: Making Empty Homes Less Inviting to the Uninvited
description: LONDON  Arriving at his supposedly empty rental property just outside London recently, Sam Chima, a housing lawyer, was dismayed to find a newly installed lock on the front door and a newly installed stranger glaring from a window.

title: Morgan Tries to Quell Rumors About Its Holdings
description: Morgan Stanley executives are battling a daily barrage of speculation and nay-saying to try to stem a sharp slide in the companys stock.

title: Zuckerman Spaeder Builds Out Its New York Practice
description: Over the last 35 years, the Washington law firm Zuckerman Spaeder has built a well-regarded litigation boutique, largely inside the Beltway. Now, with the hiring of three prominent lawyers in two weeks, the firm has moved to establish a formidable criminal defense practice in New York.

title: British Squatters Rejuvenate an Abandoned Site Near Heathrow Airport
description: The British government has promised to tighten anti-squatting laws to make it easier for property owners to evict uninvited tenants.

title: A Court Fight and a Tireless Battle Over an Image
description: When Amanda Knox and her family landed home in Seattle on Tuesday, it was the culmination of an exhaustive four-year legal, lobbying and public relations effort that ultimately succeeded when an Italian court overturned her murder conviction and freed her from prison.

title: As Regulars Falter, Unlikely Slugger Provides Blast That Boosts Phillies
description: ST. LOUIS  A lot had been made about how the Philadelphia Phillies regular lineup, reunited at last, would propel them through the postseason.

title: Gov. Perrys Rock
description: Untold decades ago, someone decided to name a hunting camp in West Texas Niggerhead, using a phrase so commonplace around the South that it was used as a brand name for oysters, soap, tobacco and even golf tees. When Gov. Rick Perrys family took over the lease for the camp in 1983, it could have demanded that the name be changed. It could have destroyed the rock on which the name was painted. It could have broken with an era when vicious racism was so casual that officials put such a word on maps around the country.

title: A.C. Nielsen Jr., Who Built Ratings Firm, Dies at 92
description: Arthur C. Nielsen Jr., who transformed the company his father founded in 1923 into an international leader in market research, helping to make its name synonymous with television ratings, died on Monday in Winnetka, Ill., where he lived most of his life. He was 92.

title: Sabathias Future a Question
description: DETROIT  C. C. Sabathia has been a boon to the Yankees since he arrived in New York, going 59-23 with a 3.18 earned run average in three seasons, and leading the team, both on and off the field. In 2009, he repaid his huge contract by leading the Yankees all the way to a World Series championship.

title: A Dreadful Missed Deadline
description: Alabama is a step from executing Cory Maples for a reason so grievously wrong that the case argued Tuesday at the Supreme Court should leave no doubt why the death penalty should be abolished. Besides being barbaric, case after case is rife with constitutional defects.

description: Adrian Beltre joined a select fraternity when he blasted three home runs in a postseason game Tuesday against the Tampa Bay Rays in Game 4 of their American League division series. title: The Wrong Way to Deal With China
description: China is undeniably manipulating its currency. Countries around the world, including the United States, are losing jobs because their manufacturing industries cannot compete with artificially cheap Chinese goods. For the good of the world economy, and its own long-term economic development, China should stop.

When completed near the end of next year, though, the six-story office building may be the greenest commercial structure in the world.

Elizabeth Warren, who joined the Massachusetts Senate race last month with strong backing from national Democrats, faced five primary opponents Tuesday night in the first debate of the Massachusetts Senate race. It turned out to be a cordial event in which the candidates threw punches at Senator Scott P. Brown, the Republican whom the nominee will face in November 2012, but for the most part, not at one another.

title: How Much to Drink During a Marathon
description: The 2011 Chicago Marathon on Sunday marks the beginning of the fall marathon season in the United States, culminating on Nov. 6 with the New York City race. In those two events alone, more than 80,000 runners will attempt to cover the 26.2-mile marathon distance. But two newly released studies suggest that there are reasons to be concerned about some of the racers readiness. The studies show that a worrying large percentage of distance runners may not know how to drink.

title: Polls Reveal Americans Doubts About Afghan War
description: As the war in Afghanistan reaches its 10th anniversary, two national surveys reveal an American public that thinks the United States should not be fighting in Afghanistan and the war has not been worth it. And a survey of military veterans examines the attitudes of those who have served both before and since Sept. 11, finding high levels of pride in their service with less certainty about American military efforts in Afghanistan.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
description: Anna Hazare threatens to go on an anti-Congress poll campaign, if his version of the Lokpal Bill is not passed in the winter session of the Parliament. Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Punjab and Manipur are slated for assembly polls next year. Mr. Hazare demanded a written commitment from the Congress Party on the issue before Thursdays holiday of Dussehra. (Hindustan Times)Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and Afghanistan President Hamid Karzai signed their first-ever strategic partnership agreement on Tuesday in New Delhi. India has agreed to train the Afghan national security forces, and the two countries pledged trade and economic cooperation, from developing trade routes to exploring for minerals and hydrocarbons in Afghanistan. (The Hindu)

title: Classic Advice: Please, Leave Well Enough Alone
description: Dale Carnegies How to Win Friends and Influence People, which turns 75 this year, has sold more than 30 million copies and continues to be a best seller. The book, a paean to integrity, good humor and warmth in the name of amicable capitalism, is as wholesome as a Norman Rockwell painting. It exists alongside Dr. Spocks child-rearing guide, Strunk and Whites volume on literary style and Fannie Farmers cookbook as a classic expression of the American impulse toward self-improvement and reinvention. Testimonials to its effectiveness abound. Its said that the only diploma that hangs in Warren Buffetts office is his certificate from Dale Carnegie Training.

Under Elattuvalapil Sreedharan, the 9-year-old Metro provides stellar service, completes projects on time and under budget, and is making a profit, despite having the lowest fares of any metro system in the world outside of Kolkata.

Marshall, asked Americans to refrain from eating meat on Tuesdays, and poultry and eggs on Thursdays, to help stockpile grain for starving people in Europe.

title: Young Artists the Focus at Madrid Show
description: Drive along Spains highways long enough and you might pass the silhouette of a black bull that stands nearly 46 feet high. Originally an advertising campaign for the Osborne sherry company, the bull  there are actually a number of them across Spain  has since become a national symbol. In 2006, after almost 50 years since the first Osborne bull went up, the Madrid-based artist SpY, who has often been referred to as the Spanish Banksy, protested bullfighting by splattering one of the bulls with a huge splash of red paint.

title: Can Cancer Ever Be Ignored?
description: As chief medical and scientific officer of the American Cancer Society,Otis Webb Brawley  who is also a professor of oncology and epidemiology at Emory University  is the public face of the cancer establishment. He operates in a world of similarly high-achieving, multiple-credentialed, respectable professionals, where insults tend to be delivered, stiletto-style, in scientific language that lay people arent meant to understand. So it can be more than a little jarring to hear, for example, James Mohler, chairman of the urology department and associate director of the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, say of his friend: I have known Otis for over 20 years. He doesnt come off as being ignorant or stupid, but when it comes to prostate-cancer screening, he must not be as intelligent as he seems. Or Skip Lockwood, the head of Zero, a prostate-cancer patient advocacy group, charge that Brawley is more concerned about saving mens sex lives than about saving the men themselves.

title: Taken by Pirates

title: How Glassybaby Is Trying to Win Over New Yorkers

The 97-employee company makes hand-blown glass votives in a variety of colors and has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars from sales to charities helping cancer patients. The founder, Lee Rhodes, a cancer survivor, says the idea originated with a glass vessel her then husband made for her, which she says gave her a soothing, peaceful feeling.

I recently returned from playing hooky for a few days to attend the Peace Corps 50th-anniversary celebrations in Washington along with 5,000 other returned volunteers  just a fraction of the nearly quarter-million who have served our country since J.F.K. challenged college students on a freezing campaign night in Michigan to devote their skills to helping people overseas.

Zuccotti joined city government as a part-time, $15,000-a-year member of the City Planning Commission, he has been chairman of the commission, first deputy mayor, chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York and the United States chairman of the global real estate giant Brookfield Properties, which owns, among other buildings, the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan.

title: Koreas Master Chef Prepares a Banquet at the Met
description: On Monday night, a raft of Korean culture and tourism groups held a dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, preceded by a pageant in the great hall (Korean fashion, as well as food, was being celebrated). The banquet reflected the cuisine of the countrys imperial court in the Chosun dynasty, which lasted from about 1400 to 1900. Han Bok-ryeo, the nations official master chef, was brought in to oversee the serving of kalbi-jjim (braised beef), kimchi, ssam (rolls), mushrooms, and root vegetables like radishes and carrots  enhanced with aromatics like baby ginseng, pine nuts, dried seaweed and dried red chile. Even tarakjuk, soft rice porridge traditionally served to the emperor at dawn, appeared as a first course, sprinkled with chives.

They have stories of what happened 2 years ago or 4 years ago or 16 years ago. They remember the key moments  the crucial plays, the turning points. They know what it takes to win the championship.

title: World Monuments Fund Places Manufacturers Hanover Building on At-Risk List

Noting that the controversial renovation of the building at 43rd Street, a branch of what was then the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, has been the subject of a court dispute, the fund said the case raises questions about the legality of recent alterations and the capacity of the New York City Landmarks Commission to enforce protective regulations.

But reports of destruction by Tropical Storm Irene, which washed out roads and flooded towns in parts of Vermont, New Hampshire and upstate New York, could be leaving the tourist season in jeopardy.

title: Fed Reports Modest Progress in Bank Compensation Plans
description: Amid the uproar over bailouts and bonuses in the fall of 2009, the chief executives of the nations largest banks walked through the iron gates of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and received a stern warning that their pay practices needed to be overhauled.

title: Coen Brothers Producing Comedy Pilot for Fox
description: More than 13 years and who knows how many White Russians after The Big Lebowski, the sibling filmmakers Joel and Ethan Coen are turning their attention to another brother shamus  not an Irish monk, but a fellow private investigator  for what could be their first television project. The Coens, the Academy Award-winning writer-directors of No Country for Old Men and Fargo, are collaborating with the Cedar Rapids screenwriter Phil Johnston on a television series called Harve Karbo, about another hapless aspiring Sam Spade. According to The Hollywood Reporter, the oddly specific series will chronicle a touchy Los Angeles private investigator  and his deadbeat friends in El Segundo  whose cases frequently force him to cross paths with a whos who of Hollywood, and if that sounds at least a little Lebowski-esque, we can abide. The series, which the Coens will produce for Imagine Television and for which Mr. Johnston will write the script, has so far received a pilot commitment from Fox, which means there are still, you know, a lotta ins, a lotta outs, a lotta what-have-yous, before Harve Karbo appears on your screen.

title: New Site Seeks to Analyze Investors Appetite for Risk
description: Would you rather be guaranteed that youll lose $489 on a $1,000 investment? Or, would you prefer a 50-50 chance of either losing all of it, or gaining $1,500?

title: Panetta Urges Europe to Spend More on NATO or Risk a Hollowed-Out Alliance
description: BRUSSELS  With the Pentagon facing severe budget cuts, Secretary of Defense Leon E. Panetta asked NATOs European members on Wednesday to heed the lessons of the Libya war and cooperate on much-needed defense spending in order not to hollow out this alliance.

title: Red Bulls Rising
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls did their best Jekyll-and-Hyde act Tuesday night at Red Bull Arena.

title: Black Eyed Peas Pull Out of Jackson Tribute
description: The organizers of a Michael Jackson tribute concert in Wales this weekend lost one of their biggest acts just days before the show when the Black Eyed Peas decided not to take part, according to wire service reports.

title: Excerpt: 'Parks and Recreation'
description: The NBC sitcom starring Amy Poehler and Nick Offerman returned in September for its fourth season.

title: New Drugs to Prevent Strokes
description: Medical researchers are usually so cautious about characterizing results that when sober cardiologists use phrases like very excited and a home run and even a new era, you pay attention.

title: Paula Wolfert Finds Lots of Love for Morrocan Food on Facebook
description: Paula Wolfert has been studying Moroccan food for almost 50 years, but in conversations about her new book, The Food of Morocco, she said she was unprepared for the flood of information unleashed by the Facebook group she started recently.

title: Musicals Festival Diary: Firsts for Everything and an Opening to Remember
description: The New York Times asked the actress Donna Lynne Champlin, who is also a new mother, to be a guest blogger as she rehearsed for Jane Austens Pride and Prejudice, a Musical, part of the New York Musical Theater Festival. In this final installment, she describes the days before opening. A review of the show appears here.

title: Budget Presses Obama Aide Into Political Fight
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama recruited William M. Daley, a business-friendly banker with a Democratic pedigree to be his chief of staff 10 months ago, Mr. Daley seemed like the right man for a White House determined to cut deals with resurgent Republicans in Congress.

title: Tigers Take the Tough Road
description: DETROIT  It could have been neat and simple for the Detroit Tigers. Win Tuesdays Game 4, against the Yankees at Comerica Park, and their American League division series is clinched. But the plans for a celebration at home blew up in spectacular fashion, as the Yankees pounded the Tigers, 10-1, and forced a decisive Game 5 at Yankee Stadium on Thursday.

title: RelayRides Gets a Lift From G.M.s OnStar
description: General Motors and RelayRides, a peer-to-peer car-sharing service that allows private car owners to rent their vehicles, announced a partnership and possible investment this week. Under an exclusive two-year agreement, RelayRides users will be able to unlock G.M. vehicles that are registered with the car-sharing service and subscribed to OnStar, the automakers communication service, with a mobile phone app.

title: Facing Fall | The Olive Eye
description: The makeup artist Tina Turnbow gives us the lowdown on her starring makeup looks for fall.

title: Back Home, and Homeless
description: Mid-June, 2011: I find myself alone in a dark wooded park tucked between million-dollar houses south of Stanford University, looking for a spot in the bushes to stash my bags. Until that morning Id been living in a cheap weekly-rate motel in Palo Alto. Before checkout, knowing I couldnt afford the $48 fee for another night, I laid out my stuff on the bed. Over the cigarette burns on threadbare sheets, I scrounged for quarters, dimes and nickels. There was enough for an extra value meal at Taco Bell. I divided everything else I had between three bags; an olive-drab backpack my brother used in the Army Rangers, a black duffel I bought at Goodwill and a satchel for my laptop.

description: And some like it cold.

title: A Trek for Cleaner Cookstoves
description: The United Nations estimates that nearly half the worlds population, some three billion people in developing countries, cook over open wood fires or primitive stoves. The practice leads to persistent health problems and accounts for nearly 20 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Dylan Tangled Up in Nobel Prize Speculation
description: Predictions for the Nobel Prize in Literature tend to be all over the place, especially in the final hours before the winner is named. But Bob Dylan?

title: A Hollywood Movie Takes on Cancer
description: This weekend I saw the movie 50/50, the story of a young cancer patient who faced even odds of surviving his disease. I wasnt sure I wanted to see a cancer movie  after all, I see cancer often enough in real life on the oncology ward where I work.

title: Democrats Seek Tax on Richest, Aiming Gauntlet at G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  In proposing a 5 percent surtax on incomes of more than $1 million a year to pay for job-creation measures sought by President Obama, Senate Democratic leaders on Wednesday escalated efforts to strike a more populist tone and to draw Republicans into a confrontation over how much affluent Americans should pay to help others cope with a struggling economy.

title: Occupy Wall Streets Tony Bennett Moment
description: I was involved in a very smart discussion yesterday about the protests around Wall Street. Questions were raised: How does this inchoate movement compare with the birth of the Tea Party? Will the White House be able to harness the populist anger to bring about tax reform? Why are there so many bongos? And most important, what are the legislative aims of the protestors? What, after all, do they want?

title: Our Kind of Tea Party
description: This issues twist on our trademark T comes courtesy of the bobo chic Parisian tableware company Astier de Villatte. It is comprised of more than 100 handmade ceramic cups, plates, teapots, flowers and tree branches. Little birds form the serifs. The sparrows around the edge give a lightness to the shape, as if its about to fly, says Ivan Pericoli, who designs the line with his partner Benot Astier de Villatte. Below, the duo, whose shop near the Palais Royal was once home to Napoleons silversmith, answers our questionnaire.

title: Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, an Elder Statesman for Civil Rights, Dies at 89
description: The Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, a storied civil rights leader who survived beatings and bombings in Alabama a half-century ago as he fought against racial injustice alongside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Wednesday in Birmingham, Ala. He was 89.

description: Photos of Robert Wilsons interpretation of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weills Threepenny Opera.

description: A conversation on the Republican presidential landscape, without Chris Christie. Also, a report from Capitol Hill on the changed dynamic between President Obama and House Majority Leader Eric Cantor.

title: David Cronenbergs Method
description: While the latest film from David Cronenberg is a further departure from the psychological horror films of his early career, it does still put psychology (and psychoanalysis) at the forefront. A Dangerous Method, starring Viggo Mortensen, Michael Fassbender and Keira Knightley, takes place on the eve of World War I and looks at the relationship between the psychiatrist Carl Jung and his mentor Sigmund Freud. That relationship shifts when Jung takes on and develops a close bond to a new patient, Sabina Spielrein, played by Ms. Knightley. The films screenplay was adapted by Christopher Hampton from his stage play, The Talking Cure. The Timess Stephen Holden writes about A Dangerous Method in his notebook about films in the festival. In this video, Mr. Cronenberg discusses how he and his team used source material  letters written by the two main subjects  to create an accurate account of both the personal and professional lives of these men.

title: David Cronenberg's 'Method'
description: David Cronenberg, the director of A Dangerous Method, discusses his film about Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Greece, Russia, Afghanistan and France.

title: Tvezs Shrug Heard Round the World
description: Steve Bartman went to a ball game. He tried to do what millions of baseball fans would love to do and catch a ball. No more, no less. But he interfered with play and was vilified because of it. He ceased being human and became a verb, a figure of hatred and of fun. The fact that he was a man of honor really meant nothing. What he did that night defined his life.

title: Monitor Must Oversee Fire Dept. Hiring Practices, Judge Rules
description: In a lacerating decision that accused Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of willfully ignoring the racial imbalance in the New York Fire Department, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday that a court-appointed monitor would be installed to oversee the departments recruitment efforts and ensure that more minority candidates are hired.

title: Recent Slam Champions Find Encores a Challenge
description: For the scrutiny and criticism that contenders like Caroline Wozniacki and Andy Murray have received for not yet capturing their first Grand Slam titles, it is the recent first-time Slam champions who have struggled most mightily to live up to their rankings.

title: Assailed for Subprime Loans, Capital One Defends ING Deal
description: Subprime lender or benevolent bank?

description: The day in sports included surfing in France, the China Open tennis tournament in Beijing and baseball in the United States.

title: Off the Runway: Paris Fashion Week
description: Scenes from Paris Fashion Week.

title: Prints Charming | Marimekkos New York City Flagship
description: If your retail therapist is counseling you to find a happy place, somewhere good to start might be the northwest corner of Broadway and 23rd Street, where a Marimekko flagship store opens its doors for business this week. The airy, industrial space in the former Toy Building has been whitewashed and minimally outfitted, allowing the brightly colored, impossibly upbeat prints for which the 60-year-old company is famous, to shine. The founders, Armi Ratia and her husband, Viljo, always envisioned Marimekko not just as a lifestyle brand, but as a way of life, and over the years their graphic sensibility touched everything from textiles to teapots, all of which are available for purchase. There is even an on-site seamstress, to whip up, say, a set of napkins in Unikko, the signature poppy print, or a pillow cover in the artist Astrid Sylwans brush strokey Vattenblnk. The folks at Marimekko hope New Yorkers will embrace the store as a meeting point; the trick, it seems, will be getting them to leave.

title: The Importance of a True No. 1 Receiver in the N.F.L.
description: Something that has really stood out on film this season is the significance of wide receivers. With the N.F.L. seemingly entirely pass-oriented these days  the four most productive weeks in league history in terms of passing yards have been Weeks 1, 2, 3 and 4 of the 2011 season  weapons in the passing game have never been more important.

title: Wall St. Protest Attracts Many New to This Sort of Thing
description: Dan Aymar-Blair  age 36, suit wearer, resident of Crown Heights, Brooklyn  never expected to find himself at a protest. Neither did Sean Aiken, a 35-year-old D.J. from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, whose interest in politics had mostly involved grumbling with his friends. The last time Peter Linard, 71, a retired waiter who lives on the Upper East Side, went to a protest, he was living in Greece, where he marched for peace  in 1961.

title: Fat Tax Update
description: Some months ago, when someone smarter than I (I cant even remember who it was!) suggested that the Fat Tax, the subject of my column today, could get backing from the Right as well as the Left, I scoffed. Now we have the potential of David Cameron, Britains decidedly Tory P.M., backing a significant national fat tax in the U.K., according to the Daily Mail. Hell be attacked for nanny-state-ism by his own members, of course, but Britains highest-in-Europe obesity rate (third in the world, after the U.S. and Mexico) and the dangers to the National Health system  the oldest single-payer system in the world and perhaps the largest (depends how you measure)  could make this interesting.

title: Landmarks Panel Declines to Approve a Puck Building Penthouse
description: Puck will have to try on a different top hat.

title: BankSimple to Go Live on Web Next Month
description: BankSimple, a Web-based banking service, says it is finally going live and expects its first customers to begin receiving their debit cards by early November.

description: Their work has been transformative and widely celebrated, as when they turned a former power station into the acclaimed Tate Modern in London in 2000.

title: Europe Calls for Infusion of Capital for Banks
description: BRUSSELS  As European officials brace for the potential of a Greek debt default, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Wednesday that she would push for more capital to protect her nations banks. And European banking regulators were trying to identify the regions most vulnerable financial institutions.

title: The Long Stagnation
description: David Brooks: Let me start with the smaller tragedy before I get to the larger one. Gov. Chris Christie will not be running for president. To me this means he will never be president. Those who hesitate the first time they have a chance to run, never win later on.

description: The Look: Frosted  a sharp white tuxedo gets a gothic spin with red lips and streaks of black hair.

title: The Small Fixes Challenge: Devising Simple Solutions to Health Problems
description: Overview | What are some local health care concerns, and what solutions can students propose to address them? In this lesson, students identify a challenge that needs to be addressed, use problem-solving strategies to devise potential solutions and seek input from the greater community through an online forum. Then they propose their ideas and seek feedback from experts.

title: Your Cheese Questions, Answered
description: Norbert Wabnig, the owner of the Cheese Store of Beverly Hills, is answering readers questions on all things cheese. Post your questions in the comments section here.

title: Amanda Hesser, You Forgot A Cookbook
description: The food writer Amanda Hesser called out a lot of her favorite cookbook authors  Heidi Swanson, Suzanne Goin, Patricia Wells, Julia Child, Mark Bittman, Marcella Hazan  in her piece for Sundays Food & Drink issue answering the question If you could have only one cookbook, what should it be?

title: Plans Announced for Movie Museum in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  The movies may finally get their museum, just not as flashy a one as originally planned.

description: Live, from Occupy Wall Street.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Greece, the Philippines, Russia and Afghanistan.

title: Deer Appear on Brooklyn Shore, in Disturbing Circumstances
description: White-tailed deer, tree-browsing icons of the suburban wildlife scene, have been making inroads in New York City. Their numbers on Staten Island have grown to the point where many residents consider them a nuisance.

title: Freddie and Fannie Reject Debt Relief
description: Home values have fallen so much in Arizona that almost half the people with mortgages there owe more than their homes are worth. So when federal money became available to help stem the tide of foreclosures, the state flagged that group for help.

title: Graphic Content | Urbanized
description: Urbanized, the latest design documentary by Gary Hustwit, had its premiere on Sept. 20 in New York (and is currently being screened around the world) and is the final in an accidental trilogy that includes Helvetica (about the ubiquitous typeface) and Objectified (about the impact of industrial and product design on commerce and the environment). Urbanized, as its title suggests, is about the design of cities. Although other films have surveyed the topic through a longer lens, Hustwits is about immediate problems  and some viable solutions.

title: Pasha Fierce
description: A collectors personal booty becomes a fantasy hotel in Fez.

title: Funny Girl Finds a Home on Broadway
description: In a display of moxie worthy of Fanny Brice herself, the producers of the coming Los Angeles revival of Funny Girl said on Wednesday they would transfer that musical to the Imperial Theater on Broadway next April  even though the show has yet to begin rehearsals.

title: The Markets Love Some Good Deal Speculation
description: Three of the biggest movers among technology stocks on Wednesday were Yahoo, Akamai Technologies and Research in Motion. What do they have in common?

title: On Our Radar: A Pipeline Lawsuit
description: Environmental groups sue the State Department and the Department of Interior in federal court in Nebraska to block the construction of the controversial Keystone XL pipeline. They say that TransCanada has already started to prepare the route for the 1,700-mile pipeline, even through federal environmental reviews are not complete. [Bloomberg News]

title: Officer Faces Charges He Abused His Authority
description: 7:23 p.m. | Updated It was the Fourth of July weekend in 2008 at the Living Room Lounge in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, when a uniformed New York police officer issued a threat: No one, he said, messes with my cousins place.

title: A Modernist Masterpiece Is About to Disappear at Kennedy Airport
description: I. M. Peis Terminal 6, originally the National Airlines Sundrome, is only weeks away from demolition.

title: Avery Clears Waivers
description: The Rangers agitator Sean Avery cleared N.H.L. waivers on Wednesday, 24 hours after the Rangers placed him there. He was assigned to the teams American Hockey League affiliate in Hartford, the Connecticut Whale.

title: Theres A Fjord In My Future
description: This conference should be interesting. They say it will be webcast live; Ill post information when the event approaches.

title: Questions and Relief at Seasons Start
description: It was another in a succession of strong years for the N.H.L.: exciting play, soaring television ratings, record revenue and the fourth straight Stanley Cup finals between traditional hockey cities. But even as the Boston Bruins were raising the silver chalice on June 15, the riot was on outside in the streets of Vancouver, a four-hour orgy of destruction that injured scores of people and caused millions of dollars in damage.

title: New Girl on Fox Keeps Drawing Viewers
description: It may be just the third week of the fall TV season, but the Tuesday night programming slate has already settled into a ratings groove. Once a wild card, New Girl on Fox is now a mainstay thanks to a full-season pickup last week and its continued perch atop the 18-to-49-year-old demographic ratings. The comedy, which stars Zooey Deschanel, lifted Fox to another overall Tuesday night win in that category. NCIS, meanwhile, fulfilled the same role it has for the last nine seasons on CBS, gathering the largest possible audience (18.9 million total viewers) while posting respectable numbers in the 18-to-49 category. The one question mark: Sarah Michelle Gellar may have to go back to vampire-slaying: her new show Ringer on CW dropped another 33 percent in what was already a dismal 18-to-49 rating. It averaged 1.5 million viewers.

title: Bahrain Orders Retrials for Medical Workers
description: Bahraini judicial authorities on Wednesday nullified the convictions and harsh prison terms given to 20 medical workers last week by a special security court prosecuting cases arising from civil unrest in the country. The medical workers were ordered released from custody, with new trials scheduled in a civilian court.

title: Land Deal Is Announced to Allow New U.N. Tower and Esplanade
description: City and state officials on Wednesday agreed to a $73 million plan that would unlock an underutilized chunk of the Manhattan waterfront between East 38th and East 60th Streets, paving the way for a new United Nations office tower and esplanade along the East River.

title: Xbox Is Now a TV Box
description: Microsoft on Wednesday announced the dawning of a new era of television. The actual announcement doesnt amount to nearly that much, but it is worth noting for what it says about our TV habits.

title: TV Chat: Ask the Critic
description: Neil Genzlinger, a television critic for The New York Times, acknowledges the ambition of the new Fox show Terra Nova, but in an exchange with readers he questioned what that really means: In TV-speak, ambitious generally means expensive. In the real sense of the word  risk-taking, ground-breaking, etc.  Terra Nova is in most ways the opposite of ambitious.

description: JACKSON, MISS.

description: Thousands of Greeks strike in the first protest since June; orchestra conductors gather before the United States Supreme Court; and homelessness declines in New York City.

title: Jurors Hear Jackson Talk of Building a Childrens Hospital
description: In a recording six weeks before he died, a slurred, barely intelligible Michael Jackson told his doctor that he dreamed of building the worlds largest childrens hospital, because I didnt have a childhood.

description: Carine Roitfeld brings the Paris collections to a close with a night of revelry fit for a vampire (or two).

description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
