title: Syrian Woman Says Reports of Her Death Were Mistaken
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The family of a Syrian woman who was reported to have been killed by armed men loyal to the government of President Bashar al-Assad, with her body later found decapitated, skinned and armless, said Wednesday that they now thought she was still alive.

title: Giuliani Ads to Promote Safety of Indian Pt.
description: 10 p.m. | Updated The operator of the Indian Point nuclear power complex has hired former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to vouch for the plants safety in a new advertising campaign scheduled to begin next week.

title: My Three Favorite Superhero Movies
description: The dirty truth that must be acknowledged before picking your three favorite superhero movies is that superhero movies are not, on the whole, very good. THATS RIGHT, NERDS  YOU HEARD ME.

title: An American Student Abroad Reflects on the Knox Verdict
description: Lily Altavena, a junior at New York University and an intern this past summer on The Choice, is studying in Florence, Italy, this fall. This is the first in an occasional series of dispatches from abroad.

title: Romney to Speak Before Controversial Figure
description: Since Mitt Romney is battling suspicion among Christian conservatives about the depth of his opposition to same-sex marriage and abortion, it is no surprise that he is joining the other major Republican candidates this week to speak at the annual Values Voters Summit, a celebration of the political aims of the religious right.

title: Michelle Obama, Iman and John Legend to Kick Off Ailey Season
description: The first lady, Michelle Obama, and the model Iman will be honorary chairwomen of the opening night gala performance of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at City Center on Nov. 30, the company said. The Ailey company also said that John Legend, the musician who has won nine Grammy Awards, will perform If Its Magic, with choreography by the companys former artistic director, Judith Jamison. This season will be the first under her successor, Robert Battle.

title: Will Siri Bring Back the iPhones Wow Factor?
description: Do you remember the first time you saw the iPhone?

title: Lens: Turkey
description: Lens: Turkey

title: The Ultimate Micromanager
description: From last weeks excellent New Yorker story by Atul Gawande on coaching, heres a resonant detail:

title: Decisive Game 5 at Stadium Calls to Mind a 2001 Series
description: Having survived Game 4 in Detroit, the Yankees will play the Tigers on Thursday night at Yankee Stadium in a deciding Game 5 of the American League division series. But while the Yankees are as much a part of October as Halloween, there is little precedent for them when it comes to playing at home in a do-or-die game in the first round.

title: Ten-Hut!
description: Rich Yeselson, writing on Ezra Kleins blog, says that my army may have arrived.

title: A Sitcom Grows Up and Finds Its Identity
description: It seems to be in the DNA of many of NBCs most memorable comedies: theyre late bloomers.

title: Rangers, Devils and Islanders Set Their Opening Night Rosters
description: Although the waiving of Sean Avery by the Rangers made headlines, there were few surprises among the three New York metropolitan area N.H.L. teams when final rosters were submitted Wednesday afternoon. In a league of one-way contracts, in which veterans are compensated equally whether they are in the N.H.L. or demoted to the minors, training camp competition is largely a myth.

title: Rescuing Neglected Composers
description: The cellist Yehuda Hanani has been fascinated in recent years with the music of Eduard Franck, a German composer who studied with Mendelssohn and was highly regarded by Schumann. During the Mendelssohn bicentenary in 2009 Mr. Hanani saw an opportunity to bring Francks music to light by programming works of both composers in the series he directs, Close Encounters With Music. Mr. Hanani revived and expanded on that idea at the Frick Collection on Tuesday evening in a program that included not only Mendelssohn and Franck scores but also a piece by Moritz Moszkowski, the turn-of-the-last-century virtuoso pianist who, it turns out, studied composition with Franck.

title: Celebrating Mandela Abstractly, With Video
description: One of these years, Mariano Riveras cutter will fail him. That great Yankees closer will prove to be mortal, and Yankee fans will have to suffer through ninth-inning anxiety, like everyone else.

title: Second Love at First Click
description: NATALIE FRIEND, a marketing contractor at NASA Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., was 65 and twice divorced when she decided to try online dating. My daughter met her husband, she explained, my friends son met his wife, my cousin met her husband  all online.

title: All the Things He Is and Isnt
description: JOEY ARIAS has a noun problem.

title: Palestinians Win a Vote on Bid to Join Unesco
description: PARIS  Despite strong opposition from the United States, Germany and several other European states, the Palestinians gained initial approval on Wednesday of a bid for full membership in Unesco  the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization  as part of their broader campaign for recognition as a state by the United Nations Security Council.

title: Asked & Answered | Picnic Magazine
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Foley Square, 4:57 P.M.
TimesCast | Greeks Protest Austerity
description: October 5, 2011 - Thousands of Greeks strike in the first protest since June, but many are disillusioned with their campaign against the country's austerity measures.

title: Shockingly Orange, Invitingly Meandering, Immensely Imposing
description: At 71 the indefatigable sculptor Richard Serra is making some of the most intensely visceral work of his career. His latest sculptures in weatherproof steel are big enough to test the boundaries of the immense Gagosian Gallery on 24th Street in Chelsea, though their power has less to do with their sheer magnitude than with the way they carve up the space.

title: Baryshnikov Packs Up His Memories in Boxes
description: Among the hundreds of video recordings that Mikhail Baryshnikov has collected over the decades are a handful that show him rehearsing with the titans of dance George Balanchine, Jerome Robbins, Martha Graham and Merce Cunningham. But perhaps the most treasured is a cloudy black-and-white clip of the 16-year-old Baryshnikov at a lesson with his revered teacher Alexander Pushkin at the Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet in St. Petersburg.

title: The Cats Table
description: He wasnt talking. He was looking from the window of the car all the way. Two adults in the front seat spoke quietly under their breath. He could have listened if he wanted to, but he didnt. For a while, at the section of the road where the river sometimes flooded, he could hear the spray of water at the wheels. They entered the Fort and the car slipped silently past the post office building and the clock tower. At this hour of the night there was barely any traffic in Colombo. They drove out along Reclamation Road, passed St. Anthonys Church, and after that he saw the last of the food stalls, each lit with a single bulb. Then they entered a vast open space that was the harbour, with only a string of lights in the distance along the pier. He got out and stood by the warmth of the car.

title: A Boys Life, Not Quite His Own
description: The Cats Table is about an 11-year-old boy, green as he could be about the world, who takes an indelible sea voyage in the early 1950s. The boys name is Michael, as is the authors, and both sailed to England from Sri Lanka; but this lovely, shimmering book of Michael Ondaatjes is no memoir. It is a tender meditation on how a child can be smuggled away accidentally, with no knowledge of the act, into the future.

title: In Paris, Piety and Purity
description: The twin themes resulted in collections bathed in incandescent white and highlighted by wimples, veils, cassocks and other mass-worthy raiment stripped down, and softened, for a modern eye.

title: Siri and Apples Future
description: Not enough hardware eye candy. That was the undertone of disappointment that surrounded the introduction of Apples new iPhone on Tuesday.

title: Plaids Notwithstanding, a Creative Surprise
description: IN Gant stores right now, you can pick up a catalog with the cover line Seasonal Stories, full of pictures of a healthy well-to-do-ish-looking family relaxing in various winter environments on what is presumably a vacation. There are ski poles and firewood and root vegetables, dark wood library shelves and distressed leather seating. Everyone is well dressed. The blazer collars are popped, even on the small boys.

title: In Paris, Piety and Purity
description: FELLINI would have been spinning (cartwheels) in his grave had he witnessed the church-y proceedings on the runways of Paris this week. Taking in those shows, you might have suspected that some designers were reprising Roma, the directors 1972 cinematic tour of the Eternal City complete with a fashion show including priests on roller skates, robotic bishops in miters and stoles, and nuns in habits made of blinking Christmas lights.

title: Cold and White: Immigrants Landscape
description: The British director John Akomfrahs Nine Muses is an unclassifiable collage of archival footage, canonical literature and severe winter landscapes. Conceptually ambitious and oblique in the extreme, its an experimental work that is difficult to unpack critically but impossible to engage without context.

title: An 18th-Century Stone Villa on the Adriatic Sea
description: A historic stone villa with five bedrooms on the Bay of Kotor in Dobrota, Montenegro, is on the market for $1.6 million.

title: Will the Aliens Be Nice? Dont Bet On It
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: House Hunting in ... Montenegro
description: AN 18TH-CENTURY STONE VILLA ON THE ADRIATIC SEA IN MONTENEGRO

title: Apples fall product announcements; rumors vs. reality for the iPhone 4s; tech news
description: Alan Yacavone of the News Technology office at The Times discusses the various product announcements made by Apple earlier this week, including the unveiling of the new iPhone 4s. Pedro Rafael Rosado explains the term virtual personal assistant. The Tip of the Week points out extra features offered by online map sites. The tech headlines of the week include Microsofts official retiring of its Zune media player, a Hotmail overhaul, and a partnership between ABC and Yahoo.

title: From the Big Bang to Today: Just the Highlights, Please
description: Its every high school students dream: Sit through one two-hour lesson and be done with history classes for life. Its also, at some point in adulthood, every grown-ups reality: I sat through all those history lessons in school, but today what I remember from them would fill up about two hours.

title: Palin Says Shes Not Running
description: UPDATE, 6:35 p.m.: Sarah Palin is not running for president.

title: Watching Out for Falling Stars, With a Smartphone in Hand
description: American stargazers could be forgiven for shaking a fist at the heavens this weekend. The Draconids meteor shower is expected to yield intense shooting-star activity, but by the time the sun sets on the United States, the action will most likely have ended.

title: The Armory Makeover
description: For the Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron, the restoration of the Park Avenue Armory is a delicate process of excavation.

title: In Los Angeles, Scaled-Back Plan for Film Museum
description: LOS ANGELES  The movies may finally get their museum, but it wont be as flashy as originally planned.

title: Huawei Wants to Sell to American Companies
description: Huawei, the Chinese computer networking company that in the past has been involved in numerous controversies with American companies and the federal government, has announced an initiative to sell its products to American businesses in the United States.

title: The Buzz
description: The Buzz

title: Tightening Your Data Belt Can Save You Money
description: The economics of an all-you-can-eat buffet are pretty easy to figure out. The restaurant makes money as long as most of the diners dont have big appetites and enormous capacity for engorgement.

title: Taking Home the Lasers, Pulsers and Sonic Care
description: ABOUT two years ago, Toby Salzman bought two hand-held gadgets that promised, if not the fountain of youth, at least a spigot: LightStim for Wrinkles ($299), which supposedly increases collagen and reduces lines by using red, amber and infrared light; and the Clarisonic Skin Cleansing System ($225), which claims to remove six times more dirt from your face than regular cleansing does.

title: Scratching the Celebrity Itch
description: TWITTER queen Lady Gaga affectionately calls her brood of fans Little Monsters; they in return swear fidelity to their Mother Monster. Rihanna, currently the most popular woman on Facebook, with more than 45,000,000 likes, enlists her troops to serve the Rihanna Navy. Katy Perry, who this year matched Michael Jacksons record of having five No. 1 songs from the same album, has her litter of Katy Kats. Then theres the rapper Nicki Minaj, who labels her female fans Barbs (after the Mattel doll) and her gay male fans Ken Barbs.

title: Kanye West, Designer (Yawn)
description: PARIS

title: Deer in the Water
description: A deer swam out of New York Harbor onto the rocks at the Brooklyn base of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge Wednesday afternoon, then returned to the water and was pulled out by police officers.

title: Cloaks: Snuggies With Panache
description: SUPERHEROES have traditionally saved the planet while wearing capes, but other do-gooders prefer a different, if related form of outerwear. Think of Sherlock Holmes, Harry Potter or Jedi warriors, all clad in cloaks.

title: Legal Marijuana Sells Vaporizers
description: RICK CUSICK, the associate publisher of the marijuana magazine High Times, remembers the first time he saw a vaporizer. It was in 2000, at a tobacco trade show in Las Vegas. I was having a party in my room at the Sahara, Mr. Cusick said, when two men walked in carrying a 50-pound drill press attached to a plywood board. The drill press had been set up with copper tubing to heat cannabis just enough so that its active ingredient, tetrahydrocannabinol, was released not as smoke but as a less scorching vapor.

title: Manhattan D.A. Is Asked to Seek to Undo 1999 Murder Conviction
description: When the police picked up Jon-Adrian Velazquez more than a dozen years ago in the killing of a retired police officer, three witnesses identified him from a lineup as the gunman.

title: Apple, Meet Facebook. Facebook, Meet Apple.
description: Id like to make anintroduction: Apple, please meet Facebook. Facebook, meet Apple.

title: In Geneva, Twin Houses Under One Roof
description: A building that houses two homes owned by two brothers, each structure with a similar layout; but the similarities end at the front door.

title: Two Families, Two Homes, One Green House
description: GENEVA  Atop a hill on the south side of Geneva, overlooking Mont Salve, is a rectangular house painted a lime green so bright that it practically glows.

title: Want an iPhone 4S? Sell, Sell, Sell
description: So you want an iPhone 4S? Do I have a deal for you.

title: Godsons of Soul Reunite to Toot Their Horns
description: Thanks to James Brown, even casual followers of rhythm and blues are on a first-name basis with the three core members of his old horn section. In one hit song after another, from the mid-1960s through the early 1970s, Brown, known as the Godfather of Soul, would address them directly, urging them on with interjections like, Hit me, Fred! or Pee Wee, take it on out! or Maceo, all right, bring your lickin stick!

title: Janet Napolitano Takes on Critics of Immigration
description: In a blunt speech on Wednesday, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano took on critics of the administrations immigration policies on both the left and right, telling Republicans that security along the border with Mexico is at an apex and rejecting calls from immigrant advocacy groups to slow the pace of deportations.

title: Detroit Still Loves Granderson, Boos Jeter
description: I noticed something interesting over the past two games at Comerica Park. There were two guys with Michigan ties playing in the Yankees starting lineup, and only one of them got any love from Tigers fans.

title: Tom Brady Cuts His Hair: Why?
description: Athletes can be superstitious about their hair, but cutting it can mean getting down to business.

title: If Samson Had This Arm ...
description: USUALLY the press conference gets the buzz going. Last week, the buzz got the press conference going.

title: $17 Million in Donations Buoy Perry Campaign
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas raised more than $17 million during the three months ended Sept. 30, his presidential campaign announced on Wednesday, a showing that is likely to outstrip most of the Republican field and could help steady a campaign battered in recent weeks by several setbacks.

title: The Values of the Bishops
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobs, Apple Co-Founder and Visionary, Is Dead
description: 8:24 p.m. | Updated  See our full obituary of Mr. Jobs.

title: United in Disdain for Dodd-Frank, Wall Street Is Split on the Details
description: While the biggest rivals on Wall Street share a common disdain for new constraints on financial risk-taking, theyre fighting over exactly how to tame the sprawling regulatory overhaul.

title: Hockey Returns
description: The N.H.L. season begins Thursday night with three games. The Rangers open the season Friday in Stockholm, Sweden, against the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Germans Weigh More Charges for Nazi Guards
description: BERLIN  German officials are considering filing charges against former Nazi death camp guards after a legal precedent set in the John Demjanjuk trial appeared to make it far easier to win a conviction more than 66 years after World War II ended.

title: Hockey Returns
description: The N.H.L. season begins Thursday night with three games. The Rangers open the season Friday in Stockholm, Sweden, against the Los Angeles Kings.

title: The Modern Arab State
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloggingheads: One-State Solution?
description: Gershom Gorenberg, left, author of The Unmaking of Israel, and Dimi Reider of +972 Magazine debate the one-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Apples Visionary Redefined Digital Age
description: Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder of Apple who helped usher in the era of personal computers and then led a cultural transformation in the way music, movies and mobile communications were experienced in the digital age, died Wednesday. He was 56.

title: Religious Groups and Bias Get the Justices Attention
description: WASHINGTON  If laws forbidding discrimination in employment applied fully to religious groups, the government could insist that the Roman Catholic Church allow women to serve as priests. If such laws do not apply to religious groups at all, a church could fire a janitor because he is black.

title: Are You Ready to Put a Foot in Your Mouth?
description: Sometimes people surprise you. For more than 20 years, Hank Williams Jr. sang his adapted version of All My Rowdy Friends Are Coming Over Tonight to open Monday Night Football. Over the years, the production values grew but the message stayed the same: Are you ready for some football? The musical bit traveled with Monday Night from ABC to ESPN. Although it has grown stale, it was harmless.

title: Is Wind Power Right for Vermont?
description: To the Editor:

title: Defendants Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Die in California Workplace Rampage
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A worker at a quarry south of San Francisco opened fire on his co-workers early Wednesday morning, killing three people and injuring six, law enforcement officials said. He fled the scene, setting off a sweeping manhunt that shut down schools and kept terrified residents locked inside their homes, then shot and wounded a woman while trying to steal her car, officials said.

title: Seeking Energy, Unions Join Protest Against Wall Street
description: Stuart Appelbaum, an influential union leader in New York City, was in Tunisia last month, advising the fledgling labor movement there, when he received a flurry of phone calls and e-mails alerting him to the rumblings of something back home. Protesters united under a provocative name, Occupy Wall Street, were gathering in a Lower Manhattan park and raising issues long dear to organized labor.

title: In New England, the Small Guy With the Big Numbers
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The numbers are eye-popping, even by the standards of a video game: 160 catches for 2,464 yards.

title: For U.S., a Tricky Path in Dealing With Afghan Insurgents
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas national security adviser met secretly in the Persian Gulf last weekend with Pakistans top military officer to deliver a tough message: rein in the Haqqani network, a deadly insurgent group in Afghanistan that the United States says has close ties to Pakistans main spy agency.

title: Grandersons Catches Add to October Lore
description: Talk about fast hands and professional skills: on Wednesday morning, just a few hours after Curtis Grandersons magnificent evening in center field, I was at the gate for the flight from Detroit back to New York, surrounded by other sleepy souls.

title: Refused and Confused
description: The refusal by an upstate New York town clerk to sign marriage licenses for same-sex couples, as reported on the front page of The Times last week, can be seen simply as a discordant footnote to the march of marriage equality in New York State. But seen in a broader context, it is also more than that.

title: Doctors Urge N.Y. to Weigh Health Risks of Fracking
description: New Yorks environmental study of the possible risks of high-volume hydraulic fracturing, a technique for natural gas drilling, addresses everything from the possible impact on job creation and the character of communities to damage to roads and wildlife. But a group of doctors, medical associations and environmental groups say there is one glaring omission: the possible effects on public health.

title: The Height of Fashion, Six Floors Under
description: PARIS

title: The Height of Fashion, Six Floors Under
description: Already a must-see, must-experience club, inspired by the American filmmakers Mulholland Drive.

title: In a Maine House, No Room to Waste
description: PRETTY MARSH, Me.

title: Making Over a Maine Cabin
description: On Mount Desert Island, a couple turned a small cabin boxed in by severe zoning restrictions into a bright and open vacation house.

title: Shopping for Tea Accessories
description: Barbara Barry, an interior designer, shopped for elegant strainers, spoons and other accessories.

title: Milton Resnick and Pat Passlofs Synagogue Art Studios
description: Inside the former synagogues on the Lower East Side where Ms. Passlof lives and works, and where her husband, Mr. Resnick, did the same until his death.

title: Sami Hayeks Contradictory Desk
description: The Ceniza desk is a mix of rough and soft textures: the back is made of wood (reclaimed Douglas fir from old barns in the Midwest, whitewashed ash or walnut), while the front is covered in leather, flannel or vinyl. (The desk above is ash and leather.)

title: Resurrecting Lamps by Aalto and Utzon
description: The Finnish company Artek is resurrecting two lamps by Midcentury Modern architects. The A808 floor lamp ($2,950 to $3,530), pictured, designed by Alvar Aalto in the 1950s, has been out of production since the late 1990s.

title: Smart-Home Systems Go Mainstream
description: I SUSPECT that our species has been longing for smart homes since prehistoric times. John Q. Caveman is in one corner of his cave, about to retire after a long day of gathering (hes never been the hunting type), and suddenly, a needling worry becomes lodged in his mind: Did he put out the fire in front of the cave? He vaguely remembers doing so, but what if hes thinking of last night, not tonight?

title: Tea Accessories
description: BARBARA BARRY, the Los Angeles-based interior designer, has created a range of products, including furniture, tableware, bedding and even luggage. But one of her favorite projects had nothing to do with design.

title: For Air-Conditioners, Time to Hibernate
description: Its time to retire that ugly window air-conditioner for the winter. But you dont have to take it out yourself. A number of companies around the city will remove, clean and store air-conditioners, reinstalling them in the spring.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. I have a number of high-end lighting fixtures. Should I leave them in the apartment as a selling feature, or can I take them with me?

title: The Race to Grow the One-Ton Pumpkin
description: DES MOINES

title: Sales at Room & Board, Mxyplyzyk and Others
description: Bongenre melamine tableware is half off, through Oct. 13 (Anya Susani plates, originally $65, are about $33); information: bongenre.com.

title: Two Eames Grandchildren on Charles and Rays Living Room
description: The Eames House was assembled in Los Angeles in 1949, almost like a kit of parts, combining off-the-shelf steel elements with panels of glass, metal, stucco and other materials, some in primary colors. The husband-and-wife team Charles and Ray Eames  titans of modern design who were becoming known for their innovative furniture, as well as their contributions to architecture, film and industrial and graphic design  created it as a home for themselves, in a eucalyptus grove in Pacific Palisades.

title: His and Hers Synagogues on the Lower East Side
description: IN Milton Resnicks living quarters, a spare cube built over a soaring, two-story studio space in a former synagogue on Eldridge Street in Manhattan, the monastic iron bed, as narrow as a childs cot, is unmade, a tangle of sheets at the headboard. But on a garment rack in a closet, worn tweed jackets hang expectantly. Theres a cane next to the bed, and in the paint-flecked mini-studio, the walls are covered with bright, kinetic paintings, pencil sketches on lined Manila paper and photographs.

title: Still House Opens in the East Village
description: Urte Tylaite wanted Still House, her new store in the East Village, to be a kind of cabinet of curiosities.

title: Brewers Test Arizonas Rookie Slugger, and He Passes
description: PHOENIX  The decision to pitch to Paul Goldschmidt still hung over Milwaukee Brewers Manager Ron Roenicke, so much that Roenicke asked the first question at his postgame interview session Tuesday.

title: When I Needed Help, I Got Propaganda
description: Mankato, Minn.

title: Patient Data Landed Online After a Series of Missteps
description: Private medical data for nearly 20,000 emergency room patients at Californias prestigious Stanford Hospital were exposed to public view for nearly a year because a billing contractors marketing agent sent the electronic spreadsheet to a job prospect as part of a skills test, the hospital and contractors confirmed this week. The applicant then sought help by unwittingly posting the confidential data on a tutoring Web site.

title: A Look Back at Steve Jobs
description: Steven P. Jobs of Apple, who died of cancer on Wednesday, was a visionary who made the technology company he co-founded one of the worlds biggest.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Oct. 6
description: Lori Leven, the owner of Love, Adorned in NoLIta answers questions; a new pair of leggings; Harry Potter inspired satchels and more.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: N.B.A. Star Travels a Long Way for a Loss
description: MONS, Belgium  As N.B.A. players and owners struggled to prevent a labor dispute from disrupting the regular season, one star player did something novel: he played in a basketball game that mattered.

title: Breyer and Scalia Testify at Senate Judiciary Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Justices Stephen G. Breyer and Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court crossed Constitution Avenue on Wednesday to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the role of judges under the Constitution, offering unscripted responses on issues like conflicts of interest and cameras in the courtroom.

title: Local Hospitals Raise Objections as Sloan-Kettering Plans a Westchester Expansion
description: Local hospitals in Westchester County and New York Citys other northern suburbs are locked in a battle with a huge Manhattan-based cancer center as it looks to increase its presence in the affluent suburban market.

title: Europe Tries to Stave Off a Reckoning
description: BRUSSELS  Many around the world are worried that Europe is about to face a Lehman Brothers moment, a big bankruptcy or sudden default that sets off a new phase of panic in Europe and beyond.

title: Flying Chariot of the Wealthy, Noisy Bane of the Earthbound
description: Fluttering off their waterfront launching pads, the whirring helicopters dance through the citys skies. They whisk in corporate executives and hurry travelers to the airports (those agreeable to a $1,750 minimum charge). They escort tourists on speedy sightseeing trips, go up to report the news and how traffic isnt moving. They carry time-sensitive documents to Wall Street.

title: Battle for Libya | Oct. 5, 2011
description: Former rebel forces used tanks and heavy artillery in an attack on Surt, the birthplace of Libyas deposed leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi; at Sidi Hamed cemetery in Tripoli, anti-Qaddafi fighters say they have found evidence of a mass grave.

title: Relying on a Rookie
description: Last Saturday afternoon, as the Yankees prepared for the resumption of Game 1 of their American League division series, Andy Pettitte arrived in the home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium to visit with his old teammates.

title: Steve Jobs, From Computers to Tablets
description: Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder and former chief executive of Apple, has died at 56.

title: N.B.A. Players Rejecting a 50-50 Split of Revenue
description: Before they walked away from each other and plunged the N.B.A. into limbo, owners and players discussed the most basic, equitable-sounding solution to their conflict: a 50-50 split of league revenue.

title: All Quiet on the Southern Front
description: El Paso

title: Batting Seventh, Leading Cardinals to Game 5
description: ST. LOUIS  One night after Ben Francisco emerged as an unlikely hero for the Philadelphia Phillies, an unheralded player in the opposing dugout took his own star turn.

title: Wheres the Jobs Bill?
description: When Eric Cantor, the House Republican leader, predictably said that President Obamas jobs bill was dead on arrival in his chamber, and would not even be debated, the president  in a break from his usual forbearance  lashed right back at him. Does he not believe in rebuilding Americas roads and bridges? Mr. Obama asked on Tuesday. Does Mr. Cantor oppose rehiring teachers or construction workers, he continued, or giving tax breaks to businesses that hire?

title: In Supreme Court Argument, a Rock Legend Plays a Role
description: WASHINGTON  Jimi Hendrix made an appearance at the Supreme Court on Wednesday in an argument over whether Congress acted constitutionally in 1994 by restoring copyright protection to foreign works that had once been in the public domain. The affected works included films by Alfred Hitchcock and Federico Fellini, books by C. S. Lewis and Virginia Woolf, symphonies by Prokofiev and Stravinsky and paintings by Picasso.

title: Former Star Had Disease Linked to Brain Trauma
description: Rick Martin, the former N.H.L. star, had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a neurodegenerative disease linked to repeated brain trauma, when he died last March of a heart attack at age 59.

title: Steven P. Jobs: His Life, His Companies, His Products
description: Steven P. Jobs, who died Oct. 5, 2011, co-founded Apple, popularized the personal computer, made music accessible and revolutionized the cellphone industry.

title: Surgery Rate Late in Life Surprises Researchers
description: Surgery is surprisingly common in older people during the last year, month and even week of life, researchers reported Wednesday, a finding that is likely to stoke, but not resolve, the debate over whether medical care is overused and needlessly driving up medical costs.

title: As School Layoffs Loom, City Points Finger at Union Chief, Who Points Right Back
description: With more than 700 school aides facing their last day at work on Friday barring a last-minute deal, the Bloomberg administration is blaming the school aides powerful labor union, District Council 37, for not doing enough to prevent the layoffs.

title: Details Emerge on Draft of Volcker Rule
description: Federal regulators are planning to vote next week on plans to prohibit banks from making certain lucrative, yet risky trades, the latest step toward reining in risk-taking on Wall Street in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

title: Details of Home Sale Emerge in Consultants Trial for Theft
description: It was December 2008 when John F. Haggerty Jr. agreed to buy out his brothers stake in their dead fathers home in Queens.

title: Years of Atonement
description: For the last 18 years, my mother and I have spent Yom Kippur, the holiest day of the Jewish calendar, at Tods Point beach in Old Greenwich, Conn., near where I grew up and where my mother still lives. Im a TV producer living in Brooklyn now, but I still go back every year. My mom reads my fathers old prayer book while I order lunch for us from the greasy concession stand that stays open into the fall, double hamburgers with grilled onions and French fries.

title: Woods Looks at His Return as a Chance at Much More
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.  After a 54-day layoff from competitive golf, Tiger Woods stepped to the first tee at CordeValle Golf Club on Wednesday morning and hit his first drive left of the fairway.

title: Hell on Rails
description: Few things say urban mass misery more vividly than a breakdown on the Long Island Rail Road, the nations oldest, largest and, lately, most trouble-prone commuter railroad. Last Thursday, lightning fried the signal system at the Jamaica Station hub in Queens, shutting service out of Penn Station at the height of rush hour. Soon after, a still-unexplained signal failure stopped all trains going east of Jamaica. Workers with mallets and spikes trudged out to the tracks to hammer stuck signals into place, a 19th-century response to a 21st-century debacle.

title: Jobs Frequently Consulted With Disney Chief
description: Steve Jobss death leaves an open seat on the board of the Walt Disney Company, which he joined in 2006 when he sold Pixar Animation Studio to Disney for $7.4 billion. The deal also made Mr. Jobs Disneys biggest shareholder. Although he frequently consulted with Robert A. Iger, Disneys chief executive, Mr. Jobs was not a frequent presence at board meetings, a fact that drew some criticism from people concerned with corporate governance.

title: A Candidate Writing His Own Campaign Rules
description: On a whirlwind trip through New York City this week that marked the beginning of a nearly monthlong book tour, Herman Cain chatted with the hosts of ABCs The View, promoted his new memoir on Fox News, met local titans like Donald Trump, shared ideas with former Mayor Edward I. Koch and enjoyed power lunching in Midtown.

title: Is Israel Its Own Worst Enemy?
description: For decades, Palestinian leaders sometimes seemed to be their own peoples worst enemies.

title: Reaction to Steve Jobss Death
description: On Wednesday night, Bits followed reaction to the death of Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder and former chief executive of Apple, who has died at 56.

title: Jets Hope Mangold Can Lift Running Game Against Patriots
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Nick Mangold practiced Wednesday and said he felt much better than he did last week. An entire team and its more-somber-than-usual head coach all but rejoiced.

title: Jobs Biography Is Highly Anticipated
description: For months, a biography of Steven P. Jobs has been one of themost highly anticipated books of the year.

title: Focused Manning Is the Calm in the Giants Hurry-Up Storm
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tight end Jake Ballard has very much enjoyed watching Eli Manning direct the Giants offense in the fourth quarter for the past two weeks, but Ballard, in his first N.F.L. season, opened his eyes wide Wednesday when asked if he could imagine trying to do Mannings job himself.

title: Gleaming City Rising From Ruins Cant Hide Psychic Scars of a War
description: GROZNY, Russia  A spectacular complex of high-rise towers was inaugurated Wednesday in what once was the war-torn city of Grozny, with banners and flashing lights and celebrity guests including Vanessa-Mae on the violin.

title: Rebirth for Soap Operas, and a Career
description: LOS ANGELES  A decade ago, Jeff Kwatinetz was one of Hollywoods fastest rising executives, a whiz kid from Chicago with a keen ear for rock bands and an eerie ability to foresee how the music business would evolve.

title: Desperately Seeking Dalrymple
description: I know you couldnt care less about Sarah Palin bowing out of the presidential race, but let me ask you this: Who wants to spend the next 13 months watching Mitt Romney run against Barack Obama? Can I see a show of hands?

title: After Setbacks in Harvesting Stem Cells, a New Approach Shows Promise
description: Stem cell research has had many ups and downs, but a stream of setbacks had left researchers almost back at square one.

title: Thursday: So This Puzzle Walks Into a Bar
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Trust me, youve heard the joke before. Even so, it might get a snicker out of you; thats how silly it is. But that you have to kind of guess the content of the theme and work those Down entries to piece it together is what makes this a Thursday and not an early week puzzle.

title: Fraud and Online Learning
description: Online college courses have made higher education possible for untold numbers of working adults who cannot enroll in traditional classes and need flexibility to receive instruction at home. But online courses are also particularly vulnerable to student aid fraud, a growing problem that federal officials must move quickly to control.

title: Council Speaker, Pulled 2 Ways on Wage Bill, Delays Taking a Stand
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, facing conflicting pressures from her longtime labor allies and her new supporters in the business community, said Wednesday that she was not ready to take a position on a controversial proposal that would require employers who benefit from city subsidies to pay workers higher wages.

title: Breaking a Silence, and Offering a Softer Portrait of a Slain Brother
description: He has cut a plaintive and hulking figure at the murder trial, shaking his head emphatically and tut-tutting under his breath, a quiet but definite reminder of his twin brother, Raymond, the former police sergeant killed by his wife in a hail of 11 bullets.

title: Accountability Avoidance
description: By a 6-to-6 vote last month, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit cleared the way for a legal challenge against a dubious legacy of the George W. Bush administration: the wiretapping of Americans international communications without a warrant or adequate judicial supervision in antiterrorism investigations.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,784 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: With Rare Double U.N. Veto on Syria, Russia and China Try to Shield Friend
description: UNITED NATIONS  By vetoing a Security Council resolution condemning Syria for its oppression of antigovernment forces, Russia and China effectively tossed a life preserver to President Bashar al-Assad, seemingly unwilling to see a pivotal ally and once stalwart member of the socialist bloc sink beneath the waves of the Arab Spring.

title: Lottery Numbers
Cancer Surgery for Red Storms Lavin
description: St. Johns basketball Coach Steve Lavin will have prostate cancer surgery on Thursday. With practice beginning Oct. 15, it is unknown how much time, if any, the 47-year-old Lavin will miss while recovering. The operation will take place at Sloan-Kettering in New York.

title: Washington: 20 Arrested in Park
description: About 20 people were arrested Wednesday afternoon after a five-day occupation of Westlake Park in downtown Seattle. The activists, members of the fledgling group Occupy Seattle, followed the example of protesters demonstrating in New York against corporate power on Wall Street and set up tarps, tents and a makeshift first aid area. The police moved in after park rangers asked the group to pack up.

title: Pilot Cites Engine Failure in Copter Crash; Early Inquiry Inconclusive
description: The pilot of the helicopter that plunged into the East River on Tuesday, killing one passenger, told his wife and a fellow pilot afterward that a mechanical problem had doomed his craft, which crashed moments after takeoff.

title: Surgery at the End of Life
description: A study looks at the number of Medicare patients who underwent surgery in the last year of life.

title: How Occupy Wall Street Turned Zuccotti Park Into a Protest Camp
description: Transforming a New York City park into a protest operations center.

title: Sabathia? Perhaps. Verlander? Nope.
description: If Game 5 of the Yankees-Tigers American League division series is close in the late innings Thursday night, C.C. Sabathia could pitch for the Yankees, Manager Joe Girardi said. But Justin Verlander will not be available for Detroit, according to Manager Jim Leyland.

title: Alabama: Immigration Law to Stay in Place During Appeal
description: A federal judge has refused to block Alabamas strict new immigration law while the Obama administration appeals a ruling last week that upholds major portions of it. Judge Sharon Lovelace Blackburn of United States District Court had upheld provisions allowing the police to ask for immigration papers during routine traffic stops and requiring schools to learn the immigration status of students when they register, as well as making most contracts with illegal immigrants unenforceable. The Obama administration and other groups oppose the law, and the administration sought to block enforcement during appeals. Judge Blackburn said that the Justice Department had not shown that the government was likely to prevail on appeal, a standard for issuing a stay.

title: Jobs on Design, Starting Over and the Value of Death
description: If youre not among the 6 million or so people whove listened to or read Steve Jobs 2005 commencement speech at Stanford University  a year after he was diagnosed with cancer  I encourage you to join the crowd. It was potent when I first watched it and particularly powerful this evening, given his passing.

title: No Presidential Candidate From Egypt Military, Officer Says
description: CAIRO  The top officer of the military council now ruling Egypt said Wednesday that the military would not offer a candidate to be Egypts next president. His remarks appeared to be an attempt to end a frenzy of speculation that erupted after state television recently broadcast an image of him walking the streets in a civilian suit and tie.

title: Modifying an Old Technique
description: Researchers have developed a method to more reliably produce human embryonic stem cells.

title: A Tough Balancing Act Remains Ahead for Apple
description: As the high-tech industry mourns the death of Steven P. Jobs, Apples executives will face the challenge of how to keep its streak of hit products going while avoiding the problems that have befallen other companies that lost their beloved founders.

title: Final Cut Pro X Gains Features Last Found in a Predecessor
description: Video editing pros have been up in arms because Apple removed some important features from its well-liked editing software, Final Cut. Well, editors, you can lower your weapons, a least a bit.

title: Heavy Traffic and New Computer System Disrupted Web Site, Bank of America Says
description: After nearly a week of interruptions and slowdowns that made its Web site inaccessible at times, Bank of America said Wednesday the problems stemmed from a combination of heavy traffic along with the rollout of a new computer system.

title: Sarkis G. Soghanalian, an Arms Dealer Who Aided U.S. Intelligence, Dies at 82
description: Sarkis G. Soghanalian, a larger-than-life arms dealer who provided weapons to Saddam Hussein and many other dictators and rebels, worked closely with American intelligence and later told his story on television, died early Wednesday in Hialeah, Fla. He was 82.

title: Reader Memories of Steve Jobs
description: We asked our readers to submit their best memories and tributes to Steve Jobs. Here are their photos.

title: App Turns Tables on iPhone Thief
description: To the snatch-and-grab robbers who prowl the citys streets and subways, the iPhone is an attractive target: ubiquitous, expensive and easily recognizable from across the street.

title: The Legacy of Steve Jobs
description: As the founder of Apple, Steven P. Jobs transformed the personal computer and created a series of revolutionary products that extended computing into every nook and cranny of our culture.

title: Israel: Envoy to Washington Fired Over Leak to a Newspaper
description: Israel dismissed its deputy ambassador to Washington over allegations that he leaked top-secret information to an Israeli journalist, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said Wednesday. The diplomat, Dan Arbel, a senior civil servant, faces a disciplinary procedure in Jerusalem. The alleged leak occurred more than two years ago, before he arrived in Washington. The case involves information related to Iran that apparently angered the United States. In December 2009, a top ministry official, Alon Bar, was suspended on suspicion of having given the information to a reporter for the newspaper Haaretz. Mr. Bar was exonerated and is now the ambassador to Spain. The investigation continued and led to Mr. Arbel, the ministry said.

title: Liberia: Ruling Favors President
description: Uncertainty hanging over Liberias imminent presidential election ended Wednesday when the Supreme Court threw out a challenge to the incumbent, Africas first woman to be elected as head of state, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, left, along with her principal rivals. The civil war here, lasting more than a decade, had scattered the countrys political class, and a small opposition party said that Mrs. Johnson Sirleaf violated a constitutional clause requiring candidates be residents for 10 years before the election, which is next Tuesday. But the court said the Constitutions authors could not have foreseen the extended conflict into which the country plunged. We considered the suit frivolous from the beginning, a spokesman for the presidents party said; the opposition politician who filed it, Simeon Freeman, criticized the decision as political.

title: On Twitter, Reflecting on the Legacy of Steve Jobs
description: We asked our Twitter followers on @nytimes to discuss the impact of Steve Jobs work using the hashtag #SteveJobsLegacy. Below is a selection of the response we received. Please continue to share your thoughts by tweeting to us at @nytimes using #SteveJobsLegacy.

title: He Pushed a Reluctant Industry Toward Digital Music
description: 11:44 p.m. | Updated Digital music is now perhaps the biggest priority in the music industry. It is the future model looked to by struggling record labels and the foundation of big-thinking start-up companies that, by at least one count, have raised more than $400 million in investment so far this year.

title: Chile: Proposal to Curb Protesters
description: President Sebastin Piera sent a bill to Congress Tuesday night calling for a strengthening of Chiles penal code, a move aimed at further repressing large student protests that have led his governments popularity to plummet. The bill, which is expected to face a stiff challenge from the opposition Concertacin coalition, would set prison sentences of up to three years for anyone who occupied public or private institutions like schools or universities, and it would also penalize other forms of demonstration. Since May, students have occupied more than 200 institutions of learning. They are demanding a range of reforms, chief among them a return to widely available free public college education that existed before the 17-year dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Corrections: October 6
description: NATIONAL

title: Jobss Death Draws Outpouring of Grief and Tributes
description: Artist, role model, innovator, life-changer. Those words popped up repeatedly on Wednesday in the outpouring of emotional responses to the death of Steve Jobs.

title: Bert Jansch, an Influential Folk Guitarist, Is Dead at 67
description: Bert Jansch, a guitarist whose blend of classical, jazz, blues and traditional British folk music inspired a long list of folk and rock guitarists in the 1960s and 70s, including Donovan, Jimmy Page, Neil Young and Paul Simon, died on Wednesday in London. He was 67.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
description: Top leaders of the Congress Party are questioning one of the United Progressive Alliance governments most significant achievements of its last term, the Right to Information Act.Salman Kurshid, Indias law minister, advocates amending the popular RTI act to prevent it from misuse that is affecting institutional efficacy and efficiency. The law, which allows citizen scrutiny of almost all government functions, has often been the target of efforts to limit its authority. (Indian Express)Indias army chief sounded the alarm over 4,000 Chinese construction workers, including some combat engineers from the Peoples Liberation Army, in the portion of Kashmir controlled by Pakistan. India has asked China to stop working on infrastructure projects inside Pakistan-controlled Kashmir, the Times of India reports. The warm relationship between Pakistan and China worries India, which fears being encircled by China and its allies.

title: Recipes: Baked, Sauted, Fried or Roasted Apples
description: Cooking an apple can turn this stalwart fruit into a culinary star.

title: How You Like Them (Cooked) Apples?
description: When you transform an apple by cooking, you may make it soft, fluffy, chewy, savory, sweet or creamy  the potential is enormous. Yes, an apple loses some juiciness and freshness when you cook it, but as an ingredient its just as versatile as a potato. (You probably know that in French the potato is called pomme de terre, or apple of the earth.) The surprise from a raw apple comes from the variety and the season, whereas the surprise from a cooked apple comes from what you do with it.

title: Court Says Regulator Exceeded Its Power
description: A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday that Finra, an important regulator of Wall Street for more than 70 years, does not have the right to take its members to court to enforce its disciplinary actions.

title: Word of the Day | meditation
description: meditation \me-d-ta-shn\ noun

title: Strong Retail Sales Send Issues Higher for 3rd Day
description: Wall Street registered gains for the third consecutive day on Thursday, following European stocks higher after central banks in Europe took action to increase liquidity. Economic data, including retail sales, also showed an American economy that is performing better than expected.

title: Group Opposed to Pipeline Seeks More Documents on Lobbyists
description: Friends of the Earth, an environmental group, expanded its Freedom of Information Act request concerning the State Departments evaluation of the Keystone XL pipeline proposal, which involves the construction of a new pipeline to carry crude from Canadian oil sands to the Gulf Coast. The environmental groups original request had centered on communication between the State Department and Paul Elliott, the chief Washington lobbyist for TransCanada, the pipeline company. Mr. Elliott was a senior official in Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clintons 2008 presidential bid. On Wednesday, the group expanded its request to cover several other lobbyists now working for TransCanada who held senior positions for Mrs. Clinton and President Obama during their campaigns. These include Jeff Berman of Bryan Cave LLC, who was national delegate director for the Obama presidential campaign. Environmental groups say the administration has shown a bias toward approving the pipeline as a result of such ties. ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

title: How to Sell Social Change? Put the Message in a Movie
description: THE widespread changes in consumer behavior and technology that are prompting marketers to rethink how they sell products are much on the minds of Madison Avenue. That was underlined on Wednesday by spirited discussions during the third day of Advertising Week 2011.

title: E-Mails Suggest White House Weighed a 2nd Solyndra Loan Worth Almost Half a Billion Dollars
description: WASHINGTON  Early last year, the Obama administration was so optimistic about the business prospects of Solyndra, the solar equipment manufacturer that declared bankruptcy last month after receiving a $528 million government loan, that officials entertained the possibility of giving the California company a second loan of almost half a billion dollars, according to internal e-mails.

title: Derrick Bell, Law Professor and Rights Advocate, Dies at 80
description: Derrick Bell, a legal scholar who saw persistent racism in America and sought to expose it through books, articles and provocative career moves  he gave up a Harvard Law School professorship to protest the schools hiring practices  died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: Once Again, Thunder in the Desert
description: PHOENIX  The scenario was frozen in time from the previous night as Ryan Roberts stood in the on-deck circle. The bases again were loaded with Arizona Diamondbacks, this time in the first inning, and Roberts watched intently as Paul Goldschmidt stared at the possibility of belting a grand slam in consecutive playoff games.

title: A Tribute, With iPhones
description: At 9 p.m. on Wednesday in San Francisco, a few dozen start-up entrepreneurs, Apple employees and iPhone fans gathered in Dolores Park, the four-square-block park in the middle of the citys Mission district, home to hipsters and artists tethered to their MacBooks and iPhones.

title: A Manifesto for Wall Street Protesters
Aiming for the Other One Billion
description: DataWind, the company behind the $35 tablet computer unveiled by the Indian government on Wednesday, hopes to spark an Internet revolution in the country.

title: Steve Jobs: Imitated, Never Duplicated
description: Wednesday evening, Apple broke the news that Steve Jobs had died.

title: News Quiz | October 6, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Oct. 6, 1981 | Egypts Anwar Sadat Is Killed
description: On Oct. 6, 1981, President Anwar Sadat of Egypt was shot to death by Islamic militants during a military parade. The assassination occurred when a truck carrying the Army officer Khalid Islambouli stopped in front of the presidents reviewing stand; Mr. Islambouli began hurling grenades toward Mr. Sadat, and three other extremists fired indiscriminately into the crowd, killing Mr. Sadat and 11 others.

title: Anglican Leader to Seek Meeting With Mugabe
description: LONDON  The Most Rev. Rowan Williams, archbishop of Canterbury, will travel to Zimbabwe this weekend as part of an African tour and will seek to persuade President Robert G. Mugabe to help end a rift among the countrys Anglicans, according to the archbishops office here.

title: The 4-Trillion-Euro Fantasy
description: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Breyer Invited to Make a Case for Architecture
description: WASHINGTON  True, he helped devise a suitable design for the federal courthouse in Boston several years ago. And he did write the foreword to a book called Celebrating the Courthouse: A Guide for Architects, Their Clients, and the Public.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 6, 2011
description: The question was written by Susan Behrens, author of Grammar: A Pocket Guide. It comes from the article, Pathogens May Change, but the Fear Is the Same.

title: Possible Answer to the Button Question in Suzuka
description: SUZUKA, Japan  As I predicted in this space on Wednesday, everyone in the paddock wants to know what the new multi-year contract for Jenson Button at McLaren Mercedes means. During an official press conference with several drivers on Thursday, Button refused to give any more information when the interviewer asked for more details about the terms of the contract.

title: Possible Answer to the Button Question in Suzuka
description: SUZUKA, Japan  As I predicted in this space on Wednesday, everyone in the paddock wants to know what the new multi-year contract for Jenson Button at McLaren Mercedes means. During an official press conference with several drivers on Thursday, Button refused to give any more information when the interviewer asked for more details about the terms of the contract.

title: Stay Hungry. Stay Foolish.
description: WHO made public statements acknowledging the accomplishments of Steve Jobs upon hearing the news of his death?

title: Are Children of Illegal Immigrants Entitled to a Public Education?
description: A new Alabama immigration enforcement law requires schools to ascertain the immigration status of students at registration. Since the announcement, officials have noticed that 5 percent of the states Hispanic children are absent from classrooms. Do the children of illegal immigrants have the right to a public education? Why or why not?

title: The Early Word: The Populist Chord
description: Todays Times:

title: 2-on-1: Are Rangers Stanley Cup Contenders, or Just a Good Hockey Club?
description: In the second installment of our season preview conversations, Jeff Z. Klein and Christopher Botta discuss the Rangers, whose season opens Friday in Stockholm against the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Tony Blair, the Unlikely Godfather
description: Many have compared the mood of England when you became prime minister in 1997 to the euphoria that greeted Barack Obamas election. Did you imagine what Obama was thinking on election night?  I knew exactly what hed be feeling. When youre fighting to win, your time line is focused on the victory. The moment you know youve got the victory is just, literally, like entering into a new, very unfamiliar territory thats got lots of flashing lights, and it can be very hard to feel comfortable at first. I spent my first few months in office mostly anxious because of the weight of the responsibility and my awareness of my own ignorance.

title: Berlin Club Gives New Meaning to Dining at Home
description: In a dimly lit room, a table is set for 14 hungry strangers. Flutes of prosecco and small plates of fried green tomatoes appear and relieve the predinner tension as guests  Berliners and travelers alike  sip, sample and chat. The aroma of bone marrow, pork belly and roasted squash floats in from the kitchen to the table, courtesy of Natalie Mouzarkel, the chef. This is the Owling Supper Club  a restaurant within a home, and, to a degree, a secret.

title: Driving the Remains of Sicilys Targa Florio Circuit
description: CERDA, Italy  Just three miles north of this Sicilian village, on old Highway 120, theres an incongruous wide spot in the road where several crumbling buildings sit behind a wire fence intended to keep the curious and mischievous out.

title: Q&A: Whipping Up an Index in Microsoft Word
description: Q.

title: At Rugby World Cup, No Need to Change What Works
description: WELLINGTON  Forty games have been played and 2,022 points and 242 tries scored, but for the eight teams left standing at the Rugby World Cup, the real business starts this weekend.

title: Suggestions for a New Monday Night Football Theme
description: It seems so simple. There are six words to live by for anyone speaking for public consumption: Do not compare anyone to Hitler.

title: Overcoming the Fear Factor in Pricing
description: My fellow blogger Paul Downs recently wrote an interesting post that described his ongoing struggle with developing a pricing strategy. He is hardly alone.

title: Vows: Michelle Rosen and David Zornitsky
description: Michelle Rosen and David Zornitsky celebrate their taste for the sweeter things in life with a wedding at Dylans Candy Bar in New York.

title: A Modern Masterpiece, No Longer Used, Will Soon Disappear at Kennedy Airport
description: While ABC has conspicuously begun to celebrate the early jet age, the Port Authority has begun to tear it down.

title: Central Banks Take Different Tacks on Europes Economy
description: BERLIN  The European Central Bank increased aid to cash-strapped financial institutions Thursday, but disappointed those expecting more drastic measures to combat slowing growth and address a deepening bank emergency.

title: Australian Coal Miner Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: The New Hope Corporation, an Australian coal miner, officially put itself on the block after receiving proposals from a number of interested parties.

title: The Jets and Jones-Drew
description: With the N.F.L.s trade deadline approaching (Oct. 18) and the Jets in need of a jolt, should they be among the teams looking to buy? If so, Jacksonville could be a place to look.

title: Which of Steve Jobss Products Mattered Most?
description: Most inventors and business leaders are lucky if they create one product that changes the way people do things. Steve Jobs helped create several. Which of his products had the greatest impact on you?

title: Swedish Poet Wins Nobel Prize for Literature
description: Tomas Transtromer, a Swedish poet whose sometimes bleak but graceful work explores themes of isolation, emotion and identity while remaining rooted in the commonplace, won the Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday.

title: Breakup Proposals for Dexia Begin to Emerge
description: 8:06 p.m. | Updated

title: Palins Impact on 2012 Remains Elusive
description: Sarah Palin has ended speculation about her presidential intentions for 2012. But her impact on the election remains to be seen.

title: Inside Knowledge for All You Outsiders
description: IN 1988 The New York Review of Books dispatched Joan Didion to report on the presidential election, an assignment that resulted in a classic essay on the modern way of campaigning titled Insider Baseball. Over the years that phrase  usually in a snappier, syntactically dubious variation, without the R  has become both a clich and a cultural principle. Inside baseball could be the name of a multimedia genre, a mode of storytelling focused, above all, on that mysterious thing called process.

title: Rocking Away the Rolls
description: Through her Web site, bodyrock.tv, the abdominally flawless Zuzana Light, 29, has become something of a fitness fetish. Her calorie-clobbering workouts are watched on YouTube by about 25 million visitors each month. Yet just five years ago, she was emotionally adrift in her native Prague, earning her keep as a nude model. It was an incredibly humiliating situation, she said. On vacation, she met her future husband and partner, Frederick Light, who brought her back to Ontario, where the couple worked at a flower shop and filmed exercise videos in their free time. Lights workout relies on short, intense exercises that riff on the burpee, a suicide sequence of squats, push-ups and jumping thats catching on at gyms across the country.

title: Echoes of 1891: Tchaikovsky? Sure
description: Carnegie Hall, to begin its new season on Wednesday evening, picked up pretty much where it had left off in the old one: still fixated, for whatever reason, on the 120th anniversary of the halls opening.

title: Its Never Really Dead in Zombieland
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Estranged Bedfellows
description: Mike Morris, the governor of Pennsylvania in The Ides of March, is an image of the liberal hearts desire, and not only because he is played by George Clooney. Morris, who keeps his cool while inflaming the passions of Democratic primary voters, is a committed environmentalist and a forthright secularist who sidesteps questions about his faith by professing that his religion is the United States Constitution. He is against war and in favor of jobs, though the economy figures much less in his fictitious campaign than it will in the real one just around the corner.

title: Opening Private Gardens to the Public
description: More than 100 private gardens in the region will be open to the public for at least one day this year as part of the Garden Conservancy Open Days Program.

title: Facebook Gets a Past
description: Everyone gets old. Even the clever young men who created Facebook, which is why Facebook is no longer going to be only about who you are now. It will soon allow you to curate, as they say in digi-speak, your past.

title: Ban on Human Centipede 2 Is Lifted in Britain
description: Its generally not a good sign when anyone in a horror movie wields a sharp instrument, but by taking some editing scissors to his film The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence), the director Tom Six has gained the right to show it in Britain, reversing a ban imposed by the British Board of Film Classification.

title: Christies Regional Handicap
description: When former Gov. George E. Pataki announced in August, to the consternation of almost no one, that he would not run for president, I wrote about the backwater that New York had become in national politics.

title: Week 5 N.F.L. Game Probabilities, Including Jets-Patriots
description: This Sunday features an A.F.C. East showdown when the Jets travel to Foxborough to take on the Patriots. I looked at my write-up for this same matchup from Week 13 last season, and much of what I wrote a year ago could be cut and pasted for this week, complete with the unstoppable force-immovable object clich.

title: Eco Meets Exoskeletal
description: Basically they asked me, and I said O.K., says the designer Gareth Pugh of his easy decision to collaborate with Melissa, the Brazilian shoe company best known for making synthetic vegan footwear with designers like Vivienne Westwood, Jason Wu and Jean Paul Gaultier. In fact, Pugh says that working with Melissa  a brand that took an early interest in his work (it helped sponsor his second fashion show back in 2006)  on his first-ever shoe collection and most mainstream venture yet feels like a natural move. The six-piece Melissa + Gareth Pugh spring collection, which recently had its debut in Rio de Janeiro, was perfected via a steady stream of intercontinental e-mails in which Pugh would tweak this, change that. Im a Virgo, he explains. Im very particular about how I want things to be. Here, Pughs gothic-abstract aesthetic in Melissas signature plastic: an exoskeletal sandal that inches over the ankle with a trio of vertebrae-like pieces in combinations of black, white and silver.

title: So, Doc, How Much Time I Got?
description: The medical team hung back in the hallway before entering the patients room. The intern had just presented the case  a 50-year-old man whod never seen a doctor until three months before, when he noticed blood in his stool. It turned out he had extensive colon cancer that had already spread to the liver and lungs. The man, Mr. M, was now admitted for his second cycle of chemotherapy.

title: Soros Loses Challenge to Insider Trading Conviction
description: 5:47 p.m. | Updated

title: Sales Rose in Back-to-School Month, and Upscale Retailers Led the Way
description: In the important retail month of September, companies tracked by Thomson Reuters beat analysts estimates and posted a 5.1 percent increase in sales at stores open at least a year. It was their biggest jump since May.

title: Runway In Review
description: Elie SaabDesigner: Elie SaabDate and Location: Wednesday, Oct. 5, Espace Ephemere Tuileries, Jardin Des Tuileries, 1erPhotos: slide show

title: Coldplay Live Concert Webcast to Be Directed by Anton Corbijn
description: To add to a directorial rsum that includes films like The American and Control as well as music videos like U2s One and Nirvanas Heart-Shaped Box, Anton Corbijn has found an assignment that he expects will keep him on his feet. And afterwards, he said, on my back, probably.

title: When Holiday and Political Calendars Collide
description: The potential for a calendar collision between the presidential election process and the 2011 holiday season now rests almost entirely with Billy Gardner of New Hampshire.

title: Radically Reshaped BBC to Include Fewer Jobs and More Reruns
description: LONDON  The British Broadcasting Corporation announced Thursday that it would eliminate 2,000 jobs, cut its sports budget, show more reruns, and broadcast fewer talk and game shows.

title: Unsavvy People
description: Nieman Watchdog has a very good piece by John Hanrahan about press coverage of the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations. Coverage was initially dismissive and minimal  and mea culpa, I wasnt paying attention myself. But its becoming clear that theres something important happening: finally, after three years in which Very Serious People refused to hold the financial industry accountable, theres a real grass-roots uprising against the Masters of the Universe.

title: Genie in A Bootie
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#805", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);100 Shoes (The Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale, $25) is not a collection of fashions most vertically daring heels, despite the Vivienne Westood platforms on the cover (and a preface by that stilt walker Sarah Jessica Parker). Instead its a brisk but dazzling 500-year shoe survey, booting the idea that foot fashion needs to be grounded: Moccasins were huge in Georgian England; American tango boots in the 1910s laced up like Grecian sandals; and that late-60s prototype by Beth Levine  it kicks off the shoe slideshow above  seems to have come from a different planet.

title: What Were Reading
description: Wine Review Online: Prime pinot noir from  Marin County?  Eric Asimov

title: Google Opens Pop-Up Shops for a Hands-On Chromebook Experience
description: When Google introduced Chromebooks, laptops running its Chrome operating system, it showed a promotional video with the tagline, Ready when you are.

title: 23 Arrested Wednesday in Wall St. Protest
description: Updated 5:55 p.m. | The total number of people arrested on Wednesday at the Occupy Wall Street protest was 23, the police said Thursday morning.

title: Thursday Reading: Missteps Exposed Patient Data Online
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Steve Jobs, From Computers to Tablets
description: Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder and former chief executive of Apple, has died at 56.

title: Celebrities Attend Chechen Leaders Party
description: There were lights and music, dancing and a huge display of fireworks. Vanessa-Mae played the violin, and even though Shakira did not attend, the actors Hilary Swank and Jean-Claude Van Damme stopped by.

title: Spalding Grays Tortured Soul
description: Spalding Gray moved to New York City in 1967, shortly after his mothers suicide, when he was 26. He lived with his girlfriend, Elizabeth LeCompte, in an apartment on Sixth Street and Avenue D, on the Lower East Side. To make ends meet, Gray occasionally worked as a stock boy, while LeCompte sold postcards at the front desk of the Guggenheim. But mostly they were finding their places in New Yorks avant-garde theater world.

title: Olympic Eligibility Restored By Court
description: The Olympic 400-meter champion LaShawn Merritt of the United States and possibly dozens of other athletes had their eligibility for the 2012 London Games restored Thursday when a doping punishment put in place by the International Olympic Committee was struck down as overly severe.

title: The Case of Wendell Walters et. al.
description: A top official with New York Citys agency that develops affordable housing was arrested, along with six others on Thursday, and accused of scheming to obtain as much as $2 million in kickbacks from contractors and developers.

title: ESPN Permanently Drops Football Pregame Song
description: Three days after the country music singer Hank Williams Jr. referred to Hitler while talking about President Obama, ESPN on Thursday permanently cut his opening song to Monday Night Football, which includes the catchphrase Are you ready for some football?

title: Gore, Grime and One Creepy Guy in an Underground Garage
description: The Human Centipede (First Sequence), from 2010, was that rare thing: a grass-roots cult hit whose novelty  in this case a horror tableau in which three people are surgically linked mouth to anus  ignites a wildfire of notoriety. The movie was memorable (in its way), its central image underscored by a studied, clinical ambience. But it lacked subtext, the resonance of, say, George Romeros critique of consumerism in the original Dawn of the Dead.

The relationship ended a few years later, not long before I bought my first iPod. . . .

title: Steve Jobs, Son of a Syrian, Is Embraced in the Arab World
description: Steve Jobs, the innovative force behind Apple, grew up in San Francisco but traced his roots back to Syria. It was a fact that many Syrians celebrated on Thursday even as they mourned his death and lamented how the political crisis gripping the country made it unlikely that a future Steve Jobs would emerge from Syria and stay there.

title: Headed East, More Hill Than Dale
description: WEST HOMESTEAD, Pa.  A long bike ride delivers you from one set of conditions to another. For almost a year  well, O.K., 10 days, but it felt like a year  I was riding in the damp and cold as a crummy weather front arrived over lower Michigan and Ohio and sat there. More than once I played the what-if game with myself: Would I trade a steady rain and a chilling wind for the heat and rolling hills of the Palouse in eastern Washington? How about for the endless prairie of Montana? A cyclist can appreciate all those challenges and enjoy meeting them, including the rain, but after a week or so of being soggy to the bone, the answer to every trade possibility was yes.

title: The Marriage Plot
description: To start with, look at all the books. There were her Edith Wharton novels, arranged not by title but date of publication; there was the complete Modern Library set of Henry James, a gift from her father on her twenty-first birthday; there were the dog-eared paperbacks assigned in her college courses, a lot of Dickens, a smidgen of Trollope, along with good helpings of Austen, George Eliot, and the redoubtable Bront sisters. There were a whole lot of black-and-white New Directions paperbacks, mostly poetry by people like H.D. or Denise Levertov. There were the Colette novels she read on the sly. There was the first edition of Couples, belonging to her mother, which Madeleine had surreptitiously dipped into back in sixth grade and which she was using now to provide textual support in her English honors thesis on the marriage plot. There was, in short, this mid-size but still portable library representing pretty much everything Madeleine had read in college, a collection of texts, seemingly chosen at random, whose focus slowly narrowed, like a personality test, a sophisticated one you couldnt trick by anticipating the implications of its questions and finally got so lost in that your only recourse was to answer the simple truth. And then you waited for the result, hoping for Artistic, or Passionate, thinking you could live with Sensitive, secretly fearing Narcissistic and Domestic, but finally being presented with an outcome that cut both ways and made you feel different depending on the day, the hour, or the guy you happened to be dating: Incurably Romantic.

title: West Memphis Three Will Attend New York Film Festival
description: After gaining their freedom following a nearly two-decade ordeal, the Arkansas men known as the West Memphis Three are planning to attend a premiere screening in New York for the latest entry in a documentary series that has helped keep their case in the public eye for more than 15 years. The three men, Jason Baldwin, Damien Echols and Jessie Misskelley Jr., who were freed from prison in August after having been convicted in 1994 of the murders of three 8-year-old boys, are expected to be at the New York Film Festival on Monday evening for a screening of the film Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory, a non-fiction feature directed by Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said.

title: Tailgating Recipes: Buffalo Chicken Wraps

Of course, weve been surprised by some of the submissions. What should not have surprised us was that a recipe from a Southern city had an eye on calorie counting. We wouldnt expect that from Chicago, Green Bay or New York, where fans are pretty well bundled up for most of the season. This weeks recipe is Buffalo chicken lettuce wraps, the spicy wing dish with a few of the calories lopped off. Its not too late to submit your own recipe for barbecue or chowder, or whatever makes your pregame feast tasty.

Alan Gilbert, like Lorin Maazel, his predecessor as music director of the New York Philharmonic, is a violinist, and though he has played in the Philharmonics chamber concerts, his appearance alongside the violinist Frank Peter Zimmermann in Bachs Double Concerto on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall was his solo debut with the orchestra.

title: S.B.A.-Backed Lending Set a Record in 2011
description: The Small Business Administration did record business in 2011, guaranteeing more money in loans to small companies than in any year in its history. But the very smallest businesses, seeking the smallest loans, had more trouble getting an S.B.A. guarantee than in 2010.
