That doesnt mean taking the public out of the loop; it means putting whatever expertise you have to work on the publics behalf.

title: Friday Reading: Panel Advises No Prostate Test for Healthy Men
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Fill-In | Tributes to Steve Jobs
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the article Jobss Death Draws Outpouring of Grief and Tributes.

title: The Lowdown | Arashi Yanagawa
description: Suffice it to say that, in Japanese, Arashi Yanagawas first name means big storm. The son of a taxi driver, Yanagawa made a name for himself as a professional boxer over a four-year career that included winning the Japanese national championships. Having satisfied his fathers deepest aspirations for his son, Yanagawa moved on to his new passion: fashion design. With no schooling or training, he simply started making clothes, founding the brand John Lawrence Sullivan (named after the Irish boxer) and learning as he went. Seven years later, JLS is one of the more respected mens-wear companies in Japan and Yanagawa maintains a solid reputation as an excellent designer. Now, he is turning his sights on mens-wear for women.

title: Eurotrashers
description: Kantoos has a righteous rant about the ECB, and the destructiveness of its tight-money obsession. Hes right: if the euro cracks up, the ECB will bear a large share of the blame.

title: Trailer for "Enlightened"
description: Mike White's new show on HBO, starring Laura Dern.

title: Commodity Prices Redux
description: Remember commodity prices? Not too long ago, the usual suspects were pointing to rising commodity prices as evidence that runaway inflation was just around the corner. Commodity prices were Exhibit A in claims that Bernanke was debasing the dollar; Paul Ryan called for monetary policy that would stabilize the price of a basket of commodities (and therefore require deflation in America whenever China experienced a boom, but hey, never mind).

title: Why Dan Marinos Record Is Going Down
description: Luis DeLoureiro, a friend and contributor to the Fifth Down, is emphatic.

title: Appeasing Critics, Groupon Revises I.P.O. Disclosure
description: 8:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Hedge Funds Are Betting Against Hungary
description: 7:25 p.m. | Updated

title: Argentina 2002
description: Floyd Norris has a good piece about Argentinas exit from the convertibility law as a precedent for possible euro exit. Regular readers know that Ive been at that parallel for a long time.

title: Back to School, With Fewer Teachers
description: On Thursday I called attention to the question of how many teachers returned to work this fall. The answer seems to be: Not that many.

title: What Were Reading
description: Details: For David Chang, its black garlic. For Todd English, its zaatar. Top chefs sing the praises of their favorite spices.  Jeff Gordinier

title: From Rags to Riches
description: My teenage memories of rainy weekends watching classic movies often had a star  Bette Davis, maybe  shrugging off a compliment with a sneer and the words This old thing?!

title: How Jobs Put Passion Into Products
description: In the early 1990s Compaq Computer was the technology darling of the day, and PC sales were surging. Dell was promoting its build-on-demand model, Gateway computer shipped its products in boxes with Holstein cow markings, and I.B.M. had introduced the ThinkPad with its Little Tramp marketing campaign. Apples Macintosh was introduced during the 1984 Super Bowl but was considered a marginal outlier with its quirky proprietary operating system.

title: Big Deal | Gilded Then, Gilded Now
description: It is a historic moment on the block of Central Park West between 84th and 85th Streets.

title: Leading Off: That Wasnt Supposed to Happen
description: For a while, the Tigers-as-Yankee-slayers became a plausible idea. The Tigers have the best pitcher in baseball, a shrewd manager, cool old-school uniforms. But when they botched a chance to win the American League division series at home in Game 4, a trip to the Bronx for Game 5 Thursday night was a no-hoper. You dont let the Yankees off the mat and win. You just dont.

title: X Factor Watch: Yes, Hell Now Admit to Being a Fan
description: All right, now that the chaff has been separated, Im completing my reluctant conversion into Fan of The X Factor.

title: 10 Years Into Afghan War, a Thunderous Duel
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE TILLMAN, Afghanistan  The sun had been up less than a half-hour on the 10th anniversary of the start of the American-led war in Afghanistan when the first rocket struck. Flying in from near the border with Pakistan, it shook this outpost with an explosion that hinted at the long day ahead.

title: Illinois Town Evacuated After Fiery Train Accident
description: An explosion and fire after a cargo train derailed in central Illinois early Friday led to the evacuation of a town in central Illinois. There were no reports of injuries.

title: Why the Yankees Cant Afford to Lose Sabathia
description: The Yankees often react to postseason failure by spending a lot of money on the best available player they can find. It is the equivalent of running to Tiffanys to buy something shiny to fix a damaged relationship. The gift will solve none of the underlying problems, but its sparkly and pleasantly distracting, for a while.

title: City Hall Woes on the Jobs Front
description: Time was that government jobs were supposed to be safe.

title: A Judges Education, a Sentence at a Time
description: ON Feb. 2, 2004, Marlo Kidd awaited sentencing before Judge Denny Chin of Federal District Court in Manhattan. She had pleaded guilty to acting as a lookout for two masked gunmen who had robbed a bank in Yonkers, and under federal sentencing guidelines, she faced a prison term of up to six years.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: TimesCast | Intuitive and Accessible
description: Oct. 6, 2011  In Manhattan, the physically challenged find freedom in the products Steve Jobs helped create.

title: An Escalator That Feeds the Building
description: Regenerative braking, which involves taking unwanted mechanical energy and turning it back into electricity instead of letting it dissipate as heat, is well established in cars like the Toyota Prius and has lately made inroads in railway locomotives.

title: My Muse Was an Apple Computer
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Meet the Contraption That Wants to Replace Central Park Horses
description: The faux-vintage electric car that horse advocates want to replace Central Parks carriage horses has classic white-walled tires, running boards, mahogany and an ah-hoogah horn.

title: Sticky Fingers | The Honey Harvest at Ghost Town Farm
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Arab Activists Celebrate Yemenis Nobel Prize
description: The message below, posted on Twitter by Wael Ghonim of Egypt, captured the sentiment of many Arab activists who use social media. Some of them, Mr. Ghonim included, had been thought to be favorites to win the prize themselves.

title: Valeria S.
description: Valeria S.

title: Changes for Me and Motherlode
description: Motherlode turned 3  this past weekend. Shes not my baby anymore.

title: Simpsons Voice Actor Speaks Out About Negotiations With Fox
description: As a star of The Simpsons, Harry Shearer provides the voices of dozens of characters on that Fox animated comedy, from the nefarious plutocrat Montgomery Burns to Homers gentle next-door neighbor, Ned Flanders. And on Friday Mr. Shearer became the first performer on that long-running series to give voice to the current demands of its acting ensemble, which is locked in a tense negotiation with the 20th Century Fox Television studio while the fate of The Simpsons hangs in the balance.

title: In South Korea, American Official Apologizes Over Rape Case
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A senior American diplomat apologized on Friday in connection with the rape of an 18-year-old South Korean woman for which an American serviceman has been accused, and the United States military imposed a monthlong late-night curfew on its troops in South Korea.

title: Detroit Exhales, Celebrates Advance to A.L.C.S.
description: DETROIT  After a tense, deciding Game 5, the Tigers have escaped New York to reach the American League Championship Series to play Texas and, as expected, are dominating the local conversation. Fans and media alike are celebrating the tough series win over the Yankees.

title: Sundance Adds New Media Projects
description: Sundance has expanded its vaunted filmmaker labs program to include projects that focus on the convergence of film and new media technologies. (Think Matthew Barney.) The first New Frontier Story Lab will start Oct. 23 at Sundances headquarters in the mountains outside Salt Lake City. Keri Putnam, executive director of the Sundance Institute, called the intersection of film and new media a new and important field where we felt independent voices needed nurturing and resources. The inaugural New Frontier workshop, underwritten by Coca-Cola and McCann, will include 11 artists working on projects like 18 Days in Egypt, an interactive documentary project that will tell the story of the recent Egyptian revolution through a collage of videos, photos, tweets and other electronic media.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $25,000,000
description: The $25 million sale of a penthouse in an East Side co-op to Paul G. Allen, a founder of the Microsoft Corporation, was the highest of the week, according to city property records.

title: Strike Three, Times Four
description: Four times in the last six years, playoff baseball in New York has concluded with a strikeout by a Met or a Yankee. If this keeps up, the city of New York can apply for a patent.

title: Bernankes Darkest Fears
description: In the latest installment of DealBooks animated series, Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, goes to see his psychiatrist.

title: Postal Workers PAC Sticks to Regular Mail
description: The Internet may be the new standard for communication, but snail mail still rules at the political action committee of the American Postal Workers Union.

title: The Formula of Melodrama
description: The DNA of The Skin I Live In, like any film by Pedro Almodvar, can be found partly in the jaw-dropping twists and hang-ups of classic weepies.

title: Within Beats a Heart of Pure Melodrama
description: In Pedro Almodvars latest release, The Skin I Live In (opening Friday), Antonio Banderas stars as a plastic surgeon who, apparently haunted by his long-lost wife, embarks upon a mysterious skin experiment on an immaculately beautiful woman. He keeps her captive in his mansion, and soon an outlandish, lurid back story to his obsession emerges.

title: Toyotas India Announcement Belies a Greater Shift for Japanese Automakers
description: Toyota said Thursday that it would begin selling the Etios, a compact sedan and hatchback developed and produced in India, to customers in South Africa, marking the first time that the brands India division would export a car to another market.

title: Notes On The Eurobubble
description: Alan Greenspan has written another deeply misleading, destructive op-ed. Also, the sun rose in the east. Greenspan is quickly establishing himself as the worst ex-Fed chairman of all time. But since he has introduced a brand-new fallacy into the debate, its worth taking on.

title: In Foreign Policy Speech, Romney Calls for an American Century
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Standing before an audience of crisply-clad, closely-shorn cadets, Mitt Romney delivered his foreign policy vision at The Citadel on Friday, calling for a strengthened military and economy to lead the country into what he called an American Century, while also accusing President Obama of weakening the nations image around the world.

title: Kookaburra Sitting Pretty in That Old Gum Tree as Court Upholds Copyright Ruling
description: Men at Work, the Australian rock band, lost its final bid Friday to overturn a court ruling that it had stolen a flute riff on its 1980s hit Down Under from a childrens song, The Associated Press reported.

title: Mark Ellen Marks and the Robots
description: Mark Ellen Marks and the Robots

title: Stephen Greenblatt on the Roman poet and philosopher, Lucretius; Andre Aciman discusses his new collection of travel essays; and Jacques Steinberg profiles on his book You Are An Ironman.
description: This week, Stephen Greenblatt on his new book The Swerve: How the World Became Modern; Andre Aciman discusses his new collection of travel essays called Alibis: Essays on Elsewhere; Jacques Steinberg profiles athletes who compete in the most grueling triathalons in You Are An Ironman; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Most Leave Illinois Town After Fiery Train Derailment
description: CHICAGO  Most residents of Tiskilwa, Ill., a town of about 800, were evacuated early Friday after a train derailed and six cars caught fire in explosions, the authorities said.

title: Worker at South Pole Station Pushes for a Rescue After a Stroke
description: Renee-Nicole Douceur, the winter manager at the Amundsen-Scott research station at the South Pole, was sitting at her desk on Aug. 27 when she suffered a stroke.

title: Russell Banks Imagines a Paroled Sex Offenders Future
description: In a country now famous for its second acts  the philandering politician, the reformed insider trader, Charlie Sheen  virtually the only American denied another chance is the sexual offender, branded in perpetuity, his whereabouts tracked by the government, a modern-day boogeyman unable by law in many states to live anywhere even remotely habitable. In his 12th novel, Lost Memory of Skin, the formidable Russell Banks bravely explores this specific plight, trying to find humanity in people who are feared and despised, frequently for good reason, and raising questions not only about the often horrendous public treatment of these outcasts but also about the ways the larger culture may contribute to their crimes.

title: Post-Blackness
description: To the Editor:

title: Up Front: Helen Schulman
description: In the mid-1980s, when Helen Schulman was in graduate school, she took a literary seminar with Russell Banks. I dont remember ever raising my hand, so I doubt he would remember me at all, she said via e-mail. But when asked to review his new novel, Lost Memory of Skin, I jumped at the chance, because of my deep respect for his work and because I thought there were still things I could learn from him. His treatment of the character of the Kid  a virginal sex offender living in a tent under a causeway  is a case in point.

title: Not Another Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Looks Arent Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: A View of Hunger in North Korea
description: Damir Sagolj, a Bangkok-based Reuters photographer, was among a group of journalists invited last week by North Koreas Economy and Trade Information Center to document the food crisis in the countrys farm belt. North Korea has appealed for food aid after a harsh winter and a series of summer floods and storms, but so far, only 30 percent of a United Nations aid target has been met.

title: Inside Bruce Jay Friedmans Pulp Arcadia
description: Youd think that someone born in the thick of the Great Depression would have a sad story to tell, Bruce Jay Friedman writes, but mine isnt one of them.

title: The Jonestown Massacre Revisited
description: Julia Scheeres describes her new book, A Thousand Lives, as the untold story of Jonestown, the Peoples Temple settlement in the jungles of Guyana where on Nov. 18, 1978, the Rev. Jim Jones orchestrated the deaths of more than 900 Americans. Well, not exactly untold. Over the past three decades, the massacre has been explored in numerous books and even several television documentaries. Yet the story does bear retelling, not least for those too young to recall the shock that swept the world at the time, but also because Scheeres adds insights harvested from some 50,000 pages of letters, journals and other documents found in Jonestown and recently released by the F.B.I. The result is a gripping account of how decent people can be taken in by a charismatic and crazed tyrant.

title: Will the Large Hadron Collider Explain Everything?
description: Lisa Randall is a professor of physics at Harvard and one of the more original theorists at work in the profession today. In the fancifully titled Knocking on Heavens Door, her second book for a popular audience, she has two avowed aims: first, to explain where physics might be headed now that the Large Hadron Collider  the enormous particle accelerator on the Swiss-French border  is finally up and running; and second, to air her views on the nature of science, its fraught relations with religion, and the role of beauty as a guide to scientific truth. Her book thus alternates between the nitty-gritty of particle physics and meditations of a more rarefied sort. Stitching the whole thing together are passages recounting the authors globe-trotting adventures: accepting the key to the city from the mayor of Padua, chatting up a scientifically curious actor on a flight to Los Angeles, attending the Barcelona premiere of an opera about physics for which she had written the libretto.

title: A Caribbean Editor Tries to Give Urban Lit a Makeover
description: Imagine this dystopian scene from the publishing world: Windsor, a New York industry giant, has been struggling to stay afloat. Among its moneymaking stratagems is Equiano, an imprint for writers of color. There is nary a Toni Morrison title in sight. Raine, the queen of black exotica, and the thug-life raconteur B. Benton become the imprints best-selling authors. Urban lit and ghetto lit, chick lits gritty cousins, begin to rake in millions for Windsor, whose blond editor in chief heads a staff of sycophants convinced that soft-core porn sells books.

title: A Novel of Flying Machines, Apocalyptics and the San Francisco Internet Boom
description: One of the startling things about getting older is that somewhere along the line, members of your generation ascend to public life: they run for office, land jobs that arent modified by the word assistant, write novels. In this last instance, they do the rest of us a service by tracing the trajectory that a swath of people cut through history, and vice versa.

title: The Photo That Exposed Segregation
description: In September 1957, Elizabeth Eckford and Hazel Bryan were captured in the sickening news photograph that prompted this book. Will Counts, a sharecroppers son and young hire at The Arkansas Democrat, took the picture, laying bare the disgrace of the Jim Crow South. In it, Elizabeth, a sheltered, scholarly teenager in a homemade dress, walks past Little Rock Central High School while Hazel, a student there, marches behind her, spewing racist abuse.

title: The Russians Are Coming
description: For a time in the mid-to-late 1920s the art of the cinema meant only one thing to the serious-minded film critics of America and Europe: Soviet-style montage, or the art of cutting shots together in a way that would produce ideas and emotions beyond those expressed in the images themselves.

title: Netflix to Stream AMCs The Walking Dead
description: Just in time for people to catch up with The Walking Dead, the AMC series that begins its second season on Oct. 16, the first season is now streaming on Netflix.

title: John Lennons Primal Screams
description: I hated Lennon, one of the old madcaps says, defiantly, in Jonathon Greens oral history Days in the Life: Voices From the English Underground, 1961-1971. Oh yes. Lennons no hero of mine. I cannot separate people and what they do from what they are. Lennon was unmitigatedly evil as far as I was concerned. Doesnt that sound terrible, like a kind of spiritual deformity  hating John Lennon? Tangled deep in the nervous system of every earthling over the age of 40, I would argue, is some fiber or filament of peak Beatlemania, some flicker of the old wild adoration. We want, we need  still  to love these men. And yet Lennon in certain aspects was really quite hateable. Cruel at times, chaotic, dissociated: on his bad days little more, so it seems, than a gigantic human flaw through which the shifting light of genius displayed itself.

title: Fashioning Narrative Pleasures From Narcotic Ones
description: No writer in modern India has held a novelistic lamp to the subcontinents densely thicketed past as vividly and acutely as Amitav Ghosh. Since the publication of The Circle of Reason, in the mid-1980s, Ghoshs work has been animated by its inventive collages and connections. River of Smoke, the second volume of his ambitious Ibis trilogy, is the work of a writer with a historical awareness and an appetite for polyphony that are equal to the immense demands of the material he seeks to illuminate.

title: Cave Hunting in Thailand
description: Near the border of Myanmar is a karst-and-mist landscape where hundreds of caves lie hidden beneath thick vines.

title: Caves and Kayaks in a Quiet Corner of Thailand
description: MY mother shot me a concerned look. No, I said, anticipating her question, This isnt our stop. I knew what she was thinking: This is exactly what we were trying to avoid.

title: Essays From One of Our Best Wishful Thinkers
description: When, in 2005 and 2006, a mysterious sweet smell wafted across Staten Island, Brooklyn and Manhattan, it discomfited already jittery New Yorkers. The same thing happened again three years later, and the smell was finally identified: fenugreek, carried on breezes from a New Jersey flavor and fragrance factory. The incident reminded me of a passage in Andr Acimans fine 1995 memoir, Out of Egypt, in which he writes about the fragrance of hilba, fenugreek. Arab Egyptians drank it for its curative powers, and reeked afterward, but for many Alexandrian Jews who aspired to being European, nothing could be more dclass than the smell of hilba. Acimans father called it une odeur darabe, an Arab smell, and hated any trace of it in the house or on his clothes. But, Aciman points out, all homes bear ethnic odors, and from the various smells of foods and perfumes the stories of communities and persons emerge. The opening chapter of Alibis, Acimans beautiful new book of essays, is an extended aria on the sense of smell.

title: The Mysterious Serial Killer Who Terrified Nazi-Occupied Paris
description: Three months before DDay, in 1944, some Parisians in the chic 16th Arrondissement started complaining about thick smoke with an acrid smell emanating from the stately town house at 21 rue Le Sueur. Worried about a chimney fire, one neighbor finally called the authorities. They discovered that the mansions basement was festooned with human bones, its coal stove burning body parts. A smaller outbuilding housed a mysterious, virtually soundproof triangular room. The former stable hid a pit about 10 feet deep filled with quicklime and rotting flesh.

title: How the Dismal Science Stopped Being Dismal
description: Listen to the economic debates of the past couple of years, and its tempting to conclude that no progress has been made in the field in over half a century. Theres John Maynard Keynes on the one side, arguing for deficit spending to offset the aftereffects of a once-in-a-lifetime financial crisis. On the other side theres Ludwig von Mises (his fellow Austrians Joseph Schumpeter and Friedrich von Hayek seem too moderate for the role), thundering that all government intervention in the economy is doomed to failure.

title: A Newspaper Columnist in Recovery
description: This fine, small-scale novel by the Canadian writer David Bergen starts with the plight of a newspaper columnist who can no longer bear to use his family as fodder. Morris Schutt owes his wide readership to his seeming annulment of the private  the description of his older daughters live-in boyfriend as rabbit-like, soft and pale with a curious nose that twitched; the stories of his son, a university dropout who plays online poker. Yet after his son is killed while serving in Afghanistan, Morris begins to lose his grasp of himself. In one of his last columns, before his agent makes him take a break, he shifts from his reader-pleasing first-person voice to the alienating second person and echoes a 17th-century mystic: The wheel turns and you have no destination where to arrive.

title: The Conservative as Elitist
description: The American right has a lot to answer for these days. Members of this group are ardent peddlers of conspiracy theories, anti-intellectualism and the demonization of opponents. This approach has contributed in no small way to the sorry state of contemporary American politics, where epithets have replaced arguments, a sense of common destiny seems lacking among citizens and compromise has become almost impossible on the most pressing national issues. A book documenting the wreckage and carefully tracing the links between right-wing ideas, policies and outcomes would be a significant contribution to public debate. Unfortunately, Corey Robins Reactionary Mind is not that book.

title: Erin Morgensterns Magician Death Match
description: Let me say at the outset that glamour and charm are notoriously difficult qualities to render on the page, and all those words like mercury and lightning and ineffability certainly apply, ditto catching, capturing and chasing. It may well be the case that we still hold The Great Gatsby in such high esteem because of those amazing parties to which none of us will ever be invited, and wouldnt have been in the 1920s, either. If glamour were easy, the entire fashion industry could do its thing on Sunday afternoons with a spool of thread and a few yards of gauze. Moreover, for the true geniuses of glamour, a spool of thread and a few yards of gauze are all it takes to make one feel that one is Marie Antoinette spinning around Versailles. For the rest of us, glamour is a sweaty struggle, rife with pricked thumbs, bulges and gaffes. This is why it is a risky business indeed to devote nearly 400 pages to a confection called le Cirque des Rves, a circus that occurs at night (as opposed to what other sort of circus, by the way?) and is famous, apparently, for doing wild, magical, life-changing, impossible things. Like a magician, the writer must pull the rabbit from the hat, cut the lady in half, make the elephant disappear and so on. We long to be fooled. In The Night Circus, her debut novel, Erin Morgenstern works hard to create just such a sense of magic, but there finally seems to be something too sensible about her sensibility to pull off the trick. The novel is  and its an odd thing to say about a work of fiction  just too real to be believed. True magic is dangerous, and there is little of that sort of propulsive danger in these pages; where it does occur is surprising, and oddly marginalized.

title: What It Takes to Be an Ironman Triathlete
description: The popular satirical blog Stuff White People Like asserts that if you find yourself in a situation where a white person is talking about a marathon, you must be impressed or you will lose favor with them immediately. And if the subject of triathlons ever comes up, just say that triathletes are in better shape than football and basketball players. Its not true, but it will make the conversation a lot more genial. I recognize in myself, a sometime marathoner, the species of endurance-sport bore the bloggers are describing.

title: The Death of a Marriage in New Orleans
description: Toward the end of A Small Hotel, Robert Olen Butlers feverish new novel, a Florida lawyer named Michael Hays tries to convince himself that his prospective lover, Laurie, blond and 26 years his junior, is something other than the ditz she proclaims herself to be. Shes a perfect client, he thinks. Surprisingly smart and self-aware and honestly self-critical. Michael could easily be describing any of the characters who populate Butlers vast and diverse body of fiction  a dozen novels and some half-dozen story collections, some more successful than others  from the Vietnamese immigrants in A Good Scent From a Strange Mountain, which won the Pulitzer in 1993, to the panoply of the famous damned in his 2009 novel Hell. Despite the humor threaded through his works, Butlers characters are indisputably tragic, in that their abundant knowledge of their own needs and flaws traps rather than frees them.

title: When Moralism Isnt Moral
description: Years ago Irving Kristol, the prime mover of American neoconservatism, said to me, in typical aphoristic style: The orthodox are always right. What he meant, I think, is that the enduring truths of traditionalism may at times be hard to grasp, but they endure for a reason. In foreign policy, it is realists who are, in Kristols sense, always right.

title: How Patients Think, and How They Should
description: Most of us believe we are rational decision makers. But medical decisions are especially complex, thanks to the numerous unknowns and the uniqueness of each persons body. Suppose youve just found out that you or a loved one has prostate cancer, one of the many examples in Jerome Groopman and Pamela Hartzbands illuminating new book, Your Medical Mind. Nearly every urologist would recommend radical surgery to remove the organ. Sounds reasonable, doesnt it?

title: Trader Sentenced to 3 Years in Insider Case
description: 8:11 p.m. | Updated

title: Inside the List
description: HEMINGWAY IN LOVE: Ernest Hemingway has been having a tough few months. First, he gets slapped around in Paula McLains best-selling revenge novel The Paris Wife, which retells the story of his years in France from the point of view of his jilted first wife, Hadley Richardson. Then hes mocked in Woody Allens Midnight in Paris as a self-serious blowhard. But a little bit of rehabilitation is on the way, thanks to Hemingways Boat, Paul Hendricksons sympathetic biography (new at No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list), not to mention the first installment of Hemingways complete letters, just out from Cambridge University Press. That project, which includes previously unseen materials from the Finca Viga, Hemingways estate outside Havana, reminds us why we fell in love with the guy to begin with  or at least why Hadley did, even if his spelling and grammar werent always so hot. The book  the first of a projected 16 volumes  includes his earliest recorded love letter to Hash, written a few days before Christmas 1920. (Hadley burned most of his letters to her after they divorced in 1927.) You can make me jealous  and you can hurt most awfully  cause my loving you is a chink in the armour of telling the world to go to hell and you can thrust a sword into it at any time, Hemingway wrote, before explaining why he hadnt kissed her goodbye on the train platform. Lord  I thot I was loving you  If I wasnt I never could and never would love any one. Guess I was thinking too much about how I didnt want you to go  Dont you believe I love you? . . . I didnt want to kiss you goodbye  that was the trouble  I wanted to kiss you good night  and theres a lot of difference.

title: Russians Shrug at Prospects of Another Putin Term, Poll Shows
description: MOSCOW  The majority of Russians have grown weary of waiting for Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin to make positive changes in their lives, and many expect little new from him as he embarks on his second stint as president next year, according to a poll published Friday.

title: Paperback Row
description: TRAVELS IN SIBERIA,  by Ian Frazier (Picador, $20.) Dubious meals, broken-down vehicles and relics of the Gulag fill Fraziers fascinating account of his journeys across the vast, forbidding region. As he demonstrated in Great Plains (1989)  a 25,000-mile jaunt from the Dakotas to Texas  Frazier makes us see how the most trivial or ephemeral detail is part of the essential texture of a place.

title: Sex, Comedy and Life During Wartime
description: In the early days of the blitz, Tory Pace lives with her mother in a little house in the southeast of London. Her children have been evacuated to the Cotswolds, and her husband, Donald, is missing in action in North Africa. Tory spends her days working in Farraways Gelatine Factory and her evenings missing her children and not much missing Donald, to whose death she is resigned.

title: Will the E-Book Kill the Footnote?
description: When my dog, Pumpernickel, first found a stray grape on my kitchen floor, she licked at it, tumbled it around in her mouth and spat it out. She accepted a lot of food from my plate not traditionally thought of as interesting to dogs: carrots, broccoli, bagels. But she would not eat grapes, nor was she fond of raisins.

title: Are You Ready for Some Change?
description: ESPN made the right decision to let go of Hank Williams Jr., but have they learned their lesson? William C. Rhoden on what ESPN should do next after the Williams controversy.

title: Is Robert Sietsema Ruth Bourdain?
description: Lee Svitak Dean, editor of the Taste section of The Minneapolis Star-Tribune, was listening to Matt and Ted Lee give the keynote address at the annual meeting of the Association of Food Journalists on Wednesday when someone asked the brothers what they thought of Ruth Bourdains  winning a humor writing award from the James Beard Foundation in May.

title: Rhoden: Are You Ready for Some Change?
description: ESPN made the right decision to let go of Hank Williams Jr., but have they learned their lesson? William C. Rhoden on what ESPN should do next after the Williams controversy.

title: Venice Scrubbed and Polished
description: With Italian austerity measures looming and construction of the Mose Flood Barrier in full swing, little remains in Venices budget to protect and restore its treasures. Which is why Save Venice Inc., a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the artistic heritage of the city, seems more relevant than ever. The organization is celebrating its 40th anniversary this year with the release of the monumental book Save Venice Inc.: Four Decades of Restoration in Venice. The 500-page, self-published volume (hardcover edition, $200; soft cover $60; all proceeds go to Save Venice) serves as a retrospective on paper of the 400 works of art and architecture that the organization has adopted and restored.

title: 2 Tibetan Teenagers Set Themselves on Fire in Southwest China
description: Two Tibetan teenagers in Chinas remote southwest set themselves on fire Friday to protest the Chinese governments Tibet policies, and at least one of them died, an advocacy group said.

title: Santorum Calls Morality Crucial to Economic Success
description: Squarely in his element, Rick Santorum delivered a confident assertion of the need for moral leadership in the political realm at the Values Voter Summit in Washington on Friday. His delivery  warm and buoyant, without a trace of fire and brimstone despite the sharply conservative message  was a reminder of why Mr. Santorum remains a force in Republican circles though he has been out of the Senate since Pennsylvanians voted him out in 2006.

title: Europe Approves Microsoft Purchase of Skype
description: BERLIN  The European Commission on Friday approved Microsofts $8.5 billion purchase of Skype, saying it had no objections to a deal that would link the worlds largest software maker with the leading Internet communications service.

title: Feeding Teenagers With Cookies and Bars
description: Teenagers always seem to be hungry, but they also always seem to be busy, with no time to eat. Martha Rose Shulman offers a solution in this weeks Recipes for Health: tasty and nutritious cookies and bars that busy teenagers can eat on the run.

title: Fordham Holds Bake Sale in Response to Berkeleys
description: In rebuttal to last weeks controversial bake sale protesting affirmative action in college admissions at the University of California, Berkeley, students at Fordham University in New York staged their own sale on Friday.

title: Sugarland to Give Free Concert in Indianapolis, Where 7 Died in Stage Accident
description: Sugarland, the country music duo, will give a free concert in Indianapolis, where seven people were killed in August when stage rigging collapsed in high winds just before the band was to play at the Indiana State Fair. Sugarland announced on Friday that it would appear at the Conseco Fieldhouse on Oct. 28 and would collect money for survivors and relatives of victims of the accident.

title: The Caucus | Focus on Foreign Policy
description: Oct. 7, 2011  With the economy still at the forefront, Republican candidates are focusing on foreign and defense issues. Also, Mitt Romney attracts new donors as the field settles.

title: Protests Swell in Bahrain After Boys Death
description: Large numbers of people filled the streets west of Bahrains capital, Manama, on Friday as a funeral march for a 16-year-old boy  who activists said was killed by the police  grew into one of the largest demonstrations in the tiny Gulf nation in recent weeks.

title: Disneys Iger to Step Down in 2015
description: 7:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Caucus Video: Focus on Foreign Policy; Romneys New Donors
description: With the economy still at the forefront, Republican candidates are focusing on foreign and defense issues. Also, a look at Mitt Romneys new donors as he takes advantage of the settled field.

title: Whats the Safer Signing, Sabathia or Reyes?
description: C.C. Sabathias seven-year contract has four years remaining at $23 million a year and an opt-out clause that he can exercise after this season, which would make him a free agent. Assuming Sabathia, a left-handed starter, will use the clause to leverage a better deal from the Yankees, which is the riskier investment:

title: Dusting Off the Recipe for a White-Bread Van
description: EVERYBODY, it sometimes seems, complains about the minivan, or at least the bland, conservative image of the minivan. But despite the best efforts of marketing departments  from Toyotas Swagger Wagon videos to Honda Odyssey ads pulsing with rock-concert fantasies  tampering with the basic van formula is a dangerous business.

title: Adding Sport to Scooters With a 3-Wheel Design
description: Higgins Bay, N.Y.

title: Random House in Joint Effort on Politics
description: Random House is expanding its publishing efforts tied to the 2012 election by teaming up with RealClearPolitics, a political Web site, to release a series of e-books during the campaign, the publisher said today. Crown Publishers, part of Random House, said it would publish three short-form e-book originals, plus one full-length book, beginning Nov. 4. The books will be written by Thomas Bevan, co-founder and executive editor of RealClearPolitics, and Carl M. Cannon, the Washington editor for RealClearPolitics. The first e-book, Election 2012, is expected to cost $1.99.

title: The Night Circus
description: ANTICIPATION

title: Apples Longtime Ad Partner Reflects on Jobs
description: Lee Clow, who worked for decades with Steven P. Jobs and Apple at agencies that include Chiat/Day, TBWA/Chiat/Day and the TBWA/Media Arts Lab unit devoted to Apple, has paid tribute to Mr. Jobs, who died on Wednesday.

title: Faith at the Center of the Circus of Sports
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 5s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Haikus for the Brewers, and Nasty Traffic for the Rangers
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 7
description: The day in sports photos, including gymnastics qualifying, a great save for Poland and some speedy New Zealand sheep.

title: Breaking Through the Synth Barrier
description: SUDDENLY it seems there are a lot more women twiddling those knobs than ever before.

title: From PBS, a Sampler of the Arts
description: THE last time a production of the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis was featured in a national PBS production was 1975. That esteemed regional theater makes its return on Friday, when its production of Gilbert and Sullivans H.M.S. Pinafore, including an exuberantly choreographed second-act number, He Is an English Man, kicks off the new PBS Arts Fall Festival.

title: Soul Selections for Hip-Hop Heads
description: THE smooth retro-soul singer Mayer Hawthorne was born just a few years ago in Los Angeles, the alter-ego of the D.J. and producer Andrew Mayer Cohen, 32. On a lark he recorded a few tracks in his bedroom, convincingly styling himself as a 1960s Motown crooner despite the fact that he is a white kid from Ann Arbor, Mich. His debut, A Strange Arrangement, was a surprise seller for the indie label Stones Throw in 2009. Now hes signed to a major label, Universal Republic, which will release his sophomore album, How Do You Do, on Tuesday.

title: Food Links for the Info-Famished
description: Were keeping tabs on Denmarks fat tax (which took effect last Saturday). Here are my thoughts, and those of the Washington Post. Also, New Zealand is in the grip of an obesity epidemic, but health minister Tony Ryall has ruled out a fat tax, citing the economy.

title: A Boulders Journey
description: Michael Heizers art installation at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art requires transporting a 340-ton granite rock through 120 miles of roads in the heart of one of the most congested urban centers in the country.

title: The Worldly Mussel Likes Time at Home
description: MUSSELS, steamed in the shell, are ideal for cooking at home, especially for those of us with small kitchens. Theyre completely satisfying, they are relatively cheap, and they couldnt be easier.

title: Europe Seems to Agree on Recapitalizing Banks  but How?
description: European leaders are finally coming around to the view that banks must be compelled to replenish their capital reserves if the euro area is ever to emerge from the debt crisis. But whether the politicians can make it happen in a convincing manner is another question  especially given that Germany and France are already divided.

title: Reds Increase, and a Monarch Makes an Appearance
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week.

title: Finding the Poetry in the Industrial Past
description: LIKE many people today, from amateurs to avant-garde architects, Theaster Gates has a soft spot for the glory days of the American industrial past. Mr. Gates, a Chicago artist, salvages what he can from the warehouses and factories that are being torn down in and around the city, many of which date to the turn of the last century. Sturdy old wood timbers have proved a special weakness.

title: The Caucus | New Mitt Romney Donors
description: Megan Liberman and Nicholas Confessore discuss Mitt Romney's new donors as he takes advantage of the settled field.

title: Graphic Books Lists Features New Titles
description: The best-seller lists are aflutter with change this week. The hardcover list leads off with Hark! A Vagrant, by Kate Beaton, who became noticed for her Web cartoons about literary, political and historical figures. Click on this link for a humorous interpretation of the discovery of Canada. Hark! is published by Drawn & Quarterly, which also has Daybreak, an art-house take on the zombie genre by Brian Ralph, at No. 6.

title: Where Hard Rock Meets Pop Art
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Act II, Scene 1: A Wedding, With a Full Cast
description: Jessie Austrian and Noah Brody know how to play a married couple. They do it eight times a week.

title: Slovaks Love and Hate Euro; Bailout May Lie in Between
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  In a television advertisement for the popular Slovak beer Zlaty Bazant, a grinning man with a paunch stands on a sunny beach, nodding his head as the narrator says, To want to borrow from everyone, that is Greek. The ad then cuts to a skinny man, standing in a field, who shakes his head. To not want to lend to anyone, the narrator says, that is Slovak.

title: Eagles Are a Dream Team That Makes Fans Scream
description: A sense of dread is creeping over Philadelphia. It is flowing through the streets, covering all of the dried-up previous layers of dread.

title: Saving Money Flying to Europe
description: To the Editor: Regarding Flying to Europe, for a Little Less (Oct. 2), Zurich worked well for me when I recently booked a fall trip. We knew we wanted to spend time in France and Germany, so I got hung up on flying to airports in those two countries. Then I stumbled on a round-trip fare to Zurich that was hundreds cheaper. Trains are not cheap in Europe, but they can be cost-effective compared to car rental (and high-priced gas), and are so comfortable. And I second the cautions on the low-cost airlines within Europe. Read the fine print before you order your tickets, or you could get stuck with exorbitant luggage charges, as well as being dumped at an out-of-the-way alternative airport. Hugh S. Fullerton

title: Poetry Made Me Do It: My Trip to the Hebrides
description: I WAS about to slide down a hill when the strangeness of my situation struck me: A poem had brought me here.

title: Hotel Review: New York James in New York
description: UPSHOT

title: Kingston, N.Y., a Rest Stop on the Hudson
description: FROM its menu of pre-Prohibition-era tipples concocted with house-made syrups to its setting in a painstakingly restored 1880s sewing machine factory, the year-and-a-half-old Stockade Tavern is the epitome of cocktail chic. But you wont find it in downtown Manhattan or across the river in Brooklyn; instead, head about two hours north to Kingston, a modest-size city in the Hudson Valley of New York.

title: Lost in Paris
description: FOUR days after I arrived in Paris, I bought an umbrella. It had been raining on and off the entire time, and during my daily walks Id been carrying a lightweight waterproof shell  bright green  which at the first sign of precipitation Id unroll from its bundle and zip up, often removing it just minutes later, when the skies temporarily cleared. This was silly, I kept telling myself. There had to be a better way.

title: A Low-Slung Piece Of Toronto Gains Casual-Hip Cachet
description: Roncesvalles Village in Toronto is thriving with small bookstores, coffeehouses and boutiques.

title: Rediscovering Paris
description: What new experiences can be wrung out of a city youve visited many times before?

title: So Far, Its Been a Half-Empty Year for Financial Forecasters
description: IN January, I set out to write quarterly columns that would check in with the same group of market prognosticators. I wanted to see how accurate their forecasts would be and what they would say when they were wrong.

title: Hand-Drawn Homage to Classic Films
description: THE movie poster is dead. Long live the movie poster. Gone are the days of hand-drawn studio posters that possessed a creativity and artistry matching that of the films themselves. Think of King Kong, with its harrowing illustrations, or Saul Basss Minimalist design for Vertigo. The contemporary studio poster is often a literal, less adventurous affair, like the vision of Julia Roberts on the back of Tom Hankss scooter in the poster for Larry Crowne, a typical example of todays photography-driven advertisements.

title: Roll Em! And Unroll Em
description: A look at some of the movie posters designed for the Austin store Mondo.

title: The Fonzs Happy Days Triumph Motorcycle to Be Auctioned
description: It seems like a cant-miss premise. The 1949 Triumph Trophy TR5 ridden by Arthur The Fonz Fonzarelli is going to be auctioned at Bonhams Classic California Sale, on Nov. 12 at the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles.

title: Iowa Republicans Eye Jan. 3 for Caucuses
description: DES MOINES  Iowa Republicans are tentatively eyeing Jan. 3 as the date for the states caucuses, the first stop in the partys battle to select a nominee to challenge President Obama.

title: Don Paterson Recites His Poem, Luing
description: The Scottish poet Don Paterson recites his 2003 poem, Luing.

title: How to Make Working at Home Work for You
description: IWAS conducting an interview from my office, which doubles as my home, and was frustrated because the loud leaf blower outside was drowning out my words and thoughts. I walked from one room to another to find some quiet, stumbling at one point over a laundry basket. All the while, I was hoping I sounded professional.

title: Top American Marathoners Success Raises Question: Is a Coach Necessary?
description: Ryan Hall, one of the few Americans who can compete against the best international distance runners, is going to try to win the Chicago Marathon on Sunday. And he is doing it without a coach, which is almost unheard of in elite distance running, or elite sports for that matter.

title: Way Off Base
description: I see some commenters reacting to the failure of major inflation to break out by insisting that inflation is defined as an increase in the monetary base  that is, the bank reserves plus currency that are what increases when the Fed prints money. As it happens, thats wrong: very old dictionaries defined inflation as a rise in money and/or credit, but the modern usage is, of course, a rise in prices.

title: Del Monte Settlement Highlights Risk in M.&.A. Advice
description: Del Monte Foods and Barclays Capital will pay $89.4 million to settle allegations of wrongdoing in the sale of Del Monte to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, Vestar Capital and Centerview Partners. The settlement is one of the largest in connection with a deal on record.

title: Week in Pictures, Oct. 7
description: A look back at the past weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Sticking to the Minivan Script
description: The once-revolutionary Nissan Quest returns for 2011 with a more conventional take on family transportation.

title: Modern Bromance
description: A longtime resident of the Lower East Side, Michael Little had taken to riding his bike to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for a decent cup of coffee. Specifically, a cup of Blue Bottle coffee, the San Francisco-based cult favorite. Fortunately for his neighbors, Little got tired of making the trek. In August, he and his friend Chad Eggers opened Lost Weekend NYC, a lifestyle shop and coffee bar that carries, in addition to Blue Bottle, a selection of mens T-shirts, hoodies and board shorts from the clothing label Saltbox and products by the grooming gurus Malin+Goetz. The cafe, housed in a light-drenched former gallery space on a burgeoning stretch of Orchard Street, is already attracting a (dude-heavy) crowd.

title: Police Clashes Spur Coverage of Wall Street Protests
description: The Occupy Wall Street protests, by design, began with little in the way of concrete goals or strategy.

title: Checking Account Wars, Behind the Scenes
description: This week, Senator Dick Durbin took to the Senate floor and called for a run on Bank of America.

title: The Amazon Dieback Scenario
description: In an article last weekend about rising stress in the worlds forests, I briefly mentioned that computer projections regarding the future of forests are still in a primitive state.

title: Why I Write: A Celebration of the National Day on Writing, Oct. 20
description: Update | Oct. 21:

title: At 77, Last Mambo King Refuses to Let the Rhythm Fade
description: With a red vest gleaming against his smart black suit, the Last Mambo King took center stage. Orlando Marin screwed on the timbales with white-gloved hands, eyed his fellow musicians, and then  bam!  mambo filled the South Street Seaport lounge. His brush stroked a cymbal; he sang out in Spanish and bobbed his head.

title: In Ford Materials, a Veritable Salad Bar
description: In his novel Car, the Southern surrealist writer Harry Crews creates a hero who is determined to eat an entire Ford Maverick from bumper to bumper.

title: Cracking Down on Rally Squirrel
description: Most people found great amusement in the squirrel(s) who dashed onto the field at Busch Stadium during Games 3 and 4 between the Cardinals and Phillies, and he has since been called the Rally Squirrel, complete with his own Twitter page. You can count Phillies pitcher Roy Oswalt among those who were not amused, nor was Busch Stadiums management. The stadium groundskeepers have now set up squirrel traps to prevent the resident critters from causing future mayhem.

title: Where Post Office Is the Towns Heart, Fears of Closings
description: NEVILLE, Ohio  While checking for mail on her daily visit, Susan Reid regaled the town postmaster with news of the wonderful swimming lessons enjoyed by her two home-schooled children. Suddenly, her 9-year-old son began tumbling around, ever so playfully, on the floor, as if he were at home.

title: Alison Berkley and Ryan Margo
description: ASPEN, Colo., is a competitive town. It is not uncommon to hear people talking about how fast they made it up a peak at 6 a.m. In a snowstorm. On a unicycle. With weights. Alison Berkley, who is 41 and has lived in Aspen almost 10 years, just rolls her eyes. She prefers to sleep late. Shes a princess, after all.

title: Bahrain Protesters Clash With Police Near Capital After Teenagers Funeral
description: Security forces clashed with demonstrators along a central highway west of Bahrains capital, Manama, on Friday, in what appeared to be among the largest protests in months.

title: Laughing at the Big C
description: IT takes a lot of particles to form a wave. Julia Sweeney, the former Saturday Night Live cast member, speaking self-deprecatingly of her pioneering 1996 one-woman Broadway show about having cancer at the same time as her brother, said, When I was doing God Said Ha, people would say, Youre finally making cancer funny. People havent done that before.

title: For Nickelodeon, the 90s Really Are All That
description: Reruns of Nickelodeon shows from the 1990s are edging their way into prime time on TeenNick, the cable channel that started showing rebroadcasting the shows over the summer.

title: Book Review Podcast: Steven Pinkers Better Angels of Our Nature
description: On the cover of this Sundays Book Review, Peter Singer reviews Steven Pinkers new book, The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined. Mr. Pinker argues that our current era is less violent, less cruel and more peaceful than any previous period of human existence.

title: A Design That Lets Two Wheels Act as One
description: A SINGLE-TRACK vehicle like a bicycle, scooter or motorcycle banks through corners in an elegant balancing act that is fundamentally different from the way a four-wheel automobile makes turns.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Indonesia, Libya and Yemen.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Luckyrice, in partnership with the Japanese Culinary Center, is throwing a sake tasting event Friday at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 123 West 18th Street (between Sixth and Seventh Avenues), in Chelsea. Artisanal brewers will be offering tastings paired with bites from local restaurants. Tickets are $50 for entry at 7 p.m. but V.I.P. tickets, $80, afford you access an hour earlier. Online tickets are only available until 2 p.m. but there will be some tickets available, cash only, at the door.

title: Devils Look to Parise for Leadership, and Some Goals
description: NEWARK  Zach Parise signed a one-year contract in July, but that does not mean he is planning to leave the Devils any time soon. Still, he continues to be asked about his long-term future.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Indonesia, Libya and Yemen.

title: Living on Wall Street
description: Since the protests started, the neighborhood of Wall Street has changed, and some residents are fed up.

title: More Evidence of a Big Greenhouse Advantage from Gas Over Coal
description: The Worldwatch Institute and Deutsche Bank Climate Change Advisors recently analyzed the full greenhouse impacts of natural gas and coal  from the well or mine to the power plant  and the work supports other studies pointing to a large and clear climate advantage from gas as a source of electricity. Heres a news release and a pdf of the study.

title: Encore for a Muscle Car Legend
description: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.

title: Placing a Value on Horsepower
description: THOUGH the advent of pollution-control laws pulled the plug on the first wave of Detroits muscle cars early in the 1970s, advances in electronic management systems and exhaust treatment have since taken V-8 power to unprecedented levels. But even in this new age of performance, where cars with clean-running factory-built engines of 500 horsepower are almost commonplace, there is still room for tuner shops that dig deeper.

title: Spicy Steaming Hot Mussels
description: I adore mussels  sweet, briny and aromatic  especially when the weather turns cool. So thats what Im making in this weeks City Kitchen.

title: Ballpark Beer and Hot Dog Prices: the Good, the Bad and the Outrageous
description: For those of you who wonder where your favorite baseball stadium ranks in gouging its customers with the cost of things like tickets, hot dogs and beer, Webstaurantstore.com answers all your questions.

title: For Some, Wall Street Is Main Street
description: Panini and Company Cafe normally sells sandwiches to tourists in Lower Manhattan and the residents nearby, but in recent days its owner, Stacey Tzortzatos, has also become something of a restroom monitor. Protesters from Occupy Wall Street, who are encamped in a nearby park, have been tromping in by the scores, and not because they are hungry.

title: A Tough Year for Market Predictions
description: Who could have predicted the turmoil in the financial markets this year caused by the earthquake in Japan, the revolutions in the Middle East, European debt problems and the downgrade of American debt by Standard & Poors? Not even the best forecasters.

title: In Swipe at Romney, Perry Highlights Abortion Stance
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas sought on Friday to ease concerns of Republican primary voters who have questioned his credentials, highlighting his unwavering support for some red-meat conservative issues: Fighting abortion. Defunding Planned Parenthood. Support for Israel.

title: Staying Power: The Many Forms of Will Barnet
description: ON a recent morning in his double-height studio at the National Arts Club, the painter and printmaker Will Barnet recalled the event precipitating the latest change in his ever-evolving artistic style: a fall in 2003 that left him unable to walk.

title: A 69 Camaro, From the Ground Up
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Ro McGonegal spends time with the latest creation from Baldwin-Motion and delves into the back story of the Brooklyn-born tuner shop, which built customized Chevrolet performance cars from 1967 to 1975.

title: PerkStreet, Kasasa and the War Over Your Checking Account
description: I remain obsessed, as ever, with the outliers in financial services who continue to be particularly generous to their customers. So when both President Obama and Senator Dick Durbin took to the airwaves to denounce Bank of Americas new $5 monthly debit card fee this week, I got curious about what was going to become of the various rewards checking accounts Ive written about in the last year or two.

title: TimesCast | October 7, 2011
description: Three women win the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize: Liberian president Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, her compatriot Leymah Gbowee and Yemeni pro-democracy activist Tawakul Karman.

title: Scent Strip
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#396", 592, 490, false, chameleonData);Stave off the approaching winter chill with the seasons hottest (read: sexiest) fragrances.

title: Krawcheck Steps Down From Post at Wall St. Regulator
description: Sallie L. Krawcheck and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority have officially parted ways.

title: TBS a Winner, Along With Tigers
description: Rooting for or against the New York Yankees has become a tradition for baseball fans and it created record numbers for TBS on Thursday night when the Yankees fell to the Detroit Tigers, 3-2, and 9.7 million viewers were glued to their television screens. It was the most-watched League Division Series game in cable history and the most-watched Division Series game on either network TV or cable since 2005.

title: European Salvo Worries Pipeline Advocates
description: In another wrinkle in the Keystone XL pipeline debate, the European Commission has given initial approval to a measure declaring that fuel from bitumen, the tar in oil sands, is higher in carbon dioxide emissions than conventional oil.

title: DealBook Celebrates 10-Year Anniversary
description: Dear DealBook Readers,

title: #trendingNYC: The Week on Twitter
description: Perhaps they had this coming  those denizens of Twitter who cheered so forcefully for the Red Sox demise that they scarcely saw the Yankees downfall coming. Maybe the fans let their guard down, if only a touch, when the bane of the Twitter-verse, A.J. Burnett, pitched effectively Tuesday night to keep the season alive in the face of a 2-1 playoff series deficit against the Detroit Tigers.

title: Perry Ally Calls Mormonism a Cult
description: A Baptist pastor from Dallas who has endorsed Rick Perry introduced the Texas governor at a conservative forum on Friday in Washington, then later told reporters that Mormonism  the religion of Mitt Romney, Mr. Perrys main rival for the Republican presidential nomination  was a cult.

title: Mindy Kaling Takes the Twitter Prize
description: We shouldnt have been surprised that our most popular story on Twitter in the Sept. 25 issue was that on Mindy Kaling, who has more than 1.5 million followers. With Tweets, if you are sitting around for more than 45 seconds, its probably not the medium for you, the actress/writer told Curtis Sittenfeld.

title: From Russia, Authentic Tchaikovsky, With Love
description: As a theme for a festival, Tchaikovsky in St. Petersburg, which Carnegie Hall is presenting through this month, is pretty vague. That did not matter a bit on Thursday night when Valery Gergiev conducted the Mariinsky Orchestra in the first of three programs presenting the six Tchaikovsky symphonies. The orchestra opened the Carnegie Hall season on Wednesday night with works by Shostakovich, Tchaikovsky (the Rococo Variations, featuring the cellist Yo-Yo Ma) and Rimsky-Korsakov.

title: Breaking Down the Rangers Overtime Loss to the Kings
description: Jack Johnsons power goal with 52 seconds left in overtime gave the Los Angeles Kings a 3-2 win over the Rangers on Friday in Stockholm. The Rangers had a 2-1 lead in the third period, but new Kings center Mike Richards tied the game with just under five minutes remaining in regulation.

title: Still Playing Someones Fierce Sister
description: ADULT children who dream of lashing out at their overbearing mothers, detached fathers and deadbeat loved ones have had a hero in Rachel Griffiths for years now.

title: My Last Play Is One for the Books
description: The shelves were definitely empty on Monday night when Ed Schmidt wrapped up the final performance of My Last Play, his one-man show about acknowledging a lifetime of failure in the theater by giving away his collection of 2,000 theater books.

title: Restricting Free Speech With Lab Coats in Illyria
description: In an unnamed Arab country theaters have been shut down and performance criminalized. From a lectern a former theater producer explains that what he is presenting is not a play but a reconstruction of a 1960s production based on the story of Shakespeares Twelfth Night. Its oddly clinical: Lab coats replace costumes, and men and women remain at a distance from one another. An ominous camera sits in front of the stage. The government is watching.

title: Reviewing the Nissan Quest
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Cheryl Jensen reviews the Nissan Quest, which is redesigned for 2012. Prior generations of the minivan were trendsetters in their segment, with innovative interior features like the 2004 models podlike instrument panel, positioned between the driver and passenger, which housed the shift lever and other controls.

title: Comedy Central Weighs In on Steve Jobs
description: Jon Stewart, host of The Daily Show, and Stephen Colbert of The Colbert Report, paid tribute to Steven P. Jobs, co-founder of Apple, on Thursday night after he died on Wednesday.

title: Big East Talking About the Future
description: The presidents of the universities in the Big East Conference participated in an hour-long conference call Friday morning, but no immediate decisions were made about the future of the league. A league official with direct knowledge of the call said that invitations to potential new members would be handed out soon, perhaps as early as next week.

title: TimesCast | Yemeni Woman Wins Nobel
description: October 7, 2011  Tawakkol Karman was one of the first to lead antigovernment protests in Yemen.

title: Mornings Are Sober but Better at CBS
description: There isnt much news you can use on The Early Show on CBS. It no longer offers dieting tips, barbecue recipes or audience makeovers. There are no pop concerts or Growing Pains cast reunions. The Early Show doesnt plan weddings or even forecast rain  weather is delegated to local affiliates.

title: An Old-Fashioned Date Cant Beat a Night Out Debating Reality TV
description: My maternal grandfather, Don Rose, was an obsessive journal-keeper when he was young. For some years beginning in his late teens, he would record his thoughts and activities in minute detail  not just that he went shopping, but also what he bought and how much it cost. (Fare, town: .50; suit cleaned & mended, 2.05; socks, .25; collars, .25.)

title: Fashions New Face | Valeria S.
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Label Maker
description: A T-shirt? asked the Lanvin shopgirl on the other end of the receiver when I inquired about logo tees. We sell blouses. Have you tried calling the outlets? My recent sartorial scavenge was prompted by Clines resort collection. I was already head over heels for the discreet French label, but then Phoebe Philo, its designer, showed an in-your-face Cline-tagged top, styled smartly beneath a bustier and a prim, tailored jacket. Only Philo could make blatant branding compulsively collectible so soon after wed all stripped the initials (save our own) off our bags and sunglasses. Ive heard they keep them in the back, said a saleswoman at Jeffrey when I went there looking for logos. Thats the secret, he added. You have to ask. A recent trip to Yves Saint Laurent confirmed this to be true. We wouldnt be YSL if we didnt have an inscribed T-shirt, would we? the sales associate coyly whispered to me before returning from the stockroom with a yummy stash of initialed tees in navy and magenta. Well always have them. Blouses, that is.

title: E-Mail Shows Senior Energy Official Pushed Solyndra Loan
description: WASHINGTON  A senior Energy Department official pushed hard for the governments $535 million loan to the now-bankrupt California solar energy company Solyndra even after he had disclosed that his wifes law firm represented the company and he had promised to recuse himself from matters related to the loan application, according to e-mails provided to Congressional investigators by the administration.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 7
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Sketches of Spain, by Turina and Ravel
description: The Spanish composer Joaqun Turina experienced a eureka moment in 1907 while having a drink with his compatriots Isaac Albniz and Manuel de Falla in Paris. He later wrote that during that evening he realized that music should be an art, and not a diversion for the frivolity of women and the dissipation of men.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 7
description: More Photographs

title: Cain Wows Conservative Crowd
description: The top religious conservatives gathered at the Values Voter Summit gave Herman Cain a rousing ovation many times over Friday afternoon as he delivered his stump speech at the annual gathering. The summit stop, at a hotel in Washington, was a detour for Mr. Cain from his book tour, which kicked off this week in New York City.

title: Leading Syrian Opposition Figure Killed, and Another Publicly Beaten
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces on Friday attacked two prominent opposition leaders, shooting one to death in the north and beating another in broad daylight in the heart of the capital, Damascus, activists said.

title: 2 Ousted Executives of Bank of America Get Final Paychecks
description: Two ousted executives of Bank of America, Sallie L. Krawcheck and Joe Price, will receive $6 million and $5 million, respectively, under newly signed agreements smoothing their departures from the bank.

title: 111 Charged in Elaborate Identity-Theft Scheme
description: A total of 111 people have been indicted in an identity-theft scheme that originated largely in the back rooms of Queens restaurants, the authorities said on Friday, and then mushroomed into a worldwide network of counterfeiters, hackers, fences and thieves who made off with an estimated $13 million in fraudulent purchases.

title: CSI: The Experience
description: A new interactive exhibition at Discovery Times Square presents visitors with the case of a dead woman behind a motel.

title: A Body, Blood and Computers: Just Like TV
description: CSI: The Experience, the new exhibition at Discovery Times Square, is based on the very sensible premise that fans of the CSI television series and its clones, CSI: Miami and CSI: NY, are by now so familiar with blood-splatter analysis, corpse lividity, latent print technology, firearms identification, dental records and the lifespan of blowflies that theyre capable of conducting an investigation on their own. And so visitors are issued a pencil, a clipboard and an evidence sheet  but, sadly, not a pair of blue latex gloves  and are dispatched to one of three crime scenes.

title: Still Souped-Up, Four Decades Later
description: Joel Rosen, a trailblazing figure in late-60s muscle, is still building performance cars at 71.

title: A Sashay to India to Spice Up Beets
description: AS much as I appreciate the sweet side of roasted beets, its the sassy recipes that I like best.

title: The Week in Pictures, Oct. 7
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the expanding Wall Street protests, the helicopter crash in the East River, and specialized air travel for dogs.

title: TimesCast | Ending Liberias Civil War
description: October 7, 2011  Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, the current president, and Leymah Gbowee, a peace activist, were awarded the prize for their roles in moving the country beyond its violent past.

title: Lens: Lee Romero
description: Lens: Lee Romero

title: Rift Deepens as N.B.A. Draws Line on Compensation
description: Any hope for a last-second resolution to the N.B.A. lockout vanished Friday, as the owners drew a firm line on player compensation, driving a deep wedge in the already fragile labor negotiations.

title: Online, a Documentary About Harvey Weinstein
description: 6:52 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES  With more of a whimper than a bang, the Barry Avrich-directed documentary about Harvey Weinstein, called Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project, finally landed on Friday. But it did not land in theaters, as Mr. Avrich hoped and expected when IFC Films picked up distribution rights to the film more than a year ago.

title: This Sunday: Pirates Like Cookies, Too
description: When I got the job as editor of this magazine almost a year ago now, it was issues like this weeks that I wished for. I am proud of everything weve published in the magazine over the last several months, but like many writers and editors, I am self-critical to the point that I can look at almost anything Ive ever done and see only the mistakes and missed opportunities therein. But that should not happen with this weeks issue. The mix of stories is the best weve assembled so far, starting with Jeffrey Gettlemans epic pirates tale. It is an exciting, dramatic work of narrative journalism overflowing with memorable moments like this: Once the pirates were in control of the Lynn Rival, they ransacked it, flinging open cupboards, eating all of the Chandlers cookies and stealing their money, watches, rings, electronics, their satellite phone and clothes. Yup, those mean pirates went right for the cookies. Awesome. Adding to the flair and intensity of Jeffreys story are the excellent illustrations by Wesley Allsbrook, the first time she has been in the magazine.

title: Arizona Republicans Disapprove of Draft Redistricting Map
description: Nearly every major Republican politician in Arizona issued a news release this week  all within an hour or so of one another on Wednesday afternoon  condemning a draft redistricting map approved by a state commission.

title: Barnes & Noble in Graphic Novel Dispute
description: In the latest salvo in publishing wars over exclusivity, Barnes & Noble said Friday that it was pulling 100 graphic novels from its shelves after the publisher of the books made a deal with Amazon to sell the digital editions exclusively.

title: Benefits for Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving the Forests, and the Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: In The Long Run We Are Undead
description: Econo-art from Cezmi Dispinar:

title: Nation-Building at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting Cervical Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloggingheads: Vice President Clinton?
description: Jamelle Bouie, left, of The American Prospect and Peter Suderman of Reason debate the possibility of an Obama/Clinton 2012 ticket.

title: The life of Steve Jobs; unemployment and recession; filming food; and self-interested patriotism.
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with John Markoff and Steve Lohr on the life of Steve Jobs; Motoko Rich on unemployment and recession; David Gillen and David Segal on filming food; and Richard Thaler on self-interested patriotism.

title: The Man Who Inspired Jobs
description: IN the memorials to Steven P. Jobs this week, Apples co-founder was compared with the worlds great inventor-entrepreneurs: Thomas Edison, Henry Ford, Alexander Graham Bell. Yet virtually none of the obituaries mentioned the man Jobs himself considered his hero, the person on whose career he explicitly modeled his own: Edwin H. Land, the genius domus of Polaroid Corporation and inventor of instant photography.

title: Prize or Not, Liberian Faces Tough Race to Keep Office
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  The day began in this battered seaside capital with shouts and drumming for a leading Liberian politician  but not the one honored with a Nobel Peace Prize on Friday.

title: La Russa and Leyland Share the Advantages of the Underdog
description: PHILADELPHIA  Tony La Russa, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, quipped Friday afternoon that he spoke more often with Jim Leyland, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, than he did with members of his own family.

title: Between Journalist and Advocate: The Amanda Knox Case
description: IN the news medias frenzy surrounding an Italian courts decision last week to free Amanda Knox, the American exchange student convicted of killing her roommate in Perugia, the journalist Nina Burleigh was a near-constant television presence. Her face looped in and out of shows like Today, Good Morning America, 20/20 and Anderson Cooper 360. She made appearances on NPR, the BBC and MSNBC.

title: A Presidential Candidates Special Team
description: EVERY four years, voters get to know the children of the presidential hopefuls: George W. Bushs Texas twins, for example, or Al Gores brood of four. But now the enterprising children of politicians take advantage of technology to help define their own image.

title: Richard Gere in Tune With Others
description: THE actor Richard Gere is selling his guitar collection on Tuesday at Christies, and unless youre up on your Gere facts, you probably didnt know that he has more than 100 guitars, rare stuff. But somehow this is not surprising. Mr. Gere has been a contented square peg in a shrinking round hole for most of his 35 years in the public eye, a Buddhist and a hunk, a movie star and widely involved activist who has lately added hotelier to his projects.

title: Live Analysis: Carpenter Finishes Off Phillies
description: It is Game 5 of the National League division series, live from Philadelphia, where Roy Halladay faces Chris Carpenter. Get updates, analysis, obscure humor and absolutely no Phillies bias whatsoever, right here at the Bats blog.

title: The Occupy Wall Street Quiz
description: All of a sudden everybodys got an opinion.

title: Egypt's Fall in the Arab World
Cathy Horyn's Paris Runway Report
description: Cathy Horyn discusses themes that have emerged during the spring 2012 collections from Paris Fashion Week.

title: Behind the Oracle-Salesforce Cloud Brawl
description: Earlier this week, Oracles chief executive Larry Ellison went to greater pains than usual to beat up on the competition. Considering the stakes, it was worth it to him.

title: For Women Bankers, a Subdued Awards Party
Split by War, Libyas Team Is United by New Goal
description: CHINGOLA, Zambia  When violent protests erupted in Libya in February, some members of the national soccer team supported Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis regime, including the captain at the time, Tariq Tayib, who called the rebels rats and dogs. Others chose to take up arms.

title: More Bleak Job Numbers
description: It would take a lot of optimism to put a positive spin on the jobs report for September, released on Friday by the Labor Department.

title: A Game to Make Zynga Nervous
description: Over the last month 66,560,159 people have played the Sims Social on Facebook.

title: In Iowa, Ethanol Can Still Trip Up a Candidate
description: Even in Iowa, King Corn is not all that it used to be. But can it still make a presidential candidate waffle?
