title: Ramiz Alia, an Enforcer for a Dictator and Later Ruler of Albania, Dies at 85
description: Ramiz Alia, a cult-of-personality enforcer who succeeded Albanias Communist dictator Enver Hoxha after his death in 1985 and presided over halting and often chaotic moves toward democracy before his own downfall in 1992, died Friday. He was 85.

title: Future of Euro Could Depend on Slovakia
description: The prospect of guaranteeing the debt of richer like Greece, Portugal and even Italy has led to public outrage in Slovakia.

title: Rivalry Is a Sign of Order Inside the Churning Big 12
description: DALLAS  Tickets are distributed with such an air of domestic tranquillity that Texas and Oklahoma might as well be exchanging his-and-her bathrobes.

title: 672 School Jobs Are Lost in Largest Single-Agency Layoff Under Bloomberg
description: Some of them spent the past few days scouring the wanted ads on the New York City Department of Educations Web site. Others made sure they learned how to file for unemployment benefits.

title: Silk Monsoons Cascade Into a Homeland Tale
description: LONDON  The ever-present tensions between history and identity, the collective past and the personal present; the paradoxical state of being that is the condition of the second-generation immigrant. These ideas are at the heart of Akram Khans finest choreography. And Desh, his first full-length solo work, which opened here at Sadlers Wells on Tuesday, is undoubtedly among the best pieces that Mr. Khan has created.

title: Ships, Steeds and Kings, on Two Legs
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  How can this demonstrate that? How can art demonstrate life or history or another work of art? With the speech O for a muse of fire, Shakespeare starts his play Henry V with words about the challenge for theater of trying to represent war. (Think, when we talk of horses, that you see them.) When Laurence Olivier made his 1944 film of Henry V he quickly bypassed the issue of theater, showing his audience real horses, real arrows, real armor, real grass; and he commissioned music by William Walton to help make the movie exciting and affecting.

title: Horrors of a Coming War Painted in a 1935 Meeting
description: On July 17, 1935, The New York Times published a statement by Varian Fry in which that young American, the editor of Living Age magazine, described anti-Jewish rioting that had taken place in Berlin two nights earlier. His account was horrific, and not only because of what it foreshadowed: ordinary Germans joining Nazi thugs in what he characterized as a holiday mood of bloody anti-Semitic violence. Old men and young men, Fry wrote, boys, Storm Troops, police, young girls of the domestic servant type, well-bred women, some even in the forties and over  all seemed to be having a good time.

title: Woods Plays Better and Has the Same Expectation: Victory
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.  The fog that delayed the start of Tiger Woodss second round for over two and half hours on Friday eventually lifted, and so did the gloom enveloping his game.

title: Philharmonic Union Authorizes Strike
description: In a sign of potential conflict to come, the musicians of the New York Philharmonic, above, have voted to authorize their representatives to call a strike, two orchestra members said on Friday. The players spoke on condition of anonymity because orchestra leaders ordered the members not to discuss the matter. The musicians contract expired on Sept. 20, but they have continued to perform, not an unusual practice. Several musicians say the atmosphere seems tenser than in the past, amid fears that a diminished contract could induce players to leave for teaching jobs or other top-tier orchestras like the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Chicago Symphony. At the same time, the orchestra has 16 openings. Members of the orchestras negotiating committee declined to comment. In a statement the orchestras management said the strike authorization vote, held last week, was standard procedure and had no effect on its desire to reach an agreement. While there are serious issues under consideration, we are hopeful that a new agreement will be reached, and that the orchestra will continue to perform according to the published concert schedule, management said. Both sides are currently engaged in negotiations, it added, but orchestra officials declined to elaborate or to provide details on contacts between the sides.

title: For Mayor, Occupy Wall Street Evokes Protests From Vietnam Era
description: The simmering discontent that has provoked the Occupy Wall Street protests has prompted numerous historical comparisons. Some are calling the movement a liberal version of the Tea Party. Others see a repeat of the 1930s populism that accompanied the New Deal.

title: Life for Walking Dead
description: Just in time for people to catch up with The Walking Dead, the AMC series that begins its second season on Oct. 16, the first season is now streaming on Netflix. The drama, about survivors of a zombie infestation, is the most prominent part of a multiyear content-licensing deal announced Friday by Netflix and AMC. The arrangement is the latest display of Netflixs determination to license back-seasons of top television shows, diversifying its streaming service beyond feature films. This year the company struck a deal with Lionsgate, the producer of AMCs Mad Men, to stream previous seasons of that show. Some other AMC Networks shows will also be streamed on Netflix just prior to the premiere of subsequent seasons, according to a news release. Those include Portlandia on IFC, Braxton Family Values on WE and All on the Line With Joe Zee on the Sundance Channel. Netflix did not disclose the terms of the deal, but it has been willing to pay substantial amounts for other shows and films.

title: U.S. Attorneys in California Set Crackdown on Marijuana
description: LOS ANGELES  Federal officials on Friday warned dozens of marijuana dispensaries throughout California to shut down or face civil and criminal action as part of a major crackdown on the states growing medical marijuana industry.

title: Embracing His Inner Obamacare
description: As part of his newfound assertiveness, President Obama is using the term Obamacare, the Republicans sneering dismissal of the Democratic health care reforms. We are skeptical that he will be able to turn it into a term of approbation. But it is heartening to see him finally out there defending his pioneering policy with no apologies and an uncharacteristic feistiness.

title: Musical Themes, Covering Landscapes
description: Red Light New Musics thematic concerts can seem either inventive or fanciful, depending on whether a listener is persuaded that the works at hand touch on the programs unifying notion. The groups season opener at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia on Monday evening was called In a Landscape: Music as Map, and it was meant, according to the season prospectus, to include works influenced by physical environments, from the arctic to the urban to the volcanic.

title: Senator Protests Agency Decision to Remove Doctor Data Online
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley on Friday joined with dozens of academic researchers, consumer groups and journalism organizations who have protested an Obama administration decision to pull off the Web a database of doctor malpractice and disciplinary cases.

title: A Suit Yields a Telling Effect on the Play in Another Suit
description: The Arthur L. Loeb Cup was played on Tuesday morning. There were 90 pairs competing, many of whom were pro-am partnerships. The tournament was held at, and the entry fees benefited, the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House in Manhattan, to which Loeb, an avid bridge player, has been a generous supporter.

title: U.S. Envoy Puts Match to Bridges With Iraq Tell-All
description: WASHINGTON

title: Fox Renews The Simpsons for Two More Seasons
description: The Springfield nuclear power plant will remain operational, and it wont be closing time at Moes Tavern for at least two more years: on Friday night, Fox announced that it had renewed its hit animated comedy The Simpsons, televisions longest running prime-time scripted series, for two additional seasons, following a contract dispute with its voice cast that had threatened to end the show altogether.

title: Will Barnet at 100
description: A mainstay of the New York art world for eight decades gets his first retrospective there.

title: Bill Cunningham | Paris
description: The caravan arrived in Paris for the final shows of the spring 2012 collections, carrying luggage filled with autumn clothes. Paris suffered a heat wave, and the guests stripped down.

title: Polands European Union Ties May Hinge on Elections
description: BERLIN  Poles are set to vote on Sunday in elections that could well determine whether the country continues its deepening cooperation with European Union allies under Prime Minister Donald Tusk or lurches back toward a more confrontational course under its former leader.

title: Senator Paul, Lift the Hold
description: Heres an addition to the file marked Extreme Dysfunction: Congress Edition. A bill that would extend life-saving cash assistance to 5,600 disabled and elderly refugees  a bill whose support is so broad that it includes Senators Charles Schumer of New York and Jeff Sessions of Alabama, a bill that would pay for itself and even raise a bit for deficit reduction  cant get through the Senate.

title: In Search of ...
description: Two very good officials are leaving two of the most important jobs in New York State  one by choice, the other because Gov. Andrew Cuomo has asked him to go. Mr. Cuomo needs to quickly find exemplary replacements to run the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. And he will have to support them when they make politically tough but necessary decisions.

title: California Prison Hunger Strike Resumes as Sides Dig In
description: LOS ANGELES  When inmates across Californias state prisons went on a hunger strike in July, prison officials negotiated with them, ultimately reaching an agreement to bring the strike to an end after three weeks.

title: The Outcast of Brownstone Brooklyn
description: The scarlet letter may have little currency left in the realm of sexual indiscretion, but it continues to be put to vigorous use among parents  the shaming impulse particularly thrives in the wealthier precincts of brownstone Brooklyn, where the exacting standards of urbane motherhood would seem to have been invented. In a place where judgment is easily rendered on those who allow their children to drink juice, there is not much sympathy available to someone like Providence Hogan, who was charged by the Brooklyn district attorneys office last March with embezzling from the PTA.

title: Lottery Numbers
Ten Years In, Afghan Myths Live On
description: TEN years after invading Afghanistan, on Oct. 7, 2001, the obvious question is whether or not the United States has won the war. Osama bin Ladens death suggests the defeat of Al Qaeda. But even after the planned withdrawal of 30,000 American troops by late 2012, nearly 70,000 will remain on the ground.

title: Stuck in Traffic? A Star Is Born
description: IF most jobs in television are not as fabulous in real life as they seem from the battered couches of the people watching at home, the job of NY1 early-morning traffic reporter has a particularly high grunge-to-glamour imbalance: Youre on the air at 5 a.m. Your job is to tell viewers when the 2/3 trains are running local south of 34th Street and just how backed up the BQE is, in exactly 60 seconds.

title: Chic in Review | The Million Dollar Blogger?
Among 3 Women Awarded Nobel Peace Prize, a Nod to the Arab Spring
description: SANA, Yemen  She is only 32 years old, an outspoken human rights activist and mother of three who was unknown outside her own country until she began leading anti-government protests this year.

title: Prominent Pastor Calls Romneys Church a Cult
description: WASHINGTON  A Texas pastor introduced Rick Perry at a major conference of Christian conservatives here on Friday as a genuine follower of Jesus Christ and then walked outside and attacked Mitt Romneys religion, calling the Mormon Church a cult and stating that Mr. Romney is not a Christian.

title: Brewers Beat Diamondbacks in Game Five
description: Nyjer Morgan delivered an R.B.I. single in the 10th inning to beat the Arizona Diamondbacks 3-2 Friday in Game 5 and send the Brewers to the National League championship series.

title: A Garage Is All Aglitter for Arts Sake
description: We were in a decommissioned bus depot at Pier 57 in Hudson River Park when the artist Chuck Close buzzed past us with his girlfriend, Sienna Shields, seated in his lap on his electric wheelchair. Their lips passionately interlocked, and they never looked up as they rolled out the door. It was Wednesday night, and the Whitney Museum of American Arts yearly gala, held this year under disco balls in an asphalt-and-steel garage, was wrapping up.

title: Liberian Peace Activist Learns of Nobel Peace Prize While on Book Tour
description: Soon after she walked into the chapel, Leymah Gbowee of Liberia started singing. She was still having a hard time believing she had just won the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Brewers Advance by Beating Diamondbacks in 10th Inning
description: MILWAUKEE  The man of many personas, Nyjer Morgan, flitted from euphoria to sadness in the aftermath of the most important hit of his career.

title: Scan-to-Buy Gets a Trial on Television
description: In a television experiment, shoppers this weekend watching HSN, the shopping network, can scan their TV screens with a smartphone to learn more about the products on display, and, HSN hopes, become more inclined to buy them.

title: Kite Fighting in New York
description: A group of Pakistani immigrants in New York are preserving a traditional South Asian sport.

title: Perry Disagrees With Supporters Comment on Mormon Church
description: TIFFIN, Iowa  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said Friday night that he does not believe the Mormon Church is a cult, but he declined to answer questions about a remark from a Texas pastor who criticized the religion of Mitt Romney and declared that he is not a Christian.

title: Collateral Damage in the Chinatown Bus Wars
description: In 2004, a seat on a bus from Chinatown to Boston cost $10, but the related costs were sometimes staggering. Indirectly, the bus business took the life of a cocktail waitress one night at work; she was killed by a stray bullet to her head. Hundreds of man-hours of police work would follow, as would the efforts of Interpol and various police agencies in the United States and Canada seven years later.

title: Numbers Scribbled Here and There Added Up to $600,000 in Bribes, U.S. Says
description: In recent years, federal prosecutors say, Wendell B. Walters has spent a fair amount of time scribbling down numbers on little pieces of paper.

title: Doctor Tells How Jackson Sought Sleep
description: In an interview recorded two days after Michael Jacksons death, Dr. Conrad Murray told the Los Angeles police that he had spent hours trying to get the singer to sleep using milder drugs before resorting to a powerful anesthetic that Jackson referred to as his milk.

title: A.I.G. Unit and a French Bank Settle a Lawsuit
description: Crdit Lyonnais, a French bank, will pay $150 million to settle a suit filed by the American International Groups SunAmerica unit over its 1993 investment in a California insurance company that the French bank had illegally acquired.

title: Unleashing the Scientist in the Student
description: Be careful! shouted a seventh grader from Coney Islands Mark Twain Intermediate School 239 for the Gifted and Talented.

title: Koch and N.Y.U. Clash Over Terrorism Report
description: A report on terrorism prosecutions written by scholars at New York Universitys School of Law has set off an ugly fight, pitting the school against former Mayor Edward I. Koch and Representative Peter T. King in what one side calls a question of intellectual freedom, and the other says is a matter of intellectual honesty.

title: One of Cuban Five Spies Is Released on Probation
description: MEXICO CITY  When five Cuban intelligence officers were charged with spying against the United States in 1998, the Cuban government immediately hailed them as heroes, with billboards, books and movies, and argued that their convictions and sentences  handed down in a Miami court  proved that the United States was an enemy, beholden to radical Cuban exiles.

title: Calendars Shed Light on Enigmatic Bloomberg Aide
description: Patricia E. Harris, the first deputy mayor, is arguably the most important unelected person in city government and may also be seen as the personification, as the head of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs charitable foundation, of the blurred lines between the mayors public and private lives.

title: That Felon Inspecting Trash? He Used to Be Mayor
description: My encounter with Gerry McCann began with a warrant for my arrest.

title: Pipeline Review Is Faced With Question of Conflict
description: The State Department assigned an important environmental impact study of the proposed Keystone XL pipeline to a company with financial ties to the pipeline operator, flouting the intent of a federal law meant to ensure an impartial environmental analysis of major projects.

title: In Schools, Yoga Without the Spiritual
description: TO om or not to om: For those who teach yoga in schools, that is a question that arises with regularity.

title: Wall Street Weeks
description: The Occupy Wall Street encampment in Lower Manhattan is covered with damp sleeping bags, interspersed among piles of wet, abandoned clothes. Molding stuff is everywhere. It looks like a scene from Outdoor Hoarders.

title: Brief Encounters, Messengers and Guides
description: WHEN Tennyson wrote that it is better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all, he could hardly have imagined the possibilities posed by the fleeting encounters described in the Missed Connections section of Craigslist. Now, Sophie Blackall picks up where Tennyson left off in Missed Connections: Love, Lost & Found (Workman Publishing), a witty, wistful collection of illustrations and commentary that originated on her blog and found their way into a charming little book.

title: Corrections: October 8
description: NATIONAL

title: Saturday: Sounds Like a Broken Record
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  When The Kids were younger, I hired a teenager to babysit so I could get out of the house and have a coherent thought once a week. One evening, the teenager showed up wearing a T-shirt that had a picture of the plastic inserts we used to put into the large holes of 45 r.p.m. records so that we could play them on our turntables. Strictly out of curiosity (and not masochism, as some of you are no doubt thinking), I asked the 15-year-old if she could tell me what the object on her T-shirt was, and thoroughly enjoyed the fact that she could not. The closest she could get, being only 15, was that the picture on her shirt was neat. To her credit, she knew that a turntable was something on which her Dad used to play records. Whatever those were.

title: Mexico: Prosecutor Quits After 32 Bodies Are Found
description: The chief prosecutor in Veracruz State resigned Friday, a day after 32 bodies were discovered in a residential neighborhood and less than three weeks after 35 bodies were dumped on a busy highway. The state prosecutor, Reynaldo Escobar Prez, resigned for unspecified personal reasons, a spokeswoman said. The departure came as federal forces flooded Veracruz and arrested 20 suspects believed to be members of rival drug gangs. President Felipe Caldern hailed the arrests on Twitter as a great blow to criminal gangs.

title: Holder Reacts to Criticism of Gun Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. lashed out at members of Congress who are investigating Justice Department actions in a disputed gun-trafficking inquiry, saying Friday in a letter that public discussion about the issue had become base and inflammatory and was aimed solely at gaining political advantage.

title: Revenge of the Gougers
description: The hardest part about writing about Bank of Americas dunderheaded plan to impose a $5-a-month fee on debit card users is deciding which of the many juicy angles to pursue. Have Bank of Americas Managers Lost Their Minds? asked The American Banker earlier this week. Thats one good angle.

title: Yanks Rodriguez Insists He Is Up to the Challenge
description: The lasting image from the Yankees failed 2011 playoff campaign was almost identical to the lasting image from their exit in 2010. The only difference was that this year, Alex Rodriguez went down swinging for the final out. Last year he looked at strike three to end Game 6 of the American League Championship Series.

title: A Night Owl Explores by Day
description: For Cosmo Baker, a D.J., music producer and writer, Sundays are a chance to wind down from traveling  coming trips include ones to South Africa and Dubai  and late-night Saturdays, while relaxing and exploring the city. Mr. Baker, 37, lives with his wife, Sydney Peck, a lawyer, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Unearthing the General

title: Podcast: Steve Jobs, Unemployment and Patriotic Spending
description: The death of Steve Jobs has set off a global outpouring of tributes rarely seen for a business figure. What made him so special?

title: Snapshots of Layoffs Effect, From the Newly Unemployed
description: The last school bell on Friday was the beginning of unemployment for 672 employees in roughly 350 city schools  school aides, parent coordinators, health aides and other support staff members. These are four of the school workers who were let go.

title: A Michigan Star Says His Game Has Matured
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  When Denard Robinson arrived at Michigan three years ago, he spoke so fast that his offensive linemen could not understand him. He also delivered every check-down pass like Justin Verlander. And Robinsons feet gyrated so quickly during his cameos in the pocket that he looked more like a tap dancer than a quarterback.

title: Warm Reception for Bachmann at Values Conference
description: Representative Michele Bachmann liked the looks of the crowd gathered at the sixth annual Values Voter Summit meeting in Washington on Friday.

title: Nocturnalist at Joan Riverss House
description: Nocturnalist visits a party at Joan Riverss house.

title: Desperately Seeking Someone
description: Lets get this out of the way: The presidential election is more than a year away, and things can and will change between now and then. Caveat: check!

title: The Turban, Defiled by Suicide Bombers, Has Biblical and Emotional Roots
description: Charlottesville, Va.

title: Its Like Sharks vs. Jets as Senate Wrangles Over Vote, but Without Music
description: WASHINGTON  Of the multitudinous insults that have zinged across the Capitol this year, a taunt most brutal was leveraged by the Republican leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on the Senate floor on Thursday night. He accused the Democratic leader, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, of fundamentally turning the Senate into the House.

title: Let Go by Boston, Playing on Into October
description: The teams that will play for the American League pennant both found unlikely sources for upgrading their lineups last winter. The Texas Rangers and the Detroit Tigers signed free agents cut loose by the Boston Red Sox.

title: Tigers-Rangers Series May Signal A.L. East Is No Longer Ascendant
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Jim Leyland sounded too exhausted to be concerned about anything but sleep. The Yankees had been vanquished, Detroits starting pitchers were back to resembling their normal rotation, and the Tigers will be facing a Texas team they defeated six times in nine games during the regular season.

title: Panels Advice on Prostate Test Sets Up Battle
description: A day after a government panel said that healthy men should no longer get screened for prostate cancer, some doctors groups and cancer patients advocates began a campaign to convince the nation that the advice was misguided.

title: Effects of the Standard & Poors Downgrade
description: Performance of treasury bonds, stocks, and the dollar since Standard & Poors downgraded United States treasury debt.

title: After a Rating Downgrade, U.S. Treasuries Turn a Profit
description: TWO months ago, Standard & Poors downgraded the bond rating of the United States government. So far, at least, the move has done wonders for investors in the very bonds that the rating agency disparaged.

title: Generals Career Is Stalled No More
description: The Army general who served as the militarys top intelligence officer in Afghanistan, but then found his career stalled after a controversial profile of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal appeared in Rolling Stone magazine, received his third star on Friday as he became the assistant director of national intelligence. The officer, Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, was the top intelligence officer for the Joint Chiefs of Staff before he joined General McChrystal in Kabul to oversee a revamping of the American-led mission in Afghanistan. He pioneered new intelligence techniques to understand terrorist and insurgent networks, and to track and attack their leadership. However, after General McChrystal was abruptly relieved of command by President Obama following the publication of the unflattering magazine profile, General Flynn saw his promotions frozen. But two official investigations, by the Defense Department and the Army, found no proof of any wrongdoing by General McChrystal or by anyone on his command staff.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: The debt crisis in Greece continued to threaten to drag down Europe, the Occupy Wall Street protests gained union support, and Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder of Apple, died.

title: McKnight Showing the Athleticism the Jets Counted On
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets special-teams coach, Mike Westhoff, has just one guideline for those who return kickoffs: they need to be moving forward when they catch the ball. There are no invisible lines in the end zone that make a kickoff too deep to return.

title: In G.O.P. Race, Foreign Policy Is a Footnote
description: WASHINGTON  Herman Cain suggested that Israels conservative prime minister would be open to allowing Palestinians right of return to the lands they fled in what is now Israel. Gov. Rick Perry suggested it was possible that American troops could be sent to Mexico if drug violence there got worse. And former Senator Rick Santorum offered that the United States should engage with the ousted Pakistani dictator Pervez Musharraf  now living in self-exile in London  to respond to the threat of Pakistans nuclear weapons falling into the wrong hands.

title: Carpenter Finishes Off the Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Philadelphia Phillies banked their season on baseballs most timeless adage: good pitching stops good hitting. It led them to 102 victories, the most in the history of the franchise. It would, they hoped, carry them to their second championship in four seasons.

title: Insurers Review Whether to Still Pay for Routine Screening
description: Insurers and clinicians scrambled on Friday to decide whether to continue to offer routine P.S.A. tests following news that an influential panel of experts no longer recommended them for healthy men.

title: Waiting Is Painful for Giants Top Pick
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The arrival of the rookie Giants cornerback Prince Amukamara has been little more than a tease to this point. He has been at practices, but not practicing. He has been a part of the team, but not a part of the action.

title: Cardinals Beat Phillies in Game Five
description: The St. Louis Cardinals beat the Philadelphia Phillies in game five.

title: Swashbuckling Times in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  On the contemporary streets of Los Angeles this past week, it became obvious, via billboards and bus posters everywhere, that Hollywood had developed a sudden fascination with the 17th Century. High and low, the symbols were there: swords, doublets and big floppy hats with a jaunty tilt.

title: Split by War, Libyas Team Reunites With a New Goal
description: Among the many Libyans who took sides in the countrys civil war were members of its national soccer team. A former captain of the team called the anti-Qaddafi rebels rats and dogs, while several of his teammates took up arms against the crumbling government. James Montague visited the reconstituted team in Zambia, where on Saturday it will try to clinch a berth in next years African Cup of Nations. Read his article here, and come back to comment.

title: Secret Gardener
description: An artist who designed and maintains the grounds of Grey Gardens worked to preserve the spirit of the homes original occupants.

title: Evergreen Gardens
description: The legend of the two Edith Beales, the subject of a new dramatized film version of Grey Gardens on HBO, continues to resonate.

title: Inside Grey Gardens
description: An exclusive look inside the legendary house shortly after it was purchased by Sally Quinn and Benjamin C. Bradlee in 1979.

title: The Threat of Black Carbon
description: Soot  also known as black carbon  from millions of villages like Kohlua, India, is emerging as a major source of global climate change.

title: Holiday Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Out of the N.B.A., Thomas Retains Influence There
description: The N.B.A.s brightest stars will take their talents to Miami on Saturday night, to a smallish gymnasium at a public research university with no particular athletic identity.

title: Want to Catch a Thief? Theres an App for That
description: The police arrested a 23-year-old Queens man on Friday for stealing an iPhone earlier in the week  and they found him with the aid of an app.

title: The World This Week  Part 1
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: After 4 Weeks, the 2011 Top Fantasy Football Experts
description: The New York Times has a reputation for having an intellectually advanced readership. Who would have thought, though, that this high I.Q. would also apply to fantasy football predictions? The readers of this blog happen to be sitting atop our Start/Sit Accuracy Challenge, which tracks how accurate several communities are at making our most difficult Who should I start? decisions. Congratulations on the strong showing thus far.

title: A Contentious Ride Into Beijing
description: Not long ago, the roads in and around Beijing were clogged by bicycles. Last week, however, the cars, trucks and buses that are the citys new source of congestion were cleared away to make room for cyclists. But cyclists of an elite variety.

title: The World This Week  Part 2
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Diane Cilento, Oscar-Nominated Actress, Dies at 78
description: Diane Cilento, an Australian actress whose long stage and screen career included an Oscar-nominated performance in the 1963 movie Tom Jones,  died in Queensland, Australia, on Thursday, a day after her 78th birthday.

title: Tigers-Yankees Game 5 Draws High Rating
description: The Tigers series-clinching win over the Yankees on Thursday night on TBS attracted an average of 9.7 million viewers, the most to watch a league division series game on cable and the most since a Yankees-Angels game on Fox in 2005.

title: Piero Weiss, Pianist and Musicologist, Dies at 83
description: Piero Weiss, a former concert pianist and recording artist who turned to musicology, becoming an author and co-author of books in the field, including a widely used textbook, and founding the music history department at the Peabody Conservatory, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 83.

title: Battle for Surt | October 7, 2011
description: Anti-Qaddafi soldiers were positioned near the front line in Surt while wounded fighters were given medical care.

title: A Decade of Dominance  Against Only One Team
description: Over the past 10 seasons, the Yankees have played nine first-round division series. In four instances, the opponent was the Minnesota Twins, and the Yankees won every one of those series. Against everyone else, they lost.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: An uncensored video clip of two senior leaders hurling abuses at each other in the Jammu and Kashmir Assembly on Monday has gone viral in the Valley. The 141-second long clip, in Kasmiri, of the bitter exchange between Assembly Speaker Mohammad Akbar Lone and members of the opposition party MLA, has been featured on hundreds of Facebook pages. (Kashmir Live)Haryana: The local administration in the Karnal district of Haryana launched a Facebook campaign to protect females. The impetus behind the drive is to raise youth awareness about the social fallout of a skewed sex ratio. (The Tribune)

title: All the Colors of Fridays Qualifiers
description: Its tough to wrap up 24 qualifying games in a comprehensive way, so lets hit the highlights with a spin around the color wheel.

title: Sweet and Sour Suzuka Qualifying Session
description: SUZUKA, Japan  We finally we had an interesting qualifying session for the front-runners. Never mind that Sebastian Vettel took the pole position again, his 12th in the 15 possible this season. The last laps of the session were worth the wait to watch the suspense as the leading drivers crossed the line probably the thickness of a sheet of paper apart: Jenson Button, who was fastest in every one of the three practice sessions this weekend, lost the pole position to Vettel by a few thousandths of a second.

title: Sweet and Sour Suzuka Qualifying Session
description: SUZUKA, Japan  We finally we had an interesting qualifying session for the front-runners. Never mind that Sebastian Vettel took the pole position again, his 12th in the 15 possible this season. The last laps of the session were worth the wait to watch the suspense as the leading drivers crossed the line probably the thickness of a sheet of paper apart: Jenson Button, who was fastest in every one of the three practice sessions this weekend, lost the pole position to Vettel by a few thousandths of a second.

title: The Wizard and the Mortal: Two Sides of Genius
description: IN August 1931, Thomas Alva Edison, age 84, became gravely ill with kidney problems. He recovered a little, then suffered a setback and was confined to bed at home, drifting in and out of consciousness. Newspapers issued multiple bulletins each day, reporting on signs of improvement or decline. The end came in the early morning of Oct. 18, 1931, with his family at his bedside.

title: The Power of Taking the Big Chance
description: STEVE JOBS, technologist and tastemaker of modern digital culture, described himself as a captain of product design, inspiring his teams of workers, as he once said, to go beyond what anyone thought possible and to do some great work, really great work that will go down in history.

title: Chrysler Then and Now
description: The smallest of the three American automakers has been known for its innovations and for its brushes with insolvency.

title: Drop that Guitar and Put Up Your Hands
description: Aug. 6, 2012, 10:39 a.m. | Updated | The Justice Department has closed its criminal case against the Gibson Guitar Company after the company agreed to a series of steps, including payment of $300,000 and forfeiture of hardwood from India and Madagascar with an estimated value of $264,000. The details can be read in a news release.

title: Do You Know These Fans?
description: Alex Rodriguez exited stage right Thursday night after striking out to end the Yankees season far sooner than many fans had hoped. Can you help us identify any of the fans in this photo who were there to see him off? E-mail us at nytsportsphoto@gmail.com.

title: Slide Show: Life After the Yankees
description: Hideki Irabu, a former New York Yankee who committed suicide in July, had tried to make a baseball comeback in Californias Golden Baseball League.

title: 3 in Indonesia Charged With Plotting Suicide Attacks
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The Indonesian police arrested three men on Saturday and accused them of plotting two suicide attacks in the last six months that injured scores of people.

title: Ah Yes, LM (Wonkish)
description: Brad DeLong, Mark Thoma, Matt Rognlie, and others are debating the usefulness of the textbook IS-LM model. So, my inflation-adjusted two cents.

title: 30 Seconds With Clark Gillies: Ex-Star Hopes Isles Shine
description: Clark Gillies, a former Islanders star, rang the Nasdaq closing bell recently, and the bell survived. In fact, the market jumped after Gillies, a rare player who could fight as well as shoot and skate skillfully, performed the honors. Gillies, 57, was a key player when the Islanders won four consecutive Stanley Cups from 1980 to 1983. A member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, he was recently honored at the 26th Annual Great Sports Legends Dinner to benefit The Buoniconti Fund to Cure Paralysis.

title: Praying, Then Producing a Hit
description: Many directors think of their work as a kind of religion, but few actually refer to their production company as a moviemaking ministry  unless of course they are the people behind Sherwood Pictures. The Georgia-based Sherwood Baptist Church has released four films, and its latest, Courageous, has shown once again that it has a way with Christian audiences.

title: Souters Career
description: Justice David H. Souter, the 105th justice to be appointed to the Supreme Court, plans to retire in June after more than 18 years on the court, people informed about the decision said.

title: Embedded at Firebase Vimoto
description: Some of the hour-by-hour conduct of the war in Afghanistan rests on young American servicemen who lead Afghan troops as their training and instincts guide them.

title: Act IV for U.S. and Klinsmann
description: Across the Atlantic Ocean, qualifying matches in the group stage for Euro 2012 conclude Tuesday. In the Concacaf region, the preliminary round of World Cup qualifiers is in full swing. And in South America, the marathon tournament that will lead to Brazil in 2014 has finally begun.

title: The Backwards S Of Doom (Wonkish)
description: Greg Ip reports on a Bank Credit Analyst analysis of the euro crisis that emphasizes the possibility of multiple equilibria; its similar in spirit to what Ive been saying, but with a niftier picture:

title: Re-Shoring
description: Ugly new term, but apparently the new thing; it refers to companies moving production back to America from China. The fact that such stories are being heard is support for those (including me) demanding action on the renminbi, because they show that there is indeed a margin at which changes in Chinese dollar costs move production back to the United States, and hence that the undervalued renminbi directly costs US jobs, as well as having the indirect effects Ive written about recently.

title: Big City Book Club: Privilege and Strife
description: Next up for the Big City Book Club is This Beautiful Life, the latest novel by Helen Schulman. The book revolves around a digital pornography scandal set amid the immense privileges and antagonisms of the New York private-school world. Join Ginia Bellafante, the Big City columnist, for a live online discussion of the novel on Tuesday, Oct. 18, from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m.

title: The Leading Interpreters of a Turbulent Era
description: FOR music lovers of a certain age and inclination, the late-1960s love affair between Judy Collins and Stephen Stills remains an epic tale, and the piece Mr. Stills wrote about it  Suite: Judy Blue Eyes  retains its hallowed place in the canon. Little wonder, then, that Ms. Collins, in a recent conversation, grew animated when discussing the song.

title: Celebrating Warhol at a Shrine to Pollock
description: Andy Warhol was obsessed with fame. You might say that it was his only consistent medium, and that everything else he did  painting, film, sculpture, publishing  was just a vehicle for examining its properties and effects. Now the Pollock-Krasner House and Study Center has taken his most famous utterance, In the future, everyone will be world-famous for 15 minutes, and used it as a springboard to create an exhibition.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 3 OKLAHOMA VS. NO. 11 TEXAS IN DALLAS

title: Al Davis, the Controversial and Combative Raiders Owner, Dies at 82
description: Al Davis, the irascible owner of the Oakland Raiders whose feuds with the National Football League reshaped professional football over the last half century and helped spur its rise to pre-eminence in the landscape of American sports, died Saturday morning. He was 82.

title: Giants Umenyiora Perfects Pass-Rush Move, Building Career Around It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora can trace the transformation of his career back to a single game film he watched in 2005.

title: Three Characters in Their Own Separate Worlds
description: When youve seen a show in New York and then go to see it in New Haven with the same director (Charlotte Moore) and two-thirds of the same cast, you expect a similar experience. But the Irish Repertory Theater production of Brian Friels drama Molly Sweeney at Long Wharf Theater yields only two-thirds of the New York experience, which is lovely. The other third is, Im sorry to say, annoying.

title: Even in a Locker Room Apart, an Undeniable Leap of Progress
description: The most exceptional thing about Brianna Amat, who has become known as the Kicking Queen, is not her twin accomplishments as homecoming queen and place-kicker. It is that she feels accepted as a full member of the high school football team in Pinckney, Mich.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Patriots Offense Soars as Defense Stumbles
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The explosiveness of the New England Patriots offense through the first four weeks has been startling. Their quarterback, Tom Brady, leads the league in passing yards and touchdowns thrown. Their top receiver, Wes Welker, is on pace for 160 receptions and 2,464 yards. Only one team  unbeaten Green Bay  has scored more points.

title: Revitalized Lions Suddenly a Hot Ticket
description: ALLEN PARK, Mich.  Down the hall from where Detroit Lions Coach Jim Schwartz characterized his teams first Monday Night Football appearance in 10 years as nothing more than a tough division game, the veteran wideout Nate Burleson stood at his locker and hyped the game against Chicago like a preacher in a revival tent.

title: A Play (in a Boston Preview) Within a 1940s Comedy
description: Gertrude Lawrence. Billy Rose. Guthrie McClintic. Do those names mean anything to you?

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Variety: A Somewhat Base Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  The quote immortalized in todays Acrostic puzzle is a confession of sorts, and a fascinating peek into the mind of a brilliant man. Walt Whitman, nineteenth century poet and essayist, admits readily that what the American people wanted to read was the sort of thing he wanted to read himself. His 1855 collection of poems, Leaves of Grass, was considered immoral in its day for its honest portrayal of sensuality.

title: Romney Tries to Reassure Socially Conservative  Audience
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.  Though Mitt Romney has stuck to a relentless focus on jobs and the economy while on the campaign trail, he departed from his usual message Saturday morning at the Values Voter Summit, devoting part of his speech to the socially conservative issues the crowd had come to hear about.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Live Analysis: College Football Week Six
description: Zach Hillesland will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: France and Wales Reach Semifinals
description: France beat England, 19-12, to reach its fifth consecutive Rugby World Cup semifinal, where it will play Wales for a spot in the Oct. 23 final.

title: Grab a Brew! Lederhosen and Dirndl Are Optional
description: OKTOBERFEST thrives on clichs: brimming tankards, dirndled Mdchens, assorted wursts. And the White Plains Oktoberfest Street Fair, from 3 to 8 p.m. Sunday, as well as the Oktoberfest at Bear Mountain State Park, held every weekend through the end of October, offer variations on the theme  beer, brats and music by bands like Alpine Squeeze and the Austrian Boys.

title: Variety for Vegans, Without the Hot Stove
description: HUNTINGTON, N.Y.

title: Protest Spurs Online Dialogue on Inequity
description: What began as a small group of protesters expressing their grievances about economic inequities last month from a park in New York City has evolved into an online conversation that is spreading across the country on social media platforms.

title: Cardinals Carpenter Becomes an Android, With a Nasty Sinker
description: PHILADELPHIA  Chris Carpenter was the last member of the St. Louis Cardinals to leave the field at Citizens Bank Park late Friday night.

title: Domestic Workers Convention May Be Landmark
description: WASHINGTON  When governments from around the globe passed a treaty in June to protect domestic workers, labor experts called it a surprising breakthrough for millions of exploited women.

title: State Did Not Rush on Fracking, Commissioner Says
description: From the quietness of his office, Joe Martens, head of New York States Department of Environmental Conservation, answered questions on Saturday morning about the charged topic of natural gas drilling in an hourlong session online.

title: Irabu Got Lost on the Road Back
description: It was the kind of inquiry that curious pitchers make, even ones with World Series rings. How, Hideki Irabu wanted to know, do you throw a changeup?

title: Fruit Wines Move Into a Sophisticated Realm
description: GUILFORD

title: Killing of Opposition Leader in Syria Provokes Kurds
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Tens of thousands of people poured into the streets of a Syrian city on Saturday for the funeral of a celebrated Kurdish opposition leader whose assassination the day before unleashed fury in the countrys Kurdish regions and threatened to open a new theater of opposition to President Bashar al-Assads rule.

title: Susies Broke Yuppie Granola
description: As a self-taught cook for a family of five, Im not exact about measurements  or anything. I just eyeball it and taste. If it seems good, Im happy.

title: Vacuum Is Feared as U.S. Quits Iraq, but Irans Deep Influence May Not Fill It
description: NAJAF, Iraq  As the United States draws down its forces in Iraq, fears abound that Iran will simply move into the vacuum and extend its already substantial political influence more deeply through the soft powers of culture and commerce. But here, in this region that is a center of Shiite Islam, some officials say that Iran wore out its welcome long ago.

title: Russian Anger Grows Over Chechnya Subsidies
description: MOSCOW  Twelve years ago, a little-known bureaucrat named Vladimir V. Putin began a war on Chechnya, vowing to crush a fierce rebellion and return the territory to the Kremlins control.

title: At Delhi 6, Cooking From Scratch
description: AT Delhi 6 in East Windsor, its tempting to begin a meal with dessert when the dessert in question is house-made paan ice cream, every bite a hint of exotica, every flavor an invitation to plan an extended trip to India.

title: No Itty Bitty Tea Shoppe Here
description: Its hard not to feel virtuous having tea at Terra at the Isabel Rose in Montclair, even if youve tipped your blood glucose level into the danger zone with an apricot-ginger scone or a slice of apple-blackberry-raspberry pie. The owner, Grace Chow Grund, says a great majority of ingredients in the baked goods, sandwiches, wraps and salads she sells at the tearoom are organic and from local farms. Teas and coffees are fair trade, and most are organic.

title: A Clash of Paper, String and Glass
description: Immigrants fight in Brooklyn for the most kites downed, and the kite fighter with the best handling skills wins.

title: Extra Point Is Almost Always Good; Is That a Good Thing?
description: The first four weeks of the N.F.L. season have been filled with surprises, but there has been one constant: the extra point.

title: Fix the Problem, and Not Just the Symptoms
description: This interview with  Joseph Jimenez, chief executive of Novartis, the pharmaceutical company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Inmates Release Brings Call for New Evidence Law
description: Not long after his mother was murdered, 3 1/2-year-old Eric Morton began to tell his grandmother what he had seen that terrible day.

title: Giddy Winnipeg Reclaims Lost Prairie Companion
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  After an absence of 15 years, the Winnipeg Jets return to life Sunday afternoon. Which is a good thing because the emotions sweeping the citizens of this prairie city at their beloved clubs rebirth have grown to a pitch so fevered that they are practically uncontainable.

title: Lawmakers End Boycott of Parliament in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Near the white tent where an ousted Afghan lawmaker lay moaning in bed, slowly starving herself in political protest, her onetime colleagues in Parliament congratulated themselves Saturday on their decision to return to work.

title: A Reality for Caddies: Pink Slips on Greens
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.  The caddie Joe LaCava was standing outside the scoring trailer waiting for postround instructions from his new boss, Tiger Woods. Scattered showers, which were in the forecast, and sprayed shots, which were not, had dampened LaCavas debut with Woods at the Frys.com Open. Cutting through the postround gloom, Woodss agent, Mark Steinberg, approached LaCava and wryly congratulated him on his first round.

title: A Long Time in the Making, a Brewers-Cardinals Rematch
description: Three years later, the memory was still vivid for Mark Attanasio, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers. Before a game at Miller Park last month, Attanasio described the scene on the field in 2008, when the Brewers clinched a playoff berth and he learned just how much the team means to his adopted city.

title: Grilled Chicken, That Temperamental Star
description: THE sauce will not behave.

Greenberg of Rockaway, Queens. Rabbi Heidi R. Hoover is to officiate at the Sands Beach Club in Atlantic Beach, N.Y.

Nancy Webb Stroud, an Episcopal priest, at the Manhattan home of their friends Patricia Galloway and Peter Webb.

Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Marys Church, where he is pastor, with Dennis M. Baker, a Jesuit scholastic with the Society of Jesus and a friend of the bridegroom, taking part.

Later that day the couple are to exchange vows at Stage 6 in a brief ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions. Daniel B. Bergman, a friend of the bridegroom, is to lead the ceremony.

description: This article was reported by  Michael D. Shear, Erik Eckholm and  Ashley Parker and written by Mr. Shear.

description: A look at tabletop food cinematography  the art of making the food in restaurant, beer and snack commercials appear drop-dead gorgeous.

title: Sony Is Said to Buy Film Rights to Jobs Biography
description: LOS ANGELES  Sony Pictures Entertainment, the studio that the produced high-speed and high-profile movies This Is It, with Michael Jackson, and The Social Network, about Mark Zuckerberg, could do it again with the Apple co-founder Steven P. Jobs. The studio late this week concluded a deal to buy film rights to the authorized biography Steve Jobs, from Walter Isaacson, according to a person who was briefed on the deal and spoke on the condition of anonymity because the studio had not authorized a public statement.

title: Kenneth H. Dahlberg, Link in the Watergate Chain, Dies at 94
description: Who the hell is Ken Dahlberg? President Richard M. Nixon asked on June 23, 1972, his voice captured on tape in the Oval Office. He would find out soon enough. Without Kenneth H. Dahlberg, Nixon might not have become ensnared in the Watergate scandal and been forced to resign.

title: Roger Williams, Pianist Known for Sentimental Songs, Dies at 87
description: Roger Williams, the pianist whose lush versions of familiar tunes like Autumn Leaves and Born Free became hit recordings in the 1950s and 60s and who continued to perform into his 80s, died on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: Ron Paul Wins Conference Straw Poll, to No Ones Surprise
description: Wildly enthusiastic Ron Paul supporters, including busloads of college students, have been a visible presence at the Values Voters Summit in Washington, so no one was surprised when Mr. Paul won the conferences annual straw poll of presidential preferences on Saturday.

title: Fixing the Post Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Coming Soon: The Drone Arms Race
description: Scott Shane is a national security correspondent for The New York Times.

title: California Begins Moving Prison Inmates
description: LOS ANGELES  Facing an unprecedented order from the Supreme Court to decrease its inmate population by 11,000 over the next three months and by 34,000 over the next two years, California prisons last week began to shift inmates to county jails and probation officers, starting what many believe will be a fundamental and far-reaching change in the nations largest corrections system.

title: One Countrys Big Gay Leap
description: LISBON, Portugal

title: Up From Ugliness
description: FROM the 1960s through the 1980s, the United States of America conducted a long experiment in ugliness. Our architects grew bored with beauty, our designers tired of elegance, our urban planners decided that function should trump form. We bulldozed row houses and threw up housing projects. We built public buildings out of raw concrete. We wore leisure suits and shoulder pads, buried heart-of-pine floors under shag carpeting, and paneled our automobiles with artificial wood.

title: Where Have You Gone, Joe DiMaggio?
description: THE melancholy over Steve Jobss passing is not just about the loss of the inventor of so many products we enjoy. It is also about the loss of someone who personified so many of the leadership traits we know are missing from our national politics. Those traits jump out of every Jobs obituary: He was someone who did not read the polls but changed the polls by giving people what he was certain they wanted and needed before they knew it; he was someone who was ready to pursue his vision in the face of long odds over multiple years; and, most of all, he was someone who earned the respect of his colleagues, not by going easy on them but by constantly pushing them out of their comfort zones and, in the process, inspiring ordinary people to do extraordinary things.

title: In This Rape Center, the Patient Was 3
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone

title: Protesters Against Wall Street
description: As the Occupy Wall Street protests spread from Lower Manhattan to Washington and other cities, the chattering classes keep complaining that the marchers lack a clear message and specific policy prescriptions. The message  and the solutions  should be obvious to anyone who has been paying attention since the economy went into a recession that continues to sock the middle class while the rich have recovered and prospered. The problem is that no one in Washington has been listening.

title: How Garbo Learned to Stand on Her Head
description: WASHINGTON

description: David Leonhardt is The New York Times Washington bureau chief.

description: Susan Gregory Thomas is the author of In Spite of Everything: A Memoir.

People would be compensated for their losses. Government oversight would be strengthened. A long-term plan would be put in place to restore a coastal environment that had suffered grievous environmental damage before the spill.

Thats truer than ever this year with the supercommittee looking for a $1.5 trillion reduction in the federal deficit. Why spend precious tax dollars overseas when the need at home is so great?

The civil war has ended there but the war on women and girls continues  and thats a pattern all over the world. This has been a heartbreaking issue to report on, and Im sure some readers will want to know how to help.

title: Daughter of Dirty War, Raised by Man Who Killed Her Parents
description: BUENOS AIRES  Victoria Montenegro recalls a childhood filled with chilling dinnertime discussions. Lt. Col. Hernn Tetzlaff, the head of the family, would recount military operations he had taken part in where subversives had been tortured or killed. The discussions often ended with his slamming his gun on the table, she said.

title: A Masters Skill, or Just Luck?
description: IN sports, the lessons of long-term performance seem obvious. Edwin Moses, the hurdler, wins 122 races over nearly a decade. Roger Federer, the tennis player, reaches the semifinals in 23 consecutive Grand Slam tournaments. Jeannie Longo, the cyclist, makes seven French Olympic teams. Implied in their feats is the message that doing something so challenging for so long proves enduring excellence.

description: IM always looking for new ways to improve my familys financial situation, which is slightly less promising than the economy of Greece.

title: High Corporate Profits May Reduce Risk in High-Yield Bonds

title: Secret U.S. Memo Made Legal Case to Kill a Citizen

title: Between Brewers and Cardinals, Sparks Fly, Along With Chaw
