description: DALLAS  Oklahoma cornerback Jamell Fleming broke late toward the pass and looked as if he was giving up an easy catch to Texas wide receiver Mike Davis.

title: U.S. Gets Win, but Its Finishing Still Needs Work
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Strictly speaking, the United States national team didnt need to win Saturday nights game against Honduras. The match, played in blustery conditions at rain-soaked Sun Life Stadium, had no bearing on 2012 Olympics qualification, 2014 World Cup qualification or any other meaningful success barometer.

title: A Genius in Silver and Black
description: Al Daviss rsum at the Pro Football Hall of Fame tells all you need to know about what he accomplished in more than half a century.

title: Corrections: October 9
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Davis Lived Up to the Label of Maverick Till His Death
description: Amy Trask glanced out her office window Saturday morning and glimpsed some fans  one of them with a dog in an Oakland Raiders jersey  who had come to the teams training center to pay their respects to Al Davis, the iconoclastic, iconic, iron-fisted owner of the team that was defined by him, and in turn reflected him. The youngest of those fans who made the pilgrimage probably thought of Davis as a throwback, perhaps a bit of an eccentric with his white or black Raiders track suits, his Brylcreemed hair, a man whose recent misjudgments of players and coaches had consigned the team to losing, occasionally cartoonish seasons.

title: Fans Raise a Glass to Al Davis
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In the back of Rickys restaurant in San Leandro, the unofficial headquarters of Raider Nation, a booth was empty Saturday afternoon except for the memories on the tabletop: a Super Bowl XV program; a Raiders program from a Sept. 27, 1964 home game against the Kansas City Chiefs with Al Davis on the cover, stalking the sideline; the California license plate JST WN BBY; a Raider beer mug, a Raider helmet telephone and two pennants, one from the 1977 Super Bowl at the Rose Bowl.

title: Man With Knife Is Shot by Police at Schenectady Newspaper Office
description: A man who walked into the office of a newspaper in Schenectady, N.Y., was shot and wounded by police officers on Saturday afternoon after he charged at one with a knife, according to law enforcement officials in the city, which is about 15 miles from Albany.

title: Phillies Feel the Sting of the Rich and Vanquished
description: Philadelphia

title: Star Turn by Pitt Running Back Cant Make Up for Turnovers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Pittsburghs offensive game plan all season has been understandably simple: feed running back Ray Graham the ball, as often as possible.

title: College Football Replay: Week 6
description: It was a day for offense, with Oklahoma, Oklahoma State, L.S.U. and South Carolina all winning with creative ease.

title: Michael Jackson, Celebrated and Sold
description: CARDIFF, Wales  At a tribute concert here on Saturday evening, Michael Jacksons music thumped and cracked as usual, his fans screamed on cue, and conflict and controversy simmered beneath the surface as they have since Mr. Jackson found fame as a child.

title: Interrupting Lockout for a Respite on the Court
description: MIAMI  The N.B.A.s player propaganda machine took a holiday Saturday.

title: Philadelphia and Jagr Line Top Devils, 3-0
description: NEWARK  When James van Riemsdyk, an emerging young forward with the Philadelphia Flyers, dreamed about playing in the N.H.L. as a youngster in Middletown, N.J., he never envisioned playing on the same team as Jaromir Jagr.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Days Best in College Football
description: COLTON CHAPPLE The Harvard quarterback threw for 414 yards and 4 touchdowns as the Crimson won, 41-31, at Cornell (2-2, 0-2 Ivy League). Chapple led three scoring drives in the second half, completing touchdown passes of 42, 27 and 26 yards to put the game out of reach. It was the first 400-yard passing game since 2003 for Harvard (3-1, 2-0).

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: A look at some of the long-form journalism we have been reading this week.

title: Cardinals Take On the Beast
description: MILWAUKEE  If you play in the National League Central Division for anybody except the St. Louis Cardinals, you probably cant stand the Cardinals and their manager, Tony La Russa. Lance Berkman felt that way for 12 seasons with the Houston Astros, banging heads with the Cardinals for division titles and playoff berths.

title: Texas Takes Game 1 After Two Rain Delays
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  In a state so parched by drought that the governor, Rick Perry, issued a proclamation declaring three days of prayer for rain in April, enter the rainmaker, Justin Verlander.

title: Inside the Mexican Suitcase
description: A slide show of recently discovered photographs taken by Robert Capa, Gerda Taro, David Seymour and Fred Stein during the Spanish Civil War.

title: Seahawks at Giants: Matchup to Watch
description: Seahawks (1-3) at Giants (3-1), 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Street Art Presented Live at Berlin Fair
description: Billed as the worlds only expo dedicated to urban art, Stroke.Artfair runs from Oct. 14 to 16 at Berlins Postbahnhof (Strasse der Pariser Komunne 8; 49-30-698-1280; www.postbahnhof.de).

title: Back to the Land in Japan
description: Japans aging farmers are in need of hearty workers. Young people from cities, stuck in low-wage jobs, are increasingly interested. And the government is helping put them together.

title: Vettel Wins Title, but Button Wins Race
description: SUZUKA, Japan  In winning the drivers title at the Japanese Grand Prix on Sunday with four races left, Sebastian Vettel has extinguished any doubts about just how good a driver he is. With nine victories and 12 pole positions this season, he is the youngest double world champion ever.

title: Vettel Wins Title, but Button Wins Race
description: SUZUKA, Japan  In winning the drivers title at the Japanese Grand Prix on Sunday with four races left, Sebastian Vettel has extinguished any doubts about just how good a driver he is. With nine victories and 12 pole positions this season, he is the youngest double world champion ever.

title: Civilized Riding
description: The Dutch bicycle is increasingly imported to the United States and is starting to be seen on the streets of New York. David Colman explains why this vehicle is so fashion friendly.

title: Dress Codes: The Dutch Bicycle
description: Dutch bicycles' unique design offers men the option to pedal to work in a suit.

title: Jets at Patriots: Matchup to Watch
description: Jets (2-2) at Patriots (3-1), 4:15 p.m. Eastern, CBSMATCHUP TO WATCH: Patriots tight ends vs. Jets defense

title: Dividing to Conquer a Newspaper Empire in Germany
description: PARIS  A newspaper publisher moves haltingly into the digital era. The families that control the company do not always see eye to eye, and they worry about what will happen when a new generation, one with less ink on its hands, takes over. A powerful press baron senses opportunity and makes an unsolicited takeover bid.

title: Germany and France Say Deal Near to Recapitalize Banks
description: Acknowledging that Europes banks still need billions of euros to cushion against a possible default by Greece, the leaders of Germany and France announced on Sunday that they would have a package of reforms by the time leaders of the Group of 20 nations meet in early November.

title: Defending Rugby Champion Exits World Cup
description: WELLINGTON  For Australia and France, their victories in the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals this weekend meant some redemption after their struggles early on in the tournament. For a young Wales team, it meant getting respect as it reached the semifinals for the first time since 1987, while New Zealand took another step in its quest to win the Cup for the first time in 24 years.

title: Artists Occupy Wall Street for a 24-Hour Show
description: For weeks, a growing collection of protesters have tried to get their grievances heard on Wall Street  even if the police have prevented them from establishing a physical presence on the fabled street.

title: Ex-President of China, Said to Be Ill, Appears in Beijing
description: BEIJING  Jiang Zemin, the former Chinese president who was said to have fallen gravely ill in July, appeared at a ceremony in Beijing on Sunday, fanning speculation about his health and the role he might play in power struggles accompanying the long-planned shift in the top leadership next year.

title: Greinke Brings Arm, Glove to N.L.C.S.
description: Zack Greinke has had to deal with his fair share of criticism in his career, from his battles with anxiety to his controversial (to some) Cy Young award. But Ryan Braun may have taken things too far when discussing his teams pitching star earlier this week.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (1) vs. Honduras (0)
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Jurgen Klinsmann notched his first win as United States coach, the German-born midfielder Danny Williams got his first start for the Americans and Clint Dempsey scored his fourth U.S. goal  a game winner  of 2011.

title: 2,000 Stage Sit In on a London Bridge to Protest Health Care Cuts
description: More than 2,000 people protesting potential cuts to the national health care system staged a sit-in on Westminster Bridge in London on Sunday afternoon, blocking traffic on one of the citys busiest bridges, The Guardian reports.

title: Fighters Enter City Once Home to Qaddafi
description: SURT, Libya  Former rebel fighters battled their way into the heart of this coastal city on Sunday, seizing a sumptuous conference center used by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to entertain heads of state, but more recently by his loyalists as a base for their fierce defense of this city, his birthplace.

title: Key Negotiators Make Final Effort to Save Games
description: On the night before the N.B.A. was to begin canceling games, league and union officials gathered one more time Sunday night, but once again parted without an agreement, or any overt signs of progress.

title: Shobukhova and Mosop Win Chicago Marathon
description: CHICAGO  Striding across the finish line with a burst of speed, Liliya Shobukhova of Russia secured her third straight victory at the Chicago Marathon, becoming the first runner, man or woman, to accomplish that feat.

title: Excerpt: 'Man and Boy' on Broadway
description: Frank Langella, left, and Adam Driver in a scene from the revival of Terence Rattigans 1963 play Man and Boy. (Video courtesy of the Roundabout Theater.)

title: Real Steel Is No. 1 at the Weekend Box Office
description: Boxing robots were No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, as Real Steel (DreamWorks Studios/Disney) sold an estimated $27.3 million in tickets. That total was solid, but the picture, which stars Hugh Jackman as a reluctant father, will need to continue drawing large audiences to justify its hefty production budget of $110 million and tens of millions more in marketing support. Many critics disliked Real Steel, but audiences, especially younger moviegoers, gave it strong marks in exit polls.

title: Matisse Sculptures to Be Auctioned
description: Since January experts at Sothebys have been trying to privately sell a suite of four bronze sculptures of a womans back that Matisse created over a period of 23 years beginning in 1908. The works belong to the Burnett Foundation in Forth Worth, and at the time the sale was announced, neither Sothebys nor the foundation would say what the asking price was, although dealers approached by the auction house reported that they were hoping for around $200 million for all four.

title: No Fun? N.C.A.A. Outdoes the N.F.L.
description: And you thought the N.F.L. was the No Fun League.

title: Channel Surfing: 6 Days to Air: The Making of South Park
description: There are almost as many laughs in 6 Days to Air: The Making of South Park as there are in an actual episode of South Park.

title: Support From a Love Sprite and Some Fractured Friends
description: Romantic and sexual trauma pervade Cheerful Insanity: Chao and Katzberg in Repertory, two plays of contrasting sensibilities at the Here Arts Center. Each barely an hour and running on different dates, they are both confessional in nature and intriguing.

title: Paul McCartney Marries Again
description: Beatles fans now have two reasons to toast to their favorite band each Oct. 9: On what would have been John Lennons 71st birthday, Sir Paul McCartney married Nancy Shevell in a small civil ceremony on Sunday at Marylebone Town Hall in London, The Associated Press reported.

title: IS-LMentary
description: A number of readers, both at this blog and other places, have been asking for an explanation of what IS-LM is all about. Fair enough  this blogosphere conversation has been an exchange among insiders, and probably a bit baffling to normal human beings (which is why I have been labeling my posts wonkish).

title: Week 5 Live: Jets-Patriots Win Probability
description: As the Fifth Down has done several times already this season, we will be using a Web feature from Advanced NFL Stats that charts win probability live during todays Jets-Patriots game.

title: Was Failure Inevitable?
description: Ezra Klein has a generally reasonable analysis of the Obama administrations failure to respond with sufficient force to the economic crisis. Broadly speaking, hes saying that the eurovenn applied: an economically adequate response lay beyond the bounds of the politically feasible.

title: In Rare Rally, Somalis Aim at Militants
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Thousands of residents of this bullet-scarred city packed into a stadium on Sunday to denounce the Shabab Islamist group for the suicide bombing last week that killed scores of people, many of them students.

title: Syria Demands That Nations Reject Opposition Council and Protect Its Embassies
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syria warned countries on Sunday not to recognize a new opposition group, the Syrian National Council, and threatened to take strict measures against any that did.

title: A.L.C.S. Game 2 Postponed
description: After two rain delays interrupted Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Saturday night, Major League Baseball did not take any chances on Sunday. With more rain expected Sunday night, Game 2 of the series between the Texas Rangers and the Detroit Tigers was postponed Sunday afternoon, about seven hours before the scheduled first pitch. It was rescheduled for Monday afternoon at 4:19 Eastern. Tigers Manager Jim Leyland also announced that right fielder Magglio Ordonez injured his right ankle in Game 1 and is out for the rest of the postseason. More details are available here.

title: A Voice, Still Vibrant, Reflects on Mortality
description: HOUSTON  Christopher Hitchens, probably the countrys most famous unbeliever, received the Freethinker of the Year Award at the annual convention of the Atheist Alliance of America here on Saturday. Mr. Hitchens was flattered by the honor, he said a few days beforehand, but also a little abashed. I think being an atheist is something you are, not something you do, he explained, adding: Im not sure we need to be honored. We dont need positive reinforcement. On the other hand, we do need to stick up for ourselves, especially in a place like Texas, where they have laws, I think, that if you dont believe in Jesus Christ you cant run for sheriff.

title: Polands Centrist Leader Claims a Second Term
description: WARSAW  In the race to govern Poland, Prime Minister Donald Tusk appeared to have a strong lead on Sunday over his conservative rival and predecessor, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, while a party that supports gay rights, abortion and some drug legalization seemed set to win representation in Parliament for the first time.

title: Preparation by Pitcher Is Fiction; Postponement of Game 2 of the A.L.C.S. Is Real
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Sundays rainout of Game 2 of the American League Championship Series gave Texas Rangers starter Derek Holland another opportunity to watch a brief segment of the most important movie in his life, a movie he has never watched to its conclusion.

title: Church Protests in Cairo Turn Deadly
description: CAIRO  A demonstration by Christians angry about a recent attack on a church touched off a night of violent protests here against the military council now ruling Egypt, leaving 24 people dead and more than 200 wounded in the worst spasm of violence since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak in February.

title: Gun Control and Gun Rights Stay Fighting Words
description: In Gunfight, his provocative, highly uneven new book about the fight over gun control, the constitutional law professor Adam Winkler writes that gun rights and gun control are not only compatible; they have lived together since the birth of America. He argues that despite the controversy over the meaning of the Second Amendment, Americans have always had the right to keep and bear arms as a matter of state constitutional law. Today, nearly every state has such a provision in its own constitution, clearly protecting an individual right unattached to militia service.

title: Giants Get Signals Crossed and Win Streak Snapped
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Antrel Rolle thought he was covering the outside receiver. So did Aaron Ross. Osi Umenyiora and Mathias Kiwanuka swore they heard a whistle. Others were less certain.

title: This Work Is About the Movers and Shakers
description: Self-indulgence is the key to all art, Ishmael Houston-Jones remarked at New York Live Arts on Wednesday. He was referring, in particular, to himself and his fellow dancers, who he insisted were all narcissistic egotists. Considering the money they make, he asked, Why else would you do it?

title: One Disease, Many Faces and Many Personal Paths
description: Take some celebrity directors, the Lifetime network and  Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and what do you get? A teary, perfectly tolerable collection of interlocking stories featuring lots of recognizable actors and two particularly well-etched segments.

title: Dont Let the Bedbugs Bite, and Kiss Blankie Goodbye
description: Presumably some parents of young children, not grasping the concept of parody, have actually been reading Adam Mansbachs filthy best seller, Go the ____ to Sleep, to their progeny at bedtime. Now comes the anti-Mansbach: Pajanimals, a puppet television show in an evening time slot that is intended to help the little buggers nod off.

title: After New Pledge to Leave, Signs of Yemeni Presidents Resolve to Linger
description: CAIRO  Amid all the chaos and conflict that have engulfed Yemen, one fact seems immutable: President Ali Abdullah Saleh will not voluntarily leave office any time soon.

title: Giants Still Own Citys Hearts, but Jets Are Closing in Fast
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Rap in and of Brooklyn, With the Rumble of the Subway Trains
description: When an orchestra wants to play outside it usually ends up in a park, a pastoral setting for picnicking and music that is familiar and not too demanding: Bernsteins West Side Story Suite, say, or Mozarts Jupiter Symphony. The audience is generally as white as the wine.

title: Harvey Weinstein Is Under the Microscope Again
description: Taking its cue from a subject whos always been able to sell sizzle sans steak, Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project is a bit of bait and switch. While its title implies a tawdry tell-all, this documentary actually delivers a virtual tribute to Mr. Weinstein, who co-founded Miramax Films, helped revolutionize American independent cinema and cultivated a reputation as a dyspeptic bull in the china shop of art-house sensibilities. Mr. Weinstein may not have authorized the director and producer Barry Avrichs rather pedestrian film. But he wont be throwing any telephones.

title: A Composers Repertory in Broad Brush Strokes
description: The philosophy behind the Composer Portraits series at the Miller Theater of Columbia University runs contrary to the kind of program you will find on almost every other concert stage in town, any day of the week. Instead of mixing works by different composers to form juxtapositions that illuminate each (or not), the Miller series generally provides a handful of pieces by a single composer, providing in its best instances a useful and nuanced overview of one artists development.

title: Bad Day? Some Om Will Cure It
description: There is anger management, but does anyone ever do anything about excessive joy?

title: Monday: Dee-lish!
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This one went down very smoothly. A nice Monday grid that fell in great big chunks, and as soon as I sussed out the CC part of the theme, my brain said, Oh, I really hope there are 10 of these! Ten cc would be such a great theme!

title: Film Fest Gleams Mysterious This Year
description: In its 49th incarnation, well into respectable middle age, the New York Film Festival has experienced a growth spurt and a burst of youthful energy. The Film Society of Lincoln Center, which hosts the festival, expanded its footprint last summer, with the opening of the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center, a street-level miniplex across West 65th Street from the lofty terrace of the Walter Reade Theater. The festivals offerings have expanded accordingly, with more classic films and retrospectives, a new documentary program and a larger selection of Views From the Avant-Garde, in addition to the 27 features in the main slate.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the trade deficit for August and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and retail sales for September, import prices for September, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for October and business inventories for August (Friday).

title: Sinopec to Buy Daylight Energy for $2.1 Billion
description: Sinopec of China agreed on Sunday to buy Daylight Energy, a Canadian oil and natural gas producer, for about $2.1 billion in cash, as Chinese companies increasingly flock to Canadas oil-rich resources.

title: A Tipoff From the Bidding Results in a Different Lead
description: When you have a 4-4 fit in a no-trump contract, you will get at most four tricks from the suit. But if that is your trump suit, you will usually get an extra trick by ruffing a loser in one hand or the other. This is why players like 4-4 trump fits. However, methods like Stayman that search for a 4-4 fit suffer from one disadvantage: if a 4-4 fit is not found, the defenders have been given free information about declarers hand.

title: More TV Shows Canceled
description: Three weeks into the new television season, prime-time schedule changes are beginning to pile up, as four new shows effectively have been canceled. CBS confirmed Saturday that it had halted production on the sitcom How to Be a Gentleman, with David Hornsby and Kevin Dillon. That came a day after the network decided to move the sixth season of Rules of Engagement into its Thursday time slot. Gentleman joins the NBC sitcom Free Agents and the CW reality show H8R, both of which were pulled from their slots on Thursday. Earlier in the week NBC made The Playboy Club the first victim of the fall season; the new drama Prime Suspect will run in its 10 p.m. Monday time slot until Oct. 31, when the newsmagazine Rock Center With Brian Williams starts.

title: Immigrant Detainees
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Romanticism
description: One line Ive been seeing in various places, including comments here, is the claim that the real way to deal with Wall Street is laissez-faire economics: no more bailouts! On this view, policy makers should raise their right hand in the air, place their left hand on a copy of Atlas Shrugged, and swear in the name of A is A that they will never again step in to rescue failing banks. And all will be well with the world.

title: Two Early Films From John Akomfrah
description: Two early films from the British-Ghanian documentarian John Akomfrah are on view at the Maysles Cinema in Harlem, one eyeing black history, the other the future. Both are thought-provoking, and they coincide with the premiere of this directors latest work, The Nine Muses, at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: The Nuremberg Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tribute to Michael Jackson
description: A concert in Wales honored the singer.

title: Free Texts Pose Threat to Carriers
description: At a time when e-mail and many other forms of electronic communication are essentially free, wireless carriers are still charging as much as 20 cents to send a text message to a phone, and another 20 cents to receive it.

title: One Outlaws Campaign for Urban Decorum
description: Jason Shelowitz has made it his mission to educate New Yorkers on proper urban decorum. All he had to do was break the law. Seventy times.

title: Freud as Philosopher
description: Sigmund Freud, that seer of the psyche, taught that you could be angry and not know it. You can also be a philosopher and not know it. And Freud was just that, an unconscious philosopher of the unconscious  one who had nary a positive word to say about philosophy. Just listen to him grouse in 1933:

title: Drawbridge in Connecticut Becomes Stuck, Disrupting Metro-North and Amtrak
description: The failure of a 100-year-old drawbridge over the Norwalk River in Norwalk, Conn., disrupted service on Sunday afternoon for hundreds of rail travelers who were forced take shuttle buses when more than six trains could not cross the river.

title: Christians Clash with Police in Cairo
description: At least 24 people were killed Sunday when a protest by Egyptian Christians over the burning of a church escalated into rioting against military rule.

title: Free Trips Raise Issues for Officials in Education
description: Since 2008, the Pearson Foundation, the nonprofit arm of one of the nations largest educational publishers, has financed free international trips  some have called them junkets  for education commissioners whose states do business with the company. When the state commissioners are asked about these trips  to Rio de Janeiro; London; Singapore; and Helsinki, Finland  they emphasize the time they spend with educators from around the world to get ideas for improving American public schools.

title: Food Trucks, Celebrities and a Madison Avenue Walk of Fame
description: HERE is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of Advertising Week 2011, which took place in New York last Monday through Friday.

title: For Archie Comics, a Return to Superheroes
description: The comic-reading public may need to revise its vision of Archie Andrews, the perpetual teenager from Riverdale. This year alone Archie Comics has announced a continuing series for Kevin Keller, the towns openly gay resident, digital versions of its regular series on the same day they are released in comic stores, and Spanish translations of its material for download.

title: Giants Run Aground vs. Seattle
description: A few talking points after the Seahawks 36-25 victory over the Giants on Sunday:

title: Israeli Cabinet Backs Outline for Social Change
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government on Sunday approved recommendations for new housing, education and tax measures to address the demands of the protests that swept the country during the summer.

title: Attendance List
description: These are the state education commissioners who attended international conferences on education financed by the Pearson Foundation, the nonprofit arm of the Pearson company, one of the nations largest educational publishers. The list was provided by the Council of Chief State School Officers, a nonprofit group that represents the officials.

title: Tavis Smiley on Poverty Tour
description: Tavis Smiley has described it as a call to conscience.

title: In Washington, Everyone Seems Mad at Teammates
description: Every poll shows it: Americans are hopping mad at Washington.

title: Rise in Health Premiums
description: To the Editor:

title: Nobel Winner Doesnt Want to Talk About It on the Campaign Trail
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  The Nobel Peace Prize is a high-voltage endorsement for a president seeking a second term to receive four days before the election. But analysts questioned whether it would have much impact in Liberia, a sweltering tropical nation where nearly half the population cannot read.

title: Jets Stagger Against Patriots, Losing 3rd Straight
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The door to the visiting interview room at Gillette Stadium swung open Sunday evening, and in walked Mark Sanchez. His arms were folded, his lips pursed and his eye black fresh and unsmeared. He just stood there, in full uniform save for his helmet, for about five minutes, leaning against a door as Rex Ryan, coach of the free-falling Jets, detailed his teams struggles for a third consecutive Sunday.

title: Revamping Alcohol Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes a weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Standing Out in a Hyperachieving Crowd
description: To the Editor:

title: Bats Replace Brickbats as Brewers Rally
description: MILWAUKEE  The National League Championship Series had been portrayed as a clash of philosophies, a battle between new-school ostentation and old-school politesse.

title: Banks Brace for Fallout on Earnings
description: The protesters who have gathered for weeks near Wall Street and the highly paid investors and analysts in the buildings that surround them dont agree on much.

title: Staving Off Change to the Grit of the Bowery
description: It is the original boulevard of broken dreams, a street where a flophouse or two still lingers from its days as Skid Row, and where every day hungry men jostle through the doors of a remaining Christian mission for a hot meal.

title: Declining Household Income
description: Real household income has fallen by about 10 percent since the start of the last recession

title: Recession Officially Over, U.S. Incomes Kept Falling
description: WASHINGTON  In a grim sign of the enduring nature of the economic slump, household income declined more in the two years after the recession ended than it did during the recession itself, new research has found.

title: Volcker Rule Could Leave Some Murky Wiggle Room
description: It was a tall order, but Americas banking regulators have taken a good stab at devising a framework for the Volcker Rule.

title: At Clairvoyants Funeral, Sharing Tales of Treasure Found and Crimes Solved
description: Maybe he really did see it coming. Just indulge the possibility, friends and family plead. Maybe he knew this was how his story would end, with a funeral inside a nondescript chapel in the Bronx, evolving quickly from a solemn remembrance to a parade of eager testimonials from former clients, who were not accustomed to being in the company of believers.

title: Biggest U.S. Banks Struggling
description: Revenue and income at the nations biggest banks have fallen recently.

title: No More Adventures in Wonderland
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Labor Talks in Detroit Go Social
description: DETROIT  For generations, labor negotiations here have been the stuff of closed doors and tight lips. Just four years ago, when the United Auto Workers settled on contracts with the Big Three, the rank-and-file learned the details by crowding into union halls for meetings that were often chaotic and confusing. Many workers complained that they had not seen the fine print until the deals had been ratified.

title: At India-Bangladesh Border, Living in Both, and Neither
description: MADHYA MASALDANGA, India  Mohammed Idris Alis watery rice paddies shimmer in the monsoon breeze just like his neighbors. His tepee-shaped stacks of jute, ready to be soaked, stripped and then turned into rope, stand as tall as the ones across the rutted footpath.

title: Conference Instability Is Filtering Down to the Next Level
description: The one remaining domino that can still reset the collegiate conference landscape is the University of Missouri, which is in the process of deciding whether to stay in the Big 12 or defect to the Southeastern Conference. Officials from the Big 12, the SEC and the Big East are all anxiously awaiting the Tigers decision, as it will largely dictate the futures of their leagues.

title: Refugee Farm Projects
description: More than two dozen farming programs in the nation work with refugees.

title: Is the Tea Party Over?
description: Austin, Tex.

title: A Fluid Protest Movement Finds a Forum to Match
description: A STRENGTH of the Occupy Wall Street protest movement has been its flexible organization and nondoctrinaire agenda: The one thing we all have in common is that we are the 99 percent that will no longer tolerate the greed and corruption of the 1 percent.

title: Brewers and Fans Are Savoring the Moment
description: Milwaukee

title: Middle School Girls Unlock a Room of Their Own, in Miniature
description: Swing open the door, and behold a tableau that perfectly captures the tween aesthetic. The polka-dot chandelier. The zebra-print wallpaper. The lime green shag rug that pulls the look together  without being too matchy-matchy, as a pre-tween might have it.

title: When the Uprooted Put Down Roots
description: SAN DIEGO  At the Saturday farmers market in City Heights, a major portal for refugees, Khadija Musame, a Somali, arranges her freshly picked pumpkin leaves and lablab beans amid a United Nations of produce, including water spinach grown by a Cambodian refugee and amaranth, a grain harvested by Sarah Salie, who fled rebels in Liberia. Eaten with a touch of lemon by Africans, and coveted by Southeast Asians for soups, this crop is always a sell-out.

title: Panic of the Plutocrats
description: It remains to be seen whether the Occupy Wall Street protests will change Americas direction. Yet the protests have already elicited a remarkably hysterical reaction from Wall Street, the super-rich in general, and politicians and pundits who reliably serve the interests of the wealthiest hundredth of a percent.

title: Patriots Defense Finds a Cure: Its the Jets Wobbly Offense
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

title: A Protests Ink-Stained Fingers
description: At the Occupy Wall Street demonstration in Zuccotti Park, youll find all of the essentials of a state-of-the-art protest: drum circles, cheeky and plaintive handwritten signs, and, next to a thrumming generator, a hub of social media activity, including live streaming of the proceedings.

title: A Farmers Market With the Tastes of Home
description: At the Saturday farmers market in City Heights, a major portal for refugees, Khadija Musame, a Somali, arranges her freshly picked pumpkin leaves and lablab beans amid a United Nations of produce, including water spinach grown by a Cambodian refugee and amaranth, a grain harvested by Sarah Salie, who fled rebels in Liberia.

title: New Law Creates a Demand for Patent Specialists
description: Patent lawyers are in such demand that their specialty may account for more than 15 percent of law firm job openings while representing just 3 percent of lawyers in the United States.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: The Myth of Voter Fraud
description: It has been a record year for new legislation designed to make it harder for Democrats to vote  19 laws and two executive actions in 14 states dominated by Republicans, according to a new study by the Brennan Center for Justice. As a result, more than five million eligible voters will have a harder time participating in the 2012 election.

title: Group Urges More Money to Aid Poor in School
description: New York State already outspends the rest of the nation on education, and a group of education experts at Teachers College at Columbia University is calling for it to spend even more.

title: Victory Lap for Fox and Hannity
description: ATLANTA  When the Fox News host Sean Hannity arrived at Centennial Olympic Park here on Thursday night, some of the hundreds of fans who had been waiting for him since sunset rushed to the rope line for handshakes and autographs. He obliged, then bounded onto a temporary stage two blocks from the CNN Center and asked them mischievously, Do you think its any coincidence that the CNN logo is in the background?

title: A Deal for the Deals
description: Trade is good for the economy and for employment. It opens new markets for businesses and allows access to cheaper, often better products from abroad. But it also has a dark side for workers displaced by foreign competition.

title: Julio Mario Santo Domingo, Colombian Billionaire, Dies at 87
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Julio Mario Santo Domingo, the Colombian magnate whose $8.5 billion fortune made him one of Latin Americas richest and most influential men, died on Friday in New York. He was 87.

title: No Right to Bear Assault Weapons
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia last week persuasively  ruled that the Constitution allows the District to ban possession of assault weapons and high-capacity magazines of bullets and to require citizens to meet sensible standards for registering guns.

title: Toby Keiths American Dream
description: Toby Keith is having a good year. His new song, Made in America, just hit No. 1 on the country charts. Its about his aging father, who flies the American flag on his farm, wears a Semper Fi tattoo and worries about global trade.

title: Navigating the City Without Sight, but With a Cane and a Teacher
description: A Queens woman with myopic degeneration learns to navigate the busy streets of New York with the help of a certified orientation mobility specialist.

title: A Community Erased by Slum Clearance Is Reunited
description: The reunion at the Frederick Douglass Center in Manhattan on Saturday had all the trappings of a block party. About 75 people turned out, greeting one another with smiles, hugs and questions about neighbors and family. They ate chicken, macaroni and cheese and cake while a man blew soulful melodies on an alto saxophone.

title: Doris Belack, Judge on TVs Law & Order, Dies at 85
description: Doris Belack, a veteran stage, television and screen actress best known for her roles as a no-nonsense judge on Law & Order and as the peeved soap opera producer in Tootsie, died on Tuesday in New York. She was 85.

title: Els Sees a Lot of Life Left in His Game
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.  All the attention was on Tiger Woods at the Frys.com Open, which suited Ernie Els fine. Like Woods, Els came to CordeValle Golf Club looking for his lost game, and he preferred not to be accompanied by an unwieldy search party of fans and pundits.

title: TV and Film, From Cond Nast
description: LOS ANGELES  Cond Nast is coming to Hollywood.

title: The Art of Wreaking Havoc With Other Peoples Money
description: When Frank Langella plays good, hes fine; but when hes bad, hes a wonder. Having ditched the halo he wore as the sainted Sir Thomas More in A Man for All Seasons in 2008, Mr. Langella  the only actor to star on Broadway as both Dracula and Richard Nixon  has stepped back into the dark side in style. And this time hes a villain that New York audiences should really love to hate: a soulless financier who wreaks havoc with other peoples money.

title: A Good Samaritan Fumbles With an Umbrella
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Freud on the Beach: Wave Theory
description: In Being and Nothingness, Jean-Paul Sartre recommends skiing as a model of human behavior. But the trouble with skiing, says Sartre (with a slightly paranoid swerve) is that you leave tracks behind you. The ideal form of sliding, he argues, would therefore be one that leaves no trace: that is, sliding over water He might have been thinking of water-skiing, of course, but I have always liked to suppose it was surfing he had in mind.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Columbus Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Officer Saved at Gunpoint by His Own Wedged Finger
description: At the tactical meeting that began Friday nights tour, the members of the plainclothes anticrime unit in Brooklyns 81st Precinct were told pay a little more attention to livery cabs. Several drivers had been robbed at gunpoint.

title: Battle for Libya | October 9, 2011
description: Forces of the Libyan transitional government said on Sunday that they had captured a couple of significant buildings in their push to the center of Surt, the hometown of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Talking Points for Jets
description: A few talking points after the Jets 30-21 loss against New England.

title: Jets Replay: Week 5
description: A look back at the Jets 30-21 loss to the New England Patriots.

title: Chinas Reluctant Consumers
description: Personal income and spending in China have declined in recent years.

title: As Its Economy Sprints Ahead, Chinas People Are Left Behind
description: JILIN CITY, China  Wang Jianping and his wife, Shue, are a relatively affluent Chinese couple, with an annual household income of $16,000  more than double the national average for urban families.

title: After Rocky Start, More Study, and Sleep, for Perry
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas struggled through his first three debates, so his aides have staged practice sessions, complete with a stand-in for Mitt Romney. He has stirred outrage among conservatives on immigration, so he is defending his stance on the campaign trail as good economics.

title: Raiders Fans Mourn an Owner Loved and Otherwise
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In the hours after Al Daviss death was announced Saturday, a makeshift memorial sprouted at the Oakland Raiders practice facility: a collage of flowers and Raiders shirts, stuffed animals and homemade cards and posters with personal messages. One note, written on lined yellow paper, seemed to encompass the complicated relationship that Raiders fans had with Davis, their teams maverick owner:

title: Navigating the City Without Sight, but With a Cane and a Teacher
description: The streets were quiet and dark except for the glare of an occasional streetlamp casting long shadows on the cracked pavement.

title: Dissenting Often, States Chief Judge Establishes a Staunchly Liberal Record
description: After he was appointed to head the Court of Appeals in 2009, New Yorks chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, drew attention by forging alliances to get more liberal rulings on the court, which has a 4-to-3 conservative majority. But a new analysis shows another side of his approach: Judge Lippman writes dissents from his own court far more than his predecessors did from their courts.

title: Art Is Fleeting, at Least When Its in the Sky
description: On a warm, clear Sunday afternoon, many New Yorkers looked up and saw not a cloud in the sky  except for the ones that were talking to them.

title: The Party Spirit on Trial
description: Richard C. Vaughan, an attorney in Lexington, Mo., was overjoyed with Abraham Lincolns 1860 election. Not because the Republican Lincoln won; indeed, he had supported John Bell, the presidential candidate from the Constitutional Union Party. Rather, his joy came from the Democrats resounding defeat. The prospect of the final overthrow of the Democracy in Missouri as well as everywhere else, he wrote to a friend, is to me a source of infinite and irrepressible pleasure in which I know you participate fully.

title: Vince Gilligan of Breaking Bad Talks About Ending the Season, and the Series
description: Warning: this post contains spoilers, starting with the next sentence.

title: Deadly Protests in Cairo
description: David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, where a demonstration led to the worst violence in the country since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak in February.

title: Giants Replay: Week 5
description: A photo replay of the Giants 36-25 loss to the Seattle Seahawks.

title: Scientists Analysis Disputes F.B.I. Closing of Anthrax Case
description: A decade after wisps of anthrax sent through the mail killed 5 people, sickened 17 others and terrorized the nation, biologists and chemists still disagree on whether federal investigators got the right man and whether the F.B.I.s long inquiry brushed aside important clues.

title: For Perry, Texas Roots Include Racial Backdrop
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who often waxes nostalgic about his small-town roots, grew up in an almost all-white rural area where many referred to slingshots as niggershooters. One elderly black resident recalls being introduced by her boss at a party decades back as my maid, Nigger Mae Lou, while just four years ago, a black high school student found a noose in his locker.

title: Corrections: October 10
description: NATIONAL

title: Rodriguez, Happy to Be on Contender, Says He Has No Hard Feelings
description: MILWAUKEE  After pitching a scoreless eighth inning for the Brewers in their 9-6 win over the St. Louis Cardinals on Sunday night, Francisco Rodriguez was asked to contemplate the past year of his career, which has had more twists and gyrations than his pitching motion.

title: Lottery Numbers
NYT Front Page for 10/10/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 10/10/2011

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
description: The government has agreed to make public the audio recordings of the proceedings of the Joint Drafting Committee constituted to frame the Lokpal Bill, in response to a query filed by an activist under the Right to Information Act, The Hindu reports.The anti-corruption activist Anna Hazare is above Parliament and had the right to threaten to go on fast to get bills passed, his adviser Arvind Kejriwal said Sunday, marking a radical change from the civil society groups position so far, The Times of India reports. Kejriwal justified his decision to campaign against the Congress Party in the an upcoming state election, saying it was the ruling partys duty to ensure passage of the Jan Lokpal Bill, the paper reports.

title: Keeping a Pity Party Short, and Pushing Hard to Improve
description: Maria Velez-Clarke has for 18 years been principal of the Childrens Workshop School in the East Village, Public School 361, one of several small schools started in the 1990s by people who had worked at the widely praised Central Park East School.

title: Good Wife Watch: The Return of Cuddy, Er, Lisa Edelstein
description: So just how quickly can the writers and producers of The Good Wife move? In Sunday nights episode, Get a Room, Eli Gold did crisis management on an outbreak of listeria possibly caused by Wisconsin cheese. The current real-life listeria outbreak caused by Colorado cantaloupes became national news less than two weeks ago. Thats some fancy dancing. (Of course, there was an E. coli outbreak in Wisconsin in mid-September, so maybe it was just a matter of subbing listeriosis in the script.) The resolution was ripped from a different headline: a pie in a chief executives face, a la Rupert Murdoch.

title: Where is Indias Steve Jobs?
In Japan, a Long-Term Study on Radiation Leaks Effects
description: TOKYO  In an effort to track the long-term health effects of the nuclear disaster at Fukushima, Japan has begun a survey of local children for thyroid abnormalities, a problem associated with exposure to radiation.

title: Polands Centrist Leader Secures a Second Term
description: WARSAW  With nearly all the votes counted Monday in the race to govern Poland, Prime Minister Donald Tusk appeared to have defeated his conservative rival and predecessor, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, securing a second term in office while a party that supports gay rights, abortion and some drug legalization seemed set to win representation in Parliament for the first time.

title: When the College Tour Takes a Detour to a Keg Party
description: Ms. Griffee, a sophomore at New York University pursuing a double major in journalism and politics, is an intern this fall on The Choice blog.

title: Festival Explores Amsterdam Club Life by Day and Night
description: Things will get moving in Amsterdam when the annual Amsterdam Dance Event takes over the city from Oct. 19 to 22, with 700 D.J.s and musicians performing in 52 venues around the city.

title: So Much for Perfection: Two Extra Points Missed
description: Do I owe kickers Mike Nugent and Olindo Mare an apology? On Sunday, the Times published an article  I wrote on how infrequently kickers miss extra points.

title: Tony Blair: They Keep Insinuating and I Keep Saying its Not True
description: I interviewed Tony Blair in his suite at New Yorks Carlyle Hotel on the steamy afternoon of Sept. 23. He was in New York for the meeting of the U.N. General Assembly in his capacity as Middle East envoy, a post announced just hours after he stepped down as British prime minister in 2007. Blair had a short window between official meetings to sit for an interview to promote the paperback publication of his 2010 memoir, A Journey. Sadly he did not have enough time  nor did the Carlyle have an extra room  to allow photographer Christian Oth and his team to set their seamless backdrop anywhere or anytime else. So there we were, a trim, tanned, tieless former prime minister, his press secretary, an aide, a book publicist, a photographer and his two assistants and a reporter, all occupying one room in which the air conditioning seemed not to be functioning. At the conclusion of the interview, a flustered Cherie Blair rushed in to join the party, apparently after overhearing from the next room too many questions concerning reports that had run in the conservative tabloid that has dogged the Blairs for decades. I couldnt resist coming in after hearing all that Daily Mail nonsense, she declared. Heres what was left on the cutting room floor.

title: When the Music Stops
description: Wedding season is just around the corner, and soon the streets of Delhi will be full of marching brass bands in colorful, shiny, ill-fitting jackets and pants. No Indian wedding seems to be complete without sonorous trumpets and drums playing classic Hindustani songs or the latest Bollywood item numbers.

title: The Victor Cruz Show, the Good and the Ugly
description: Giants games boil down to Victor Cruz. At least it has seemed that way recently. He caught two touchdown passes to help beat the Eagles. He lived to tell the tale of  laying the ball on the turf even though he wasnt touched against Arizona. And he had a spectacular catch against the Seahawks but also played a role in two crucial turnovers.

title: This Week in Small Business: A 40 Percent Chance
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Channel Surfing: Bored to Death
description: Theres no other comedy on television quite like HBOs Bored to Death. Its simultaneously old-fashioned and amazingly up to the minute, a gumshoe fantasy set in a very real world: the Brooklyn brownstones and cafes and Manhattan co-op apartments and watering holes that shelter what passes for literary culture in 21st-century New York. The novelist Jonathan Ames, the shows creator, works out his love-hate relationship to the citys writing life (and those who live it) with a mix of whimsy and precise observation that can make even the most cleverly written network sitcoms  Modern Family, Community  seem mass produced and one-size-fits-all in comparison.

title: Complaint Box | Electric Delivery Bikes
description: Like everyone else, I like to order pizza or other takeout food and have it at my door and still warm in 15 to 20 minutes. But a recent encounter with a deliveryman on a bicycle that had been souped up with an electric motor  the type that is becoming ubiquitous in neighborhoods throughout the city  alerted me to the perils to pedestrians that the drivers of these illegally motorized vehicles can cause.

title: Final Dagger on  0-3 Road Trip for Jets
description: If the Jets knew before Sundays game that they would hold Wes Welker in check for the most part while limiting Tom Brady to one touchdown pass and intercepting him once, they probably would have signed up for it.

title: On Our Radar: Oil Spill Off New Zealand
description: Five days after a container ship hit a reef, clumps of oil begin washing up on New Zealands North Island, stirring fear that the fuel could foul delicate estuaries. Workers had begun pumping fuel from the ship but halted the effort after weather predictions of gale-force winds. [Associated Press]

title: 2 American Professors Awarded Nobel in Economic Science
description: The Nobel in economic science was awarded on Monday to Thomas J. Sargent of New York University and Christopher A. Sims of Princeton University for their research on the cause and effect of government policies on the broader economy, a major concern of countries still struggling to address the aftermath of the recent financial crisis.

title: Superior Energy to Acquire Complete for $2.7 Billion
description: Superior Energy Services, an oil field services company based in New Orleans, agreed to buy a rival, Complete Production Services, for about $2.7 billion.

title: Netflix, in Reversal, Will Keep Its Services Together
description: 7:19 p.m. | Updated

title: New Yorks Public Architecture Gets a Face-Lift
description: It was business as usual when I stopped at the Queens Central Library in downtown Jamaica the other morning. Visitors were nosing through racks of dog-eared best sellers, schmoozing near the circulation desk and peering into banks of computers on long tables in the lobby.

title: Face Forward
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#31", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);High-tech, versatile and available in almost every skin tone, the fanciest new foundations have nothing to hide.

description: Sea explorers announced Monday the discovery of a new sunken treasure that they plan to retrieve from the bottom of the North Atlantic.

title: S.S. Mantola Video Highlights
description: Sea explorers have discovered sunken treasure that they plan to retrieve from the bottom of the North Atlantic.

title: Report Sees Tight Global Cereal Markets
description: For some Americans, fall is traditionally a season of celebrating the harvest and anticipating a groaning Thanksgiving table. Globally, its also the time of year for some important reports on cereal markets and food security.

title: A New Generation of Dissenters
description: If the Occupy Wall Street protesters ever choose to recognize a person who gave their cause its biggest boost, they may want to pay tribute to Anthony Bologna.

title: Hue Jacksons Tribute to Al Davis
description: The Raiders emotions overflowed after they beat the Texans on the day after Al Daviss death.

title: Collect Call | Mary Ellen Mark and the Robots
description: In this new column, Lynn Yaeger peeks at peoples terrifically odd, amusing and magnificent collections.

title: Monday Reading: Post-Storm Foliage Deals in New England
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Renaissance Gets Revised Offer From Plato
description: Renaissance Learning said on Monday that it had received a revised unsolicited cash offer from Plato Learning for $16.90 a share, or $496 million.

title: Go Princeton! (And NYU)
description: This years Nobel goes to Chris Sims and Tom Sargent. Many congratulations. Id advise both of them to grab as much sleep as they can over the next few months, because its gonna be exhausting.

title: Venture Capital Fund-Raising Tumbles in Third Quarter
description: With the market for initial public offerings still on ice and dark clouds looming over the United States economy, the venture capital industry is struggling to raise money.

title: Light Trading Helps Push Big Gains on Wall Street
description: Wall Street rallied on Monday in light trading after French and German leaders promised to develop a plan to confront Europes debt problems.

title: Europe Delays Meeting on Debt Crisis Actions
description: A crucial European Union summit meeting intended to address the euro zone debt crisis was delayed for nearly a week on Monday to give government leaders more time to fashion a solution.

title: Eight Noteworthy Apps for Children
description: If you coexist with children and iPads, youve undoubtedly discovered they have an insatiable app-itite (sorry, couldnt resist). Here are eight recent noteworthy selections for younger users, listed from young to old.

title: The Invisible Center
description: A question to which I think I know the answer: A number of my colleagues in the commentariat write longingly about the need for a centrist who will propose doing what needs to be done  combine short-run stimulus with long-term measures that will reduce the deficit.

title: New Label-Printer Hotness!
description: Theres no glory in writing about label printers. Yet today will end and tomorrow the sun will rise and millions will look at the unlabeled boxes and cartons in their junk closet and say I wish I had some way of labeling those.

title: Stick It to Me
description: I didnt think I was a good candidate for facial acupuncture. For one thing, the only time Im perfectly still is when Im asleep (or getting an expensive haircut). And quite frankly, if Im going to be stuck with needles, I would like them to deliver the kind of instant gratification that only Botox can provide. That said, when I heard there was a kind man in Midtown who would listen to my problems (but not judge me), calm me down (without meds) and erase my fine lines (without toxins or fillers), all in under an hour, I snagged the first available appointment.

title: Monday Matchup: Bears at Lions
description: Bears (2-2) at Lions (4-0), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Lions by 5

title: Another Traumatic Month for Paulson
description: Tired of incessant leaks to the media about its poor performance, Paulson & Company, the hedge fund started by the billionaire John A. Paulson, decided a few weeks ago to amend its reporting policies to make it harder to obtain performance data.

title: Perry Video Attacks Romney on Health Care
description: In a striking new video, Rick Perry attacks Mitt Romney as both the inspiration for President Obamas health care reform and a repeated flip-flopper who shouldnt be considered for the White House.

title: U.N. Finds Systematic Torture in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Detainees are hung by their hands and beaten with cables, and in some cases their genitals are twisted until the prisoners lose consciousness at sites run by the Afghan intelligence service and the Afghan National Police, according to a United Nations report released here on Monday.

description: A reader sends me this:
