description: Q.

title: What Were Reading
description: The San Francisco Chronicle: Gov. Jerry Brown signed a law banning the possession, sale and distribution of imported shark fins starting in 2013.The state had previously banned cutting fins off sharks in California waters.  Nick Fox

title: Change of Command Set at European Media Group
description: PARIS  Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, said Monday that its chief executive, Hartmut Ostrowski, would step down at the end of the year, citing personal reasons for the surprise move.

title: Ohioans Want to Pry Space Shuttle From New York
description: Hundreds of Ohioans are asking President Obama to take a space shuttle away from New York City before it even arrives.

title: Lens: Feinstein
description: Lens: Feinstein

title: Heartbreak Falls Fast From the Michelin Galaxy
description: Heartbreak, a German-Swiss East Village spot that won a Michelin star last week, isnt just closed for renovations, its closed for good.

title: Winning One for Al Davis
description: There might not have been a more inevitable result than the Raiders winning their game over the Texans on Sunday. There simply was no other possible ending. Because wherever you think the sports worlds No. 1 curmudgeon landed in the afterlife after his death on Saturday, Al Davis was going to make eternity unbearable for whoever is in charge had his beloved team not given him a proper sendoff victory. After years of raging at the N.F.L. machine, his raging might have produced actual thunder. Or an earthquake.

title: A Texas Rainout, but Not for the State Fair
description: Through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. His Phillies homerism is no longer an issue.

title: San Marinos Uphill Battle
description: In Europes smallest recognized soccer nation, population 30,000, victories are as rare as the coins and stamps that make it a collectors haven.

title: One Win, 106 Losses, No Traffic Lights
description: SAN MARINO  This is Europes smallest recognized soccer nation, population 30,000, and victories in the tiny, mountaintop republic are as rare as the coins and stamps that make it a collectors haven.

title: Monday Motorsports: Sebastian Vettel Is Youngest Repeat Champion in Formula One History
description: At the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix last year, Sebastian Vettel, then 23, simultaneously won a race and a season championship. At the Japanese Grand Prix on Sunday, Vettel finished third at more than two seconds off the winning pace, yet with four races left on the Formula One calendar, Vettel, now 24, has drained the 2011 season of most, if not all of its drama by clinching his second championship in a row.

title: Harold Dieterle Will Turn to Europe for the Marrow in Brooklyn
description: Early next year, Harold Dieterle will step away from the Asian kitchen for which he has become known at Perilla and Kin Shop and open the Marrow in a new hotel in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Superior Energy to Acquire a Rival for $2.7 Billion | Superior Energy Services agreed on Monday to buy a rival, Complete Production Services, for about $2.7 billion.

title: Whats in Your Childs School Lunch?
description: If I werent a journalist covering parenting issues (and this week, writing for Motherlode), I would have missed it.

title: Jazzy New Leader for CUNY Biography Center
description: The prize-winning author Gary Giddins has written biographies of Louis Armstrong, Charlie Parker and Bing Crosby. Now he will help other writers recreate the lives of their chosen subjects as the new acting executive director of the Leon Levy Center for Biography at the CUNY Graduate Center. Among his many trophies Mr. Giddins can count a Guggenheim Fellowship, a National Book Critics Circle Award, a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Jazz Journalists Association, and a Grammy.

title: Bank of America Equalizes Health Costs for Gay Employees
description: Bank of Americas new monthly debit card fee has been roundly criticized in recent weeks. But a new change in corporate policy change is likely to receive a much warmer reception.

title: Pasha Fierce
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Social Media Accounts of Violence in Cairo Challenge Official Narrative
description: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo, at least 24 people were killed and more than 200 wounded on Sunday night in Cairo when a demonstration by Christians angry about a recent attack on a church in Upper Egypt devolved into violent clashes with the military.

title: Scant CO2 Benefit from Chinas Coal-Powered Electric Cars
description: Much has been made of Chinas big push to build and deploy 1 million electric vehicles a year by 2015. The move will help cut smog and oil imports. Less has been made of the scant impact this is likely to have on the countrys emissions of carbon dioxide, given its enduring reliance on coal for most of its electricity. Heres a Your Dot contribution describing the situation from Lucia Green-Weiskel, who has worked in China for the Innovation Center for Energy and Transportation and co-authored a report on electric vehicles there for the United Nations.

title: A Village Street Slips Quietly Off the Subway Map
description: Charlton Street, a sleepy three-block lane in the southern end of the West Village, is not exactly the most famous roadway in New York. Its achievements, by this citys standards, are average stuff: a row of landmark 19th-century town houses; a former residence of George Washington.

title: China Suspends Boat Traffic on Mekong
description: HONG KONG  China announced Monday that it was suspending passenger and cargo traffic in the headwaters of the Mekong River after the Thai border police heard gunfire on the river, found two Chinese cargo vessels adrift carrying 920,000 amphetamine pills and one body, and then discovered the floating bodies of 11 Chinese crewmen.

title: Copts Denounce Egyptian Government Over Killings
description: CAIRO  An angry crowd of thousands gathered at the largest cathedral here on Monday to mourn the death of two dozen Coptic Christian demonstrators killed the night before in clashes with security forces, as liberal activists lamented the militarys increasingly tight hold on power.

title: Nearly 6,000 Corvettes Recalled for Weak Rear-Hatch Hinges
description: General Motors is recalling almost 5,800 of its 201112 Chevrolet Corvette coupes because the rear hatch could come off in a crash, the company told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Further Reading on the Nobel Economics Laureates
description: The spotlight today is on Christopher A. Sims of Princeton University and Thomas J. Sargent of New York University, the winners of the Bank of Sweden Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel.

title: Huntsman Calls for New Foreign Policy
description: HOOKSETT, N.H.  With a pledge to erase the old map and adopt a foreign policy to address modern threats, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. drew distinctions from his Republican rivals on Monday by calling for the United States to expand its global engagement and abandon a cold war military mindset.

title: Sondheim to Receive New York City Arts Honor
description: Stephen Sondheim has been tapped to receive New York Citys highest prize for achievement in the arts. The Handel Medallion will be awarded to Mr. Sondheim on Nov. 1 by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Alec Baldwin at a ceremony at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Hearty Do-Ahead Dishes
description: This weeks hearty one-dish vegetarian meals are meant to appeal to families that include a mix of meat-eaters and vegetarians. My best friends have a vegetarian relative who is undergoing some serious surgery and will be recuperating at their home. Theyre in need of several do-ahead recipes that they can all enjoy throughout the week, dishes that can be reheated at different times, as they often get home from work late.

title: Countdown at City Center, as Reopening Approaches
description: Maybe you missed certain flicks of the fan in Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters popular Revelations because of City Centers poor sight lines.

title: Tunisian Islamists Riot Over Animated Film About Iran
description: Riot police clashed with large numbers of Islamist protesters on Sunday in the Tunisian capital in a spasm of religiously based violence that stemmed, in part, from the television broadcast of an animated movie that is critical of the Iranian revolution.

title: Are Bike Rentals a Success? Depends Who You Ask
description: As I reported last week, Paris has begun rolling out new electric vehicles in a car-sharing program called Autolib.

title: Street Style Photos: Uniquely Shaped Heels
description: The best of readers street fashion submissions for the week of Oct. 3.

title: For a Doctor, Survival and Transformation
description: When a doctor becomes a patient, the lessons learned can ripple outward  not just to patients who are similarly afflicted, but also to the physicians who treat them.

title: Prognosis: Slight Rise in Blood Pressure Carries Risk
description: A review of studies suggests that young and middle-aged people with slightly elevated blood pressure, or prehypertension, are nonetheless at much greater risk for stroke than those in the normal range.

title: Risks: Stress May Harm Preemies Development
description: The stress of living in a neonatal intensive care unit results in decreased brain size and abnormal neurological findings for very preterm babies, a small study suggests, and the more the stress, the greater the effect.

title: University of Texas Acquires Coetzees Papers
description: The South African writer J. M. Coetzee wrote his Ph.D. dissertation on the early fiction of Samuel Beckett, receiving his degree from the University of Texas at Austin in 1969, the same year Beckett was awarded the Nobel Prize. Thirty-four years later, Mr. Coetzee himself received the Nobel Prize for literature. Now the Harry Ransom Center, the same library where Mr. Coetzee did his research on Beckett, has acquired Mr. Coetzees papers. Among the more than 160 boxes and filing cabinets of material are family photographs, business correspondence, recordings of interviews, notebooks and early manuscripts for his novels and his autobiography.

title: My Three Favorite Things to Buy at Duane Reade
description: I miss the old, unglamorous Duane Reade, where you could find shampoo without having to wander through a maze of sandwiches, yogurt parfaits and frozen pizza. Still, stick with it and you can find a few things worthy of navigating the aisles.

title: Lens: Rich Russian Kids
description: Lens: Rich Russian Kids

title: For Adobe, the Future Is in the Past
description: When I entered the office of Kevin Lynch, Adobe Systemss chief technology officer, on Friday in San Francisco, I was immediately caught off guardby a large high-definition television hiding in the corner of the room. It was at least 50-inches wide and propped up at a 45 degree angle on a drafting table.

title: Looking Back at the Values Summit
description: Representative Ron Paul of Texas won the straw poll at the Values Voter Summit in Washington over the weekend, not much of a surprise given his campaigns propensity to truck in supporters. Mitt Romney didnt do so hot in the unscientific poll, but the more ominous sign for his appeal to religious conservatives came from a new flare-up in the debate over the nature of his faith.

title: Judge Quits Tribunal in Khmer Rouge Inquiry
description: BANGKOK  A German judge responsible for the indictment of Khmer Rouge suspects in a joint Cambodian-U.N. tribunal has resigned, citing political interference by the Cambodian government, the tribunal announced Monday.

title: Hearing From the 99 Percent
description: As The Times reported on Sunday, offshoots of the Occupy Wall Street movement have taken the dialogue to the streets with protests in several cities and online with more than 200 Facebook pages and Twitter accounts:

title: Profile in Style | Eva Karayiannis
description: The Cyprus-born, London-based beauty applies the same principles to home dcor and personal style as she does to designing clothing, accessories and store interiors for her label, Caramel Baby & Child. I like things to be casual and comfortable, but also elegant and chic, she says. Informal formality, so to speak. Her closet, filled with pieces by Prada, Marni and Rochas, reflects a penchant for pops of color, lush fabrics, refined prints and clean tailoring  the same attributes that separate Caramel from other kiddie companies. See more >>

title: Virtually Warhol: A New App
description: Andy Warhol has always had wide appeal, and now a new app for iPhones, iPod Touch, iPads and Androids will give art lovers in-depth archival materials, images, film and video clips spanning his entire career.

title: Detroit Set for Tigers/Lions Double Tilt
description: Please forgive, in advance, if you meet a distracted Detroiter today, or a sleepy one on Tuesday.

title: Really? The Claim: Sleep Apnea Causes Sexual Problems
description: THE FACTS

title: Groupon: Transparent About Our Lack of Transparency
description: Groupon has made it clear time and again that it doesnt quite want to act like the usual boring business. On Monday, the online coupon giant proved that yet again, by putting a new spin on transparency.

title: Hearing Bilingual: How Babies Sort Out Language
description: Once, experts feared that young children exposed to more than one language would suffer language confusion, which might delay their speech development. Today, parents often are urged to capitalize on that early knack for acquiring language. Upscale schools market themselves with promises of deep immersion in Spanish  or Mandarin  for everyone, starting in kindergarten or even before.

title: Stutterer Speaks Up in Class; His Professor Says Keep Quiet
description: RANDOLPH, N.J.  As his history class at the County College of Morris here discussed exploration of the New World, Philip Garber Jr. raised his hand, hoping to ask why Chinas 15th-century explorers, who traveled as far as Africa, had not also reached North America.

title: How the Volcker Rule May Affect Foreign Banks
description: Drafts of the proposed Volcker Rule, implementing Section 619 of the Dodd-Frank Act, have begun circulating in advance of a vote by the federal agencies to issue the proposal. The Volcker Rule would ban many forms of proprietary trading by banks and would strictly limit their investments in private equity and hedge funds.

title: Is Failure the Secret to Success? Student Edition
description: Paul Toughs article What if the Secret to Success Is Failure? received a tremendous response from readers when it appeared in the Education Issue last month, including 270 comments on our Web site and 40 percent of the magazines page views. But we were very excited to see the article have a kind of second life over at The Learning Network, a New York Times blog for students and teachers. Our colleagues at The Learning Network used the article to kick off a new Reading Club, and there were 534 student comments on Toughs article. The Reading Club forum encourages discussion, and it was pretty exciting to see students thoughtfully debate questions about social class and character; parental influence and character; and the difference between struggle and failure. There was a lot of respectful disagreement, though the comments I read seemed to be nearly unanimous on one point: No report cards for character, please.

title: The Laptops Dont Work, but the Messages Get Through
American Film Institute to Give Award to Shirley MacLaine
description: Alfred Hitchcock was one of the first to see Shirley MacLaines cinematic appeal, casting her in his 1955 film, The Trouble With Harry. Now, with more than 50 Hollywood movies to her name, Ms. MacLaine will receive the lifetime achievement award from the American Film Institute, which will be presented at a gala tribute in Los Angeles on June 7, the BBC reported.

title: A Recycling Companys New Office Reflects Its Ethic
description: TerraCycles offices after the redesign.

title: About That 99 Percent
description: 6:18 p.m. | Updated to correct reference to 99th percentile of wealth.

title: The Surprising Money Habits of Successful Entrepreneurs
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Life Without Government
description: BASTROP, Texas

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Adara Media, Mountain View, Calif., hired four executives. Two will be based in Mountain View: Jeff Cohen, vice president for strategic accounts, and Brandon Meyers, sales director. One, Mark Hersch, vice president for strategic accounts, will be based in Chicago. The fourth, Andrew Freedman, regional sales director for the eastern region, will be based in New York.

title: A Search for Bargains Goes Social
description: Decades ago, Macys proclaimed, Its smart to be thrifty. Now, consumers who are concerned about the economy have elevated thriftiness to a lifestyle, as evidenced by everything from TV shows about extreme couponing to retailers that try to turn shopping into a quest for values.

title: Spotify Loss Widens Despite Higher Revenue
description: Spotify, the streaming digital music service that was just given a big boost through a partnership with Facebook, saw its revenue more than quintuple last year, but the company still lost more than $40 million, it reported on Monday.

title: The Caucus | A New Political Force?
description: Oct. 10, 2011 - Washington looks for political implications as the Occupy Wall Street protests gain strength. Also, a report from New Hampshire, where the Republican campaign is centered this week.

title: Is There a Solution to Giants Running Woes?
description: There are plenty of reasons for Giants fans to be up in arms Monday, even if they arent among the thousands (millions?) of disappointed knockout pool participants who had the Giants winning easily over the Seattle Seahawks.

title: India Wedding Band Blues
description: Band musicians in Delhi, India, endure low wages and strict bandmasters while being looked down upon in society.

title: Are Better Times Ahead for the Jets?
description: It was somewhat surprising that the Jets left Gillette Stadium late Sunday night with mixed emotions. Players spoke of frustration, of shock, at losing three consecutive games, all against quality A.F.C.opponents. Yet they also sounded much more encouraged than in weeks past, happier certainly than after the debacles in Oakland and Baltimore.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Disappointment? Apples iPhone 4S Breaks Sales Records
description: It has the repetition of a Hollywood movie script: Apple releases a new product. Some in the media and analysts quickly bemoan the new product, saying it didnt live up to the hype they created.

title: Provocateurs Strong Showing Is a Sign of a Changing Poland
description: WARSAW  Waving a gun and a sex toy at a news conference may have branded Janusz Palikot as an extreme politician, but the ensuing notoriety had its benefits. Just a few years later, one out of 10 Polish voters cast a ballot for the socially libertarian-style party that bears the provocateurs name.

title: A Shiny Failure, Reborn as a Rehab Center
description: With buffed hardwood floors, a fireplace in the living room, marble in the bathrooms and Silestone in the kitchen, the 2,200-square-foot, full-floor apartment on West Broadway looks exactly like the luxury condo it was meant to be. The furniture is plush and neutral, original artwork hangs on the walls, there is a Wii console hooked up to the flat-screen television and, when the sights of TriBeCas bustle from the second-floor windows are not enough, there is a planted, furnished roof deck upstairs, with views stretching from the Empire State Building to ground zero.

title: The Difference Between Puffery and Fraud
description: The Justice Department and the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, filed separate civil charges last week against Bank of New York Mellon, accusing it of defrauding customers of its foreign exchange services. The cases raise sticky questions about when marketing claims cross the imperceptible line from puffery to fraud.

title: Government Aims to Build a Data Eye in the Sky
description: More than 60 years ago, in his Foundation series, the science fiction novelist Isaac Asimov invented a new science  psychohistory  that combined mathematics and psychology to predict the future.

title: Romney Turns Again to the Economy
description: MILFORD, N.H.  Mitt Romney on Monday accused President Obama of fostering divisiveness in America and said the protests against Wall Street were unfairly criticizing an entire sector of the countrys economy.

title: Revisiting the Global Food Crisis
description: Another new report has just become available on the subject of world hunger, and it may frustrate some readers. The new edition of State of Food Insecurity in the World, an annual report from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, does not actually estimate the number of hungry people across the globe.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 10
description: A view of the day in sports included wheelchair fencing and the worlds least stressed security guard.

title: Mushroom Lasagna
description: This lasagna tastes very rich, even though it really isnt. It combines an olive oil bchamel with a simple mushroom ragout and Parmesan cheese. I prefer no-boil lasagna noodles because theyre lighter than regular lasagna noodles. But I still boil them because I think the results are better if theyre cooked until theyre flexible (a couple of minutes) first.

title: Edison2, X Prize Winner, Claims 350 M.P.G. Equivalent for Prototype
description: Edison2, the tiny, Virginia-based engineering company that won the $5 million mainstream class in the Automotive X Prize last year, recently tested the performance of its all-electric, four-passenger Very Light Car design  a rounded pod with outboard-mounted wheels  at Roush Laboratories in Livonia, Mich.

title: Behind a Surprising Income Trend
description: Anyone with detailed knowledge of the annual Census Bureau data on household income may be surprised by the new study Robert Pear describes in todays Times. From the article:

title: Now Showing | Ryan Roche
description: To showcase her second womens wear collection, Ryan Roche enlisted the filmmaker Anna Palma and the model Stephanie Christian of Supreme to capture the labels cashmere knit capes and day dresses.

title: Andy Murray Completes Rare Double in Tokyo
description: Andy Murray became the first player in 2011 to win both the singles and doubles titles at an A.T.P. tournament, taking the singles title on his own and pairing with his older brother Jamie to win the doubles at the Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships in Tokyo.

title: Shake, Rattle and Roll
description: Q. Can human actions cause earthquakes?

title: Week 5 Quick Hits: Bills Up, Eagles Down
description: Andy Benoit takes a quick tour of every N.F.L. game on Mondays. Did he miss something? Share your thoughts in the comments section.

title: Japan Courts the Money in Reactors
description: TOKYO  Even as Japan plans to phase out nuclear power as too risky for domestic use, the government is supporting a new push by Japanese industry to sell nuclear power technology to other countries.

title: California Bans Indoor Tanning for Minors
description: California this week became the first state in the country to ban indoor tanning for anyone under 18, a move that drew praise from health organizations.

title: Decorating a Locker, Virtually
description: Middle-school girls are transforming their once-barren metal lockers with fanciful decorations that fully cover the drab chipped paint and Sharpie commentary of any former inhabitants. In todays Times, Elissa Gootman describes the next frontier in nesting  polka-dot chandeliers, zebra-print wallpaper, lime shag rugs and other decorating options.

title: Amy Winehouses Father Signs Deal to Write Book About Her
description: Less than three months after  the death of his daughter,  Mitch Winehouse has made a deal to write a book about her, his publisher said on Monday. The book, titled Amy, is a heartfelt and revelatory memoir that will tell what Mr. Winehouse says is the true story of Amy Winehouses life.

title: Joe the Plumber May Be Joe the Candidate
description: Samuel J. Wurzelbacher, better known as Joe the Plumber from the 2008 presidential campaign, has filed papers to run for a House seat in northern Ohio.

title: Envy May Bear Fruit, but It Also Has an Aftertaste
description: Why envy? It seems to be the most useless of the deadly sins: excruciating to experience, shameful to admit, bereft of immediate pleasure or long-term benefits. To an evolutionary psychologist, theres a certain logic to seducing thy neighbors wife or stealing his goods, but whats the point of merely coveting them?

title: The Return of Delmon Young
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Now batting third for the Detroit Tigers and playing left field  Delmon Young?

title: Egyptian Christians Criticize Government Over Killings
description: Egypts Coptic Christian church harshly criticized the government on Monday over its actions in crushing a protest in Cairo the night before that left at least 24 dead.

title: A Delivery From Space That Made a Big Splash
description: Using a powerful space telescope, scientists have found evidence that the water in the Earths oceans could have been delivered by comets.

title: Caucus Video: Meaning in the Wall Street Protests
description: Washington looks for political implications as the Occupy Wall Street protests gain strength. Also, a report from New Hampshire, where the Republican campaign is centered this week.

title: At Long Last, Facebook Releases an iPad App
description: It has been the equivalent of waiting for Bigfoot. Bloggers had seen it. Developers said they had worked on it. Facebook denied its existence.Everyone else just wanted to know if it was real.

title: Prevention: Doubts on Womens Use of Supplements
description: Older women who used common dietary supplements died at slightly higher rates than women who did not rely on supplements, a large study has found.

title: Dream Act Becomes Law in California
description: In California, illegal immigrants enrolling in college will be eligible for state scholarships and financial aid beginning next July.

title: If Banks Are Outlawed, Only Outlaws Will Have Banks
description: Yglesias tells us that some Occupy Wall Street protesters have picked up Ron Paulish monetary ideas  although some know better. I thought Id say a word about one particular idea that sounds plausible to some people but is actually quite wrong: banning fractional reserve banking.

title: Questions on Tactic to Prevent H.I.V.
description: In the past year, three landmark clinical trials have shown that a daily dose of the antiretroviral medication Truvada can protect individuals from infection with H.I.V.  a significant discovery, given the failure so far of all efforts to develop a vaccine against the virus.

title: In Senate Race, Warren Raises More Cash Than Brown
description: BOSTON  With help from national fund-raising groups, Elizabeth Warren has already raised $3.15 million for her United States Senate campaign, catapulting ahead of her Democratic primary opponents.

title: With Davis Gone, Who Will Lead Raiders?
description: N.F.L. executives on Sunday gave Al Davis something he seldom gave them: a moment of silence.

title: Flaunting Youthful Navet
description: Perhaps youve seen them on YouTube, the young girls shaking their bodies in emulation of Beyonc while making faces more like Shirley Temples. Perhaps youve wondered if they understand the erotic implications of their movements. Is this sexual pantomime damaging? Where will it lead?

title: The Appraisal: Sobering Up Amid Citys Lures
description: This week the Appraisal visits TriBeCa Twelve, a soon-to-open home for young adults recovering from substance abuse. It will be run by Hazelden, the Minnesota-based operator of a network of rehab centers, and be housed in a planned luxury condo development on West Broadway that Hazelden bought after the development went belly up. The Columbia University psychiatry department is a partner in the effort. Although the popular image of live-in centers for people recovering from substance abuse runs more toward campus-like complexes in bucolic settings, where fresh air and natural beauty replace the lures of drugs and alcohol, this one  intended to serve as a transition from rehab to real life  is in the midst of a heavily traveled night life zone, near bars, clubs and restaurants that would seem to pose threats to a residents hard-won sobriety. Have you or has someone you know been in rehab or a similar situation and found the temptations of city life hard to resist? Or do you think that treatment centers need not be remote to be effective? Please share your thoughts and experiences.

title: In Birds, a Possible Clue to the Cycle of Abuse
description: Although it has never been definitively proven, many social scientists believe that abused children are more likely to become abusers as adults. Now for the first time, there is evidence of the phenomenon in animals in the wild.

title: A science lesson from the singer Bjork, the life and times of University of California San Franciscos Susan Desmond-Hellman and a new study on the nature of envy.
description: A science lesson from the singer Bjork, the life and times of University of California San Franciscos Susan Desmond-Hellman and a new study on the nature of envy.

title: New Hampshires Contrarian Streak
description: Tuesday nights Republican debate will be on favorable turf for Mitt Romney: New Hampshire, where he owns a home and has led in every poll of Republican voters, sometimes by a substantial margin.

title: New Way to Gain a Clear View of the Brain
description: A group of Japanese neuroscientists is trying to peer into the mind  literally. They have devised a way to turn the brains opaque gray matter into a glassy, see-through substance.

title: Sigmund Freud, 1909
description: Sigmund Freud visited the United States only once, in 1909, to give a series of lectures. The New York Times found nothing about the visit worth mentioning except his departure. Prof. Sigmund Freud appears on Page 9 on Sept. 21, along with Dr. C. G. Jung, in a list of passengers sailing to Bremen, Germany, aboard the Kaiser Wilhelm Der Grosse. It was the first time the newspaper mentioned his name.

title: TimesCast | October 10, 2011
description: October 10, 2011 --Egyptians express outrage over the killing of Coptic Christians; politicians debate how to exploit or undercut the Occupy Wall St. protests; and Netflix will not split its services.

title: In Brazil, Energy Finds Put Country at a Whole New Power Level
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Of all those who might smile at Brazils unfolding oil boom, Walter Link could rank near the top. A U.S. oilman here at a time of nationalist fervor, he was the former chief geologist for Standard Oil Company of New Jersey whom Brazil hired to find its oil reserves.

title: Your Economic Outlook: Mixed Up
description: Contradictory data are nothing new in economics, but amid the slump in the United States and Europe, readers may find themselves paying increasing attention to indicators that seem to point every which way.

title: Susan Desmond-Hellmann
description: An interview with the oncologist, translational scientist and former Genentech executive now leading the University of California, San Francisco.

title: China Marches On With Nuclear Energy, in Spite of Fukushima
description: BEIJING

title: DVRs Bring Some Shows a Ratings Boost
description: The time is coming when judgments about television shows based on initial ratings may be a foolish policy  especially with more and more viewers using recording devices to watch shows long after they have been first broadcast.

title: An Innovator Shapes an Empire
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The phone call, at home one night last week, came from a student seeking donations for the University of California, San Francisco.

title: Ex-President of Cape Verde Wins Good-Government Prize
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Pedro de Verona Rodrigues Pires, the former president of Cape Verde, the desertlike archipelago about 300 miles off the coast of West Africa, has won one of the worlds major prizes, the $5 million Ibrahim Prize for Achievement in African Leadership.

title: In Milwaukee, Sausages Arent Just for Tailgating
description: MILWAUKEE  They appeared from behind the left-field fence in the middle of the sixth inning, five tall, costumed wieners with heads like Easter Island statues but wearing hats. The Miller Park crowd of 43,613 cheered and whistled Sunday as the Milwaukee Brewers famous racing sausages lined up on the warning track and took off.

title: Normans Conquest
description: In the American fall collections of 1960, Norman Norell did something seemingly too radical for a man who ate most of his meals at Schraffts and Hamburg Heaven. He had his models paint their faces in the bohemian-urchin style of Paris in the 20s, with darkened eyes and red lips, finished off with shingle haircuts. Then he put the girls in pants. Technically these were split skirts, but who cares? The effect was the same. Long before Yves Saint Laurent issued le smoking, square Norman was there. They may seem a little avant-garde at first, he told The Times after his 1960 show, for which he received a standing ovation, but I really do believe in the look. He had uncanny instincts for anticipating change: the elongated sweater look, the return of waistlines in the mid-60s, the dolman-sleeve rage of the early 70s. He showed leopard patterns in the 40s. The flapper makeup told a lot about Norell as well: stage-struck at an early age, he designed costumes in the 20s at the Astoria studio of Paramount Pictures, dressing Gloria Swanson in Zaza, and later worked on Broadway musicals and burlesque shows before moving to ladies fashion.

title: The Incredible Good Luck of Breaking Bad
description: Breaking Bad, which just ended its fourth season on Sunday, had its premiere on Jan. 20, 2008. It started with a straightforward and rather narrow premise: A mild-mannered chemistry teacher named Walter White finds out he has cancer, and so he decides, in order to build up a fortune to leave to his family, to start cooking meth.

title: Children Spend a Day at Protesters Encampment
description: With public schools and some private schools closed for Columbus Day, a new wave of protesters joined the ranks of Occupy Wall Street on Monday: a few dozen children who gathered at Zuccotti Park with their parents, carrying homemade signs riddled with charming misspellings and cheering Occupy Wall Stre-et Is The Place to Be-ee.

description: Lens: Rosenthal

Prostate Test Finding Leaves a Swirl of Confusion
description: For men living with a diagnosis of prostate cancer, the news that the P.S.A. test does more harm than good has been unsettling and confusing.

description: Weber on the Web

description: The dancer Charles Askegard gave his final performance with New York City Ballet on Sunday.

description: Photographs from Egypt, Libya, Liberia and New York.

title: Advisory Firm Urges Ouster of Murdoch and His Sons
description: 8:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Bloomberg Says Protesters Can Stay On, if They Obey Laws
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, seemingly softening his language about the Occupy Wall Street protest, suggested on Monday that he did not anticipate an effort by the city to remove the demonstrators from a park in Lower Manhattan.

title: Primary Yields Runoff for French Socialists  and a Surprise
description: PARIS  Franois Hollande, a centrist, took the lead in the first round of the Socialist primary this weekend, beginning the battle to see who will oppose President Nicolas Sarkozy in the general election next year.

title: Round Midnight with Librado Romero
description: There is a certain tender melancholy in the air, cloaked in shadows and soft light, as the city winds down. Revelers squeezing the last thrills from a night on the town. Lovers walking slowly hand in hand, before they kiss, part and vanish home. A solitary figure in a subway car as it rattles uptown.

title: 1930 Model A Ford Wraps a Year on the Road
description: After a year of happy rumbling in a 1930 Model A Ford, Jonathan Klinger knew that his return to automotive modernity would be an adjustment.

title: Apple Plans Jobs Remembrance
description: Apple is planning what it describes as a public celebration to remember its founder and former chief executive, Steve Jobs, who died Wednesday.

title: German Hand Bolsters American Identity
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the German coach of the American soccer team, has his own ideas, large and small.

title: In Britain, Official Stays After Apology
description: LONDON  Britains minister of defense, Liam Fox, appeared on Monday to have won at least a temporary stay in office after a protracted public apology for misjudgments in his personal relationship with a man who has traveled widely with him on his overseas trips and been a frequent visitor to his Whitehall office.

title: The Caucus Click: Political and Family History
Mariusz Kwiecien Withdraws From Met Performance
description: Mariusz Kwiecien, cast in the title role of the Metropolitan Operas highly touted new production of Mozarts Don Giovanni, injured his back at rehearsal on Monday and was scratched from Thursdays opening night, the Met said. Peter Mattei will take his place. Mr. Kwiecien hurt himself during the opening scene of the dress rehearsal and was taken to the hospital. A Met spokesman said he had no immediate information on the nature of the injury, Mr. Kwieciens condition or when he might return. Mr. Mattei is appearing at the Met as Figaro in Rossinis Barbiere di Siviglia.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Libya, Indonesia and Liberia.

title: Netflix Backtracks
description: Netflix changed course and decided not to split up its online streaming and DVD services.

title: In Iowa, Religious Right Is Now a Force Divided
description: DES MOINES  Measured by national polling, media attention and millions in the bank, the Republican field appears to have come down to a bout between two heavyweights: Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, vs. Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

title: Beyonc Accused of Plagiarism Over Video
description: Several of the dance moves in the new music video by Beyonc for her song Countdown bear a striking resemblance to the work of the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, who told a radio station in Antwerp on Monday she believed Beyonc had stolen her ideas.

title: An Ad Campaign Fit for the Jet Set
description: The new ABC series Pan Am is reviving memories about the jet age and how much different flying was then. One difference that is still to be pointed out: There was a lot less advertising in airports back then.

title: An Ode to Cheap Books in a Former Borders
description: The e-book and Amazon.com helped to undo Borders. But Martin Carmody is not deterred.
