title: Battle for Libya | October 10, 2011
description: Heavy fighting raged in Surt on Monday as fighters pushed through residential areas that have been used as cover by snipers loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Downsized and Downtrodden, Men Are the New Women on TV
description: I am the man! Will (Mather Zickel) hollers lustily into his headset after scoring a kill in a combat video game. His wife, yelling from another room, orders him to pipe down.

title: Challenge to Students: Have Space Station Run Your Experiment
description: Make a two-minute video. Get an experiment flown to the International Space Station.

title: Dance Institute, Centered in Harlem
description: For 35 years the National Dance Institute has been a gypsy, in the words of its founder, Jacques dAmboise, the former New York City Ballet principal dancer. The institute rented and borrowed space here and there as it brought dance, performance and arts education to thousands of New York City public school students.

title: A Goodbye, Understated but Riveting in Its Duets
description: On Sunday afternoon at New York City Ballet, the dancer Charles Askegard played four consecutive roles: a noble cavalier in formal attire (the pas de deux from George Balanchines Diamonds); an unadorned dancer in white T-shirt and black tights (Balanchines Episodes); a harsh messenger of death in gray shirt and black trousers (Jerome Robbinss In Memory of...); and finally an American cowboy (Balanchines Western Symphony). With this display of range, Mr. Askegard made his farewell to City Ballet.

title: How to Fix Californias Democracy Crisis
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: NBC and Packers Cruise to Victory
description: With the Fox broadcast of Game 2 of the American League Championship Series postponed because of rain, the Sunday Night Football game between the Green Bay Packers and the Atlanta Falcons dominated the night en route to another Sunday ratings victory for NBC. (The Packers defeated the Falcons, 25-14). The competing shows, meanwhile, continued to struggle, especially on ABC. As little as two weeks ago the network was looking at a successful debut of its series Pam Am, as the premiere episode was sampled by nearly 11 million total viewers. Three episodes later, the series has fallen sharply week-to-week, with another 27 percent drop this week in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and a dwindling total viewership of 6.4 million. The numbers werent much better for Desperate Housewives, which tied a series low in the 18-to-49 category for a new episode.

title: Cricket Hovers After Sex to Ensure Mates Safety
description: Biologists have long thought of the male cricket as an insect version of the stalker boyfriend. In laboratory studies, a male cricket often lingers after copulating in an effort, researchers believed, to make sure his mate does not go searching for a different partner or reject the slow-release package of sperm he has just deposited.

title: Post Games
description: De mortuis nihil nisi bonum. Dont rip the dead. It seems to be the generous sentiment behind most of the coverage following the deaths of two Bay Area titans in the last week, Steve Jobs and Al Davis. And who can argue with that? Jobs was Apple; Davis was the Oakland Raiders; each transformed his industry. Who doesnt love an iPad (or appreciate Apples market capitalization)? Who doesnt thrill to the high-arcing vertical bomb that results in a 60-yard touchdown?

title: George Vecsey: Nice Touches to Start the Klinsmann Era
description: George Vecsey of the Times assesses the first few months of the Jurgen Klinsmann era in a column that is on nytimes.com and will be in Tuesdays print editions. On Monday, he joined Klinsmann and the team on its visit to the September 11 Memorial in Manhattan.

title: India: Gates Foundations AIDS Program in India Has Made Uneven Progress Over 8 Years
description: A large and costly AIDS prevention program that the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation pioneered in India eight years ago has had mixed results, according to a preliminary analysis published on Monday in The Lancet.

title: Childrens Library Discovery Center
description: A new addition to Queens Central Library is part of a quiet revolution reshaping New Yorks public architecture.

title: He Joked, and the World Laughed With Him
description: Funny novels, like funny movies, rarely gain traction with prize committees. People assume that its the gloomy buggers that are the serious ones, Martin Amis has said, but in fact, anyone who has ever been anywhere in fiction is funny. A great comic actor, if he or she sticks around long enough, might win not an actual Oscar but a consolation prize: a lifetime achievement award. The National Book Awards need something similar for Americas comic writers. Among the first Id nominate is Bruce Jay Friedman, whose prose, over the past five decades, has mostly been a pure pleasure machine.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,788 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Men and Women of a Certain (Privileged) Age
description: The 25-year-old photographer Anna Skladmann had to be patient when dealing with some of the subjects of her long-term portrait series, Little Adults. They had people to see and places to be.

title: Tim Cook Is Thinking Different
description: For people who are curious about how Apples new chief executive, Tim Cook, will compare to the companys previous C.E.O., Steve Jobs, theres not a lot to go on yet.

title: Amid Protests, Blankfein Cancels College Talk
description: The students of Barnard College were expecting to hear from Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, as part of a lecture series titled Power Talks.

title: Making Peace Can Be a Real Battle
description: WOMEN, WAR & PEACE

title: Chinas Sovereign Wealth Fund Tries to Bolster Stocks of Major Banks
description: HONG KONG  Trying to stem a steep decline in the stock prices of Chinas four main banks, the nations sovereign wealth fund started buying their shares Monday and plans to buy more in the coming year.

title: Video: Netflix Backtracks
description: Related: Netflix Abandons Plan to Rent DVDs on Qwikster

title: A Theologian Weighs In on the Mormon Church
description: A leading Southern Baptist theologian spoke out Monday on the question of Mormons, Christianity and elections, clearly trying to soften the harsh message of Robert Jeffress, a Southern Baptist pastor who created a political tempest over the weekend.

title: After 20 Hours Adrift, 7 Rescued in Florida Keys
description: MIAMI  They were very lucky, was how a Coast Guard rescuer described seven of the eight people who went fishing in the Florida Keys on Saturday, only to end up bobbing in choppy seas, miles off shore, for 20 hours after their boat capsized.

title: TimesCast | Mistrust of Egypt's Military
description: October 10, 2011  Egyptians expressed outrage over the killing of 26 Coptic Christians by the military during a crackdown on protests on Sunday.

title: Army Leaders Warn Against Shrinking Forces Too Much
description: WASHINGTON  The Armys two top leaders argued Monday against shrinking their service too much, warning that the nation may have to rethink its defense strategy if the ground forces become too small.

title: Tea or Coffee? Land Line or Cellphone? Hogs or Humans? Census Has Answers
description: Twice as many Americans play computer games as do crossword puzzles. More go bird watching than attend classical music concerts. Iowa has six times as many hogs as people. A record 26.6 million households do not use land lines but rely only on cellphones. And about one in 13 women in their early 20s identify themselves as gay or bisexual.

title: You Have to Gamble on Your Health
description: Hanover, N.H.

title: Jobss Cause of Death Is Released by Coroner
description: Steven P. Jobs died at home in Palo Alto, Calif., of respiratory arrest caused by a pancreatic tumor at about 3 p.m. on Wednesday, according to his death certificate.

title: For Altidore, Playing Time Is Positive Development
description: HARRISON, N.J.  There is something oddly elliptical about a coach, in this case Jurgen Klinsmann, who says something that seems obvious but often is not.

title: Big Temptations for Wells Fargo
description: Will Wells Fargo get hooked on Wall Street? The bank, based in California and led by John G. Stumpf, mostly has resisted the siren call to put down stakes in Lower Manhattan. But Wells Fargo kept Wachovias fledgling investment bank when it bought its struggling rival three years ago, and the company is still hiring. A couple of senior M.& A. bankers joined just last week. But getting much bigger would come at a price.

title: Slovak Leader Vows to Resign if Euro Bailout Vote Fails
description: WARSAW  On the eve of a vote in Parliament, Slovakias prime minister threatened on Monday to resign if her governing coalition did not pass the expansion of the euro currency zones bailout fund.

title: Should Men Get Prostate Cancer Tests?
description: To the Editor:

title: Idol Singers Morning-After Moment
description: Scotty McCreery started out the most recent season of American Idol as a scrawny stick with a deep and hollow voice and an Alfred E. Neuman grin. By the time the show ended, hed become a Nashville slickster would-be, with exaggerated gestures and bulging swagger. Lauren Alaina arrived at the show a savant, a flexible singer with preternatural confidence and a gift for interpretation. But with each week, she seemed to grow younger and younger, losing the boom in her voice, her confidence, her grip on the shows narrative.

title: Pressed, Sheriff Agrees to Jails Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES  Accusations of inmate abuse in the countrys largest jail system have piled up over the last several days and weeks, with tales of volunteers witnessing beatings of prisoners. And when news broke of a federal investigation into the conduct of several guards, the Los Angeles County sheriff, Lee Baca, reacted angrily, saying the inquiry overstepped its authority.

title: Marketers Work Around the Gore to Reach a Zombie Shows Audience
description: BING, the two-year-old Microsoft search engine, has paid for product placements in movies including Source Code and television shows including The Vampire Diaries and Hawaii Five-0.

title: Jagjit Singh, Reviver of Persian Ghazal Singing, Dies at 70
description: Jagjit Singh, a singer of wide popularity in South Asia who helped revive and popularize ghazals  a venerable form of Persian poetry set to music expressing the writers feelings, especially about love  died on Monday in Mumbai. He was 70.

title: Facebook iPad App Improves on Web Site
description: Until now, navigating Facebook.com on an iPad felt like trying to write an e-mail on a calculator.

title: Joe Aceti, Director Who Shaped TV Sports, Dies at 76
description: Joe Aceti, an innovative television director who for three decades helped shape network coverage of major sports events, including the Olympics, the World Series and the Ali-Frazier Thrilla in Manila, died on Oct. 4 in Kirkland, Wash. He was 76.

title: Gulf Shrimp Are Scarce This Season; Answers, Too
description: LAFITTE, La.  The dock at Bundys Seafood is quiet, the trucks are empty and a crew a fraction of the normal size sits around a table waiting for something to do. But the most telling indicator that something is wrong is the smell. It smells perfectly fine.

title: A Dark Mood Surrounds Corporate Jet Makers
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Naked in Massachusetts
description: I have my doubts that Elizabeth Warren is elitist and Im not convinced Scott Brown is sexist, but Im sure of this: we just got our first glimpse of how sadly petty and predictably reductive the 2012 U.S. Senate campaign in Massachusetts is bound to be.

title: NATO Commander Says Resilience of Qaddafi Loyalists Is Surprising
description: WASHINGTON  The commander of NATOs air campaign in Libya has said that hundreds of organized fighters loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi pose a resilient and fierce threat in the two remaining pro-Qaddafi strongholds, and are exploiting the urban settings to complicate the alliances mission to protect civilians.

title: Many in Both Parties Want a Window Into the Deficit Reduction Panels Work
description: WASHINGTON  On one crucial point, a powerful Congressional committee seeking ways to reduce the federal budget deficit has managed to produce a rare bipartisan consensus: Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives in and out of Congress say the panel is doing too much of its work in secret.

title: The Milquetoast Radicals
description: The U.S. economy is probably going to stink for a few more years. It is beset by short-term problems (low consumer demand, uncertain housing prices, too much debt) and long-term problems (wage stagnation, rising health care costs, eroding human capital).

title: Romney, on Friendly Turf, Keeps His Message on the Economy as Attacks Fly
description: HOPKINTON, N.H.  Facing an increasing barrage of attacks on his character from Republican rivals and critics, Mitt Romney ignored the criticism Monday and sought to maintain his focus on the nations struggling economy ahead of a debate on that topic here Tuesday night.

title: When the Catch Disappears
description: Shrimpers on the Gulf Coast say this years season is a bad one, if not the worst in memory.

title: Chipping Away at Gridlock
description: Democrats scored a small but significant victory for the cause of progress in the Senate late last week when they voted to prohibit one of the many delaying tactics that keep the chamber tied up in pointless partisan arguments. It was a long way from desperately needed filibuster reform, but it showed that sufficiently frustrated senators can take action to prevent the Senate from being a total dead weight.

title: Fliers vs. Airlines Rights
description: Airlines have long been able to remove disruptive passengers from their airplanes. But while in the past only fellow travelers knew what had happened, now social media exposes these disputes to a worldwide audience.

title: No Car, No Hotel, No Luggage. But He Got the Account.
description: ALMOST all of my business flights are commercial, not private. Ill be the first to admit that Im not a good flier.

title: Enabling Mr. Assad
description: There is a lot of shame to go around after the United Nations Security Council failed last week to pass a resolution condemning Syrias brutal crackdown. Russia, which used its veto, clearly values its arms sales and other trade with Damascus over the lives of the more than 2,900 Syrians killed during pro-democracy protests. China, which followed Russia, clearly fears any popular movement.

title: Questioning Prostate Cancer Tests
description: American men now have an authoritative warning that getting a blood test for prostate cancer may push them toward needless tests and treatments that would do them more harm than good. The United States Preventive Services Task Force, after an exhaustive review of the scientific evidence, has suggested that healthy men should no longer receive the P.S.A. blood test to screen for a protein that may indicate cancer.

title: Chinese City Shuts Down 13 Wal-Marts
description: HONG KONG  The fiercely nationalistic municipal government of Chongqing in southwestern China ordered all 13 Wal-Mart stores there to close for 15 days and fined the company $420,000 in a labeling dispute that has broader political implications for Western companies operating in China.

title: Putting a Face on Whats at Stake in a Clash Over the Minimum Wage
description: At its most elemental, a battle brewing in the City Council comes down to this: Do a few thousand New Yorkers like Kimberly Ortiz deserve a raise?

title: New Yorks Housekeeping Money
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg testified last week in a trial about whether a former campaign aide had absconded with the mayors $1.1 million contribution to the Independence Party. That party gave Mr. Bloomberg its line in 2009. While the court is focused on that question, the public should be asking a larger one. Mainly, why could the mayor write such a large personal check to the party?

title: A Brash Style and Power Plays Allowed Davis to Wrest Control
description: When F. Wayne Valley hired Al Davis to coach the Oakland Raiders in 1963, he could not have imagined that Davis would one day shrewdly maneuver him out as the principal owner.

title: Regulators to Set Forth Volcker Rule
description: WASHINGTON  The outlines of the Volcker Rule, one of the flagship provisions of the sweeping financial regulatory overhaul passed last year, will begin to take shape this week as regulators propose rules to limit the ability of most banks and Wall Street firms to use their own funds to buy and sell stocks, corporate bonds and derivatives.

title: Al Qaeda Group Confirms Deaths of Two American Citizens
description: WASHINGTON  Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula on Monday issued a statement on Islamist Web sites confirming the deaths of Anwar Al-Awlaki and Samir Khan, two American citizens who were killed in a drone strike in Yemen last month, while saying that their killings contradicted the principles that the United States says it was founded upon and stands for.

title: States Adding Drug Test as Hurdle for Welfare
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  As more Americans turn to government programs for refuge from a merciless economy, a growing number are encountering a new price of admission to the social safety net: a urine sample.

title: Game-Ending Slam Gives Rangers Room to Breathe
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Nelson Cruzs slump hurt enough, but even after he hit a game-tying home run in the seventh inning, the Detroit Tigers figured it was safer to pitch to him in the ninth than to Mike Napoli as they desperately fought to take the Texas Rangers into extra innings Monday night.

title: Outside Panel Backs Prostate Test Advisory
description: In the wake of a government panels advice last week that healthy men should no longer be routinely screened for prostate cancer, an independent team of experts sought to explain, in an assessment of the scientific evidence in a prominent medical journal, why a simple blood test generally results in more harm than good.

title: Coveted Jobs in Iraq Breed Diploma Fraud
description: BAGHDAD  For two years, an assistant dean at Iraqs largest university received threats from a police officer: sign a fraudulent document certifying that the officer had graduated from the university, the dean was told, or he would be arrested or even killed.

title: Volatility, Thy Name Is E.T.F.
description: Did you watch the markets on Monday? In the last 18 minutes of trading, the Standard & Poors 500-stock index jumped more than 10 points with no news to account for the rally. If you were left scratching your head, you were not alone.

title: This Time, It Really Is Different
description: The title of the white paper is, admittedly, a mouthful: The Way Forward: Moving From the Post-Bubble, Post-Bust Economy to Renewed Growth and Competitiveness. It was commissioned by the New America Foundation, which hoped that it might re-center the political debate to better reflect the countrys deep economic problems, according to Sherle Schwenninger, the director of the foundations Economic Growth Program. Its authors are Daniel Alpert, a managing partner of Westwood Capital; Robert Hockett, a professor of financial law at Cornell and a consultant to the New York Federal Reserve; and Nouriel Roubini, who is, well, Nouriel Roubini, whose consistently bearish views have been consistently right. It is scheduled to be released on Wednesday.

title: Olympic Protester Maintains Passion
description: More than 40 years after Tommie Smith and John Carlos ignited the sports world with their black-gloved fists raised on the victory stand at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics, Carlos says, I still feel the fire.

title: Democrats Try Wary Embrace of the Protests
description: WASHINGTON  Leading Democratic figures, including party fund-raisers and a top ally of President Obama, are embracing the spread of the anti-Wall Street protests in a clear sign that members of the Democratic establishment see the movement as a way to align disenchanted Americans with their party.

title: Robert M. Schaeberle, Nabisco Chief, Dies at 88
description: Robert M. Schaeberle, who led Nabisco through two mergers but retired as chairman and chief executive in 1986 as the company moved toward one of the biggest and most contentious leveraged buyouts in Wall Street history, died on Sept. 29 at an assisted living facility in Exeter, N.H. He was 88.

title: Lottery Numbers
Ex-Aide Said She Drew Cuomo, as Attorney General, Into Rain Forest Case
description: Two years ago, Andrew M. Cuomo, then New Yorks attorney general, unexpectedly jumped into a legal fight over an issue that had little to do with the state: damage to the Amazon rain forest from oil drilling.

title: Representing Himself, Under Threat of Electric Shock
description: NEWARK  It is to be a most curious trial: the defense lawyer has been ordered not to move beyond a few square feet in the courtroom. He is allowed to lean on the lectern, but if he steps in either direction he will be in trouble.

title: Just a Few Weeks Before Halloween, Weather Fitting for the Fourth of July
description: Toby Crane knew his window of opportunity was small.

title: Anti-Qaddafi Fighters Face Stiff Resistance in Surt
description: SURT, Libya  From the windows of an apartment overlooking this seaside town, a commander peered through binoculars and yelled orders into a walkie-talkie, directing fire at a white building in the distance flying Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis green flag.

title: Exonerated of Murder, a Boxer Makes a Debut at 52
description: PHILADELPHIA  The television crew had him up at dawn doing the Rocky fandango, dashing up the 72 stone steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art and dancing around in triumph like another over-the-hill, underdog pugilist who had made it big.

title: Peru Leader Ousts 30 Police Generals in Anti-Corruption Drive
description: President Ollanta Humala of Peru has dismissed two-thirds of the generals in the countrys national police force, the most forceful move yet in an anti-corruption drive he announced shortly after taking office in July.

title: A Metropolitan Opera High Note, as Donations Hit $182 Million
description: Velvet costumes evoked Tudor opulence at Donizettis Anna Bolena during last months opening night at the Metropolitan Opera. The red carpet was out; celebrities lent pop culture pizazz; and the audience had a genuine star, Anna Netrebko, to cheer for, which it did, lustily.

title: After Losing Ace, Cardinals Pieced Together a New Plan
description: MILWAUKEE

title: At One College, a Fight Over Required Drug Tests
description: Linn State Technical College in Linn, Mo., informed students this semester that they would be required to submit to a urine test that would be checked for illegal drugs as a condition of studying at the college. Almost immediately, the American Civil Liberties Union and other groups sued on behalf of several dissenting Linn State students and have won a temporary injunction. The A.C.L.U. says Linn State is the first public college in the country to require all adult students to submit to mandatory drug tests. Linn State officials however, say the policy is legal and was developed in the interest of their 1,200 students.

title: Late Patriots Drive Chips at the Jets Foundation
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It was an ideal situation for the Jets. In spite of themselves, they trailed New England by 6 points Sunday midway through the fourth quarter. The Patriots had the ball at their 22. The Jets had all three timeouts. All they needed was a stop, and an improbable victory seemed possible.

title: Tuesday: Sore All Over
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I have a cold. Im not sure why Im telling you this, except that I hope youll understand if there are mistakes, as Im currently typing this with my head on my desk. Seeing the entries FEVER and ACHY in the northern part of the grid made me want to nod and say, Yup, but nodding and saying Yup would be too painful, so youll just have to believe me when I say that theyre there. I need to conserve my energy for the rest of the post.

title: In Wave of Labor Unrest, Kuwait Customs Strike Halts Oil Shipments
description: Three thousand striking customs officers disrupted oil shipments from Kuwait on Monday, escalating the labor unrest that has been gaining momentum in recent weeks in the emirate.

title: N.B.A. Cancels First 2 Weeks of Play
description: The N.B.A. canceled the first two weeks of the season Monday night after another marathon bargaining session between league and union officials ended in frustration and despair.

title: Giants Struggle to Find the Running Game Theyve Become Known For
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Conceptually, the Giants still believe they are a dominant running team. They talk about running the ball. They scheme so they can run the ball. Establishing the run is something Coach Tom Coughlin has preached for years and is a significant element in the amorphous (yet often-invoked) notion of Giants football.

title: Big East Is Considering a Move to 12 Members in Football
description: Scurrying to revive a football conference dwindling in programs and in relevancy, the Big East said Monday that it was considering moving to a model that consisted of 12 football-playing universities.

title: Wall St. Banks Help Hedge Funds Recruit
description: Wall Street banks often boast that they hire the best and the brightest. Now, scrambling to bolster profits, they have become full-time headhunters for some of their biggest hedge fund clients, a role that is rife with potential conflicts.

title: Sanctions Pose Growing Threat to Syrias Assad
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian economy is buckling under the pressure of sanctions by the West and a continuing popular uprising, posing a growing challenge to President Bashar al-Assads government as the pain is felt deeply by nearly every layer of Syrian society.

title: Mayors Say U.S. Is Ignorant of Cities Needs
description: CHICAGO  Three big-city mayors who took part in a panel discussion Monday night criticized the federal government for not giving them the tools they need to help their cities thrive.

title: Remembering Al Davis
description: Thoughts of the Raiders' owner often lead to his penchant for swimming against the tide.

title: For Ukrainian Leader, Disparate Paths to Cross
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Every game of chicken has to end sometime.

title: Video: Remembering Al Davis
description: Thoughts of the Raiders owner often lead to his penchant for swimming against the tide, says William C. Rhoden.

title: Translating Reality: If He Goes, So Do You
description: The Mets have cleaned out their lockers and gone home, and given their third consecutive fourth-place finish and the need to cut payroll, its a fair bet that numerous players who finished the season with the team will not return next spring.

title: Iran: Airline Banned on Ticket System
description: The International Air Transport Association said Monday it had suspended Iran Air, the Iranian national airline, from the system for processing international ticket payments as a result of strengthened American economic sanctions against Iran. The suspension severely limits the ability of Iran Air to book passengers abroad. Irans civil aviation authority denounced the action as a violation of international rules. The airline association is not obliged to follow the U.S. embargo against Iran, said Farhad Parvaresh, the director of the Civil Aviation Organization of Iran.

title: China and Myanmar to Settle on Myitsone Dam
description: Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi of China and his counterpart from Myanmar, U Wunna Maung Lwin, agreed to properly settle matters after Myanmar suspended construction of the large Myitsone hydroelectric dam that was being financed and led by a state-controlled Chinese company, Chinas official Xinhua news agency said Monday. The report did not say whether China was demanding financial compensation for work done on the project before Myanmar backed out.

title: Numberplay: Turtles All The Way Down
description: Stephen Hawkings 1988 book A Brief History of Time begins with the following famous anecdote.

title: NYT Front Page for 10/11/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 10/11/2011

title: Iran: 14 New Arrests in Bank Scandal
description: Irans top prosecutor reported 14 new arrests on Monday in connection with a record $2.6 billion embezzlement uncovered last month at Bank Melli, the largest commercial bank in the country, and called on its fugitive managing director to return home from Canada, where he fled as the fraud was about to become public. The new arrests, coming atop 22 arrests already reported, were announced by Gholam Hossein Mohseni Ejei, the national prosecutor general, at a news conference in Tehran. He did not identify any of the suspects but according to Iranian state media accounts of the announcement, they include a number of bank managers.

title: Wine Country Internet Provider Takes On Justice Department
description: The Obama administration has found an unlikely adversary in wine country.

title: Wisconsin Democrats Start Drive to RecallGovernor
description: Democrats in Wisconsin made a long-mulled plan official on Monday night: next month, people will begin collecting signatures to recall Gov. Scott Walker, a Republican in his first year in office whose move to limit collective bargaining rights for public workers set off a political firestorm across the state.

title: Iraq: 19 Die Near Basra and in Baghdad
description: A land mine explosion on Monday in southern Iraq and attacks on security forces in Baghdad killed 19 people. In southern Iraq, near Basra, six soldiers were killed as they tried to clear land mines. Later in the day, an improvised bomb exploded near security forces in western Baghdad, killing 13 people, including 3 security officers who were responding to an earlier explosion. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but it appeared similar to others carried out by Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

title: Street Protests Continue to Spread
description: As the Occupy Wall Street protests spread from Lower Manhattan to Washington and other cities, leading Democratic figures ponder how closely to embrace the movement.

title: Markets End Mixed a Day After Rally
description: Stocks on Wall Street treaded water all day awaiting the outcome of a vote in Bratislava, where Slovakian lawmakers debated whether to back an expansion of the European bailout fund.

title: Corrections: October 11
description: NATIONAL

title: Riggleman to Interview With the Mets
description: The Mets will interview Jim Riggleman for their bench coach position this week to replace Ken Oberkfell.

title: Pujols Pounds Out His Frustration in Game 2
description: MILWAUKEE  Albert Pujols lingered in the batters box Monday night to watch the flight of a ball he had just lifted high into the air. He was savoring the moment, it seemed.

title: Big Data in the Dirt (and the Cloud)
description: Big data, the term for scanning loads of information for possibly profitable patterns, is a growing sector of corporate technology. Mostly people think in terms of online behavior, like mouse clicks, LinkedIn affiliations and Amazon shopping choices. But other big databases in the real world, lying around for years, are there to exploit.

title: Internet Censorship Growth Hampers News, Study Says
description: A detailed study of Internet censorship in China and Iran shows that blocking techniques are changing rapidly and are becoming significant new obstacles for news organizations, governments and businesses.

title: Robert Loughlin, Artist and Design Expert, Dies at 62
description: Robert Loughlin, an artist and quirky sage of Modernist design whose work as a picker and dealer in 20th-century furnishings influenced high-end interior decoration in the United States even though he chose to live in a trailer park, died on Sept. 27 in North Bergen, N.J. He was 62.

title: Word of the Day | unearthly
description: unearthly \n-rth-le\ adjective

title: Another Sexual Assault Is Reported in Brooklyn
description: A man crept up behind a woman in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, on Monday evening, groped her and then ran away, the police said.

title: He's 97 and Famous. Spare Some Change?
description: Professor Irwin Corey, whose comedy career spans more than 80 years, has spent the past 17 years panhandling near his expensive Midtown apartment, for money to donate to Cuban charities.

title: Tuesday Preview: Euro 2012 Places on the Line
description: Updated below with results.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
description: The 2G spectrum case continues to dominate headlines as the Central Bureau of Investigation on Monday booked former Telecom Minister and DMK leader Dayanidhi Maran and his brother, media baron Kalanithi Maran. (Hindustan Times). The bureau conducted simultaneous searches on their houses and offices. Mr. Maran is accused of receiving kickbacks from Malaysia-based company Maxis immediately after it acquired Aircell for $800 million (Times of India).

title: Living in Both, and Neither
description: At times I wonder, are we human beings or are we animals, asks Manik Mia, one subject in this article by Lydia Polgreen about the enclaves of Bangladeshis living within Indias borders.

title: Oct. 11, 1968 | First Manned Apollo Mission Lifts Off
description: On Oct. 11, 1968, Apollo 7 was launched from Cape Kennedy, Fla., with astronauts Wally Schirra, Donn Fulton Eisele and R. Walter Cunningham aboard, beginning an 11-day mission in Earth orbit. It was the first successful manned mission of the Apollo program.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 11, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the blog post, The PlayStation Breach: Why You Should Remain Calm.

title: News Quiz | Oct. 11, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Interacting on Sims Social
description: WHAT new game is gaining huge popularity on Facebook?With WHAT other Facebook games is this program competing?WHAT company created the game?WHAT games do you play online?

title: A Mentors Passion for Pictures and Social Justice
description: In the mid-1980s, after Id run through my small savings and dropped out of photography school, a friend invited me to a class at Empire State College taught by a guy named Mel.

title: Myanmar Frees Prominent Dissident; More Political Prisoners Expected to Follow
description: BANGKOK  Myanmar freed a prominent dissident on Wednesday at the start of what state media said would be the release of 6,300 prisoners in a general amnesty that was expected to include a number of political prisoners.

title: How Do You Personalize the Things Youre Required to Have at School?
description: According to this article, middle school students across the country are creating elaborately decorated lockers featuring items like $25 mini chandeliers and motion-sensor-equipped lamps. Is this an innocent trend that simply allows students to create an individualized space at school, or does it make students who cant afford decorations feel inferior? How do you personalize the things you bring to, or have at, school  whether a locker, uniform, backpack, binder, or desk?

title: Harbaugh and How the 49ers Were Built
description: From 1983 to 1998, the San Francisco 49ers won at least 10 games each season. They made the playoffs 15 times in those 16 years, and again earned playoff berths in 2001 and 2002.

title: The Early Word: Alliances
description: Todays Times

title: Inside the Cain Tax Plan
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book The Benefit and the Burden.

title: Forza 4 Doubles Down on Cars, Graphics and Clarkson
description: For gamers playing Forza 4, the new racing simulator game released Tuesday for the Xbox 360 console, every day is a track day.

title: Director Lynch Turns Attention to Paris Night Club
description: If theres something familiar about the brand-new Silencio, a subterranean club in Paris (142 rue Montmartre; www.silencio-club.com), it may be because you are a fan of the director David Lynch. A cross between Studio 54 and a 20th-century Parisian salon, the club takes its name from Mr. Lynchs 2001 film Mulholland Drive  but thats not where the connection ends. He also helped design it.

title: Armchair Ethicist, Voter Edition
description: Between 1 and 5 p.m. E.S.T. today, October 11, you can discuss the following letter with the Ethicist, Ariel Kaminer. Post your comments below, and check back later to see what the Ethicist has to say.

title: Former Ukraine Premier Is Jailed for 7 Years
description: KIEV, Ukraine  From the moment President Viktor F. Yanukovich took office last year, a central question was whether he would lead Ukraine west, toward Europe, or into a tight symbiosis with the countrys Soviet-era masters in Moscow.

title: A Familiar Figure Begs on the Street, but Not for Himself
description: He is a familiar sight, the old man who solicits change from drivers stopped at a red light on East 35th Street in Midtown Manhattan every day near Third Avenue.

title: The Shortfalls of Early Cancer Detection
description: The outcry among many physicians and patients over a government panels recent announcement that healthy men should no longer receive P.S.A. blood testing to detect prostate cancer is rooted in a long and impassioned history among cancer screening advocates that early detection must always save lives. But as science has taught us, thats not always the case.

title: What Happened Next
description: In my last post I imagined an exchange between myself and two tiny visitors. Three weeks without a sale, an extremely unusual event, had forced me to take a hard look at the numbers and explore what to do next.

title: Congress: The Week Ahead
description: After a bit of unpleasantness on the Senate floor last week, members are expected to come together Tuesday to pass a bill to impose tariffs on some Chinese goods to punish Beijing for keeping its currency artificially depressed. The bill has a slim chance of ever being taken up in the House, where Democrats are pushing Republicans to consider the measure.

title: Qatar Bets on Hobbled European Banks
description: Qatari investors are on the hunt for deals across Europe after agreeing to buy the private bank operations of the troubled European firms Dexia and KBC Group.

title: Five Things to Watch For in the G.O.P. Debate
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mitt Romney enters the Republican presidential debate on Tuesday as the likeliest target of questions and criticism from rivals eager to slow the building sense of momentum behind his campaign.

title: On Our Radar: A New Fracking Frontier
description: The debate over horizontal hydraulic fracturing spreads to North Carolina, where geologists have identified deposits of natural gas along a 150-mile trench where the states coastal plain meets the Piedmont. [Associated Press]

title: In His Voice, There Is Peace
description: The death of velvet-voiced singer Jagjit Singh, widely credited for reviving the popularity of classical Hindustani love songs in Urdu, known as ghazals, spurred an outpouring of tributes and emotion from fans and musicians on Tuesday.

title: A Word With: Ryan Adams Returns With New Album After Hiatus
description: Its been two and half years since Ryan Adams announced he was quitting his band, the Cardinals, and taking a break from music because he had Mnires disease, a debilitating inner-ear disorder that affects hearing and balance.

title: Number Trouble
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Number Trouble
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Wild Horses and Hard Choices
description: My first wild horse sighting came when a coworker and I, navigating a barely visible dirt road in our big Forest Service truck this summer, had just reached the crest of a ridge on our way to survey a remote wilderness area in eastern Nevada.

title: New York May Lose 10,000 Wall St. Jobs, Report Says
description: 8:09 p.m. | Updated

title: The Frustrations of Coaching Wayne Rooney
description: LONDON

title: Strike Adds to Problems at Indian Auto Plant
description: MUMBAI, India  A strike at the biggest Indian car company, Maruti Suzuki, idled one of its four major production plants for the fifth consecutive day on Tuesday. The dispute pits the aspirations of manufacturing workers against the economic realities of a national labor glut.

title: App Smart Extra: Starry, Starry Night
description: Last weeks App Smart column identified a few great apps for tracking meteor showers.

title: Dollar Thrifty Takes Itself Off the Market
description: The Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group said on Tuesday that neither Hertz Global Holdings nor anyone else had submitted a buyout offer that met its conditions by a Monday deadline, and the company said it was no longer pursuing a sale.

title: Nobel Laureate Faces Soccer Star in Liberian Election
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Liberians lined up in the rain Tuesday to choose between a petite but tough Nobel Peace Prize laureate and a hulking former soccer star in this battered countrys second presidential election since the end of a bloody civil war.

title: As Greece Avoids a Default, Recapitalization Plans Emerge for European Banks
description: BRUSSELS  Far-reaching efforts to strengthen European banks began to take shape Tuesday just as Greece cleared a major hurdle that would allow it to avoid a disorderly default on its debt.

title: Accel in Brazilian E-Commerce Investment
description: CAMPINAS, Brazil  Accel Partners has invested in elo7, a Brazilian online handicrafts marketplace.

title: Trailer: Eames
description: A trailer for the documentary Eames: The Architect and the Painter, in theaters Nov. 18.

title: The N.B.A.s Money Games
description: The New York Knickerbockers are about to enjoy one the best starts to a new season that they have had in a decade. Thats because there wont be a start to the new season.

title: A Nude Awakening
description: Theres something very sexy-cool about a glossy, nude lip. It says, Im hot, but I didnt try too hard, and it works for almost everyone. (And for almost every designer, judging by how many copped the bare-lip look for their resort and spring shows.) Its also super-low-maintenance. You dont have to be concerned that your color will bleed, says Lisa Houghton, who did the makeup on the previous page. The only caveat: you need a well-prepped pucker. Houghton exfoliated our models lips by dabbing on a bit of Elizabeth Arden Eight Hour Cream and rubbing it off with a tissue. Then she applied a mixture of Ardens Crystal Clear Lip Gloss and a touch of High Shine Lip Gloss in Tropicoral for the right pinkish tone.

title: 99 Cents Only Chain in $1.6 Billion Buyout
description: The low-cost retailer 99 Cents Only Stores agreed on Tuesday to sell itself to a group of investors that includes its founding family for $1.6 billion in cash, ending a months-long sales process.

title: Slovakia Rejects Euro Bailout
description: WARSAW  Europes efforts to stem the sovereign debt crisis suffered an embarrassing and potentially costly setback on Tuesday night when Slovakias Parliament failed to approve the expansion of the euro rescue fund, a development that brought down the government.

title: Textile Makers Fight to Be Heard on South Korea Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON  There are still a few textile mills in the Carolina Piedmont, making futuristic fabrics that cover soldiers helmets and the roofs of commercial buildings.

title: Brad Pitt, Zombies and Weapons: A Mystery in Hungary
description: If Hungary ever finds itself the target of an undead invasion, its police force should now be well supplied to defend the nation. Law enforcement officers there have seized dozens of weapons, including pistols, rifles and machine guns, amid conflicting reports about whether they were to be used in the filming of World War Z, a zombie movie starring Brad Pitt, Matthew Fox and Mireille Enos, produced by Mr. Pitts company, Plan B Entertainment.

title: Hand Raised High, a Stutterer Struggles to be Heard in Class
description: I hope readers of The Choice will take a moment today to read my colleague Richard Perez-Penas nuanced account of Phillip Garber Jr.s efforts to get his professor at County College of Morris in New Jersey to call on him in class.

title: What Were Reading
description: Fresh Off the Boat: Eddie Huang says Andy Ricker of Pok Pok, in Portland, Ore., will be taking over the original BaoHaus in a few weeks to serve up his famous Thai-style chicken wings. Mr. Ricker won Best Chef Northwest at the James Beard Awards this year.  Nick Fox

title: Intellectual Styles Of The Rich And Clueless
description: Oh, my. Jeff Immelt, who President Obama for some reason appointed to head his job creation panel, insists that whats good for GE is good for America:

title: Twitter Trolls Haunt Discussions of Bahrain Online
description: That bit of advice about Bahrain, delivered to Twitter followers of a conference of Arab bloggers in Tunisia last week, highlights an often aggressive effort on social media to cajole, harass and intimidate commentators and journalists who write about the protests in Bahrain and the governments response.

title: Edible Selby | Pie Squared
description: Melissa and Emily Elsen, two sisters from South Dakota, opened Four & Twenty Blackbirds, their pie and coffee shop in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn, with the expectation that they would serve about 10 pies a day. A little over a year later, they are averaging more like 50 pies a day, with customers traveling from around New York City to sample their fresh, seasonal fillings, like blueberry rhubarb or strawberry balsamic. Though they are doing a brisk business, the sisters Elsen continue to make their crust from scratch, two pounds at a time. We love the homespun, hands-on intensity of it, Emily says. When you make a good pie crust, its really gratifying. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Inside Martha Marcy May Marlene
description: In Anatomy of a Scene, the writer and director Sean Durkin discusses Martha Marcy May Marlene.

title: Stocks, Flows, and Fuzzy Math
description: I read David Brooks citing the Tax Foundation this morning, and I thought he must have misread them. They couldnt possibly have compared one years take from higher taxes on the rich with the total stock of debt, could they? They cant possibly be that stupid, or think that their readers are that stupid, can they?

title: Investor Says Momentum Builds for Breakup of Research in Motion
description: The call is growing louder for Research in Motion to explore a sale of all or part of the company.

title: Palin Takes Crony Capitalism Fight to South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  On her first trip to South Korea, former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska sounded just like a politician on the campaign stump on Tuesday, lashing out at her pet enemy: crony capitalism.

title: Wise Words On Europe
description: Kash Mansori has a very good piece on the eurozone crisis, making some points Ive also tried to hit. Basically, he sees the peripheral countries mainly as victims of an overwhelming tide of cheap money from the core, who are now suffering whiplash when that inflow came to a sudden stop:

title: Now Showing | Ryan Roche
description: A film showcases Ryan Roches latest collection.

title: A Top Egyptian Minister Quits in Protest Over Killings
description: CAIRO  Egypts finance minister resigned Tuesday in protest over the killing of two dozen unarmed Coptic Christian protesters by the security forces, as reverberations from the outburst of violence two days ago continued to shake Egypts interim government.

title: Young and Unawed by Woodss Shadow
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.

title: Metro Pucks: Report Cards, Awards and Analysis
description: The Rangers did not win a game. The Islanders and Devils did, but not after enduring the embarrassment of getting shut out before capacity crowds at their home openers. What was learned from the first six games of the season for the Rangers, Devils and Islanders? Not much in the 82-game big picture. But for the faithful who couldnt wait for the second weekend in October, hockey provides plenty to analyze.

title: Sony Unveils a Camera for Speed Demons
description: It seems like camera makers are bragging less about how many megapixels are on their sensors  which is nearly useless as a measure of quality anyway  but are taking up a new selling point: speed.

title: Chevrolet Confirms Colorado Pickup and Camaro ZL1 Convertible
description: WARREN, Mich.  During a media event marking Chevrolets 100th anniversary, held at the General Motors Design Center here, G.M. announced that a new version of the Chevrolet Colorado midsize pickup truck would be offered to American buyers. The automaker also unveiled a convertible model of its ultra high-performance Camaro ZL1.

title: Notes From the Underground | Kimann Foxman
description: It was a curious scene, walking up lower Broadway in broad daylight and hearing the heavy beats pumping from a window above. A freight elevator ride and hefty door charge later, youd never guess it was midafternoon, as a few hundred people crowded an empty loft space and danced to music played by an all-star roster of D.J.s. The nine-hour event was in celebration of the 12th anniversary of Tim Sweeneys weekly radio show Beats in Space, which has been broadcast every Tuesday night on WNYU (89.1) since 1999. The lineup included Rub N Tug, Kimann Foxman (of Hercules and Love Affair fame, pictured here), Matthew Dear and Sweeney himself.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Martha Marcy May Marlene
description: Cults, paranoia and a breakdown of trust are among the central topics explored in the psychological drama Martha Marcy May Marlene, written and directed by Sean Durkin. The film, which plays this week at the New York Film Festival before opening in theaters on Oct. 21, follows one young woman (Elizabeth Olsen) after she has escaped from a cult and has gone to stay with her sister (Sarah Paulson) and her sisters husband. In this video, Mr. Durkin narrates a scene from the film that illustrates the haziness of Marthas psychological state after her escape.

title: Regulators Advance Volcker Rule
description: Federal regulators on Tuesday took a much-anticipated step toward reining in risky trading on Wall Street, introducing a proposal that would prohibit federally insured banks from making certain types of bets with their own money.

title: Detroit Gets Its Motor Running
description: Its hard not to root for Detroit. The city, that is. It has been dealt a pretty brutal hand by recent history, enduring the crippling combination of economic freefall, Canadian winters and Matt Millen. And no matter what you think of the place, gosh, nobody deserves Matt Millen.

title: An Olsen Sister Finds a Spotlight All Her Own
description: ON a rainy afternoon last month, Elizabeth Olsen apologized profusely for pushing back by more than an hour a luncheon interview at a restaurant in the Gramercy Park neighborhood of Manhattan. Im so sorry, she said. I really hate being late.

title: Latino Players Find Home on the Prairie
description: More than 1,500 miles from his home campus in Altus, Okla., a junior-college baseball coach might have seemed out of place recently at a rundown diamond in Brooklyn. But that is how he likes it.

title: Preserving Memories of Pets, and Then Some
description: Amy Finkel lives in an apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, that does not allow pets. But she does have a groundhog (Chompers), an armadillo (Fleischesser) and a boar (Angel). They are all, however, dead and stuffed  and in the case of the boar, it is just the head.

title: A Passion for Pictures, and for Social Justice
description: Mel Rosenthal, a photojournalist and teacher with a passion for social justice and the South Bronx neighborhood where he grew up, is retiring from Empire State College after 36 years. Our colleagues on Lens are giving him a sendoff including a slide show of his work and a Q. and A. about how he earned the trust of his subjects. I was walking down street one day, some gang members saw me, Mr. Rosenthal recalls. They said, What the hell you doing here? One lifted up his pants. He had two Berettas strapped to his ankles. I said, Do you really need two guns?  Read more on Lens

title: Treatment of Trauma to Brain Is Studied
description: Techniques being used to treat psychological lapses from traumatic brain injuries, the signature wounds suffered by troops in Iraq and Afghanistan, appear to be helpful, but lack rigorous scientific support, a government-appointed panel reported Tuesday after completing the most comprehensive analysis of the evidence to date.

title: Raine Group Ramps Up
description: The Raine Group, an investment boutique focused on the media and entertainment industries, said Tuesday that it had made a major hire and closed on its first private equity fund.

title: Presidents Jobs Measure Is Turned Back in Key Senate Test
description: WASHINGTON  In a major setback for President Obama, the Senate on Tuesday blocked consideration of his $447 billion jobs bill, forcing the White House and Congressional Democrats to scramble to salvage parts of the plan, the centerpiece of Mr. Obamas push to revive a listless economy.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.11
description: The day in sports included world championships for fencing in Italy and for artistic gymnastics in Tokyo.

title: Why Im Not In Zuccotti Park
description: Some readers have been asking me to go make a speech at one of the OWS demonstrations. If you think about it, however, youll see why I cant.

title: Weber on the Web
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Hockey Heroes
description: Hockey Heroes, a short film made for the web by Bruce Weber, features Sidney Crosby and Alexander Ovechkin.

title: Ban Hybrids From the Fast Lane, and Everyone Slows Down
description: Last spring I wrote about the indignation of hybrid car owners in California who were about to lose their rights to drive in the carpool lane. The state lawmakers who approved the July 1 cutoff seemed to take the position that virtue was its own reward.

title: Magical Days on Panamoti Island
description: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Wall St. Banks Help Hedge Funds Recruit | In an effort to secure lucrative brokerage and trading business, big banks like Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America have become powerful recruiting forces for their biggest hedge fund clients. The banks are scouting finance executives, accountants and receptionists for free. Goldman calls the practice talent introduction.

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company in London
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 15th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from London.

title: Another Potential Transatlantic Suitor Emerges
description: Two bidders for Transatlantic Holdings have already walked away, but another potential suitor may yet make an offer for the reinsurance company.

title: Banning Sexy Ads Near Schools
description: It will never happen here, but oh, how I wish it would. Over at The Gloss, Jessica Pauline Ogilvie reports that Britain is banning outdoor overtly sexual ads within 100 meters of a school, and ridiculously sexual, over-the-top, basically porn ads wont be allowed on billboards at all.

title: The Big-Band Theory
description: When Preston Miller rst picked up a tuba, he knew he had found his instrument. Its big, its loud and its fun, he says. So is the marching band at Allen High School, the largest in the country.

title: Excerpt: 'Last Man Standing'
description: Tim Allen is a put-upon father in his new sitcom on ABC.

title: Video, a New Tool for the Police, Poses New Legal Issues, Too
description: When a man was fatally shot by a police officer on a street in Oakland, Calif., late last month, the shooting was captured by a video camera.

title: Excerpt: How to Be a Gentleman
description: The new CBS sitcom updates the Odd Couple.

title: Wasteland of Mutants and Thugs
description: This is a tale of exhilaration and crushing disappointment, of awe and anger. This is my story of Rage, the simultaneously inspiring and infuriating new game from id Software.

title: Online Game Challenges You to Live On $1,000 A Month
description: Could you live on $1,000 a month? An online game called Spent lets you see what its like to make the tough choices necessary to get by on that amount of income.

title: Worsening Attitudes
description: Americans have given their economy a vote of no confidence. Or at least, very little confidence.

title: The Republican Scramble, Continued
description: The comment stream in response to my Monday column  Is the Tea Party Over?  was divided for the most part into one camp of readers proclaiming the inevitable triumph of the Tea Party, and another, larger camp praying for its demise. Theres no point quarreling with faith (in the first case) or hope (in the second). To my mind the question is whether the Tea Party will transform itself from a backlash  the Party of Against  into a force that can make things happen. The movements best hope of making that leap any time soon, which you can view with approval or alarm, is Rick Perry.

title: News Corp. Filing Rebuts Criticism of Board
description: News Corporation went on the defensive Tuesday morning after an investor advisory firm urged shareholders to vote against reinstating several key members of the media giants board of directors, including the chairman and chief executive, Rupert Murdoch, and his son James Murdoch.

title: Some Pregame Comments: U.S. vs. Ecuador
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The United States mens national team plays Ecuador in an international friendly at Red Bull Arena on Tuesday night in the fifth game of the Jurgen Klinsmann era. Though additional matches for the rest of the year have not been announced, it is expected that the U.S. will play in Europe next month.

title: Less Is More | Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby
description: In the last several months, the British designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby of BarberOsgerby have once gain proven their impressive versatility. Theyve produced an inexpensive, wildly practical plastic chair for Vitra and directed a group of students from the ECAL in Lausanne, Switzerland, to create a playfully luxe group of objects based on a traditional Baccarat goblet. And theyve been on fire  pardon the pun  since they were named in June as the designers of the 2012 Olympic torch, a sleek, triangular form with 8,000 perforated circles that represent each of the people who will carry the torches. (Yes, 8,000 torches  one for each torchbearer  will be produced.) But their latest effort is not about design in the expected sense.

title: No Major Zombie Injuries After Accident on Film Shoot
description: Its apparently a bad week to be producing a motion picture about the living dead. After what may or may not have been a weapons raid on the Brad Pitt zombie movie, World War Z, a platform collapse in Canada on the set of the latest installment in the Resident Evil series has resulted in injuries to 16 actors portraying zombies, The Associated Press reported.

title: Seattle Superhero Arrested in Pepper-Spraying Episode
description: Maybe now hell go by Pepper Man.

title: A Marathon Runner Delivers a Baby
description: Amber Miller, a veteran marathon runner, did not have much time to celebrate after finishing the Chicago Marathon on Sunday: She had a baby to deliver.

title: Christie Endorses Romney Ahead of Debate
description: 3:34 p.m. | Updated  LEBANON, N.H.  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey endorsed Mitt Romneys bid for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday afternoon by praising his business and government experience, declaring, Mitt Romney is the man we need to lead America.

title: Bachmann Releases Her Economic Plan
description: It doesnt have the catchiness of Herman Cains 9-9-9 plan. It is more succinct than Mitt Romneys 59-point proposal.

title: In Supercomputing, a Turn to Energy-Saving Graphics Chips
description: In computing, as in so many fields, the best path to progress is often not a straight line.

title: Tax S.U.V.'s?
description: Matt Welch, left, of Reason and Robert Frank of Cornell University debate taxing owners of sport utility vehicles.

title: A Dark Lyricist Turns to Tales For Children
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Can you trust Colin Meloy with your children?

title: Wheelies: The High-Occupancy Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Tappan Zee Bridge Project Gets Fast-Tracked
description: Updated: A fuller version of this article can be found here.

title: A.I.G. Is Now Worried About Bad P.R.  for Policyholders
description: Insurance providers are constantly coming up with new products to sell to policyholders. But the American International Group has hit upon one of the more unusual new services weve heard of in some time: reputation insurance.

title: Language Lessons From Babies
description: In todays 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass writes about new science of bilingualism and how scientists are teasing out the earliest differences between brains exposed to one language and brains exposed to two.

title: Cue the Kitsch: Soderbergh to Make Liberace Film Starring Douglas and Damon for HBO
description: You spend enough years in Las Vegas and eventually its kitschy charm leaves an indelible mark on you. Having made three movies about Danny Ocean and his Rat Pack-like team of casino-heist experts, as well as critically acclaimed films like Traffic, Erin Brockovich and Sex, Lies and Videotape, Steven Soderbergh has turned to the only subject that was left for him: a biographical movie about Liberace.

title: Playing From the Crib to the Console
description: Video game use is exploding among the youngest among us, according to a new survey.

title: Should a Stutterer Speak in Class?
description: Philip Garber Jr. is 16 and taking two college classes. He is thoughtful, engaged and eager to contribute to class discussion  a dream student in many respects. But because his stutter is extreme, it takes him far longer than other students to ask a question or make a comment. So, as Richard Prez-Pea writes in todays New York Times, his history teacher has asked him not to.

title: Dreams of a McCain Presidency
description: The most interesting part of Ezra Kleins lengthy what went wrong assessment of the Obama administrations economic policy is the way it raises the possibility that a John McCain presidency might have delivered a more effective response to the Great Recession. With McCain in the White House and a Democratic majority in Congress, Klein implies, we might have had a smaller, better-targeted stimulus package (perhaps more like the one that Alice Rivlin recommended) joined to a more robust intervention in the housing market (like the one McCains campaign proposed in the autumn of 2008). Jonathan Chait takes this idea and uses it to make a broader argument that a McCain presidency would have forestalled the popular backlash against deficit-financed stimulus:

title: Israel and Hamas Agree to Swap Prisoners for Soldier
description: JERUSALEM  Israel and Hamas announced an agreement on Tuesday to exchange more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners for an Israeli soldier held captive in Gaza for five years, a deal brokered by Egypt that seemed likely to shake up Middle East politics at a time when the region is immersed in turmoil.

title: Obama Pushes Jobs Plan as Senate Prepares to Vote
description: PITTSBURGH  President Obama continued the drumbeat for his jobs plan on Tuesday, even as White House officials acknowledged that the bills prospects in the Senate were tenuous and Mr. Obama himself vowed not to wait for Congress to advance ideas to get American back to work.

title: The Avante-Garde Arrives in Montclair, at Adara
description: Does Montclair, N.J., hunger for a restaurant whose mission statement promises to explore the relationship between food, art and technology?

title: Prostatectomy  - series
Stanford Teams With City College (Think Engineering School)
description: In the chess match to determine which university will get a chance to build a graduate school of applied sciences on public land in New York City, Stanford is trying what might be called a C.C.N.Y. stratagem.

title: Brightness Rises | Patrick Coxs Third Act
description: Patrick Coxs Wannabe loafer, a design-y take on the traditional schoolboy shoe, was a smash hit in the early 90s  almost a million pairs were sold every year. I was just a kid in England doing this thing that became gigantic and global, says Cox, who was 31 at the time. Stores opened in London, then Paris and New York, and the chunky, heeled shoes all flew out the door. Then came what Cox now calls his Second Album Syndrome. Wannabe was so huge, he remembers. So big. So unexpected. What could he possibly do to top it? Though the company chugged along for a few years, Cox eventually sold it in 2007. Faced with a noncompete clause, he traveled for a bit and eventually opened a bakery calledCox Cookies and Cake  on the naughty side of Soho in London, selling baked goods that cheekily made references to the peep shows and X-rated video stores that flanked his storefront.

title: Reviewing Per Se
description: More photos of Thomas Kellers four-star restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Missouri to Play in the Big 12 Next Season, and Then Decide
description: The future of Missouris athletic program remains the biggest mystery in college sports, though a conference call Tuesday morning provided some clarity. The Big 12s interim commissioner, Chuck Neinas, said Missouri would play in the league for the 2012-13 season, giving the university time to decide whether to stay in the league or attempt to join the Southeastern Conference.

title: The Coast of Utopia
description: A look at the dwellings of Cabo Polonio, a remote beach village in southeastern Uruguay.

title: CNBC Expands Two Programs and Cancels Two Others
description: The business news channel CNBC is rearranging two of its market hours by canceling two programs and expanding two others in their place.

title: Wheres the Beach? Under the Seaweed.
description: AN invasion of seaweed that is extraordinary in volume and geographic scope has been besieging the eastern Caribbean since June, sending resorts and government agencies from Anguilla in the north to Tobago in the south scrambling to rid beaches of the smelly, brown, bug-attracting algae before the impending high season.

title: Director of Avatar, Titanic Promotes Innovation
description: 3:50 p.m. | Updated The death last week of Steven P. Jobs led some to wonder about the future of innovation in the United States. They need not worry, according to James Cameron, the film director whose movies like Avatar and Titanic have a gee-whiz element that is underpinned by science.

title: DealBook: Momentum Builds for Breakup of RIM
description: The call is growing louder for Research in Motion to explore a sale of all or part of the company.

title: For Cruz, a Bit of History
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. His Phillies homerism is no longer an issue.

title: Video Shows Protesters Arrested in Boston and Washington
description: The police in Boston arrested more than 100 people early Tuesday morning following a march tied to a national protest movement that began on Wall Street in New York.

title: James Woolery of JPMorgan Surveys the M.&A. Scene
description: Earlier this year, James C. Woolery left one of the plum legal jobs in the world, as a partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, to become the co-head of North America mergers and acquisitions alongside Chris Ventresca at JPMorgan Chase.

title: A Glacial Ice Bar in Patagonia
description: The first ice bar in Patagonia, Argentina, opened last week just outside the town of El Calafate. GlacioBar, billed as the only bar in the world made out of glacial ice, is the latest addition to Glaciarium, a new science museum dedicated to the regions hundreds of glaciers.

title: Why Believe In Keynesian Models?
description: A correspondent asks a good question: what evidence makes me believe that Keynesian economics is broadly right, given the relative absence of experience with large fiscal stimulus programs?

title: Iranians Accused of a Plot to Kill Saudis U.S. Envoy
description: WASHINGTON  The United States on Tuesday accused Iranian officials of plotting to murder Saudi Arabias ambassador to the United States in a bizarre scheme involving an Iranian-American used-car salesman who believed he was hiring assassins from a Mexican drug cartel for $1.5 million.

description: LONDON  Rupert Murdochs former chief lieutenant, Les Hinton, will appear before Parliament to answer further questions on the News of the World phone hacking scandal, lawmakers said Tuesday.

description: A slide show depicting an intestinal obstruction in a child.

description: A slide show depicting an intestinal obstruction repair.

title: Criminal Complaint in Alleged Iran-Backed Assassination Plot
description: The Justice Department released a criminal complaint against two men with alleged ties to the Iranian government in a suspected plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to the United States and bomb the Saudi and Israeli Embassies in Washington.

title: Gate Worldwide Agency Absorbs Carrafiello-Diehl
description: A well-known advertising agency in the Northeast, Carrafiello-Diehl & Associates, is closing and its remaining accounts and employees are being absorbed by an agency named the Gate Worldwide.

title: Bone Fracture Repair
description: A slide show depicting the repair of fractured bones.

title: Council Debate on School Layoffs Grows Heated
description: At an often heated hearing before the City Council on Tuesday, Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott defended the administrations decision to lay off 672 school support workers last week and said that officials had warned of the layoffs in June. City Council members  some of whom argued that counting the citys share of unemployment-benefit and food-stamp costs, the savings from the layoffs would be insignificant  were unconvinced that they were necessary. Read more on SchoolBook

title: Arizona Gets 2015 Super Bowl

title: Next Years Rotation Is on Girardis Mind

title: N.B.A. Players Use Twitter Carefully
description: With the N.B.A. lockout growing nastier, players having a vehicle to unload their thoughts directly to fans is potentially an image disaster. Even before the Twitter age, it was only a matter of time until a player said something that instantly made all players look ridiculous and out of touch  think Patrick Ewings Sure, we make a lot of money, but we spend a lot, too comment that became the eye-roller of the 1999 lockout. Now, that danger is only 140 characters away.

title: The Bilingual Baby Brain
description: Babies raised in bilingual or non-English-speaking households in largely English-speaking territory think differently. Perri Klass has a fascinating article  in todays New York Times on exactly how differently: they take longer to distinguish phonetic sounds in either language, but then hear them in both; they retain an interest in other languages longer; and as their languages develop, so do strong multitasking and problem-solving skills.

title: Joseph Cedar Discusses Footnote
description: In his latest film Footnote, the writer and director Joseph Cedar uses Hebrew philology and Talmudic scholarship to weave together a dramatic mystery. Concerning a father and son who are rival professors at a university, the movie looks at how a scholar can devote his life to a single topic of study. When he wrote about it at Telluride, A. O. Scott said the film blends academic satire, classic Jewish humor and an almost Shakespearean sense of the tragic potential of the paternal bond. Footnote is screening at the New York Film Festival this week and in this video, Mr. Cedar discusses elements of the film and some of the research he did to put it together.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite increased efforts to destroy fields of opium poppies and wean Afghan farmers off the countrys biggest cash crop, poppy cultivation in Afghanistan rose in 2011 and spread into areas once declared poppy free, according to a United Nations survey released Tuesday.

title: Response of the Police Is Expanding With Protests
description: DENVER  Whatever the original impulse behind Occupy Wall Street, or the speculation of what the movement might become, this much is true: The groups of protesters, now camping or hanging out in many American cities, and the police agencies that have responsibility for public safety and order, are both shifting into new postures of action and response.
