title: Raymond Geuss
description: A historical perspective on philosophy by Raymond Geuss, a professor of philosophy at the University of Cambridge.

title: Blind Faith That Is Shaken Under a Revival Tent
description: It was after midnight at the dawn of the 1960s. Donna Johnson was 3, her brother 1, her father gone. Her mother had sold everything  knickknacks, flatware, all of her slacks  to join a traveling caravan of evangelists led by the preacher Brother David Terrell. Holding tent revivals in a new town every few weeks, they were essentially carnies, but instead of hawking funnel cakes, they were selling God.

title: Motherwell Painting Declared a Forgery
description: A forged Robert Motherwell painting was branded with the equivalent of a scarlet letter on Tuesday in a legal settlement involving three art galleries and the Dedalus Foundation, which owns the copyrights to Motherwells works. Spanish Elegy, the painting at the center of the dispute, was sold to a European gallery, Killala Fine Art, for $650,000 in 2007 by Julian Weissman, who had previously worked as a salesman at Knoedler & Company in Manhattan. Before the sale Dedalus initially concluded that Spanish Elegy was authentic, but later backtracked and declared the work, supposedly painted by Motherwell in 1953, to be a fake. The Killala gallery said in its lawsuit that it had relied on the foundations assurance in making the purchase. Mr. Weissman was accused of acquiring the painting from Glafira Rosales, a dealer on Long Island, and of hiding its provenance, according to court papers. As part of the settlement, Ms. Rosales and her gallery will pick up most of the cost of reimbursing Killala for the price of the painting and Dedalus for its expenses. Mr. Weissman will pay the remaining portion. The foundation marked the back of Spanish Elegy (above) with a stamp in capital letters and indelible ink that says Dedalus has determined that this painting is not an authentic work by Robert Motherwell but a forgery.

title: Romney Readies for Health Care Attacks at Debate
description: HANOVER, N.H.  If theres one thing that Mitt Romney is bracing for at Tuesday nights debate, it is an assault on his health care record as governor of Massachusetts.

title: Baritone in Don Giovanni Taken to Hospital
description: Mariusz Kwiecien, the Polish baritone who was cast in the title role of the Metropolitan Operas new production of Don Giovanni, which opens on Thursday night, underwent surgery for a herniated disk on Tuesday, his manager said. The doctors feel that Mariuszs prognosis is excellent, said the manager, William Guerri, of Columbia Artists Management. But it was unclear when he might return to the stage. Its a wait-and-see proposition, Mr. Guerri said. Mr. Kwiecien felt pain during the opening scene of Mondays dress rehearsal, the manager said. He was taken by paramedics to a hospital, said the Met spokesman, Peter Clark. The Met tapped Peter Mattei, who was on hand for a production of Rossinis Barbiere di Siviglia, to replace Mr. Kwiecien for the opening of Don Giovanni. The opera has 16 more performances into March, although Mr. Kwiecien was scheduled to be in the cast only through Nov. 11.

title: Samurai Shopper | The Wages of Skin
description: Ouch. My face hurts. I know, its killing you too  oldest joke in the book. But its no joke: one occupational hazard of testing skin-care products is overdosing on irritants. Chemicals can get under your skin, and even natural substances  essential oils, for example  can wreak havoc: lavenders aroma can be therapeutic and calming, but dont ply your face with lavender oil. Ditto minty or citrusy oils and anything acidic, unless buried in a gentle formula. Hypoallergenics can also be problematic. Many contain potential endocrine disrupters and other nasty components. Besides, allergies are as varied as fingerprints; theres no one-size-fits-all solution to irritated skin.

title: U.S. Says Man Admitted Plot to Blow Up Passenger Jet
description: DETROIT  Even before the plane had landed, a badly burned Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab was admitting to a fellow passenger that, yes, he had just been trying to ignite an explosive device, a prosecutor said Tuesday as Mr. Abdulmutallabs trial on charges of trying to blow up a plane in 2009 began.

title: A Gypsy Love Story, Now With a Happy Ending
description: Presentations of live, high-definition ballet in movie theaters worldwide, keeping abreast with those of opera and theater, have become a trend in the last year or so. Just now, however, only one ballet company is making the most of them: the Bolshoi in Moscow. During the 2010-11 season it screened performances of Don Quixote, Copplia and Swan Lake; in the 2011-12 season it is presenting six more, starting last Sunday with Esmeralda.

title: Justin Vernon, the Good Boyfriend
description: Among the surprising revelations in Jon Caramanicas magazine profile of Justin Vernon (the man behind the band Bon Iver) in June  like the existence of a tattoo of the state of Wisconsin on his collarbone  was Vernons relationship with the songwriter Kathleen Edwards. According to Vernon, Edwards helped keep him sane, and he, in return, was helping produce her latest record. Vernon, as you would expect, said nice things about his girlfriend: I would always try to write songs like her, he told Caramanica. I was never that good.

title: A Closer Look at the Haqqani Anniversary Attack on American-Afghan Outposts
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE ORGUN-E, Afghanistan  Last Friday, on the 10th anniversary of the start of the Afghan war, at least several dozen fighters from the Haqqani insurgent network launched a complex attack against multiple American-Afghan outposts near the Pakistan border.

title: Electronic Master and Pupil
description: The electronic music producer Deadmau5 performed at Roseland Ballroom last week and his protg, Skrillex performed at Starland in Sayreville, N.J.

title: Electronic Music That Plays to the Senses, Both Sound and Sight
description: Most of the time, it might not matter what Skrillex is doing with his hands. Every time the bass dropped during his outrageous, frenetic, head-and-body-abusing set at the Starland Ballroom in Sayreville, N. J., on Sunday night, it rendered most other input moot. The bass was a warhead, landing with a boom, sticking around with a wobble.

title: From Bemidji State to Flyers Rookie
description: NEWARK  Before the Flyers played in New Jersey on Saturday, a few of Matt Reads teammates gave him some advice in the visiting team locker room.

title: Plenty Bakery Opens on Upper East Side
description: Plenty is a new bakery, but its a throwback to a time when places with homey cakes and pastries tempted many neighborhoods. The owner, Jessica Weiss, pictured, speaks lovingly about the crumb cake, rugelach and such that her father and grandmother baked. She grew up baking on Long Island, in the Five Towns, but until recently ran and owned a tutoring company for standardized tests. She did some catering jobs before opening Plenty, which has a few tables and also serves soups, salads and sandwiches. Gradually, the inventory will expand with black-and-white cookies and more layer cakes.

title: Sea Salt Harvested From the Surf Off Amagansett
description: Many weekend mornings find Steven Judelson, above, wearing waders and splashing into the surf off the beaches of Amagansett to haul five-gallon buckets of water from the sea. Then he and his wife, Natalie, evaporate it to make sea salt with a Hamptons pedigree. The Judelsons, two well-traveled lawyers who are passionate about food, had seen sea salts from around the world in markets and thought, Why not out here?

title: Microwave Popcorn Minus the Chemicals
description: Kristy and Coulter Lewis were dissatisfied with the ingredients and additives in microwave popcorn. Quinn Popcorn, named for their baby son, uses organic ingredients and a simple food-grade parchment paper bag instead of a pouch treated with compounds like perfluoro-octanoic and metals to keep the bag from absorbing grease and increase the amount of corn that pops. You add Quinn Popcorns oil and seasoning mixture after the corn is popped, so grease-proofing the bag is not an issue. And if a few kernels may be duds, what pops is delicious.

title: Patent Ductus Arteriosis (PDA)

title: Netanyahu Statement on Shalit Deal
description: Below is the complete text of remarks made by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday, at the start of an emergency cabinet meeting to discuss a prisoner exchange agreement with Hamas. The agreement would secure the release of a single captive Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit, and more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners.

title: An Abundant Menu at Occupy Wall Street
description: Living on the streets of New York can no doubt be uncomfortable, unsanitary and lacking in privacy. But for the Occupy Wall Street protesters, food is not an issue, reports Jeff Gordinier for the Dining Section.

title: Hip Joint Replacement

title: For Three Teenagers, Easing Lifes Struggles Through Poetry
description: On paper, To Be Heard may sound like the kind of production thats better at raising awareness than at holding anyones interest. In a straightforward vrit style, it tracks the intertwining trajectories of three underprivileged New York City teenagers whose lives are transformed by their participation in a pedagogically progressive slam-poetry program at University Heights High School in the Bronx. There are inspirational triumphs and painful setbacks, and, yes, the students read their poems in sincerely unguarded performances.

title: Deep Lakes, Icy Climate, Great Wine
description: PENN YAN, N.Y.

title: The Good Life Comes a Little Harder in the Finger Lakes
description: The Finger Lakes in west-central New York State fits very few of the preconceptions many people have about wine regions. Forget about the glitz and conspicuous consumption associated with Napa Valley, or even the bucolic wealth and gracious living emblematic of what Robert Mondavi used to call the good life.

description: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

title: TimesCast | Former Ukraine Leader Jailed
description: October 11, 2011 - Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former Ukrainian prime minister, is sentenced to seven years in prison.

title: Challenging an Unhealthy Focus on Weight and Aesthetics
description: Darryl Robertss scattered documentary America the Beautiful 2 treads similar territory as his America the Beautiful from 2008. (Was it really that big a hit?) Among its deserving concerns are the punishing demands for weight loss in the modeling profession, the dire toll of plastic surgery and anorexia, and other manifestations of how the prevailing aesthetic abuses women (and, it suggests, men). A persistent refrain is its view of the body mass index as an insidiously excessive criterion for health.

title: Love in the Time of Stonewall
description: In 1979, George Segal, the famous Pop artist, was commissioned to create a sculpture to commemorate New York Citys Stonewall uprising in 1969  the seminal (although not the only) event to kick-start the gay liberation movement. The bronze sculpture, covered with a white patina, was finally unveiled in Christopher Park in Greenwich Village in 1992, after years of controversy. It depicts a life-size male couple standing a few feet away from another life-size female couple sitting on a park bench. Beth Suskin, my partner of 35 years, and I, Leslie Cohen, were the models for this sculpture. This is our love story.

title: Two New Shows on Oprah Winfrey Network
description: Oprah Winfreys 10-month-old cable channel had a reset of sorts on Monday with the introduction of The Rosie Show, a 7 p.m. talk show by Rosie ODonnell, and Oprahs Lifeclass, a remix of old episodes of The Oprah Winfrey Show, at 8 p.m.

title: Stanford Researcher Finds Lots of Leaky Web Sites
description: The Web is porous. Remarkable information trickles in from everywhere. It also sometimes spills out without its users knowing exactly where or how.

title: Cardinals Freese Has His Turn in the Spotlight
description: ST. LOUIS  David Freese, who hit his third home run of the postseason Monday night in Milwaukee, has been something of a revelation for those outside St. Louis, his hometown, who may not have heard of him before his recent outburst.

title: A War Not for Abolition
description: One Saturday in late September 1861, Manhattan witnessed a scene that was becoming commonplace in countless New England towns and cities: well over 1,000 soldiers marched through the city, in the words of one observer, Singing reverently and enthusiastically in praise of John Brown! Abolitionism was hardly a universal idea, but the name on everyones lips was that of its most fiery, violent advocate. No military hero of the present war, the New York Independent noted, has thus been honored.

title: Who You Gonna Bet On, October 2011
description: Sorry, but if I am not for myself, who will be for me? For readers new to this, back in 2010 Business Week ran a story contrasting my pessimistic views with the bullish outlook of hedgie John Paulson, and making it clear that only a fool would believe the views of some bearded professor.

title: New Protesters Bring New Agendas
description: The groups of protesters inspired by Occupy Wall Street are shifting into new postures and responses.

And when a crowd of eager guests showed up at the Park Avenue doorstep of the billionaire industrialist David H. Koch, instead of being greeted with open arms they were met by three stern men in suits, sunglasses and polished shoes.

title: Senate Jabs China Over Its Currency

Where they cannot find alignment is on how best to address that problem, while maintaining Americas relationship with its biggest lender and a major trading partner.

description: WASHINGTON  Five health and environmental groups sued the Obama administration on Tuesday over its rejection of a proposed stricter new standard for ozone pollution, saying the decision was driven by politics and ignored public health concerns.

title: After Five Games, Jets Part Ways With Mason

description: A former director of a publicly traded energy company was sentenced on Tuesday but avoided prison after pleading guilty to tipping off his son that the energy company was a takeover target.

title: Qaddafi Forces Give Ground in Surt
description: SURT, Libya  Through boulevards and narrow streets, fighters allied with Libyas transitional government pushed boldly into a residential district here on Tuesday, capturing Qaddafi loyalists, war loot and territory as the battle moved from the citys edges to its center.

title: A Face-Off in a State With a History of Contrarian Votes
description: The location of Tuesday nights Republican debate is favorable turf for Mitt Romney: New Hampshire, where he owns a home and has led in every poll of Republican voters  in the most recent one, by a 32-point margin.

title: Thailand: Bangkok Is Warned of Flood Danger Next Week
description: The worst floods in more than 50 years threaten to overwhelm barriers protecting Bangkok, and residents should be prepared for the danger, said Deputy Prime Minister Kittiratt Na-Ranong, who called it a crisis. Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has urged officials to complete work on three flood barriers and five more canals to drain water from the capital before high tides peak on Monday. Officials are also shoring up flood walls, preparing evacuation plans and readying medical supplies, city officials said.

title: Israels West Bank General Warns Against Radicals

title: Bill Would Overhaul No Child Left Behind

Historically, the route to fixing broken systems goes through struggle, confrontation and even revolution.

title: Uganda: Parliament Votes to Halt New Oil Ventures
description: Parliament voted in an emergency session on Tuesday to halt development of Ugandas nascent oil sector. The session was called on Monday to debate the potentially lucrative industry, in which foreign contracts have been kept secret and allegations of corruption are rampant. The session continued on Tuesday with members of Parliament accusing officials close to President Yoweri Museveni of accepting millions of dollars in bribes. Lawmakers also called for a delay in the imminent signing of an agreement between the government and three oil companies, and suspended new ventures until a national oil policy could be put in place. The vote comes at a time when commodity prices have skyrocketed and dissent is spreading. Large reserves were discovered in 2006 that could turn Uganda into a major oil industry player in Africa.

title: What Parkinsons Teaches Us About the Brain
description: Scientific discoveries can be serendipitous, and so it was when Jay L. Alberts, then a Parkinsons disease researcher at Emory University in Atlanta, mounted a tandem bike with Cathy Frazier, a Parkinsons patient. The two were riding the 2003 RAGBRAI bicycle tour across Iowa, hoping to raise awareness of the neurodegenerative disease and show people with Parkinsons that you dont have to sit back and let the disease take over your life, Dr. Alberts said.

title: A Vatican Secret For Columbus Day
description: In a post-Dan Brown world the mere mention of the Secret Vatican Archives conjures up nefarious mystery and intrigue. In fact, the Secret in the archives name refers to the private nature of the thousands of documents that line more than 50 miles of shelves in a two-story bunker beneath the Vatican Museums. Many of the documents have unique historical importance, like the 1493 papal bull granting to Spain lands recently discovered by Christopher Columbus. The document, known as the Inter Caetera bull, is well known to scholars but perhaps less so to the general public, which will be able to peruse a fragment online at luxinarcana.org on Wednesday, the day denoting Columbuss arrival in the Americas in 1492. It is one of 100 documents that will go on a rare public viewing at the Capitoline Museum in Rome in February as part of an exhibition celebrating the 400th anniversary of the foundation of the archives. Drafted by Pope Alexander VI, the papal bull not only granted Spain certain rights in the newly discovered lands but also called for the evangelization of the indigenous people there. It is part of the history of the colonization of the Americas that gave rise to a series of problems whose consequences would be felt over time, said Luca Carboni, secretary general of the archives.

Mr. Singh, whose reputation for rectitude has been tarnished by a string of scandals, has been struggling to regain some ground on Mr. Hazare, who has gone on the offensive against Congress in a key by-election. The children, he explains, havent seen their 8-year-old sister, Kajal, since April 21, 2010.

description: BRUSSELS  European banks need to raise more capital to protect themselves against losses on sovereign debt or politicians will do it for them, the European Union said on Wednesday.

title: Cellphones Are Servers and Servers Are Cellphones
description: SAN DIEGO  The marriage of computing and cellphone technology is about to get a lot more interesting, with phones acting more like computer servers in a data center, and computers looking more like phones.

title: Venn In The Course Of Economic Events
description: Mike Konczal has been having useful fun with Venn diagrams lately. Heres his explanation of various approaches to dealing with an economy in which large parts of the private sector are engaged in forced deleveraging:

title: Current Affair
description: Known for electric facials that make A-list clients look as if theyve had face-lifts, Melanie Simon uses her magic machines (and Circ-Cell, her product line) to coax youth from even the most stubborn complexions. Go to circcell.com.

title: MDC Looks Abroad for Acquisition
description: MDC Partners, the agency holding company known for its acquisitive ways, is making its first deal involving a public relations agency outside of North America.

title: U.S. Tax Evasion Case Touches Julius Baer
description: PARIS  A tax evasion investigation in the United States has reached Julius Baer, a spokesman for the Swiss lender confirmed Wednesday, a day after the government charged two advisers with conspiring to help clients evade United States taxes on more than $600 million hidden in offshore accounts.

title: S. Korean State Visit Highlights Bond Between 2 Leaders
description: WASHINGTON  During the state visit of South Koreas president, Lee Myung-bak, which began on Wednesday, he will be feted at a White House state dinner, invited to speak to a joint session of Congress, and treated to a road trip to Detroit with President Obama, where the two leaders plan to tour a General Motors factory together.

title: Iran Sees Plot Accusation as Diversion From Wall Street Protests
description: A day after the Justice Department accused Iranian agents of plotting an elaborate international scheme to assassinate a Saudi Arabian diplomat on American soil, the government of Iran appeared to coalesce around at least one explanation for the news: Occupy Wall Street.

title: Wednesday Reading: More Evidence Against Vitamin Use
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Liz Claiborne Sells Portfolio of Brands
description: Liz Claiborne continues to clean out its closet of brands.

title: Giving: The Pratham Gala
description: Pratham, the Mumbai-based nonprofit which helps educate underprivileged children in India, raised $1.1 million at its annual tri-state gala last week at the Pierre Hotel in New York City. The evening began with cocktails, and the 400 guests who paid $500 or more for a single ticket noshed on snacks like bhelpuri and dhokla.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: A Postcard on Amazon Forest Trends
description: 2:32 p.m. | Updated I received an e-mail last week from a publicist at Fleishman-Hillard, forwarding news that Brazils Ministry of Environment had announced the lowest Amazon deforestation rates for the month of August since precise monitoring began in 2004. The core line:

title: Shares Are Bolstered by News From Europe
description: Wall Street closed higher on Wednesday, after a new plan was unveiled to recapitalize European banks and a deal was struck in Slovakia that is expected to permit the creation of a larger, more powerful euro zone bailout fund.

title: Accessories as Art
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: BlackBerrys Service Hiccups Spread; Five Continents Affected
description: Research in Motion said Wednesday that after three days it was still trying to restore service for BlackBerry customers spanning five continents.

title: Former Saudi Ambassador on Alleged Plot
description: Former Saudi Ambassador to the United States Prince Turki bin Faisal Al Saud reacts to the alleged Iranian-backed plot against its embassy in the United States.

title: Another Chance for a Pitching Duel
description: All too often in the postseason the overly hyped pitching matchups end up failing to deliver on their promise. With the National League championship series tied at one game each, it will be another chance for an epic battle of team aces as Yovani Gallardo of the Brewers faces off against Chris Carpenter of the Cardinals.

title: Feeling Ageless Under Water
description: At 59, I dont feel particularly old, but sometimes my joints do. Old injuries to both knees have turned into arthritis, and a ruptured ligament and long-gone cartilage have left me a bit wobbly. Bursitis in my hips and bone spurs in my feet dont help much.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Guardian: From the archives, the newspapers original (and scathing) review of French Country Cooking by Elizabeth David, published in 1951 and still a living, breathing classic.  Julia Moskin

title: Chevrolet to Sell Purely Electric Spark Hatchback in U.S.
description: General Motors introduced the 2012 Chevrolet Spark subcompact four-door hatchback in Detroit on Wednesday. The news was swiftly upstaged, however, by the subsequent announcement that a purely electric version would be available to American customers in limited quantities in 2013.

title: Prada and Schiaparelli at the Met
description: Elsa Schiaparelli may share a birthday with Karl Lagerfeld (Sept. 10), but Miuccia Prada is unquestionably her sister in soul. Putting these two nimble minds together makes sense, and not simply because both are educated Italian women who enjoy a good fashion joke. The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced today that the spring 2012 exhibit at the Costume Institute will be Elsa Schiaparelli and Miuccia Prada: On Fashion. It will open May 10 and run through Aug. 19, with the gala on May 7.

title: Data Reveals Wide Variation in Dental Fees
description: Consumers could save significant money on dental care by simply shopping around and asking about prices in their own communities, an analysis of health claims data shows.

title: Tigers Ignore the Pain
description: Something far more notable happened Tuesday night in Detroit than simply a playoff baseball game. Sure, the Tigers 5-2 victory over the Rangers in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series was riveting enough, even if all you did was contemplate the personal expansion of the Tigers Miguel Cabrera  dude, Little Caesars Pizza doesnt need another mascot  and what on earth the Rangers Colby Lewis was thinking by throwing the ball anywhere near Cabreras bat in the fifth inning.

title: London Dispatch | Maltby Street Market
description: Borough Market has long held sway as an essential stop on the London food tour. But in the wake of disagreement over increasing rents and trading loyalties, some of Boroughs headlining purveyors left in search of new digs, setting up shop further east in and around the Victorian railway arches of Maltby, Stanworth and Druid Streets. A few years ago, Borough traders used these arches mainly for storage. But when the Monmouth Coffee Company started selling straight from its Maltby Street production site, word spread and a trickle of curious visitors began to arrive. Other vendors, encouraged, followed suit with their own stalls and the buzz got louder.

title: U.S. Coach Doesnt Play the Superstar Card
description: Harrison, N.J.

title: Would-Be Plane Bomber Pleads Guilty, Ending Trial
description: DETROIT  The trial of a man accused of trying to blow up a commercial airliner with a bomb sewed into his underwear ended Wednesday, just a day after it had begun, when Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, the accused, abruptly announced that he would plead guilty to all of the federal counts against him.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.12
description: The day in sports included surfing in France and the artistic gymnastics world championships in Tokyo.

title: Egyptian Generals Plead for Understanding After Death of Coptic Protesters
description: CAIRO  Under mounting criticism at home and abroad over clashes with troops that killed two dozen Coptic Christians on Sunday, Egypts military rulers issued an extraordinary plea for sympathy on Wednesday, urging Egyptians to understand that soldiers in riot gear and armored trucks had been terrified of an angry crowd of demonstrators.

title: Ultrasound
description: A slide show explains ultrasounds.

title: Ear Surgery
description: A slide show explaining a surgery to move disproportionately large or prominent ears closer to the head.

title: Tracking the Debris From Japans Tsunami
description: Just over six months have passed since a huge tsunami slammed into northeastern Japan, killing thousands of people and wrecking towns and villages along the coast.

title: Not Just Another Bear Story
description: I didnt hit her. She started it. Thats not my mess. Young children are bad  pathetically, often annoyingly, occasionally heartbreakingly  at making excuses. Most of them are terrible liars. Its sometimes even funny.

title: Complete Blood Count
description: A slide show explaining complete blood count.

title: Animal Bite - First Aid
description: A slide show depicting the first aid procedure to treat an animal bite.

title: Meckel's Diverticulectomy
description: A slide show depicting a surgery to remove an abnormal pouch (Meckel''s diverticulum) in the wall of the small intestine.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (0), Ecuador (1)
description: HARRISON, N.J.  While its defense looked sturdy against a quality team, the United States did not build on Saturdays promising offensive display against Honduras. In fact, you could argue that Tuesday nights game against Ecuador represented a step in the wrong direction  a step away from the opponents goal.

title: Sunset Park Man Is Arrested in Groping Attack
description: A Sunset Park man was arrested early Wednesday in a sexual attack on a young woman. The episode was the latest in a series of attacks that have alarmed Brooklyn communities from Park Slope to Bay Ridge since March.

title: Where in the World Should Seth Go?
description: My next trip is shaping up to be a doozy. Ill be heading to ____________, one of a handful of cities Ive always wanted to explore. And boy, does it have a fascinating world of ____________ to check out. Because Im always looking for bargain accommodations, Ill be staying at a ____________. As usual, I wont be taking taxis: transport will be exclusively by ____________. And though I usually shun shopping on my travels, this time Ill be looking for the perfect memento to bring home, the best____________ I can find in town.

title: U.S. Challenged to Explain Accusations of Iran Plot in the Face of Skepticism
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Wednesday sought to reconcile what it said was solid evidence of an Iranian plot to murder Saudi Arabias ambassador to the United States with a wave of puzzlement and skepticism from some foreign leaders and outside experts.

title: The Perfume Project
description: Sensorium, a nerdy, interactive exhibit devoted to perfume, has arrived in the meatpacking district. Open till Nov. 27, its sponsored by both Firmenich, a fragrance house, and Sephora (the $15 entry fee can be redeemed for a Sephora gift certificate). Explaining the project, Allison Slater, the vice president for retail marketing at Sephora, said: People arent as interested in fragrance, and sales are down. Our sales arent as bad as others, but still.

title: Loud and Clear
description: new NYTD.embeddedSlideshowBuilder(NYTD.options);

title: Caregivings Hidden Benefits
description: Could there be measurable benefits to your health, and to your brain in particular, from being a caregiver?

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

title: Fine-Tuning Your Flight Search
description: LAST month, Google introduced the first version of its new flight search feature (Google.com/flights) and the response has mostly focused on what it does not offer. Right now, it can search only for round-trip tickets for select domestic destinations. And while it is much faster than other travel search engines, it does not display fares from all the airlines that serve a particular route.

title: Dow Jones European Executive Resigns
description: 9:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Between the Lines, Wall St. Banks Face a Deficit of Trust
description: By almost any measure, Morgan Stanley is fine.

title: Mary Ellen Mark and the Robots
description: In a new column, Lynn Yaeger peeks at peoples terrifically odd, amusing and magnificent collections, starting with the robot menagerie of the photographer Mary Ellen Mark. Their batteries have probably all melted. Im a bad robot mom, Ms. Mark said, looking with wry affection at the crowd of robots  pink fembots in frilly aprons! Mean metal guys with clock bellies!  that have taken up residence in her downtown loft, a place that has been her studio since almost before SoHo was SoHo. Read more (and view photos) on T Magazines Moment blog.

title: U.S. Accuses Virginia Man of Espionage at Syria Protests
description: Updated  | A revised version of this post can be found here.

title: Have a Question for N.F.L. Reporter Judy Battista?
description: Are the Buffalo Bills really that good? (And what about the 49ers?) Are the Indianapolis Colts really that bad? Can Tim Tebow succeed as the starting quarterback in Denver? What will the Raiders be like without owner Al Davis? Will Los Angeles get an N.F.L. team any time soon? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The New York Times, will answer questions from readers of The Fifth Down. Send in your questions and answers will appear on the blog on Friday.

title: For Each U.S. Job Opening, 4.6 Unemployed
description: There were 4.6 unemployed workers for every job opening in the United States in August, according to new data from the Labor Department.

title: Putting Down the iPad So My Kids Can See Me Read
description: In the name of encouraging my kids to read, Ive dumped my iPads Kindle app.

title: S.E.C. Advances Volcker Rule
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission became the latest agency on Wednesday to support an initial version of the so-called Volcker Rule, a new regulation aimed at curtailing risky trading on Wall Street.

title: At City Ballet, a Need for Surprises
description: More than any other ballet company in the world, New York City Ballet has the marriage of music and dance written into its constitution. Elsewhere you may find dancing thats just as musical, perhaps even more so. (Among the worlds troupes today, the Royal Ballet in London at its best is probably the most musically responsive.) But only at City Ballet is the heart of the repertory about dance making music register in space. As the companys Balanchine Black & White Week in May demonstrated, its founder-choreographer, George Balanchine, was often prepared to strip everything else away until musicality was virtually all that remained.

title: Groundbreaking Set for New Arts Center in Brooklyn
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday will break ground for a renovation of the 1918 Strand Theater in Brooklyns BAM Cultural District, to be shared by BRIC Arts/Media House, a multidisciplinary arts and media complex, and the UrbanGlass reNEWal Project, a center dedicated to artistic glass.

title: Finalists Named for National Book Awards
description: For the second year in a row books about war and foreign locales enchanted the judges of the National Book Awards, whose finalists were announced on Wednesday.

title: Frank Fires Back at Gingrich
description: Representative Barney Frank will not go quietly.

title: Disruption on the Path to Transformation
description: Tom Friedman has posted a column that considers two views of world events  one seeing a great disruption, the other an exciting transformation. He ends the piece, not with a conclusion, but by asking readers which narrative they believe. (Theres more on the thinkers behind these views below.)

title: City Council in Harrisburg Files Petition of Bankruptcy
description: The City Council of Harrisburg, Pennsylvanias financially troubled capital, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday, a surprise move that was immediately opposed by the mayor and Gov. Tom Corbett, who argued that the filing was illegal under state law.

title: In Nimby Sentiments, a Gender Divide
description: A consulting firm that conducts an annual poll on public attitudes toward development has come up with a new twist on Nimbyism: women are far more likely than men to fight proposals to build new power plants, shopping malls and big-box stores.

title: Cadillacs Cue: Tap, Drag, Scroll, Speak (and Drive, Too)
description: Screen-swiping, pinching to contract, tapping an icon  these actions, popularized on smartphones, have become so ingrained in our mobile societys muscle memory that Cadillac has decided to build its new infotainment system around them.

title: Cleared of Murder, Sheehan Reports to Jail on Gun Conviction
description: The Queens woman who shot her husband 11 times but was acquitted of murder was taken into custody Wednesday to await sentencing on a weapons possession charge.

title: HBO Orders Third Season of Boardwalk Empire
description: The saga of organized crime in America didnt end in 1921, and Boardwalk Empire wont conclude then, either. On Wednesday, HBO announced it had renewed Boardwalk Empire, its period drama about mobsters, corrupt public officials and one particularly short-tempered federal agent in Prohibition-era Atlantic City, for a third season. The series, which is created by Terence Winter (a producer of The Sopranos) and adapted from Nelson Johnsons book of the same title, was nominated for 18 Emmy Awards in its debut season, including nods for dramatic series and for the lead actor, Steve Buscemi, who plays the bootlegger and political powerbroker Nucky Thompson; among the eight Emmys it picked up was an award for the direction of its pilot episode, handled by Martin Scorsese, an up-and-comer we think youre going to be hearing a lot about. Boardwalk Empire is believed to be one of the costliest series that HBO has produced, with a reported budget of $18 million for its pilot episode alone.

title: A Red-Letter Day, and a Party to Match
description: LAKE HAVASU CITY, Ariz.  When Arizona executes prisoners, it uses lethal injection  not drawing and quartering, hanging or beheading, all of which have fallen out of favor since they were used with some regularity in Europe centuries back.

title: Too Much Moneyball: The Story of the New York Yankees
description: Have you seen Moneyball, the inspiring, based-on-a-true-story film of how the Oakland As, despite a meager payroll, managed to compete with baseballs richest teams?

title: Rain Returns, but Will Victor Martinez?
description: DETROIT  A misty rain was falling at Comerica Park three hours before the scheduled first pitch of Game 4 of the American League Championship Series, but Tigers Manager Jim Leyland had more pressing matters on his mind.

title: Think Pink
description: October is National Breast Cancer Awareness month, and thousands of designers, retailers and businesses are participating in this years effort to support the cause by offering exclusive items in the movements signature color  pink! From Tumis iPad case to Ann Taylors diamond pendant necklace and the New York Giants enthusiastic pink sneakers and gloves, heres how fashion is helping to find a cure.

title: Fewer Births in a Bad Economy
description: American birth rates have fallen noticeably in the last few years, a trend that seems to be tied to the poor economy, according to a new analysis from the Pew Research Center.

title: Students React to SAT Cheating Scandal
description: Over at SchoolBook today, students from Stuyvesant High School have weighed in on the frequency of cheating on the SAT, inspired by the recent local scandal surrounding a young man who sat for the test under others identities.

title: Deep Thinking About the Future of Food
description: Trying to tap into the best thinking about the future of global agriculture, as I have tried to do in my work as a reporter, can be an exercise in frustration. Many groups and many bright people go at the problem, but not many of them go at it in a holistic way.

title: A Company Grows, and Builds a Plant Back in the U.S.A.
description: Today, Taphandles employs 33 people at its headquarters in Seattle and about 450 at the Chinese factory that produces the beer-marketing products it sells to breweries. But its owner, Paul Fichter, who founded the company in 1999 and anticipates $11 million in revenue this year, expects that ratio to change. Mr. Fichter, 40, just signed a lease on a 41,800-square-foot factory in Woodinville, Wash., and began manufacturing some of his products there last month.

title: Congress Ends 5-Year Standoff on Trade Deals in Rare Accord
description: WASHINGTON  Congress passed three long-awaited free trade agreements on Wednesday, ending a political standoff that has stretched across two presidencies. The move offered a rare moment of bipartisan accord at a time when Republicans and Democrats are bitterly divided over the role that government ought to play in reviving the sputtering economy.

title: Scientists Solve Puzzle of Black Deaths DNA
description: After the Black Death reached London in 1348, about 2,400 people were buried in East Smithfield, near the Tower of London, in a cemetery that had been prepared for the plagues arrival. From the teeth of four of those victims, researchers have now reconstructed the full DNA of a microbe that within five years felled one-third to one-half of the population of Western Europe.

title: Did the Government Do Something Right?
description: Weve just published a small-business conversation with Paul Fichter, a manufacturer who is bringing some of his work back from China. Mr. Fichters company, Taphandles, makes beer-marketing products. He recently signed a lease to start manufacturing some of those products in Woodinville, Wash., where he expects to employ 150 workers by 2015. Mr. Fichters decision comports with a trend noted in a Boston Consulting Group analysis released last week that found that manufacturing outsourced to China has begun to return to the United States as the economic advantages have started to shift.

title: Franklin Kameny, Gay Rights Pioneer, Dies at 86
description: Franklin E. Kameny, who transformed his 1957 arrest as a sexual pervert and his subsequent firing from the Army Map Service into a powerful animating spark of the gay civil rights movement, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 86.

title: Study Points to Heavy-Handed Repression of Tibetan Area in China
description: BEIJING  The rise in anti-Chinese tensions and protests in a restive Tibetan region of Sichuan Province, including a startling wave of monk self-immolations, has taken place in the aftermath of sharp increases in the security budget for the area, which indicates the conflict is partly a result of heavy-handed tactics by the local security forces, according to an assessment by Human Rights Watch.

title: Occupy Wall Street Occupies Headlines
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. Splashed across the front page of the local newspaper here on Tuesday was a 24-year-old Occupy protester named Keith Cuesta.

title: In Playoffs, Depth Does Not Take a Holiday
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. His Phillies homerism is no longer an issue.

title: Whos on First? Met Opera Announces Changes After Injury to Don Giovanni Star
description: The Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday gave an update on who will fill in for Mariusz Kwiecien in the title role of Don Giovanni. Mr. Kwiecien had to withdraw because of a back injury that led to surgery. Peter Mattei, who is replacing him on opening night on Thursday, will also step in for the performances of Oct. 17 and Oct. 22. Substitutes for Oct. 25 and Oct. 29 were not announced.

title: More Wireless Devices Than People
description: SAN DIEGO  Watching all those people juggling phones and tablets and e-readers in stores, subways and coffee shops, not to mention the many small shops continually offering new models of phones, you could think that there are more wireless devices than people.

title: Caught in a Wide Web, a Trader Faces Prison
description: Last Friday, on a crystalline autumn afternoon, Michael A. Kimelman sat in the backyard of his home in Larchmont, N.Y. His toddler son was perched on his lap, sucking on a pacifier. His older boy played baseball with a friend, while his wife and daughter gawked at 10 egg-producing hens housed in their new chicken coop.

title: Romney the Inexorable
description: I spent last nights Republican debate trying to imagine scenarios where Mitt Romney loses the G.O.P. nomination for president. Rick Perry gets bitten by a radioactive Lincoln-Douglas debate champion and develops a sudden facility for public argument? A long-lost codicil to the Constitution is discovered, in which the Founding Fathers endorse the 9-9-9 tax plan? Utah renames itself the Republic of Deseret and secedes from the Union, forcing Romney to make a tragic choice between his religion and his country? Or, perhaps most unlikely of all  Jon Huntsman is embraced by the Tea Party and pulls off a surprise upset in Iowa?

title: Corporations, People and Truth
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: Israeli-Hamas Agreement to Trade Prisoners May Reshape Politics in Region
description: JERUSALEM  The prisoner exchange between Hamas and Israel that is expected to begin next week could reshape regional relationships, strengthening Egypt, Hamas and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel while posing an acute challenge to the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank.

title: Arrest Is Made in Hacking of Celebrities Private E-Mail
description: LOS ANGELES  A Florida man was arrested Wednesday and charged with breaking into and commandeering the e-mail accounts of at least 50 celebrities  including the actresses Scarlett Johansson and Mila Kunis and the pop singer Christina Aguilera  to steal photographs, financial data and personal correspondence, the F.B.I. said.

title: On Our Radar: Charges in New Zealand Oil Spill
description: The container ship that struck a reef off the coast of New Zealand a week ago and is still spilling oil into the sea seems to be at risk of breaking apart, officials say. The captain has been arrested and charged with operating a vessel in a manner causing unnecessary danger or risk. [ABC News]

title: Want to Know About That Mushroom? Just Ask
description: Oct. 17: Please note: we are no longer accepting photos for this feature. Too many mushrooms already! Thanks to those who sent in the 300 or so pix we have received.

title: New Team, Older Curse
description: For sheer futility in professional sports, the Chicago Cubs are the standard. They have not won the World Series in 103 years. They have not won a pennant since 1945. Their history is pocked with excruciating near misses  a billy goat, a black cat, fateful errors on the field and in the stands.

title: A Disappearing Underwater World
description: Mark Hay, a biology professor at Georgia Tech, writes from Fiji, where he is investigating coral-seaweed competition in the coral reefs.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Myanmar, Bhutan and Washington.

title: Ohio Senator Asks NASA to Wrest Shuttle From Intrepid Museum
description: The tussle on Capitol Hill over the space shuttle Enterprise continued on Tuesday with a senator from Ohio demanding that NASA rescind its award to New York City.

title: Slovakia Deal Revives Hope on Fund to Save Euro
description: BRUSSELS  The day after Parliament in tiny Slovakia voted to reject the expansion of a European rescue fund, causing the government to fall and threatening efforts to end Europes debt crisis, politicians there struck a deal that should permit the expansion of a rescue fund for the euro after all.

title: New Book Coming From Author of Henrietta Lacks
description: Rebecca Skloot, the veterinary technician-turned-author whose nonfiction book The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks has not budged from the paperback best-seller list in 30 weeks, will write a new book focusing on the bonds between people and animals, her publisher said on Wednesday. The new book, currently untitled, will be released by Crown Publishers, part of Random House.

title: 3 Years After Triple Crown Bid, Trainer Is Given a 10-Year Ban
description: New York authorities on Wednesday revoked the license of Richard Dutrow Jr., the trainer of the 2008 Kentucky Derby winner, Big Brown, barring him from state racetracks for 10 years and potentially ending the career of one of thoroughbred racings more controversial and successful horsemen.

title: Universal Delays On-Demand Test Plan
description: 9:27 p.m. | Updated

title: Adenoid Removal
description: A slide show explaining adenoid removal.

title: Partial Knee Replacement
description: A slide show depicting a partial knee replacement.

title: A Path Toward Sustaining a Cultivated Planet
description: Justin Gillis has posted a very helpful new piece on the Green blog that builds on efforts Ive made here to get beyond the eternal food fight. Below you can read the key passage in which Gillis discusses Solutions for a Cultivated Planet, a new Nature paper from Jonathan Foley of the University of Minnesota and many co-authors. The core themes in the paper are echoed in a TEDx talk Foley gave last year:

title: The Look of Karen Os Psycho Rock Opera
description: The costume, hair and makeup tell the story just as much as the music and choreography do, Karen O explained days before tonights opening of her much-anticipated psycho-opera, Stop the Virgens. The symbolic evolution of what happens to the characters is witnessed through their physical transformations.

title: Hiatal Hernia Repair
description: A slide show depicting the repair of a hiatal hernia.

title: Radial Keratotomy for Myopia
description: A slide show explaining radial keratotomy, a corrective surgery to treat nearsightedness, or myopia.

title: Divisions Grow on Federal Reserves Policy Committee
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserves policy-making committee is increasingly divided between advocates for stronger steps to bolster the economy and dissenters who see little benefit and considerable risk in such efforts, according to minutes of the committees most recent meeting.

title: Discover Cardholders Can Pay With Points at Amazon
description: 5:15 p.m. | Updated To note that Discover cardholders automatically earn as much as 1 percent cash back because some cardholders earn less than 1 percent.

title: Oil Executive Promotes Shale Gas to Europeans
description: LONDON  A senior executive from Exxon Mobil warned Wednesday that Europe could miss a chance to reduce its dependence on imported energy by making it too difficult to develop shale gas and so-called unconventional resources.

title: His Photos Are Proof: Hes With the Band
description: The photographer Bob Gruen was so deeply embedded with rock bands that he was considered a virtual member.

title: His Photos Are Proof: Hes With the Band
description: ONE afternoon in June 1975, John Lennon got lost in the mammoth Westbeth artists complex in Manhattan, looking for Bob Gruens photo studio and apartment, after partying all weekend with Harry Nilsson.

description: A slide show depicting the repair of an inguinal hernia.

description: A slide show depicting a parathyroidectomy.

description: A slide show depicting the repair of a diaphragmatic hernia.
