description: Jeff Zeleny reports from the site of Tuesdays Republican debate on Mitt Romneys posture as the front-runner.

title: Young and Martinez Back in Tigers Lineup
description: 4:13 p.m. | Updated Rain has delayed the start of Game 4 between the Tigers and the Rangers. First pitch is now expected to be at 5:15 p.m.

title: Hemangioma Excision
description: A slide show explaining hemangioma excision.

title: Asia Society to Host China-India Program
description: Leading writers from China and India will meet for panel discussions in New York early next month as part of a new initiative called The Chindia Dialogues. The event, to run Nov. 3 through 6 at the Asia Society, will focus on cultural and social trends in both countries as well as their interaction with each other.

title: To the Barricades
description: Gail Collins: David, I was sorry to see you didnt have a little bit of sympathy for the Occupy Wall Street protesters.

title: Wall Streets CrackBerry Withdrawal
description: Wednesday had the makings of a relatively good day for Wall Street. The stock market was edging toward positive territory for the year. Europe was hashing out a deal to recapitalize its banks. And enraged protestors remained encamped at Zuccotti Park, letting bank chieftains breath easy in their Park Avenue palaces.

title: A Matter of Gravity: Developing Space-Based Experiments
description: Overview | In this lesson, students read about a new contest seeking student science experiments to be conducted on the International Space Station. They learn more about space-based research, design experiments they would like to see carried out in microgravity and develop scripts for video pitches to promote their ideas.

title: Palestinians in Gaza Celebrate Prisoner Swap Deal
description: GAZA CITY  Palestinian joy erupted quickly in this isolated enclave at the first word of the Israeli-Palestinian prisoner swap agreement announced late Tuesday. And through the hours of Wednesday as the agreements details became clearer, the celebrations spread and Hamas, the governing authority here that rejects Israels legitimacy, claimed much of the credit.

title: What You Get for ... $599,000
description: OAK GROVE, ORE.

title: Caucus Video: Romney, Center Stage
description: Jeff Zeleny reports from the site of Tuesdays Republican debate on Mitt Romneys posture as the front-runner.

title: CBS Is Top Network Standing
description: So far, CBS has done pretty well for itself over the course of this still-young fall season. How well? According to Nielsen ratings data from Sept. 19 through Oct. 9, CBS has 20 of the top 30 shows among the broadcast networks in total viewership, making CBS the first network to accomplish such a feat. It was also the number one network in average viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Stalwarts NCIS and NCIS: LA certainly helped the networks cause on Tuesday, garnering 18.7 million viewers and 15.4 million respectively, although the two dramas hit season lows in the 18-to-49 demo. If it can hold steady, ABC will have a new entry in the top 30 with the new Tim Allen comedy Last Man Standing. The two-episode series premiere was sampled by nearly 13 million total viewers.

title: In Living Wage Talks, Warfare Trumps Discourse
description: Long ago, I passed boiling summers driving taxis in New York City (an experience that no doubt still summons nightmares for my former passengers, not to mention wayward pedestrians). Other summers, I worked as a doorman, hauling bags and opening doors for royally snooty Park Avenue dowagers.

title: DealBook: Wall Streets CrackBerry Withdrawal
description: The BlackBerry outage, which seemed contained to the places most afflicted by the sovereign debt crisis, had spread to the heart of American capitalism.

title: Protesters Take Aim at Dimon, but Miss His Office
description: The nearly month-old Occupy Wall Street protest has apparently settled on a favorite target for their ire, Jamie Dimon. On Tuesday, protestors marched to his apartment building in Manhattans Upper East Side, bearing a giant fake check critiquing the low taxes of Americas wealthiest individuals.

title: Leg Lengthening
TV Chat: Ask the Critics
description: Now that viewers have gotten a look at most of the new shows this season, the fall television picture is becoming clearer: sitcoms like New Girl (with Zooey Deschanel) and 2 Broke Girls (with Kat Dennings) have gotten votes of confidence, Tim Allens Last Man Standing earned a spot in the Top 30, while H8R, Free Agents and How to Be a Gentleman are out or on their way. Did these shows deserve their fates, for better or worse? Speaking of comedies, HBO unveiled Enlightened and came back with a new season of Bored to Death and a male breast-feeding scene. Has HBO finally gone too far? The television critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger have posted answers to your questions and comments.

title: Nose Surgery
description: A slide show depicting nose surgery.

title: Pitchfork Announces New York Festival
description: The online music magazine that runs the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago  the influential outdoor showcase for indie bands  has plans to start a new festival in New York City next February, teaming up with one of the citys largest music promoters, the Bowery Presents.

title: The Moneyball of Campaign Advertising (Part 2)
description: [For the first post in this two-part series, see here.]

title: TimesCast | October 12, 2011
description: The Nigerian who tried to down an airliner with an underwear bomb pleads guilty; Myanmar begins releasing some political prisoners; and a breakthrough for phone-based voice recognition.

title: After a Quarter-Century, an Author Looks Back at His Holocaust Comic
description: Art Spiegelmans Maus, the most unconventional great book yet written about the Holocaust, the one that turned Nazis into cats and Jews into mice and Poles into pigs, turns 25 this year. It was the first comic book to win a Pulitzer Prize, and it changed the way comics  the term seems wrong for Maus  are viewed in America. It proved they could be serious art.

title: First Stop: Target. Next Stop: eBay.
description: ITS been a month since Target released its Missoni for Target line and scrums of shoppers cleared the discount retailers shelves and crashed its Web site. But as with some earlier limited-edition masstige collections, the frenzy has continued in the secondary market, with sold-out items going for breathtakingly inflated prices on eBay and Craigslist and in consignment shops.

title: Hunting for a Vaccine
description: Two experimental vaccines against dengue fever are being developed, and researchers think they may be available commercially in five to seven years.

title: For Bargain Fanatics, Uptown Mayhem
description: THE discount department store Century 21 and I go way back  well, back to 1999 or so, when, like thousands of brides attempting the minimalist glamour of Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, I bought an off-white slip dress at its flagship across from the World Trade Center. Never mind that I wasnt yet engaged; I reveled in the price tag ($159, down from $1,595  thats 90 percent off) and designer label (Vera Wang, as opposed to Bessette Kennedys more original Narciso Rodriguez, but still) and stashed the gown confidently in a trunk.

title: Bunion Removal
description: A slide show depicting bunion removal.

title: Cuomo Vows Reforms at Residential Care Agencies
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, saying he was startled by problems with the handling of abuse and neglect allegations at state facilities, on Wednesday vowed reforms at six agencies that provide residential care for the disabled, the elderly, children and the mentally ill.

title: 20111012-Lens-Delano
description: FSA Photos Delano

title: Frank Fires Back at Gingrich
description: Your run-of-the-mill critic of Dodd-Frank wants to tame or repeal the enormous regulatory overhaul.

title: Mobile Devices Account for a Growing Portion of Web Traffic
description: The prediction that Internet traffic originating from mobile devices will eventually exceed that of desktop computers connected to the Internet is on its way to a reality.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Myanmar, Bhutan and Washington.

title: Bookshelf
description: In Ingo Schulzes cheery novel Adam and Evelyn (Knopf, $28), a lecherous East German dressmaker gets a bit too cozy with his comrade clientele, inciting his girlfriend to go on a sex-charged romp through newly democratic Hungary.

title: Ukrainian Opposition Leader to Be Freed Soon, Daughter Says
description: KIEV, Ukraine  For the last few months, the people who visited Yulia V. Tymoshenko in Detention Center No. 13 have been slipping something into the stacks of documents they bring her to read  the handwritten notes known in prison slang as malyava, exchanged by generations of Soviet inmates, who would crumple them into pea-sized balls or roll them into narrow cones and shoot them out of blowpipes.

title: In Norway, a Home and Corporate Headquarters
description: A four-bedroom 2,648-square-foot contemporary waterfront house was built for the co-founders of Beat.no, a music streaming service.

title: Secrets to Coaching Success: Share Your Thoughts
description: What makes a great coach or manager?

title: Subway Surfer Becomes a Mini-Celebrity, Worrying Transit Officials
description: He is the subways latest celebrity passenger, a man whose exploits draw a crowd of captivated riders who cheer him on, talk about tracking him down on Facebook, and, of course, post videos of him on YouTube.

title: A Downtown Icons Nurturing Spirit
description: TWO years ago, Ellen Stewart, the founder and longtime impresario of La MaMa Experimental Theater Club in the East Village, was speaking to her entire staff at a nearby restaurant when she dropped a bombshell. Mia, she said, will be the new me.

title: A Home and Headquarters
description: MJOMNA, Norway  On the western coast of Norway, a two-story house with a geometrical facade and an off-white exterior sits on a craggy waterfront stretch of Mjomna, one of hundreds of remote islands speckling the deep blue waters of the Sognefjord. The house calls to mind the Oslo Opera House, with its minimalistic origami-like folds. But the comparison goes beyond appearance: these walls, too, are bursting with music.

title: Obama Campaign Treating Romney Like Nominee  By Attacking
description: 5:51 p.m. | Updated Republicans are months away from their first presidential primaries and caucuses, but the Obama campaign already is giving Mitt Romney the nominee treatment  trying to define him irrevocably as a shape-shifter, with an eye to the 2012 election.

title: Homes for $599,000
description: A 1932 house in Oak Grove, Ore., a bungalow in Los Angeles, and a circa 1800 cabin with a modern addition in Hillsborough, N.C.

title: Langone Doesnt Hesitate in Aiding Romney
description: Ken Langone isnt wasting any time.

title: City Ballets Fall Season
description: New York City Ballets four-week fall season ended on Sunday.

title: The Campus as Runway
description: Thanks to the Web, college women have instant access to the latest fashion trends. Many take them seriously, leaving the disheveled student look behind.

title: Theatrical Offerings and Instruction for Singing Birds
description: The Da Capo Chamber Players have always been drawn to works in which instrumental color is put to descriptive or dramatic use, and to open its 41st season on Monday at Merkin Concert Hall, the ensemble assembled seven painterly, theatrical scores, mostly by British composers.

title: Jules Allens Sweet Science
description: Allens Photos of Gleasos Gym

title: The Campus as Runway
description: JULIA FLYNN was darting to her classes at Columbia University last week in a Marc by Marc Jacobs daisy-patterned dress and high-heeled Chlo boots, her polished turnout accessorized with a Starbucks venti latte. Im really loving the whole Chanel, Valentino and McQueen shows, she said. They completely inspired me. She had gleaned her information that very morning from Style.com.

title: Idol Star at No. 1
description: This has been a good week for American Idol on the music charts. Scotty McCreery, who won this years competition, has opened at No. 1 on the latest Billboard chart with his first album, Clear as Day (Mercury Nashville/19 Recordings/Interscope), and reached numerous sales milestones. Clear as Day, which sold 197,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, had the biggest opening week in three years for an Idol winners first album, and it is also the first debut by an Idol champion to open at No. 1 since Ruben Studdards Soulful, in 2003. If that were not enough, Mr. McCreery, who turned 18 on Sunday, is also the first country act to open at No. 1 with a debut, and is the youngest man to have a first album start in the top slot, Billboard reported. Also this week, Adeles unstoppable 21 (XL/Columbia) is No. 2 on the album chart with 112,000 sales, and her recent single, Someone Like You, remains the No. 1 digital song, with 218,000 downloads. The No. 2 spot on the digital songs chart is also unchanged from last week: Maroon 5s Moves Like Jagger, featuring Christina Aguilera, had 186,000 downloads. Tony Bennetts Duets II (Columbia) is the No. 3 album this week with 71,000. Other new titles in this weeks Top 10 include Feists Metals (Cherrytree/Interscope), at No. 7, and Take a Back Road (Curb), the fourth album by Rodney Atkins, at No. 8.

title: Embracing Communal and Hymnal
description: Welcome to the Stone, and to the Ives geek-out party, the violinist Hilary Hahn announced brightly on Monday at the Stone, a tiny, boxy East Village new-music laboratory operated by the saxophonist and composer John Zorn. Ms. Hahn, a performer who draws sizable throngs to prominent auditoriums, was making a point by celebrating her admirable new CD, Charles Ives: Four Sonatas, of Ivess violin sonatas at Mr. Zorns space, which seats fewer than 100.

title: I Am Not Your Mirror Image
description: Russ Roberts tries to debunk my explanation of the reasons to believe in a broadly Keynesian view of the world  and reveals more than he intended.

title: Are Americans More Prone to A.D.H.D.?
Romancing the Reich
description: They met in 1929, in the photographers shop where she worked, in Munich. He was 40, she was 17. He devoured her with his eyes, she said. Soon after, he had her family investigated, to check that her bloodlines were Aryan. He was Adolf Hitler, an amateur artist whose charisma as a reactionary orator had propelled him to the forefront of Germanys National Socialist party. She was Eva Braun, an attractive blonde from a middle-class family who, after one year at a school run by nuns, was back home living with her parents. We know how the story ends, though we cant help wondering why  was she completely lacking in intelligence, or morals, or both? In Eva Braun: Life With Hitler, translated from the German by Damion Searls (Alfred A. Knopf), Heike B. Grtemaker takes on a task few biographers  Im tempted to say no biographer in her right mind  would tackle, so scant and unreliable is the material.

title: Expressing Trauma in Words and Spins
description: What has dance got to do with genocide or torture? At first the mind recoils from any such link. Yet amazingly, the French-Algerian choreographer Rachid Ouramdane plunges in, evoking post-traumatic conditions in movement imagery, and in the process he extends the whole notion of what dance can express.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Oct. 10
description: Solange Knowles answers fashion questions; Uniqlo opens, Cameo rings and more.

title: Hard Times On Wall Street
description: A wonderful juxtaposition:

title: The Caucus Click: DeMint Emerges
Park Slope, 2:12 P.M.
description: For the Jewish festival of Sukkot, which starts Wednesday evening and which Jews celebrate by erecting (and eating in) a temporary booth called a sukkah, Congregation Beth Elohim, in Brooklyn, commissioned a community sukkah designed by B-an-G Studio, a new architecture firm. The firms principals, Babak Bryan and Henry Grosman, won the peoples choice award in last years Sukkah City competition, held in Union Square. For Beth Elohim, Mr. Bryan and Mr. Grosman designed a sukkah made of 3,000 pieces of wood, which members of the congregation put together. To complete the design, temple members are painting 1,500 laser-cut cardboard leaves in colorful bursts of red, orange and yellow. The leaves will be affixed to the sukkahs frame of wood and bent-steel spines.

title: Running Skirts Go Girly
description: RUNNING skirts are getting more swish.

title: American Idol Scores Big on Pop Charts
description: On the music charts, this has been a good week for American Idol.

title: Bonuses Tied to Medicares Star System Reward Insurers
description: For the first time, a government-backed quality rating will have a financial meaning to health insurance companies looking to attract millions of older Americans to privately run Medicare coverage next year.

title: Seeking Acceptance, and Family, in Ones Shifting Gender
description: Southern Comfort, which is playing at the CAP21 Theater Companys new space in Chelsea, will never have the exposure of Chaz Bono, who is putting a human face on the transgender-rights struggle for millions of viewers this season on ABCs Dancing With the Stars. But in its own small way, this affecting folk-bluegrass musical by Julianne Wick Davis and Dan Collins makes a heartfelt bid to shift perceptions.

title: House Hunting in ... Romania
description: AN EIGHT-BEDROOM HOUSE IN CENTRAL ROMANIA

title: An Eight-Bedroom House in Central Romania
description: An eight-bedroom family home that is currently operating as a hotel and restaurant in the village of Apoldu de Sus in Transylvania, is on the market for $467,000.

title: Bass Fishing at Montauk Lighthouse
description: Fishing in Montauk, N.Y., is an extreme sport.

title: Scene City: Taking Sides Over a Book on Women
description: Rappers and moguls unveil Culo by Mazzuco, a book featuring the female backside.

title: Taking Sides Over a Book on Women
description: THERE were a few questions just waiting to be asked at the party for Culo by Mazzucco, a book of artistic photographs that presents its models stark naked and bottom-first.

title: Footwork as Nimble on Court as Onstage
description: At a pivotal moment in Lysistrata Jones, a musical comedy about basketball and sex that is coming to Broadway next month, the title character has to make a layup on the stage-turned-court. Patti Murin, the 5-foot-4 actress playing Lysistrata, made 34 of 39 shots during an Off Broadway production last spring  a solid showing for a hoops newbie who didnt know a layup from a free throw before being cast.

title: Up the Career Ladder, Lipstick In Hand
description: WANT more respect, trust and affection from your co-workers?

title: March on City Hall Calls for End to Stop and Frisk
description: With a chorus of plastic drumbeats, solidarity chants and fluttering flags, more than 400 protesters made a pilgrimage across the Brooklyn Bridge to City Hall Park in Manhattan.

title: Free text messages; Pioneer AppRadio; the documentary film Connected; tech news.
description: The Times technology reporter Jenna Wortham discusses new free messaging services that let users text over a Wi-Fi connection without having to pay SMS fees to wireless carriers. Tiffany Shlain, the founder of the Webby Awards and the director of the documentary, Connected, talks about making the film and her observations on the social impact of modern technology. Pedro Rafael Rosado gets a look at Pioneer AppRadio and the tech news roundup includes Facebooks new iPad app, declining traffic to Google+ and the recent business U-turn by Netflix. Sam Grobart, the Personal Technology editor at The Times, previews his new article on life with a high-tech toilet. For Mac users wondering how to use repair utilities without a system DVD on Mac OS X 10.7, the Tip of the Week explores Apples built-in Lion Recovery feature.

title: Raising Eyebrows
description: IT wasnt quite the slip-up (or slip-down, as it were) most people expect during a presidential campaign, but whatever happened to Ron Pauls eyebrows at Tuesday nights debate certainly caught some viewers attention.

title: Meredith Buys Rachael Ray Magazine
description: The Meredith Corporation, the publisher of Better Homes and Gardens, More and Family Circle, announced Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to purchase Every Day with Rachael Ray magazine and its related digital assets from the Readers Digest Association.

title: Thinking Globally, Rapping Locally
description: I would not consider myself to be a quote unquote real New York rapper, ASAP Rocky said in an interview last month. I dont even like New York rappers.

title: Current TV Adds The War Room to Its Lineup
description: Jennifer Granholm, the former Michigan governor, will soon become the third host of a progressive prime-time program on Current TV, the fledgling competitor of MSNBC.

title: The iPhone 4S Review Roundup
description: Just two days before the new Apple iPhone 4S hits store shelves the reviews are out. What are the critics saying? To be frank, theyre not being very negative; most love the iPhone 4S, specifically the newly improved camera, its latest software update and the new humble personal assistant, Siri.

title: Bathtub Gin
description: LIKE an infestation of voles, speakeasies continue to burrow their way into the citys night life. The latest is Bathtub Gin, a fake Victorian bar hidden behind a coffee shop in Chelsea. Opened last month, the lounge hopes to corral herds from the meatpacking district with the easy refinement of cocktail culture.

title: Dissident Creates by Remote Control
description: From his studio in Beijing, Ai Weiwei, the outspoken Chinese artist and dissident, had a clear view of Rikers Island. For months Mr. Ai, who was detained by Chinese authorities in the spring and released under close surveillance in June, has been limited in his travel and communications with the outside world. But recently he was able to escape, at least digitally, and even to make new work in another country.

title: A Mixed-Race Family Tree
description: The family tree of a mixed-race woman.

title: New Hampshire Threatens Early December Primary
description: Will the 2012 elections officially start in 2011?

title: Robert W. Galvin, Who Ushered Motorola Into the Modern Era, Dies at 89
description: Robert W. Galvin, who took the reins of Motorola from his father and built a family-run business that pioneered Depression-era car radios and wartime walkie-talkies into a global maker of color television sets, cellphones and other ubiquities of the electronic age, died early Tuesday in Chicago. He was 89.

title: Her Life Is a Real Page-Turner
description: TO keep her independent bookstore not only solvent but thriving (revenue is racing ahead of last year by 16 percent), Sarah McNally has a limitless supply of small tricks up her sleeve. And a whirring, wheezing behemoth at her side.

title: Saving Philip Johnsons Brick House
description: Ever wonder how Philip Johnson managed to live in a fishbowl? If he needed a nap, he sometimes walked across the lawn from his famous Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., to the lesser-known Brick House, where an upholstered bedroom, like something from the Arabian Nights, awaited. Perhaps to maintain the illusion that he needed nothing more than his house of windows, the Brick House was rarely shown in photos of its more-famous neighbor. Now the National Trust for Historic Preservation has begun to raise money to preserve the Brick House, which was completed in 1949 and has been closed to the public since 2008 because of problems that include leaks resulting in mold on silk wall coverings, furniture and books.

title: Denied Veterans Benefits Over Same-Sex Marriage, Ex-Sailor Challenges Law
description: In what experts say is the first case of its kind, a disabled Navy veteran from Connecticut is challenging the constitutionality of two federal laws that define marriage as being between opposite-sex partners, saying the government denied her veterans benefits because she is married to a woman.

title: Shopping for Storage Solutions
description: David Obel Rosenkvist, the vice president for North America of the furniture company Fritz Hansen, searched for visually pleasing storage solutions for athletic gear.

title: A Sergio Rodrigues Shop Opens in New York
description: Sergio Rodrigues is in the enviable position of amassing a cult following while still alive. And at 84, the Brazilian designer shows no signs of stopping. Next week, he has a new store opening in New York, his first in this country in more than 40 years. (His previous store, OCA, in Carmel, Calif., closed in 1968.)

title: Sales on Pratesi, Alvar Aalto and More
description: Discontinued Alvar Aalto lighting and furniture will be on sale at Artek  from Friday to Sunday (the A338 Bilberry light in chrome, originally $320, will be $160); 199 Lafayette Street (Kenmare Street), (212) 219-0589.

title: Storage Solutions for Athletic Gear
description: WHEN David Obel Rosenkvist moved his family to Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, from a town outside Copenhagen in August, he discovered a problem most New Yorkers will be familiar with: a lack of storage space. For Mr. Rosenkvist, the vice president for North America of Fritz Hansen, a Danish furniture company, the situation was especially problematic, as he, his wife and his two children are all outdoors enthusiasts.

title: The Unhappy Hipsters
description: It was early in 2010, and Molly Jane Quinn, a writer, and Jenna Talbott, a graphic designer, were working, none too happily, at Design New England, a regional magazine. They cheered each other up one chilly January evening by making a tumblr blog with a simple, hilarious engine: marrying photos from Dwell magazine with deadpan captions parodying the magazines signature hipster anomie. His sartorial attempt to blend in with the concrete did little to assuage the tension, read one early post.

title: Market Ready
description: Q.  Is it worth renovating my bathroom before I try to sell my apartment?

title: Weaving by African Women at the Textile Museum
description: Everyone thinks of African art in terms of sculpture and masks that are made by men, said Vanessa Drake Moraga, the curator of Weaving Abstraction: Kuba Textiles and the Woven Art of Central Africa, a show opening Saturday at the Textile Museum in Washington. But textile and fiber arts are the domain of women.

title: High-End Furnishings Direct to You
description: Flash sales may be all the rage, but two new Web sites are betting that consumers want more online access to full-priced high-end home furnishings.

title: Eco Meets the Economy
description: IN August, Lloyd Alter came up against the limits of his environmental convictions when he had to replace the leaky roof on his house in Toronto.

title: A Bridge Just Far Enough
description: Eleanor Lanahan and John Douglas, Vermont artists, built an addition with a bridge to maintain their private space while living together.

title: One Couple, Two Houses and the Bridge in Between
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.

title: Along the Heated Trail of the Man Who Created Muslim Superheroes
description: Muslim children need new role models. That is the message at the heart of The 99, a comic book of superheroes who each exemplify one of the 99 qualities that Muslims believe Allah embodies, like generosity, strength and patience.

title: The Buzz
description: A preview of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: Hold Off on iOS 5 Update
description: If youre in a rush to update your iPhone or iPad to Apples latest operating system, iOS, which became available Wednesday, hold off a bit.

title: Two Declarers, Two Distinct Finesses
description: Three in an Adams family of bridge competed at the New England Summer Regional in Sturbridge, Mass., in June.

title: The Lure of Carnivorous Plants
description: ABOUT 200 million years ago, certain plants with strange leaves showed up on what became the eastern half of North America. Because they grew in marshy, infertile soil, they had to devise other ways to find nutrients. And so they began to catch and eat bugs.

title: Carnivorous Plants Attract Adventurous Gardeners
description: Strangely beautiful and long misunderstood, insect-eating plants find an audience.

title: Robert Wilsons interpretation of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weills Threepenny Opera
description: Charles Isherwood on Robert Wilsons interpretation of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weills Threepenny Opera.

title: Trying to Outrun Wealth and Fame
description: ON a bright September afternoon at the artist Pat Steirs studio in West Chelsea, two attractive blond heiresses were taking a series of portraits. Jaime Johnson, 29, and her younger sister, Daisy, 24, were sometimes capturing Ms. Steir alone, sometimes including themselves in the shots. There were few props, other than a selection of straw trilbys and fedoras. Jaime lets me use the hat to cover my face, Daisy explained. I dont like my face in photos.

title: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan
description: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan

title: 3 Officials Quit Amid Scandals in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Three senior Ugandan government officials resigned Wednesday, and the president addressed the nation over several mounting corruption scandals, particularly in the countrys nascent oil sector.

title: Snubbed by Apple, T-Mobile Looks Beyond the iPhone
description: T-Mobile must feel like the only kid in the class who didnt get invited to the party of the year.

title: Some Experts Question Irans Role in Bungled Plot
description: Updated | Thursday | 9:34 a.m. Just 24 hours after American officials announced that they had disrupted an Iranian plot that sounded like a rejected Quentin Tarantino script  centering on an Iranian-American used-car salesmans failed attempt to hire a Mexican drug cartel to assassinate Saudi Arabias ambassador in Washington  a number of prominent American experts on Iran have suggested that Irans government might not have been behind the scheme at all.

title: Early New Hampshire Primary Could Backfire on Romney
description: Ive generally been of the view that the earlier that the Republican primaries and caucuses begin, the better off Mitt Romneys campaign will be.

title: iPhone's Siri vs. My Human Assistant
description: To help resolve his girlfriend situation, filmmaker Casey Neistat pits the iPhone 4Ss virtual assistant, Siri, against his real-life personal assistant, Thurman.

title: South Carolinas Trouble-Prone Quarterback Runs Out of Last Chances
description: There are things a quarterback in the Southeastern Conference cannot get away with. He cannot drink with friends at a popular tavern despite being under age and expect that no one will see him. He cannot take his key and scratch the car of a man who he claims swiped his parking spot in the pouring rain. He cannot have three girls in his dormitory room at one time and expect no questions about it.

title: Broadway Basketball
description: Chris Mullin, the retired N.B.A. All-Star, plays host at a basketball camp for the cast of the coming Broadway musical Lysistrata Jones.

title: Rookie Receivers Emergence and Masons Performance Led to Trade, Jets Say
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When the Jets pursued Derrick Mason in August, they offered to let him spend Mondays and Tuesdays in Nashville, where his son and daughter live. It was an uncommon arrangement, but the Jets felt comfortable because Mason did not have to absorb an entirely new offense.

title: Choosing the Right iPhone Data Plan
description: If you have decided to get a new iPhone, the choice is a whole lot harder than what color  black or white  or how much storage  16, 32 or 64 gigabytes  you want.

title: Preventing a Syrian Civil War
description: Doha, Qatar

title: Supreme Court Weighs Strip-Search Propriety
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court considered on Wednesday whether the Constitution places limits on strip-searches of people entering jails, and quickly confronted two separate line-drawing problems, both involving the task of balancing dignity against security.

title: Hollywoods Black List Gets an Upgrade
description: 8:34 p.m. | Updated What do Slumdog Millionaire, Juno and The Kings Speech have in common? They all started as unproduced scripts on the Hollywood Black List.

title: Federal Mediator to Meet With N.B.A. Sides
description: A federal mediator will try to accomplish next week what months of intense negotiations did not: labor peace in the N.B.A.

title: An Embrace of the U.S., Spun and Mixed by Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  With his New York Yankees jersey, baggy jeans embroidered with U.S.A. down one leg and his casual greeting of Whats up?, Ali Jabbar, a rapper and a student in Islamic studies, seems an alien in his own culture.

title: In Iraq, Hip-Hop Takes Root
description: Despite faint traces of cultural impact as the United States military prepares to withdraw from Iraq, a hip-hop scene has blossomed among youth.

title: United States Free-Trade Partners
description: The United States will have free-trade agreements with 20 countries.

title: Auburn Is Cleared in Investigation Into Newton
description: Saying it had found no violations, the N.C.A.A. announced the end of its 13-month investigation into Auburns football program Wednesday, including the recruitment of the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback Cam Newton.

title: How to Pick the Best iPhone 4S Carrier
description: If youre in the market for an iPhone 4S, you may be wondering which carrier you should give your money to. After all, you now have a new choice to consider, Sprint, not to mention the ever-shifting landscape of each carriers plans and add-ons. Lets try to break it down.

title: A Shelf-Obsessed Writer
description: I cant remember when I first became obsessed with the cafes free bookcase, but sometime in the last year it was suddenly so, and I was regularly making pilgrimages there. I took books home to read, and brought others in to replace them. I noticed which ones were snapped up quickly and which sat for too long. I rooted for the galley of Emily St. John Mandels smart novel The Singers Gun to find a good home, but felt a little smug about another novel  which sucked up all the press in the universe when it came out, even though it was not its authors finest work, not by a long shot, and one might wonder if perhaps the author was even phoning it in  which no one touched for weeks.

title: Report Finds No Wrongdoing in Afghanistan Copter Crash
description: WASHINGTON -- The official military investigation into a helicopter shoot-down that caused the largest loss of American life during a single day of the war in Afghanistan has found no wrongful actions by personnel involved in the mission, nor were there equipment failures.

title: How to Stop the Drop in Home Values
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: U.S. Acts to Fine BP and Top Contractors for Gulf Oil Spill
description: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department formally cited BP and its two chief contractors on Wednesday for numerous safety and environmental violations in the operation of the doomed Deepwater Horizon well.

title: Season Lost by the N.H.L. Could Teach the N.B.A.
description: The league commissioner, dressed somberly in a dark blue suit, stepped to the microphone before a hushed roomful of reporters in a New York hotel and spoke the words no one wanted to hear.

title: Tending a Small Patch of Capitalism in North Korea
description: RASON, North Korea  A seaside casino resort developed by a Hong Kong company chauffeurs Chinese officials and businesspeople from the nearby border in a red Humvee.

title: Math Drills, via the Smartphone
description: Its tough to call something a smartphone when its packed with apps like iWhoopieCushion, Zombie Crisis and Pimple Popper.

title: McGwire Talks, Cardinals Listen
description: ST. LOUIS  He still looks as if he could hit a baseball 500 feet. Ten years after Mark McGwire took his last major league swing, and six years after his evasive testimony before a Congressional committee on steroid use, his blacksmith arms still pop out from under a black sleeveless T-shirt, like the one he wore Tuesday afternoon.

title: The Gift of Glib
description: Right now youre probably asking yourself, how did Rick Perry do in the big Republican debate in New Hampshire this week?

title: Questioned on Donations, Comptroller Vows Review
description: Confronted by damaging questions about the source of his campaign donations, John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, said Wednesday that he would conduct an internal review of his donations but defended the conduct of his campaign.

title: Democratic Senators Ads May Break New Ground
description: WASHINGTON  A new series of political advertisements on behalf of an embattled Nebraska senator could open the door to a flood of similar ads financed by outside groups and even businesses working directly with political candidates  a sharp departure from past practice.

title: A Lot of Talk, but Few Stars Have Left the Country to Play
description: If he were desperate for competition  without regard to geography, lifestyle or paycheck  Carmelo Anthony could board a flight to Italy, Spain or France tomorrow. The jobs are there. Games are being played. Basketball goes on, even without the N.B.A.

title: Securing the Mexican Border
description: Marc Lacey of The New York Times reports from Douglas, Ariz., on how the numbers of illegal immigrants crossing the border there has significantly dropped over the last 10 years.

title: Wal-Mart Sales Improve at Its Stores in the U.S.
description: After a two-year slump, Wal-Mart says it has turned a corner at its stores in the United States.

title: At the Border, on the Night Watch
description: DOUGLAS, Ariz.  The lanky young man with two bales of marijuana slung over his back who was apprehended by Border Patrol agents in a rugged area about a mile from the border here one recent night represented both the significant strides the country has made in controlling its southern border and the challenges that remain.

title: Unlikely Turn for a Suspect in a Terror Plot
description: WASHINGTON  His nickname was Scarface, the legacy of a brutal knife attack on a dark Houston street three decades ago that left his left cheek permanently marred. Friends and neighbors in Texas said that he could be gruff and intimidating, and that he often stood outside his house at night smoking and talking on his cellphone in a language they did not understand.

title: Speedy Rookie Is a Hit in the Giants Defense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jacquian Williams did not realize he was fast until he was 12. That was when one of his older cousins, weary of the constant requests from Williams, finally relented and picked him to play in a backyard football game.

title: A Not-Really-on-Wall-St. Protest, but the Fallout Is Felt There
description: The man traveled alone, pulling a mask of George Washington  or, at least, the version that is embossed on the front of quarters  over his face.

title: Siri, Can You Hear Me?
description: Sam Grobart talks to Siri, the iPhone 4S virtual personal assistant.

title: One Girls Courage
description: KENEMA, Sierra Leone

title: The Toilet of Tomorrow?
description: An expensive new toilet from Kohler offers features that most people never realized their own toilets were missing.

title: Bells and Whistles Descend Upon the Throne
description: Much has been written about the so-called war for the living room, that grand contest among tech, cable and media companies to dominate our leisure time through the television shows we watch and the music we listen to.

title: 8 Killed in Salon Shooting in Southern California
description: SEAL BEACH, Calif.  A gunman burst into a beauty salon in this sunny Pacific Coast town on Wednesday, killing eight people and severely injuring one more in a rampage that sent patrons and workers diving to the floor and running out of the building for safety.

title: No Jobs Bill, and No Ideas
description: It was all predicted, but the unanimous decision by Senate Republicans on Tuesday to filibuster and thus kill President Obamas jobs bill was still a breathtaking act of economic vandalism. There are 14 million people out of work, wages are falling, poverty is rising, and a second recession may be blowing in, but not a single Republican would even allow debate on a sound plan to cut middle-class taxes and increase public-works spending.

title: Investors Trust in Chinas Government Falters
A Campaign Windfall for 4 Republicans Who Voted for Same-Sex Marriage
description: ALBANY  As the State Legislature this year debated the legalization of same-sex marriage, a group of wealthy financiers who support both gay rights and Republican causes offered a reassurance to Republican lawmakers: Stand with us now, and we will stand with you later.

title: Protesters Told to Vacate Park, for Its Cleaning
description: Responding to what he called unsanitary conditions at the private park in Lower Manhattan that has served as home base to the Occupy Wall Street protest for more than three weeks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Wednesday night that protesters would be made to leave temporarily as the property was cleaned in stages.

title: The Charges Against Iran
description: Charges that Iranian officials ordered the assassination of Saudi Arabias ambassador to the United States are chilling and bizarre. If true  and American officials insist they have strong evidence  this is only the latest reminder of why the United States and its allies must use all possible diplomatic and economic pressures to isolate Tehran and block its nuclear ambitions.

title: 3 Witnesses Rebut Claim by Consultant on Poll Work
description: Not long after the 2009 mayoral election, a lawyer for Michael R. Bloombergs re-election campaign heard that a reporter was trying to track $1.2 million that Mr. Bloomberg had given to the Independence Party so that a political operative named John F. Haggerty Jr. could provide ballot security.

title: A Smart Immigration Move at Rikers
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg speaks often about the need for smart and humane immigration reform. He has now rightly thrown his support behind a City Council bill that would place sensible limits on how far New York City goes to help the federal government detain and deport illegal immigrants who pose no threat to the community.

title: With Just Three 9s, Cain Refigured Math for Taxes
description: It was a strategy session at 28,000 feet. Herman Cain, the Republican presidential candidate, and his advisers were on a campaign flight this summer between Atlanta and New Hampshire, tossing around policy ideas.

title: Bloggingheads: Are Mormons Christians?
description: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and David Weigel of Slate debate Mormonism, Christianity and politics.

title: Night Watch on the Mexican Border
description: Where Arizona meets Mexico, patrols play cat and mouse with migrants.

title: Curious Contents of the Digital Library
description: Perhaps you havent read Mrs. Molesworths Uncanny Tales or C. Schweiggers Schweigger on Squint. Perhaps you missed How to Be Happy Though Married or the Farmers Bulletin devoted to House Rats and Mice. No worries. They are available in 24 digital formats, including versions to suit just about any e-book reader you own. These titles, and millions more, are all out of copyright and part of the accelerating effort to digitize the public domain contents of the worlds libraries.

title: Thursday: Proceeding Without Thinking
description: Administrivial Exciting New York Times Crossword Puzzle Contest Alert! Heads up, my friends: Will Shortz and one of our top constructors will hold a forehead-slapping puzzle contest involving next weeks puzzles that you will definitely want to get in on. Exact instructions will follow at the top of each days puzzle (and I will post them here as well), but hold on to all of your puzzles from Monday through Friday, because the Saturday puzzle will contain a metapuzzle that will use clues from the rest of that week. When you have solved the metapuzzle, e-mail your answer to crossword@nytimes.com. PLEASE DO NOT POST YOUR ANSWERS HERE ON THE BLOG, AND PLEASE DO NOT MAIL THEM TO ME. Only answers e-mailed to that address will be considered. Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6 p.m. Eastern Time on Sunday, Oct. 23, will receive copies of Will Shortz Picks His Favorite Puzzles: 101 of the Top Crosswords From The New York Times. Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners names will appear on Friday, Oct. 28, at http://www.nytimes.com/wordplay.

title: A Wedding and an Unwelcome Guest
description: A wedding is an easy peg to hang drama on, for reasons that hardly need much elaboration. Two words suffice: family togetherness. In We Live Here, a programmatic play by Zoe Kazan that opened on Wednesday at City Center in a Manhattan Theater Club production, the summer nuptials of the daughter of an artsy clan in New England brings about a painful family reckoning with the impact of a tragedy from a dozen years before.

title: Court Hears Claim That an Arms Sting Lured a Russian
description: The reputed Russian arms trafficker Viktor Bout was offered the chance to put weapons worth millions of dollars into the hands of terrorists in order to kill Americans, and he jumped at the opportunity, a federal prosecutor told a jury in Manhattan on Wednesday.

title: Second Passenger in Helicopter Crash Dies
description: A second passenger in the helicopter that crashed last week in the East River has died in New York City.

title: Dip in Birth Rates Reflects Recession, Report Suggests
description: WASHINGTON  Birth rates in the United States declined sharply during the recession, according to a report by the Pew Research Center released Wednesday. The analysis, based on data from all 50 states and the District of Columbia, suggested women were putting off having babies while the economy was weak.

title: In Court for Disrobing, and Doing It Again
description: Holly Van Voast has stripped naked in Times Square. She has stripped naked on the Staten Island Ferry. She has stripped naked in the middle of Grand Central Terminal  earning herself a date in Midtown Community Court on Wednesday.

Half the stalls in their shared bathroom are missing doors, and their halls are lined with spooky rows of empty cubicles whose last occupants either took off or died off.

As the Archdiocese of New York embarks on a five-year, $175 million renovation of what has been described as the nations largest Roman Catholic Gothic sanctuary, architects and historians have meticulously reviewed every detail of James Renwick Jr.s original blueprints.

description: The Greenwood family tree, emblematic of a growing number of American bloodlines, is a mix of races that can be challenging to track, sometimes even confusing for the family itself.

description: States that allow some combinations of nonprofit and for-profit corporations.

description: WASHINGTON  Despite issuing harsh calls for Tehran to be held to account, the Obama administration does not plan to shift its policy of pressure on the Iranian government after disrupting what officials said was a plot to assassinate a Saudi Arabian envoy in Washington, administration officials said on Wednesday.

description: Anti-Qaddafi fighters helped injured comrades while battling Qaddafi loyalists in Surt.

description: ST. LOUIS  Under normal circumstances, Chris Carpenter would be nervous handing a one-run lead to a bullpen with four innings left to play.

title: A Quest for Hybrid Companies That Profit, but Can Tap Charity
description: A new type of company intended to put social goals ahead of making profits is taking root around the country, as more states adopt laws to bridge the divide between nonprofits and businesses.

title: TimesCast | Plane Bomber Pleads Guilty
description: October 12, 2011 - In a surprising turn, the Nigerian man who tried to bomb a Detroit-bound airplane in 2009 abruptly pleads guilty.

title: House Panel Issues Subpoena for Records on Gun Program
description: A House committee subpoenaed the Obama administration on Wednesday over a law enforcement program that allowed illegal gun purchases in the United States in an effort to link the weapons to Mexican drug cartels. Representative Darrell Issa, Republican of California and chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, said a subpoena went to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for Justice Department documents related to the program, called Fast and Furious. Mr. Issa has said that Mr. Holder provided misleading testimony to Congress on May 3 about when he first learned of Fast and Furious, which was overseen by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. A Justice Department spokeswoman, Tracy Schmaler, said that the department had already provided thousands of documents and made many officials available for interviews and testimony. So any notion that the department isnt working with the committee is simply wrong, she said.

title: Libya Fighters Say Capture of Surt Is Near
description: MISURATA, Libya  Anti-Qaddafi fighters said they had edged closer to capturing the coastal city of Surt on Wednesday, and commanders and journalists inside the city said the fighting appeared to be confined to just two areas of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis hometown.

title: A News Story Is Growing With Occupy Protests
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Splashed across the front page of the local newspaper here on Tuesday was the story of a 24-year-old Occupy protester named Keith Cuesta. He was not in New York, where some have been living in a park near Wall Street for nearly four weeks, but about 1,000 miles away in Tampa, where a small group of self-described 99 percenters have decided to camp out in solidarity.

description: Time: 20 to 60 minutes

title: From Needle Stick to Cure for Hepatitis
description: As doctors-in-training in the early 1990s, my friends and I became obsessed with the question of what we would do if we were pricked with an infected needle at work. We all had witnessed the inexorable, often painful march toward death of patients with hepatitis C and AIDS. We imagined the despair we would feel in that situation: the dashed hopes, the lost years of schooling and training. Many of us saw ourselves walking out of the hospital and not looking back. We couldnt imagine throwing ourselves back into the fray.

title: The Strategies of Game 4
description: DETROIT  The fourth game of the American League Championship Series started more than two hours late, and it stretched across 4 hours and 11 innings. But it was all worth it  for the Texas Rangers, who beat the Detroit Tigers, 7-3, and for people who are fascinated by baseball strategy.

title: Word of the Day | gory
description: gory \gr-e\ adjective

title: Booster Seats Continue to Improve, I.I.H.S. Finds
description: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a nonprofit financed by the insurance industry, has issued a new round of booster-seat ratings in which the organization named a record 31 seats as Best Bets, the top grade offered in the survey. Another five seats were named Good Bets; more than 40 seats received the second-lowest rating, Check Fit; while six were rated Not Recommended.

title: Roasted Chilies Bring the Heat
description: The chili harvest of West Texas, southern New Mexico and Chihuahua, Mexico, begins in late summer and lasts through the first hard frost. You can encounter the smell of chilies roasting anywhere, with the frequency and randomness I associate with leaves burning in New England. I didnt know this until I went to New Mexico, where I'd traveled for the Hatch Chile Festival, an event every native or long-termer politely advised me to avoid. (Well, its a nice drive, theyd say, and they were right about that.)

title: Corrections: October 13
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Syrian-American Is Arrested on Charges of Spying for Damascus
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Wednesday accused a Syrian-American man of secretly working for a Syrian intelligence service. It said he collected information about people in the United States who were protesting the Syrian governments crackdown on the countrys pro-democracy movement, as part of a scheme to silence, intimidate and potentially harm the protesters.

title: Britain: Ulster Inquiry to Reopen
description: The British government said Wednesday that it would reopen its investigation into the involvement of British forces in one of the most high-profile killings in Northern Ireland during the 30 years of violence known as the Troubles. But the decision to appoint a prominent British human rights lawyer to prepare a report on the extent of police and army collusion in the 1989 killing of Patrick Finucane, a lawyer who had represented Irish Republic Army activists, angered his family. They had demanded a full judicial inquiry similar to the one that was completed last year into the Bloody Sunday killings of 1972, when British troops shot and killed 13 unarmed Catholic protesters, with another protester dying later of his wounds. The $300 million cost of that inquiry, and the 12 years it took to complete, were cited by the government as reasons for not appointing a similar inquiry in the Finucane case. A previous inquiry had shown that Mr. Finucane was shot 14 times by Protestant gunmen as he ate a meal at his home with his wife and children.

title: European Report Criticizes Turkey; Serbia Is Now Candidate for Bloc
description: A report issued Wednesday by the European Union enlargement office criticized Turkeys reaction to recent gas drilling conducted by Cyprus in the Mediterranean, suggesting continued troubles with Turkeys longstanding bid to join the bloc. Turkey refuses to recognize the Greek Cypriot government  itself a member of the bloc  as the sole representative of the disputed island and calls for the reunification of Turkish Cypriots in the north and Greek Cypriots in the south. Turkey has called the gas exploration by the Greek Cypriots an act of provocation and started its own seismic exploration program in the sea, escorted by the Turkish Navy.

title: Britain: First Steps on Change for Women Ascending to Throne
description: Prime Minister David Cameron has taken the first formal step toward a constitutional change that would allow girls and women to ascend to the British throne before their younger brothers. Mr. Cameron told the House of Commons on Wednesday that he had written to the governments of 15 other Commonwealth nations that recognize Queen Elizabeth as head of state urging their acceptance of a change in the succession rules set by the Act of Settlement, adopted in 1701, which stipulates that male children have precedence over their older sisters in succession to the throne. Mr. Cameron also urged that the law be changed to eliminate a prohibition on the accession of any monarch who is married to a Roman Catholic, calling the ban an historical anomaly. The changes are said to have broad support in the other Commonwealth nations, though some are said to have reservations about opening a discussion out of concern that it might reopen potentially acrimonious debate on whether the monarchy should be abolished.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Free Texting
description: Text-messaging plans and fees can add quite a bit of revenue to the coffers of the wireless carriers, but newer services for sending messages free over Wi-Fi networks may soon take a bite out of those profits. On this weeks Bits Tech Talk podcast, Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter at The Times, discusses her recent article about how free text apps like iMessage make cellphone users happy and carriers nervous.

title: The New York Times, August 16, 1858
description: The original newspaper article on the laying of the cornerstone for St. Patricks Cathedral in New York City.

title: Lottery Numbers
Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
description: Industrial production slowed to 4.1 percent in August, raising fears that Indias economic growth could fall faster and further than analysts previously thought. Data showed a sharp decline in mining activity combined with slower growth in manufacturing. (Financial Express) One large Indian technology outsourcing company, Infosys, however, reported stronger growth in the three months ending in September, thanks in part to the declining rupee. (Mint)

title: State Puts Pressure on City Schools Over English Language Learners
description: New York City schools are broadly failing to meet the needs of many of their thousands of students who are still learning English, and they must improve or they may face sanctions, state education officials announced Wednesday.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday, because of Sukkot. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Cleaning Together to Escape Day Labor
description: After years of waiting on a Brooklyn street corner trying to land jobs cleaning houses, Teresa Bucio decided there had to be a better way to earn a living.

title: Spilled Oil Makes Landfall After New Zealand Cargo Ship Accident
description: Videos of the cargo ship that became stuck on a reef off the coast of New Zealand a week ago were broadcast almost immediately, as the ship began spilling oil and debris. Now more have begun to surface, documenting the sludge-covered beaches as the leaked oil makes landfall.

title: Cuomo Says He Will Reform Agencies Serving Disabled
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, saying he was startled by problems with the handling of abuse and neglect allegations at state facilities, on Wednesday vowed reforms at six agencies that provide residential care for the disabled, the elderly, children and the mentally ill.

title: Nina Sorokina, Dancer With the Bolshoi Ballet, Dies at 69
description: Nina Sorokina, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet from the 1960s to the 1980s whose impeccable technique, charm and buoyancy made her an ideal partner for her husband, the fiery, athletic Yuri Vladimirov, died on Oct. 8 in Moscow. She was 69.

title: Euro 2012 Playoffs: First Among Seconds
description: For a reason that has yet to be uncovered, UEFAs European Championship seems to routinely provide the stage for unfancied nations to upset the odds. Whether it was Denmarks triumph as a last-minute entry in 1992, Latvias reaching the 2004 tournament at the expense of Turkey, whom it eliminated in the qualification playoffs, or Greeces triumph over Portugal in Lisbon in the same year, the Euros retain a shock quality that their more illustrious relative, the World Cup, often lacks.

title: David Hess, Songwriter and Actor, Dies at 75
description: David Hess, a songwriter for Elvis Presley, Pat Boone and others in the 1950s and 1960s who went on to play murderous movie villains, died on Friday in Tiburon, Calif. He was 75.

title: Mildred Savage, Author of Parrish, Dies at 92
description: Mildred Savage, the author of Parrish, a tale of a teenager struggling into manhood in the vast tobacco fields of the Connecticut River Valley in the late 1940s and early 50s  a story later adapted for a popular movie of the same title  died on Friday at her home in Norwich, Conn. She was 92.

title: Petition Filed by Parents of Schoolchildren Killed in May 2008 Earthquake
description: A petition and partial translation of a petition filed by parents of children who dies in the May 2008 earthquake.

title: Anyone Who Fights Will be Ground to Dust
description: MANESAR  Two lanes of traffic and a barbed wire-topped fence separate the grey-striped Maruti Suzuki India plant from dozens of workers on strike outside.Security guards in blue shirts and navy slacks eye the workers, coalesced under a fuchsia-colored tent, warily through the fence. Striking workers, both inside and outside the plant, have halted production, costing Maruti and its vendors an estimated 30 billion Indian rupees (about $612 million) so far.

title: In Baghdad, Hip-Hop Takes Root
description: Despite faint traces of cultural impact as the United States military prepares to withdraw from Iraq, a hip-hop scene has blossomed among youth.

title: News Quiz | Oct. 13, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Oct. 13, 1943 | Italy Switches Sides in World War II
description: On Oct. 13, 1943, one month after Italy surrendered to Allied forces, it declared war on Nazi Germany, its onetime Axis powers partner.

title: Israel and Hamas Agree to Swap Prisoners for Soldier
description: WHAT is Hamas?WHAT country brokered the exchange of Palestinian prisoners for an Israeli solider?WHAT is the conflict between the Palestinians and Israelis regardingGaza in particular?

title: Love Letters
description: Scans of Damien Echols and Lorri Davis correspondence.

title: Jack Delanos American Sonata
description: Jack Delanos touchstone as a documentary photographer was Paul Strands imperative that one had to have a real respect for the thing in front of him. Through his long career  photographing everything from coal miners, sharecroppers, railroad men and Puerto Rican canecutters  he conveyed a deep respect for not just the travails of Everyman, but a true appreciation of the dignity that lay within.

title: Can Tax Cuts Pay for Themselves?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: A Death-Row Love Story
description: The letter came through a slot in the cell door. It was early 1996. Damien Echols looked at the postmark  Brooklyn, N.Y.  and the name on the return address: Lorri Davis. He opened the envelope and examined the messy handwriting.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 13, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, Realignment of Star Power.

title: Do You Participate in Class?
description: October 13, 10:40 p.m. | Updated  A history professor at the County College of Morris in Randolph, N.J., asked a student with a stutter not to raise his hand during class because she felt his stuttering took up valuable class time (although the professor later disputed that account). What do you think about the professors decision not to allow the student to participate verbally in class? What has been your experience with class participation?

title: Mumbai Comic Convention Spotlights Local Talent
description: The Indian market for comics and graphic novels is booming, and there is no better proof of this than the second Comic Con India. The first such convention took place in Delhi earlier this February and will remain the key event in future while Mumbai will see an Express version, running Oct. 22 and 23 at the World Trade Center (Cuffe Parade; 91-22-6638-7272; comicconindia.com/Express), that will travel to different cities each year.

title: N.F.L. Needs Fair Method for Recording Interception Statistics
description: On the final play in the first half of Sundays game between the Jets and the Patriots, Tom Brady threw a quick out to tight end Aaron Hernandez. Jets cornerback Antonio Cromartie intercepted the pass near the Patriots goal line and ran the ball back to the 41-yard-line as the clock expired.

title: What Went Wrong at One Madison Park
description: Where else in Manhattan can you get this? shouted Ira Shapiro as he stood high above the streets of Manhattan on the penthouse terrace of One Madison Park. It was a bright blue spring morning, and he stretched out his arms to show off the view, a clear shot in three directions: north to the Empire State Building, south to the Brooklyn Bridge and west over the Hudson River to Jersey City. Music drifted upward from the bandstand in Madison Square Park, a lovely expanse of trees and paths, 57 stories below. It was by far the tallest building on the block. We wanted to change the skyline of Manhattan, Shapiro said. And we did.

description: LONDON  The Occupy Wall Street protests are spreading to London.

title: In Case You Didnt Notice: Sewage Odors Are Drawing Fewer Complaints

title: Offshore Wind Is a Bit Closer, Backers Say
description: These may be uncertain times for renewable energy, with the collapse of Solyndra and a persistently low price for natural gas, a competitor, but the talk is upbeat at the American Wind Energy Associations annual offshore wind conference, in Baltimore.

title: Pratt & Whitney to Buy Rolls Royces Stake in Joint Venture

title: Should Children Be Allowed on Facebook?
description: Facebook really is after your kids.

title: N.F.L. Week 6 Game Probabilities
description: My statistics disagree with the consensus favorites in only one matchup this weekend: Panthers versus Falcons at Atlanta. Its not surprising most people favor the home-team Falcons. Carolina is 1-4, coming off a 2-14 season, while Atlanta is 2-3, coming off a 13-3 season. But statistically theyre nearly identical teams, with one critical difference.

title: Artists Logos Show Reach and Hostility of the Web
description: HONG KONG  Few personal journeys can shed as much light on the age we live in as the one traveled by Jonathan Mak in the last week.

title: Blitz for Fish, Bliss for Anglers

title: Is the Herman Cain Surge for Real?
description: The question that everyone is asking about Herman Cain right now is very simple: Is his surge in the presidential race for real?

title: Former Chief of CVS Caremark Joins Private Equity Firm
description: Thomas Ryan, a former chief executive of CVS Caremark, has joined the private equity firm Advent International as an operating partner.

title: Thursday Reading: Fewer Babies in a Weak Economy
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The Comptrollers Poster Problem
description: If for some bizarre reason you want your eyes to go out of focus, look up Section 10-119 of the citys Administrative Code.

title: The Next Boom in Mobile Devices Is the Car
description: SAN DIEGO  Cars, one of the great mobile devices to begin with, are about to get connected to the Internet like never before. It will change not just how we drive, but the economics of the car business.

title: Obama Raises More Than $42 Million for Campaign
description: 9:47 a.m. | Updated President Obamas campaign raised more than $42 million in the third quarter of the year, once again outpacing his Republican rivals despite the countrys economic woes and his low poll numbers.

title: Where Is the Love for Bugs?
description: If human beings were to disappear tomorrow, the world would go on with little change, the biologist E.O. Wilson once wrote. But if invertebrates were to vanish, he said, I doubt that the human species could last more than a few months.

title: With Apologies, Officials Say BlackBerry Service Is Restored
description: After a week of problems that plagued BlackBerry service across five continents, Research in Motion on Thursday said it had resolved technical issues and that service had begun returning to normal.

title: Legends Of The Fall (Of 2009)
description: Mike Konczal has some thoughts on the Obama administrations economic missteps, and mentions that there were reports in Fall 2009 that the administration was afraid of the invisible bond vigilantes:

title: Australia Abandons Refugee Swap Plan
description: SYDNEY  Prime Minister Julia Gillard of Australia announced Thursday that she was abandoning her governments controversial plans to ship asylum seekers to Malaysia as part of a refugee swap deal  a humiliating about-face for the beleaguered leader that leaves her immigration policy in turmoil.

title: Spill Cleanup Closes New Zealand Beaches
description: AUCKLAND  The authorities closed 22 kilometers of beaches along New Zealands east coast to the public on Thursday as hundreds of workers began cleaning up debris and oil spilled from a stranded cargo ship.

title: Varieties Of Uncertainty
description: Some of the usual suspects have lately been touting a research paper by Baker et al that supposedly shows that policy uncertainty is an important factor in restraining the economy, and claiming that this vindicates the Republican view. Larry Mishel sets the record straight.

title: Low Rates As A Sign Of Failure
description: Brad DeLong and Atrios pile on to David Cameron for suggesting that his austerity program, which has rather notably failed to deliver growth, is responsible for Britains low borrowing costs. As they say, British rates are low for the same reason US rates are low  not as a reward for fiscal virtue, but because everyone now expects the economy to stay depressed, and policy rates near zero, for years to come.

title: Timely | Laura Marling, Will of the Wisp
description: Songs simmer awhile inside her head before choosing their own moment to froth out fully formed. Or so has claimed Laura Marling, a 21-year-old British sensation who is perhaps the quintessential folk singer of her generation. Its a romantic idea, this ghostly pale lass with wispy blond hair transmuting somehow  perhaps via inspiration from the Muses  her own admittedly tangled emotions into divinely inspired songs to be sung by her divinely bestowed voice. And its an idea bolstered by the fact that her first two albums earned her a Mercury Prize nomination each. Marlings newly released third effort, A Creature I Dont Know, poetically titled like all her albums, trades some of her teenage urgency for a more muscular, acrobatic lyricism  the result being 10 tracks that feel evolved, or more grown-up even. In any case, its clear that when Marling found this new sound, the Muses did not abandon her.

title: The Eternal Adolescence of Beavis and Butt-Head
description: Some 15 years ago, these were two of the best-known laughs in America. One begins with an uhhhh that gives way to an airy, affected heh-heh-heh  it could belong to a snob who has had one too many electroshock treatments  while the other is more guttural, a throat-clearing hnhnhnhn that sometimes shifts to a higher register and back again, like Scooby-Doo being strangled. The first belongs to Butt-Head, the second to Beavis, and in their animated show, which MTV broadcast from 1993 to 1997, that laughter punctuates just about everything the two boneheaded teenagers utter. Its so automatic that I imagined it had actually been automated  that an engineer pressed a button every time their laughter was called for, and voil: uhhhh-heh-heh-heh, or hnhnhnhn, or both overlapping.

title: Seeing Things | California Design, 1930-1965
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Spaceys Richard III Arrives in BAMs New Winter-Spring Season
description: As a certain Shakespearean monarch has said, An honest tale speeds best, being plainly told, and in the meantime a not-so-plain production of Richard III will make its way to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in January as part of the 2012 winter-spring season. The Bridge Projects presentation of the play, starring Kevin Spacey as the deformed, unfinshd Duke of Gloucester and directed by Sam Mendes, will be presented at the Harvey Theater from Jan. 10 through March 4 with its official opening night scheduled for Jan. 18, the academy said Thursday. The production was first staged over the summer at the Old Vic Theater in London (where Ben Brantley wrote that Mr. Spacey gives fierce and flashy physical life to every twist of a power-mad mans corkscrew mind) and will be the final season of the Bridge Project, a three-year series of collaborations among the academy, the Old Vic and Neal Street, Mr. Mendess company.

title: As Thailand Floods Spread, Experts Blame Officials, Not Rains
description: BANGKOK  As some of Thailands worst flooding in half a century bears down on Bangkok  submerging cities, industrial parks and ancient temples as it comes  experts in water management are blaming human activity for turning an unusually heavy monsoon season into a disaster.

title: Interactive: Insider Trading at Galleon
description: 1:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Vacant Taxi or Occupied? That Is the Question
description: The humble, occasionally head-scratching taxicab roof light is coming in for a makeover. New Yorkers, what would you like to see sitting atop your cab?

title: What Were Reading
description: St. Lawrence University: Each fall, 12 undergraduates are chosen to spend the semester in Arcadia, a camp site deep inside Adirondack National Park where they fend for themselves for four months, studying geology, botany and survival skills. Two current students wrote this account of what they grow, cook (in their yurt kitchen), and eat in the wild.  Julia Moskin

title: U.S. and China Data Highlight Weakness in Global Economy
description: The weakness in the global economy was underscored by reports published Thursday about the balance of trade in the United States and China.

title: Tailgating Recipes: Sausage and Cheese Chowder
Leading Off: Trading Curses
description: You have to hand it to the Red Sox. When the season ended with their historically cataclysmic slide out of a playoff spot, everyone expected some fallout. But the Red Sox drove right by fallout and straight into comical territory, doing everything but erecting a tent and ordering in some elephants.

title: Cubs Shelves Thin, Not Bare
description: Much of the focus of the discussion in regards to Theo Epsteins potential hiring as general manager of the Cubs has been centered around the fact that the team is buried under the weight of bad contracts and that there are no reinforcements on the way.

title: Iran Sees Terror Plot Accusation as Diversion From Wall Street Protests
description: Irans leaders marshaled a furious formal rejection on Wednesday of the United States accusations that the Islamic republic had schemed to assassinate the Saudi ambassador in Washington, calling the case a cynical fabrication meant to vilify Iran and distract Americans from their own severe economic problems, highlighted by the Occupy Wall Street movement.

title: Poetry Pairing | Charms That Forestall Harm
description: TodaysPoetry Pairing matches Linens, a poem by Kay Ryan, with a 2007 article from Science Times, Do You Believe in Magic?

title: A Mushroom Expert Will Answer Your Questions
description: This week, Gary Lincoff  author of the Audubon Societys Field Guide to North American Mushrooms, past president of the North American Mycological Association, and instructor at the New York Botanical Garden  is visiting City Room, to field your questions about local fungi. Submit your questions on City Room.

title: Clifford Chance Hires 3 Ex-Prosecutors
description: Three former federal prosecutors from New York are reuniting in private practice, agreeing to join the law firm Clifford Chance, the firm said on Thursday.

title: In Battle, a Soldiers Heart Is Revealed
description: It is a theme that has been delivered over and over  war brings out the best and worst in people. Watch any old war movie starring Lee Marvin, or read the papers from the early days of the Iraq war, and you will see deeds of valor peppered with foolish and disgraceful acts of cowardice.

title: Looking to Save Money, More Places Decide to Stop Fluoridating the Water
description: MIAMI  A growing number of communities are choosing to stop adding fluoride to their water systems, even though the federal government and federal health officials maintain their full support for a measure they say provides a 25 percent reduction in tooth decay nationwide.

title: Does He Have Your Attention? Alec Baldwin to Host Podcast for WNYC
description: 1:16 p.m. | Updated

title: On a Remote Mountain, Effort to Transition Security to Afghans
description: Observation Post Twins was built for one purpose  to allow American troops to introduce an Afghan security presence into the valley.

title: Preparing for a Way Out of Afghanistan
description: OBSERVATION POST TWINS, Afghanistan  Much of what the Pentagon hopes to accomplish in Afghanistan before withdrawing most of its forces by 2014 is visible from this small, sandbagged mountaintop, where the risks and ambitions guiding the latest effort to reshape a foreign nation are equally clear.

title: The 10 Percenter
description: Henry Louis Gates Jr. is having lunch at New Yorks Union Square Cafe, hoping Danny Meyers chicken soup will soothe his allergies. He has just returned from Newark, where he interviewed Mayor Cory Booker for his new PBS series, Finding Your Roots. After lunch hes catching a flight to Marthas Vineyard for Bill Clintons birthday party. Author of 14 books, editor in chief of the online publication The Root, documentary producer and presenter, Gates, 61, is a one-man multimedia industry.

title: Allen, Coen and May: 3 Wits, One Show
description: THE producers of Relatively Speaking (which opens at the Brooks Atkinson on Oct. 20) have asked me to conduct an in-depth interview with Ethan Coen and Woody Allen, with whom it turns out I have written three one-act plays. I have done this by submitting questions to both men who will presumably answer them in depth. Ive interviewed Woody Allen before but I have only recently met Ethan Coen and we have never spoken although our silence is friendly. My challenge will be to ask the probing questions that will reveal the deeper, more complex nature of both men in a way that will not hurt ticket sales.

title: Chris Martin of Coldplay Asks: What Would Bruce Do?
description: Chris Martin, the lead singer of Coldplay, is one of the worlds biggest rock stars, a species for whom tardiness is all but a right. Yet he was full of apologies when he popped through the door of a Midtown Manhattan restaurant, no entourage in sight, for a recent interview.

title: Case Against Strauss-Kahn Is Dropped in France
description: French prosecutors have dropped an investigation into a claim by a French writer, Tristane Banon, that Dominique Strauss-Kahn tried to rape her during an interview in 2003. The prosecutors office said on Thursday that Mr. Strauss-Kahn admitted to sexual aggression but that the statue of limitations on that charge had expired. Read more

title: Ben Sisario on Coldplay and Mylo Xyloto, the bands new album; Jon Caramanica on the Harlem rapper ASAP Rocky; and the weeks new releases.
