title: New York Times Plans Staff Reductions
description: 12:20 p.m. | Updated In the midst of a deteriorating advertising climate, The New York Times plans to eliminate up to 20 newsroom positions and seek additional savings in the business units, the company said Thursday.

title: Former Ukrainian Premier Faces New Investigation
description: MOSCOW  Ukraines domestic intelligence service said Thursday that it had opened a new criminal case against the countrys former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, less than 48 hours after she was sentenced to seven years in prison in a trial that was widely believed to be politically motivated.

title: Forget All That Stuff About Dirty, Dancing Is Downright Dangerous
description: Nobody can stop the youth of America from dancing, and nobody can stop the American film industry from making movies about people who try. The most impressive thing about Craig Brewers remake of Footloose  the 1984 Kevin Bacon movie with the Kenny Loggins theme song that will now be stuck in my cranium for another 27 years  is that it handles its shaky, shopworn premise with sensitivity and conviction.

description: Laura Phinizy Nix and Gibbs Patton Fryer were married Saturday at St. Stephens Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. David A. Williams, the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

description: Jessica Diane Marshall and Dr. Daniel Patrick OBrien Jr. were married Saturday at Old St. Marys Roman Catholic Cathedral in San Francisco. The Rev. Bartholomew Landry, a parochial vicar at the church, performed the ceremony.

description: Elizabeth Ann Mazzagetti and Keith Eric Waggoner were married Friday afternoon. Msgr. Lawrence Connaughton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in New York, where he is the pastor.

title: P. D. James Writes a Pride and Prejudice Sequel (but No Zombies)
description: In one of the more recent sequels to Pride and Prejudice, Elizabeth Bennet does battle with zombies, so its no great stretch to imagine her as a Regency-era crime sleuth. But the author who has done so is, of all people, P. D. James, the 91-year-old monarch of British crime fiction, better known for her novels about Adam Dalgleish, the brainy Scotland Yard detective who writes poetry on the side.

title: Aniella Gonzalez, Joseph McCart VI
description: Aniella Gonzalez and Joseph Donald McCart VI were married Saturday evening. The Rev. Sammy Chong, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College in Massachusetts.

title: Read Their Lips
description: The photographer Elle Muliarchyk grew up speaking half a dozen languages, from Czech to Vietnamese (her father was a diplomat and her mother was a journalist and a linguist), and during a brief career as a model she picked up some French and Italian. Her experience in the global village of fashion and her interest in languages come together in Lips of Babel, a series of mesmerizing close-up video portraits of models delivering tongue twisters in their native tongues. Tongue twisters are something we all have from childhood, Muliarchyk says, adding that they often say a lot about their culture of origin. One from Nigeria translates as Lady Seamstress, why are you so sad? Did a hen lay an egg on the dress you just made? while another, from India, says, A husband slapped his wife for no apparent reason. News of the project spread quickly through the modeling world  entirely by word of mouth  and Muliarchyk has captured 50 and counting. The first 24 are on view next week at Motilo.com, and one segment is available, above.

title: Faith Salie, John Semel
description: Faith Coley Salie and John Winston Semel are to be married Sunday in Rome. Giulio Mambrini, a friend of the couple who was deputized by the office of the mayor of Rome, is to officiate in the Campidoglio Wedding Hall. Later in the day, Robert Weiss, another friend of the couple, is to lead a separate ceremony with a reading from the Bible and from works of literature in front of family and friends at Casina Valadier, a restaurant in the Villa Borghese park in Rome.

title: Milestones: Michele Bachmann

title: On Our Radar: Invasive Carp Reach North Dakota
description: Asian carp have been found for the first time in the James River in North Dakota, officials from the state game and fish department say. They range from fingerlings that might be this years spawn to older fish of up to 20 pounds. Imported in the 1970s to control algae growth in aquaculture and wastewater treatment facilities, the carp soon escaped and are considered highly invasive species. [The Jamestown Sun]

description: Is Silicon Valley facing a cash crunch?

description: In a push to bring in more foreign investment, North Korean officials guide Chinese business people and reporters on a tour of a free trade and economic zone in the country.

description: TULSA, Okla.  Michele Bachmann was 22 and newly married when, in the fall of 1979, she and 53 other aspiring lawyers arrived on the manicured campus of Oral Roberts University here. They were the inaugural class in an unusual educational experiment: a law school rooted in charismatic Christian belief.

title: After Attacks, Iraqis Return to Normalcy as They Now Know It
description: BAGHDAD  On Wednesday morning, a suicide car bomber struck a police station tucked between a row of upper-middle-class homes and a city block packed with storefronts offering the necessities of urban life: a bakery, barbershop, falafel place.

title: Cody Lindquist, Charles Todd

title: At Some Indian Hotels, Floors for Women Only
description: For women, traveling alone can be challenging. But some hotels, like the ITC group of luxury hotels in India (the ITC Gardenia in Bengaluru is shown at right), are helping to make it more appealing by offering floors exclusively for female guests.

title: Changing What Your Children Choose to Eat
description: Last spring, Allison Robicelli wrote an essay titled Chicken Nuggets and French Fries: Confessions of a Mother and a Chef, on Nona Brooklyn, and Lisa Belkin linked to it here on Motherlode. I read it; many of you did. We sympathized with the chef whose kid loved French fries best, and we had ideas.

title: Florida Governor Wants Funds to Go to Practical Degrees
description: Those students interested in studying anthropology in college may want to do their homework before choosing to do so at a public institution in Florida.

description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Heres That Rainy Day
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. His Phillies homerism is no longer an issue.

title: Notes From the Paddock in Korea
description: YEONGAM, South Korea  Its a long but agreeable train ride from Seoul down to Mokpo, where the Korean Grand Prix takes place at the Yeongam track just outside town. But once at the circuit, you feel a little bit out in the middle of nowhere.

title: Notes From the Paddock in Korea
description: YEONGAM, South Korea  Its a long but agreeable train ride from Seoul down to Mokpo, where the Korean Grand Prix takes place at the Yeongam track just outside town. But once at the circuit, you feel a little bit out in the middle of nowhere.

title: Pedro Almodvar's Skin
description: The director Pedro Almodvar discusses his new film The Skin I Live In.

title: Theater Talkback: Dont Worry About Me  but Get Out of My Spotlight
description: There they go again, stealing the spotlight from their cowed and embittered progeny, the unforgivable but unforgettable monsters Mom and Dad. These Freudian demons have been showing up all over the place for ages, in recurring nightmares, best-selling memoirs and novels and, perhaps most deliciously, on the stage.

title: Iran Scoffs at U.S. Account of Alleged Assassination Plot
description: The government of Iran on Thursday escalated its rebuttal of American criminal charges that it was behind a murder conspiracy in Washington, calling the claims that Iranian agents had plotted to kill the Saudi ambassador with the help of a Mexican drug gang so ludicrous that even politicians and press in the United States were expressing skepticism about such a scheme.

title: Deal With Time Warner Brings the CW to Netflix
description: 2:01 p.m. | Updated Once a Netflix skeptic, Time Warner has struck its biggest deal yet to allow the online service to license its television content.

title: A Beautiful Prisoner Lost in Almodvars Labyrinth
description: Theres an early decisive moment in Pedro Almodvars exhilarating film The Skin I Live In, when Robert Ledgard, a plastic surgeon and madman played with soul weariness by Antonio Banderas, gazes at the image of a woman on the wall of his bedroom. Shes bigger than life, this woman, and more beautiful. He calls her Vera (Elena Anaya), and shes stretched out in the classic recumbent pose of the odalisque: that exotic Turkish harem dweller and Orientalist fantasy painted by the likes of Goya, Ingres and  Manet, and given opulent new life and reverberant meaning by Mr. Almodvar, a master of his art.

title: Petition on Debit Card Fee Attracts 200,000 Supporters
description: An online petition started by a young Washington, D.C., woman opposing Bank of Americas new $5 a month debit-card fee has attracted more than 200,000 supporters  and, according to the organizer, a personal call from a bank executive.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.13
description: Rafael Nadal is upset by Florian Mayer at the Shanghai Masters tennis tournament and the Tigers stay alive in the American League Championship Series.

title: Notes From the Underground | Good to Go
description: The recent Good to Go show at the Bowery Poetry Club was a mishmash of performance types. The evenings host, the Canadian comedy star and television personality Sabrina Jalees, kept the audience entertained with hilarious in-character stand-up sketches, and Ben Lerman, an unassuming guy with a ukulele, sang an unexpectedly gripping story about being Ben Lerman  and playing the ukulele. The show was peppered with original choreography from the Good to Go Girls  Jessy Smith, Molly Merkler and Jillian Hollis (shown here)  a bubbly trio of classically trained dancers whose skits toyed with physical comedy and burlesque. All in all, it was a surprisingly professional and well-curated event from one of downtowns few remaining homes for the obscure.

title: My Three Favorite Recommendations from My Teenage Daughter
description: As a parent, you imagine your children will adopt your excellent tastes, and it can be disheartening when they develop an enthusiasm for Hannah Montana or The Real Housewives of New Jersey (Gilligans Island was so much better). But they can also lead you to some pretty great discoveries. To wit:

title: At Redone Bloomingdales, Hit the Escalators
description: EVERYONE has her own shopping pattern for Bloomingdales, the mother ship on Lexington Avenue and 59th Street, but mine turns out to be not so original. I always head to the contemporary brands on the second floor, skip the third entirely (a bland sea of office clothes) and the cruise designer stuff on the fourth. I have my favorite corners  J Brand and Theory  but I never ventured into the low-ceilinged, crammed denim area. Just too uninviting.

title: In 2008, Cain Endorsed Romney
description: As he competes with Mitt Romney for the Republican presidential nomination, Herman Cain is quick to tick off his list of what makes Mr. Romney unelectable. But Conor Friedersdorf of The Atlantic points out that in 2008, Mr. Cain ignored those same objections and endorsed Mr. Romney over several other candidates, including Representative Ron Paul of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona, who went on to win the nomination.

title: ArtsBeat | Oct. 13, 2011
description: Pacific Standard Time, an art and design festival in Los Angeles, makes a splash in Southern California; and in New York, Chris Mullin, a former N.B.A. star, holds an unusual basketball practice.

title: Tigers Look to Verlander, History for Hope
description: Its come down to this for the Detroit Tigers: lean on their ace, Justin Verlander, for a win Thursday or the Texas Rangers win the American League Championship Series and advance to the World Series.

title: Computer Virus at U.S. Drone Fleet Base Nothing to Worry About, Air Force Says
description: The Air Force acknowledged for the first time this week that a computer virus has infected a network at a base in Nevada where pilots operate armed drones in the skies over Afghanistan by remote control.

title: Slovakia Approves European Rescue Fund
description: BERLIN  Slovakia on Thursday became the final country to ratify the expansion of a European rescue fund, giving the bloc a critical tool to address the sovereign debt crisis and bolster the euro, but one few expect will solve Europes debt problems.

title: Shhh! Dont Name That Auditor
description: Do you know who audits the books of the companies in which you own stock?

title: In African Cave, Signs of an Ancient Paint Factory
description: Digging deeper in a South African cave that had already yielded surprises from the Middle Stone Age, archaeologists have uncovered a 100,000-year-old workshop holding the tools and ingredients with which early modern humans apparently mixed some of the first known paint.

title: As Online Courses Grow, So Does Financial Aid Fraud
description: While serving nine months in a South Carolina prison on forgery charges, Michelle N. Owens capitalized on the explosion in online higher education to tap into a new  and highly lucrative  way to profit from fake documents.

title: England, So Close, Yet So Far
description: Peter Denchs Take on his Homeland

title: Koppel Joins NBCs Rock Center With Brian Williams
description: NBC has added one of TV newss biggest names of the past, Ted Koppel, to the roster of correspondents for its coming prime-time newsmagazine, Rock Center With Brian Williams.

title: Beneath Pedro Almodvars Skin
description: The director Pedro Almodvar goes below the surface with his latest film, The Skin I Live In. The movie, which played at the New York Film Festival and opens Friday, involves a plastic surgeon (Antonio Banderas) and a special woman in his life, Vera (Elena Anaya). Their relationship is complex, to say the least. In her review, Manohla Dargis describes the film as an existential mystery, a melodramatic thriller, a medical horror film or just a polymorphous extravaganza. In this video, Mr. Almodvar talks about how skin factors into the narrative. He also discusses reuniting, after 21 years, with the actor Antonio Banderas for the project.

title: On False Equivalence and False Inequivalence
description: Just over a week ago, I wrote a quick post on a new sociological analysis of organized efforts to sow doubt about global warming. The analysis was illustrated by a flow chart of what the researchers called the climate change denial machine. I added an update a day later describing a chart of the climate alarmism machine created in response by an Australian blogger.

title: Ping-Pong, Anyone?
description: No matter how many tickets and t-shirts a tour sells, the Arctic Monkeys still sleep on the bus.When youre a teenager, you drive in a van from Sheffield to small-town gigs across England, party every night, meet girls: everything moves fast and you like it. Your song about some girl who looks good on the dance floor, which rhymes a reference to the Montagues and Capulets with banging tunes and D.J. sets, leads to Internet fame, the fastest-selling debut in British history and, in 2006, instant, MySpace-amplified international stardom.

title: Gunmen Seize 2 Aid Workers Near Kenya-Somalia Border
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Somali gunmen struck again inside Kenya, abducting two European aid workers on Thursday afternoon from a sprawling refugee camp near the Kenya-Somalia border, officials said.

description: Photographs from Libya, Nepal, Guatemala and New Zealand

title: New Book Covers the Covers of the 1980s
description: Before music came in clouds it came in sleeves. For the iTunes generation this may come as a surprise, but to buy music in the pre-digital era required a trip to a store, where rows of labeled bins held vinyl discs in a variety of formats: long-playing albums, 45s, 12-inch singles. These records, as they were called, came in paper sleeves that were covered front and back with artwork.

description: In Foreign Policy, Nouriel Roubini (a k a Dr. Doom) and Ian Bremmer talk about why Occupy Wall Street actually matters. Roubini says:

title: European Banks Face Deadline to Raise Capital Levels
description: BRUSSELS  Europes banks face a deadline of three to six months to strengthen their balance sheets and to compensate for the decline in value of Greek and other south European sovereign debt, European officials said Thursday.

title: G.O.P. Allies Form House Super PAC
description: In a sign of the intensifying fight for control of the House, allies of Congressional Republicans are forming a new Super PAC to raise and spend unlimited amounts of money to defend the G.O.P. majority next year.

title: Google Said to Be Planning an MP3 Store
description: Five months after it introduced a cloud music service with limited capabilities, Google is in negotiations with the major record labels to expand that service and also open an MP3 store that would compete with Apple and Amazon.

title: Strauss-Kahn Is Not Charged in French Case
description: PARIS  For the second time this year, legal officials chose on Thursday not to prosecute Dominique Strauss-Kahn on charges of attempted rape, despite what investigators here said was evidence of sexual assault, ending months of scandal that have tarnished a political career that once seemed destined to lead to the French presidency.

title: More on #OccupyWallStreet
description: Occupy Wall Street has attracted some famous faces: Slavoj Zizek dropped by over the weekend, and Mark Ruffalo wrote about his time there for The Guardian. Also spotted there: Russell Simmons and Kanye West; Michael Moore, Susan Sarandon, Tim Robbins, even one of the stars of Gossip Girl, whatever that is. Danny Glover visited the L.A. branch of the movement. Food businesses like Ben and Jerrys, Liberatos Pizza and Sixpoint Craft Ales have donated food to the protesters. More should get on board.

title: Spotted on the Street | Bettina May
description: In this new column, the makeup artist Tina Turnbow runs into real beauty on the streets of New York City.

title: Goodell, Union to Meet with Congress on H.G.H. Testing
description: Representatives of the N.F.L., including Commissioner Roger Goodell, and the players union will meet with members of Congress on Friday in Washington to discuss the holdup in putting a blood testing program for human growth hormone into effect.

title: Channel Surfing: Bordertown: Laredo
description: The police-ride-along genre of reality television, somewhat listless of late, gets a nice boost from Bordertown: Laredo, which has its premiere with back-to-back episodes Thursday night on A&E.

title: In American Literature, the Volkswagen Beetle as Muse and Mutant
description: Its hard being a single dad  especially when your son is a 1971 Volkswagen Beetle, says the back cover to How to Keep Your Volkswagen Alive, a new novel by Christopher Boucher (Melville House). However curious the books premise, it works a pretty well-plowed surrealist furrow, hailing back to Kafka and Gogol by way of My Mother the Car and Christine.

title: 36 Seconds in Quebec City
description: A look at the enchanting Francophone capital of Quebec province.

title: 36 Hours in Quebec City
description: Quebec is a city of delightfully stark, yet virtually seamless contrasts.

title: 36 Hours in Quebec City
description: QUEBEC is a city of delightfully stark, yet virtually seamless contrasts; centuries-old fortification walls lead to chic open-kitchen restaurants, and cobblestone streets give way to bike paths and innovative art institutions. The enchanting Francophone capital of Quebec province, and one of the oldest cities in North America, Quebec City received a major face lift before its 400th anniversary in 2008. Perhaps more significant than the new boutique hotels, revitalized parks and gleaming cultural centers was the overdue attention the city finally received, which continues to propel it forward. Quebec City, a historic, cultural and culinary center beside the St. Lawrence River, has emerged from the long shadow cast by its ever popular neighbor, Montreal.

title: San Francisco Seeks Bird-Safe Buildings
description: Like anyone who feels more at home outside than in, Ive spent a considerable portion of my life gazing out windows. (Considerable, I said, not productive).

title: After a Rejection
description: JUST because your mortgage application has been rejected doesnt mean you wont eventually get funding.

title: Looking Inside the iPhone 4S
description: The team over at ifixit, a popular free repair manual Web site, has been busy dissecting Apples iPhone 4S like a frog in a science classroom.

title: Is a Little TV Really That Bad for Babies?
description: Should babies watch TV? Of course, the American Academy of Pediatrics says no. But does no really mean no watching the Republican presidential debate while you nurse the baby, or locking the toddler out of the room while the kindergartner watches Dora the Explorer?

title: Arthur Dubin, Historian of Railroads Golden Era, Dies at 88
description: Arthur Dubin, a leading historian of the golden age of American passenger railroads, when trains bore names like ocean liners and Champagne glasses were filled by elegantly attired servers, died on Oct. 3 at a nursing home in Riverwoods, Ill. He was 88.

title: T Exclusive Video | Laura Marling
description: In this exclusive video, Marling performs Dont Ask Me Why from her third album for T Magazine.

title: Buffetts, Buffetts Everywhere
description: Greg Sargent points us to a new Congressional Research Service report (pdf) showing that there are a lot of millionaires paying lower taxes than many middle-class Americans. On average, the tax code is progressive  but there are a lot of cases where it isnt.

title: TimesCast | October 13, 2011
description: The hedge fund billionaire Raj Rajaratnam is sentenced to 11 years; South Koreas president visits the United States; and Occupy Wall Street protesters and the Tea Party agree on one thing.

title: Hackitude
description: It really is hard having a conversation about, well, anything when the other side just rolls out the talking points instead of discussing the issues. And while I should be used to it, having it happen face to face still gets me. If you want to know what Im talking about, watch Fareed Zakaria this weekend.

title: La Scala Names Barenboim Music Director
description: The Teatro Alla Scala in Milan has appointed Daniel Barenboim as its music director, the first person to hold the title since Riccardo Muti left amid acrimony six years ago. Mr. Barenboim, who is also music director of the Staatsoper in Berlin, will take up the post on Dec. 1, on a five-year contract.

title: California Health Insurer Will Issue Refunds
description: Blue Shield of California, a large nonprofit health insurer based in San Francisco, said on Thursday that it planned to return an additional $295 million to its customers as part of the pledge it made earlier this year to cap its earnings to 2 percent of its revenue.

title: Neighborhood Joint | casaBAN
description: The competition is fierce at an antiques store in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn that specializes in midcentury-modern furniture.

title: Name That Green Space in Queens
description: Feeling inspired? New York City is holding a naming contest for a soon-to-be-unveiled green space in Queens.

title: Cutting Through Cute to the Real Japan
description: ONE thing is certain about the artist known as Tabaimo: her animated videos have never followed the fashion for kawaii, or cuteness, that has ruled Japanese contemporary art for years. Instead, they focus on the anxieties bubbling beneath the surface of everyday life.

title: Occupy Wall Streets Political Disobedience
description: Our language has not yet caught up with the political phenomenon that is emerging in Zuccotti Park and spreading across the nation, though it is clear that a political paradigm shift is taking place before our very eyes. Its time to begin to name and in naming, to better understand this moment. So let me propose some words: political disobedience.

title: Someone Is Stealing Purses at Katzs Deli
description: If she had simply had her hand in the pickle jar at one place  or if she had stuck a finger in the maple-butter dish at the other  this would be a different story, and probably more delectable.

title: Where Grits Days Are Numbered
description: AT 3:30 p.m. on a Tuesday in late September, three men were sitting at the sidewalk tables in front of Tournesol on Vernon Boulevard. Pascal Escriout, the Frenchman who owns the bistro, was sharing a bottle of Bordeaux with a couple of friends  Robert Gonalves, his partner in Domaine Wine Bar a few doors down, and one of the guys from Sweetleaf, the coffee house over on Jackson Avenue.

title: Obama Says Facts Support Accusation of Iranian Plot
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama vowed on Thursday to push for what he called the toughest sanctions against Iran, saying that the United States had strong evidence that Iranian officials were complicit in an alleged plot to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States.

title: The Science of Movies? A Film Festival Judges Just That
description: When Alexis Gambis fell in love with fruit flies, it was a difficult relationship to explain to his friends. So he turned the lab where he was studying the flies genome sequences into a studio and made a film about his passion.

title: A Taste for Modern in Antiques
description: IT may not be Bergdorfs, as its owner likes to joke. But the competitive shopping at casaBAN  an antiques store far from Fifth Avenue, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn  is just as fierce.

title: Sounds for a Samovar: Carnegie Hall Russian Night
description: For all the attention being lavished on Tchaikovskys appearances in the festival that opened Carnegie Hall in 1891 as a pretext for the halls 120th anniversary celebration, Carnegie has made no point of reviving the works the composer conducted, which included his Marche Solennelle, his Third Orchestral Suite and two of his a cappella choruses. But willy-nilly, one of those works did appear on Tuesday evening, when Daniil Trifonov played Tchaikovskys First Piano Concerto with Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Orchestra in the hall.

title: Winners of Oprah Winfreys Ultimate Favorite Things Meet Their Beetles
description: On Thursday morning, 21 people assembled in Orland Park, Ill., a southwest suburb of Chicago, to receive the keys to their 2012 Volkswagen Beetles. The cars were among 276 promised last November as surprise gifts to attendees at a special Ultimate Favorite Things studio taping of The Oprah Winfrey Show, now discontinued.

title: A Fix for Severe iOS 5 Loading Problems
description: A lot of people have experienced problems loading Apples new iOS 5 iPhone and iPad operating system, usually getting an error message and being left temporarily without use of the device. It appears that the demand is overtaxing Apple servers, so some people just cant get to the download, a problem that will clear itself up shortly.

title: Cancer Risk From Barretts Esophagus Lower Than Thought
description: People who have a condition known as Barretts esophagus, a complication of acid reflux disease, have a higher risk of developing esophageal cancer  but the risk is far smaller than widely believed, a new study shows.

title: The Puppy Diaries
description: Chapter One

title: Escape Tactics | Houdini: Art and Magic
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: From Manhattan to Sierre Leone
description: Thomas W. Commeraw, an African-American ceramist in early-19th-century New York, ran a workshop on the Lower East Side waterfront. He painted blue scallops, tassels and petals on beige and tan containers for gallons of oysters, preserved fruit and alcohol, among other products.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Management and Musicians Approve Labor Agreement
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra management and musicians said on Thursday that they had approved a labor agreement that represents a major step toward bringing the orchestra out of bankruptcy court. The agreement would drastically cut salaries, reduce the size of the orchestra and pull the musicians out of the nationwide union pension plan, according to the musicians.

title: Parenting Anew, at a Puppys Beck and Call
description: A few years ago while in Carmel, Calif., I spotted a man struggling to control a golden retriever lunging down the sidewalk on a leash.

title: Catching Up on All the New Facebook Features
description: Over the last few weeks, Facebook has announced so many new features that many users havent noticed them all yet. It didnt help that many of these features were not actually available to most users when they were announced and then talked about all over the Internet. Now that most of them are available to everyone, heres a catch-up list of the new features.

title: A Different Skirmish Over A.T.M. Card Fees
description: The latest skirmish over card fees is about the fees charged at independently operated A.T.M.s  those cash machines not affiliated with banks that you see in convenience stores, hotel lobbies and airports.

title: Google Posts Strong Earnings and Exceeds Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google showed on Thursday that it was making money from people searching online with their mobile devices, providing evidence that it could follow users wherever they searched the Web.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Nepal, Guatemala and New Zealand

title: Excerpt: 'Happy Endings'
description: The ABC sitcom is the only 'Friends' clone left from last season.

title: Hurting at Home, U.S. Ranchers Find Markets in Russia for Their Beef, on the Hoof
description: MOSCOW  American cattlemen are finding homes on a new range  the steppes of Russia.

title: What Should We Ask Siri?
description: In the video above, I get to know Siri, Apples new virtual personal assistant, a little better.

title: Boat Capsizes in Hudson
description: A commercial boat  a tugboat or barge  capsized in the Hudson River on Thursday afternoon, the Fire Department said. Three people were rescued from the water, none of them seriously injured, and no one is missing, the Fire Department said. The boat went down off West 50th Street around 4:30 p.m. and began drifting downriver, a department spokesman said.

title: Dont Give Me What I Want
description: A FEW days before I was dumped, I sat in the campus library. It was the eve of my first chemistry exam that semester. Under the dusty lights of the reading room, I was supposed to be studying. Instead, I stared at the cracked screen of my cellphone, waiting for a call.

title: Insider Trading Sentencing
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the former chief of the Galleon Group, was sentenced to 11 years in prison, a punishment that exceeds any other given for insider trading.

title: A Tough Night for Fox as Well as Tigers
description: With a rain-delayed extra-inning Game 4 of the American League Championship Series between the Detroit Tigers and Texas Rangers forcing its way into prime time on Fox, the other broadcast networks were able to take advantage of an X Factor-less Wednesday night of television (the Rangers eventually won the game, 7-3).

title: Pamela Rosenkranz and Nikolas Gambaroff: This Is Not My Color/The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People
description: Swiss Institute Contemporary Art

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 14-20
description: Movies

title: Night Scented Stock
description: Marianne Boesky Gallery

title: The Other Father of Cubism
description: The Acquavella Galleries splendid Georges Braque exhibition is a 42-gun salute to this pioneering French Modernist. The first large Braque survey to be staged in New York in more than 20 years, it musters a vigorous if compressed account of more than five decades of art making, with 42 paintings and collages, almost all top-notch. More than half have been borrowed from American and European museums; the rest come from private collections and in several cases have not been on public display in quite some time.

title: Christopher DArcangelo: On the Work of ChristopherDArcangelo (1975-1979)
description: Artists Space

title: Bob Dylan: The Asia Series
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: Exploring Truth (and Fiction) Through a Camera Lens
description: In the 1980s photography mutated into a monster that threatened to swallow fine art altogether. In the hands of artists like Cindy Sherman, Jeff Wall, Gregory Crewdson, Andreas Gursky and legions of copycats, photography parsed the days most urgent questions about representation, propaganda, truth and reality. But in the ensuing decades, the answers became increasingly routine, and today the beast that art photography was finds itself tired and toothless.

title: Nicholas Krushenick: A Survey
description: Gary Snyder Gallery

title: Rent vs. Buy
description: For years my colleague David Leonhardt has been helping people calculate whether it makes more sense to rent or buy a home, based on the relative costs of each decision. This week, the economists at Capital Economics noticed an interesting phenomenon related to this tradeoff. For the first time in three decades, the median monthly mortgage payment is about the same as the median rental payment:

title: Gabriel Orozco: Corplegados and Particles
description: Marian Goodman Gallery

title: College Football All  Day  Long
description: If youre at the game or on the couch and in need of real college football analysis or even some wisecracks  or have some of your own to share  Joe Drape and Zach Hillesland will be live-blogging all day on Saturday, with on-site feeds from Pete Thamel at Oklahoma State-Texas and Pete Bigelow at Michigan-Michigan State. Join the party and impress your friends.

title: Ask Pixars John Lasseter Your Questions
description: Pixar Animation Studios, the home of Woody and Buzz, not to mention James P. Sullivan and Nemo, is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year. And its been an impressive run  not one box-office dud among its 12 features (though some critics, including A. O. Scott of this paper, registered their disappointment with this years sequel to Cars). The company, however, is not one to rest on its laurels. Theres a full slate of Pixar films to come, including Brave, the first of its features with a female protagonist. And Finding Nemo and Monsters Inc. will return to theaters in 2012 and 2013 for limited 3-D runs.

title: The Slipcovering of a School
description: THE old New York School of Printing, on 49th Street through to 50th, west of Ninth Avenue, is a modernistic surprise in the tenement miscellany of Hells Kitchen. Opened in 1960, it was designed by Hugh Kelly and B. Sumner Gruzen in two parts, a fluid, guitar-box auditorium set off by a stern, rectangular sweep of glass blocks and steel swing-out windows. Concealed under a plastic screen years ago, the glass blocks were exposed for a while this year, only to be covered up again.

title: 60s Going on 30
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Obsessed Men in Pursuit of Friends With Feathers
description: The Big Year follows three men who are drawn into a vortex of competition, driven to outdo one another in a ruthless yearlong quest for supremacy in a difficult, all-consuming enterprise. They travel North America by foot, bicycle, helicopter and rental car, from the Everglades to the Aleutians, their journeys (and the movie) propelled by an urgent question: Which one will see the most birds?

title: Joshua Stein
description: Mr. Stein, 56, is a commercial real estate lawyer and the sole proprietor of the law firm that bears his name. Before starting the firm over a year ago, he was a partner in the Real Estate Practice Group in the New York office of Latham & Watkins.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Oct. 14-20
description: Pop

title: Theater Listings: Oct. 14  20
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information: nytimes.com/theater.

title: TimesCast | South Korean State Visit
description: October 13, 2011 - South Korea's president comes to Washington, a day after Congress passes a free trade agreement with the country.

description: Jazz
