description: NEW CANAAN

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Oct. 14-20
description: Classical

title: 9 Are Arrested at Protest at Foreclosure Auction
description: It was just after 3 p.m. Thursday in a second-floor courtroom in Brooklyn when an auctioneer announced to a crowd of about 60 people that she would begin selling foreclosed properties.

title: Astrologist Meets Wig Seller in Simmering 60s
description: Change is in the air in Sylvan Oswalds Nightlands, and neither its beneficiaries nor its potential victims know quite what to make of it.

title: Its Not Easy for SEC Quarterbacks
description: ATLANTA  Take any typical quarterback in the Southeastern Conference and there is a decent chance that he had a opportunity to play professional baseball because of his strong arm, but was instead drawn to football by the allure of the big crowds in the SEC.

title: Dear FloFab: How Soon Can I Say Goodbye to Weekend Guests?
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 14-20
description: Dance

title: Honoring a Larger-Than-Life Jazz Trumpeter
description: The guest of honor spoke rarely and succinctly during a concert called Wynton Marsalis at 50 at the Rose Theater on Wednesday night. This seemed to be a minor struggle. I promised Ryan I wouldnt talk tonight, Mr. Marsalis said several times, with a chuckle; presumably he meant Ryan Kisor, his fellow workhorse in the trumpet section of the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra.

title: Q & A
description: Getting a Copy

title: Sometimes Old-Guard Talent Must Lean on New
description: More than a handful of names have been made at the New York Musical Theater Festival. The impish [title of show] duo Jeff Bowen and Hunter Bell, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Next to Normal team of Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey, and the pastiche-happy Altar Boyz writers Gary Adler, Michael Patrick Walker and Kevin Del Aguila all rode the wave of festival hype to acclaim.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 14-20
description: Art

title: Acrobatics, Doll-Like Movements and Coy Gestures
description: Along with Houston Ballets debut at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday evening was another first: the presentation of the inaugural recipient of the Rudolph Nureyev Prize for New Dance, Jorma Elos ONE/end/ONE. I wish Mr. Elos ballet had been one to remember; alas, the grant, worth $25,000, is off to a weak start.

title: A Muse Rekindles That Old Magic
description: THERE was a time in the not-so-distant past when the idea of Suzanne Farrell anywhere but onstage seemed impossible. For more than two decades she was George Balanchines muse, willowy, glamorous and alluringly distant, the face of not only New York City Ballet but also of ballet in America. Then, after she retired in 1989, she seemed to disappear, rarely spotted around a city where she had at one time seemed omnipresent. She once told a journalist that, in between coaching gigs, she enjoyed doing nothing more than playing cards and reading mystery novels.

title: Spare Times for Oct. 14-20
description: Around Town

title: Saved From Extinction: Classics and Curiosities
description: Film preservation takes many forms, some perilously close to Dumpster diving.

title: A Boulevard Changes Direction
description: Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City has resisted change. But now, it is an urban developers dream slowly coming true.

title: A Mixture of Styles and Flows
description: With a political even-handedness that deserves a place in the annals of diplomacy, the Brooklyn Academy of Music is presenting the Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan this week and the Beijing Dance Theater next week. If I too were diplomatic, I would confine my response to Cloud Gates Water Stains on the Wall  choreographed by the companys founder and artistic director, Lin Hwai-min, with its first New York performance on Wednesday evening  to describing the many respects in which it is truly admirable. Instead, however, I start by saying that it left me cold throughout its almost 75 minutes.

title: Bank Rules That Serve Two Masters
description: When there are two powerful factions in Congress, one of which wants to take an action and the other of which wants to avoid it, what should Congress do?

title: A Comeback Hatched in the 2010 A.L.C.S.
description: ST. LOUIS  Lance Berkman of the Cardinals, who on Thursday was named the National League comeback player of the year, took time before Game 4 of the league championship series to ruminate on his turnaround this season.

title: An Altered Pinafore Opens Festival of Arts From Beyond the East Coast
description: Before we get to the PBS Arts Fall Festival, lets take a moment to mention some of the things PBS does well.

title: Sorting Out the Many Sides of a Sculptor
description: Any show with anarchy in its title promises a certain amount of chaos. But even that doesnt prepare you for the confusion of David Smith: Cubes and Anarchy, at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: A High-Rise Change of Plans
description: A suburban house with a big yard  thats what Marisa and Rich Fuller were convinced they wanted. She is from Long Island and he is from New Jersey, and after six years of living in a one-bedroom rental in a Manhattan high-rise, returning to the suburbs seemed like the natural next step.

title: Bach Counterpoint Explored With Violins and Piano
description: The German violinist Frank Peter Zimmermann, who began his season as the New York Philharmonics artist-in-residence with a luminous account of the Berg Violin Concerto last week, returned to Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening for a recital devoted to Bachs Sonatas for Violin and Keyboard (BWV 1014-19).

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Oct. 14-20
description: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS

title: Icahn Seeks to Shake Up Navistar
description: Carl C. Icahn has already had a busy year, having taken aim at companies like Clorox and Forest Labs. That hasnt stopped him from adding yet another target to his portfolio.

title: High Aims for Arts Sake
description: Alfred Stieglitz was a mountainous presence in the landscape of early-20th-century American modernism, as a photographer, as a thinker and as an art dealer  or, as he preferred to see himself, an art advocate occupying hazy terrain between philanthropy and commerce.

title: Leader Named at Solar Company
description: A bankruptcy court on Thursday approved the hiring of a chief restructuring officer at the California energy company Solyndra. R. Todd Neilson, who served as the bankruptcy trustee for the boxer Mike Tyson and the rap impresario Suge Knight, will now lead Solyndra as it struggles to emerge from bankruptcy.

title: From Canada to Meetup.com, the Journey of a Protest Meme
description: It began with an e-mail on July 13.

title: Microdiskectomy
description: A slide show depicting microdiskectomy.

title: Telemundo Plans Its First Presidential Debate
description: Capitalizing on a dispute between Republican candidates and the leading Spanish-language network, Univision, that networks main competitor, Telemundo, has announced that it will host a debate among the Republicans in the presidential race.

title: Now its Mitt Romney vs. Herman Cain as Mr. Cains 999 plan gets more exposure.
description: Now its Mitt Romney vs. Herman Cain as Mr. Cains 999 plan gets more exposure. Political correspondents Ashley Parker and Trip Gabriel, and Deputy Political Editor Paul Volpe join hief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear in Washington.

title: More Than Just Comic Books, but Plenty of Those, Too
description: Cupcake, a cupcake, owns a bakery named Sweet Tooth. He and his friend Eggplant, an eggplant, enjoy a good steam at the Russian baths and they jam in a band with Brown Egg, a brown egg, and Avocado, a  well, you get it. Cupcake also dreams of visiting Turkey to meet Turkish Delight, the greatest pastry chef in the world.

title: Serving Up Comics in Specially-Marked Boxes
description: A marketing mainstay of bygone days, prizes inside boxes of cereal, is alive and well, with brands like the Big G line of cereals from General Mills offering various free trinkets and tchotchkes from time to time.

title: Children of Immigrants Are Focus of City-Backed Education Project
description: At New York City public schools, the dropout rates among children of immigrants are notably higher than that of their peers. Preparedness for college is especially low  only 7 percent of students enrolled in the schools English Language Learners program are ready for college or a career according to state standards, reports Kirk Semple on the SchoolBook blog.

title: Toyota and Honda Bounce Back
description: FOR a car dealer, few things are more frustrating than watching would-be buyers walk away because the particular model they want is out of stock.

title: Kidney Transplant
description: A slide show depicting a kidney transplant.

title: Picasso Will Return With Just Two Colors
description: Never mind that attendance at the Guggenheim Museum in New York is nearly the highest its ever been. When Picasso Black and White opens a year from now, expect a few more.

title: Running the Alco-6
description: A restored vehicle was one of the most famous race cars of its era.

title: Still Flooring It After All These Years
description: YEARS before he won 15 national championships as a driver and became such a wizard with engines that a sheik from Qatar hired him to work on his own dragsters, Frank Manzo was a 16-year-old who liked to hang out at the Sunoco gas station in Matawan, N.J., his hometown.

title: Protesting The Establishment
description: Their politics differ, but the Occupy Wall Street and Tea Party movements agree on one thing.

title: A Vision for Saab, Perhaps Too Late to Save It
description: AT last springs New York auto show, Jason Castriota worked hard. Hour after hour, he stood explaining to group after group of visitors the idea behind his futuristic Saab PhoeniX concept car.

title: Mechanical Wonder From an Age Gone By
description: LONG, strong and dangerous, like a gun barrel mounted on spoke wheels, the coal-black 1909 Alco-6 Racer gleams in the late summer sunlight.

title: Saudi Claims Alleged Iranian Plotter Also Orchestrated Bahrain Unrest
description: Updated | Friday | 11:37 a.m. While a number of prominent experts on Iran are not convinced that the Iranian government really did authorize a plot to assassinate Saudi Arabias ambassador in Washington  with the help of a Mexican drug cartel and a used-car salesman  one well-connected Saudi commentator insists that the scheme was real, and part of a much broader conspiracy against his nation.

title: Hand Splint
description: A slide show depicting the construction of a hand splint.

title: Liposuction
description: This slide show depicts liposuction, the removal of excess body fat by suction using special surgical equipment.

title: Dynasts of the Daily Press
description: In place of press lords the United States has had press families: the Binghams in Louisville, the Chandlers in Los Angeles, the Ochs-Sulzbergers in New York and Chattanooga. None, though, compared in power or zaniness with the family of Joseph Medill at its height. Born in 1823, Medill was a fervent abolitionist, one of the founders of the Republican Party, and is perhaps most notable for having helped put Abraham Lincoln over as his partys candidate in the 1860 presidential election. In 1855 Medill bought a one-third ownership of The Chicago Daily Tribune, and eventually controlled the majority stock in the paper, which he took great care before his death in 1899 to make certain stayed in his family.

title: Protesting the Establishment
description: Their politics differ, but the Occupy Wall Street and Tea Party movements agree on one thing. Kate Zernike reports from Atlanta.

title: Obamas Call to Boehner Goes Off Message
description: President Obama called Speaker John A. Boehner on Thursday to congratulate him on the passage of long-stalled free trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama. But something else the president said rang in Mr. Boehners ears  that Republicans had offered no real alternative to Mr. Obamas $447 billion job creation plan  and the speaker then tried to set the record straight.

title: Connections and Anxieties
description: A look at the work of the artist known as Tabaimo.

title: Georges Braque: Pioneer of Modernism
description: Images from the new exhibition at the Acquavella Galleries.

title: Customers Run Into Trouble in the iCloud
Zynga Is Headed for the Nasdaq
description: Zynga, the online gaming giant, is one step closer to the public markets.

title: Last Resort Remains an Oasis of Dreams
description: Palm Springs-by-the-Sea it is not. That slogan belonged to a vintage advertising campaign, glimpsed in Bombay Beach, for a waterside paradise on the edge of the Salton Sea in the southern California desert. In the 1950s and 60s, this 385-square-mile body of water, created in 1905 when the rampaging Colorado River spilled over its banks, became a celebrity magnet and tourist destination. But its vogue quickly faded.

title: Newest Small Cars Trade on Both Looks and Personality
description: THE Kia Soul has become a star on YouTube: in a television advertisement, the small, angular Soul is driven by hip-hop hamsters through a world of dull cardboard box cars. The Soul stands out as the only cool one  a trucklike car with a pugnacious appearance whose offbeat, almost cartoonish character appeals to young drivers.

title: Characters on Wheels
description: To attract younger buyers, designers are creating distinctive cars with personality.

title: Mopping Up His Life After Years in Prison
description: Youve seen them railing on television: those maniacal shifty-eyed hucksters peddling flimsy abdominal toners that promise rock-hard eight-packs in a matter of weeks when used only five minutes a day.

title: Used-Car Dealers Have a Deal for You. No Kidding.
description: DURING a recent promotion, an auto dealer in Louisville, Ky., sent fliers to a select list of used-car owners and wooed them to his lot with balloons, refreshments and a free toolkit. Salesmen from as far away as Texas were on hand to escort customers to a packed office.

title: What Compromise?
description: THE formula for better fuel economy in cars has long been a simple equation: the smaller the vehicle, the farther it goes on a gallon of gas.

title: How to Prepare for iOS 5
description: Apple has released a major upgrade to its operating system for iPhones and iPads. Called iOS 5, the new software, which is a free download, has more than 200 improvements according to its maker.

title: Academy Unveils Entrants for Best Foreign-Language Film
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences on Thursday announced the 63 films that will be in the running in February for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, so the speculation season is now officially under way. New Zealand, which submitted The Orator, by the Maori director Tusi Tamasese, will be competing in the category for the first time, but the list of nominees, down by two countries compared with last year, includes many familiar names.

title: A Hometown Visit, en Route to the Past
description: Fireflies in the Garden, a family melodrama about coming to terms with your parents (theyre people too, as it turns out), weighs in as such an innocuous appeal to the heart that it hardly seems deserving of the critical lash. The familiarity of its milieu, its characters and their hurts and grievances, recall any number of other movies. Whats striking about this one, though, is how its predictability can seem like a hedge or maybe a defense against the very possibility of surprise.

title: Antiques That Offer a Taste of the Modern
description: I walk by the shop occasionally, and its window display has come to seem like a cruel magic trick. One day, an Indonesian stool stood front and center, begging for a privileged spot in my apartment; the next day, when I returned for a second look, it was gone. I was also obsessed with an edgy rocking chair: printed velvety cushions on a low-slung white frame with clean Danish lines. I had steeled myself to resist, but last week it was still reclining in the window, almost mockingly.

title: A Brutal Home Invasion Breaks Open a Family
description: In the addled mind of the home-invasion thriller Trespass are a few half-baked notions about class warfare in America. Kyle Miller (Nicolas Cage), a loudmouthed wheeler-dealer whose glamorous house is taken over by thieves disguised as policemen, is a shady, fast-talking diamond trader up to his bulging eyeballs in debt. So much for privilege.

title: Preacher Held by Afghan Spy Agency Is Near Death
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An itinerant preacher who had been detained for 12 days by the Afghan intelligence service arrived at a hospital badly beaten, suffering from kidney failure, and slipping in and out of consciousness, said doctors at the hospital and local health clinic where he was treated Thursday. They said they were not sure he would survive.

title: Return of the Video Game Sequel: Part 12
description: There may not be an entertainment category that is so predictable as video games. The latest video game sales figures came out Thursday from NPD, which measures sales of consumer products. And the list of best-selling games looks very familiar, going back many, many years.

title: Hulus Owners Call Off Plans to Sell Company
description: 9:08 p.m. | Updated

title: Couple, Accused of Abducting Their 8 Children, Are Held on $75,000 Bail
description: More than two weeks after they were apprehended in Harrisburg, Pa., with their eight children, whom they were accused of abducting from a foster care facility in Queens, the two parents returned to New York on Thursday for their arraignment.

title: In New York, Comic Con Takes On a Cozier Feel
description: Sometimes it pays to be No. 2.

title: Grit and Homers Carry Tigers Past Rangers
description: DETROIT  Injured, exhausted and facing elimination, the Detroit Tigers went into what could have been their final game of the season needing a strong performance from their ace, Justin Verlander, a revival of their offense and maybe a little luck to stay alive.

title: Mayors Efforts on Oaklands Crime Problem Are Questioned
description: This summer, after the murder of Jesus Campos, an Oakland restaurateur known as Chuy, Mayor Jean Quan called a news conference at Otaez, the popular restaurant in the citys Fruitvale neighborhood where Mr. Campos was gunned down. She offered her solution to violence in the area: surveillance cameras. The installation of cameras and extra police patrols in the district had already caused crime to drop, she said.

title: Drone Attack Kills a Senior Militant Leader in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  A C.I.A. drone strike on Thursday killed a high-level commander in the Haqqani network, the militant group that has been the largest killer of American troops in Afghanistan, American officials said.

title: Debating a Labor Contract on Facebook
description: DETROIT  As Fords 41,000 hourly workers weigh the merits of their proposed four-year contract in plants and union halls across the United States this week, their debates have spilled onto Facebook, providing a glimpse into which issues are influencing their votes most.

title: California Inmates End 3-Week Hunger Strike
description: LOS ANGELES  The hunger strike at California state prisons has ended, the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation said Thursday.

title: Channel Surfing: The League
description: Football season opened last week, and already Week 2 is bringing one of the most complex trades ever engineered in professional sports.

title: For Grieving Madden, a Death in the Family
description: John Madden was an assistant coach at San Diego State working on defensive plans for the next game against North Dakota State when he first met Al Davis.

title: Scientific Trek Turns Into a Game of Spot the Alien
description: In the annals of redundant remakes, The Thing is a particularly irritating example. Though technically a prequel to John Carpenters outrageously effective 1982 film of the same name, this new Thing recycles plot points and regurgitates key effects, albeit with a new-millennium layer of grossness.

title: Q&A: Getting a Response From Stalled Software
description: Q.

title: A Bike to Take You to the Far Ends of the Earth, or the Supermarket
description: BY the laws of probability, you wouldnt expect many Timbuktu-bound motorcyclists to begin their world tours from your local Starbucks parking lot. But thats where youre likely to see their circumnavigation-ready machines, just about any Sunday morning, in just about any blue-state suburb from Scituate, Mass., to Santa Monica, Calif.

title: House Passes Another Bill to Reduce Access to Abortions
description: 8:22 p.m. | Updated House Republicans have had a laserlike focus on dismantling various forms of federal regulations this month, the centerpiece of their job creation agenda.

title: Multitasking on the Slopes
description: Chalet Girl may not be particularly creative or genre busting or even a great example of a romantic comedy. But its premise might make you smile: Kim (Felicity Jones), a girl from the wrong side of the tracks  in this case, working-class London  gets a job at the Austrian chalet of a rich family (Brooke Shields, Bill Nighy and Ed Westwick). There she parlays her skills as a former skateboarding champ into snowboarding, becoming an ace while battling class prejudice and catching the eye of the familys son, Jonny (Mr. Westwick).

title: Cold Pizza from Herm Cain
description: By almost any measure  social, political, economic, logical  Herman Cains 9-9-9 tax plan is nuts, nuts, nuts. Go ahead and jack up the price of nearly everything that moves in the United States with a 9 percent national sales tax on all new purchases and services. Talk about instant branding: every time you buy something, youll be hit with the Herm Cain tax at the checkout line.

title: For Young Offenders, Hope in a Jury of Their Peers
description: Juvenile justice is a field where the cure aggravates the disease. Take a kid of 15 or who shoplifts, gets into a fight, is caught with marijuana or is out at night spray-painting graffiti with a gang. Hes no hardened criminal  yet. After a tour through the juvenile justice system, however, he may well be. Hell be mixed in with real criminals, in an environment where violence is the only path to respect. Hell understand what society expects of him: more crime. Perhaps most important, hell have a criminal record  a major deterrent to getting a job.

title: The Drugs? They Came From the Police
description: The first time he saw the chewing-tobacco can, Steve Anderson, a former undercover police officer, testified, it was in a book bag on the floor of a car that he and other undercover officers were using in a buy-and-bust operation.

title: Resistance From Union in Ford Vote
description: DETROIT  Voting by Fords unionized workers on a new contract has been unexpectedly negative, signaling a rejection of its hold-the-line pay provisions and raising at least the possibility that Detroits fragile labor peace could be disrupted by a strike.

title: Its Expensive and Classy, but Its No Longer a Boat
description: FROM tailfin Cadillacs to the Hummers of the S.U.V. heyday, the principles of auto luxury have been passed down like slab-sided commandments: bigger, stronger, faster.

title: Trudging Through Zombified West Africa
description: The Dead, a zombie movie directed by two British brothers, Howard J. Ford and Jon Ford, was shot in West Africa and uses local people as walking-dead extras. So its scenes frequently feature Africans machine-gunning other Africans or hacking them to death with machetes.

title: Cathartic Stories and Deep Loss
description: LINWOOD, N.J.  When Larry Lhulier succeeded in a campaign to revive a journalism class at Mainland Regional High School this fall, he couldnt have imagined that the biggest story in the 50-year history of the school would unfold before the first class was even held.

title: How You Say It Isnt Clear, Even if Youre From Here
description: To honor the fact that Arizona became a state in 1912, centennial celebrations are being planned in communities large and small, including Casa Grande, a history-rich railroad town surrounded by desert.

title: Trying to Sell Old-School Vinyl and Stay Afloat Financially
description: These are bad times for record shops, but apparently boom times for regret over their demise; if anything it has almost become a clich. The excellent recent low-budget documentary Sound It Out tracked the challenges that one British store owner faces to stay open. Now Happy Life, a no-budget feature set in the debris-ridden precincts of the East Village and Brooklyn, depicts a similar struggle.

title: Squeezed Out in India, Students Turn to U.S.
description: NEW DELHI  Moulshri Mohan was an excellent student at one of the top private high schools in New Delhi. When she applied to colleges, she received scholarship offers of $20,000 from Dartmouth and $15,000 from Smith. Her pile of acceptance letters would have made any ambitious teenager smile: Cornell, Bryn Mawr, Duke, Wesleyan, Barnard and the University of Virginia.

title: Labor Rights, Under Republican Attack
description: In the past month, the National Labor Relations Board has come under furious attack from Republicans in Congress, and decades-old workers rights are at risk. Backed by a well-financed lobbying and publicity offensive, Republicans are using a recent labor-law complaint against Boeing to achieve a radical goal that goes far beyond the legal issues in the case: unraveling workers rights that have been part of the fabric of our social contract since the Great Depression.

title: Behind a Baseball Rivalry, a Battle of Beer Companies
description: Nearly 30 years on, Tony Ponturo still remembers how exciting it was to be recruited for the job of a lifetime. An advertising executive at the agency that handled the Anheuser-Busch account, Ponturo was flown to St. Louis during the 1982 World Series, in which the hometown Cardinals were playing the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Outlook Brightens for U.S. Gas Exports
description: Its enough to make aspiring American natural gas exporters salivate. In Asia, the clean hydrocarbon now fetches four times its price at home. But such a price gap must last decades to justify the infrastructure investments required to make exports possible. Still, surging global demand and booming drilling in the United States mean such outlays might now make sense.

title: Professor Defends Treatment of Stutterer
description: Calling herself the victim of a character assassination, the college professor who asked a student with a severe stutter not to pose questions in class said that her actions were misinterpreted, and that she did not mean to silence him.

title: Dreaming About Dancing the Cha-Cha on the Trading Floor
New Gadgets, Without the New Car
description: TODAY, many new cars come with built-in navigation systems, rearview cameras, apps that connect the vehicle to a smartphone and remote starters. Fortunately, you dont have to buy a new car to add these features, although you may have to enlist the services of a professional installer to get some of these devices working.

title: Privately Owned Park, Open to the Public, May Make Its Own Rules
description: Zuccotti Park, the half-acre plaza in Lower Manhattan now synonymous with Occupy Wall Street, exists in a strange category of New York parkland, identified by a seeming oxymoron: a privately owned public space.

title: Militants Aided by Iran Fired at G.I.s in Iraq, Officials Say
description: BAGHDAD  Militants trained and financed by Irans Quds Force attacked United States forces in Iraq on Wednesday, American officials said, continuing a role they have played in recent years in a proxy war between the United States and Iran.

title: America the Overcommitted
description: Austin, Tex.

title: Builders of Corn Mazes Hope to Lose Visitors, and One Actually Did
description: As corn mazes go, the one on Bob Connors farm in Danvers, Mass., isnt particularly challenging.

title: In New England, Never Hearing the End of It
description: BOSTON  The former manager, Terry Francona, has gone, his future unknown. The former general manager, Theo Epstein, has gone as well, but with a destination (Chicago) and a mission (to win a title for the Cubs.)

title: New Jersey High School Teacher Posts Anti-Gay Entry on Facebook
description: A New Jersey high school teacher became the center of a Facebook controversy on Thursday after writing on the site that homosexuality is a perverted spirit that has existed from the beginning of creation and complaining about a school display recognizing October as Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender History month.

title: In Michigan, Obama Seeks Some Mileage Out of Auto Bailout
description: ORION TOWNSHIP, Mich.  President Obama arrives here on Friday on another visit to Michigan, seeking not only the electoral votes that are essential to his re-election effort, but a platform for a far bigger message.

title: Examining Everything From the Big Bang to Twitter
description: In its frenetic pace and surface-skimming analysis, Connected unfolds like a manic burst of Internet browsing: a cinematic clickstream of Wikipedia-worthy overviews, Facebook family albums and Twitter-sized philosophizing. Directed by Tiffany Shlain  the founder and initial producer of the annual Webby Awards for excellence on the Internet  this documentary essay ricochets among personal memoir, a social topology of the digital era, the evolutionary origins of human civilization and (deep breath) a cosmic history of the universe in the period after the Big Bang.

title: A Serial-Killer Study
description: A good thriller earns its suspense by building toward it. Texas Killing Fields, a serial-killer study inspired by an actual case, takes its suspense for granted, which leaves it weak where it should be at its most chilling.

title: The Banks Falter
description: As the first of the major banks to report its earnings each quarter, JPMorgan Chase is a barometer of conditions in the financial industry. The mercury is falling.

title: Developments Rekindle Debate Over Best Approach for Terrorism Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  The guilty plea by the so-called Underwear Bomber and charges in an assassination plot linked to Iran have added new fuel this week to the simmering debate over whether terrorism cases are better handled in the criminal justice system or by the military.

title: Apocalypse 1861
description: One can only begin to imagine Commander James F. Schencks indignation. Being fired on once without any clear provocation was troubling enough. Being fired on three times while flying a white flag of neutrality  that was an affront to the Stars and Stripes. What had begun as an investigation into the whereabouts of a missing American merchant vessel and its crew, during the summer of 1861 in what is now central Vietnam, quickly devolved into a lesson in respect for Western maritime customs.

title: Lottery Numbers
One Mans Crusade Is More a Portrait of a Land and Its Culture
description: Yandombe, in the Central African Republic, is the stealth star of Lavinia Curriers Oka! This movie may have its leading man and dutifully hit its plot points, but the incidental sights and sounds  the climate, topography, fauna and Pygmy population  largely keep it watchable.

title: Egypts Failing Army
description: The Egyptian Army played a pivotal role during the demonstrations that ousted President Hosni Mubarak when it refused to fire on peaceful protesters. The military was widely seen as respected, competent and able to oversee a peaceful transition to democracy.

title: Taxis Must Accommodate Wheelchairs, U.S. Attorney Says, Supporting Advocates Suit
description: The United States attorneys office in Manhattan said on Thursday that the lack of wheelchair-accessible taxicabs in New York City violated the Americans With Disabilities Act and it urged a federal judge to force the city to quickly address the problem.

title: More Games in Danger, Stern Says
description: N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern upped the ante Thursday in the leagues contentious labor talks with the players union. He said regular-season games may be canceled through Christmas if the two sides do not reach an agreement by Tuesday, when the two sides are set to meet with a federal mediator.

title: In and From Congress, Calls to Limit Pentagon Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Leading members of Congress joined the defense secretary and the new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on Thursday in arguing against any additional cuts in military spending as a special committee seeks to find more than a trillion dollars in new savings in the overall budget.

title: Rabbit-Hole Economics
description: Reading the transcript of Tuesdays Republican debate on the economy is, for anyone who has actually been following economic events these past few years, like falling down a rabbit hole. Suddenly, you find yourself in a fantasy world where nothing looks or behaves the way it does in real life.

title: The Thing Itself
description: Ground zero in Lower Manhattan is a mass grave. So when it came time to rebuild the World Trade Center, the whole enterprise was enshrouded with passion and symbolism. The developers wanted a project that would proudly assert the American spirit. They wanted to send a message that the terrorist damage would not last. They wanted it to commemorate the tragedy and celebrate the revival. Everything, therefore, had to be big: the countrys tallest building, the most expensive commuter rail station, the costliest memorial.

title: After Year of Tinkering, Cardinals Bullpen Takes Shape, Just in Time
description: ST. LOUIS  The final out secured Wednesday night, St. Louis Cardinals reliever Jason Motte patted his fist into his glove softly and repeatedly, as if patiently waiting for a teammate to toss him a ball. No pointing skyward to celebrate his four-out save in Game 3 of the National League Championship Series. No fist-pumping. Nothing demonstrative.

title: Friday: Pilots Point?
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  The last time we saw Caleb Madison at the helm of the J.A.S.A. class, (Across Lite, Solution, blog) he was encouraging them to flaunt their IT factor. Now, with Mr. Madison off getting a good education at Yale, the constructor Ian Livengood has taken over teaching the class, and they continue to construct. Good for them, I say, because they continue to crank out some very nice puzzles.

title: Killing Medicaid the California Way
description: VIRTUALLY all of the debate over the health care legislation enacted last year has focused on the constitutionality of the individual mandate, the requirement that, by 2014, nearly all Americans either purchase health insurance or pay a fine if they fail to do so. The Supreme Court now seems likely to decide the fate of the mandate, perhaps as early as June.

title: Dennis Ritchie, Trailblazer in Digital Era, Dies at 70
description: Dennis M. Ritchie, who helped shape the modern digital era by creating software tools that power things as diverse as search engines like Google and smartphones, was found dead on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley Heights, N.J. He was 70.

title: April 3, 1968. Lorraine Motel. Evening.
description: Even before the first flash of lightning  and there will be plenty of that before evenings end  an ominous electricity crackles through the opening moments of The Mountaintop, Katori Halls surprisingly thin new play about a monumental subject, which opened on Thursday at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater. Its not that what were looking at appears in itself to be fraught with significance. Its only a generic, dirt-toned motel room, depressingly familiar in its seediness.

title: Common Sight for Some Subway Riders: Broken Elevators and Escalators
description: At the Delancey Street subway station in Manhattan, the escalator works so infrequently that Karen Lee Benson tries to avoid using that stop unless her husband is with her. Consider the alternative: a 60-stair hike to the street with her two sons under 3 and their strollers.

title: Consumers Right to Sue
description: The question of how far companies can go in taking away their customers right to sue returned to the Supreme Court this week. The case involves a subprime credit card company called CompuCredit, which was sued by three customers in federal court for deceptive practices under the 1996 Credit Repair Organizations Act.

title: Goodell and Union to Meet With Congress on Blood Testing
description: Representatives of the N.F.L., including Commissioner Roger Goodell, and the players union will meet with members of Congress on Friday in Washington to discuss the holdup in starting a blood-testing program for human growth hormone.

title: Second Chances After Prison
description: With state prison costs driven mainly by recidivism, the federal government must do all it can to support programs like the Second Chance Act, which guides newly released prisoners to drug treatment, mental health care, housing and jobs to keep them from going right back to jail. The House, which supports continued funding, must hold fast against a Senate appropriations bill that would zero out this important program.

title: Complications of Groping Inquiry Underscore Diverse Nature of Serial Molesters
description: The police have called it Pattern No. 9: a dozen sexually oriented attacks that have sent fear across several Brooklyn neighborhoods, and wrought responses by grass-roots organizers and political and religious leaders aimed at stopping or catching the serial gropers.

title: Why Republicans Killed the Jobs Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlantic 10 Bringing a Bounce to Brooklyn
description: The Atlantic 10 mens basketball coaches gathered at a hotel in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge on Thursday to smile for television cameras, dispense radio sound bites and press the flesh with newspaper reporters at the conferences media day.

title: Assemblyman Appears Ready to Join Race for Congress
description: Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, calling Congress a swamp of dysfunction, has begun accepting contributions for a race against a fellow Democrat, Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn.

title: Mad Men (and Women) in Cleats: Selling the Sizzle
description: Who are the most popular soccer players in the United States? Forget inquiring minds. Marketers and advertisers want to know.

title: Barriers to Bringing Real Change to Myanmar
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pricey Cable Corral for Neatniks
description: If you seriously hate tangled earphone cables, a pricey little retaining strap may be your ticket to cable cleanliness.

title: Evidence of Domestic Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Offshore Tax Loopholes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Elections in Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: Custody Battle May Have Fueled Killings at Salon, Victims Kin Say
description: LOS ANGELES  The gunman who killed eight people at a Seal Beach, Calif., hair salon on Wednesday may have been enraged by a custody fight with his former wife, who worked at the salon, according to friends and family members of some of the victims.

title: Riding a Horse as Far as Hell Go
description: DETROIT

title: Massachusetts Senate Approves Casino Measure
description: BOSTON  The Massachusetts Senate passed a bill on Thursday that would legalize casino gambling, paving the way for three resort-style casinos and one slots parlor in the state.

title: Battle for Libya | October 13, 2011
description: Anti-Qaddafi fighters continued to battle loyalist forces in Surt and take care of their injured.

title: Eating Disorders a New Front in Insurance Fight
description: People with eating disorders like anorexia have opened up a new battleground in the insurance wars, testing the boundaries of laws mandating equivalent coverage for mental illnesses.

title: Democrats and Weprin Outspent Turner to Replace Weiner
description: Democrats poured $1.5 million into their failed attempt to retain the Congressional seat last held by Anthony D. Weiner, vastly outspending the Republican candidate, Bob Turner, who ultimately prevailed in New Yorks Ninth District.

title: NYT Front Page for 10/14/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 10/14/2011

title: Economic Malaise in Uganda
description: The Ugandan shilling is one of the worlds worst-performing currencies against the dollar this year, and the overall economic malaise is fueling an urban protest movement that has become the longest in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Discontent Simmers in a Market as Ugandas Economy Staggers
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Sam Katende wipes his brow as a burst of steam from his frying pan blows into his face.

title: Tailgating Crowds Unlikely Roar: Ahoy!
description: SEATTLE  The University of Washingtons football stadium loomed ahead, beyond the traffic, as the Miles family steered toward its usual parking spot one Saturday last month. For 50 years, the family members have arrived at Huskies home games through this entrance the same way: grill gassed, coolers stocked with microbrews, clad entirely in purple.

title: Hedberg Replaces Brodeur and Saves Everything
description: NEWARK  The backup Devils goalie Johan Hedberg knew for days that he would not be starting on Thursday against the Los Angeles Kings, but he always tries to be ready just in case. The preparation paid off when Hedberg replaced an injured Martin Brodeur, stopped all 16 shots he faced in regulation and two more in a shootout to give the Devils a 2-1 win.

title: Huskies Tailgating Crowd Sets Sail
description: Boaters are putting a twist on tailgating at University of Washington football games.

title: Egypts Arrests of Smugglers Show Threat of Libya Arms
description: CAIRO  Egyptian Interior Ministry officials acknowledged on Thursday that they had arrested five small groups of smugglers transporting weapons from Libya, including antiaircraft missile launchers, across Egypt toward its border with Israel, raising new concerns about security in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Egypt Promises to Address Coptic Christians Concerns
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian government pledged on Thursday to investigate all disputes over the building of churches around the country as hundreds of people gathered in Cairo to mourn the two dozen Coptic Christians who were killed on Sunday night in clashes with the military at a demonstration over one such conflict.

title: Evan Lamberg to Lead Universal Music Publishing
description: The Universal Music Group has named Evan Lamberg the president of its publishing unit in North America, the company announced on Thursday, in the latest in a series of management changes at the worlds biggest music company.

title: Clashes in Syrian Uprising Leave at Least 14 Dead
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces clashed with army defectors in southern Syria on Thursday and killed at least 14 people elsewhere including an 18-month-old boy, rights activists and residents of the affected areas reported.

title: Friday Night Blight
description: Saturday night has long been the loneliest night of the week in the television business, but lately its been joined by another evening pining for viewers: Fridays.

title: Georgia: Licenses Suspended in Cheating Scandal
description: The first formal repercussions from a cheating scandal in the Atlanta school district were handed down Thursday by the Georgia Professional Standards Commission. Eleven teachers who were accused of changing scores on state standardized tests will lose their licenses to teach for two years. Three people in leadership positions in schools where cheating was discovered have lost their licenses permanently, said Kelly Henson, executive secretary of the commission. The commission is expected to review approximately 200 teachers and administrators, using information gathered by state investigators. About 120 educators named in the report remain on paid leave. Some educators might also face criminal charges.

title: Rookies Crash Course in Life in the N.F.L.
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jeremy Kerley has three receptions for 35 yards and one touchdown in his five-game N.F.L. career  or 934 receptions, 11,971 yards and 65 touchdown catches fewer than Derrick Mason has in his 223-game career over 15 seasons.

title: Mexico: Suspect Arrested in Casino Fire
description: The army said Thursday that it had captured the man responsible for an arson attack on a Monterrey casino that killed 52 people. The suspect, Carlos Oliva Castillo, known as The Frog, a leader of the Zeta drug organization, was arrested in Saltillo on Wednesday after hours of shootouts between soldiers and gang members. The authorities have arrested 11 others, including a state police officer, in connection with the August casino attack, one of the worst attacks by organized crime on unarmed civilians in Mexicos history.

title: The Mayor Stands Firm Against the Lobbying of Puppy-Dog Eyes
description: They curl up on the fringes of New York City royalty, positioned to eavesdrop on conversations no one else can hear, but unlikely to pass along the details. They come from a well-worn class of political companion, intended to generate sympathy for even the surliest of leaders, but have failed to persuade the citys first man to accept them as his best friends. They stand, and sit, as symbols of compromise in the private life of an uncompromising mayor.

title: Pennsylvania: Gas Company Sues Over Zoning Rules
description: Range Resources, a natural gas drilling company, has filed suit against Cecil Township, saying it did not follow proper legal procedure while drawing up zoning rules that would regulate gas drilling, a company spokesman said. The suit, which was filed on Wednesday in Washington County Court, adds to the growing debate over how much municipalities can regulate land use as drilling in the Marcellus Shale ramps up. This summer, Range sued South Fayette, another western Pennsylvania town, over its zoning ordinance.

title: News Corp. Hits a Bump as Investors Prepare to Meet
description: The European edition of The Wall Street Journal accounts for less than 1 percent of total business at its parent company, the News Corporation. But the controversy this week over an unorthodox circulation deal that resulted in the resignation of the newspapers publisher could carry outsize influence among investors already concerned about ethical practices at the company, analysts said Thursday.

title: Chile: Land Donated for Giant Telescope
description: European astronomers said Thursday that they had taken another step toward the construction of the largest optical telescope on the planet on a mountain in Chile. Known as the European Extremely Large Telescope, it would feature a segmented mirror 131 feet across that would dwarf any that exist or are currently planned. Astronomers say the giant telescope will be able to study planets around other stars. Alfredo Moreno, the Chilean minister of foreign affairs, signed an agreement with the European Southern Observatory, a consortium of 15 nations, donating 189 acres of land around the Cerro Armazones mountain for the telescope, in exchange for 10 percent of the observing time on it. Pending final approval by the European consortium, the billion-dollar telescope could begin operating early in the next decade.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,470 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,789 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Inflation in China Eases, but Food Prices Up Sharply
description: HONG KONG  Inflation slowed slightly for consumers last month in China and slowed a little more at factories, as stringent controls on bank lending and a gradually strengthening currency began to tame strongly rising prices, data released by the Chinese government on Friday showed.

title: Italy: Premier Faces Confidence Vote
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said Thursday that his government was the only credible alternative capable of leading Italy through the economic crisis. His government faces a confidence vote in Parliament on Friday. If he loses it, he will be forced to step down. On Tuesday, the government unexpectedly failed to pass routine legislation, prompting the call for the confidence vote.

title: Occupy San Francisco Is Nothing Like the Old Days
description: Call it occupation envy.

title: Philo Dibble, Diplomat and Iran Expert, Dies at 60
description: Philo Dibble, a career Foreign Service officer who played a central role in the release of two American hikers who had been held in an Iranian prison for more than two years, died at his home in McLean, Va., on Oct. 1, 10 days after the hikers were freed. He was 60.

title: President Clinton Sees Golf as a Path to Fitness for All
description: Before he turned to politics, former President Bill Clinton caddied at the Arlington Hotel Open, also known as the Hot Springs Open, an Arkansas stop on the PGA Tour in the late 1950s and early 1960s.

title: Seeking a Balanced Diet of Permits and Empanadas
description: As citizen uprisings go, it was rather scrumptious. Instead of chants and bullhorns, the protest in San Franciscos Lower Haight on Oct. 2 featured bourbon apple walnut crumble pie and Madagascar vanilla ice cream con sea salt.

title: Law Intends to Cut Down on Vehicles Impounded
description: Vehicle seizures in the Bay Area have been more common than sobriety tests at checkpoints during the past decade. Tens of thousands of unlicensed drivers across California have had their cars impounded, and cities have reaped millions in revenue.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
description: The Supreme Court on Thursday asked why no action was taken on the Nov. 2, 2007, letter written by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to former Telecom Minister Andimuthu Raja favoring the transparent sale of valuable spectrum  transmission airwaves  by auctioning it. (The Hindu) The problem could have been prevented if Mr. Singhs advice was taken and Mr. Raja was not allowed to follow the first-come, first-served policy, according to the judges.

title: Turning to a Support Group to Deal With Celibacy
description: Publicly, he is a religious brother with a Roman Catholic order.

title: New President for HBO Sports
description: HBO Sports reached out to its rival, Showtime, for a new president with the hiring of Ken Hershman to replace Ross Greenburg. Nearly three months ago, Greenburg resigned after 33 years at HBO Sports, the last 11 years as its president. Hershmans portfolio has included boxing, where HBO has long been a leader, and mixed martial arts, which HBO has not entered.

title: Cant Get into D.U.? Try an Ivy League
description: Moulshri Mohan was an excellent student at one of the top private high schools in New Delhi, writes Nida Najar in this New York Times article about a surge in Indian students applying to American colleges.When she applied to colleges, she received scholarship offers of $20,000 from Dartmouth and $15,000 from Smith. Her pile of acceptance letters would have made any ambitious teenager smile: Cornell, Bryn Mawr, Duke, Wesleyan, Barnard and the University of Virginia.

title: Lower Medicaid Dispensing Fees May Pressure Pharmacies
description: In Rio Grande City, Rene Martinezs Starr Pharmacy has one line for Medicaid patients and another for non-Medicaid patients. On some days, most of his clients can be found waiting on the Medicaid line, a testament to the importance of that federal-state health insurance program in this poor city along the Texas-Mexico border  and to Mr. Martinezs bottom line.

title: Oct. 14, 1964 | Martin Luther King Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
description: On Oct. 14, 1964, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was named the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize. The Oct. 15 New York Times quoted the civil rights leader: I do not consider this merely an honor to me personally, but a tribute to the disciplined, wise restraint and majestic courage of gallant Negro and white persons of goodwill who have followed a nonviolent course in seeking to establish a reign of justice and a rule of love across this nation of ours.

title: The Sweet Science of Body and Soul

Men with hats, stogies and secrets. The leonine and the louche. Wiry trainers possessed of supreme cool and confidence.

title: A Girl Not Named Sybil
description: What about Mama? the psychiatrist asks her patient. Whats Mama been doing to you, dear? . . . I know she gave you the enemas. And I know she filled your bladder up with cold water, and I know she used the flashlight on you, and I know she stuck the washcloth in your mouth, cotton in your nose so you couldnt breathe. . . . What else did she do to you? Its all right to talk about it now. . . .

title: Women in India: Bringing in the Other Half
description: When put in charge, women in India are better than men at providing clean water and adequate sanitation for their communities. And despite the gains women have made in the developed world, theyre still doing about as much of the housework and childcare as women in India.

title: Annual Art Fair Sprawls Across Paris
description: Always an art lovers paradise, Paris outdoes itself during the sprawling International Contemporary Art Fair, or FIAC, one of the worlds grandest such events, which will be held this year from Oct. 20 to 23. Centered in the glorious  and recently renovated  Grand Palais, it also extends to the Jardin des Tuileries, Jardin des Plantes, the Museum of Natural History and other institutions throughout the city. Altogether 168 galleries from 21 countries will show paintings, sculptures, installations and more ephemeral works of art.

title: Founder of Scarsdale Concours Retains a Soft Spot for Classics
description: When Evan M. Cygler and his fellow Scarsdale High School classmate Denis OLeary III decided in 2003 to put together the first Scarsdale Concours dlgance, Mr. Cygler figured that if it was successful, it might come back for a couple years, raise a little money for Westchester County charities and provide some entertainment for the two car enthusiasts  who at the time were 15-year-old sophomores  before they left for college.

description: 49ers (4-1) at Lions (5-0)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Lions by 4.

title: Comrade Liberty
description: Approaching the Statue of Liberty by boat for the first time in 1999, Wang Qingsong had visions of Botticelli. It was just a little bit like The Birth of Venus, he said. It was a goddess born from the water.

title: Reader Responses: A Total Collapse
description: An otherwise-healthy man one night discovers he cant stand up. Readers weighed in on what the cause could have been.

title: The Land of Milk and Money
description: Fredy Harianto was one of 30 or so people who congregated at the headquarters of Boot HK, an incubator for Internet start-ups in Wan Chai, one of Hong Kongs many business districts, to hear a lecture on how to create a punchy, likable corporate blog voice. The attendees were mostly young; each had sharp clothes and impeccable posture. Only two were born in Hong Kong.

title: Ask the Contractor
description: THE PANEL:

title: Brazil Makes Its Own Manhattan
description: So Paulo is almost beyond the imagination  a drizzle-shrouded megacity of almost 20 million that sprawls like Los Angeles and boasts enough skyscrapers to vie with New York. The gritty financial engine of the new Brazil, So Paulo exerts influence over commerce, media and culture. The Brazilian writer Roberto Pompeu de Toledo calls it an urban labyrinth that reaches toward the infinite. It might not have the palm-fringed glamour of Rio de Janeiro, but in the view of urbane Paulistanos, Brazil has only one truly global city: theirs.

title: Melissa McCarthy Can Take a Joke
description: At St. Francis Academy, the Catholic girls high school you attended in Illinois, you played tennis and were the captain of the cheerleading team. Then you suddenly quit to become a sullen Goth. Why? I remember being in a pep rally, and I heard one of the coaches of the boys teams making a dumb joke about the dumb cheerleaders, and I thought, Are you kidding me? Im out there doing back handsprings and aerials on blacktop to cheer for your stupid team that, by the way, is not doing that well. And youre in here with the guys making fun of it? I was like, Im done.

title: Food and Drink
description: I loved Sam Siftons description of family dinner in his home and the pictures of other families sharing the meal. My husband is a lawyer with a long commute who returns home long after the children are in bed. We often have a nice family dinner on the weekends, but sitting down together once a week was not enough, so we have tried to make breakfast our family meal of record. It may only be granola and orange juice, but we are around the table, and the television is off. I know that this has a direct impact on our present relationships, because when attitudes get bad in our family, we often realize that we have been short-shrifting family mealtime. It is also a big help that this reduces some of Dads guilt about not being home earlier most nights.

title: The Curious Case of Ryan Gosling
description: In the Danish director Nicolas Winding Refns Drive, Ryan Gosling is a stunt driver and part-time mechanic who moonlights as a wheelman for thieves (when hes not tooling around late-night Los Angeles listening to moody, synthy pseudo-80s tunes). In George Clooneys Ides of March, Gosling is a whiz-kid political operator drawn into campaign-trail bloodsport. Weve all seen enough movies centered on these archetypes  the rigorously self-controlling loner caught up in a heist gone bad; the idealist tested by the way the real world works  that by now we think we know them like old friends. But in Goslings hands, these characters seem unknowable and unresolved and volatile. He plays them as men whose easy charm and surface gentleness conceal a capacity for unexpected brutality, whether professional/moral (Ides of March) or skull-stompingly physical (Drive.) Theyre golden-retrieverish golden boys with the potential to burn the world down.

title: A Total Collapse

title: What You Get for $300,000 in....
description: Listings for New York, Seattle, San Francisco and 9 other locations.

title: Joint Venture
description: I smoke a fair amount of marijuana. Sometimes I ask my friends if they want me to pick up weed for them as well, in which case they give me the money upfront. As with any other commodity, prices are usually cheaper when buying in bulk. I will often not give the change to my friends and instead use those few dollars to further my own discount. Is this unethical? Im the one going through the effort of gathering buyers and conducting the illegal transaction. Or does that just make me a drug dealer? NAME WITHHELD

title: The Right Moves
description: In the video for Losing My Religion  the song that would finally make R.E.M. a household name, even in my own rural Midwestern house  Michael Stipe spends the first couple of minutes slouched in a chair and pacing the rough wooden floor of a big, empty room. While he sings, he flaps his arms a little at the elbows. Occasionally, his bandmates appear, all wearing white shirts like Stipe, accessorized with a jacket, pants with pleats or vests. It was the early 90s. In the video, its raining outside. For some reason, theres a pitcher of milk on the windowsill.

title: Gerties Ghost
description: In 2000, Bokara Legendre, an artist and a stage performer, inherited her familys plantation in the Lowcountry of South Carolina. She promptly set about making the place her own, redecorating the antebellum mansion with abstract paintings and a pastel color scheme. But this seemed to unsettle the house. The first night Legendre spent in her redone bedroom, there was a problem with the fireplace, and the chamber filled with thick black smoke. As a member of the plantation staff put out the fire, he glimpsed an apparition: the late mistress of the house, Legendres mother, Gertie. She was not pleased with the changes.

title: Do Attractive People Have Advantages Others Dont?
description: A new study has concluded that wearing makeup makes women more likable. Does this match your own observations? Why might cosmetics affect how a person is perceived?

title: From Oil and Gas Revenue, the Greenest of Schools
description: When students returned to school this fall in rural Mosca, Colo., they had plenty to cheer about besides the Thunderbirds, their football team. In August, the school district completed construction of the new Sangre de Cristo K-12 school, replacing an old metal building that more closely resembled a potato cellar, according to some students, referring to the low, dark warehouses for storing one of the regions primary crops.

title: Mad About Her: Pauline Kael, Loved and Loathed
description: THE longtime New Yorker film critic Pauline Kael didnt just write about movies  she made it seem as if they were worth fighting about. Nearly 20 years after her retirement and a decade after her death, she remainsan often polarizing figure. On Oct. 27, the Library of America will publish The Age of Movies: Selected Writings of Pauline Kael, followed four days later by the publication ofPauline Kael: A Life in the Dark, a sometimessurprisingbiography by Brian Kellow, from Viking. A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis discuss her work and its legacy.

title: An Imaginary Ratchet
description: One thing Ive been seeing in responses to the argument that Keynesianism is necessarily about favoring big government  it isnt  is the assertion that it actually is in practice, because Keynesian policies lead to rising spending in slumps that isnt withdrawn when the economy recovers.

title: Pension Funds Challenge News Corporation Board
description: A week before the News Corporations annual shareholder meeting, the company is facing a growing chorus of investors rallying against company leadership after a phone-hacking scandal in Britain and a controversy this week over an unorthodox circulation arrangement in Europe.

description: Via Charlie Stross, I see that the Murdoch empire has another scandal  this time involving misleading advertisers rather than readers, by inflating circulation numbers. Wow.

title: Record Prison Time for Rajaratnam
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group chief at the center of the United States massive insider trading investigation, was sentenced to eleven years in prison. His sentence is the longest ever for insider-trading in the United States, and follows a ten-year term for Zvi Goffer, a hedge fund manager at Galleon.

title: Give Young Boys in Morocco a Camera ...
description: FOR the last five years the Spanish filmmaker Oliver Laxe has lived mainly in the northern Moroccan city of Tangier, where he developed a film workshop at a shelter for disadvantaged children. At first glance, Mr. Laxes debut feature, You All Are Captains, looks to be a straightforward reflection of this experience: he appears as himself, lecturing on photographic optics and showing his young charges, all preadolescent and adolescent boys, how to operate a 16-millimeter camera.

description: IN 1966, the bravest man in movies must have been Alex Cord, the Long Island native who stepped into the John Wayne role in Gordon Douglass color and CinemaScope remake of John Fords 1939 Stagecoach.

title: To Indian Students, Harvards Admission Rate May Appear Almost Welcoming
description: In a front-page article on Friday reported from New Delhi, Nida Najar writes of selectivity rates at Indian universities that have driven some students to find refuge at American colleges, whose admissions rates may look welcoming by comparison.

description: The owner of a French restaurant in San Diego, whose arrest on charges of employing undocumented immigrants gained national attention and sent a tremor of fear through the restaurant industry, pleaded guilty to some of the charges Thursday.

title: Getting the Booster Seat Right
description: Time to review the booster seats. Thursdays Washington Post reported on the most recent booster seats evaluations from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, and while more booster seats than ever were best bets, meaning that they position a safety belt properly in most cars, many (including ours) were rated check fit.

title: With Cleanup Postponed, Joy and Tension in Zuccotti Park
description: After fears of eviction, Occupy Wall Street protesters celebrated, marched and continued their protest in Downtown Manhattan.

title: Picture This: New Star Wars Comics, and Graphic Novels of Stieg Larssons Trilogy
description: When moviegoers were first introduced to Star Wars in 1977 they were promised a story that took place a long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away. At the New York Comic Con on Friday, Dark Horse is revealing a new comic book series, Dawn of the Jedi, that explores the Jedi myth long before Luke Skywalker took his first step.

title: Churches Take Steps to Show Their Love for Animals
description: As a boy in San Antonio, Paul Flotron helped his family raise miniature schnauzers. He was there for the dogs births, and his family showed the dogs at competitions all over Texas. When he was 10, his family moved to St. Louis, where he accumulated the Flotron Miniature Zoo, including dwarf crocodiles, African pancake tortoises, birds, boa constrictors, hermit crabs, fish, and always dogs.

title: For Dispirited French Voters, None of the Above Seems Best
description: PARIS  This is a grumpy French presidential campaign, with only a few voters passionate about their choices.

title: Leading Off: The Base That Roared
description: With all the nutty, quirky things that happen in baseball, its hard to manage something truly stupefying. Once youve seen a squirrel influence the outcome of a playoff game, a moth lodge in a pitchers ear and not come out, gnats take out a dynasty and, of course, Bartman, well, what can truly surprise you?

title: Requiem Lass
description: I met Patti Smith at the Electric Lady recording studios on West Eighth Street in Manhattan on a sunny August afternoon. Both the place and the date have a special significance in Smiths personal mythos and in the broader mythology of rock n roll. The facility, which you enter through a nondescript storefront on a once famously scruffy block now given over to discount shoe stores and student-friendly eating places, was Jimi Hendrixs brainchild, and it stands as an enduring part of his legacy. A rack in the reception area is stocked with foldout LP sleeves of some of the legendary records that were cut here  Stevie Wonders Talking Book, AC/DCs Back in Black, David Bowies Young Americans  and the psychedelic murals that Hendrix commissioned line the subterranean hallways leading to Studio A. There, his portrait hangs in the lounge, a benevolent godhead gazing down at the latter-day strivings of his fellow musicians.

title: Wider, Wedgier BMW 3 Series Gets a 4-Cylinder Engine for 2012
description: The sixth iteration of the BMW 3 Series sedan, arriving at United States dealers in February, has grown bigger in terms of wheelbase and overall length, smaller in terms of the engine bay and more efficient all around. It remains, however, thoroughly recognizable as the brands volume-leading saloon.

title: Location-Based Services Can Put Businesses on the Map
description: Although Starkville, Miss., is home to Mississippi State University and the fighting Bulldogs, its not a large city with a dense urban epicenter  the typical playground for those who use location-based marketing services such as Gowalla and Foursquare.

title: For U.S.C., Injuries and Inconsistency
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As showcase games go, the tussle between U.S.C. and Cal on Thursday night functioned more as a display of the middling Pac-12. With Stanford and Oregon legitimate top 10 teams and Arizona State lingering in the top 25, the rest of the Pac-12 has looked fairly lackluster this year.

title: A War Injury With a Big Impact: The Plain Old Headache
description: Ask anyone about the signature wounds of the current wars and the list is likely to include lost limbs, traumatic brain injury, post-traumatic stress, back strains and knee pains. But a new study from Johns Hopkins University says the plain old headache has been a leading cause of attrition in units deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: A White House Debut for Doo.Ri
description: Michelle Obama has not been entirely consistent when it comes to dressing for state dinners. Since the considered choice of a gold gown by Naeem Khan, a designer with Indian roots who is based in America, for the first dinner for the prime minister of India in November of 2009, she has mixed things up, wearing Peter Soronen to a dinner for the Mexican president, and that controversial Alexander McQueen dress for the president of China. She wore another dress by Mr. Khan to a dinner for the chancellor of Germany.

title: Hbbe Signs On for Five More Years at Royal Danish Ballet
description: Nikolaj Hbbe, 43, the popular former principal dancer at the New York City Ballet, has extended his term as artistic director at the Royal Danish Ballet for another five years, the company said on Friday.

title: Police Clear Protesters From Denver Park
description: While protesters in Wall Street gained a last minute reprieve and averted a showdown with police on Friday morning, those gathering in Lincoln Park in Denver were not so lucky.

title: Is Verizon Out Again?  Madison Ave. Cant Connect
description: At Bistro Chat Noir, an upscale French restaurant on Manhattans Upper East Side frequented by celebrities like Woody Allen, Madonna and Natalie Portman, the phone and Internet service is often out, so credit cards cannot be processed. When that happens, Suzanne Latapie, a manager and one of the owners, asks customers to fill out forms with their credit card information, so she can process payments later, sometimes using a neighbors Internet line.

title: Veterans Hurt Locker Lawsuit Dismissed
description: Score one for the screenwriter. A United States District Court judge in Los Angeles has dismissed a lawsuit by an Iraq war veteran, Sgt. Jeffrey Sarver, that claimed the film The Hurt Locker was based on him without his permission and that he had suffered ridicule because of it and was denied employment.

title: Sardinia, Remembered
description: A visitor fondly recalls the crystal-clear water in deserted coves of the Maddalena archipelago.

title: In Sardinia, Memories Come Floating Back
description: ON a mid-September day in the Maddalena archipelago, off the northeast shore of Sardinia, autumn still felt far off. The temperature hovered around 85 degrees, but a light Mediterranean wind kept our sailboat moving briskly and the ships captain, Luca Imbagliazzo, and me pleasantly cool.

title: Songs of Abandon, Love and the Everyday
description: Roach Gigz

title: Winning the Post-Friends Sweepstakes
description: IF you were to go by its debut, the ABC sitcom Happy Endings should probably have been called Inauspicious Beginnings.

title: The Timess executive editor Jill Abramson on her new book, The Puppy Diaries; Helen Schulmans This Beautiful Life; the science of the human brain; best-seller news
description: This week, the Timess executive editor Jill Abramson on her new book, The Puppy Diaries; Helen Schulman talks about her novel This Beautiful Life, a selection of The Big City Book Club; Christopher Chabris discusses new books about the science of the human brain; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Who Was the Carouser?
description: A few years ago, when I was anxiously trying to read every book ever written on markets and how they go awry, I came across a reviewer on Amazon with a particularly arresting take on the subject. His screen name was the_carouser, and unlike most of the customers weighing in on these sorts of books, he did not seek to impress others with his catastrophic outlook. He presented himself as a U.K.-based trader who specialized in fading market panics, and this seemed legitimate. I was so impressed by his point of view that I tried to contact him directly, thinking he might be useful as a source or possibly even a writer.

title: Details of Israeli Soldiers Release Emerge
description: An Israeli soldier held captive by militants in Gaza for five years is likely to return home as early as Tuesday, news agencies and Israeli media reported on Friday, a week after Israel and Hamas reached an agreement on a prisoner swap.

title: Toyota to Return to Le Mans in 2012 With Hybrid Racecar
description: On Friday, Toyota announced that its motorsports division in Germany, the same unit that set a lap record for electric vehicles on the Nrburgring in August, would develop a hybrid racecar to compete on the 2012 FIA World Endurance Championship circuit, including the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

title: British Defense Minister Resigns
description: LONDON  Britains defense minister, Liam Fox, resigned abruptly on Friday after more than a week of damaging newspaper headlines about his personal and professional relationship with a 33-year-old man who accompanied him on numerous official trips abroad and appeared to have brokered access for wealthy people who shared Mr. Foxs interest in fostering still closer ties with the United States and Israel.

title: Fill-In | N.B.A. Labor Battle
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the article Owners Sacrificing Games (or Season?) in Bid to Balance N.B.A.

title: More of a Gehry-Designed Museum in Minneapolis
description: The University of Minnesota unveiled its $14 million expansion to the Frederick R. Weisman Art Museum on Oct. 2 in Minneapolis. Frank Gehry, who designed the original stainless-steel structure in 1993, also designed the expansion.

title: Britain Agrees to New Inquiry Into Poisoning Death of a Former K.G.B. Officer
description: LONDON  A coroner has agreed to open a full inquest into the radiation poisoning of the former K.G.B. officer Alexander V. Litvinenko, potentially bringing the case before a British legal forum for the first time, opening new seams of information about his death and possibly stirring new tensions with Moscow.

title: The Uniqlo Flagship Challenge
description: With its 300 L.E.D. screens, 100 fitting rooms and three floors stocked top to bottom with basics beyond, the new 89,000-square-foot Uniqlo flagship on Fifth Avenue at 54th Street in Manhattan, which opens today, is just a tad overwhelming. And since vast shopping opportunities often end in devastating splurges, I arrived to test-shop the store with a plan: 10 items, $200 (which meant that the +J section on the second floor was off-limits). I started at the beginning, the bottom floor, where walls of cashmere V-neck sweaters bragged grand-opening price tags ($89.90 marked down to $49.90). So as not to throw the entirety of my allowance at four candy-colored sweaters, I jumped on the theme-park-style escalators and went straight up to the third floor. It was there that I did a double take: Japanese engineered denim for $9.90! With $190 left, I grabbed a mens flannel shirt ($29.90), a fluffy down vest ($49.90), a two-for-one Breton-striped lounge set ($24.90) and a pair of very holiday slippers ($12.90; if I dont wear them, someone in my family will come Christmastime); $72.50 to go and my winter shopping was almost done. Then I turned a corner and found myself staring into an aquarium-like tube filled with the companys famous (and effective!) Heattech pieces. I chose a knit cap ($12.90) and matching gloves ($12.90), a pack of socks ($9.90) and a camisole ($12.90). I had $23.90 left, enough for a pink umbrella ($12.90). Who knew Uniqlo sold umbrellas? Chic ones! Had I just $2 more  $11 was all that was left  Id have bought two.

title: Beauty Amid the Bruises
description: After moving to New York from California in 1978, Jules Allen went to the legendary Gleasons Gym to learn to box. But he stayed to make the sweat-soaked photographs that populate a just-published book, Double Up. On Lens, David Gonzalez interviews Mr. Allen and presents a slide show. Check it out ringside on Lens

title: Virgin Atlantic and British Airways Compete Over BMI
description: The rivalry between British Airways and Virgin Atlantic continues, this time over the midsize European carrier BMI.

title: Opposite Sides of the Protest Come Together, Briefly
description: Two men at Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan on Thursday could hardly have looked more different.

title: A Maestro Reflects on a Life of Batons and Knitting Needles
description: LONDON

title: Untraditional, but Still an Irish Tradition
description: SAY youve dedicated your life to an exacting dance tradition, one which most of the world knows nothing about. Then this tradition hits the big-time: theres a show, youre one of the stars and now the world knows one very particular take on this tradition. And you. But youre a serious artist; how do you deepen and expand your career beyond this commercial megahit? Do you abandon your tradition? Fuse it with something else?

title: Oct. 16  22
description: Theater

title: Police Clear Camp of Offshoot Demonstrators in Denver
description: DENVER  A park in front of the State Capitol that had been the scene for close to three weeks of a protest encampment allied with the Occupy Wall Street movement was cleared by police officers in riot gear early Friday morning. The police said 24 people had been arrested after refusing orders to disperse.

title: World Food Day: Addressing Hunger Around the Globe
description: World Food Day falls on Oct. 16 (Sunday) this year. It is a worldwide event intended to increase awareness, understanding and informed year-round action to fight hunger around the world.

title: Real Names, Please, for Sunday Magazine Reply All Feature
description: Under its new editor, Hugo Lindgren, The New York Times Sunday Magazine underwent a nicely-executed redesign last spring. One change, though, troubles me.

title: A Novelist Bypasses the Middle to Seek Out the Margins
description: MIAMI BEACH  Russell Banks, whose new novel, Lost Memory of Skin, is set here, first came to Florida in 1958. He was 18, had just dropped out of Colgate and was hoping to join Fidel Castro and his rebels in Cuba. He never made it off the mainland, Mr. Banks recalled recently, but just being in Florida felt revolutionary.

title: A Shoe for Wanderers
description: I hear from lots of publicists touting technology products that supposedly help older adults, and I ignore most of the gizmos theyre promoting. Without a skilled and unbiased Consumer Reports-type lab to test these inventions  and could someone please create one soon?  its too hard to tell which actually work well.

title: Hearty One-Dish Vegetarian Meals
