description: One-pot meals are easy to make, save on cleanup time and, most important, can taste delicious as the flavors of the various ingredients blend together. This week, Martha Rose Shulman offers five new vegetarian versions of the one-pot meal. She writes:

title: On Our Radar: Seals Hit by Baffling Illness
description: A mysterious disease is sickening and killing scores of ringed seals along Alaskas north coast. Since late July, about 100 of the animals, which serve as prey for polar bears, have been found with lesions on their flippers and in their mouths; nearly half have died. [Associated Press]

title: Perry Urges Aggressive Energy Production Policy
description: 2:17 p.m. | Updated WEST MIFFLIN, Pa.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas released a long-promised jobs and energy proposal that resembled a wishlist for the oil and gas industry, promising drilling across much of the country, including in Alaskas wilderness, and a curtailing of environmental regulations that includes a dismantling of the Environmental Protection Agency in its current form.

title: Happy Second Birthday to Us
description: On October 15 two years ago, The Learning Network was reborn as a blog.

title: The Bag Tells All
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league.

title: Eyes Once on the Ticker Are Now on the Meter
description: SCOTT CURTIS spent 25 years trading stocks on Wall Street before he lost his job in the recession.

title: The Fizzled-Out Bidding War for Southern Union
description: Examining the fizzled-out bidding war for Southern Union, one is reminded of Shakespeares tale filled with sound and fury, signifying nothing.

title: G-20 Seeks Broader Solution for Europe Debt Crisis
description: PARIS  Even as officials of the Group of 20 industrialized nations were gathering here on Friday to flesh out a solution to the European debt crisis, a new challenge confronted them, when ratings agencies warned that globally interconnected banks in France and elsewhere faced rising risks.

title: Angered by Shalit Deal, Israeli Defaces Rabin Memorial
description: Shortly after midnight in Tel Aviv on Friday, an Israeli man defaced a memorial to Yitzhak Rabin, on the spot where the former Israeli prime minister was assassinated in 1995 by a right-wing extremist who opposed his efforts to make peace with the Palestinians.

title: The Caucus | Cain Under Fire
description: Oct. 14, 2011 - A look at the intense criticism Herman Cain has undergone this week over his economic plan. Also, campaign finance filings are due to the Federal Election Commission on Saturday.

title: Inside the List
description: CALL 999: Does the road to the White House run through Barnes & Noble? Herman Cain, the long-shot Republican presidential hopeful who took first place in last months Florida straw poll, certainly seems to think so. Since This Is Herman Cain! My Journey to the White House was released on Oct. 4, the former Godfathers Pizza executive has been spending an awful lot of time in bookstores, signing copies and doing riffs on exclamation-point-happy policy prescriptions like Natural resources are there for a reason. Use them!(Anyone else want to hear those guys from the Miller Lite commercials stage a shout-off between Cains Nine, nine, nine! slogan  a reference to his flat-tax plan  and the Occupy Wall Street movements We are the 99 percent?) It took Cain about three months and a few professional collaborators to write the rather slender book, but less than one day after official publication to hit the top 10 on Amazon. According to his publisher, Threshold Editions, the book has already gone back for a sixth printing, with some 100,000 copies in circulation.

title: The Golden Retriever Who Came to Stay
description: Lets be real. Its hard to keep a straight face writing about puppies. Animal behaviorists like Alexandra Horowitz may apply hard science to shed light on why your shiba inu isnt interested in the television or your corgi mix likes to eat manure. The good poet  John Galsworthy, Rudyard Kipling  will wrest a sigh from the readers maudlin breast with paeans to loyal companions long departed. But most dog-crazy writers avoid spilling too much ink on the subject. Were wary of fashioning sentences that are a prose equivalent of the idiotic high-pitched babble we direct at our animals all day long. (Full family disclosure: my husband routinely cradles our 85-pound Labrador in his arms and sings to her, as he did when she was a puppy, the Baby Mine song from Dumbo.) If were not sentimental, well surely be unoriginal. Its like writing about sex. The opportunity to humiliate oneself lurks around every paragraph.

title: The Suite Life | Sophie Calle at the Lowell Hotel
description: Before boarding a flight from Paris this week, Sophie Calle stuffed her suitcase with a selection of choice possessions that hold personal significance, including one red and one white wedding dress, a wig, a framed portrait of Freud, a sprawled stuffed cat and an issue of TeleStar with Peter Falk on the cover, circa 1986. Upon arrival in New York, the French artist, best known for her intensely autobiographical work, proceeded to unpack these items at the Lowell Hotel where she has taken over a suite for Room, an installation commissioned by French Institute Alliance Franaise as part of Crossing the Line, an annual festival of contemporary art. Calles inventory also includes a few specialty items she sourced locally, like a burnt mattress, a baby stroller and a Remington Noiseless Portable typewriter. The artist herself will also appear from time to time over the shows run.

title: Up Front: Joseph Epstein
description: Joseph Epstein, who taught at Northwestern from 1974 to 2002 and edited The American Scholar from 1975 to 1997, reviews two books about the Medill family on the cover. In 1972, he wrote a much-discussed essay about William F. Buckley Jr. and his position as Americas most famous intellectual.

title: Adventures in the Orgasmatron
description: To the Editor:

title: Epicurean Fragments
description: To the Editor:

title: Sibling Harmony
description: To the Editor:

title: Caucus Video: Attacks on 9-9-9; Campaign Finance Preview
description: A look at the intense criticism Herman Cain has weathered this week over his economic plan. Also, campaign finance filings are due to the Federal Election Commission on Saturday.

title: Loves Labors
description: To the Editor:

title: Is the Brain Good at What It Does?
description: The human brain gets a lot of press these days, but not all the publicity has been good. Its reviews are reminiscent of Barack Obamas during the 2008 presidential campaign, when one side said he was a socialist Muslim foreigner and the other thought he was a savior from on high. To its detractors, the brain is a kludge, a hacked-up device beset with bugs, biases and self-deceptions that undermine our decision making and well-being at every turn. To its admirers, it contains vast potential we can all unlock to improve our lives, thanks to neural plasticity that enables the adult nervous system to change in more dramatic ways than previously thought. Lately, a growing army of Chicken Littles retorts that this very plasticity has been hijacked by the Internet and other forms of technological crack that are rewiring our brains into a state of continual distraction and intellectual torpor.

title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Authors?
description: One day, I stumbled across a book on Amazon called Saltine Cracker. It didnt make sense: who would pay $54 for a book entirely about perforated crackers? The book was co-edited by someone called Lambert M. Surhone  a name that sounds like one of Kurt Vonneguts inventions. According to Amazon, Lambert M. Surhone has written or edited more than 100,000 titles, on every subject from beekeeping to the worlds largest cedar bucket. He was churning out books at a rate that was simply not possible for a human being.

title: Jeffrey Eugenides on Liberal Arts Graduates in Love
description: There was no predicting where Jeffrey Eugenides would go after his first two novels, so different were they in tone and form. The Virgin Suicides  humid, dreamlike, entranced  comes off as a single thought. Middlesex, a chatty multigenerational saga that winds its way from Turkey to Michigan to San Francisco to Berlin, sweeping together the burning of Smyrna, the rise and fall of Detroit, the immigrant experience, the Nation of Islam, the sins of Nixon and, of course, the lore and genetics of intersexuality, has as many moving parts as a Rube Goldberg machine. The Virgin Suicides, edged with antic wit and edging toward the surreal, glances in Nabokovian contempt at the petty preoccupations of rangers and realists. Middlesex, for all the novelty of its hermaphroditic protagonist, is straight-up realism, start to finish.

title: A Child of the Blacklist Becomes a Teenage Spy
description: Maile Meloy, author of two novels and two story collections that have been praised for their meticulous realism, has written her first book for young readers, and defying expectations of admirers such as myself, its a fantasy. Though a longtime fan of Meloy, I couldnt help approaching The Apothecary, a story of teenage spies and transformative elixirs, with trepidation.

title: It Takes a Monster to Learn How to Grieve
description: When I opened the envelope on my doorstep containing this book, I immediately had to sit down. A Monster Calls is about coming to terms with grief. And it is based on the last story idea from my first mentor: brassy, big-hearted Siobhan Dowd, then a human rights campaigner, who was kind  or crazy  enough to hire me as an intern in 1997 when I was 18 years old. She died four years ago from breast cancer at the age of 47.

title: Chimeras, Angels and a Girl in Prague
description: Any book that opens with Once upon a time is inviting high expectations. Its a phrase that inevitably evokes fairy tales and leather-bound classics about epic adventures, setting up the anticipation that readers will discover worlds filled with magic. And it may be a clich, but its not necessarily an unwelcome one.

title: Bookshelf: Boo!
description: Pamela Paul reviews new childrens books about Halloween and spooky creatures.

title: Bookshelf: Night
description: Pamela Paul reviews new childrens books about dreams and the night.

title: Bookshelf: Boo!
description: CREEPY MONSTERS, SLEEPY MONSTERS  A Lullaby  By Jane YolenIllustrated by Kelly Murphy 32 pp. Candlewick Press. $14.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 5)

title: Bookshelf: Night
description: TWINKLE, TWINKLE, LITTLE STAR  Written and illustrated by Jerry Pinkney 40 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 0 to 4)

title: Michael Ondaatjes Passage From Ceylon
description: Once, on holiday, a friend and I descended a narrow iron ladder into a floodlit cavern and followed a guide into a small boat. As he rowed us through eerily motionless waters under a low, stalactite-fanged ceiling, the overhead lights went out, and only his flashlight pierced the darkness. In its beam we could see the play of the variegated colors across the crystal-crusted walls, and the slow-moving flickers of eyeless fish, our vision completely dependent on his single beam. Reading Michael Ondaatjes mesmerizing new novel, The Cats Table, is like being guided, just as surely and just as magically, through the authors lustrous visions. As he did in his great 1992 novel, The English Patient, which won the Man Booker Prize and became an Academy Award-winning film, Ondaatje conjures images that pull strangers into the vivid rooms of his imagination, their detail illumined by his words.

title: A Keats Brother on the American Frontier
description: Suppose you wanted to write a novel about John Keats, everyones favorite English Romantic poet, whose travels in realms of gold were purely imaginary, and who died in 1821, poor and spitting blood, at the obscenely young age of 25. Faced with such narrative restrictions, you might be tempted to invent a brother who was everything that Keats was not: practical, rich, footloose, married with a child, healthy enough to reach middle age. Why not send this imaginary brother across the Atlantic to the rank-grown forests (as Keats wrote in a later poem) of America, Kentucky, say, and invent encounters with luminous figures like John James Audubon and giant catfish and backwoods swindlers living on bear sandwiches greased with bear fat? A lively correspondence between the two brothers, spiced with verses, might serve to delineate the striking differences in their situations, and cast a reciprocal light on the poetry and the prairies.

title: Nation-Building, Our National Pastime
description: Nation-building is in bad odor these days, among the foreign policy cognoscenti and the general public alike. Weariness with the long struggles in Afghanistan and Iraq has produced a grand opposition alliance of isolationists, realists, populists and left-liberal anti-interventionists, who all agree it is past time to give up the hopeless dream. As Peggy Noonan recently put it, We should not occupy their lands, run their governments or try to bribe them into bonhomie. American soldiers should not be social workers. When she visited Afghanistan earlier this year, Noonan asked an American general how the war was going and was appalled to hear his answer: Great. We just opened a new hospital. Noonan lamented that the American soldier was no longer allowed to be a warrior in a warrior army.

title: The Marriage of Semite and Anti-Semite
description: Philip Roth, writing in these pages two decades ago, called the virtuosic Israeli writer Aharon Appelfeld a displaced writer of displaced fiction, who has made of displacement and disorientation a subject uniquely his own. Indeed, Until the Dawns Light, Appelfelds masterly and finely wrought 16th novel, begins with a displacement. The year is 1912; a young mother, Blanca Hammer, is fleeing by train with her 4-year-old son, Otto, from some unnamed menace, toward an unknown destination. It all transpired quickly and with frightening precision, Appelfeld writes, as though they were no longer their own masters but in the hands of the railways, which treated them mercifully and moved them from place to place, almost without pain.

title: Blood in the Sand
description: James Lee Burke presses onward with his singular mission to rewrite the American western in FEAST DAY OF FOOLS (Simon & Schuster, $26.99). The southwest Texas landscape is familiar genre territory, and the stand-up protagonist, Sheriff Hackberry Holland, is the latest in a long line of principled lawmen. But the good guys dont ride horses anymore, the bad guys have traded their six-guns for automatic weapons and a country club sprawls across part of the old Outlaw Trail.

title: The Curious C.D.O. Bankruptcy
description: Something odd is going on in New Jersey.

title: Ruth Toner and Simon Fiorucci
description: IF love is supposed to be ephemeral, elusive and maybe also undiscovered by its experimenters, then the wedding of Ruth Bushnell Toner and Simon David Fiorucci may have hit love at its source. After all, the couple met while looking for dark matter, one of the most ephemeral and elusive (and in fact, undiscovered) phenomena in physics.

title: The Graphic Novel as Orientalist Mash-Up
description: Craig Thompsons Habibi is a work of fantasy about being ashamed of ones fantasies. This anxiety is native to comics, or at least to the broad strain of American comics written by white males. The work of R. Crumb, for example, is a gallery of self-loathing  portraits that register an artists recoil from his own noxious imaginings. Thompsons work is much prettier than anything drawn by Crumb, but the anxieties are similar. If Habibi had been content to mine this narrow but rich vein of adolescent angst it might have been a comics comic, or at least an instructive book for young adults. Instead, it aspires to address questions of spirituality, environmental degradation and religious pluralism. The result is frankly a mess, though it does include some arresting pictures.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 6s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BETTER ANGELS OF OUR NATURE: Why Violence Has Declined,  by Steven Pinker (Viking, $40.) Are humans essentially good or bad? Has the past century seen moral progress or a moral collapse? Pinker addresses these questions and more.

title: For Children of Same-Sex Couples, a Student Aid Maze
description: It took five attempts for one prospective college student and her mother to fill out the 106-question federal form that would determine whether she would be eligible for financial aid. And that was not just because the form was frustratingly complicated. What tripped them up was the fact that the student had two legal mothers  and the form had room for only one.

title: Paperback Row
description: CREATE DANGEROUSLY: The Immigrant Artist at Work,  by Edwidge Danticat (Vintage, $14.95.) Danticat, whose books include the story collection Krik? Krak! and the novel Breath, Eyes, Memory, grew up in Haiti in the 1970s, under the Duvalier dictatorships (she has lived in the United States since the age of 12). These essays reflect on the Haitian diaspora and artists who create despite the horrors that drove them from their homelands.

title: I Was an Under-Age Semiotician
description: It is an occupational hazard of being a writer to be appalled by the prose style you deployed in your youth. Most of the time the flaws reflect unchecked enthusiasm, or literary clichs that have not yet worn away, or a certain inability to settle on a defined voice. But reading my own college juvenilia, I have a strange and almost total sense of disconnection. This is from a paper I wrote at the age of 19:

title: M.L.S.: Playoff Race Goes to the Wire
description: Six teams are vying for the three remaining slots in Major League Soccers postseason with only two weekends left in the regular season.

title: Holding Zuccotti Park
description: Cheers erupted after an announcement was read from the Bloomberg administration that Brookfield properties, which owns Zuccotti Park, would not require protesters to leave.

title: For Rupp, Focus Is on Families in Need
description: 4:08 p.m. | Updated

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Double Dipping
description: What happens when a super-hero goes bad? Thats the premise behind Irredeemable, a series written by Mark Waid and illustrated by Peter Krause. The former hero in question is the Plutonian and in his path are his former allies, the Paradigm, who try to impede his quest for mayhem. Plutonians turn to the dark side may be bad for the people he used to protect, but its good for Boom! Studios, which publishes the series as two collected editions hit our lists this week. On the hardcover list, at No. 7, is The Definitive Irredeemable, a deluxe reprint of the first three volumes of the series. On the softcover list, at No. 2, is volume seven, which finds the ex-hero in exile at an alien asylum.

title: Israel Plans to Build More Housing in East Jerusalem
description: The Israeli government has submitted formal plans to build a new neighborhood of Jewish housing in a part of Jerusalem beyond the 1967 lines close to the West Bank city of Bethlehem, the anti-settlement Israeli group Peace Now reported Friday.

title: How to File for Financial Aid if Your Parents Are Gay
description: Filling out the federal form for student financial aid is an arduous task for most applicants. But if you have two mothers or two fathers, or if you happen to be married to a same-sex partner, it can quickly escalate into an even more complicated exercise.

title: When It Comes to Charity, Their Address Says It All
description: Imagine what they would have had to do if they lived, say, a mile away, in the 400 block of Grand Street. Pay attention to the number 400.

title: Calls Flood In, City Backs Off and Protesters Stay
description: Inside City Hall, the calls poured in late Thursday, predicting a debacle: Hundreds of people sympathetic to the Occupy Wall Street protest were streaming into Lower Manhattan, vowing to resist a forced cleanup of the park taken over by demonstrators.

title: New Biography Says van Gogh Did Not Kill Himself
description: A new biography of Vincent van Gogh and a 60 Minutes report on it scheduled for Sunday night call into question the long-accepted notion  central to the myth of the troubled artist  that he committed suicide.

title: Way Is Cleared to Rebuild Greek Orthodox Church Lost on 9/11
description: Even before the fires were extinguished at ground zero, everyone agreed that St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church at 155 Cedar Street  crushed by the collapse of 2 World Trade Center  would rise again.

title: Vikings Stadium Project Remains Stalled
description: Minnesota legislators appeared to be making little immediate headway on a special legislative session needed to approve a proposed Vikings stadium project one day after a crucial report on a new stadium in Arden Hills, according to a report in The Minneapolis Star Tribune.

title: Pair of Police-Protester Incidents Adds Fuel to Occupy Wall St.
description: Updated, 8:11 p.m. | Amid the chaos in Lower Manhattan on Friday morning as the Occupy Wall Street protesters marched through the streets, there were two encounters between protesters and the police that were captured, however imperfectly, on video and then ricocheted across the Internet.

title: Striped Bass Poached in Spicy Soy Sauce
description: Mark Bittman poaches a filet in soy sauce and scallions.

title: The Hyeres Competition
description: The International Festival of Fashion and Photography takes place each spring at the Villa Noailles near Hyeres, in the south of France. Viktor & Rolf and Romain Kremer are among the designers who participated in the competition. Jury leaders have included Martin Margiela, Azzedine Alaia, Raf Simons and Hussein Chalayan. The Hyeres Festival is an excellent way for emerging designers and photographers to get some recognition. The deadline for applications for the spring 2012 festival is Dec. 5. So apply! For details, go to villanoailles-hyeres.com/hyeres2012.

title: The Minimalist: Striped Bass Poached in Spicy Soy Sauce
description: Poaching  cooking in simmering liquid  is a fairly forgiving way to cook fish, since its not likely to dry out. (It also virtually eliminates the likelihood of anything sticking to the bottom of the pan, which is often in the back of your mind when you saut.) I love using this method with striped bass, which has the added bonus of being a local fish, but you can use any firm white fillets or steaks. Its also a great way to cook mackerel or bluefish, other locals.

title: In a Culture Clash, Olympus Ousts Its British Chief
description: TOKYO  The struggling Japanese camera maker Olympus wanted a change agent. Just not this much change, evidently.

title: CBS Masters Viewers Universe With Big Bang Theory
description: 3:36 p.m. | Updated ABC said on Friday that it was canceling Charlies Angels, according to The Associated Press.

title: Chemistry as the Language of Life
description: Mark Hay, a biology professor at Georgia Tech, writes from Fiji, where he is investigating coral-seaweed competition in the coral reefs.

title: Reckless in Seduction, if Not Onstage
description: Since becoming the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera in 2006, Peter Gelb has made it a priority to persuade strong, successful directors from theater and film to take on major new productions. And why not? Opera is theater. In theory, gifted directors who are mostly new to opera should bring fresh, bracing perspectives to bear.

title: T Exclusive Music Video | Laura Marling
description: A film by Harrison Boyce and Nathan Brown of Boyce & Brown. Location: Manhattans Audio Visual Arts (AVA)

title: Hotel Review: Inn at the Black Olive in Baltimore
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Restaurant Report: Rustic Stone in Dublin
description: When the Irish economic crisis hit, even a Michelin star and a celebrated reputation couldnt save the chef Dylan McGraths fine-dining restaurant, Mint, which closed in spring 2009. Making a comeback with a more casual approach, he opened Rustic Stone in August 2010, emphasizing (gasp) healthy cuisine, free of the fatty crutches of butter and cream  and in a location bordering the pub-filled Temple Bar district, where indulgence is king.

title: Letters: Fall Foliage
description: Fall Foliage

title: Of Parties, Prose and Football
description: CIVILIZATION begins with distillation, William Faulkner wrote, and in Oxford, Miss., his adopted hometown, its possible for a literary pilgrim to visit whats left of his liquor cabinet.

title: Detour Near Kennebunkport, Me.
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., is probably best known as a summer playground for the wealthy, most notably the former president, George H. W. Bush. The old money is plenty visible: confident young men stride around town in freshly pressed khakis and preppy haircuts, vintage sailboats glide into port, and straight-backed seniors sip cocktails in Adirondack chairs.

title: A High-End Trip Into a Chilean Desert
description: IF youve heard of the Atacama Desert in northern Chile at all, youre likely to know one thing: its the driest desert on earth. Thats all I knew going in, though it triggered my reflexive mistrust of superlatives.

title: In Denver, Shops in the Rubble of the Gold Rush
description: Now a shopping destination, the area has had a history that stretches back to the gold and silver rushes of the 19th century.

title: Faulkners Ole Miss
description: A trip to view William Faulkners spirits is the best possible way to begin a long weekend in Oxford.

title: Same-Sex Parents and Paying for College
description: When applying for financial aid for college, having two same-sex parents can be an asset or a disadvantage, depending on the circumstances, as the following examples illustrate. The expected family contribution, used by colleges to determine financial aid packages, takes into account the students household size, family income and assets, and the number of students in college, among other factors.

title: As Calls for Protests Go Global, Italy Jumps the Gun
description: Online organizers have set Saturday as the date to spread the Occupy Wall Street protests to cities around the world.

title: In a Volatile Market, Some Turn to Insurance Instead of Bonds
description: LIFE insurance, its fair to say, is a subject that provokes  strong opinions. People who like insurance see it as a way to leave money to heirs tax-free or to make sure there is money for a rainy day. Those who dont like it see a product that generates huge fees for the seller and a diminishing benefit for buyers who probably dont understand it.

title: Financial Planners Red Flags
description: If youre a company trying to persuade Americans to trust you with their money, the last thing you want is former employees accusing you of cheating them out of theirs.

title: Ameriprise and the Meaning of Its 401(k) Lawsuit
description: My column this week is about Ameriprise, a company rich with history, though not always the good kind. It deserves a ton of credit for making financial planning central to its work with customers, but it has also run into plenty of trouble with regulators over the years.

title: Questions for Amazon on Privacy and the Kindle Fire
description: The dream of every retailer is to know exactly what its customers are thinking. Are they comparison-shopping? Just looking? Will a discount help close the deal? Or is price no object? Amazons coming tablet, the Kindle Fire, is equipped with a Web browser that, thanks to the wonders of cloud computing, is partly housed on Amazons servers. That will give the retailer opportunities to track customer behavior all over the Web, gathering data and marketing intelligence as it goes.

title: Projected Yearnings
description: We asked the Paris-based artist and lighting director Thierry Dreyfus to make the T for our winter womens issue because he lights so many of the clothes that we see on the runways. (He did 25 shows last season alone.) But it wasnt just the halos at Comme des Garons or the bulbed ceiling that lifted from the floor at Rag & Bone that made Dreyfus such an easy and desirable pick. All over the world  at hotels in Belgrade and Athens, in galleries in Singapore and Milan, and at design fairs in London and Miami  Dreyfuss installations alter and electrify their surroundings and our experiences of them. Here, he tells T how the projected image of our signature initial happened (by accident), and the kind of light he hopes women will wear this winter.

title: Mariusz Kwiecien Set to Return to Met Stage
description: Just two weeks after undergoing surgery for a herniated desk, the baritone Mariusz Kwiecien will return to the stage in the title role of Don Giovanni at the Metropolitan Opera on Oct. 25, the company said on Friday. Mr. Kwiecien, his surgeon and manager reported in a conference call that his recovery is progressing at a remarkable pace, Peter Clark, the Met spokesman, wrote in an e-mail. He is expected to carry out all the stage action, with the possible exception of climbing down a ladder in the opening scene, Mr. Clark said. Mr. Kwiecien felt pain during the dress rehearsal last week and had to withdraw from early performances in the run. Doctors operated on his back on Tuesday.

title: Bishop Indicted; Charge Is Failing to Report Abuse
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A bishop in the Roman Catholic Church has been indicted for failure to report suspected child abuse, the first time in the 25-year history of the churchs sex abuse scandals that the leader of an American diocese has been held criminally liable for the behavior of a priest he supervised.

title: What Works to End Bullying?
description: We grown-ups really want to find some good news on bullying, but its pretty hard to come by.

title: Five-Ku: Short Poems on the Original Footloose
description: This weeks Riff discusses how the movies Drive and Ides of March could affect Ryan Goslings star potential. Below is an accompanying Five-Ku on an older movie that launched the career of a heartthrob of yore.

title: Off the Charts: Imports Are Falling, Again
description: Imports to most countries plunged when the credit crisis began in 2008, and then recovered. But in recent months, slowing economies have led to renewed declines in most countries in the euro zone.

title: Europes Consumers Are Pointing the Way Down
description: AS European leaders scramble to save the euro and prevent Greeces debt woes from spreading, the economic performance of euro zone countries is diverging at a fast clip.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Libya, Thailand and Tunisia.

title: A Biologist Decries Slaying of Whooping Cranes
description: Heres a sad Dot Earth postcard from John B. French, Jr., the leader of the whooping crane restoration program at the U.S. Geological Surveys Patuxent Wildlife Research Center in Laurel, Md. He describes the sixth and seventh shooting deaths of whooping cranes raised in this federal program and released in the United States this year. The video above has some general background on the program.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Libya, Thailand and Tunisia.

title: Drawn Together by a Love of Cartooning
description: Theirs is a comic book romance.

title: For Walking Dead Creator, It Takes a Novel To Explain What Spawned the Governor
description: Robert Kirkman wont rest until zombies have taken over the world, or at least many corners of the pop-culture landscape.

title: Perry Addresses Wifes Comments on His Faith
description: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

title: Finding Room for Improvement
description: Tech-savvy owners of the Nissan Leaf have developed multiple gadgets for improving the cars efficiency.

title: TimesCast | October 14, 2011
description: Italys prime minister survives a close confidence vote; Occupy Wall Street protesters dig in; and criticism grows for the Republican candidate Herman Cains tax-reform plan.

title: Candidates Report Third-Quarter Fund-Raising
description: 5:12 p.m. | Updated The 2012 presidential candidates must file their third-quarter fund-raising reports with the Federal Election Commission by Saturday at midnight. The numbers will reveal not merely how much they are raising, but how much they are spending and where they are spending it. The chart below is a top-level breakdown of where the candidates stand, and will be updated as candidates reports become available.)

title: New Paul Ad in Iowa Focuses on Abortion
description: Ron Paul is best known for his antigovernment crusades and his rebukes of the Federal Reserve.

title: Citizens Testing Finds 20 Hot Spots Around Tokyo
description: TOKYO  Takeo Hayashida signed on with a citizens group to test for radiation near his sons baseball field in Tokyo after government officials told him they had no plans to check for fallout from the devastated Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. Like Japans central government, local officials said there was nothing to fear in the capital, 160 miles from the disaster zone.

title: Insurance as an Investment Alternative
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about some investors who are turning to life insurance to insulate themselves from the volatility in the stock market. Insurance, after all, allows you to leave money to your heirs tax free or to make sure you have money when you need it.

title: Look of The Moment | Sienna Miller
description: The Look: Fluff Piece  an electric dress with feathers and plenty of sparkling appliqus is as attention-grabbing as any bird of paradise.

title: Report Faults Wall Street for High Energy Prices
description: A new report by Better Markets, a nonprofit group advocating constraints on speculative trading, blames Wall Street for inflating prices at the gas pump and the grocery store.

title: A Burst of Autumn Color in the Great Allegheny Passage
description: CUMBERLAND, Md.  One reason I began my cross-country bike trip in midsummer was so I could be on the road as the seasons changed. I had some chilly, autumnal weather before it was actually autumn, but the foliage has been slow to turn this year. Its only in the past week or so that the colors have taken on the burned yellows and burnished reds that we associate with fall, but I was lucky enough to be in the woods when it happened.

title: Politico Reporter Resigns Amid Plagiarism Allegations
description: A reporter for the news Web site Politico resigned on Thursday after allegations that she had used content in a number of her stories from articles that had been published in The New York Times, The Associated Press, NJ.com and other sources.

title: Book Review Podcast: Jill Abramsons Puppy Diaries
description: In Sundays Book Review, Alexandra Styron reviews The Puppy Diaries: Raising a Dog Named Scout, the new book from The Timess executive editor, Jill Abramson. The book, which began as a popular blog, examines the joys and trials of living with a rambunctious golden retriever puppy.

title: Qaddafi-Era Flag Is Said to Have Set Off Gunfire in Tripoli
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Hundreds of anti-Qaddafi militiamen converged on several neighborhoods of Tripoli on Friday, firing heavy weapons on residential streets in a rare outburst of violence that may have started with demonstrations in support of the deposed leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Unflinching Underdog Working on an Upset
description: TIFFIN, Ohio  Justin Suddeth, a defensive back at Heidelberg University, does not need to look at the schedule to know when the coming opponent is Mount Union, a Division III football juggernaut with 10 national championships and only one regular-season loss in the last 17 years.

title: A Golden Touch Turns Leaden
description: No wonder Occupy Wall Street took its protest this week to East 86th Street and the 28,500-square-foot limestone mansion owned by the billionaire hedge fund manager John A. Paulson. What better symbol of the excesses of Wall Street than Mr. Paulson, who made billions betting on the real estate collapse and whose opulent surroundings stand in such contrast to the million of Americans who have lost their homes?

title: The Tapas Bar Brought Home
description: IN many cities in Spain, where much of life is lived in the street, tapas are a daily indulgence. Rather than invite friends over, you meet at a tapas bar, have a few drinks and nibble up a storm from an array of savory dishes. Your little group can wax and wane, as some peel off, stopping for tapas at a few more places.

title: Tapas for Dinner
description: Translated to a home setting, Spanish tapas make a great way to entertain, perfect for a small city kitchen. Not at all a formal sit-down meal scenario, it works for a small group as well as a crowd. You can dispense with chairs, plates, even forks. All you need are napkins, glasses, toothpicks, and a few serving dishes.

title: Busy Week in Food: Even More Links!
description: Is part of the reason that Danes are so happy because they cook? (Maybe. And they also have far less income inequality: a dishwasher in Denmark makes $25 an hour, gets sick days, health care, maternity leave, and a pension.)

title: When Electric Car Owners Talk, Nissan Listens
description: Union City, Calif.

title: Islanders Goaltender Out With Concussion
description: Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro sustained a concussion in practice this week and is out indefinitely, the team said Friday.

title: Huntsman Will Boycott Las Vegas Debate
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. wont be at the next debate, in Las Vegas. But its not a sleight by the organizers.

title: Among the Lectures, a Bit of Shtick
description: Even after five days, The Rosie Show sticks out on the Oprah Winfrey Network.

title: The Electric Leafs True Believers Wont Leave Well Enough Alone
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Autumn Unfolds, With Birdsong and Crackling Leaves
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week.

title: Bachmanns Fund-Raising Troubles Continue
description: ROCK RAPIDS, Iowa  Although candidates are not required to report their fund-raising and expenses for the financial quarter ending Sept. 30 until Saturday, Representative Michele Bachmann offered a peek here Friday into the top-line number she would report.

title: Romneys Rainmakers: Where Are They Now?
description: A vintage photo of Mitt Romney  the Republican presidential contender, the former Massachusetts governor and Bain Capital founder  is making the rounds on the Internet. (Due to those annoying copyright rules and the fact that Bain Capital says it doesnt own the photo, we cant post it, but you can see it here.)

title: Frieze Frame | Sarah Lucass Bedside Manner
description: Pretty much every art fair seems to have its own drain  the place everyone eventually winds up at the end of the night. And the one thats emerged at Frieze this year is the lounge at the St. John Hotel, on Leicester Square in Londons Chinatown, where the artist Sarah Lucas is in bed-sidency. Inside the Maritime bar, up one flight of blue, porthole-lined stairs from the hotels entrance, several of Lucass sculptures hang from the ceiling  plastic buckets and patio chairs from which stuffed pantyhose swing like Ernesto Neto-inspired breasts, conjuring the shapes of individuals who seem ready to party. Lucas herself evidently likes to stay up late; though shes spent most of the week in pajamas in Room 15, when I visited last night, around last call, she was holding court with a room packed with fair-weary revelers like Gavin Brown and MoMA P.S. 1s Peter Eleey.

title: Weekend Fare
description: This weekend is the kickoff for the first Cider Week in New York, which runs from Sunday through Oct. 23. There will be more than 85 restaurants throughout the city and Hudson Valley participating in the weeklong celebration of fermented apple juice. Consider the New Amsterdam Market, South Street (between Beekman Street and Peck Slip), which is holding a hard-cider revival on Sunday from noon to 4 p.m. with hard-cider tastings, Marlow and Sons is running a cider bar, and tapas-size snacks. Early admission is from noon to 1:30 p.m., with $45 tickets, which includes 10 tastings. General admission starts at 1:30 p.m., with five tastings for $20 and 10 for $35. Additional tastings are $5 each.

title: House Panel Examines Details of Solyndra Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department may have made a decision without precedent when it allowed Solyndra, the now bankrupt solar technology company, to restructure its loans so private investors  not the government  would have first call on its assets in case of liquidation, two Treasury Department officials acknowledged Friday before a House subcommittee.

title: Insider trading, Big Pink, putting people to work, and default choices
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Peter Lattman on insider trading; Natasha Singer and David Gillen on Big Pink; Robert Shiller on putting people to work; and Steve Lohr on default choices.

title: Armed U.S. Advisers to Help Fight African Renegade Group
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that he had ordered the deployment of 100 armed military advisers to central Africa to help regional forces combat the Lords Resistance Army, a notorious renegade group that has terrorized villagers in at least four countries with marauding bands that kill, rape, maim and kidnap with impunity.

title: Research Group Sees Deterioration in U.S. Fuel-Economy Gains
description: For all the attention devoted to American car buyers rediscovery of smaller, more fuel-efficient vehicles in 2011, a report released this week suggests that such purchase trends are having little impact on overall fuel economy.

title: Podcast: Insider Trading, Job Creation and Fighting Cancer
description: A federal judge in Manhattan this week imposed the longest insider-trading sentence ever in the United States.

title: In Athens, Crisis as Muse
description: The economy of Greece continues to flounder, but in Athens there are signs that the struggles have given birth to an artistic awakening.

title: Ad Agencies Gear Up for Fourth Quarter
description: 6:12 p.m. | Updated This is the time of year when advertising agencies begin to announce major business moves in anticipation of positioning themselves for growth through the important fourth quarter and into the new year.

title: Should Insurers Pay for Eating Disorders?
Huntsman Details Money Woes
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. has just $327,000 left in his campaign account and more than twice that in debt, his campaign said on Friday, underscoring the Republican presidential candidates continued difficulties raising money since entering the race in late June.

title: Lean on Me: Trust and Friendship Around the World
description: Among the many reasons Americans are lucky is that they tend to have people they can depend on.

title: Now Playing | The Two
description: When they met in Paris she called herself a painter and he called himself a magician. She had just come from New York and was working on a series of portraits. Hed been touring the south of France doing a show of tricks with coins, cards and cigarettes. They dated and they broke up and then they started the band, the Two.

title: Siri Is One Funny Lady
description: Man, I thought I was brilliant asking Siri, the new iPhones virtual assistant, funny questions like What is the meaning of life?

title: Health Law to Be Revised by Ending a Program
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration announced Friday that it was scrapping a long-term care insurance program created by the new health care law because it was too costly and would not work.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: Welcome to a look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Remedies for Clunks and Leaks
description: SCIONS and Toyotas needing new pistons and rings and Ford Focuses with steering issues are among the vehicles covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Despite Intelligent Design, It Doesnt Ace the Test
description: TESTED 2012 Scion iQ

title: Rubbing Out Friction in the Push for Mileage
description: Detroit

title: The Week in Pictures, Oct. 14
description: A slide show of images from cultural events this week.

title: The Week in Culture, Oct. 14
description: More Photographs

title: Harvest Tart With Pumpkin, Roasted Red Peppers and Olives
description: Time: 2 1/2 hours, plus at least 2 1/2 hours resting

title: A Dinner Party Thats Warm, Welcoming and Meatless
description: WHENEVER I wanted to whip up a meatless meal for company, Id fall back on the time-honored strategy of pouring in the cheese, eggs, butter and cream to make everything seem festive and satisfying.

title: Manhattan Rental Market Rebounds
description: Rents have recovered and vacancy rates have fallen again in Manhattan.

title: TimesCast | Berlusconi Survives Vote
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi holds onto power in Italy after facing the closest confidence vote yet.

title: Starting Simple, Ending With Spectacle
description: Showmanship, like most things, seems to come naturally to Pat Metheny. As a virtuoso guitarist, an expansive composer and, above all, an inveterate searcher, he knows how to bring human scale and feeling to the most outsize sort of spectacle. He can also pull off the inverse, making reflective solitude seem grand and overwhelming, like a balloon incarnation of Emily Dickinson in the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: Chic in Review | Burberry Rules the World Wide Web
description: Alba, JessicaSues the weight-loss garment, Belly Bandit, for listing her under the Celebrity Testimonials section of its Web site. Heck, Id be upset, too, if Id dieted for months after giving birth and a silly slimming gimmick got all of the credit.

title: Half of Votes Counted, Ford Labor Contract Leans Into Yes Territory
description: DETROIT  The ratification outlook for a proposed four-year labor agreement between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union improved on Friday, but opposition at several large plants that have yet to finish voting could still be enough to sink the deal.

title: Those Third-Term Blues
description: It gets more complex and harder to get your message out and advertising rates keep going up.

title: A New Pakistan Policy: Containment
description: Washington

title: Breaking With Traditional
description: Upper Brookville

title: Many Foreclosures, Few Listings
description: PRICES are down across the board so far this year in urban, suburban, rural and shore areas, in both northern and southern New Jersey  everywhere except areas close to Manhattan commuter train service, and in all price categories except, surprisingly, the uppermost.

title: Coming Out to the World on the Web
description: LIKE a lot of people who post videos of themselves on YouTube, Kristina Cecil wants the world to know a few personal facts:

title: An 80s Scandal Comes to a Quiet End
description: SID R. BASS, the billionaire investor, certainly did not give the impression of an unhappy husband on the night of Sept. 26, when he attended the black-tie opening of Anna Bolena at the Metropolitan Opera. Whenever a photographer took a picture of his wife of nearly 23 years, Mercedes T. Bass, the philanthropist and fashion plate whose name appears on the Mets Grand Tier, Mr. Bass was there by her side, his white pocket square complementing her Oscar de la Renta dress.

title: In His Shoes
description: After being largely eclipsed by its flashier rivals, most notably the red-soled Louboutin, the quietly elegant Manolo Blahnik is once again emerging as the it shoe.

title: In His Shoes
description: THIS is the tale of the little stiletto that could, a shoe that in the long-ago days of the luxury-goods boom scampered to the top of a rarefied heap. It was just a handful of years ago that the name of Manolo Blahnik, a 68-year-old London cobbler born in the Canary Islands, was familiar only to hard-core fashion hunters and residents of ZIP code 10021.

title: The Lease Is Up, and Now, So Is the Rent
description: A LITTLE more than two years ago, Tom Graney was paying a reasonable $2,200 for a spacious two-bedroom apartment on 11th Avenue and 52nd Street.

title: Sales Over Rentals, Even in a Credit Crunch
description: IN the last few years a number of new condominium projects, facing poor sales and tighter lending requirements for buyers, have chosen to become rental buildings. While rentals dont usually generate as much initial revenue as sale properties, developers see them as a safe long-term bet, generally easy to fill and providing steady revenue.

title: Another White House Description of Solyndra
description: Among the insights to be drawn from the unfolding Solyndra scandal is that the flavor and texture of political scandal have changed in the digital age. The leaked  Pentagon Papers consisted of mostly dry academic prose. The written reports submitted in the Red Scare investigations of the 1950s varied in tone from sinister to bombastic.

title: Administration Nixes the Class Act
description: The Obama Administration on Friday announced that it was scrapping the Class Act, the government-run insurance program for long-term care authorized by the Affordable Care Act, essentially because the numbers could not be made to work. Robert Pear reports:

title: Love the One Youre (Born) With
description: VIENNA GIRARDI was the winner of the 2010 season of the reality dating show The Bachelor. What she won, albeit briefly, was the heart of Jake Pavelka. The pair have since broken up  she says because of his lust for fame; he says because shes a liar.

title: TimesCast | Protesters Dig In
description: A scheduled cleanup of Zuccotti Park was postponed, and Occupy Wall Street protesters dig in.

title: McCain to Pawlenty: Watch the Money
description: Tim Pawlenty had money on his mind a few weeks before he ended his bid for the Republican presidential nomination two months ago.

title: Bill Cunningham | Flirty
description: The erogenous zone of present-day fashion is the shoe. Guests put some of the amazing variety in the spotlight at the recent New York and Paris shows.

title: European Preview: Oct. 15-16
description: John Godfrey teased some of these games in his weekly United States national team TV guide, but heres a little more on the biggest games in Europe this weekend from Rob Hughes.

title: Johnson & Johnson Wins Suit Over Antibiotics Side Effects
description: Johnson & Johnson on Friday won a significant lawsuit concerning whether it adequately alerted doctors to the risks in prescribing its popular antibiotic Levaquin.

title: Special Section: Cars
description: With small cars back in vogue, Saab on the ropes and used cars commanding new-car prices at the dealership, The Times offers a special Cars section, which examines the forces that are shaping and buffeting the auto industry.

title: Hit the Escalators
description: EVERYONE has her own shopping pattern for the Bloomingdales mother ship on Lexington Avenue and 59th Street, but mine turns out to be not so original. I always head to the contemporary brands on the second floor, skip the third entirely (a bland sea of office clothes) and the cruise designer stuff on the fourth. I have my favorite corners  J Brand and Theory  but I never ventured into the low-ceilinged, crammed denim area. Just too uninviting.

title: Religion, Politics and Tax Exemptions
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Rights Group Welcomes Obamas Decision to Send Troops to Uganda
description: As my colleagues Thom Shanker and Rick Gladstone report, President Obama said Friday that he had ordered the deployment of 100 armed military advisers to central Africa to help regional forces combat the Lords Resistance Army, a notorious renegade group that has terrorized villagers in at least four countries with marauding bands that kill, rape, maim and kidnap with impunity.

title: A Choice From Many Potential Lines of Play
description: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands  Play in the 40th World Team Championships starts here on Sunday.

title: Messages From Prison to an Irresistible Beat
description: There is a point late in more more more ... future when you think the Congolese choreographer Faustin Linyekula and his collaborators might take their title seriously, and keep going till this mythical future comes  or till they drop. Some of them already have, in fact, collapsing or slumping to the floor only to rise again and again.

title: Siri Answers Questions From Readers
description: On Thursday, we asked readers to submit questions for Siri, Apples new virtual personal assistant in the iPhone 4S. Below are some of Siris most entertaining answers. We threw in some questions of our own because, well, once we got started, it was hard to stop.

title: Toe to Spine, a Study in Precision
description: The amalgam of formality and informality, of technique and rawness (sometimes wildness) in the work of the choreographer Liz Gerring is something rare. Her six dancers, all attractive, look purpose-bred. The intensity with which they all use their backs is particularly impressive, as is the accentuation they bring to very simple steps. Yet they look neither homogenized nor groomed. Though the way any one of them raises a limb often looks wholly unschooled, you later realize that each moves the very same way the next time, and that so do the others. What looked nave proves to be precise.

title: Generational Exchange: Father and Son, Side by Side
description: The dull, conservative older generation and the rebellious, daring younger one: this is the primal narrative of the arts. But these days the situation is all too often reversed, with up-and-coming artists creating cautious, bland work that would have been unthinkable to their pioneering elders.

title: MTV's Next Reality Star
description: MTV's college channel, mtvU, will next attempt to capture university life of an entirely deaf university.

title: A Closer Look at Accused Self-Identified Tiger Poachers
description: The Wildlife Conservation Society has produced a short video about the remarkable case in which accused Thai tiger poachers were tracked down using cell-phone photos taken by one of the the gang, and connected to a particular slain tiger by camera-trap photos taken by conservation biologists.

title: Views to a Kill
description: Abraham Lincoln. Anwar Sadat. John Lennon. Franz Ferdinand. Lee Harvey Oswald. John F. Kennedy. Martin Luther King. Osama bin Laden. Robert Kennedy. Mohandas Gandhi. Anwar al-Awlaki.

title: A Mash-Up of Methods to Celebrate Life
description: Be afraid, please be afraid of me, sings the composer and violinist Daniel Bernard Roumain in Symphony for the Dance Floor, his latest evening-length cross-genre amalgam.

title: A Surface Still Shiny After 20 Years
description: The Spin Doctors took a moment to pose for a group photo before exiting stage left at their sold-out Bowery Ballroom show on Thursday night. They were joined by a member of their management team, and by a meaningful prop: the plaque commemorating sales of five million copies of their major-label debut, Pocket Full of Kryptonite (Epic). The crowd, which had just heard the album performed in sequence, greeted this bit of ceremony with obliging pep, cheering both the accomplishment and, implicitly, its own contribution to it.

title: Lifes a Pain, and Then You Play Penn
description: Martina McBride isnt a singer given to lighthearted gesture. Shes an adult, singing about adult topics, with one of the biggest and most healing voices in Nashville. Shes best when tackling painful subjects, and while shes capable of happiness, she could never be glib.

title: This Detective Is Sharp but Also Introspective
description: An early sign that Case Histories isnt going to be a typical British mystery: the voice of Nanci Griffith singing the lovely John Prine song Speed of the Sound of Loneliness. Strumming guitars and Texas twangs are not the usual soundtrack for tea-fueled detection and beatings on dark Edinburgh streets.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 14
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Bowery hotel that houses two different worlds, a legendary comedian who panhandles in Midtown, and a cleanup in Zuccotti Park.

title: One Definition of Collaboration: Putting Heads Together, Then Taking Turns
description: Cuqui Jerez is a Spanish choreographer, but her show The Rehearsal is not a dance. It is being presented by Performance Space 122, but not at Performance Space 122, which is undergoing renovations. And those are only two of the contradictions built into this offering at the Crossing the Line festival. At the shows opening on Wednesday, Ms. Jerez and the four other troupe members seemed right at home at the Performing Garage, headquarters of the playfully experimental Wooster Group.

title: Geren Named Mets New Bench Coach
description: The Mets took another step in revamping their coaching staff on Friday by naming Bob Geren, the former manager of the Oakland Athletics, as their bench coach for the 2012 season.

title: China-India Program at Asia Society
description: Leading writers from China and India will meet for panel discussions in New York early next month as part of a new initiative called The Chindia Dialogues. The event, to run Nov. 3 through 6 at Asia Society, will focus on cultural and social trends in both countries as well as their interaction with each other. The Chinese-born writers who will take part include Ha Jin, Su Tong and Yu Hua; on the Indian side, Amitav Ghosh, Amit Chaudhuri and Siddhartha Deb are among those scheduled to speak. In addition, the American scholars Jonathan Spence and Orville Schell will participate, and separate musical performances by musicians from each country are also scheduled.

title: Teen Spirit Smells Like . . . Victory!
description: If you have  or have ever had  a teenager in your home or, really, if you have ever known a teenager, then chances are theres been an occasion when you wondered, What was he thinking? (Or if he was thinking.) Thats why you should check out National Geographics October cover article by David Dobbs, The New Science of the Teenage Brain. Its full of fascinating things. Even Shakespeare is enlisted to sum up the problem of teenagedom, through a character who says, of 10- to 23-year-olds, There is nothing in the between but getting wenches with child, wronging the ancientry, stealing, fighting. The bard neglects drinking, drug doing, driving while drinking or drug doing, cutting classes, indulging all sorts of cyber shenanigans, playing too much of that damn Halo video game  wait, I sound like the ancientry, dont I?  but you get the idea. Teenagers are crazy.*

title: Is Race Reflected by Your Outfit?
description: THE GIST Our perception of race is altered by the clothing people wear.

title: At Muriel Brandolinis Auction, a Style Makers Cache
description: A selection of Muriel Brandolinis furniture and art collection will be auctioned next week at Phillips de Pury & Company.

title: At Auction, a Style Makers Cache
description: I LIKE things in their own juice, Muriel Brandolini said as she conducted a visitor around an installation of her personal collection of furniture and art at Phillips de Pury & Company, which will auction the selection next week. Ms. Brandolini was referring to her taste for objects that speak of their era, yet maintain a sense of quirky character.

title: A Gentle Push for Bikers, Not a Shove
description: NEXT summer, New York City plans to introduce its bike-share program, making two-wheeled travel possible for thousands more residents and tourists. Shared bikes, available at rental kiosks around the city, will have built-in safety features like a handlebar bell and front and rear lights that stay on all the time.

title: U.S. to Play France in Paris on Nov. 11
description: U.S. Soccer announced Friday that the national team would play a friendly against France on Nov. 11 at the Stade de France outside Paris.

title: Now Online | T Magazine Winter Womens Fashion 2011
description: The winter fashion issue starts with our cover star, the musician and photographerPatti Smith, and a profile of her by A.O. Scott. Inside, the actress Kirsten Dunst talks about awards, playing dress up and Hitchcock; the Arctic Monkeys show what life on the road is like; and Henry Louis Gates Jr. discusses black culture in America. And dont miss news of a Norell sale, Suzy Menkes on why old clothes move museum tickets, an article that explores whether acupuncture can really get rid of wrinkles and a look at the two women who are the real lovers behind a West Village sculpture. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $17,000,000
description: The three-bedroom condominium at 15 Central Park West that sold for $17 million  after last trading hands in 2008 for $6.8 million and thus generating nearly $10 million profit in just three years  was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.

title: The U.S.-South Korea Trade Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Micro-Mini Mom
description: I am a 14-year-old girl, and I get along with my mother pretty well. But she tends to wear clothes that are appropriate for girls my age  and totally wrong for 42-year-old mothers: skirts that are way too short, cropped tops and cutesy branded tees. I feel humiliated when my friends see her dressed up like that. But when I try to discuss the issue calmly, we end up screaming at each other. What can I do? Gillian

title: Milestones: Mitt Romney
description: An interactive timeline of Mitt Romneys life and career.

title: Busy Moms Morning Yoga
description: To the Editor:

title: Virgin Atlantic and British Airways Compete Over BMI
description: The rivalry between British Airways and Virgin Atlantic continues, this time over the midsize European carrier BMI. On Friday, Virgin Atlantic confirmed that it was in talks with the German carrier Lufthansa, the parent company of BMI, over a deal for the troubled airline. Britains Sky News reported earlier that the International Airlines Group  British Airways owner  was also in preliminary discussions. It was unclear whether the airlines were interested in buying BMI outright or merely adding some of its assets.

title: Unilever Buys Russian Cosmetics Brand
description: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch firm, has agreed to buy an 82 percent stake in Concern Kalina, a Russian cosmetics brand, for $537 million. Under the terms of the deal, Unilever will add Kalinas portfolio to the companys existing skin, hair and oral care brands in Russia. Consumer product companies have been looking to the emerging markets and beyond for growth. Russias economy is on track to grow 4.3 percent this year.

title: Childrens Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tall Tale, but True: Men in Heels
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Dressing Against Character
description: THE actor Kevin McHale, 23, plays Artie Abrams on Glee, in its third season on Fox. Before that, he belonged to the boy band NLT. A native of Plano, Tex., Mr. McHale now lives in Los Angeles. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: Foreclosures Empty Homes, and Criminals Fill Them Up
description: The boarded-up homes that changed the face of Jamaica, Queens, in recent years were bad enough, the flotsam of the record wave of housing foreclosures that roared through the streets like nowhere else in New York City.

title: Picking Up Public Radio, but Still No Talking Back
description: APP WNYC

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 14
description: See the Slide Show

title: The Critics Of Modern Macro Are Wrong
description: Its even worse than they think.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 11 MICHIGAN AT NO. 23 MICHIGAN STATENoon Eastern, ESPNIf Michigan State wins today, it will have its first four-game winning streak against its in-state rival in almost 50 years. Michigan is trying to climb back to national prominence. The winner gets sole possession of first place in the Leaders Division of the Big 10. Michigan State comes in with the top defense in the nation, allowing 173.4 total yards a game and having held four of its five opponents to 7 points or fewer. Spartans linebacker Denicos Allen had two sacks against Ohio State last week. Michigan quarterback Denard Robinson, right, is electrifying but has nine interceptions. The Wolverines are outscoring opponents, 114-21, in the second half, and much of the credit goes to the defensive coordinator Greg Mattison.

title: Wal-Marts Unlimited T-Mobile Data Plan
description: Thanks to consumer watchdogs, T-Mobile has not closed its deal with AT&T  but T-Mobile has closed a deal with Wal-Mart, and its one that consumer advocates might support.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: No Marriage License,

title: This Sunday: Twitterify the Magazine
description: Like some people, I have misgivings about Twitter. Nota philosophical quarrel. Its more that Im just not very good at tweeting. Mostly, I do it to promote the magazines articles, but sometimes that feels too self-serving, and I impulsively tweet something that momentarily strikes me as witty and/or meaningful. That never goes well. A few weeks ago, I tweeted inanely about umbrellas. Why should anyone care? It haunts me still.

title: Far From His Usual Haunts
description: Timothy Haskell, a designer of haunted houses, scares people for a living. This season he has created two: Nightmare: Z-Day, a zombie playhouse in the Bronx, running until Halloween, and Nightmare: Fairy Tales, on the Lower East Side, through Nov. 5. Mr. Haskell, 37, whose background is in Off Broadway theater, lives in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, with his wife, Rebeca Ramirez, who works at  Heart of Brooklyn, a partnership of cultural institutions,  and their son, Diego Haskell-Ramirez, 6.

title: A Centrist Pioneer in Egypt Faces New Competition
description: CAIRO

title: Going With Your Gut First, Then Your Heart
description: IN marriage and relationships, even on first dates, someones diet has become like their clothes or religion. It tells you something about how they feel about the planet, their bodies, their communities and their children.

title: Part of Alabama Immigrant Law Blocked
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  A federal appeals court in Atlanta temporarily blocked two provisions of Alabamas far-reaching immigration enforcement law on Friday, but left much of it in effect as the state and the United States Justice Department continued to fight over the law in the courts.

title: Educational Exchanges
description: To the Editor:

title: Regents Plan Push for Aid to Illegal Immigrants
description: When they vote on their legislative agenda on Tuesday, New York States top education officials will focus for the first time on the contentious topic of illegal immigration.

title: When a Casual Classic Gets Dressed Up
description: On any given evening, Recette, at 12th and Greenwich Streets, is a classic little West Village spot, casual, crowded and chatty, with candlelight and dark wood tables. But on the second Monday of each month, the staff removes about half of those tables, drapes the others with white cloths and hosts a quieter, more elegant evening. Mondays With Jesse, as the series is called, includes a 10-course tasting menu, an amuse-bouche, a glass of sparkling wine, sweets and a baked item to take home from the chef, Jesse Schenker, and the pastry chef, Christina Lee. Last week, the crowd included two friends weighing restaurants and education.

title: With Business Already Down, Dutrow Awaits Ruling on 10-Year Suspension
description: The day after being barred from racing in New York for 10 years, the trainer Richard Dutrow Jr. won the feature race at Belmont Park on Thursday with a filly named Tiz the Argument. He has three more horses entered at Belmont on Saturday, an afternoon that, if New York authorities get their way, will be his last as a horseman in good standing until 2021.

title: Kathryn and Gregory
description: Kathryn and Gregory talk about their first encounter at a Lindy Hop dance.

title: Gas Boom Aids Pennsylvania, but Some Worry Over the Risk
description: MONTROSE, Pa.  In the economic downturn three years ago, Adam Diaz idled the trucks at his bluestone quarry and silenced the saws at his lumber mill.

title: Testing State Aid Recipients for Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: In Israel, Swap Touches Old Wounds
description: JERUSALEM  Arnold Roth had just returned from synagogue on Friday morning when the phone rang. It was Israels Justice Ministry, telling him that two of the people who murdered his 15-year-old daughter Malka at a Jerusalem pizzeria a decade ago would be freed next week as part of an exchange of 1,000 Palestinian prisoners for an Israeli soldier held by Hamas.

title: Procter & Gamble Settles Trademark Dispute With Small Company
description: A Connecticut mother and businesswomanhas won the right to name her company after her daughter, Willa, despite the objections of the nations largest consumer products company.

title: A Top Quarterback Teased for Being 28
description: The age jokes have become, well, old. Brandon Weeden, the senior quarterback for the Oklahoma State Cowboys, certainly does not look or feel a day over 28, which is what he will be Saturday when he takes the field at Royal-Memorial Stadium to face the Texas Longhorns.

title: Bloggingheads: Conservative Class War?
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of the Independent Women's Forum debate conservative reaction to Occupy Wall Street.

title: Perry Promises Increased Drilling and Decreased Regulation
description: WEST MIFFLIN, Pa.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas released a long-promised jobs and energy proposal Friday that resembles a wish list for the oil and gas industry, promising new drilling across much of the country, including in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, as well as a curtailing of environmental regulations and dismantling the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: South Koreas Leader Helps Obama Woo Michigan
description: LAKE ORION, Mich.  The chief question rippling through a General Motors plant here in this vital swing state on Friday, as President Obama and his new B.F.F., President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea, tootled around on their free trade victory tour, was this: How did Mr. Obama get Mr. Lee to don that Detroit Tigers hat?

title: Korean Leaders Grandson Attending School in Bosnia
description: The grandson of the North Korean leader Kim Jong Il has started attending classes at United World College, a private English-language high school in Mostar, Bosnia, the former head of the Hong Kong branch of the school has confirmed. Stephen Codrington, currently the head of the Awty International School in Houston, Tex., interviewed the boy in Macau. Kim Han Sol, 16, is the son of Kim Jong Ils oldest son Kim Jong Nam. I was very impressed by his idealism, Mr. Codrington said in a phone interview from Singapore. Hes an intelligent, insightful boy with a maturity beyond his years. He has a real yearning for changing the situation on the Korean peninsula, which he feels very deeply about. Mr. Codrington said that the student passed the objective criteria for admission and received no special preference.

title: Philippines: Dictator Is Denied Burial Honors
description: The body of the former Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos will remain for now in its refrigerated crypt in the northern Philippines, as it has for most of the two decades since he died in exile in Hawaii. President Benigno Aquino III  the son of former President Corazon Aquino, who ousted Mr. Marcos in a 1986 uprising  appeared to put an end to a public spat with Mr. Marcoss son, who was demanding that the body be buried in the national cemetery in Manila along with other dignitaries. Speaking to reporters on Wednesday, Mr. Aquino said that a state funeral would be the height of injustice toward the victims of Mr. Marcoss strongman rule. Ferdinand Marcos Jr., who is now a senator, said he was offended by the surprise announcement, which appeared to ignore the recommendation of a presidential commission to bury Mr. Marcos with honors. All these talks, discussions and debates turned out to be just a stage play, Mr. Marcos said. The president replied, I think I will have to communicate this to the vice president, I apologize, hes been doing the study on my behalf.

title: In Year 11 as a Tiger, Finding Life After Toledo
description: It would have been understandable if the veteran Tigers third baseman Brandon Inge had taken his gear and gone home for good in late July.

title: Heres the Herminator
description: You may have heard that Herman Cain, the former chief of Godfathers Pizza, has become the latest in a list of peculiar front-runners for the Republican presidential nomination. Perhaps the Tea Party wing is just expressing its hostility toward Mitt Romney. Perhaps theres just something peculiar about the Tea Party.

title: Gaza Set to Embrace Released Prisoners
description: GAZA CITY  As soon as the minarets fell silent after the noon prayers, the noise of drills, hammers and saws rose from the center of Gaza City on Friday as workmen hurled planks and scaffolding poles into place in a huge stage that is being built to greet released prisoners.

title: Friday Night Music
description: As a baby boomer accustomed to listening to great old stuff, who has finally gotten into active artists, I face a new source of anxiety: will the next, long-awaited album live up to expectations?

title: Union Says Not Yet to Test for H.G.H.
description: Despite the urging of two Congressmen on Friday for the N.F.L. to begin testing for human growth hormone, the players union appeared steadfast in its position that it needs more scientific information before it will consent to such a program.

title: Liberia: President May Face Runoff
description: Partial presidential election results announced Friday suggest that the incumbent, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, could be headed to a runoff next month. With votes counted from 2,242 out of 4,457 polling places, Mrs. Sirleaf had 45 percent of the vote, to 30 percent for the ticket led by Winston Tubman, which also includes the former international soccer star George Weah, according to the National Elections Commission. If these percentages hold up, Mrs. Sirleaf would have less than the majority needed to win outright. In third place with 12 percent and the potential to be kingmaker is the former warlord Prince Johnson.

title: The Bleakness of the Bullied
description: I have watched with a heavy heart these last few years as one child after another has committed suicide because he or she was bullied.

title: Romney Raises $14 Million in 3rd Quarter, Second to Perrys Receipts
description: Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, raised just over $14 million for his presidential campaign during the three months that ended Sept. 30, according to campaign filings delivered to the Federal Election Commission on Friday.

title: The Death Penaltys De Facto Abolition
description: A new Gallup poll reports that support for the death penalty is at its lowest level since 1972. In fact, though, the decline, from a high of 80 percent in 1994 to 61 percent now, masks both Americans ambivalence about capital punishment and the countrys de facto abolition of the penalty in most places.

title: In Private, Wall St. Bankers Dismiss Protesters as Unsophisticated
description: Publicly, bankers say they understand the anger at Wall Street  but believe they are misunderstood by the protesters camped on their doorstep.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: The nations ports suggest that the holiday shopping season may disappoint, the Wall Street protests continued and continued to provoke, Europe pressed harder to find a solution to the deepening debt crisis and the iPhone 4S went on sale.

title: A Park, a Memorial, a Debate
description: AN October rain was pelting down on the overgrown and under-loved slice of the Village formally known as St. Vincents Triangle Park. At its apex, an ugly three-story brick building still shielded the gargantuan oxygen tanks that once pumped life into the bitterly missed St. Vincents Hospital, which succumbed to bankruptcy in 2010. From the squat structures double driveway and loading dock, patients who did not leave the hospital alive were removed to their final resting places.

title: Brewers Hairston Haunts La Russa, His Fathers Favorite Manager
description: ST. LOUIS  It was a little gift from one family to another, a miniature pull-cart holding a flower arrangement. Tony La Russa and his wife, Elaine, sent it to Jerry Hairston and his wife, Esperanza, after the birth of their son Jerry Jr., in 1976, when La Russa and Hairston were teammates on Class AAA Iowa in the Chicago White Sox farm system.

title: The 1930s Sure Sound Familiar
description: Not long ago, someone suggested that I read Since Yesterday, a book by Frederick Lewis Allen, a popular historian of the 1930s and 1940s. Published in 1940, it turned out to be a shrewd, concise, wonderfully written account of America in the 30s.

title: Selective Prosecution in Ukraine
description: The seven-year jail sentence imposed on Yulia Tymoshenko, the former prime minister of Ukraine, reeks of Soviet-style political revenge.

title: Mets Owners Seek to Avoid Trial by Jury in Madoff Case
description: The owners of the Mets are seeking to avoid a jury trial in the case filed against them by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs fraud. The owners could be forced to pay hundreds of millions of dollars in the case.

title: The Merits of Safe and Sound
description: WHY mess with a good thing?

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: That Old Celery Fizz

title: California: Arrests in Gang Crackdown
description: More than 100 people, almost all of them connected to Central California gangs, were arrested this week in the latest effort to curb street gangs, Attorney General Kamala Harris announced on Friday. The arrests resulted from an 18-month investigation by the California Department of Justice and other law enforcement agencies that began after a gang network set up operations in Gilroy. The operation also led to the seizure of 44 firearms, 81 stolen vehicles, 3 pounds of methamphetamine and other drugs. A majority of the 103 suspects arrested were gang members with felony convictions, the Department of Justice said. Suspects will face charges relating to auto theft, guns, gangs and the sale of narcotics.

title: Lottery Numbers
6 Attacks Linked to Pattern in Brooklyn
