description: The police said Friday that they had added six attacks in subway stations to a pattern of sexual assaults that have badly shaken several neighborhoods in South Brooklyn, bringing the total number of cases in that area up to 20 since March.

title: China: Social Media Rules Weighed
description: With the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party scheduled to begin meeting Saturday, Wang Chen, a senior propaganda official, said that social media need to be more tightly regulated. The government seems likely to follow through on many hints that it would step up regulation of various Twitter-like microblogs like Weibo, said Bill Bishop, an independent analyst specializing in social media.

title: G.O.P. vs. the Environment
description: As of Friday, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives had voted 168 times this year to undercut clean air and water laws while blocking efforts to limit global warming, protect public lands and guard against future oil spills. Henry Waxman, the senior Democrat on the Energy and Commerce Committee, calls this the most anti-environmental Congress in history.

title: Britains Self-Inflicted Misery
description: For a year now, Britains economy has been stuck in a vicious cycle of low growth, high unemployment and fiscal austerity. But unlike Greece, which has been forced into induced recession by misguided European Union creditors, Britain has inflicted this harmful quack cure on itself.

title: Baby Boy Dies; Was Given Pills as a Toy
description: A 13-month-old boy died after he apparently swallowed pills from a bottleof prescription drugs that his parents had given him to play with as a rattle, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Saturday: Rodins Thinker
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  So by now we all know that Joon Pahk ripped through Jeopardy!, won an ungodly amount of (pre-tax) money, qualified for the Tournament of Champions, and generally made us all proud, yes? Good, because today hes back as a constructor with a tough but ultimately fair and fun puzzle that contains quite a few interesting consecutive-consonant and unique entries. Notice that I didnt say crunchy. Youre welcome.

title: The Tigers Phone It In
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Friday was the first time the Detroit Tigers didnt bother to show up for the A.L.C.S.

title: Corrections: October 15
description: FRONT PAGE

title: For the Jets, Kickoffs and Returns, at Least, Have Not Been a Problem
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Nick Folk, the Jets kicker, says there is not much of an art to booting a football off a tee for a living.

title: Allegations of Iranian and U.S. Plots Are Added to a History of Hostility
description: WASHINGTON  When an Iranian scientist was shot and killed in front of his home in Tehran on July 23, he was the third researcher with supposed ties to Irans nuclear program to be assassinated in less than two years.

title: Battle for Libya | October 14, 2011
description: Fighters in Surt pounded loyalists holed up in two neighborhoods with rocket and machine-gun fire Friday, but also suffered heavy casualties themselves. Wounded men streamed into frontline medical units and then were evacuated to field hospitals on the citys outskirts.

title: Memorial Service for Steve Jobs at Stanford
description: Apple is planning to hold a memorial for its former chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, on Sunday on Stanford Universitys campus.

title: For Perry, Lobbyist Is a Take-No-Prisoners Ally
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Behind every politician there are men and women working in the wings, operatives who can make calls, fix problems, raise money, punish enemies.

title: One Day, Maybe, Artisanal Train Cars
description: Among the 275 tenants filling four million square feet of leasable space at the Brooklyn Navy Yard  now in the midst of its biggest expansion since World War II  are any number of industries that do not easily evoke the imagery of On the Waterfront. These are businesses where fine art is warehoused, where antiques are restored, where jewelry and leather garments are made  where the prosperous life, so much and so misleadingly in evidence in modern New York, receives its methodical upkeep.

title: Big East Planning to Add Six to Make 12
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The Big Easts expansion plans have solidified with a model for what the conference hopes its new 12-team football league will look like.

title: Wild Days Behind Him, Envoy Keeps Low Profile
description: WASHINGTON  For years, Adel al-Jubeir was the playboy Saudi envoy and man about town, hosting parties on the diplomatic circuit, hobnobbing with this citys political elite and appearing at events with media celebrities like Campbell Brown, then the White House correspondent for NBC News.

title: Aggressive Bills Leave No Room for Errant Passes
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It seemed as if Eli Manning had figured it out. The questions he faced after throwing a career- and league-high 25 interceptions last season seemed a distant memory. Through four games, he had thrown just two interceptions and the Giants had won three in a row.

title: Photos From China Offer Scant Clues to a Succession
description: BEIJING  It seems a mundane enough photograph: on July 14, the front page of Peoples Daily, the Communist Partys official newspaper, showed President Hu Jintao shaking hands with military scholars. Mr. Hus heir apparent, Vice President Xi Jinping, was close behind.

title: N.B.A. Players Union Fights Off Impression That It Isnt United
description: LOS ANGELES  N.B.A players on Friday rejected Commissioner David Sterns threat to cancel games through Christmas if there was no breakthrough in Tuesdays scheduled meeting with a federal mediator.

title: A Tour of Asia and an Eye for Detail
description: THE narrow entrance to Lucky Buddha in Thornwood belies this restaurants beautifully apportioned vastness. Inside the entry a monumental Buddha perches on a seat of river stones, a pond with swimming koi below, his presence only the beginning of an array of appealing Asian touches.

title: U.N. Official Urges World to Stand Up for Syrians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A top United Nations official urged the international community on Friday to protect Syrian civilians from a brutal military crackdown by the government of President Bashar al-Assad, as activists said that at least 11 people were shot dead in demonstrations nationwide.

title: Racial Disparities in Infant Mortality
description: Chart shows infant mortality rate, cause of death and characteristics of mother.

title: Egypts Military Expands Power, Raising Alarms
description: CAIRO  Egypts military rulers are moving to assert and extend their own power so broadly that a growing number of lawyers and activists are questioning their willingness to ultimately submit to civilian authority.

title: Taking a Tour of the Mediterranean
description: WHILE there are French dishes available at Caf dAzur in Darien, the menu at this small restaurant is more aptly defined by the description on its window: Mediterranean Bistro and Bar.

title: Germans Condemn Police Use of Spyware
description: BERLIN  A group that calls itself the Chaos Computer Club prompted a public outcry here recently when it discovered that German state investigators were using spying software capable of turning a computers webcam and microphone into a sophisticated surveillance device.

title: Tackling Infant Mortality Rates Among Blacks
description: PITTSBURGH  Amanda Ralph is the kind of woman whose babies are prone to die. She is young and poor and dropped out of school after the ninth grade.

title: U.S. Sending More Contractors to Secure Libyas Weapons Stockpile
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department is sending dozens of American contractors to Libya to help that countrys fledgling efforts to track down and destroy heat-seeking antiaircraft missiles looted from government stockpiles that could be used against civilian airliners.

title: New Varieties Leave Red Delicious Behind
description: GILLETTE, N.J.

title: Jets Guard Says Internal Critics Hurt Team Unity
description: Jets guard Brandon Moore responded Friday to Santonio Holmess critical comments Thursday about the offensive line, telling ESPNNewYork.com that such talk fragments the locker room.

title: High Output and Low Prices
description: The large production capacity of Pindar Vineyards in Peconic exploits economies ofscale that translate into low prices for consumers. Thats alluring these days.

title: A Taste of New Orleans, With a Side of Barbecue
description: Maras Homemade looks like a typical Long Island storefront: a long, narrow space with tile floor, bare wood tables and paper napkins. Its dcor and food, though, evoke New Orleans, turning an ordinary-looking place into a destination restaurant.

title: The World This Week, Part 1
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: The World This Week, Part 2
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Cardinals Dont Waste Off Night by Brewers
description: ST. LOUIS  The crowd at Busch Stadium gasped when Jerry Hairston Jr., the Milwaukee Brewers third baseman, swooped to his side to snatch a sizzling line drive. They groaned when Yuniesky Betancourt, the Brewers shortstop, dashed onto the outfield grass, his back to home plate, to corral a fluttering fly ball.

title: A Glimpse Into a Maestros Salon, After Hours
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN, a man of peace with an innate theatricality, knew the value of playing against type; when the mood struck, he would jokingly threaten to clear the wee-hour revelers from his living room by digging into Aaron Coplands gnarly Piano Variations. So said his daughter, Jamie Bernstein, as she narrated Late Night With Leonard Bernstein, a look at the after-hours maestro, which opened the 2011-12 season in the Copland House concert series last month.

title: A Final Curtain, but More Opening Ones Are Ahead
description: East Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Both Sides Say They Dont Feel the Pressure
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Pressure was a popular topic in the Rangers clubhouse Friday. Predictably, nobody would admit to feeling any for Game 6.

title: Fats Waller, Reimagined
description: If one musical number captures the spirit of Aint Misbehavin (even more than the title song), its probably the 1938 toe-tapper The Joint Is Jumpin. But in the Crossroads Theater Companys spirited new production, its the out-of-character numbers that are most memorable.

title: Following Uncertainty and Finding Music
description: UNCERTAINTY is getting a particularly bad rap these days, not least from politicians and pundits who blame it for the reluctance of businesses to hire and consumers to spend. But to Carl Testa, a musician for whom the act of making art is not divorced from the conditions in which it is made, the rise of uncertainty is a precursor to social transformation.

title: In New England, Taking on German Expressionism
description: YOU could say that Adam Van Doren was born with a silver-edged book in his hands. A third-generation member of the famous Van Doren clan of New York and Cornwall, Conn., he grew up among writers, poets, critics and academics. His grandfather, Mark, and great-uncle, Carl, were both Pulitzer Prize-winning professors at Columbia University; his uncle, Charles, also taught at Columbia until his involvement in the TV quiz show scandal of 1959 brought his career to an abrupt end.

title: Be Careful Just Whom You Decide to Interrupt
description: Im sorry to interrupt, but could you guys please finish up? a woman asked Nocturnalists correspondent at Town Hall theater on 43rd Street on Thursday night as he conducted an interview. He was sitting in her seat, she said.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.14
description: The day in sports included gymnastics in Mexico and volleyball in Qatar.

title: Iran: Did Plot Dialogue Take Place?
description: American officials said Thursday that they had conveyed their concerns to the Iranian government over the alleged plot to assassinate Saudi Arabias ambassador to the United States. But on Friday, Irans official Islamic Republic News Agency insisted that American officials had not been in direct contact with Iran. Payton Knopf, a spokesman for the United States Mission to the United Nations, said, though, that there has been direct contact with the U.S. government. He declined to elaborate.

title: Cheating in New York City Schools: 14 Cases
description: A collection of reports by the special commissioner of investigation for the New York City school system.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Regents to Vote on Change to Cut Risk of Teachers Test-Tampering
description: The New York State Board of Regents will decide Monday whether to bar teachers from grading their own students standardized tests, a longstanding practice that state officials say creates a temptation for educators to cheat in an era of high-stakes exams.

title: Vic Miles, Reporter and Anchor on WCBS-TV, Dies at 79
description: Vic Miles, who brought a no-nonsense, get-to-the-essence style to his 24 years as a reporter and anchorman for WCBS-TV/Channel 2 in New York, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Ray Aghayan, Costume Designer, Dies at 83
description: Ray Aghayan designed his first dress, at 13, for a member of the royal court of the shah of Iran, which at the time employed his mother as a couturier, a sort of in-house designer for the personal and ceremonial needs of the Reza Pahlavi family.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Indias longest railway tunnel, through the Pir Panchal mountain range, was opened on Friday. The seven-mile long tunnel, which will connect Kashmir with the outside world, will be operational by 2012, Northern Railway officials said. (Greater Kashmir)Manipur: A 2-month-old blockade on arterial highways connecting Manipur is wreaking havoc in the state, the Manipur Peoples Party said, causing skyrocketing prices for food, fuel and other basic amenities. (Nagaland Post) However, the chief minister of Manipur, Okram Ibobi, rubbished these reports, saying you people sit there and report, come to Manipur tomorrow and see it is not true. (Telegraph)

title: A Texas Town
description: In Irving, Tex., a town transformed by immigrants, a crackdown on illegal immigration is creating discord among residents.

title: Hamilton Takes First Step Toward Silencing Critics  and Dethrones Red Bull
description: YEONGAM, South Korea  Lewis Hamilton scored pole position for the Korean Grand Prix during an exciting qualifying session on Saturday. He broke up the streaks of Red Bull team drivers Sebastian Vettel and Mark Webber, who had secured all 15 pole positions this year.

title: Hamilton Takes First Step Toward Silencing Critics  and Dethrones Red Bull

title: Strikes Hit Yemen as Violence Escalates in Capital

title: With Maya Moore
description: Maya Moore just wins. And wins. And wins. A four-time all-American at Connecticut, she won two national basketball championships and advanced to two other Final Fours, and the Huskies posted an N.C.A.A.-record 89 consecutive victories. Moore continued where she left off at the next level. Drafted first over all by the Minnesota Lynx in April, she finished third on the team in scoring at 13.2 points a game. She was the leagues rookie of the year and helped lead the Lynx, with the fellow All-Stars Seimone Augustus and Lindsay Whalen, to the franchises first championship.

title: A Bit More About Cain
description: A brief note while waiting for a family member to finish with the doctor: From comments I see that some readers believe that Cains second 9 is a profits tax, which Ive argued in the past probably falls on capital owners. But it isnt: its a tax on all business income, defined as sales minus purchased inputs and dividends  but with no deduction for wages. So the new element here is, in effect, a 9 percent tax on wages paid.

Then theres Boise State, which could be a member of the Big East by the end of this week. And dont forget once-mighty Texas, less than two years removed from an appearance in the national title game, proving once again that its sputtering football program cant back up its boardroom leverage, branding power and market reach.

title: B&Bs That Break the Dolls-and-Doilies Mold
description: The phrase bed and breakfast often conjures images of stuffy homes filled with dusty doilies and collections of wide-eyed dolls. But the B&B industry and its standards have evolved. Say goodbye to the days of squeaky beds and frivolous throw pillows and embrace the shift toward classically elegant and strikingly modern retreats. Whether you prefer attentive or hands-off service, accommodations steeped in history or an urban atmosphere, there is a (feather-topped or custom-built) bed and a (candlelit or grab-and-go) breakfast that fits your needs.

title: U.S. Cuts Back the Proposed Size of Its Force in Iraq

description: SPORTS

title: Mayoral Fund Encourages Slim-Chance Candidates
description: For the past 10 months, Phil Ting, after a days work as San Franciscos assessor-recorder, has rolled up his sleeves and campaigned for mayor. He has shaken hands with residents around the city and promised to reform the citys beleaguered mass transit system.

title: Big East Says It Hasnt Invited Anyone, Yet
description: Big East officials spent much of Saturday trying to fend off erroneous media reports regarding the leagues expansion. They said that no invitations to potential new members had been issued despite multiple reports to the contrary.

title: Bocce Courts
description: Members of the Martinez Bocce Federation  192 teams of up to 10 players each  go toe to toe on 15 outdoor courts in Martinez Waterfront Park from the spring through the fall. In winter, a group that calls itself the Martinez Morning Mafia gathers here to play every morning, rain or shine. LOUISE RAFKIN

title: They Bark, They Fetch, and Their Humans Vote
description: Last week, Supervisor John Avalos, a San Francisco mayoral candidate, landed one of the citys more coveted endorsements when he won the backing of DogPAC, a relatively new political action committee representing dozens of dog lovers groups citywide.

title: Rallies Across the Globe Protest Economic Policies
description: Hundreds and in some cases thousands of people expressed discontent with the economy in Asia, the Americas and Europe.

title: After Solyndra, a 2nd Solar Energy Firm Is Scrutinized
description: Three weeks before Solyndra, the solar-panel manufacturer, based in Fremont, declared bankruptcy, the United States Department of Energy issued a $197 million loan guarantee to another Bay Area solar company that uses the same innovative, but risky, technology.

title: The No. 1 Player, and Master of the Late Rally
description: When he was ranked No. 1 a few years ago, Veselin Topalov got into a strange habit of falling behind in tournaments before storming back to win.

title: At the Library, Vintage Hip-Hop and Meditation
description: Chuck D of Public Enemy once famously said that rap music was the CNN of the ghetto. These days, it seems, the New York Public Library is Madison Square Garden  or maybe the Hot 97  for lions of hip-hop trying to send glossy new books to the top of the charts.

title: Loss Leaves Red Bulls a Must-Win Game
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan.  In the final stretch of the Major League Soccer regular season, the experience of a veteran like Thierry Henry can make all the difference in a teams scramble to qualify for the playoffs.

title: Rangers Storm Back Into Another World Series
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  A year ago the Texas Rangers made franchise history when they reached the World Series for the first time, but the journey ended in disappointment when they lost to the San Francisco Giants in five games.

title: Jeanne Cathcart, Brian Gari
description: Jeanne Marie Cathcart and Brian Gari were married Saturday at their New York apartment. Sandra B. Wells, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Lindsey Barst, Jason Gumer
description: Lindsey Sarah Barst, a daughter of Dr. Robyn J. Barst and Dr. Samuel M. Barst of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married Saturday evening at her familys vacation home in Amagansett, N.Y., to Jason Brian Gumer, the son of Sherie B. Gumer and Dr. Arthur Gumer of Atlanta. Rabbi Scott E. Colbert officiated.

title: Paying for the Prom
description: Despite difficult financial times, the high school prom is still a must-attend event.

title: Kathryn Phillips, Gregory Charvat
description: Kathryn Elizabeth Phillips and Gregory Louis Charvat were married Saturday at Bournedale, an events space in Plymouth, Mass. Michael R. Sheppard, a friend of the bridegroom, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to perform the ceremony.

title: Kevin Burke, Miguel Pedraza-Cumba
description: Kevin Clifford Burke and Miguel Luis Pedraza-Cumba were married Saturday morning in New Brighton, Staten Island. The Rev. Susan Karlson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of Staten Island.

title: Jennifer Mushkin and Jared Goldman
description: Jennifer Mushkin and Jared Ian Goldman were married Saturday evening at Hempstead House in Sands Point, N.Y. Rabbi Dr. Robert S. Widom officiated. Gary Wayne Gewant, an uncle of the bridegroom who became a Universal Life Church minister for the occasion, led the couple in their vows.

title: Samantha Herman, Adrian Jachens
description: Dr. Samantha Paige Herman and Dr. Adrian William Jachens were married Saturday evening at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Judge Jerald R. Klein of Civil Court in the Bronx officiated.

title: Sylvia Simson and Olaitan Gambari
description: Sylvia Ester Simson, a daughter of Claudine Y. Simson and Moris M. Simson of Austin, Tex., was married Saturday to Olaitan Gambari, a son of Fatimah A. Gambari and Ibrahim A. Gambari of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Patricia Dugan and William Perlmuth
description: Patricia Anne Dugan and William Alan Perlmuth were married Saturday evening at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Sam Go, Stokes Young
description: Jesamyn Go and Stokes Enley Young were married Saturday evening at the Villa at Moosebeck, an event space in Spring Glen, N.Y. Dan Klyn, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Margaret Winterkorn-Meikle and Matthew Meyers
description: Margaret Katherine Winterkorn-Meikle, the daughter of Dr. Jacqueline Winterkorn of Roxbury, Conn., and the late Dr. Thomas H. Meikle Jr., was married Saturday to Matthew Todd Meyers, the son of Claude B. Meyers and Joseph J. Meyers of Manhattan. Judge Kiyo A. Matsumoto of Federal District Court in Brooklyn officiated at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Andrea De Gregory, Julian Leone
description: Andrea Lynn De Gregory and Julian Leone were married Saturday afternoon at the Harbor View Hotel in Edgartown, Mass. James S. Pringle, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Rachel Gore, Jonathan Freed
description: Rachel Elizabeth Gore and Jonathan Tyler Freed were married Friday in Nashville. Richard McCarty, a friend of the brides family and the provost of Vanderbilt University who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated at the Belle Meade Plantation, a museum and events space.

title: Devin MacLachlan, Bruce Marcus
description: Devin Mitchel MacLachlan and Bruce David Marcus are to be married Sunday evening at the Kimberly hotel in New York. Allison Dolan Hall, a Spiritual Humanist minister, is to officiate.

title: Charles Dupree and Matthew Cole
description: The Rev. Charles Thomas Dupree and Matthew Bodine Cole were married Wednesday at the Lake Hill, N.Y., weekend home of James Conrad, a friend of the couple. Janet W. Baus, another friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Allison Sheppard, Joshua Sirchio

Sirchio of Lafayette Hill, Pa. The Rev. Peter M. Donohue, the president of Villanova University, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony there in St. Thomas of Villanova Church.

title: Lily Koppel, Tom Folsom
description: Lily Koppel and Tom Folsom were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, where Michael McSweeney, the New York City clerk, performed the ceremony.

title: Marisa Van Saanen and David Murray
description: Marisa Bronwyn Van Saanen and David J. Murray were married Saturday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Washington. The Rev. Kevin OBrien, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Victor H. Kazanjian, an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: Megan Sullivan, Steven Sharpe
description: Megan Mary Sullivan and Steven Peter Sharpe were married Thursday at St. Barnabas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bellmore, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph C. Coschignano , the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Christine Diaz, Austin Morda
description: Christine Diaz and Austin Daniel Morda were married Saturday at St. Edward Church in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Michael E. Giglio, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony with the assistance of Ramon G. Diaz, a Roman Catholic deacon and an uncle of the bride.

description: Julia Inger Weiss and Brett David Taxin were married Saturday in St. Petersburg, Fla. Rabbi Gary M. Klein officiated at the Vinoy Renaissance hotel, with Cantor Deborah Jacobson taking part.

title: Jacqueline Goulart, Jonathan Berliner

Goulart of Ridgewood, N.J., was married Saturday to Dr. Jonathan Levi Berliner, a son of Barbara Levi-Berliner and Edward M. Berliner of Weston, Conn. The Rev. Katherine Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Basin Harbor Club in Vergennes, Vt.

title: Emily Heller, Joseph Lazarus
description: Emily Elizabeth Heller and Joseph Hobart Lazarus were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Mikki Bourne at the Conservatory of Flowers in Golden Gate Park in San Francisco.

title: Julian Petri, Thomas Miller
description: Peter Julian Vico Petri and Thomas Marshall Miller were married Saturday. The Rev. Holly Lyman Antolini performed the ceremony at St. Jamess Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass., where she is the rector.

title: Katherine Homan, James Tyrrell III
description: Katherine Schuyler Homan, the daughter of Patricia A. Homan and Philip Schuyler Homan of Bowie, Md., was married Saturday to James Edward Tyrrell III, a son of Kathleen A. Tyrrell and Mr. Tyrrell Jr. of Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. Kevin Regan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington.

title: Naomi Wender, James Leslie
description: Naomi Joy Wender and James Alexander Leslie were married Saturday evening at the Down Town Association, an event space in New York. The Rev. David J. Robb, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated. The couple met at Columbia, from which each received an M.B.A.

title: Sarah Maltzman, Neil Shah
description: Sarah E. Maltzman and Neil D. Shah were married Saturday in an outdoor ceremony at the International, a golf club in Bolton, Mass. Judge John M. Julian of the Edgartown District Court in Edgartown, Mass., officiated. On Friday evening the couple exchanged vows in a traditional Indian ceremony at the Holiday Inn in Boxborough, Mass., which was led by Pandit Jayant Sane, a Hindu priest.

title: Katherine Schuman, Ripley Odell
description: Katherine Ardath Schuman and Ripley Scotten Odell were married Saturday evening at their apartment in Manhattan. Joanne Hubbard Cossa, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Rebecca Dince, Adam Zipkin
description: Rebecca Smith Dince and Adam Ross Zipkin were married Saturday. Rabbi Serge A. Lippe officiated at Carlyle on the Green, an events space in Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Kelly Kocinski, Josiah Trager
description: Kelly Lynn Kocinski, a daughter of Sharon L. Voris of Pierceton, Ind., and Dennis C. Kocinski of St. John, Ind., was married Saturday in Las Vegas to Josiah Samuel Trager, the son of Roberta E. Weisbrod of Brooklyn and the late Judge David G. Trager. The ceremony, at the Four Seasons Hotel, was led by Elena M. Paul McDonald, a friend of the bride who received authorization from the State of Nevada to officiate, with Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court in Brooklyn taking part.

title: Nicole Popov, Brad Doppelt
description: Nicole Love Popov, the daughter of Lela P. Love and Peter N. Popov of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to Brad S. Daniel Doppelt, a son of Diane and Earl Doppelt of Purchase, N.Y. Acting State Supreme Court Justice Alex M. Calabrese, who presides at the Red Hook Community Justice Center in Brooklyn, is to officiate at Tribeca Rooftop in Manhattan.

title: Sara Blumstein, Michael Elkin
description: Sara Lynn Blumstein and Michael Scott Elkin were married Saturday evening at Century Country Club, an event space in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Aaron D. Panken officiated, with Cantor Shira Ginsburg taking part in the ceremony.

title: Lottery Numbers
Stoic Tigers Can Only Watch the Scene
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Miguel Cabrera stood with his arms crossed, a matter-of-fact pose, in front of his locker stall as the sounds of the Texas Rangers celebration seeped into the Detroit Tigers clubhouse.

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: RYAN TANNEHILL AND ROBERT GRIFFIN III The opposing quarterbacks in No. 21 Texas A&Ms 55-28 victory at home against No. 20 Baylor combined for 845 passing yards and 9 touchdown passes. The Aggies Tannehill, left, threw for 415 yards and a career-high 6 scores, and Griffin, right, had a team-record 430 yards and 3 touchdowns.

title: The Torment of St. Anthony
description: The Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth has acquired what some scholars now say is the first painting made by Michelangelo.

title: Bacon Ice Cream, and More
description: Cast iron and irony mix at the Park Slope Pork-Off, one of the city's local cook-offs that are to the Pillsbury Bake-Off as Twitter is to ham radio.

title: Ernesto Neto at the Armory
description: Images from the installation of Ernesto Netos work at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: Ginger Ale Remains the Rangers Bubbly of Choice
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As has become their custom, the Texas Rangers celebrated their second consecutive American League pennant by spraying ginger ale on one another on the field after their 15-5 victory against the Detroit Tigers in the American League Championship Series on Saturday night.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Tehelka writes about the tussle between the government and Indias news media, particularly its cable news channels. Ashok Malik writes that the government now fears the media more than it does the opposition. The governments efforts to rein in the media have faltered, even as news outlets have become more shrill and unethical, he says. Vinod Mehta, the editor of Outlook magazine, tells Mr. Malik: Transgressions of the media, in style and in content, are growing. The atmosphere of polemics and name calling is distorting national debate.

title: Bills at Giants: Matchup to Watch
description: Bills (4-1) at Giants (3-2), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Vettel Takes 10th Victory, Red Bull Takes Title, but Hamilton Provides the Story
description: YEONGAM, South Korea  Sebastian Vettel may have won the Korean Grand Prix on Sunday in his usual dominating manner, taking his 10th victory of the season and the 20th of his career. And his team, Red Bull, may have won the 2011 constructors title thanks to that result. But all of the excitement both on track and off throughout the weekend came from another man: Lewis Hamilton.

title: Vettel Takes 10th Victory, Red Bull Takes Title, but Hamilton Provides the Story
description: YEONGAM, South Korea  Sebastian Vettel may have won the Korean Grand Prix on Sunday in his usual dominating manner, taking his 10th victory of the season and the 20th of his career. And his team, Red Bull, may have won the 2011 constructors title thanks to that result. But all of the excitement both on track and off throughout the weekend came from another man: Lewis Hamilton.

title: Niners-Lions: A Rarely Relevant Rivalry
description: It would seem unlikely that over the course of 62 seasons, two N.F.L. teams could combine for eight championships but manage to play each other in 50 largely irrelevant games. But mediocrity has been the standard when it comes to games between the Detroit Lions and San Francisco 49ers.

title: A Videocamera That Captures 360 Degrees of Action
description: Video in 3-D may be all the rage, but there is an inexpensive new video tool that I think has greater potential to change the way you shoot video.

title: A Dedication to King, and the Work Yet to Do
description: WASHINGTON  They came from across the country, some arriving before dawn, carrying folding chairs, cameras and a strong, proud sense of history. Thousands stood and sat together under a bright blue sky Sunday as a memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.  the first honoring an African-American in the area of the Mall  was dedicated at last.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu
description: The Sunday shows cover several issues this week, focusing in particular on the 2012 presidential race, the threat of sanctions against Iran and President Obamas job creation proposal.

title: Machiavelli and Humanitys Lukewarm Response to Warming
description: After I wrote on the hidden factor behind the lopsidedness of the climate-energy policy fight (the inertia in a society and economy deeply reliant on fossil fuels), Paul Birkeland of Seattle posted an apt quotation from Niccolo Machiavelli:

title: Cain Says His Deadly Fence Plan Was a Joke
description: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

title: The Fight Against Female Genital Cutting
description: In October 2011, The New York Timess Celia Dugger reported from West Africa on community-based efforts to eradicate female genital cutting.

title: SNL Suggests What the Mayor Might Say About Protesters
description: New Yorks billionaire mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, has tread a careful line in responding to the Occupy Wall Street protest movement  expressing support for the protesters First Amendment rights, while criticizing their anti-Wall Street message.

title: Footloose a Wallflower; Real Steel Still Dancing
description: Hollywoods box-office blues continued over the weekend as remakes of Footloose and The Thing fizzled. Real Steel (DreamWorks Studios) repeated as No. 1 by a sliver, taking in about $16.3 million for a two-week total of $51.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. Footloose stumbled in second place, selling an estimated $16.1 million in tickets, a frail result given the months-long marketing push that Paramount Pictures lavished on the film. The good news: Footloose, built around a cast of unknowns, cost only about $24 million to make. The Thing (Universal Pictures) was third with $8.7 million in ticket sales  not exactly a bloodbath given its production cost of about $38 million but a disappointment nonetheless. George Clooneys Ides of March (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth, taking in about $7.5 million for a two-week total of $22.2 million. Dolphin Tale (Warner Brothers) rounded out the top five with $6.3 million in ticket sales, lifting its four-week tally to $58.7 million. For the weekend, North American theaters recorded $89 million in ticket sales, a 32 percent drop from the same weekend last year.

title: As Yemeni Revolt Escalates, Pro-Government Forces Fire on Protesters for a Second Day
description: SANA, Yemen  For the second day in a row, demonstrators in the capital escalated their protest by marching into government-held territory on Sunday, and for the second day in a row they were fired on by pro-government forces. At least five people were killed.

title: Sunday OWS Notes
description: A couple of scattered notes on whats going on.

title: Zimbabwe: 3 Women Charged With Sexual Attacks on 17 Men
description: The police in Zimbabwe on Friday charged three women in connection with a spate of sexual attacks on male hitchhikers over the past two years, CNN reports.

title: Climate Change Is Shrinking Species, Research Suggests
description: Climate changes laundry list of impacts  melting glaciers and rising sea levels, shifts in timing for bird migration and flower budding, a poleward shift of species  just got a new addition: shrinking species.

title: Metro Pucks: Tavares and Isles at Head of Class
description: Our weekly review of the performances of the three local N.H.L. teams.

title: Kinder Morgan to Buy El Paso for $21.1 Billion
description: 9:53 p.m. | Updated

title: A Print Shop Cranks Back Up, Ancient as Ever
description: The first thing about Robert Warners print shop is it is urine-free.

title: Drawing Inspiration From Rilke
description: The conductorless Orpheus Chamber Orchestra has long demonstrated its mettle in Baroque and classical fare. More recently it has ventured into romantic and contemporary terrain, which is invariably harder to navigate without a conductor.

title: Israel Releases Names of 477 Prisoners to Be Freed in Trade
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Israel on Sunday released the names of the first 477 Palestinian prisoners that it will exchange for a soldier held by the militant faction Hamas, and the list revealed why the country has found the trade so wrenching: a majority of the inmates were convicted of manslaughter, attempted murder or intentionally causing death.

title: Dissecting Freedom on a Grand Scale
description: There are many moments in Visible when what seems casual is likely to be painstakingly drawn, when multiple layers of sound, text and movement create a kind of symphony. The production still seems half-baked, yet when it coheres, its like good jazz: without being literal it finds its way back to its theme.

title: A Conductors Homecoming
description: Polished but perfunctory music making and unadventurous programming were often the hallmarks of Lorin Maazels tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic. An amiable matinee concert on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall, the first time Mr. Maazel has conducted the Philharmonic since his departure in 2009, continued that tradition.

title: In Italy, Rioting Leads to Recriminations
description: ROME  As the smoke cleared Sunday, a day after a peaceful, inchoate demonstration near the Colosseum turned into a riot, Italy fell into national soul-searching and finger-pointing.

title: The Centurys Sounds, So Far
description: A festival of 20th-century music is just so yesterday.

title: Hollande Wins Runoff to Become Socialist Candidate for French Presidency
description: PARIS  More than six months before the French presidential election, the main candidates appear to be set, with Franois Hollande, 57, winning a runoff election on Sunday to become the Socialist Partys presidential candidate.

title: Postal Union Turns to Wall Street for Advice on Its Future
description: Can Ron Bloom, the restructuring expert who helped shore up the automobile and steel industries in the United States, save the ailing United States Postal Service?

title: When Applying the Paint Was Spreading the News
description: Early on the morning of July 27, 1861, New Yorks 69th (Irish) Regiment returned from the First Battle of Bull Run, landing by steamboat at what is now Battery Park.

title: Exeunt
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company has announced that Michael Boyd will step down as artistic director next year, after more than a decade in the job, the BBC News reported. The executive director, Vikki Heywood, will leave her post at the same time. Under their supervision, the company recently completed a $177 million renovation of its theaters in Stratford-Upon-Avon, England, and a successful six-week run of performances in New York at the Park Avenue Armory. Mr. Boyd is also a chief architect of the World Shakespeare Festival, a celebration set to run from April to September 2012. Mr. Boyd said in a statement that it was time for me to pass the challenges on to a new artistic director. The company is expected to announce a successor early next year.

title: Following Coaches Orders, Giants Produce Closing Kick Against Bills
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Near the end of every Giants practice, as the players shoulders are drooping and their legs are dragging, a familiar refrain can be heard from the coaching staff.

title: Monsters v. Kittens
description: Stan Lee, a co-creator of childhood mainstays like Spider-Man, the X-Men and the Fantastic Four, will join with 1821 Comics to start a multimedia imprint for children called Stan Lees Kids Universe. The imprint, announced at the New York Comic Con on Friday and reported on galleycat.com, is to feature five books, including Monsters vs. Kittens, created by Dani Jones, and Reggie the Veggie Crocodile. Also among their plans is a video game for iPhone and iPad. At a Comic Con panel presentation, Mr. Lee said, Our main purpose is we feel that there arent enough comic books or books for kids that really hit the target, that gives them excitement and humor together and are filled with surprises. We have a whole new group of new characters that the kids can call their own, just as the teenagers called Spider-Man their own so many years ago. Mr. Lee is also collaborating with the 1821 Comics co-founder Terry Douglas, the writer Max Work and the artist Skan Srisuwan on a graphic novel, Romeo & Juliet: The War, a futuristic interpretation of the play  but with superpowers. The book is to be released in November.

title: Was Schwartz Justified in Being Upset With Harbaugh?
description: Lions Coach Jim Schwartz chased after Niners Coach Jim Harbaugh and bumped him after what he apparently felt was an overexuberant celebration by Harbaugh following the 49ers 25-19 victory on Sunday.

title: Kenyan Forces Enter Somalia to Battle Militants
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Kenyan military stormed into Somalia on Sunday, sending hundreds of troops to battle the Shabab militant group and becoming the latest East African country to be dragged into Somalias intractable anarchy.

title: A Surprising Twist in a Career That Has Been Full of Them
description: Kenny Anderson is one of the most intriguing athletes I have covered. He didnt score the most points or transform the game, but his career from 13 to 35 illustrates the dark and light spots of an industry built on the backs of children.

title: One Big Happy Family (and Prisoner)
description: In the horror movie The Woman Chris Cleek is a prosperous country lawyer with oil industry contacts and a secretary he flirts with. He runs his handsome home with almost military efficiency, having trained his family  Brian, in middle school, a chip off the old block; Peggy, a wary, withdrawn teenager; Darlin, his charming post-toddler daughter; and Belle, his docile wife  to heed his authority. He enjoys his camouflage gear, scoped rifle and solo hunting expeditions. So when he finds the fierce, feral Woman subsisting in the woods, why shouldnt he capture her in a net, suspend her in manacles from the roof of a ground cellar and enlist his family in her rehabilitation?

title: Gross Miscalculation
description: Somehow I missed this: Joe Weisenthal informs us that Bill Gross has publicly apologized for getting the bond market so wrong, predicting a spike in interest rates when QE2 ended. As Weisenthal points out, however, Grosss exaggerated fear of deficits was very widespread; it was, indeed, what all the Very Serious People were obsessing about, even as the real economy was falling apart.

title: Wheldon, Indy 500 Winner, Dies After Crash
description: Dan Wheldon, a popular and congenial racecar driver from England who won the Indianapolis 500 for the second time in May, died Sunday in a fiery 15-car accident early in a 300-mile IndyCar Series race at Las Vegas Motor Speedway.

title: A Grand Opening for the Martin Luther King Jr. Monument
description: An expansive three-hour ceremony opened the memorial to Martin Luther King Jr. in Washington on Sunday, with speeches by President Obama and civil rights leaders like Representative John Lewis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and songs by performers like Aretha Franklin, my colleagues Helene Cooper and Sabrina Tavernise reported:

title: Monday: Welcome to Day One of the Crossword Puzzle Contest
description: Administrivial Contest Rules Alert! All the puzzles this week, from Monday to Saturday, have been created by one person, Patrick Berry. Have your solutions handy, because the Saturday puzzle conceals a meta-challenge involving the solution grids of all six.When you have the answer to the meta-challenge, e-mail it to: crossword@nytimes.com. Please do not post your answers here on the blog and please do not mail them to me! Only answers e-mailed to the above address will be considered.Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6 p.m. Eastern time Sunday, Oct. 23, will receive copies of Will Shortz Picks His Favorite Puzzles: 101 of the Top Crosswords From The New York Times. Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners names will appear on Friday, Oct. 28, at nytimes.com/wordplay.

title: An Innocent Whos Adrift in Mumbai
description: Life, according to a song in the Bollywood comedy My Friend Pinto, is cute, and has many moods: sometimes its misty, sometimes its crispy (or so goes the translation). My Friend Pinto also has many moods, too many really. Its cute, sort of, as well as crudely slapstick and sweetly picaresque, and just a bit misty and crispy.

title: From Britain, Its Legoland
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla.  The Merlin Entertainments Group is one of the worlds largest operators of amusement parks and tourist attractions, entertaining more than 40 million visitors annually. But the company operates almost entirely overseas, and it has no presence in central Florida, the sweaty epicenter of the theme park universe.

title: A Performance From Soup to Nuttiness
description: Had you been at Roulette, the theater in downtown Brooklyn, on Friday night, you would have learned  or been reminded of  a few things. Performing artists are unparalleled and exciting problem solvers, for example. The creative process, on the other hand, is often quite boring. And: the saints are the sinners who keep trying.

title: Though Others Failed, New East River Ferries Are a Hit
description: After several failed attempts at encouraging the use of boats to commute across the East River, city officials have an unforeseen problem: too many ferry riders.

title: Jokes and Their Relation to Crisis
description: In June, the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney found himself under attack for a joke he tried to make at a meeting with a group of unemployed people in Tampa, Fla. I am also unemployed, Romney announced, insinuating that the job he lacked was the presidency.

title: NBC Anchor Broadens His Portfolio
description: There is something disconcerting about seeing Brian Williams sitting in front of the television.

title: Ratification of Ford Pact by U.A.W. Seems Likely
description: DETROIT  After facing strong opposition early on, a proposed contract at Ford with the United Automobile Workers union appeared nearly certain to be ratified after receiving a wave of support over the weekend.

title: Life in Smoke and Mirrors
description: If there is a single theme running throughout Julian Barness work, from his 1985 masterpiece, Flauberts Parrot, to A History of the World in 10  Chapters (1989), Love, Etc., and recent collections like Pulse (2011), its the elusiveness of truth, the subjectivity of memory, the relativity of all knowledge. While earlier books examined our limited ability to comprehend other people and other eras, his latest novel, The Sense of an Ending  which was shortlisted for this years Man Booker Prize (the winner will be announced Tuesday)  looks at the ways in which people distort or tailor the past in an effort to mythologize their own lives.

title: Film Society Director to Step Down
description: Richard Pea, programming director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and chairman of the New York Film Festivals selection committee, announced on Sunday, the festivals closing night, that he will be stepping down from both posts by the end of 2012.

title: Relearning Who You Are
description: To the Editor:

title: Scholarship You Could Dance To
description: Theres a grainy 1972 video online of  Eddie and Charlie Palmieri playing Vamonos Pal Monte at the old Central Park Bandshell. It is one of the most deeply New York things you will ever see, multi-ethnic and multi-generational and crazily rocking. As the onstage hand-held camera whirls around, you see the brothers Andy and Jerry Gonzalez, then in their early 20s, in the band, Andy on bass and Jerry on congas, each in his own rhythmic trance.

title: Bids to Buy Citigroups EMI Group Are Said to Fall Short of Expectations
description: When the Warner Music Group, the home of Neil Young and Green Day, was sold in May for $3.3 billion, music executives and media analysts were pleasantly surprised. The higher-than-expected price, after a frothy auction that drew as many as 20 suitors, seemed to indicate an enduring faith in music as an investment after a decade of bad news.

title: Saints Payton Coaching With Broken Leg
description: Jim Schwartz and Jim Harbaugh will get most of the headlines for their postgame altercation, but Sean Payton is making a case that he is the toughest coach in the N.F.L.

title: Spare in Vocals, but Robust in Melody
description: On the fast-changing choral scene in New York these days, you cant tell the players without a program.

title: Al Qaeda Tries a New Tactic in Somalia: Philanthropy
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Al Qaeda is not known for its philanthropic activities, but this weekend in Somalia the terrorist group appears to have branched into a new business: distributing humanitarian aid.

title: New Zealand to Meet France in Final of Rugby World Cup
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  Previous defeats to France in important Rugby World Cup matches mean New Zealand will be trying to stay grounded despite its impressive semifinal victory against Australia on Sunday.

title: Aggressive Bidding Pays Off at World Teams
description: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands  The 40th World Team Championships are under way here. There are 22 teams in each event: the Bermuda Bowl, the Venice Cup and the dOrsi Senior Bowl. They are playing a round robin of 16-board matches to qualify eight teams for the knockout stage, which begins on Sunday.

title: Video of Deadly Race Car Crash
description: Dan Wheldon, a two-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, died Sunday afternoon after a 15-car wreck at a race in Las Vegas. The video above, posted on the North American Racing Leagues YouTube channel, begins with shots from the roof of Mr. Wheldons car and then pans out to show the enormous pile-up that tore race cars into piece and swallowed some of them in flames.

title: Republican Debates Are a Hot Ticket on TV
description: In September 2007, Fox News put Mitt Romney, Mike Huckabee, Ron Paul, Rudy Giuliani and a man who was, back then, a long shot for the Republican presidential nomination, John McCain, on a debate stage in New Hampshire. The face-off attracted 3.2 million viewers  the most of any debate so far that year.

title: Sue Mengers, Hollywood Agent, Dies at 79
description: LOS ANGELES  Sue Mengers, a powerful agent who represented stars like Barbra Streisand and Steve McQueen and helped shape Hollywoods vibrant revival in the 1970s before suddenly retiring to become an interested observer and party hostess to the changing film industry, died on Saturday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 79.

title: Battered, RIM Pins Hopes on Next Wave of Devices
description: OTTAWA  After months of misery underlined by the declining market share of its BlackBerry phone in North America, a profoundly unsuccessful move into tablet computers and, just last week, a prolonged failure of its service for millions of users worldwide, Research in Motion has a new opportunity to convince the world that it remains relevant.

title: Academic Fraud Online

title: Finding Archimedes in the Shadows
description: BALTIMORE  The Archimedes Palimpsest could well be the title of a Robert Ludlum thriller, though its plots esoteric arcana might also be useful for Dan Brown in his next variation on The Da Vinci Code. It features a third-century B.C. Greek mathematician (Archimedes) known for his playful brilliance; his lost writings, discovered more than a hundred years ago in an Istanbul convent; and various episodes involving plunder, pilferage and puzzling forgeries. The saga includes a monastery in the Judaean desert, a Jewish book dealer trying to flee Paris as the Nazis closed in, a French freedom fighter and an anonymous billionaire collector.

title: Juvenile Offenders
description: To the Editor:

title: A Question of Identity and Its Mark on the Body
description: Since the choreographer Rachid Ouramdane has created several pieces about the psychological effects of torture and genocide, its good  for the sake of our nervous systems and his  that his latest work, World Fair, shows him headed in a different direction. Or is it? Maybe some artists just have one subject matter and one genre to which theyre best suited? Whereas Mr. Ouramdanes Far ... and Ordinary Witnesses feature dance imagery and qualities that draw me into his disturbing vision, World Fair, which was performed on Friday and Saturday at New York Live Arts as part of the Crossing the Line festival, strikes me as objectionably cerebral and unappealing.

description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Dr. Feisel Krekshi, the new dean of Tripoli University, arrived for his first day of work accompanied by 25 young men who fought their way onto campus with Kalashnikovs and homemade grenades.

title: Hollywood Dishonors the Bard
description: ROLAND EMMERICHS film Anonymous, which opens next week, presents a compelling portrait of Edward de Vere as the true author of Shakespeares plays. Thats according to the lesson plans that Sony Pictures has been distributing to literature and history teachers in the hope of convincing students that Shakespeare was a fraud. A documentary by First Folio Pictures (of which Mr. Emmerich is president) will also be part of this campaign.

title: Bowl Championship Series Standings
description: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a teams B.C.S. score.

description: There is one berth still there for the taking in the Major League Soccer playoffs and there are four teams still with a chance of claiming it. Colorado and Houston locked down postseason berths over the weekend.

title: After Off-Season Rancor, Young Is Leading Rangers Again
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  In the silence after the Texas Rangers loss to the San Francisco Giants last year in the World Series, Michael Young addressed his anguished teammates. Young, the undisputed leader of the team, who then played third base, was already looking ahead, telling the players to retain their focus for a return trip the next year.

description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Sarah Benson last encountered college mathematics 20 years ago in an undergraduate algebra class. Her sole experience teaching math came in the second grade, when the first graders needed help with their minuses.

title: Routine Goal-Line Play Leads to a Sudden Death and Unsettling Questions
description: PHOENIX, N.Y.  It was just another routine goal-line play in a high school football game on a Friday night. With a playoff berth on the line, Homer High School was nursing a 7-6 lead on its home field with about six minutes to play in the third quarter against a conference rival, the Phoenix Firebirds of John C. Birdlebough High School. On third down from the Phoenix 6, Homer ran a dive up the middle and was stopped short.

title: Iran Reacts to Pressure From America
description: Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, promised on Sunday that Iran would deliver an unforgettable response to any improper actions from the United States over an alleged Iranian plot to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States.

description: SEATTLE  Amazon.com has taught readers that they do not need bookstores. Now it is encouraging writers to cast aside their publishers.

It might rail against the hypocrisy of elites who lecture others about tolerance. It would chastise politicians who stuff their pockets while refusing to listen to those who elected them.

description: New Yorks second-largest union of state workers, seeking to avoid thousands of layoffs that were set to begin this week, struck a last-minute deal with the Cuomo administration on Sunday on a revised package of wage and benefit concessions.

description: Herman Cain found out how tricky being in the national spotlight is on Sunday as he was pushed to admit that his signature economic plan, 9-9-9, would result in increased taxes for some people.

description: With less than two weeks left to apply in the competition for $400 million in land and subsidies to build a science and engineering graduate school in New York City, some of the worlds great universities continue to change plans and jockey for position, and there is a growing view among them that Cornell and Stanford have emerged as the favorites.

title: For $10, Hell Find the Guys Who Didnt Do It
description: He is one of New Yorks busiest casting directors, yet very few know of his work.

description: DETROIT  There was a time  last season, for instance  when a game between the Detroit Lions and the San Francisco 49ers would have meant so little that it would have elicited a shrug and a snooze. That was then, when the teams started the season a combined 1-9.

title: John Miller to Join CBS, Bolstering The Early Show
description: Every week or so comes another signal that CBS is reshaping The Early Show, its low-rated morning newscast. On Monday will come another: the announcement that John Miller is joining the network as a senior correspondent with a special emphasis on the morning show.

title: Vive LUnion
description: Soon after he arrived in Paris, in early October 1861, John Bigelow, the newly appointed American consul general to France, paid a visit to a quiet house on Rue Taitbout, about a mile north of the Louvre. The home belonged to the grandly named douard-Ren Lefbvre de Laboulaye, a small, soft-spoken professor of history at the Collge de France, one of the countrys elite institutions of higher learning. Laboulaye was an expert on American history, and Bigelow was there to ask him for a small favor: to change the way the French thought about Americas civil war.

title: Elizabeth Warrens Appeal
description: For a few years now, politicians straining against all of the antigovernment demagogy have been searching for a way to energize public interest and remind voters of the essential government services and protections they rely on and all too often take for granted.

title: A Sensible Path in California
description: Gov. Jerry Brown of California took a stand for immigrants rights and humane, sensible government when he signed several new bills into law. It is a welcome change from the intolerance and counterproductive policies being adopted in so many other states around the country.

title: Volcker Rule Divides Regulators
description: Regulators have faced a barrage of complaints from lawmakers and financial industry lobbyists in their 14-month-long quest to constrain risky trading on Wall Street, an effort known as the Volcker Rule. Now, as regulators begin a push to produce a final draft of the rule, they face hurdles from an unexpected group: themselves.

title: Cambridge Vote Ends With Supermarket Mogul on Top and Grocer in Last
description: CAMBRIDGE, England  Cambridge University has not had a candidate like Abdul Arain for its top post of chancellor in the more than 750 years the post has existed. Royal consorts, dukes, lords, military heroes, even a bishop beheaded by Henry VIII have all filled the largely ceremonial post, but never anybody quite like Mr. Arain, the proprietor of Al Amin grocery store on this citys busy Mill Road.

title: Dedication of the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial
description: A dedication ceremony, which ended with a speech by President Obama, took the audience back through 48 years of history, to 1963 and a defining moment for the civil rights movement, when Dr. King led the March on Washington and gave his I Have a Dream speech on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Unreasonable Strip-Searches
description: Do jails have the right to strip-search anyone in custody, even for a minor offense, if there is no reason to suspect the person is concealing a weapon, drugs or other contraband? The Supreme Court heard arguments on this question last week. If it allows jails to engage in this practice, it will weaken the Fourth Amendments protection against unreasonable searches.

title: John Liu and His Campaign Books
description: Comptroller John Liu is New York Citys top financial officer. He oversees the citys $66 billion budget and its $120 billion pension fund. That makes it all the more troubling when there are questions about numerous irregularities in his own fund-raising operations.

title: Big Cash Edge Powers Obama in Drive for 12
description: President Obama is exploiting his early lead in campaign fund-raising to bankroll a sprawling grass-roots organization and information technology apparatus in critical general election battlegrounds. He is doing so even as the Republican candidates conserve cash and jockey for position in what could become a drawn-out nominating battle.

description: Four rounds in a boxing ring could not undo 26 years in prison, but Dewey Bozella made the most of them, winning a unanimous decision Saturday at the Staples Center in Los Angeles in what he says will be his only professional fight.

title: Losing Their Immunity
description: As the Occupy Wall Street movement continues to grow, the response from the movements targets has gradually changed: contemptuous dismissal has been replaced by whining. The modern lords of finance look at the protesters and ask, Dont they understand what weve done for the U.S. economy?

title: Tensions Flare as G.I.s Take Fire Out of Pakistan
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE SHARANA, Afghanistan  American and Afghan soldiers near the border with Pakistan have faced a sharply increased volume of rocket fire from Pakistani territory in the past six months, putting them at greater risk even as worries over the disintegrating relationship between the United States and Pakistan constrain how they can strike back.

title: Pleas Unheeded as Students U.S. Jobs Soured
description: The college student from Moldova was in the United States on a cultural exchange program run for half a century by the federal government, a program designed to build international understanding by providing foreign students with a dream summer of fun in America. So he summoned his best English for the e-mail he sent to the State Department in June.

title: Another Tibetan Sets Fire to Self Over China Rule
description: BEIJING  A 19-year-old former monk in a Tibetan town in western China set himself on fire on Saturday in a desperate plea for Tibetan independence, according to reports on Sunday by Tibet advocacy groups. The flames were put out by police officers stationed on the street, and he was taken to a police station, the reports said.

title: Kodak Strikes Patent Licensing Deal With Imax
description: Eastman Kodak announced on Sunday that it had agreed to license some of its patents to the IMAX Corporation, helping to raise money while the company tries to turn its fortunes around.

In the first three innings of Game 6 of the National League Championship Series at Miller Park, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Milwaukee Brewers combined for six home runs (a major league postseason record) and 13 runs to chase both starting pitchers with remarkable haste, even for this series.

title: Two Top Executives Resign From Wal-Mart China

With a range of 290 km, these cruise missiles are being deployed to improve Indias military reach into the Tibet Autonomous Region and counter Chinas elaborate missile deployment along the Sino-Indian border, reports the Indian Express. At an estimated cost of 65,000 crore rupees ($13.2 billion), this is one of Indias biggest military expenditures.

title: Invincible Goldman Loses Stride, Briefly
description: The exceptionalism of Goldman Sachs has taken another knock. For a brief period last week, shares of the company, led by Lloyd C. Blankfein, traded at a bigger discount to book value  or assets minus liabilities  than those of its rival JPMorgan Chase. This rarely happens and suggests that investors fear that Goldman Sachs franchise as a trader of securities and adviser to corporations and governments may be somehow damaged.

title: Oct. 17, 1931 | Al Capone Guilty of Tax Evasion
description: On Oct. 17, 1931, the Chicago mobster Al Capone was convicted on five of 23 income tax evasion counts he faced, and which later yielded an 11-year prison sentence. During the trial, Mr. Capones efforts to avoid a strict sentence were thwarted by Judge James H. Wilkerson, who refused to offer a lenient sentence in exchange for a guilty plea. Wilkerson also swapped out the jury after Mr. Capone tried to bribe the people who were serving on it.

title: Air France Fires Its Chief Executive
description: PARIS  Barely four months after appointing him to a new four-year term, the board of Air France-KLM voted Monday to dismiss its group chief executive, Pierre-Henri Gourgeon, who had grown deeply unpopular with investors as he struggled to cope with high operating costs and increasing scrutiny of the carriers safety culture since a crash killed more than 200 people two years ago.

title: Wells Fargo Earnings Rise 21%, to $4.1 Billion
description: 5:18 p.m. | Updated with closing stock price.Wells Fargo, the nations largest consumer lender, reported Monday that its third-quarter earnings rose 21 percent, even as a drop in revenue indicated a disappointing sign for the San Francisco-based bank.

title: Raising Children Means Letting Them Go
description: My father has always said that raising children is a process of letting go. From the moment your children are born, your job is to prepare them to function in the world without you, and perhaps your biggest challenge is preparing yourself for that separation. I couldnt help hearing my fathers voice this weekend, while reading Emily Rapps moving piece in The Timess Sunday Review about having a son with Tay-Sachs, a rare and untreatable genetic disorder from which he will probably die before he turns 3. As Ms. Rapp writes, her story is closer to most of ours than we would like to imagine: on some level, we are all getting ready for the day when our children leave us or we leave them. Read her story, Notes From a Dragon Mom, and then come back here to share your thoughts.

Goldman Sachs employees, for example, have given $350,000 to Mr. Romney and $45,000 to Mr. Obama. They donated more than $1 million to Mr. Obama in 2008. Read more

title: Much Ado About a Handshake
description: Todays talk will, of course, be all about the handshake. When 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh grabbed Lions Coach Jim Schwartzs hand and gave him an overzealous jerk, prompting Schwartz to chase him down maniacally as they left the field Sunday, it became the perfect sports story for this era. Its easy to argue about, was captured fully on video that can be replayed endlessly and is entirely silly. It had no impact on how the game turned out, much less anything deeper or more meaningful. Which means it will be debated until the N.F.L. can provide you another distraction. (Tim Tebow is starting next week!)

Its most conservative counterpart has followed suit. An Islamist do-gooder with forearms as broad as the Nile has vowed to win a seat in Parliament.

title: Is the Good Enough Marriage Good for the Children?
description: The Atlantics current obsession with the alleged decline of men continues in the magazines November issue with a cover story by Kate Bolick that begins with a sad summing-up of her own relationship status (I am 39, with too many ex-boyfriends to count and, I am told, two grim-seeming options to face down: either stay single or settle for a good enough mate. At this point, certainly, falling in love and getting married may be less a matter of choice than a stroke of wild great luck.) and then meanders on into a long discussion of the future of marriage in man-challenged America.

title: Steven Pinkers History of Violence
description: My column yesterday took a modest jab at Steven Pinkers The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined, and I thought that I would follow up with a few more comments on his thesis. I should stipulate that I am broadly convinced by the argument that our current era of relative peace reflects a longer term trend away from violence, and broadly impressed by the evidence that Pinker marshals to support this view. (I found the books story more persuasive than did, say, John Gray, to pick out the most hostile review Ive seen to date.) But here are some criticisms and caveats.

The museum has entered into a licensing agreement with Fine Paints of Europe, a Vermont company that produces high-end commercial paints,to create a set of 200 interior and exterior wall colors drawn from well-known paintings in the Guggenheims collection and from wall colors that curators, artists and designers (including Frank Lloyd Wright himself) have used for exhibitions over several decades.

title: Ailment Can Steal Youth From the Young
description: Patrick Fox, now 14, considers himself lucky. It took only a year to find out why he was always tired, his heart raced and he ached all over, why he became overheated easily and had terrible headaches almost every day. Once a happy, active child and good student who enjoyed school, by age 12 he could hardly get out of bed.

title: The Caucus | Another Obama Bus Tour
description: Oct. 17, 2011  President Obama begins another campaign-style swing to sell his jobs bill. Also, John Harwood interviews White House Chief of Staff William M. Daley.

title: Frieze Frame | Oliver Larics Not So Original Footage
description: Oliver Laric is an artist who rarely has anything new to say. His work frames the creative potential of repetition, championing the idea of the copy as denser in meaning and, in this day and age, somehow more genuine, than any notion of a true original. A copy has simply lived more: it contains within it not just the image or idea at hand, but also the imprint of time, place or identity linked with that moment as well as the motive of duplication. Versions, Larics video treatise on this subject, features an animated slide show of contemporary copies (the infamously Photoshopped 2008 image of missile tests in Iran, in which the missiles were cloned for heightened visual impact; Internet memes like the Zidane head butt, remixed and disseminated by users around the world); and historical antecedents (recycled character animations from early Disney movies; figurative archetypes taken from classical sculpture) that trace its relevance back to far before copy and paste was a way of life. Laric updates the piece regularly, and now a handful of versions of Versions are circulating online with many of his other works, causing discrepancies and redundancies that surface as a digitally savvy form of authenticity.

title: A Brand That Takes a Stand
description: Two longtime advertising agency executives are finding out what life is like on the other side of Madison Avenue as they bring out a line of snacks with cause marketing at its core.

title: Limbaugh Defends Lords Resistance Army
description: Updated | 6:02 p.m. Apparently sensing an opportunity to tarnish President Obamas standing with listeners who were unaware of the suffering caused by the African rebels who call themselves the Lords Resistance Army, Rush Limbaugh responded to the presidents deployment of 100 military advisers to combat the group in central Africa on Friday in a segment of his radio show headlined, Obama Invades Uganda, Targets Christians.

title: He Made It on Wall St. and Used It to Help Start the Protests
description: Robert S. Halper, a retired Wall Street trader, spends time each day in Zuccotti Park talking to protesters about politics and their thoughts on reforming the banking system.

title: Potato and Pesto Gratin
description: Ive always loved the combination of pesto and warm potatoes. I usually just toss steamed potatoes with the sauce, but this time I sliced up some Yukon golds, tossed them with the pesto and made a gratin.

title: A Surfeit of Pesto
description: Summer is long gone, but my basil doesnt know that. When tomatoes are around I have no trouble staying on top of my crop, as rare is the tomato salad on my table that isnt showered with slivered basil leaves. Now Im making big batches of pured basil with olive oil to freeze and use later for pesto and pistou (the Provenal version of pesto, minus the pine nuts). I make the pine nut and garlic paste and blend it into the basil and olive oil along with the cheese when I need the pesto; the garlic will taste much better if its fresh. If you dont like the taste of raw garlic, you can always leave it out.

title: Amish Renegades Are Accused in Bizarre Attacks on Their Peers
description: BERGHOLZ, Ohio  Myron Miller and his wife, Arlene, had been asleep for an hour when their 15-year-old daughter woke them and said that people were knocking at the door.

title: In San Francisco, a Gathering of the E.V. Converted
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Electric car owners, advocates and even a few critics gathered Sunday in 26 cities across the country for the first National Plug In Day, sponsored by Plug In America, a nonprofit group that advocates an accelerated shift to plug-in vehicles.

title: Government of Jordan Is Dismissed by the King
description: AMMAN, Jordan  King Abdullah II of Jordan, under growing pressure to accelerate political reform and genuine anticorruption measures, fired his government on Monday, just eight months after doing so for similar reasons in the early days of the Arab Spring.

title: Where is Matt? Back Spanning the Globe
description: A signature of the Today show, Where in the World is Matt Lauer? is being revived after a three-year break.

title: No Combat Role for U.S. Advisers in Uganda, Official Says
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Most of the 100 military advisers being sent to Uganda to help hunt down the Lords Resistance Army, a brutal guerrilla group in central Africa, will stay in Uganda, which the group has not attacked in years, an American government official said Monday.

title: Bloomberg Says He Seeks Balance Between Right to Protest and Right to Be Silent
description: Updated 5:10 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, speaking on the day that Occupy Wall Street protesters marked their one-month anniversary in Zuccotti Park, said he was trying to strike a balance between protecting protesters right to free speech and the needs of Lower Manhattan residents.

title: Im Keeping My Coach, but You May Not Need One
description: A guy I know wanted to start a coaching service for runners. Hes pretty fast and had run some marathons and a 50-mile race. He also coached his wife, who had successfully run a marathon. He asked if I wanted to be a coach, too, or at least provide online training advice to clients.

title: Dutrow Given 30-Day Stay of 10-Year Suspension
description: Richard Dutrow Jr. is still in the horse racing business after a New York State Supreme Court judge on Monday granted a 30-day stay of the 10-year suspension handed down by state racing authorities.

title: U.S. Debated Cyberwarfare in Attack Plan on Libya
description: WASHINGTON  Just before the American-led strikes against Libya in March, the Obama administration intensely debated whether to open the mission with a new kind of warfare: a cyberoffensive to disrupt and even disable the Qaddafi governments air-defense system, which threatened allied warplanes.

title: Former N.H.L. Players Accept Announcers Apology
description: Three former N.H.L. enforcers said they have accepted Don Cherrys apology for calling them pukes, turncoats and hypocrites on a Hockey Night in Canada telecast Oct 6. Cherry, a cantankerous analyst, apologized during the show Saturday, and called Stu Grimson, Chris Nilan and Jim Thomson, my type of guys.

title: A Hostage-Taker Calls, and a French News Blog Begins Tweeting
description: Pierre Haski, a co-founder of the French news blog Rue 89, received the first call from the hostage-taker just before noon on Monday.

title: Germany Lowers Expectations for E.U. Summit
description: BRUSSELS  At the start of a crucial week for the euro, Germany sought Monday to play down expectations of a decisive breakthrough at a summit meeting of European Union leaders this weekend, indicating that an emerging five-point plan designed to end the euro zones sovereign debt crisis could take months to implement.

title: Jagr Wearing One More Guise in N.H.L. Return
description: PHILADELPHIA  Jaromir Jagr just keeps reinventing himself, over and over.

title: Hearing the Repertoire of a Very Fearsome Fish
