title: Ex-Chief Executive of Olympus Ties Ouster to His Claim of Fraud by the Company
description: TOKYO  The British executive who was publicly pilloried as a bad manager when the Japanese company Olympus fired him on Friday, struck back on Monday, saying he was forced out because he was about to expose potential financial fraud at the company.

title: Chimp to Man to History Books: The Path of AIDS
description: Our story begins sometime close to 1921, somewhere between the Sanaga River in Cameroon and the Congo River in the former Belgian Congo. It involves chimps and monkeys, hunters and butchers, free women and prostitutes, syringes and plasma-sellers, evil colonial lawmakers and decent colonial doctors with the best of intentions. And a virus that, against all odds, appears to have made it from one ape in the central African jungle to one Haitian bureaucrat leaving Zaire for home and then to a few dozen men in California gay bars before it was even noticed  about 60 years after its journey began.

title: Management Looks to Take Chinas Shanda Private
description: SHANGHAI  Shares of the Chinese gaming and Internet giant Shanda Interactive soared early Monday after the company announced a management-led buyout that would take the Nasdaq-listed company private.

title: Devils Become Digital Host for New Jersey Youth Hockey
description: NEWARK  If you want up-to-date statistics for the players on the New Jersey Devils, the teams official Web site is a wise place to click. If you want to find out how the Hackensack Comets, Edison Eagles, Livingston Lancers, Don Bosco Prep Ironman and all the other New Jersey high school ice hockey teams are faring, you can also go to Devils.nhl.com.

title: Childbirth: Limited Gains From Supplemental Calcium

But supplemental calcium does not prevent preterm birth or improve bone density in pregnant women, according to a new report, and may be helpful only in lowering the risk of hypertension.

When it came, in the form of a 15-car pileup that killed the two-time Indianapolis 500 champion Dan Wheldon, there seemed to be little shock, just sadness that the worst-case scenario had indeed occurred.

description: The deluge begins Tuesday when the 31st annual CMJ Music Marathon, which has grown into a five-day overload of musicians, begins with acts who are all hoping for some kind of attention: a record deal, a gig, a blog post, a tweet.

title: American Held in Egypt as Israeli Spy Could Be Freed
description: JERUSALEM  An American law student from Queens who also has Israeli citizenship and was arrested in Egypt in June, charged there with spying for Israel, is expected to be released in the coming days in exchange for scores of Egyptians held in Israel.

title: Cuomo Names McCall, a Former Rival, to Lead the SUNY Board
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, coming full circle a decade after his disastrous first bid to win the Democratic nomination for governor, on Monday appointed the man who bested him, former State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, to lead the board of trustees for the State University of New York.

title: AMC Sets Record With The Walking Dead
description: Hart Hanson, the creator of Foxs Bones, may have said it best when the ratings for Sundays second season premiere of AMCs The Walking Dead were released on Monday afternoon. Wow, he wrote on Twitter. Them zombies are coming for all of us on network TV.

title: Makeup. Dont Leave Home Without It.
description: BUSINESS travel isnt new to me. When I was in my 20s, I would leave on a Sunday night and not come home until Friday. Now, two decades later, Im flying all over the place once more.

title: Captain Scotts Lost Photographs
description: Newly released photographs taken by Robert Falcon Scott during his expedition to the South Pole from 1910-1913 have recently been released.

title: I.B.M. Beats Forecasts and Raises Profit Estimate for Year
description: I.B.M. reported solid quarterly profits on Monday, showing that despite the shaky economy, corporations continued to spend on information technology. But the companys stock dropped as sales fell short of expectations.

title: Antarctic Odyssey, Through the Eyes of a Polar Pioneer
description: David M. Wilson, a polar historian, was having drinks in a London art salesroom several years ago when an unknown collector approached him. He said, Youll never guess what I have in my collection, Mr. Wilson recalled.

title: Putin Defends Decision to Seek Presidency
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin confronted criticism over his decision to seek a return to the presidency next year, warning in a television interview shown on Monday of a return to the volatility of previous decades should Russia swerve from its current course.

title: A Company With Balanchine in Its Pedigree
description: WASHINGTON  WASHINGTON  Last weekend, while the Suzanne Farrell Ballet was performing at the Kennedy Center Eisenhower Theater here, I sometimes couldnt help wishing that the company were on a larger stage. This week, when it comes to the Joyce Theater in New York, it will be on a stage considerably smaller. Fortunately, the repertory will be almost entirely different.

title: Australia: Mans Serious Illness Shows the Danger of Daring to Eat a Garden-Variety Slug
description: An Australian man has been hospitalized for more than a month in serious condition as a result of eating two garden slugs on a dare, according to Australian news media and ProMED , an online service that tracks disease outbreaks.

title: Australians Assess Their Greenhouse Plan
description: In the wake of Australias move to add a price to carbon dioxide emissions  which is particularly notable considering the country is one of the worlds big exporters of coal (and related CO2 emissions)  I sent a query to some Australian analysts of climate and energy policy to see if this holds lessons for the United States.

title: The Caucus Click: Carolina Cue
Turncoat of Placenta Is Watched for Trouble
description: In mother-and-child paintings and Henry Moore sculptures, mothers and babies meld together with such ease they appear as one. But in the course of some pregnancies, the embryos struggle for nutrients can escalate into all-out war with the mother, a dangerous condition called pre-eclampsia.

title: Sandra Lee Opens Up on Life With Cuomo and Offers Career Advice
description: In a rare appearance at an event that was not about food, New Yorks de facto first lady, Sandra Lee, on Monday offered a glimpse into the household she shares with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and gave young women some blunt career advice.

title: Peering Beyond a Monologists Stage Presence Into His Uncensored Mind
description: Skiing is better than sex, Spalding Gray once said, because for me a good round of sex might be seven minutes. Skiing you can do for seven hours.

title: Two Cancer Studies Find Bacterial Clue in Colon
description: For years, Dr. Robert A. Holt, a genomics researcher at the British Columbia Cancer Agency, wrestled with a question about colon cancer. Might it be caused, or pushed along, by a bacterial infection?

title: Coaches Throw No Punches and Earn No Penalties
description: The pigskin pugilists were barely off the field before the real question about Jim Harbaugh and Jim Schwartz was asked: What will the N.F.L. do with two of its brightest young coaches who behaved as if they were even younger  perhaps still on the junior high school playground?

title: Not Such a Stretch to Reach for the Stars
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  A starship without an engine?

title: From Telomeres to the Origins of Life
description: BOSTON  The October night before he learned he had won the 2009 Nobel Prize in medicine, the biochemical researcher Jack W. Szostak says he slept like a log.

title: Edgar M. Villchur, a Hi-Fi Innovator, Is Dead at 94
description: Edgar M. Villchur, whose invention of a small loudspeaker that could produce deep, rich bass tones opened the high-fidelity music market in the 1950s to millions of everyday listeners, died on Monday at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 94.

title: The Underappreciated Hunks of Occupy Wall Street
description: No one ever said the revolution would be sexy. In fact, media coverage of Occupy Wall Street suggested quite the opposite, tending to emphasize the unkempt woolliness and generally unsanitary nature of the movement.

title: Paul Plan Would Eliminate Cabinet Departments to Cut $1 Trillion
description: 9:29 p.m. | Updated LAS VEGAS  Representative Ron Paul on Monday unveiled an aggressive budget plan that would greatly shrink the federal government that he is seeking to run, eliminating the agency that oversees airport security, the Departments of Energy and Education and three others, while cutting all war financing.

title: Legends Of The Rentiers
description: I feel Dean Bakers pain. Dean is exercised over an NPR report which says that Argentina is suffering from its 2001 default  a claim that is totally at odds with the evidence. Argentina actually did very well by thumbing its nose at creditors.

title: Drawing Dance: A Cunningham Dancer At Rest
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 16th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from London.

title: Fiddling With a Two-Year Gap in the Busy Life of Copernicus
description: Dava Sobel has long taken a quirky approach to science history. In Galileos Daughter (1999), for instance, she focused not on the standard biographical material but on the scientists love for his illegitimate daughter, consigned to a convent at 13 and dead of dysentery at 33.

title: Ending Speculation, Michael Wolff Leaves Post at Adweek
description: MICHAEL WOLFF, a combative and contrarian figure of Manhattan media for the last generation, has left his job as the editorial director of Adweek, ending weeks of speculation over his job security there.

title: Clues About Early Diets Found in Fossilized Teeth
description: By studying the pits and scratches on fossilized teeth and analyzing the carbon isotopes on enamel, researchers have discovered new information about the diets of early hominids.

title: A Good Week for Priscilla at the Box Office
description: The Broadway musical Priscilla Queen of the Desert, which opened to mixed reviews in March and had one of the rockiest summers at the box office for new productions, had its highest-earning set of performances last week since late May, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group for theater owners and producers. Priscilla earned $860,673, about 59 percent of the maximum possible gross last week; the show earned $920,741 during the playing week that included Memorial Day weekend, while it reached a low point of $547,180 in early September.

title: Your Photo, Justified
description: Boy band heartthrob. Breakout solo artist. Crossover movie star. Surprisingly deft comedian. And now . . . Justin Timberlake  photography guru?

title: On Teamwork, at Least, Chimps and Children Vary
description: Cooperation, that fine art of working together toward a common goal, is more appealing to children than to chimpanzees, a new study reports.

title: Raising an Album, From Pigpen to Studio
description: Followers of Matthew Herbert, a British electronic musician obsessed with the possibilities of using found sounds, knew he would eventually do something like One Pig.

title: Vector Autoregressions And Keynesian Macro
description: Some readers wanted to know about how the Sims/Sargent methodology plays into Keynesian or IS-LM-type models. Does it support them? Well, yes, but the case needs a bit of explaining.

description: To the Editor:

title: It Wasnt a Wreck, Not Really
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  John Lasseter dug into his shrimp parmigiana, thought for a moment or two and tried to describe the pressure of directing a big-budget sequel like Cars 2.

title: An Author Withdraws as Book Award Finalist
description: In case there were any doubt that the annual announcements of literary prizes can yield high drama, an author was asked to withdraw from the shortlist for the National Book Awards on Monday, five days after she was mistakenly named a finalist by the National Book Foundation.

title: On One Baroque Evening
description: The Juilliard School has assembled a respectable group of period-instrument players to teach in its historical-performance program, but it has also lined up a few starry guests to give master classes and direct concerts. Jordi Savall, who first visited the program when it began, two seasons ago, was on the podium on Saturday evening to lead Juilliard415, the programs student ensemble, in a performance of Baroque suites at the schools Peter Jay Sharp Theater.

title: Israel and Palestinians Prepare to Swap Prisoners
description: RAFAH CROSSING, Gaza Strip  The cactus-lined highway that leads to this international gateway between Gaza and Egypt was draped in green bunting and flags on Monday, as Hamas stamped its Islamist mark across the scene of a long-awaited Israeli-Palestinian prisoner exchange scheduled for Tuesday.

title: The Chemistry of Fresh Enthusiasms
description: Among the various motivations behind the festival SONiC: Sounds of a New Century, a nine-evening series of new-music concerts running throughout the city, one standout is the claim that all the included works are from composers 40 or younger. Eighth Blackbird, a polished, personable, routinely dazzling sextet, has never bound its repertory so rigidly; included in its swelling canon are staples by Schoenberg and Boulez.

title: After a Killing, Trying to Heal Through Theater
description: On the afternoon of April 4 students at the school of the Freedom Theater, an Arab-language troupe in the Jenin refugee camp on the West Bank, were doing a reading of Spring Awakening, which was supposed to be their graduation project, when they heard five shots fired just outside their building. Rushing outdoors, they discovered the founder of the theater, Juliano Mer Khamis, crumpled and bleeding so heavily that he died before doctors could treat him.

title: Fitzpatrick the Underdog?
description: William C. Rhoden discusses the contradiction of calling Ryan Fitzpatrick an underdog.

description: William C. Rhoden discusses the contradiction of calling the Bills Ryan Fitzpatrick an underdog.

title: A Bobby Short Tribute Is Exuberant and Reverent
description: What fragrance is kinda young, kinda now, kinda free, kinda wow? For those old enough to remember, that pitch from a 1970s TV commercial featuring Shelley Hack may unlock memories of a happy-go-lucky Bobby Short, who composed the jingle singing the praises of Charlie, the Revlon perfume for sophisticated on-the-go gals.

title: Lumire | Wanna Know a Secret?
description: Despite the economic crisis gripping Europe, there is one industry in France that is still going strong: the discovery, telling and selling of secrets. I confess to being a sucker for books about secrets, of which I have dozens, organized in three subject areas.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Any old pond will do. Michael L. May set out one recent Wednesday morning from his cramped office at the Rutgers University entomology building to collect a few dragonflies.

description: The University of Missouri is heading down a path to join the Southeastern Conference, said a university official with direct knowledge of the situation.

title: Escorting a Wife Out Before Plotting Begins
description: Any Given Monday, a biting comedy at the 59E59 Theaters about the consequences of infidelity, opens with Lenny, a middle-aged public school teacher in Philadelphia, hunkered down in his den, the remains of a pizza by the couch and the end of To Kill a Mockingbird playing in the background. Its been four days since he helped Risa, his wife of 24 years, move out after she told him she was leaving him for another man. Carried her bag, even.

description: FRANKFURT  A major development bank sharply reduced its growth forecast for Eastern Europe on Tuesday and warned of risks to the regions banks, another example of how the sovereign debt crisis is radiating outside the euro zone.

description: The memorial for Steve Jobs on the Stanford University campus Sunday night featured an intimate series of tributes from friends, colleagues and family.

description: To the Editor:

title: In an Earlier Time of Boom and Bust, Rentals Also Gained Favor
description: During the boom years in Manhattan real estate, credit was easy, speculators developed building after building to meet rising demand for apartments, and values kept climbing, fed by a flurry of resales. But then Wall Street plummeted and the housing market followed suit, as values deflated and apartment sales came to a standstill.

title: Olympus Chief Goes, but Push for Reform Goes On
description: Olympuss embarrassing decision to dump its British chief executive two weeks after naming him to the job shows that reform in Japan is a slow and fitful process. The executive, Michael C. Woodford, was brought in to clean house at the company, and became one of Japans handful of foreign corporate bosses. That the board decided to fire him so soon shows the medicine was distasteful. It also strengthens the case for a bigger dose.

title: McCourts Complete Divorce, With Frank Taking Dodgers
description: Frank and Jamie McCourt said Monday that they had settled their divorce case, resolving one major cloud hovering over the Dodgers, the team they jointly owned.

title: Big Hole in White House Lawn Prompts Equally Big Questions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who has been traveling the country urging Congress to pass his jobs bill so Americans can be put to work on infrastructure projects, need only look out a window in the West Wing to see one such project. Under way on his front lawn for the last 17 months, it is highly visible and yet mysterious.

title: TimesCast | Kenya's Military In Somalia
description: October 17, 2011  Kenyas military crosses into Somalia, waging a war against Shabab Islamic militants.

title: The Cardinals See Greater Things Ahead for a Series M.V.P.
description: MILWAUKEE  In the St. Louis Cardinals Champagne-soaked clubhouse, the announcement that third baseman David Freese had won the Most Valuable Player award of the National League Championship Series set off a chant of M.V.P.! from his celebrating teammates. Freese stood on the makeshift TBS platform holding the trophy with a mix of pride and embarrassment. As someone who grew up in the St. Louis suburb of Wildwood, Mo., he could hardly be more grateful.

title: Derek Fisher, Champion Point Guard and Face of the Players Union
description: When strikes and lockouts cripple sports leagues, the prominent voices leading the players are almost never active players themselves. That is not surprising. The lawyers who run sports unions on a daily basis have broader experience in labor issues and more expertise.

title: Speedy In-Flight Wi-Fi, Even During a Wild Ride
description: HENDERSON, Nev.

title: The Evangelical Rejection of Reason
description: Quincy, Mass.

title: Tracking Jets vs. Dolphins on Monday Night Football
description: So is this officially the Jets first must-win game of the season? Coach Rex Ryan thinks so, and not just because the Jets need to get back to .500 after losing three in a row on the road at Oakland, Baltimore and New England.

title: Back Home, Known for a Tragedy, Not Successes
description: LONDON  When the Englishman Dan Wheldon won his second Indianapolis 500 in May, taking the lead for the first time when another driver hit the wall in sight of the checkered flag, it barely rated a mention in Britains sports sections  and then, commonly, only in the fine print of the who won what summaries at the foot of the page.

title: The Great Restoration
description: If, in the 1960s, you had tried to judge America by looking at the sit-ins and Woodstock, you would have had a very distorted picture of where the country was heading. You wouldnt have been able to predict that Richard Nixon would win the youth vote in 1972, which he did. You wouldnt have been able to predict that Republicans would go on to win four out of the next five presidential elections, a streak only interrupted by Jimmy Carter, who ran as a conservative Democrat.

title: Bureaucracy in Greece Defies Efforts to Cut It
description: ATHENS  Stories of eye-popping waste and abuse of power among Greeces bureaucrats are legion, including officials who hire their wives, and managers who submit $38,000 bills for office curtains.

title: TimesCast | Greece's Big Week
description: October 17, 2011 - Greek public workers start new strikes as parliament is expected to take up new austerity measures, including new taxes.

title: Pairings: Filet of Beef With Swiss Chard
description: St.-Joseph wines, more vinous than fruity with an often chewy density, suggest beef, perhaps a nice hunk of tenderloin for two. This cut offers a good chance to try grass-fed meat. It is ordinarily tougher, but the filet is steak at its most tender. And while the filet is often bland, grass-fed meat can have a stronger flavor. Here, it is seared, then roasted, if you can call it that: the beef cooks so fast you might just walk it past a hot oven.

title: Finding Autumn in St.-Joseph
description: THE weather has been so bizarre this year that I almost hesitate to associate wine with the seasons. But autumn seems to have finally begun in earnest, so I feel compelled  and relieved, actually  to dip into the St.-Joseph.

title: We Can All Become Job Creators
description: Howard Schultz. God bless him.

title: Farmers Facing Loss of Subsidy May Get New One
description: It seems a rare act of civic sacrifice: in the name of deficit reduction, lawmakers from both parties are calling for the end of a longstanding agricultural subsidy that puts about $5 billion a year in the pockets of their farmer constituents. Even major farm groups are accepting the move, saying that with farmers poised to reap bumper profits, they must do their part.

title: For Bachmann, a Bid to Reconnect in Iowa
description: PERRY, Iowa  Hoping for a second look from Republicans who just two months ago considered her a front-runner, Representative Michele Bachmann is going back to basics  a lot of hand-shaking and shoulder-rubbing at small events in early-voting Iowa; sharpening her message on red-meat issues to stir conservative voters.

title: Justices Take Case on Lying About Honors From Military
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether Congress can make it a crime to lie about having earned a military decoration.

title: Q.&A.: Fixing Picasa Photos Fast
description: Q.

title: A Pipeline Merger Meets a Need, and Perhaps Resistance
description: Kinder Morgans planned $21.1 billion takeover of the El Paso Corporation is seen as a potential catalyst for consolidation in an unheralded but increasingly important part of the energy industry: the companies whose pipes carry the oil and gas.

title: Bloomberg Says Tent City Goes Beyond Free Speech
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, speaking Monday as Occupy Wall Street protesters celebrated the passage of a month encamped in Zuccotti Park, said he was trying to strike a balance between protecting protesters right to free speech and the needs of Lower Manhattan residents.

title: Massachusetts Tries to Rein In Its Health Costs
description: BOSTON  On the Republican campaign trail, the health care debate has focused on the mandatory coverage that Mitt Romney signed into law as governor in 2006. But back in Massachusetts the conversation has moved on, and lawmakers are now confronting the problem that Mr. Romney left unaddressed: the states spiraling health care costs.

title: Accounting Board Criticizes Deloittes Auditing System
description: In an unprecedented rebuke to a major accounting firm, the group that oversees the industry released a report criticizing Deloitte & Touche, saying that it lacked an adequate system of quality control in its audits.

title: Stop the Keystone XL
description: Robert Redford urges President Obama to oppose the Keystone XL pipeline, which would deliver crude oil from Canada through the American heartland to refineries on the Gulf Coast of Texas.

title: Is Religion Above the Law?
description: The religion clause case recently argued before the Supreme Court  Hosanna-Tabor v. EEOC  centers on the ministerial exception, the doctrine (elaborated over the last 40 years) that exempts religious associations from complying with neutral, generally applicable laws in some, but not all, circumstances.

title: Miller Buckfire Plans to Name Golub Its Chairman
description: One of stalwarts of the restructuring world, the boutique investment bank Miller Buckfire, plans to name Harvey Golub its chairman on Tuesday, bringing in a financial services veteran to help oversee a revamping of its operations.

title: Studies Clash on the Impact of Closing Indian Point
description: In a case of dueling studies, research commissioned by opponents of nuclear power indicates that electricity in New York State would remain reliable and reasonably priced if the Indian Point nuclear reactors were permanently shut down. The findings directly contradict those of experts hired by the Bloomberg administration.

title: Iowa Caucuses Set for Jan. 3
description: Change that pencil marking on the political calendar to ink pen: The Iowa caucuses will be held on Jan. 3.

title: Despite Protests, Cuomo Says He Will Not Extend a Tax Surcharge on Top Earners
description: ALBANY  Even as Occupy Wall Street stokes debate over income inequality, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo dug in his heels on Monday against extending a so-called millionaires tax on high-earning New Yorkers, saying the income tax surcharge would place New York at a competitive disadvantage with neighboring states.

title: Republicans and Foreign Policy
description: For a while, we were concerned that the candidates for the Republican presidential nomination were not saying much about national security and foreign affairs. Now that a few have started, maybe they were better off before.

title: Worries Circled Las Vegas Track Before a Pileup
description: LAS VEGAS  The recipe for disaster in auto racing is hardly a secret. Start with a problematic racing layout, mix in a field of expert drivers with rookies and rusty ones, put millions of dollars on the line and then add speed. Lots of speed.

title: Failed Attack on U.S. Base Rattles an Afghan Valley
description: ROKHA, Afghanistan  As the suicide bombers threaded their way past patchwork farms and snow-dusted mountains here in eastern Afghanistan, they had to stop for directions. It was 4 a.m. and, apparently in need of help finding their target, they pulled up to a police station and asked the overnight guards, Which way to the Americans?

title: Who Mailed the Anthrax Letters?
description: There was a strong sense of relief when the federal government concluded that a lone psychologically troubled government scientist mailed anthrax-laced letters in 2001, killing five people and terrorizing the nation. Now its evidence is looking increasingly shaky.

title: G.O.P. Freshmans Fiscal Message Clashes With His Finances
description: WASHINGTON  There is Representative Joe Walsh, a freshman from Illinois, deriding his colleagues once again for their poor stewardship of the economy. During the debt ceiling debate, Mr. Walsh took to the airwaves to call President Obama a liar for suggesting that the nation might default. Just the other day, Mr. Walsh held court at a Tea Party rally, complaining that Republican leaders in Congress had been there too long to understand how best to deal with the nations daunting fiscal issues.

title: Another Test of Marriage Equality
description: Senator Patrick Leahy, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, took a step toward true equality for all Americans last week by planning a vote next month on whether to repeal the law that bars the federal government from recognizing lawfully performed marriages between same-sex couples.

title: Eminent Domain Fight Has a Canadian Twist
description: A Canadian company has been threatening to confiscate private land from South Dakota to the Gulf of Mexico, and is already suing many who have refused to allow the Keystone XL pipelineon their property even though the controversial project has yet to receive federal approval.

title: Smaller Shelters and Persuasion Coax Homeless Off Bronx Streets
description: Not far from the Major Deegan Expressway in the South Bronx is an abandoned subway platform where someone placed a plastic chair, a flimsy mattress and a nightstand. Nearby, in an old construction site, a truck trailer is lined with enough discarded furniture that it looks like a makeshift bedroom.

title: Elouise Cobell, 65, Dies; Sued U.S. Over Indian Trust Funds
description: Elouise Cobell, a heroine to American Indians for leading a 15-year legal battle that ended with the federal governments agreeing to pay $3.4 billion in compensation for mismanagement of Indian trust funds since the late 1800s, died on Sunday in Great Falls, Mont. She was 65 and lived on the Blackfeet reservation near Browning, Mont.

title: Pro-Qaddafi Enclave in Desert Is Said to Fall After a Battle
description: Libyan forces fighting the vestiges of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis toppled government said Monday that anti-Qaddafi fighters were in complete control of Bani Walid, a loyalist desert enclave south of Tripoli, the capital, but had yet to proclaim total victory in his Mediterranean hometown of Surt.

title: Lawyer Defends Himself on Charges He Orchestrated Murder of a Witness
description: NEWARK  With his pinstripe suit and cobalt tie, the defense lawyer, Paul W. Bergrin, looked the part as he addressed the jury for the first time. The prosecutions witnesses are liars, he said, as defense lawyers do. They will say and they will do anything, he said.

title: City Aims for Teamwork to End Dig-Pave-Dig Cycle on Roads
description: For many New Yorkers, the process is all too familiar: A utility company arrives, lays waste to a roadway and paves it over  just in time for private contractors to turn up and gut the street anew.

title: The Missed Red Flags on Groupon
description: This summer, Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, flew to Chicago to personally pitch his firm to underwrite what was supposed to be the hottest initial public offering of the year: Groupon, the fledgling online coupon company that was being valued at around $30 billion.

title: Stroke Victim Is Flown From South Pole
description: Renee Nicole Doucuer, who was serving as winter manager at the Amundsen-Scott research station at the South Pole when she suffered a stroke on Aug. 27, was airlifted from the isolated base on Monday. Ms. Doucuer was resting in New Zealand on Monday. She is expected to undergo tests on Tuesday to determine the severity of her stroke, and the results will determine when she flies home to Seabrook, N.H. Ms. Doucuer, 58, had been trying to leave the South Pole since her stroke. But Raytheon, which operates the station under contract from the National Science Foundation, determined that any rescue during Antarcticas winter would unnecessarily put other lives at risk. Ms. Doucuer and her family pressured Raytheon and the National Science Foundation to have a plane on standby should the weather improve. The flight that ultimately retrieved Ms. Doucuer was the first scheduled one of the spring season. A C-17 cargo plane, which was not intended to carry passengers, made room for Ms. Doucuer and a doctor from the station.

title: An Investor Creates a Tempest in a Coffee Cup
description: When shares of Green Mountain Coffee Roasters began trading on Monday morning, they held the distinction of being the best-performing stock on a major exchange over the last five years.

title: Lottery Numbers
Uganda: Security Forces Clash With Protesters
description: Security forces fired rubber bullets and tear gas at stone-wielding protesters Kampala on Monday as an activist group tried to reignite street demonstrations against high commodity prices and corruption. Protest organizers were arrested in Kampala, the capital, and in the southern cities of Mbarara and Masaka. In Kampala, rioting broke out in the downtown Kiseka market, with traders throwing stones as columns of police officers and armored vehicles swept the area. A tear gas canister landed in a nearby secondary school where students were taking national exams. Opposition politicians and activists called for a resumption of the protests this week. During the initial protests last spring, at least nine people were killed and hundreds were arrested.

title: The Northeast Passage Opens Up
description: Map shows routes once impassable by the Arctic ice cap that have opened up into new shipping lanes.

title: Giants Enter Bye Week Liking Where They Are, and Where Theyre Going
description: The final five minutes of the Giants 27-24 win over the Buffalo Bills might end up being recalled for changing the tenor of their season.

title: Police Eyes Hovering Over Muslims
description: Hello to you, and to whoever might be spying on us tonight.

title: Officer Held in Civil Rights Case After Frisking
description: A New York City police officer was charged on Monday with violating the civil rights of a black man whom he falsely accused of resisting arrest.

title: Banks Start to Make More Loans
description: Despite all the bleak economic news, a funny thing has been happening in the financial industry over the last few months: the banks have quietly turned on the lending spigot.

title: Tuesday: Day Two of the Crossword Contest
description: Administrivial Tournament Reminder! Its not too late to sign up for the Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament, held this year on Friday, October 21 at Will Shortzs Westchester Table Tennis Club.New York Times crossword puzzles, mouth-watering desserts, and additional puzzles by our puzzle master make for an evening of fun that raises money for a great cause, the Pleasantville Fund For Learning.You can even pay at the door, so if you will be in the area, stop by and say hello. Ill be there to greet you, but Im just warning you: the brownies are mine. All mine.

title: Moral Issues Behind iPhone and Its Makers
description: I hate to tell you this, but your best friend has a dark secret in his past, the kind of shameful history that might just have you looking at him (or her?) a little sheepishly, with a furtive, sidelong glance instead of the former adoring gaze.

title: Warming Revives Dream of Sea Route in Russian Arctic
description: ARKHANGELSK, Russia  Rounding the northernmost tip of Russia in his oceangoing tugboat this summer, Capt. Vladimir V. Bozanov saw plenty of walruses, some pods of beluga whales and in the distance a few icebergs.

title: After 2 Days, Defense Rests in Bloomberg Consultants Trial
description: Lawyers for a political consultant accused of stealing money from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rested their case on Monday after two days of testimony, using their four witnesses to suggest that their client, John F. Haggerty Jr., had delivered the services that the mayor paid for.

title: A Front-Runner, but the Race Is Long
description: LAS VEGAS  He has consistently outperformed the rest of the Republican presidential field in debates. He has built a powerful fund-raising machine. He has rolled out one big-name endorsement after another. He has avoided being drawn into distracting sideshows or becoming rattled by his opponents.

title: Battle for Libya | October 17, 2011
description: With anti-Qaddafi fighters saying they were in control of Bani Walid, it appeared that only a small district of Surt remained as a stronghold for loyalists to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Dinner and Derangement
description: During thousands of elaborate restaurant meals over dozens of piggy years, Ive received many exacting, even loopy, instructions.

title: Plaintiff for the Past
description: Elouise Cobell was soft-spoken, but her politeness and sense of propriety took nothing away from her tenacity. Ms. Cobell, who died on Sunday at the age of 65, was a cattle rancher, a member of the Blackfeet Tribe and a determined advocate for nearly forgotten rights of American Indians.

title: Broadcast of an Animated Film Roils Tunisia Before Elections
description: TUNIS  In the final week of the first election campaign of the Arab Spring, political discourse here in Tunisia has been all but consumed by contention over the television broadcast of an animated film, Persepolis, which touched off accusations of heresy and censorship.

title: A Tea Party Panel Supports Health Care Laws Repeal
description: A Tea Party commission trying to crowd-source a plan to reduce the federal budget deficit says it found broad support for repealing the health care legislation passed last year and eliminating entire federal departments, but much less enthusiasm for changes to Medicare and Social Security.

title: Countless Grievances, One Thread: Were Angry
description: PHOENIX  Ken Alandts guitar, which he covered with bumper stickers and waved in the air at the Occupy Phoenix protest on Monday, is a symbol of the movement itself  a mlange of disparate causes, all of which prompt his blood to boil.

title: Salmon-Killing Virus Seen for First Time in the Wild on the Pacific Coast
description: A lethal and highly contagious marine virus has been detected for the first time in wild salmon in the Pacific Northwest, researchers in British Columbia said on Monday, stirring concern that it could spread there, as it has in Chile, Scotland and elsewhere.

title: Trump Joins Bachmann on Call With Supporters
description: He has had pizza in Times Square with Sarah Palin. He has dined at the swank Jean Georges restaurant on Central Park with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. And on Monday night, Donald Trump joined Representative Michele Bachmann on a telephone conference call, the latest evidence for his strange king-making role in the Republican nominating race.

title: N.B.A. and Union Meet With Mediator
description: A federal mediator met separately with officials from the N.B.A. and its players union in hopes of bringing an end to the leagues four-month long lockout. In the meetings, which lasted a few hours each, the mediator, George H. Cohen, heard arguments from both sides and asked questions of the representatives from the league and the union. He will meet the two sides together on Tuesday. Cohens suggestions are nonbinding, so he will have to use his powers of persuasion to get the league and the players to move closer to a deal.

title: Italy: Hundreds of Raids, but No Arrests
description: The police conducted hundreds of raids across the country on Monday against people Deputy Interior Minister Alfredo Mantovano described as far-left anarchists. The police were searching for suspects in the riot that caused millions of dollars of damage and injured 135 people in downtown Rome during a demonstration over the weekend. The police made no arrests, however, beyond the 12 people arrested Saturday.

title: France: Spy Agency Chief Faces Inquiry
description: Bernard Squarcini, head of the state counterespionage agency, faces further investigation on charges that he broke press freedom laws by obtaining records of a reporters calls in order to unmask a government mole, his lawyer said Monday. The lawyer said that the preliminary charges include violating secret correspondence and unlawfully collecting data. President Nicolas Sarkozy has denied asking the agency, the Central Directorate of Internal Intelligence, to investigate the source of information published in the newspaper Le Monde about political contributions made by the LOreal heiress Liliane Bettencourt.

title: Regents Set to Alter Rules for Grading State Exams
description: Teachers in New York State will soon be banned from grading their own students state standardized tests, a Board of Regents committee decided on Monday, part of an effort to curtail cheating on the high-stakes exams.

title: Live Discussion of This Beautiful Life
description: Thanks to all of you who participated in todays discussion. Again, we apologize for the technical hiccups that may have wiped out some comments. Next up, on Tuesday, November 29, well talk about Truman Capotes classic, Breakfast at Tiffanys, which I invite people to reread if its been a while.  GB

title: Occupy (Fill in the Blank)
description: Occupy protests around the U.S.

title: Still Strong, Economy in China Cools Slightly
description: BEIJING  Chinas economy pulled back a bit from its pell-mell pace in the third quarter, the government said Tuesday, as measures to rein in inflation and head off speculation put a brake on growth.

title: Questions Raised Over Perry Campaigns Reimbursements for Use of Private Plane
description: In the first two weeks of Rick Perrys presidential campaign, his aides turned to Brian D. Pardo, a Texas businessman under investigation by federal securities regulators, to use his Cessna Citation X business jet to fly to campaign events.

title: Corrections: October 18
description: NATIONAL

title: Against a Winless Team, a Win Is a Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Every locker-room barb or play-calling criticism that emerged from the Jets facility last week made one thing about their game Monday abundantly clear: they had more to lose than they stood to gain.

title: Brooklyn Artist Among Those Chosen for International Project
description: When the Brooklyn artist Kabir Carter goes to Istanbul next week he will be the first of 15 American artists chosen by the Bronx Museum of the Arts as part of a collaboration with the State Departments Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs to bring art projects to 15 foreign countries.

title: Revis Dominates Matchup and Spoils Dolphins Plan
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Darrelle Revis has developed a habit of tracking opposing receivers even when the Jets defense is not on the field, following them step for step along the sideline, as if stalking them from across the field.

title: Word of the Day | exuberance
description: exuberance \ig-z-b(-)rn(t)s\ noun

title: NYT Front Page for 10/18/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 10/18/2011

title: Videos of a Texas Dust Storm Blocking Out the Sky
description: A fearsome dust storm whipped through the Panhandle and South Plains of Texas on Monday with wind gusts up to 75 miles an hour in some places, according to the National Weather Service. The wind caused some power failures and knocked out windows, and The Associated Press reported that a small cargo plane was flipped over at the Preston Smith International Airport in Lubbock.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
description: A besieged Congress party suffered a resounding defeat in the by-elections whose results were announced on Monday (Indian Express). As many had predicted, the Congress candidate Jai Prakash came in third in the Hisar Lok Sabha election, but the partys loss was exacerbated by defeats in Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra and Bihar. While the Congress denied a downslide, maintaining that none of the seats were their strongholds, the BJP hailed the victory of its candidates as the peoples verdict against a corrupt Congress government (The Hindu).

title: A Relegation Fight No One Wants
description: A British soccer official stirred up a hornets nest Monday by charging that some of the foreign owners who have bought into Englands Premier League have been meeting behind the scenes to discuss a plan to end the practice of relegation and promotion.

title: Jets Replay: Week 6
description: Darrelle Reviss 100-yard interception return for a touchdown got the Jets offense going in a 24-6 win over the Miami Dolphins.

title: TimesCast | Racetrack Safety
description: An IndyCar driver's death raises questions over safety at a Las Vegas track.

title: Israeli Soldier Swapped for Hundreds of Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  In an elaborate prisoner exchange that could roil Middle East politics, an Israeli soldier held for more than five years by the militant Palestinian group Hamas was swapped on Tuesday for hundreds of Palestinians who have spent many years in Israeli jails, all them freed to jubilant welcomes tinged with bitterness and grief.

title: Madras Masala
description: This has not been an auspicious time for Muthuvel Karunanidhi, the octogenarian leader of Tamil Nadus Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam.

title: News Quiz | Oct. 18, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Oct. 18, 1968 | American Olympic Medal Winners Suspended for Black Power Salutes
description: On Oct. 18, 1968, the United States Olympic Committee suspended the medal-winning sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos from the American national team and barred them from the Olympic Village for their conduct during the playing of The Star-Spangled Banner at a medal ceremony at the Summer Olympics in Mexico City. Mr. Smith, who won the gold medal, and Mr. Carlos, who took bronze in the 200-meter event, wore black gloves on the podium. As the American national anthem played, the two raised their fists in a gesture of support for the black power movement.

title: As Danger Laps at Its Shores, Tuvalu Pleads for Action
description: Tuvalu, a tiny archipelago of nine South Pacific islands threatened by rising seas, is on the front lines of the planets climate change debate. Current projections indicate that it will become unlivable within 50 years, resulting in an exodus and the erasure of a rich 3,000-year-old culture.

title: As Water Rises, Theres No Place Like (or for) Home
description: Amelia Holowaty Krales had been anxious the morning she photographed a boy in pink shorts floating in a shallow pool of coastal water, eyes closed, toes pointed up. [Slide 1.] It was the king tide in Tuvalu, a small archipelago in the South Pacific that is threatened by rising sea levels.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 18, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, Park Cleanup Is Canceled, and Showdown Averted.

title: The Tax Reform Act of 1986: Should We Do It Again?
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book The Benefit and the Burden.

title: Gerhard Richter Show in London Spans Decades
description: The work of Gerhard Richter spans decades and many styles and techniques. So it seems appropriate that a new major exhibition on the German artist at the Tate Modern in London, running through Jan. 8, is titled Panorama. The show includes some of Mr. Richters greatest works, and coincides with his 80th birthday.

title: 36,000 Mini Cooper S Models Investigated for Fire Hazard
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether reports of engine fires constitute a problem requiring the recall of 36,000 Mini Cooper S models from the 2007 and 2008 model years. The Cooper S models are all powered by the brands 1.6-liter turbocharged engine.

title: Champions League Tuesday Preview: Bayerns Steel Curtain, and Mourinhos Return
description: Matchday 3 in the Champions League opens with eight games and some new questions: When will Bayern Munich give up a goal? When will Manchester City and Manchester United win a game in this round? When will Inter turn things around? And where did Thorsten Fink disappear to?

title: Correction Has Arrived for N.F.L. Passing Barrage
description: For weeks, we have been told that the N.F.L. has turned into a passing league. That the pinball-machine passing and scoring numbers were the new norm. That all the rules changes over the past three decades had left us with a game that looked more like the Arena Football League. Then Week 6 came.

title: The Early Word: Rolling
description: In Todays Times:

title: Islamists Prepare for Egypts Election
description: WHAT is the Muslim Brotherhood?

title: Do You Support Affirmative Action?
description: Abigail Fisher, a white woman, alleges that she was denied admission to the University of Texas because of her race. Her case has advanced and may be heard by the Supreme Court. How do you feel about the consideration of a persons race or ethnicity in college admissions or job applications? In the name of diversity, is it fair to give one person an advantage over another?

title: Q&A: Buying E-books Without Wi-Fi
description: Q.

title: Behind the Class Act, a Numbers Game
description: Let the post-mortem on the Class Act begin.

title: Even at the Laugh Factory, Losing Data Is No Laughing Matter
description: Jamie Masada will never forget the phone call last year that alerted him to the erasing of a chunk of his business and of his life. The call came from a manager at the online backup-storage company to which Mr. Masada had entrusted what might well have been the worlds most valuable collection of stand-up comedy video  1,500 hours of acclaimed comics performing on the stage of Mr. Masadas groundbreaking Hollywood comedy club, The Laugh Factory. Some of the video was historic, including Rodney Dangerfields earliest performances and stars like Dave Chapelle and Dane Cook honing their acts before hitting it big. And much of it existed only on the servers of the data storage company.

title: Industry Flouts Bluefin Catch Limits, Study Says
description: A new study commissioned by the Pew Environment Group suggests that the fishing industry makes a mockery of efforts to regulate the catch of the endangered bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean.

title: In Tripoli, Clinton Pledges U.S. Help to a Free Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged political and economic support for Libyas transitional government on Tuesday, even as a senior administration official warned that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his loyalists remained a lethal nuisance who could stall the countrys evolution.

title: One on One: Jeff Jarvis, Author of Public Parts
description: Jeff Jarviss latest book, Public Parts, aims to defend societys move to public displays of personal information in an age of the Internet, social media and blogging. In the book, Mr. Jarvis argues that people should embrace what he calls publicness, rather than fear the Internet and itspotentialerosion of privacy.The following is an edited interview with Mr. Jarvis.

title: Bank of America Notches $6.2 Billion Profit
description: Buoyed by one-time gains from accounting changes and the sale of assets, Bank of America reported a $6.23 billion profit for the third-quarter Tuesday, even as weakness on Wall Street hammered underlying results and the firm surrendered its position as the countrys largest bank by assets.

title: Goldman Sachs Reports $428 Million Loss
description: Goldman Sachs, weighed down by problems in its private equity portfolio and the broader global economic woes, reported a loss of $428 million, compared with a $1.7 billion profit a year ago.

title: Virginia Reveals Challenges Ahead for Obama
description: President Obama arrives in Virginia on his bus tour today, just as some Democratic candidates for the state legislature are running away from him.

title: Thieves Said to Steal Truck Carrying Presidential Equipment
description: Thieves stole a truck filled with more than $200,000 worth of sound equipment, podiums and presidential seals used by President Obama, a Virginia affiliate of NBC News reports.

title: Living Longer Than Predicted
description: In cancer parlance I am known as an outlier. What that means is cancer should have ended my life years ago.

title: Bright Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Bright Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: For Wealthy Indian Family, Palatial House Is Not a Home
description: MUMBAI, India  When Indias richest man completed his extravagant 27-story new house here last year, it incited a public debate along the lines of Whats he trying to prove?

title: Detroit Beats New York, in Baseball and in Terror Trials
description: Bad enough that Detroit had New Yorks number in the baseball playoffs. Now it has outclassed us in handling people accused of terrorism. Guess which situation should truly leave New Yorkers hanging their heads.

title: Did Bad Loans Continue at Bank of America After 2008?
description: Bank of America is out with earnings on Tuesday. It had net income of $6.2 billion, or 56 cents per share, but that is not the part I found most interesting in a quick review of the numbers. Instead it is the progress, or lack of same, in getting past all the bad mortgages it sold into securitizations.

title: Hopes of Big Deal in Europe, Then Denials
description: PARIS  The roller-coaster saga of Europes debt crisis continued Tuesday, as hopes that Germany and France were near agreement on abig infusion of bailout money sent American stocks up in late trading.

title: Updates on the Israeli-Palestinian Prisoner Swap
description: The prisoner swap between Israel and Hamas began on Tuesday with the exchange of an Israeli soldier, held captive for more than five years, for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as our colleagues Ethan Bronner and Stephen Farrell report. The Lede provided updates on the release of prisoners.

title: Lookout Introduces a Security App for iPhones
description: Most iPhone users blithely believe that their phones are safe from hackers. Unlike Android phones, which have been the target of a few malicious attacks, iPhones have so far been less vulnerable because Android is growing faster and because, unlike Apple, it does not screens all apps before allowing them in its app store.

title: Watching an Autistic Child Regress
description: Terrible pain too often accompanies mother love (and father love, for that matter). I could not let Megan Libermans post from Monday on Emily Rapps Notes From a Dragon Mom inch down the screen without flagging another  admittedly far less hopeless  reflection on maternal loss that I read some days ago in The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: Single-Family Skyscrapers Take Mumbai
description: Not far from Mukesh Ambanis 27-storey tower, Antilia, a competing skyscraper is making its way into Mumbais skyline.

title: Cornell Gains Partner in Graduate School Bid
description: Cornell University announced on Tuesday that it is joining forces with Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in its bid to build a science graduate school in New York City. Technion, a highly regarded university in Haifa that is heavily focused on computer science and electrical engineering, has been a crucial incubator for businesses in Israels high-tech boom.

title: Tuesday Reading: Do You Need a Coach?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Israel and Palestinians Begin Prisoner Exchange
description: The exchange of Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier held by Hamas, for the first batch of more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners in Israel began on Tuesday.

title: Lucy And The Eurozone Football
description: There has been a rhythm to the euro crisis: again and again, investors start to realize how bad things look, and spreads rise; then policy makers put together some sort of response, which produces a partial (but only partial) return of confidence, until it becomes clear just how inadequate that response was; then return to step one.

title: Homelessness Drops in New York City
description: Chronic homelessness declines in New York City because of a new transitional housing program.

title: Washington Hts. Board Resists Plan for 4 Towers
description: Local residents call the neighborhood the Heights because of its steep terrain and riverside bluffs, not because it has vertigo-inducing buildings.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Goldman Sachs Reports $428 Million Loss | Goldman Sachs, weighed down by problems in its private equity portfolio and the broader global economic woes, reported a loss of $428 million, only the second quarterly loss since the investment bank went public in 1999.

title: Surprise Anti-Austerians
description: It is indeed a mixed-up, muddled-up, shook-up world. Right now, the two most prominent institutions calling for an end to the disastrous turn to short-run austerity are  Goldman Sachs and the International Monetary Fund.

title: Views of the 99 Percent': Corporate Power Is Up While Living Standards are Down
description: Offshoots of the Occupy Wall Street movement have spread across the United States with organized protests coming to life in dozens of cities throughout the country. But are the demonstrations resonating with the general public?

title: Levels And Changes
description: Jared Bernstein is annoyed at an Investors Business Daily piece that totally misinforms readers about how to think about the effects of stimulus and austerity.

title: Steam Punks
description: It was perhaps only a matter of time before the D.I.Y. ethos touched the spa world, and it has done so with style in Portland, Ore., with Lyly, a handsome, minimalist sauna in the southeast quadrant of the city. The owner, Jessica Kelso, was inspired by traditional Scandinavian bathhouses lyly is Finnish for the steam produced when water is poured over sauna rocks  and wanted to bring their sense of accessibility to Stumptown. I felt like your choices in Oregon were a hippie hot springs experience or really spendy, overly attentive spa experiences, neither of which had ever appealed to me, she says. The Lyly vibe is one of communal shvitzing rather than solitary pampering. A $15 fee gets you access to an elegantly designed cedar sauna, wet steam room and lounge; though massages and facials are available by appointment, scrubs, salts, masks and foot soaks are do-it-yourself. The place has become as popular with corporate types as it is with the citys artists, musicians and restaurant servers. Everyone looks the same wrapped in a white towel, Kelso says, although we do see a lot of tattoos in Portland.

title: Our Blogs, Ourselves
description: Ryan Avent and I have been corresponding about the role of the economics blogosphere, for the Christmas issue of The Economist. I dont know what parts of our conversation will actually show up there, but having assembled my thoughts I might as well put some of them up here.

title: What Were Reading
description: Wine Review Online: Get to know assyrtiko, the great white wine of Santorini. Ed McCarthy takes us on tour.  Eric Asimov

title: Just What the Jets Ordered
description: Welcome to what can officially be described as the N.F.L.s season of dysfunction, the final requirement for that distinction being reached sometime in the Jets 24-6 victory over Miami on Monday night. One team looked barely motivated to get off its own bench, managed 5 whole passing yards in the first quarter, and expended far less energy on offense than its players did squawking at one another all week. And that was the team that won.

title: Ex-Inmate Shares Stories of Stint as a Death Row Chef
description: Last month, Texas prison officials decided to end the tradition of special meals for inmates facing execution after Lawrence Russell Brewer, 44, requested a large dinner before his Sept. 21 lethal injection. Mr. Brewer, a white supremacist gang member, had been convicted of chaining James Byrd, Jr., a 49-year-old black man, to a pickup truck and dragging him along a road until he died. As his final meal, Mr. Brewer had requested a pound of barbecue with half a loaf of white bread; three fajitas with fixings; a cheese omelet with ground beef, tomatoes, onions, bell peppers and jalapenos; two chicken fried steaks smothered in gravy with sliced onions; a triple meat bacon cheeseburger with fixings on the side; a large bowl of fried okra; a meat lovers pizza; a pint of vanilla ice cream; a slab of peanut butter fudge with crushed peanuts; and three root beers. He was given some of the items, in smaller portions, but ate nothing. After the states decision, Brian D. Price, 60, a former inmate who as jailhouse chef cooked last meals for 218 prisoners on death row in Huntsville, Tex., offered to prepare meals for the condemned for free. Texas said thanks but no thanks. Mr. Price discusses:

title: Two Marathons in Two Months Is Too Much for Many
description: Seventy days after he finished second in the Olympic marathon at the Athens Games in 2004, Meb Keflezighi took second in the New York City Marathon in what was then a personal-best 2 hours 9 minutes 53 seconds.

title: Zombie Apocalypse? Atlanta Says Bring It On
description: ATLANTA  Welcome to the Zombie Capital of the World.

title: How Active Is Your Daily Commute?
description: For people who cant find time in their day for exercise, the solution may be rethinking how they commute to work. The latest Global Athlete column explores the benefits of active commuting by walking or riding a bike to the office.

title: My CMJ Review: First Nights Assignments
description: During the CMJ Music Marathon, The Times invites readers to review shows on Twitter by tweeting with the hashtag #mycmjreview. ArtsBeat will publish some of the best reader reviews. Here, Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The Times, assigns the gigs indie music fans should review on Tuesday night.

title: Bank Shares Lift Wall Street in a Turnaround
description: Financial stocks propelled Wall Street higher on Tuesday as more banks and companies in other industries reported quarterly results, providing investors with fresh insight into the outlook for the global economy.

title: Mercedes Fires U.S. Chief and Cancels Dealer Meeting
description: Daimler, the parent of Mercedes-Benz, has dismissed Ernst Lieb, the president and chief executive of the luxury automakers American subsidiary.

title: Anita Caspary, Nun Who Led Breakaway From Church, Dies at 95
description: Anita Caspary, the onetime mother superior who led the largest single exodus of nuns from the Roman Catholic Church in American history, died on Oct 5 in Los Angeles. She was 95.

title: On Our Radar: A Listing, Leaking Ship
description: Rough weather forces workers to stop pumping oil from a damaged container ship that seems to be on the verge of cracking apart completely and sinking off the coast of New Zealand. The government calls it the largest maritime spill in the countrys history. [nzherald.co.nz]

title: A Year in the Work of Calder
description: Some of the best-known photographs of Alexander Calder, taken in 1941 by his friend Herbert Matter, show Calder in the high-windowed studio he fashioned next to a cow pasture in Roxbury, Conn., surrounded by such an explosion of sculpture and sheet-metal scraps that it looks as if a small airplane had just crashed into the site.

title: Where Do You Rank Among the 99 (or 1) Percent?
description: Updated 12:14 p.m. to switch $846.4 trillion to billion. This is an error of the Kiplinger tool, and weve informed them of the miscalculation. Kiplinger says the error has been fixed.

title: Despite Millions of Record Sales, UB40 Members Are Bankrupt
description: Four original members of UB40, the British reggae band that sold more than 70 million records, have been declared bankrupt by a judge in Britain, the BBC and Billboard reported. A judge in the Birmingham County court said government tax officers could seize the bands assets and property to pay off outstanding debts in a ruling against the saxophonist Brian Travers, the drummer Jimmy Brown, the trumpeter Terence Oswald and the percussionist Norman Hassan.

title: LinkedIn Wants to Make More Money From Job Recruiters
description: LinkedIn, the social network for businesspeople, is adding on to its biggest business: matching jobs to job seekers.

title: Pesto Portobellos
description: I used this combo for two dishes. First I made burgers with big portobellos that I tossed with olive oil and basil, then stuffed with pesto; then I stuffed smaller portobellos with pesto and roasted them. I liked both. You can make a meal out of either dish.

title: Before the World Series, a Refresher on Ticket Scams
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league.

title: Parents Urged Again to Limit TV for Youngest
description: Parents of infants and toddlers should limit the time their children spend in front of televisions, computers, self-described educational games and even grown-up shows playing in the background, the American Academy of Pediatrics warned on Tuesday. Video screen time provides no educational benefits for children under age 2 and leaves less room for activities that do, like interacting with other people and playing, the group said.

title: Spring Ahead | The Mini Bag
description: A snapshot of springs best trends and a hint at what youll want to wear next year.

title: Dropbox Confirms $250 Million Investment
description: Dropbox, the online storage company, confirmed on Tuesday that it had raised $250 million in its latest fund-raising round, an investment that values the company at $4 billion, according to people close to the company.

title: Lens: Child Prisons
description: Lens: Child Prisons

title: Much-Needed Win for Jets, but What Does It Mean?
description: The prevailing emotion in the Jets locker room late Monday night after they beat the hapless Miami Dolphins, 24-6, was that of relief. Never has being an average team with a 3-3 record felt so good.

title: Winter Vegetable Soupe au Pistou
description: This is a big, simple soup made with winter vegetables  all diced small and thrown into a big pot with water and simmered for an hour. Its garnished with the Provenal version of pesto, which does not contain any pine nuts. It makes a hearty meal.

title: A Boss Collection for a New Jersey University
description: A collection of documents, articles and books about Bruce Springsteens career that has been growing for years at the Asbury Park Public Library will be moved to nearby Monmouth University in West Long Branch, N.J., the university said.

title: Friends Still Let Friends Drive Drunk
description: On Sept. 15, Matthew Grape, 21, got into the passenger seat of a car with one of his Duke University fraternity brothers. The driver hit a tree, escaping with minor injuries, but killing his dear friend. According to local press reports, the driver was charged with impaired driving.

title: Publishing Perils in the Digital Age
description: These are uncertain times for many established writers, as the case of the Hawaiian novelist Kiana Davenport shows. Until recently she had a deal with Riverhead Books, a literary line that is a division of Penguin, for a Civil War novel, The Chinese Soldiers Daughter. Ms. Davenport received an initial $20,000 advance for the tale, which was scheduled for publication next summer. That wasnt enough money to survive on, so the writer cast about for another source of income, and self-published a book of old stories on Amazon. The result: Her novel has been canceled, the publisher wants its money back, and her publishing career is in jeopardy.

title: More On Climate and Energy Procrastination
description: Here are three reactions to my post about Machiavellis view of the impediments to making big changes in societies  as in the asymmetrical nature of the battle to take the carbon out of energy systems in the face of both societal inertia and intensive efforts by entrenched interests to maintain the status quo. The first two remarks came in a group e-mail exchange and so relate to each other.

title: Mysterious Site Creates a Horror Movie, Starring You
description: 4:10 p.m. | Updated   Adding some details on the origin of the site and interview with its creator.

title: A Deserved Award for Gavin Schmidt of Real Climate and NASA
description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated Gavin Schmidt, the climate modeler at NASA and Columbia University who has long endured the slings and arrows that come with blogging on climate, has now gained a laurel for his efforts  the inaugural $25,000 Climate Communications Prize of the American Geophysical Union. [The geophysical union release is now posted.]

title: Eichmann Drama Opening in Boston, With Broadway in Mind
description: The respected character actor Michael Cristofer will play Adolf Eichmann, locked in a battle of wills and wits with Mossad agents in 1960 Buenos Aires, in the new drama Captors at the Huntington Theater Company this fall, the company said on Tuesday. An outside team of commercial producers has already secured the rights to transfer the work to Broadway, which they hope to do during the 2011-12 season after the end of the Huntington run, a spokeswoman for the theater added.

title: How Essential Is Indian Point?
description: As I reported in Tuesdays paper, opponents of the Indian Point nuclear power plant assert that its two reactors can be retired in the next few years because alternatives exist that pose less risk and would not cost substantially more. New York Citys position, however, is that retiring the reactors would raise prices sharply and reduce reliability.

title: Mark McNairy Makes Us Smile (Again)
description: Gentleman of varying persuasions of style are already familiar with the name Mark McNairy. Shoes from the designers footwear collection,  Mark McNairy New Amsterdam, and tailored pieces from the Ivy League-inspired outfitter J. Press, where McNairy was formerly creative director, have made their way into an eclectic mix of closets, from traditional to trendy. When it was announced this summer that McNairy would introducea complete line of subversive-preppy clothes and accessories for men in the spring, all those fans cheered, and now  its official  hes doing womens wear, too. Inspired by his daughter, Daisy, the 50-piece collection is charmingly boyish, but (very McNairy) sexily so, with oxford shirts paired with boyfriend boxers and rugby tanks over miniskirts. Echoes of some of the mens line motifs  a daisy print, an exploded camouflage and a floral-on-plaid shirt  mix easily with more overtly feminine pieces, like the ditsy Laura Ashley-like button-down. Basically, I make womens clothes from a guys point of view, McNairysays. It has nothing to do with fashion  theyre items that transcend trend.

title: In a Battle of the E-Readers, Booksellers Spurn Superheroes
description: The tablet wars have begun. Superheroes are the prize  or perhaps the victim.

title: A Clip From The Swell Season
description: A scene from "The Swell Season," a documentary about the musicians Markta Irglov and Glen Hansard, opening Friday.

title: Romney Feeling New Hampshire Chill on Nevada Turf
description: When Mitt Romney takes the stage Tuesday evening in Las Vegas at yet another Republican debate, some people across the country in New Hampshire think he might be making a bad gamble.

title: A Spanish Class Says Mexican Pledge, and Some Respond No Me Gusta
description: First all the Peters were asked to call themselves Pedro, and the Johns, Juan.

title: Court Refuses to Indict Berlusconi in Tax Fraud Case
description: ROME  A court in Milan on Tuesday refused to indict Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in a tax fraud and embezzlement case that focused on the acquisition of TV rights by his familys media company, Mediaset.

title: Bringing the Undead to Life
description: The television series The Walking Dead films in and around Atlanta, which has become the Zombie Capital of the World.

title: Making Sense of Romance in the Office
description: TerraCycle started as a project in my dorm room, a bunch of friends getting together every once in a while over a beer and talking about our first product, plant food made out of worm waste. I guess I was officially the chief executive and given that my friends didnt get a salary  no one did back then  they were perhaps best described as interns.

title: HBO Explores Link Between N.H.L. Fighting and Depression
description: In the aftermath of the deaths this summer of three N.H.L. players, HBOs Real Sports produced a segment that does not shine a positive light on fighting in the game.

title: Cains Turn in the Hot Seat
description: Many of the Republican candidates for president have found that being in the spotlight during the televised debates can be uncomfortable and politically dangerous.

title: No Camping Signs Begin to Sprout
description: Just in case the Occupy Wall Streeters are getting any ideas about expanding their territory or scoping out alternative sleeping sites, some of the privately owned public spaces in the city are giving notice: Dont even think of camping here.

title: The World Series Cover Story
description: Programs for the World Series have changed over the years with the focus moving from owners to managers to players, and the price rising from a dime to $15.

title: Get Your World Series Programs Here!
description: They feature some of the nations most famous players, managers, owners, stadiums and even presidents. There are pictures of elephants, bears and tigers, as well as cartoons of babies and spacemen. Some graphics are Baroque, while others scream Art Deco.

title: In the Midnight Hour, a Second Wind
description: TO be fair, the party really started at noon. For a second year, Vice and Intel hosted the Creators Project, a two-day festival with art, design and music that included a D.J. set by the French duo Justice, at the Tobacco Warehouse in Dumbo, and a performance by the English pop group Florence + the Machine, to packed crowds under the Manhattan Bridge archway.

title: U.S. Moves to Cut Back Regulations on Hospitals
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration moved Tuesday to roll back numerous rules that apply to hospitals and other health care providers after concluding that the standards were obsolete or overly burdensome to the industry.

title: Vain Glorious | Oscars New Fragrance
description: What: Live in Love, Oscar de la Rentas first new fragrance in 10 years.

title: Second Suspect Charged in Sex-Attack Pattern
description: 11:18 p.m. | Updated A Queens man was charged on Tuesday in connection with at least one in a string of 20 sexual assaults in Brooklyn since March, the police said.

title: Critics Picks Video: Au Hasard Balthazar
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Robert Bressons 1966 drama Au Hasard Balthazar, which tells the story of a donkey in rural France and the girl who loves him. Mr. Scott points out that the film isnt a fairy tale about an animal with human qualities, but rather an unsettling and tragic examination of some of the deepest mysteries of existence. Balthazar is the name of the donkey who is adopted by a family and befriended by Marie (Anne Wiazemsky).

title: Sentence of the Weeks, Oregon Edition
description: A. What we know from the physics of morphogenetic fields is that each family is beholden to one governing energy field. (A flier on a college campus in Oregon)

title: Scene City: Music, Art and Booze Mix in Dumbo
description: Justice, Yeah Yeah Yeahs and others gather for two-day festival, hosted by Vice and Intel.

title: Deutsche Banks Lehman Claims
description: Does Deutsche Bank have buyers remorse, or a legitimate argument that it bought a Lehman Brothers claim that provided for treatment as a general unsecured claim and thus it should be treated as a general unsecured claim?

title: Debit Cards With Rewards Not Extinct (Yet)
description: Even though debit card reward programs are getting harder to find, most of the programs remaining havent changed much  at least, not yet.

title: The Reviewing Life
description: THE restaurant was Chinese in theory, with Continental accents, and wedged into a basement in Midtown. There was foie gras in the dumplings. The music was the sort one hears in elevators in cities far from home. One of my guests happened to be a dead ringer for the actor Matthew Broderick.

title: In Pennsylvania, Feeling the Tug of Home
description: DANVILLE, Pa.  The closer you get to the end of a long journey, the more powerful the tug of home becomes. As the finish line begins to seem inevitable, the whole trip starts to feel as though its in the past while its still going on.

title: Commodity Panel Moves to Rein In Speculative Trading
description: 7:31 p.m. | Updated

title: Wheelies: The Homage Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Scientists See Promise in Vaccine for Malaria
description: Preliminary results from the trial of a malaria vaccine show that it protected nearly half of the children who received it from bouts of serious malaria, scientists said Tuesday.

title: DealBook: Dropbox Confirms $250 Million Investment
description: Dropbox, the online storage company, confirmed on Tuesday that it had raised $250 million in its latest fund-raising round, an investment that values the company at $4 billion, according to people close to the company.

title: Getting Right to Work, New Sixers Owners Fire Stefanski
description: The old economic adage says its smart to buy in a down market.

title: Off the Shelf | The Navajo Blanket
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Onegin, a Tsarist Oupost in the Village
description: Plush velours upholstery, crystal chandeliers and a stand of birches in a 122-seat dining room will set the stage for Russian food at Onegin, which opens Friday in Greenwich Village.

title: Clear Channel Strikes Deal With LivingSocial
description: Daily deals are coming to the radio.

title: Channel Surfing: Clean House New York
description: On Monday night Clean House finally landed in New York, too late for the Collyer Brothers by about six decades.

title: The Quandary Posed by a New Down Syndrome Test
description: A new test was introduced Monday that can determine if a fetus has Down syndrome using a sample of the mothers blood. The test, and others like it, are expected to reach the market in the coming year and might eventually reduce the need for invasive tests that carry a slight risk of inducing miscarriages.

title: Its a Jungle Out There: Wildlife in the Pantanal
description: The Transpantaneira Highway, despite its grand name, is an unfinished dirt road running 90 or so miles from the Brazilian town of Pocon into the Pantanal, a vast wetlands many consider South Americas finest destination for animal viewing.

title: Lessons From the Financial Crisis
