description: BOSTON  What did the financial crisis teach central bankers?

title: Training Concerns Hover Over Delivery of Afghan Equipment
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Can a fledgling Afghan Army plagued by corruption, illiteracy and years of atrophy maintain a $500 million fleet of sophisticated armored vehicles provided by American taxpayers?

title: For the Keystone Battle, a Folk Hero
description: Randy Thompson, a laconic cattle buyer, may seem an unlikely symbol of activism. Yet his likeness is now on hundreds of T-shirts across Nebraska.

title: Documents: Mortgages and Gas Leases
description: Over the past year, bankers, credit union officials, insurers, real estate experts and appraisers have raised questions about the potential impacts that oil and gas leases have on residential and farm mortgages. The following is a collection of documents that relate to these issues, with key sections highlighted and annotated to explain their meaning.

title: Which Americans Are Most Generous, and to Whom
description: The richest Americans give a greater share of their income to charities than low- and middle-income Americans do, but the mix of beneficiaries is decidedly different, according to congressional testimony from Frank J. Sammartino, the assistant director for tax analysis from the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Should Character Be Taught? Students Weigh In
description: Last month we announced a new feature: the The Learning Network Reading Club, an opportunity for students to read, and discuss online, a relevant, provocative long-form Times article.

title: Offenses Point to High-Scoring World Series
description: ST. LOUIS  In the 1932 World Series, when the Yankees swept the Chicago Cubs, the teams combined to average 14 runs per game. All these years later, withstanding strong challenges from the designated hitter and the steroids era, those 14 runs per game remain a World Series record.

title: Spring Ahead | The Centerpiece Belt
description: A snapshot of springs best trends and a hint at what youll want to wear next year.

title: Jerry West Looks Deep Into the Mirror
description: LOS ANGELES  For Jerry West, silhouetted on the N.B.A. logo, cast in bronze at the Staples Center and enshrined in the Basketball Hall of Fame, his legacy was never the problem. His life was.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 18
description: The day in sports included surfing in Peniche, Portugal, a victory by CSKA Moscow in Champions League soccer and rowing at the Pan American Games.

title: Following Troops, Kenyan Officials Go to Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyan officials made a surprise visit to Somalia on Tuesday to reassure the weak Somali government that Kenya was not harboring intentions to occupy Somalia, despite sending hundreds of troops across the border over the weekend.

title: Iran Says Saudi Plot Defendant Belongs to Exile Group
description: Iran injected a new twist on Tuesday into the week-old American accusation of an Iranian plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to Washington, asserting that one of the defendants really belongs to an outlawed and exiled opposition group.

title: ABC and CBS Share Ratings Spoils
description: ABC and CBS settled for a split ratings victory on Monday night as Dancing With the Stars averaged 17.5 million total viewers over a two-hour period and led ABC to the highest total audience. CBS claimed the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, though Two and a Half Men continued to fall from its lofty early-season perch to 14.9 million total viewers, down another million viewers from last week. One more drop of that size and the show will be in the same Charlie Sheen territory as last year.

title: Pictures of the Day: Mideast and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Gaza, Israel, Yemen and Mexico.

title: The Sifton Reader
description: A selection of 10 reviews from Sam Siftons two-year tenure as The Timess restaurant critic.

title: Timescast | October 18, 2011
description: Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier captured by Hamas, was exchanged for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners. Ethan Bronner reports from Jerusalem and Stephen Farrell reports from Gaza.

title: Airlines Battle Back to Profit, a Fare and a Fee at a Time
description: The same things making many air travelers grumble these days  rising fares with more and more fees, fewer flights, planes filled to the brim  are the things giving airline executives a reason to smile.

title: Saving Shalit, Encouraging Terror
description: Washington

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Gaza, Israel, Yemen and Mexico.

title: Jacques Ppin: How to Chop Garlic
description: The chef demonstrates proper technique for chopping garlic.

title: Jacques Ppin: How to Sharpen Knives
description: The chef demonstrates how to sharpen knives at home.

title: Week 6 Film Review: Eagles Up, Grossman Down
description: A closer look at Sundays games, with the benefit of film analysis:

title: Excerpt: Interview With Jacques Ppin
description: A clip of the chef in conversation with Jeff Gordinier, a Dining reporter for The Times, at a recent event at the Times Center in New York.

title: Cheese Lovers Debate What Puts the Funk in Funky Town
description: Some newspaper articles are best consumed right away. Others have a tendency to ripen, gaining extra layers of funk and complexity as the days pass.

title: Londons Latest In Spot | The Arts Club
description: London may be brimming with private members clubs, but its latest  the newly revamped Arts Club in Mayfair  is creating quite a stir. Founded in 1863 by a group of friends (including Charles Dickens), the formerly fusty establishment has reopened with Gwyneth Paltrow (an investor) as its creative director. The stylish Art Deco-inspired interior designed by David DAlmada features marble floors, cashmere walls and art by Tomas Saraceno, John Baldessari and George Condo. Boldface names like Cameron Diaz, Mario Testino and Charlotte Dellal have been spotted supping in the restaurant, and Paltrow is known to belt out a few tunes at Club Nouveau, the nightclub downstairs thats run by Mark Ronson. Also on the mike at times are Ronnie Wood, Mica Paris and Noel Gallagher. It costs 1,000 to join, the same fee applies each year, and the first list closes on Oct. 31. Being famous and fabulous is not a requirement, but it doesnt hurt to be either, or both.

title: Adventures In Credibility
description: Menzie Chinn takes us through the Real American Jobs Act, which is every bit as ludicrous as one might imagine. What caught my eye, however, is who the GOP is leaning on for economic validation: namely the Heritage Foundation.

title: Sharp Criticism for Egyptian Interview With Soldier
description: CAIRO  An exclusive interview by Egyptian state television with Sgt. First Class Gilad Shalit of Israel  fresh from captivity, and before he had seen his family  provoked strong but polar opposite reactions on both sides of the Israel-Egypt border.

title: After Hiding, He Becomes a Celebrity
description: Symbol alert! Ali Smiths new novel opens with a perplexing prologue: a story within a story about a man on an exercise bike whose eyes and mouth are covered by what look like mailbox flaps. A small boy appears, jimmies the flaps off with a dinner knife and instructs the man in how to make a paper airplane. The man complies and discovers that outside, on its top, it looks like a plain folded piece of paper. Inside, underneath, it is packed tight into itself with surprising neatness like origami, like a small machine.

title: Live Blogging the CNN Debate in Las Vegas
description: Seven of the Republican candidates for president will gather again tonight for the eighth debate of the year and the first held in the West.

title: Old Havana, Souped Up and Sexy
description: Usually, when an M.C. asks, Do you want to dance?, the question is a prod. When the Cuban choreographer Roclan Gonzlez Chavez posed it at the end of his Kings of Salsa concert on Sunday afternoon, the answer had already been confirmed. It seemed that half the audience at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts had been onstage already, demonstrating how its done in the Bronx. Getting this crowd on its feet took no persuasion at all, which was fortunate for Mr. Chavez, since just sitting and watching his show was a frustrating experience.

title: Disgruntled Palmer Is Traded at Deadline
description: The N.F.L. trade deadline is normally a somnolent affair, just a few moves involving disgruntled and mostly forgotten players. But the Cincinnati Bengals and the Oakland Raiders rocked the league Tuesday with quarterback Carson Palmer, who had threatened to retire rather than play again for the Bengals, moving to the Raiders in exchange for a first-round draft pick and another pick that could become a first-rounder.

title: Intels Third-Quarter Earnings Outpace Wall Street Forecasts
description: Intels message to Wall Street on Tuesday: What slump?

title: Julian Barnes Wins the Man Booker Prize
description: The novelist Julian Barnes won the Man Booker Prize on Tuesday night for The Sense of an Ending, a slim and meditative story of mortality, frustration and regret.

title: Jacques Ppin: How to Make an Omelet
description: Jacques Ppin demonstrates how to cook a traditional French herb omelet.

title: Red Bulls Soler Looks Back and Peeks Ahead
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls, considered at the start of the season by many to be among the elite teams in Major League Soccer, are on the verge of being eliminated from the leagues postseason playoffs. A win Thursday against Philadelphia at Red Bull Arena would send the Red Bulls to the postseason as the 10th and final qualifier.

title: Drinking Kava on Fiji Time
description: Mark Hay, a biology professor at Georgia Tech, writes from Fiji, where he is investigating coral-seaweed competition in the coral reefs.

title: A Shopping List for Corporate Buyers
description: Gartner Inc., a research firm that advises top executives on information technology, sells peace of mind as much as insight. Buy this, says a Gartner endorsement, and youll be moving with the rest of our forward-looking clientele. That is a big deal; even though $3.6 trillion is spent on information technology a year, few executives want to feel as if they are moving too fast or too slow.

title: After Igniting Wall St. Protests, Magazine Proposes One Clear Demand
description: Three months ago, the Canadian magazine Adbusters called for a protest on Wall Street, providing the spark that began a wildfire of protest across the country and, over the weekend, in an increasing number of cities around the world.

title: Calibration And All That (Wonkish)
description: Brad DeLong sends us to Roman Frydman sending us to an interview of Tom Sargent that touches on the shift of freshwater schools to calibration  which basically means tweaking the parameters of your model until it fits some aspects of the data, rather than flat-out estimating the model.

title: Gadfly of the 60s, Getting His Due
description: Paul Goodman Changed My Life pays tribute to a man  poet, teacher, social critic, guru without portfolio  whose name was once a household word and whose books were talismans of intellectual seriousness and social concern. His current obscurity is something this documentary, directed by Jonathan Lee and including eloquent testimony from friends, family and admirers, is determined to overcome.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,794 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Attention, Shoppers: Thats Jacques Ppin in Aisle 3
description: Wait. Was that Kikkoman soy sauce on Jacques Ppins kitchen counter?

title: TPC Does Herman Cain
description: The Tax Policy Center has the distributional analysis of 9-9-9. Its awesome:

title: Spring Ahead | Electric Pastels
description: Right now fall is favoring cool-factor shocks of bright, neon colors. But the spring collections took a different approach, revisiting pretty with pastels that, thankfully, arent too jejune. Everyone from Ralph Lauren to LWren Scott and Diane Von Furstenberg chose to dress women  grown women  in tones of mint, lemony yellow and sorbet pink. Meanwhile, at Marni, Christopher Kane and Rochas classic silhouettes had a retro tinge with swirls of 60s-era daisies. Louis Vuitton delighted in remodeling things like boyish biker jackets in chickadee yellow and Easter egg blue. I wanted to add another dimension to the neons and thought that washing out some of those vivid colors would add an interesting contrast, says the designer Jill Stuart, whose Art Deco Miami dresses were coated in colors like macaroon pink and sea foam green.

title: Is Choice Less Accepted for Mothers?
description: The subset of women in America who most frequently make use of abortion services, writes Lauren Sandler in Slate this week, are  mothers. In 2008, according to the Guttmacher Institute, 61 percent of women who terminated their pregnancies already had at least one child. And in the period since the economic woes of the recession started hitting families, the National Abortion Federation reported to Ms. Sandler, fully 72 percent of clients who came seeking abortion services were mothers.

title: Carlo of Sesame Street, on Being an Illegal Immigrant in Real Life
description: Carlo Albn: nice American boy. Carlo Albn: illegal immigrant. When he was in high school, Mr. Albn was both, not to mention frequently stoned and a regular cast member of Sesame Street.

title: House Reopens Case Against Jackson in Blagojevich Case
description: The House Ethics Committee, after a two-year delay, has reopened its investigation into whether Representative Jesse Jackson Jr. conducted a public campaign in late 2008 to secure an appointment to President Obamas former Senate seat in Illinois, and perhaps broke House rules in the process.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Frise With Croutons and Spicy Olives
description: Adapted from Essential Ppin by Jacques Ppin (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2011)

title: Theres the Wrong Way and Jacques Ppins Way
description: MADISON, Conn.

title: Mary Meekers Internet Trends
description: Mary Meeker, the former securities analyst who joined the Kleiner Perkins venture capital firm, is still producing her influential annual Internet trends report.

title: Duke Foundation To Aid Artists
description: The Doris Duke Charitable Foundation will award $50 million over 10 years to more than 200 performing artists, dance companies, theaters and presenters, the foundation is to announce on Thursday. Rather than allotting funds for specific projects as foundations typically do, the Doris Duke Performing Artists Initiative will invest in artists future work with flexible multiyear cash awards of as much as $275,000, starting next year. The program will offer more support to artists through residencies. Artists cannot apply for the funds; they will be chosen through an anonymous peer-review process. But the residencies will be open to joint applications from both artists and organizations. The foundation hopes to encourage artists to take creative risks, explore new ideas and address needs like health care and retirement savings.

title: A Rare Rhapsody and Other Russian Pleasures
description: Sorting out the world of Russian orchestras can seem like a trip down the rabbit hole. The young, energetic ensemble that performed at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening was billed as the St. Petersburg Symphony Orchestra, a group directed by Alexander Titov but led here by Vladimir Lande, its principal guest conductor. But it is more properly the St. Petersburg State Academic Symphony Orchestra, a group founded in 1967 as the Orchestra of Ancient and Modern Music and known briefly (from 1985 until the end of the Soviet era) as the Leningrad State Orchestra.

title: My Three Favorite Collections of Private Papers
description: To check Debbie Nathans piece on the multiple-personality postergirl Sybil, a photo researcher and I headed to the special collections room at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, which houses transcripts of Sybils psychotherapy sessions. Going through the boxes of Sybils late biographer, Flora Rheta Schreiber, which also contain her personal letters and photographs, impressed me with the intimacy of such collections. Here are some striking private details from the archives of three great public figures.

title: Calder at Pace Gallery
description: A new exhibition explores the artists work in 1941, a seminal year in his career.

title: 36 Lawmakers Berate State Dept. on Pipeline
description: With a decision expected by the end of the year from the Obama administration on the proposed Keystone XL pipeline, members of Congress have sent two letters to Secretary of State Hillary Clinton raising concerns over the State Departments handling of a critical environmental review of the project.

title: Apples Profit Gains 54%, but iPhone Sales Fall Short of Expectations
description: For any other big company, a 54 percent increase in profit and a 39 percent jump in revenue would be enviable. For Apple though, weak sales of its star product  the iPhone  were enough to overshadow everything else when it reported fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, sending the companys shares tumbling nearly 7 percent in after-hours trading.

title: Chasing Opportunity in an Age of Upheaval
description: Nicolas Berggruen is passionate about investing. A compact, handsome billionaire, Mr. Berggruen is often talked about for his eccentricities  he does not own a home, preferring to jet around the world and live out of hotels  but his ability to find, invest in and turn around neglected companies points to a hardened and savvy approach.

title: Protests Are a Payday for Security Firms
description: They call when they make the Forbes 400 list. They call when annual hedge fund rankings appear, when their names are mentioned on CNBC and when their children travel abroad. And, these days, they call when protesters camped in Lower Manhattan grow uncomfortable with the idea of their existence.

title: Exotic Investments That Offer Gains, but Also Pose Risks
description: Stocks are scary these days and too risky for many investors. Cash instruments and government bonds have yields close to their lowest levels ever. That combination could heighten interest in the myriad funds that focus on exotic, none-of-the-above assets.

title: In Uncertain Times, Municipal Bonds Call for Caution
description: When the prominent banking analyst Meredith Whitney predicted late last year that hundreds of billions of dollars of municipal bond defaults would occur in 2011, it rattled the nearly $3 trillion market.

title: Take Advantage of Tax Breaks Now, Experts Say
description: In Washingtons war of words over economic and tax policy, Republicans and Democrats are aiming increasingly hostile barbs at each other that are leaving investors and business owners uncertain, even confused, about what tax and business strategies to pursue, according to financial advisers.

title: What to Ask a Prospective Wealth Manager
description: What do you do when your financial adviser becomes damaged goods?

title: The Specialized Art of the Appraisal
description: Whether it is fine wines, vintage movie posters or abstract paintings, some people spend a great deal of time and money compiling collections of valuables. Even if theyre collecting out of personal passion, rather than as an investment, it makes sense to keep tabs on how much the collection is worth.

title: For Charity, Bidding for Access to Stars  Even a Hug
description: Afew months ago, the restaurateur Jimmy John Liautaud had a private tour of the guitar collection of David Howell Evans (stage name the Edge) of U2. Then Mr. Liautaud and his wife, Leslie, sat down with the musician to chat about kids, family, being on the road, Mr. Liautaud recalled.

title: A World of Alternatives That Goes Beyond Stocks and Bonds
description: As the stock market continues to roil with no sign of abating, many investors have turned to alternative investments in hedging strategies.

title: Revealed: The Officer Behind the Skinny Tie
description: There are many unknowns about the Occupy Wall Street protest in downtown Manhattan: Where is the next march? Who are its leaders? What do they really want? When will it end? But an even bigger question, perhaps, has emerged: Who is the Hipster Cop?

title: Spin Recycle: What the Post-Debate Debate Might Be
description: If a presidential campaign is a test of a candidates ability to govern, the moments immediately after a presidential debate measure a campaigns ability to twist, manipulate, cajole and spin members of the press.

title: Vegetarian Recipes for Entertaining
description: Theres no need to rely on meat or dairy to make a meal feel like a celebration.

title: At the Protests, the Message Lacks a Melody
description: Every successful movement has a soundtrack, the songwriter Tom Morello told reporters after he had tried to fire up the crowd at the Occupy Wall Street Protest last week with a Woody Guthrie tune and one of his own labor songs.

title: Cooking in Parchment Without the Crimping
description: For cooking fish or vegetables en papillote, PaperChef, a Canadian company, has introduced parchment cooking bags that eliminate the bother of cutting and crimping parchment paper.

title: Sip a Little Wine Now, Buy a Bottle Later
description: Giving a new twist to the notion of try before you buy, TastingRoom offers more than 50 sets of six sampler bottles of wine. Once you try the wines, you can order full bottles of them.

title: Frieze Frame | Ken Okiishis Manhattan Transfer
description: The Frame section of the Frieze Art Fair, curated by Cecilia Alemani and Rodrigo Moura, made space for experimentation on the fairs fringes in the form of 25 solo artist presentations presented by a younger batch of international galleries. Among them was Alex Zachary, one of New Yorks most idiosyncratic galleries both in terms of space and location. (It has been operating out of a multilevel, formerly residential condominium a couple of blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.) Fittingly, the artist Ken Okiishis project at Zacharys Frame booth was a curious meditation on the psychogeography of Manhattan real estate and mythologies of uptown bohemia. Eulogizing the recently shuttered Lexington Avenue establishment Gino as a point of departure (which over time has hosted luminaries as diverse as Sophia Loren, I. M. Pei and Robin Byrd), Okiishi began by outfitting the booth in the iconic Scalamandr-designed zebra wallpaper that made its debut in the restaurants dining room circa 1930. He applied the same print to parasols bolted to the walls, whose slow and steady motorized twirling evoked bygone pageantry and ritziness. Faux-antique photographs of an early-20th-century apartment were hung beside the umbrellas; in actuality these were digital images lifted from the present-day Streeteasy.com listing for a unit on West 67th Street that was once home to Marcel Duchamp, from 1916 to 1918. East Side, West Side, Depression era, recession era: Okiishis project drew foggy connections between places and times that are factually disparate but psychically proximate. These artifacts repurposed as ready-mades contribute to a meandering mental map of the city that relies on legends like Duchamp (and Ginos) as its compass.

title: It Was Real, Cradle to Grave. Or Was It Just TV?
description: Mine was a short life but an eventful one. So bizarre and unpredictable was it that I sometimes wonder if it was a dream, a thing experienced yet not experienced, like a stadium rock concert that you mostly watch on the overhead screen because your seats are so far from the stage. To tell you the truth, Im kind of glad its over, since it was exhausting. Let me tell you about it.

title: In Dead Zone of Chernobyl, Animal Kingdom Thrives
description: In the months since the Japanese tsunami, weve heard a lot about Chernobyl as a worst-case example: heres how bad Fukushima could have been. Now PBSs Nature offers another vision: Chernobyl as a best-case demonstration that life abides despite the human races efforts to eradicate it. As long as the life in question isnt ours, that is.

title: Scandinavian Food Before It Was Fashionable
description: NOT to gloat, of course, but the resurgence of interest in Scandinavian food is something I have been anticipating for a long, long time. Currently the cuisine is termed Nordic, as championed by the celebrated Copenhagen chef Ren Redzepi, who will discuss his inventive cooking styleat the Union Square Greenmarket on Saturday. He and his disciples swear by ingredients that are local, seasonal and, preferably, wild. Nordic also has a nice exotic ring, summoning visions of Greenlanders and Laplanders fishing through ice, simmering up blubber confits and salt-curing chunks of Donner and Blitzen.

title: Get Away? Not by the Hairs on Their Chinny Chin Chins
description: Before you tune in A&Es newest show, think for a moment about the message youre sending to Marg Helgenberger, Emily VanCamp and Mariska Hargitay. Youre telling these lovely and presumably hard-working actresses, who all have shows in the same time slot, Id rather look at hogs than look at you.

title: A Priest and His Buddy on a Downstream Journey
description: The Catechism Cataclysm: did you repeat that twisty little title until you tripped over your tongue? Or, better yet, did you just challenge someone near you to say it three times in a row? The answer may be a good indicator of whether youll find this regressively oddball buddy picture infectiously playful or just plain irritating.

title: Battle For Libya | October 18, 2011
description: Fighting in Surt continued Tuesday, while Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged political and economic support for Libyas new transitional government in Tripoli.

title: Baby Beets: Cute, Sweet and Handy
description: Love Beets are baby beets cooked and seasoned with honey and ginger; balsamic vinegar and white wine; olive oil and chiles or plain mild vinegar. The flavorings give the naturally sweet roots nice personality (the plain vinegar flavor was less appealing). The beets are convenient for hors doeuvres, salads, side dishes or for slicing into sandwiches. They are sold refrigerated in a resealable package.

title: Buffett Returns to Cartoonland, Joined by Jay-Z
description: He may never reach the heights of Dora the Explorer or SpongeBob SquarePants, but Warren E. Buffett is back in 2D. And this time he gets some help from the rapper Jay-Z.

title: Gallup Poll Is First to Find Plurality Support for Marijuana Legalization
description: A Gallup poll released Monday finds that 50 percent of Americans support legalizing marijuana while 46 percent are opposed.

title: Mary Meeker on the State of the Net
description: Mary Meeker, a Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers partner, released her latest report on Internet Trends on Tuesday.

title: Californias Olive Oils Challenge Europes
description: AMERICAN food lovers have long taken for granted that only olive oils from the Mediterranean are worth buying  preferably with an olive tree, an Italian flag and some words like authentic cold pressed on the bottle.

title: Deficit Panel May Need Push, Lawmakers Say
description: WASHINGTON  With just five weeks until its deadline, a secretive Congressional committee seeking ways to cut the federal deficit is far from a consensus, and party leaders may need to step in if they want to ensure agreement, say people involved in the panels work.

title: Reviewing Prime & Beyond
description: Prime & Beyond serves great steaks, but it also offers a rare opportunity to taste what Korean barbecue is like when made with USDA prime meat. Bulgogi (thin-sliced steak) and kalbi (short ribs) have a rich, succulent depth that you dont often taste at the DIY BBQ joints on 32nd Street. And the burger, although plain  not a bulgogi burger marinated with garlic, sesame, and sugar  is fantastic, served Korean-style, with rice, kimchi, and a softly fried egg to bind all together.

title: As Economy Goes, So Go Takeovers, Even as Bargains Abound
description: The merger market is like a pack of lemmings. If the economy is good , the takeover market will follow, but when times are bad, the market stalls.

description: October 18, 2011 - In Gaza, hundreds of Palestinian prisoners arrived on buses and were greeted by celebrations after the prisoner swap that freed Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit.

description: To the Editor:

title: TimesCast | Gilad Shalit Freed
description: October 18, 2011 - Gilad Shalit, held for more than five years by Hamas, was traded for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails in an exchange that could shake up regional politics.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Meats Place

title: Hard Feelings Test Hope in Israel-Hamas Deal
description: JERUSALEM  Just off the bus in Gaza after six years in an Israeli prison, one of hundreds traded to Hamas for an Israeli soldier, Wafa al-Bass declared her next goal: abduct more Israeli soldiers. Others who returned said they could not feel satisfaction until the thousands of remaining Palestinian prisoners were freed.

title: European Bailout Plan May Not Satisfy Markets
description: Bailing out Europes banks may be less expensive than governments feared and investors hoped. European Union officials are discussing a plan that would require lenders to hit a demanding core Tier 1 capital ratio of 9 percent, but would not require them to factor in the effects of a deep recession. A lower-than-expected bill is good for the finances of euro zone governments, but may not be enough to win back the markets confidence.

title: Commander Who Pepper-Sprayed Protesters Faces Disciplinary Charge
description: A New York police commander who pepper-sprayed protesters during the opening days of the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations last month faces an internal disciplinary charge that could cost him 10 vacation days, the police said Tuesday.

title: In Defense of the Back-Room Deal
description: Washington

title: Olympus Defends Fees Paid to Advisers
description: Responding for the first time to accusations of fraud, the Olympus Corporation said that acquisition fees paid to unidentified advisers amounting to 30 billion yen ($391 million) were not excessive and followed appropriate accounting procedures.

title: Whats Your Favorite Vegetarian Dish for Entertaining?
description: This week, Melissa Clark offers a full vegetarian menu for a dinner party, with recipes for farro and fresh tomato soup, a harvest tart with pumpkin, roasted red peppers and olives, dandelion salad with garlic confit dressing, and other dishes. (A slide show with more vegetarian recipes for entertaining is here.)

title: At Protest Central, Sleep, if You Can
description: It was 4:30 a.m. when Nocturnalist awoke to a kneecap hitting our shin. Mired in sleep, we were disoriented  where were we? The necrotic chill of the slab of pavement we lay on suddenly registered and we snapped awake: It was Monday at Zuccotti Park, Occupy Wall Streets de facto headquarters. With hundreds of people flocking to the park, a half-acre plaza in the financial district where the protest movement has made its encampment for the past month, it seemed incumbent upon Nocturnalist to check out what has arguably become a hot new nightspot.

title: Caught Between Two Conferences
description: Two technology conferences, two blocks away from each other in San Francisco, were two worlds apart.

title: Does Sex Ed Undermine Parental Rights?
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: A Blessed Barbecue Feast and a Half-Century of Pilgrimages
description: On one holy night each year, the men of Oak Grove United Methodist Church stay up through the dawn while slow-smoking 275 hams beneath an open-air shed. At 5 a.m., as three tons of pork approaches slide-from-the-bone succulence, the stew-stirrers arrive to take their positions around six 40-gallon cauldrons, armed with long paddles.

title: Avoiding the Bank Snare
description: To the Editor:

title: Long-Term Care Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: True to Mailers Life, a Brawl Over the Sale of His Brooklyn Heights Apartment
description: Norman Mailers Brooklyn Heights apartment has seen its share of fighting.

title: Where Teenagers Find the Jury Isnt Rigged
description: On Friday, Fixes examined the Youth Court of the District of Columbia, a forum where first-time nonviolent teenage offenders are judged by others who have been in the same situation. The D.C. Youth Court is one of the largest of some 1,000 youth courts around the country. These courts are designed to help minor offenders avoid a criminal record and stay out of juvenile justice  traditionally an efficient production line for criminality.

title: Rhode Island: Judge Rules for Unions in Pension Suit
description: Labor unions won the first round of a potentially significant challenge to pension reform on Tuesday, with a Rhode Island state judge ruling that there is an implied contract between the state pension system and the employees who stand to benefit from it. In 2010, eight public employee unions sued the state, arguing that reducing pension benefits for workers with more than 10 years of service violated their contractual rights. The state had tried to have the suit dismissed. The ruling may complicate the states pension reform efforts, which will be the focus of a special legislative session next month.

title: As City Plants Trees, Some Say a Million Are Too Many
description: In a city of steel and concrete, a single tree offers a burst of green, a cooling canopy and an antidote for frayed nerves. It seems as if nobody is against one tree. But try planting a million of them.

title: Bystanders Neglect of Injured Toddler Sets Off Soul-Searching on Web Sites in China
description: BEIJING  Last Thursday, a van navigating the narrow streets of a hardware market in Foshan, in the southern province of Guangdong, struck and ran over a 2-year-old girl. The driver paused, then drove away. A surveillance camera showed that the toddler lay grievously injured for seven minutes, ignored by at least 18 passers-by, while a second vehicle ran over the child and drove on. A 57-year-old rag collector finally went to her aid.

title: A Night in Zuccotti Park
description: The Nocturnalist camps out with Occupy Wall Street protesters.

title: It Didnt Add Up
description: The Obama administration was wise to suspend a long-term care insurance program that was part of its health care reform package. The program, which was to be financed by the premiums paid by enrollees, seemed unlikely to remain financially solvent in coming decades.

title: New Malicious Program by Creators of Stuxnet Is Suspected
description: The designers of Stuxnet, the computer worm that was used to vandalize an Iranian nuclear site, may have struck again, security researchers say.

title: Clip: Tower Heist
description: A scene from the new comedy with Ben Stiller and Eddie Murphy, opening November 4.

title: Taking Big Risks to See a Chinese Dissident Under House Arrest
description: BEIJING  They have been pummeled with sticks or chased by rock-throwing security agents. Some have been beaten, robbed and dumped in remote farm fields without cellphones or money.

title: Gilad Shalits Release
description: We share the joy of Israelis over the release of Sgt. First Class Gilad Shalit, who was held by Hamas for five years. We will leave it to the Israeli people to debate whether the deal  which includes the release of more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners  will make their country safer or lead to more violence or more abductions of Israeli soldiers or other citizens.

title: Despite Victory, Concerns About Jets Remain
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On a conference call Tuesday, Rex Ryan uttered two of the more baffling statements of his tenure, one right after the other.

title: Release Date in U.S. Set for New Sony Mobile Game Console
description: Jack Tretton, the president and chief executive of Sony Computer Entertainment America, announced Tuesday that the companys PlayStation Vita mobile gaming device would go on sale in the United States on Feb. 22, 2012.

title: Goldman Loss Offers a Bad Omen for Wall Street
description: Goldman Sachs, once Wall Streets highest flier, has been grounded, and it does not bode well for the rest of the financial industry or the New York City economy that depends on it.

title: U.S. Weighs Its Strategy on Warfare in Cyberspace
description: WASHINGTON  The four-star Air Force general who oversees Pentagon efforts in cyberspace acknowledged Tuesday that the Defense Department had more work to do in clarifying the militarys doctrine for waging offensive computer warfare and setting up rules of engagement to guide specific cyberattacks.

title: Rangers Turn to Wilson, Their Ace and Student of the Game
description: ST. LOUIS  While shopping years ago at the South Coast Plaza mall in Costa Mesa, Calif., the Hall of Fame pitcher Jim Palmer strolled through the mens department at Nordstrom. He got more than the duvet he was looking for.

title: Leaner Airline Industry Is Profitable
description: The airline industry is leaner and earning money.

title: Some Risks as Obama Confronts Congress
description: EMPORIA, Va.  For the last several weeks, President Obama has railed against the do-nothing Congress. Not content with that, he is now needling it as the know-nothing Congress.

title: Big Easts Fate: Others Control Ball
description: After the Big East staved off football extinction in 2003, the league became familiar with reading its own obituaries.

title: Lawsuit Seeks Release of Police Commissioners Schedule
description: A civil liberties group filed a lawsuit on Tuesday seeking to force the New York Police Department to release the daily schedules of Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.

title: Civil Rights and Resisting Arrest
description: The arrest of a New York City police officer, who was accused of violating the civil rights of an African-American man during a stop-and-frisk arrest, provides good reason for Justice Department officials and state lawmakers to investigate whether others on the force are engaging in similar practices.

title: Bank of America Loses Title as Biggest in U.S.
description: For Bank of America, it is the end of an era.

title: A Fierce Clash for Romney and Perry as Republican Candidates Debate
description: LAS VEGAS  Mitt Romney came under intensive attack from his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination at a debate here Tuesday night, with a newly assertive Rick Perry leading a sometimes personal barrage against him on conservative consistency, health care policy and even the immigration status of yard workers at his home.

title: Q. and A.: Tom Morello Offers a Record of Rousing Hopelessness
description: Tom Morello has always written protest music. It is his aesthetic, his raison detre, his trademark. His politics are famously far left and incendiary. In the 1990s, he was the guitarist and one of the ideological forces behind Rage Against the Machine, the hard rock band that did social commentary during a period in American history when few were protesting.

title: Q. and A.: Everlast Sees the Ungrateful Living All Around Him
description: Some events change a mans perspective. In the last three years, Everlast says, he toured Iraq to play for the troops and watched with increasing rage as old friends and family members struggled financially after the mortgage crisis and stock market crash. He also married, and he and his wife had a daughter who they learned has cystic fibrosis.

title: Lottery Numbers
Q. and A.: Ry Cooder on Woody Guthrie, Politics and a New Album
description: Ry Cooders been called a lot of things: a musicians musician and a musical archeologist; a virtuoso of rock and blues guitar; and an explorer of international styles. But no one has ever labeled Mr. Cooder, 64, a folksinger. No one has accused him of singing protest songs and serving up social commentaries in the tradition of Woody Guthrie, Pete Seeger, Phil Ochs or Bob Dylan. Mr. Cooders most recent album, Pull Up Some Dust and Sit Down (Nonesuch), may change that perception.

title: Battle for a Holdout City Stalls Healing in Libya
description: SURT, Libya  The commander, defying a shower of bullets, urged his men to train their heavy weapons on a nest of pro-Qaddafi snipers in a school down the street. But then someone said that the loyalists had asked to surrender, and he told his men to hold their fire. It was a hopeful moment. After weeks of violence, the fighters were exhausted, the city was destroyed and hundreds of civilians were trapped in their homes in the area.

title: Harold Leppo, a President of Lord & Taylor, Dies at 74
description: Harold Leppo, who oversaw Lord & Taylors expansion into a national department store chain as its president during the 1970s and 80s, died on Friday in Stamford, Conn. He was 74.

title: Great From Day 1, Pujols Draws Superlatives On and Off the Field
description: ST. LOUIS  Ty Cobb hit .240 as a rookie. Willie Mays started 1 for 26. With Albert Pujols, there was no progression. From the moment he arrived in the major leagues, on opening day 2001, he was the best player in the game. Three Most Valuable Player awards and three World Series into his career, he still is.

title: 4 People Are Found Held Captive in Basement
description: PHILADELPHIA  Scraps from their captivity still littered the basement boiler room where they had been held: A sneaker, some plastic cups, stained blankets and a mayonnaise jar filled with urine.

title: Imagined in America
description: Hong Kong

title: Europe Cautiously Signals Its Displeasure Over a Prosecution in Ukraine
description: BRUSSELS  After the sentencing of Ukraines opposition leader, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the European Union on Tuesday abruptly put off a meeting with the countrys president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, in the clearest sign yet that efforts to integrate Ukraine, a former Soviet republic, more closely with Western Europe are stalling.

title: N.B.A. Talks Pause After 16-Hour Marathon Meeting
description: With a federal mediator prodding them along, and the stakes increasing by the day, negotiators for the N.B.A. and its players union returned to the bargaining table for a marathon session that began early Tuesday and bled into Wednesday morning.

title: Candidates Fighting Words Draw G.O.P.s Fire
description: BOSTON  In her nascent Senate campaign, Elizabeth Warren has captivated the national Democratic base with her scrappy populist rhetoric, most notably in a viral YouTube video in which she exhorts wealthy business owners to pay their fair share of taxes on the grounds that there is nobody in this country who got rich on his own.

title: Glad Cuts the Hyperbole for Its New Green Trash Bag
description: HOW much are marketers of green products scaling back ambitious efforts to sell eco-friendlier brands as life-changers and planet-savers? Well, a line of recycled paper products, introduced by Marcal in 2009, bears the name Small Steps rather than something grander like Giant Leaps.

title: A Melodic Emblem Falls Out of Tune
description: PARIS  Since 1856, the four major bells atop the northern towers of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame have rung every 15 minutes, without fail. They rang for the end of World War I and the liberation of Paris in 1944. Most recently, they chimed in honor of the victims of 9/11.

title: Senate Saves the Potato on School Lunch Menus
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate stood up Tuesday for the humble white potato and rebuffed an effort by President Obama to limit its consumption by millions of schoolchildren around the country.

title: Gloom Grips Consumers, and It May Be Home Prices
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Ernest Markey lost his stone-cutting business in 2009. He then sold his home for half a million dollars less than its value at the peak of the housing bubble and moved with his wife, Marie, to a smaller home in a less affluent suburb. They gave up two new cars and bought one. Used.

title: Prophecy of Machines
description: Is music technology?

title: RIM Unveils an Upgrade, but Little Else
description: OTTAWA  Research in Motion unveiled little more than a rebranding of what it called its next generation platform for BlackBerry smartphones and tablet on Tuesday at its software developers conference, disappointing many analysts.

title: Gay Pastor in New York Urges Change in Malaysia
description: The Rev. Boon Lin Ngeo, a Malaysian Protestant pastor whose message of tolerance for homosexuals has drawn fire in his country, sat with his male partner on a lime-green sofa inside the Office of the City Clerk in New York on a late summer day, where they waited their turn to be married.

title: Two Competing Theories in Bloomberg Consultants Trial
description: In his closing argument on Tuesday, Dennis C. Vacco took aim at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, his voice rising with each sentence as he insisted that the mayors cohort was desperate for him to win re-election in 2009 and as he questioned the credibility of the mayor himself.

title: A Story of Drugs and the Police
description: Because Yvelisse DeLeon of Coney Island was due at an interview for a bartending job on the evening of Jan. 25, 2007, she spent part of the afternoon getting herself ready. That process included a trip to Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Wednesday: Day Three of the Crossword Contest
description: Administrivial Heads Up For Friday! The Friday, October 21 crossword puzzle will be available at the normal time and place, but will have a format that will not be available in Across Lite.However, we will be offering a PDF version that you will need to print out to solve. That version will be available here on the blog and the Premium Puzzle Page on Thursday, October 20 at 10 p.m. Eastern time.

title: Inquiry Faults Citys Insertion of Political View in Parents Petition Over School Cuts
description: It all began with a parents suggestion: Why not draft a petition for parents and students to sign and send to Albany protesting cuts in state aid to city schools?

title: Officer Guilty in a Strange Hunt for Treasure
description: After learning two years ago that officials had foiled a plot by a rogue New York City police officer to jolt him with a stun gun and burglarize his apartment in Inwood, Jason B. Holt faced a question: Should he leave the building?

title: Latinos Said to Bear Weight of a Deportation Program
description: A deportation program that is central to the Obama administrations immigration enforcement strategy has led disproportionately to the removal of Latino immigrants and to arrests by immigration authorities of hundreds of United States citizens, according to a report by two law schools using new, in-depth official data on deportation cases.

title: Anne Frank, a Mormon?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Quinn Says City Must Find Balance in Response to Protests
description: Speaking on Tuesday before an audience composed largely of business leaders, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, said that she was not anti-Wall Street but that the anger of the Occupy Wall Street protesters should not be ignored.

title: Out With Textbooks, in With Laptops for an Indiana School District
description: MUNSTER, Ind.  Laura Norman used to ask her seventh-grade scientists to take out their textbooks and flip to Page Such-and-Such. Now, she tells them to take out their laptops.

title: An Electrifying Ancestor
description: Evolutionary biologists at Cornell University have found that most land vertebrates  including humans  are descended from a predatory fish that lived hundreds of millions of years ago and could sense electrical fields in its environment. Soon, in evolutionary terms, the lineage of that fish split in two. One line led to fish that still retain a sophisticated electro-sensing apparatus, like the North American paddlefish. The other line led to land vertebrates  including us  that have lost the ability to detect weak electrical currents without calling the electrician.

title: Insurers See an Opening in Commercial Mortgages
description: Over the past several months, the commercial mortgage market has been volatile, plagued by weak investor appetite, wary lenders and warnings by ratings agencies of increasing risk. But one bright spot is emerging, as life insurance companies have taken advantage of the lull to become major lenders.

title: In Queens, Neglected Sector Attracts Big Developers
description: Willets Point, the unsightly jumble of auto shops in northeastern Queens, looks pretty much as it did in May 2007, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced plans for a $3 billion mixed-use development on the site  with the notable exception that Citi Field, the new home of the New York Mets, now looms over it.

title: Peter Mullen, Power at a Leading Law Firm, Dies at 83
description: Peter P. Mullen joined the Manhattan law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom in 1961, when it consisted of just 10 lawyers; when he stepped down as its de facto chief executive in 1994, it had more than 1,000, and was one of the worlds richest and most prominent firms.

title: Confessions of a Rookie Re-Enactor
description: The First Battle of Bull Run, like freshman year of college, was a time for earning reputations  and nicknames. On that same afternoon when Confederate Gen. Thomas Jonathan Jackson won his moniker, Stonewall, he bestowed an equally flattering reputation on a Union regiment called the 14th Brooklyn, which wore red wool trousers as part of their local militia uniform modeled after the French chasseurs. The 14th Brooklyn  the only regiment in the Union Army called by a citys name rather than a state  was giving Jackson and his troops quite a time on Henry House Hill, and at some point Stonewall braced his soldiers for yet another charge by shouting Hold on Boys! Here come those red-legged devils again!

title: In Rift Between Murdochs, Heir Becomes Less Apparent
description: LONDON  It was a striking display of unity: Rupert and James Murdoch, father and son, walking side by side through central London as they faced a crisis that had laid siege to their company. Pushing through a crush of paparazzi on a street not far from Buckingham Palace, James reached out to place a reassuring hand on his fathers back.

title: Scenes From a Red Bulls Practice
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls trained at Red Bull Arena instead of Montclair State University on Tuesday, but Thierry Henry and Rafael Marquez declined to speak with the news media, and Coach Hans Backe said he had yet to see the play on which Henry drew a red card last Saturday.

title: Glad Tosses Out Some Plastic
description: Glad plans to spend $30 million to $40 million on a campaign for a new kitchen trash bag that the company says saves enough plastic  the equivalent of 140 million bags  to cover Manhattan.

title: Romneys Lawn Care History and the Fight Over Immigration
description: Rick Perrys most pointed attack against Mitt Romney in Tuesday nights debate concerned an immigration matter that came to light when Mr. Romney was campaigning for president four years ago.

title: More Mortgage Debt Than Property Value
description: Chart shows the ratio of total mortgage debt to property value in major metropolitan areas of the U.S.

title: Report Faults Sleeping and Awake Controllers
description: Two airliners landed in error at Reagan National Airport on March 23 after the lone tower controller on a midnight shift fell asleep and regional officials reacted incorrectly, a federal investigation concluded. As air traffic managers tried to figure out why the tower was not responding, a regional controller left the pilots of the incoming flights with the erroneous impression that they could land using rules for airports with unmanned towers, the National Transportation Safety Board said in a report Tuesday. The planes landed safely. The board blamed the tower controllers fatigue and the Federal Aviation Administrations scheduling practices for the incident. The F.A.A. has since revamped scheduling, assigned at least two controllers to every tower overnight and revised the guidelines for when a tower does not respond.

title: Las Vegas Debate Fact Check
description: Romneys Texas Jobs Claim

title: In Prisoner Swap, a Day of Joy and Tension
description: The exchange of Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier held by Hamas, for the first batch of more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners in Israel began on Tuesday.

title: Whats Behind the Lack of Confidence
description: Economists are scrambling to understand why Americans are so pessimistic about the economy. As I describe in an article in Wednesdays paper, a leading theory blames the funk on the collapse in housing prices, which has erased a vast amount of wealth and convinced many Americans that they will never recover financially.

title: United Auto Workers Approve a New Four-Year Contract With Ford Motor
description: The United Auto Workers has ratified its proposed contract with the Ford Motor Company after union members at two assembly plants in Kentucky approved the accord.

title: Viewers Get Latest Episode of Real Republicans of the Trail
description: Mitt Romney said he liked Herman Cains chutzpah. He laughed, mirthlessly, when Rick Perry accused him of lying about hiring undocumented workers in his home. And he really didnt enjoy being interrupted. Mr. Romney put a hand on Mr. Perrys arm, space invasion of the first kind, and said, Im speaking, Im speaking, Im speaking, Im speaking.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Debate in Las Vegas
description: Seven of the Republican candidates for president gathered for the eighth debate of the year and the first held in the West.

title: Do We Have a Set Point for Exercise?
description: Does exercising at one point during the day make you less active the rest of the time?
