description: waif \waf\ noun

title: Three Lawmakers Propose Cutting Contractor Wages
description: WASHINGTON  Already facing the prospect of losing billions of dollars in revenue from cuts in government spending, federal contractors could also see limits on how much they can be paid in salary with federal funds.

title: Western Republican Leadership Conference (WRLC)/CNN Debate at the Venetian Resort Hotel Casino
description: The following is a transcript of the Western Republican Leadership Conference (WRLC)/CNN Republican presidential debate in Las Vegas, Nev., as provided by Federal News Service.

title: Herman Cains Freewheeling Quotes
description: Herman Cain speaks his mind  and writes his own rules.

title: Behind Cains Humor, a Question of Seriousness
description: It is safe to say that no other Republican on the campaign trail this year  or ever  has begun a speech with the phrase Awww, shucky ducky! the way Herman Cain did this year to the utter delight of his audience, which responded with wild applause.

title: The Caucus | Las Vegas Debate Wrap-Up
description: In the most contentious debate so far, Mitt Romney and Rick Perry clashed repeatedly. It signaled the start of a tough new phase of the campaign.

title: NYT Front Page for 10/19/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 10/19/2011

title: Red Sox Deny Drinking Report
description: The Red Sox late Tuesday issued a statement denying news media reports that Boston players were drinking beer in the dugout during games this season. Jon Lester has admitted drinking in the clubhouse with Josh Beckett and John Lackey, but the three men, and the former manager Terry Francona, each were quoted in the team statement saying no one drank in the dugout. We accept their statements as honest and factual, Larry Lucchino, the team president, said in the release.

title: Rick Santorum Clashes With Mitt Romney
description: Former Senator Rick Santorum, seeking a chance to be an alternative to Mr. Romney and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas mixed it up with both of them all evening.

title: Pete Rugolo, Arranger and Composer, Is Dead at 95
description: Pete Rugolo, the chief arranger for the Stan Kenton Orchestra in its late-1940s heyday and a prolific composer and arranger for television and film, including the series Richard Diamond, Private Detective, The Fugitive and Run for Your Life, died on Sunday in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 95.

title: Romney and Perry Clash
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas led an intense and sometimes personal barrage against Mitt Romney.

title: Corrections: October 19
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The "9-9-9" Plan Under Attack
description: Herman Cain spent the debate's opening moments defending his 9-9-9 tax plan against nearly unanimous criticism from his fellow candidates.

title: Vegas Debate: A Game of Seven-Candidate Draw?
description: Im not intrinsically averse to declaring winners and losers in presidential debates. But there are times when everything is fought more or less to a draw.

title: Lenny Speiller Reprimanded Over Petition
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott reprimands Lenny Speiller, the Department of Educations director of public affairs, for his actions regarding the insertion of political views into a petition for parents.

title: Relationship Tension, Over Screeching Feedback
description: Sexual energy drives many good songs, and when a male and female duo write and sing songs together about the unspoken dialogue underlying their relationship, the result can be electric.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
description: On Tuesday two core members of Anna Hazares India Against Corruption movement quit over the groups political turn, the Hindustan Times reports. Rajendra Singh and P.V. Rajagopal expressed discontent over the teams anti Congress campaign in the run-up to the Hisar by-election, which the Congress party eventually lost.

title: Deputies Hunt Exotic Animals on the Loose in Ohio
description: Last Updated | 2:35 p.m. The authorities in the Ohio town where wild animals roamed overnight and early Wednesday said that by the afternoon all but two  a monkey and a wolf  had been accounted for.

title: Champions League Wednesday Preview: Porto Leery of APOEL
description: Dont look now, but as the Champions Leagues group stage comes its halfway point with eight games on Wednesday, the pride of Cyprus leads Group G. APOEL (Athlitikos Podosfairikos Omilos Ellinon Lefkosias in Greek, or Athletic Football Club of Greeks of Nicosia) goes to Portugal to face Porto leading the group by a point.

title: The Worlds Best Vada Pav, Vadkhal Edition
description: A recent reporting trip took me down the road that connects the pulsing metropolis of Mumbai to the laid-back retreat of Goa. About 80 kilometers (50 miles) outside the city, in the town of Vadkhal, my traveling companion insisted we make a snack stop. I am never really averse to snack stops, but I was surprised because he had been rhapsodizing about the fresh, Konkan-style fish curry that awaited us at our destination.

title: Oct. 19, 1987 | Stock Market Crashes on Black Monday
description: On Oct. 19, 1987, a day that became known as Black Monday, the stock market crashed as the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged 508 points, or 22.6 percent in value, its largest single-day percentage drop. The crash came after a two-week period in which the Dow dropped 15 percent.

title: News Quiz | Oct. 19, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Thousands in Greece Protest Austerity Bill
description: ATHENS  By now, it almost feels like a ritual: a strike and large demonstration disrupted by skirmishes and tear gas ahead of a parliamentary vote on new austerity measures that Greece needs to take to qualify for the next installment of aid the country needs to fend off default.

title: British Police Clear Encampment, Home to Hundreds, After Ruling
description: LONDON  After a long and bitter legal battle that has tested Britains reputation for tolerance, the authorities began clearing an encampment east of London on Wednesday, two days after the Court of Appeal upheld a ruling that occupation by its owners  so-called travelers  was unlawful.

title: Around the World, Young and Imprisoned
description: Lizzie Sadin started researching her project Children Behind Bars in 1999 though it took her more than a year to be allowed to shoot inside a prison in Russia. By then, she had noplans to seek out prisons in other countries.

title: Dont Blink! The Hazards of Confidence
description: Many decades ago I spent what seemed like a great deal of time under a scorching sun, watching groups of sweaty soldiers as they solved a problem. I was doing my national service in the Israeli Army at the time. I had completed an undergraduate degree in psychology, and after a year as an infantry officer, I was assigned to the armys Psychology Branch, where one of my occasional duties was to help evaluate candidates for officer training. We used methods that were developed by the British Army in World War II.

title: Bad Guys vs. Worse Guys in Afghanistan
description: One afternoon this summer, in a park beside the Ajmil River, I sat with seven residents of Shahabuddin, a collection of villages in northern Afghanistans Baghlan Province. It was the first week of Ramadan, and the park was almost empty, but still the men  some middle-aged, others stooped and gray-bearded  whispered conspiratorially and became silent whenever anybody walked close. Several minutes into our conversation, one of the younger men, whod been mutely worrying at a piece of grass, rose and abruptly stalked off. The others, embarrassed, apologized for him. If Nur-ul Haq finds out we spoke to you, one of them explained, he will kill us.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 19, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article, Inflating the Software Report Card.

title: Zombies Turn Up the Heat in Atlanta
description: WHY has Atlanta magazine dubbed that city the zombie capital of the world?WHY do you think so many people want to be extras on The Walking Dead?

title: What Role Does Television Play in Your Life and the Life of Your Family?
description: A new study about children under the age of 2 states that television may be harmful to the childrens development. The studys authors suggest parents refrain from letting their young children watch television, the same advice they issued in 1999. What age do you think is appropriate for children to begin watching television? Do you have rules in your home about how much television you can watch per day?

title: Poll Finds Some Believe Mayor Has Lost Focus
description: A narrow majority of New York City voters believe that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has lost his focus midway through his third term, according to a poll released Wednesday morning by Quinnipiac University.

title: Are Employers Requiring People to Work Longer Hours?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: A V-12 in a Ford Ka? Forza 4 Makes Realism Customizable
description: In a Web advertisement for Forza Motorsport 4, the new racing simulator for the Xbox 360, we hear Jeremy Clarkson say that car enthusiasts are an endangered species. Mr. Clarkson, the host of the BBCs Top Gear show, laments that lovers of speed and performance are being trapped in practical cars and commuter slogs. That, he says, is why a racing simulator like Forza provides sanctuary.

title: Jerry Jones Was Right; Cowboys Should Have Passed
description: Jason Garrett has received a lot of criticism for his decision to call three straight runs while up, 16-13, with 3 minutes 36 seconds to play in Sundays game in New England, perhaps the harshest of which came from his boss. We rolled the dice at the end and went conservative, the Cowboys owner, Jerry Jones, said,and it bit us. You always second-guess whether or not we should have tried to run a little offense down there instead of running it three times.

title: The Early Word: Combative
description: In Todays Times:

title: In Hong Kong, a Monthlong Celebration of Food and Wine
description: Good food and drink rank high among Hong Kongers obsessions, so its appropriate that there is a whole month devoted to it. Wine & Dine month kicks off with the Wine & Dine Festival, which runs Oct. 27 to 30 at a picturesque location on the West Kowloon promenade. Food and wine tastings may be purchased from over 200 exhibitors (general admission is free). New at the festival this year are Spanish and Japanese purveyors who promise themed food and entertainment.

title: Tip of the Week: Mobile Updates to Your Social Network
description: Dedicated smartphone apps for social-media networks make it easy to post status updates on the go. Users with regular cellphones can also keep their friends in the loop by simply sending text messages directly to a phone number specified by the site. A few setup steps may be needed first to get the text-based posting activated (and every service may not work with every wireless carrier out there), but Facebook, Twitter and Google+ all have guides for getting started.

title: Turkey Pursues Kurdish Rebels After 24 Soldiers Are Killed Near Iraq
description: ISTANBUL  Kurdish militants killed at least 24 Turkish soldiers in an attack near the Iraq border on Wednesday, one of the deadliest strikes in years, and Turkeys military responded by sending hundreds of troops into northern Iraq in a counterattack on Kurdish insurgent hide-outs.

title: Market Volatility Hurts Profit at BlackRock
description: 8:51 p.m. | Updated

title: Rare Parity in the St. Louis Lineup
description: It is no secret that Albert Pujols is a great player, possibly one of the best ever. But as the Cardinals marched to the World Series, Pujols had something truly rare for him: help from his teammates.

title: Does This Service Providers Web Site Make You Want the Service?
description: Dr. Debra Jaliman has run a dermatology practice in Manhattan for the past 25 years. Ten years ago, she created a Web site to promote both her practice and her line of skin-care products.

title: Europes Leaders Gather as Pressure Mounts on Debt
description: FRANKFURT  Still trying to dampen expectations for a grand gesture to address the debt crisis, most of the key figures in European politics gathered in Frankfurt late Wednesday under intense pressure to deliver a decisive response.

title: Morgan Stanleys $2.15 Billion Profit Exceeds Expectations
description: 8:54 p.m. | Updated

title: Qatar Bank Seeks Turkish Unit of Struggling Dexia
description: The state-backed Qatar National Bank is in talks to buy the Turkish division of Dexia, the struggling French-Belgian bank.

title: The Ecologists of Tomorrow Talk Shop
description: Most people grow out of the frog-catching phase of childhood, Samantha Attwood says, but some dont.

title: Wild Flag Is What Passes for an Inspirational Supergroup at CMJ
description: This years CMJ Music Marathon feels light in established acts, those midlevel bands who are used to the grind of this festival and make it an essential part of their tour schedule. Whats left is an agglomeration of small acts, and smaller acts, with the occasional boldface name screaming loudly from beneath the pile.

title: Coming Attractions: Occupy Wall St., the Documentary
description: Occupy Wall Street, the protest movement that began in Lower Manhattan and quickly spread across the country and around the world, might be coming to a theater near you.

title: South Park Provides the Stage for a Book of Mormon Reunion
description: If youd like to see what happens when Trey Parker, Matt Stone and Robert Lopez combine their comic talents but cant get your hands on tickets for their bawdy, blaspheming Broadway hit, The Book of Mormon, cable television will soon provide a more easily accessible alternative.

title: Frenchwoman Abducted in Kenya Dies
description: PARIS  A disabled Frenchwoman kidnapped by Somali gunmen in Kenya this month has died in captivity, the French government announced Wednesday.

title: Permira to Buy Alcatel-Lucent Unit for $1.5 billion
description: The private equity firm Permira has agreed to buy Genesys, a call center provider, from the telecommunications giant Alcatel-Lucent in an all-cash deal worth $1.5 billion.

title: Debate Suggests Brutish Campaign to Come
description: 12:55 p.m. | Updated Rick Perry and Mitt Romney braced Wednesday for a new, more aggressive phase in their presidential rivalry after a debate Tuesday night in which both men made clear how deep the personal animosity between them goes.

title: Abbott Labs to Split Into 2 Companies
description: 8:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Olympus in Apparent Reversal on Payments to Advisers
description: TOKYO  The Japanese camera maker Olympus acknowledged Wednesday that it had paid $687 million in advisory fees for its acquisition of a British medical equipment company. In doing so, the company seemed to back off statements it had made a day earlier and to partly confirm claims made by its former chief executive.

title: Wednesday Reading: What to Ask a Financial Adviser
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Solidarity: 99 Percent Elusive
description: As a lifelong member of the group now known as the 99 percent, and also as someone who hasnt a prayer of ever breaking into the 1 percent, I know that I should feel a bond with every 99 percenter out there. I know the troubles created by that 1 percent. Ive been to Zuccotti Park. I get it: 99 = good, 1 = bad.

title: Jennifer Lopezs Talent Show Finds U.S. Home on Univision
description: The marriage may be ending but the show goes on for Jennifer Lopez and Marc Anthony. The duo has sold their television series QViva! The Chosen to 21 broadcast networks internationally. On Wednesday, the first three broadcast network deals were announced by the shows producer, XIX Entertainment, the company of Simon Fuller, the creator of American Idol.

title: Fears Revived in Bangkok as Flood Waters Surge
description: BANGKOK  Thousands of Thai soldiers and volunteers worked on Wednesday to strengthen Bangkoks flood defenses as water surged to the edges of the city, two days after officials proclaimed that the worst was over.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Wall Street Grapples with Diminished Reality | The first loss at Goldman Sachs since the financial crisis points to what could be a more lasting shift in the financial industry, as the bank that was once Wall Streets highest flier has been grounded.

title: Complaint Accuses Pepsi of Deceptive Marketing
description: 11:30 a.m. | Updated Four consumer advocacy and privacy organizations filed a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday alleging that PepsiCo and its Frito-Lay subsidiary are engaging in deceptive digital marketing practices targeted at adolescents.

title: Samurai Shopper | Odor Eaters
description: Once upon a time, washing with soap and water was considered radical hygiene. There was even a church injunction against water on the grounds that bathing spurred sensuality and indolence  talk about the odor of sanctity. At the same time, pestilential stench was a sign of Satan; bad odors indicated physical and moral decay. Alain Corbins The Foul and the Fragrant chronicles France in the 18th and 19th centuries when the masses stank to high heaven and perfumed gloves and sleeves inured the aesthete from those very rank rank and file. But the aristocracy was not entirely immune. Casanova, Corbin tells us, nearly fainted at the musky smell of an old nymphomaniac duchess. I sat next to her on the bus yesterday, and I nearly died too.

title: Abbott Plans to Split Into Two Companies
description: Updated: 12:45 p.m. Abbott Laboratories said on Wednesday it would separate into two publicly traded companies, one focused on medical devices like heart stents and the other in what it called research-based pharmaceuticals, such as its blockbuster rheumatoid arthritis drug Humira.

title: Fostering Insights by Engaging the Whole Brain
description: Heres a fresh look at efforts to bring data to life using sound, motion and graphics. Ive posted before on the largely untapped potential to communicate information and ideas in new ways. The images above of brain activity related to processing or speaking words (from the National Institutes of Health) convey how multimedia communication might more fully engage the brain.

title: Rising Demand May Save Intel From Low-Price Competitors
description: Intel has a message for its doubters: Time, in terms of a rush to build more big computing centers, is on its side.

title: Withholding Judgment on Sam Bradford
description: Chase Stuart, who contributes to the Fifth Down, took some criticism from Rams fans in August for writing on Pro-Football-Reference.com that Sam Bradfords rookie season in 2010 was overrated. Stuarts point was that football pundits were overrating Bradford  he was being called a surefire star  not that Bradford was a failure.

title: On Our Radar: Wild Animals Escape in Ohio
description: Lions, tigers, bears and other animals escaped from an exotic pet farm in Zanesville, Ohio, prompting the local authorities to issue a shoot-to-kill order that resulted in death for most of the animals. [Reuters]

title: What Were Reading
description: Wine Spectator: Matt Kramer advises newcomers to wine to avoid the hedonistic approach and go for the edge.  Eric Asimov

title: Q. and A. With Soccer Men Author Simon Kuper
description: The British author Simon Kuper was born in Uganda and grew up in England, the Netherlands, the United States, Sweden and Jamaica. His soccer writing has taken him to even more far-flung corners of the globe  even on daring forays inside the minds of Diego Maradona and Wayne Rooney  for the profiles of what he calls the rogues, geniuses and neurotics of world soccer that make up his new book, Soccer Men. Kupers previous books include the prize-winning Football Against the Enemy and the groundbreaking Soccernomics, written with the economist Stefan Syzmanski.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

title: CMJ Reader Reviews: Day 1  Titus Andronicus, Wild Flag and Radical Dads
description: Critics from The New York Times will be squashed into many of the citys clubs during the CMJ Music Marathon alongside other music fans and chroniclers. But we cant be everywhere. This year, weve invited readers to join us in appraising CMJ shows on Twitter.

title: Efficiency Gains Help Offset Costs for Ford in New Contract
description: DETROIT  Workers at the Ford Motor Company showed that they were clearly not happy with the four-year labor agreement their union negotiated, but in the end they approved it rather than jeopardize hefty bonuses and thousands of new jobs in an uncertain economy.

title: Baseballs Place in a Fast-Moving World
description: Considering we live in the era of 700 television channels, iPhone movie-watching, countless hours stolen by Facebook and video games and, well, you get the picture, it is hardly stunning that the World Series has tumbled down the entertainment ladder and now looks up enviously at episodes of Dancing With the Stars. And considering the World Series, which begins on Wednesday night  you did know that, right?  will feature St. Louis Manager Tony La Russa spending at least 47 minutes pondering pitching changes and double switches, baseball might consider staging a few dance numbers to keep its loyal watchers from lapsing into comas.

title: Ingvar Wixell, Swedish Baritone, Dies at 80
description: Ingvar Wixell, a Swedish baritone whose intelligent, vivid performances in the Italian repertory made him a respected fixture on the worlds opera stages, died on Oct. 8 in Malmo, Sweden. He was 80.

title: For Now, Its a Cheaper Safari
description: IF youve ever dreamed of taking a luxury African safari, the time is now.

title: Romney Versus the Field
description: In a sense, last nights Republican debate went badly for Mitt Romney. When youre the clear frontrunner and the candidate who was supposed to provide your chief competition has spent the last month self-destructing, you have no business allowing yourself to get nettled by him  much less put your hand on his shoulder, talk over him angrily, mock his poor showings at previous debates, and complain at length that hes breaking the debates rules of order. Nate Silver has the right take on the heated Romney-Rick Perry exchange:

title: X Factor Watch: Lets Vote on the Judges
description: Can reality-show judges be impeached?

title: Bulls and Bears Battle Over Green Mountain Coffee
description: Earlier this week DealBook reported on the fierce debate surrounding Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, one of Americas hottest businesses. Is it the leader in the single-serve coffee-drinking revolution? Or is it an overvalued, overhyped company whose Keurig roasting system is a passing fad?

title: Will Phone Stunt for The Sitter Yield Right Numbers at Box Office?
description: When it comes to publicizing movies, a lot of stars do as little as possible  a perfunctory wave from a red carpet, a do-I-have-to-be-here chat with Jay Leno.

title: Food and Gasoline Helped Push the Consumer Price Index Higher in September
description: A rise in food and energy prices pushed up the index for consumer prices in the United States in September, although the increase was slower than in August, according to government statistics released on Wednesday.

title: For Cate Edwards, After Loss and Turmoil, a Day for I Do
description: ATLANTA  Cate Edwards will have a day of her own on Saturday.

title: For Veterans, Age Is Rhodes Scholarship Obstacle
description: Mitchell B. Reiss, the president of Washington College, in Chestertown, Md., has started a one-man campaign to end what he sees as a lingering, unfair form of discrimination against veterans: the age limits on candidates for the prestigious Rhodes Scholarships, which pay for two years of graduate study at Oxford University.

title: The Un-Bazooka
description: There was some excitement yesterday over reports that the European were going to establish a 2 trillion euro rescue fund. Was this the big bazooka needed to put an end to the debt crisis? No, for three reasons.

title: Deer-Car Collisions Are Less Frequent, but More Costly
description: As I was driving my children home from an after-school activity recently, I had to brake as a herd of deer sauntered across the road in the dusk, their eyes glinting in the glare of my headlights. My children were thrilled to see them, but I was quietly relieved I had seen them in time to stop.

title: More Do-Good Design | Kartell Loves Milano
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: U.S. Solar Panel Makers Say China Violated Trade Rules
description: Seven American makers of solar panels filed a broad trade case in Washington against the Chinese solar industry on Wednesday, accusing it of using billions of dollars in government subsidies to help gain sales in the American market.

title: Star in Canada Is Answer to Trivia Question
description: The most productive passer in the history of professional football is 39 years old, a Utah State alumnus, a cancer survivor and virtually anonymous to the average United States citizen. His name is Anthony Calvillo, and he has never taken a snap in the N.F.L.

title: Money And Inflation, British Edition
description: Update: small correction on Adam Posens promise. Also, as several commenters have pointed out, a major factor in those high inflation numbers is the fact that Britains VAT didnt just return to previous level; the Cameron government increased the rate from 17.5 to 20.

title: You, Batman, Must Keep Arkham City in Line
description: Ive never been a comic book guy. As I kept telling people last week while New York Comic Con was in town: Im not anti-comics; I just never got into them.

title: Q&A: New Years Eve Weekend in New York
description: Q.

title: The Toll of Stress on Parents  and Kids
description: Call us Generation Squeeze.

title: Trailer: Batman: Arkham City
description: Batman: Arkham City, from Warner Brothers, is an expansive urban sequel to Arkham Asylum from 2009.

title: CMJ Offers a New New Sound, Right Next Door
description: Often at the CMJ Music Marathon you dont have to walk more than 15 feet to have your mind changed about the sounds of the day. At Public Assembly in Williamsburg on Tuesday, all you had to do was go to the next room. All night, and into the morning, a pair of labels were facing off in adjacent spaces.

title: Holding Out at Zuccotti Park Is a 44-Year-Old Tradition
description: Resistance runs deep at Zuccotti Park. You might even say its in the ground. The protesters clinging tenaciously to that little parcel in Lower Manhattan owe a big spiritual debt to Chock Full o Nuts.

title: A Snapshot of Shark Finning
description: The global campaign in defense of sharks has picked up considerably in the last two or three years. What was once a niche issue  a sharp decline in shark populations because of soaring demand for their fins in parts of Asia  has gone mainstream.

title: Coffin Joe Lives On
description: Larry Rohter discusses the horror films of Jos Mojica Marins, otherwise known as Coffin Joe.

title: At Fieldston School, Division Over the Dismissal of a Popular but Polarizing Teacher
description: There are perhaps few schools in the nation with as progressive a pedigree as Ethical Culture Fieldston School, where students are not only expected to live the values of tolerance and inclusion, but also to make the world more tolerant and inclusive. Half those in the schools kindergarten classes this year are minority students, with Fieldston leading a push for diversity among New Yorks elite private schools. The new head of school, Damian Fernandez, an openly gay Latino, began the year promising a deeper commitment to the schools liberal roots in ethical learning.

title: Citigroup to Pay Millions to Close Fraud Complaint
description: WASHINGTON  As the housing market began its collapse, Wall Street firms and sophisticated investors searched for ways to profit. Some of them found an easy method: Stuff a portfolio with risky mortgage-related investments, sell it to unsuspecting customers and bet against it.

title: A Cult Figure Conjures the Macabre
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  SEATED on a sofa in the living room of his modest apartment here, dressed in shorts and flip-flops, Jos Mojica Marins seems inoffensive. He is mild mannered and soft-spoken, and nothing suggests he has made a career of writing, acting in and directing provocative horror movies with titles like Hallucinations of a Deranged Mind.

title: As Jobless Claims Rise, Businesses Try to Manage the Burden of Benefits
description: When Mary White opened her unemployment insurance statement in August and saw that her account had been docked for a claim from an employee who had quit more than a year before, she was baffled.

title: New U.S. Envoy to Talk With North Koreans
description: WASHINGTON  The United States will resume exploratory talks with North Korea next week in Geneva and has appointed a full-time envoy with a background in nuclear issues, the State Department announced Wednesday.

title: Blaming Government More Than Wall Street
description: Americans blame the federal government more than they blame Wall Street for the nations current economic distress, according to a new poll from Gallup. In fact, forced to declare jaccuse to just one culprit, twice as many chose the feds:

title: Select Images From This Weeks Online Childrens Book Review
description: Pamela Paul reviews this seasons new board books.

title: This Seasons Board Books
description: CHARLEY HARPERS COLORS By Charley Harper 24 pp. AMMO. $9.95. (Board book; ages 1 to 3)

title: Eurofile | Britains First Two-Star Pub
description: I do hope the food isnt all fussy, said my friend Edwina as we drove out of London on a beautiful Indian summer afternoon for Sunday lunch at the Hand and Flowers pub in Marlow, which is midway between Maidenhead and Henley-on-Thames in Buckinghamshire. Her slightly grumpy apprehension derived from the fact that Hand and Flowers had just received two Michelin stars, a first for any British pub. I do loathe the term gastropub, she added. I bet this place will be full of horrid people wearing new Barbour jackets and Wellies, and dont forget we must be home by 5 p.m. Now lost in a sea of red wine was last nights admission that she had a date with her married Spanish airline pilot.

title: Are You Managing Your Unemployment Insurance?
description: Every Nov. 30, the State of Illinois sends out a statement that tells businesses what rate they will pay in the coming year for unemployment insurance. I view the rate as one indication of how I did this year as a manager. This time around, Im anticipating a gift, because we had no unemployment claims this year, and I expect the rate to go down. In a bad year, the statement feels more like a reprimand, one that comes with a bill attached.

title: Treading Lightly Beyond Peanuts and Cracker Jack
description: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league.

title: Is Occupy Wall Street Being Overhyped?
description: David Brooks: Gail, can we talk about the overhyping of the Occupy Wall Street movement?

title: Environmentalist Explains Shifts on Biotechnology and Nuclear Power
description: Keith Kloor has a fascinating interview with the British environmental writer and activist Mark Lynas on the Yale Environment 360 Web site. The exchange centers on Lynass new book, The God Species: Saving the Planet in the Age of Humans,and particularly on his conclusion that some technologies that have been anathema to environmentalists are vital to a smooth human journey in this century  particularly nuclear power and crops developed using biotechnology. Also notable is Lynass revised view of the skeptical environmentalist Bjorn Lomborg, whose face he once plastered with a pie. I encourage you to read it and weigh in here.

title: UIST 2011: Crowdsourcing Research
description: Kyle Murray, a doctoral student in Computer Science at the University of Rochester, prepares to demo Legion, a crowdsourcing application toolkit.

title: Why Occupy?
description: An article by Marc Lacey in Tuesdays New York Times looked at the many different issues motivating protesters in America and abroad to join the growing Occupy Wall Street movement. Reporting on protesters around the country, Mr. Lacey found that not every group or individual that has embraced Occupy marches for the same reasons. Though many protesters seem united in feeling that a system designed to benefit the rich and connected is not working in their favor, many are also more concerned with specific challenges affecting their local communities, such as education and the environment.

title: Americas Car Museum Takes Shape in Tacoma
description: To hear David Madeira tell it, building a 165,000-square-foot, four-story museum to house the breadth of American automotive history is a solemn task and a mathematical quandary.

title: Anti-Austerity Strike in Greece
description: The strike, the second this month, was one of the biggest in months, if not years.

title: Consider the Romney-Perry Showdown (and Talk It Over)
description: Who came outlooking better (or worse) in the exchange during Tuesday nights debate between Mitt Romney and Gov. Rick Perry over immigration?

title: Statistics Have A Well-Known Keynesian Bias
description: OK, several correspondents have weighed in on the story Id heard about the economics department that abandoned econometrics because it was rejecting its models. It wasnt quite as alleged, but close enough.

title: Police Kill Dozens of Animals Freed on Ohio Reserve
description: ZANESVILLE, Ohio  The womans voice sounded a little annoyed. Theres a bear and a lion out, she told the 911 operator on Tuesday. Right up behind us.

title: Peter and the Starcatcher Flying to Broadway
description: The recent surge of new American plays on Broadway shows no sign of letting up. Peter and the Starcatcher, which blends inventive staging with the world of make-believe in a tale of the orphan boy who became Peter Pan, will open this spring at a Broadway theater to be announced, the producers confirmed on Wednesday.

title: U.S. Urges Opening Up Old Grand Jury Records
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, in a move that could open up more transcripts of historically significant grand jury testimony from many years ago, is proposing to change a rule that imposes strict and permanent secrecy requirements on such records.

title: Obama Unveils Business Partnership to Boost Military Hiring

title: Smaller Record Labels in Deal With YouTube
description: Many small, independent record companies have had frosty relations with YouTube ever since the company was sold to Google in 2006, when three of the four major labels made a quick $50 million thanks to a last-minute equity deal.

title: Jazz in Name Only  if That  at CMJ
description: The line outside Le Poisson Rouge wrapped around the block on Tuesday night for a CMJ Music Marathon showcase with the header Future Now. The question this seemed to invite was, could jazz actually be making an impression at this years CMJ?

title: The Herms Time Machine
description: The quest to counter the relentless march of time has been pursued by dreamers and puzzled over by scientists since, well, the beginning of time. Now, the French luxury giant Herms has cleverly succeeded in achieving the very appearance of slowing time with its new watch the Cape Cod Grands Heures, first introduced at Baselworld 2011, and available in stores in time for the holidays. The face of the new watch, which has three choices of distinct dials, shows numeric hour indicators that are clustered together, spread far apart, standing solo and intermittently spaced  all allowing for a variable speed that gives the illusion that time is moving more slowly, or more quickly. Want your afternoons to seemingly pass at a more leisurely pace? Choose a dial with wide open spaces between 2 and 4. Prefer a purportedly longer happy hour? Try the version with larger gaps between 5 and 7. This ingenious trick of time is managed by an oval wheel system that allows for the speeding and slowing of its motion, while the minutes and seconds march steadily, and constantly, on. The clever dial design encourages the romantic notion that time can actually take its time, but the hours, alas, remain the same. Always the hours.

title: Saudi Video Blogger Reportedly Detained for Showing Poverty in Riyadh
description: A popular Saudi video blogger was detained this week, along with his crew, after his report on poverty in the kingdoms capital, Riyadh, was viewed hundreds of thousands of times on YouTube, human rights activists said.

description: Citing an unnamed Daimler executive, a German newspaper reported Wednesday that Ernst Lieb, the former president and chief executive of Mercedes-Benz USA who was dismissed Monday, was fired after repeatedly flouting rules governing the use of company funds and influence.

title: Warhol Foundation Ends Authentication Board
description: 4:59 p.m. | Updated The Andy Warhol Foundation announced on Wednesday that it will dissolve its authentication board early next year. In a statement, the foundation said the move reflects its intent to shift focus toward maximizing grant making and other charitable activities. In recent years, the foundation has been involved in legal disputes over its authentication process for works whose owners said they were by Warhol.

title: Listeria Outbreak Traced to Cantaloupe Packing Shed

title: A Couple of Good Bands Buoy CMJs Opening Night
description: The first day of the CMJ Music Marathon is for lowering expectations. Im spoiled because most of the shows I hear during the year are by bands that have already gotten somewhere  even if its only to an opening-act slot with some indie-label pals  and are playing clubs that expect people to listen. The beauty and aggravation of CMJ is that its a plunge into the lower echelons, the ones triaged out of my usual schedule. This is the province of peculiar club layouts, blaringly murky sound systems and disheveled guys in yesterdays T-shirt poking at their keyboard and mixer, wishing they were Erasure circa 1989. I start to wonder if the next five days are going to be like that.

description: Evanescence, a gothic-flavored alternative rock band, made a big splash in the early 2000s. Now the band has returned to the top of the music charts with its first new album in five years, although the sales are far from the blockbuster numbers of its  and the music industrys  heyday.

Simon Cowell and Co. once again led the network to an overall victory in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and against Tuesday competition, The X Factor posted better 18-to-49 ratings than its previous Sunday and Thursday installments while drawing an average of 10.1 million total viewers.

My friends and I copied songs from each others digital music libraries and occasionally rifled through albums in indie record stores to unearth beloved oldies like Le Tigre and Sam Cooke.

title: Frieze Frame | Ida Ekblads Ruckus
description: Ida Ekblad is at once a sculptor, painter, video maker and poet. Her motley creations  crude and polished, blithe and bold  offer perspectives on modern art and culture, with and without a capital M. Her sculpture reaches back to beatific tropes of postwar art history, which she solders together with the harsh trash of todays world: industrial materials (scrap metal is a favorite) collected from streets and junkyards. Her paintings marry similar sentiments, committing the intangible debris of brutish shapes and colors to canvas.

title: Officials Renew Call for U.S. Review of Stop and Frisk Policy

title: TV Chat: Ask the Critics
description: This week, the critic Mike Hale took a look at a spate of major cast changes in prime time and came up with a report card on how the shows  Two and a Half Men, CSI, The Office, Law & Order: SVU and House  are handling the new characters. Only CSI got an A, while Two and a Half Men received a cringe-worthy D. But the critic Neil Genzlinger says he actually enjoys the Ashton Kutcher version of Men. How would you grade the shifts? Then theres The X Factor, which is doing well with the 18-to-49 demographic but not with Mr. Genzlinger, who has some issues. Is there any reality in that reality competition or is Simon Cowell orchestrating everything? And what to make of the American Academy of Pediatrics warning, yet again, that parents should limit the amount of time infants and toddlers spend in front of the television screen? Are you suffering the effects of too much TV watching as a baby? You asked and the critics answered your questions:

title: Spring Ahead | White
description: A snapshot of springs best trends and a hint at what youll want to wear next year.
