description: Libyan revolutionary forces fought building by building against the final pocket of resistance in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis hometown, Surt.

title: Curbside at School, a Red Carpet
description: IN the West Village, a stunningly decked-out woman is nothing unusual. But Rose Cameron still managed to turn heads in the neighborhood recently, with her long black hair and full-length fur coat. Perhaps it was because she wasnt leaving Bar Pitti at midnight, but exiting the Little Red School House after dropping off her child. The time: 8:30 a.m.

title: Here Come the (Stylish) Grooms
description: ON the evening of June 24, in Paris, mens fashion writers sat down for the spring Givenchy show at the Pompidou Center. Chairs had been arranged in the street-level lobby, and by the time the show began  an arrow of scowling men in bird of paradise prints  an audience had formed outside the windows as well.

title: U.S. Denies Iran Claims That Saudi Plot Defendant Belongs to Exile Group
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials on Wednesday denied Iranian news reports that a man charged in a plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to the United States is actually an agent of an exiled Iranian opposition group.

title: Controlling Her Voice, and Her World
description: Nika Roza Danilova, the singer who performs as Zola Jesus, seems single-minded, and her show on Tuesday night at the Knitting Factory was a unity. She had written the songs and programmed the synthesizers, played by three musicians, which blended thickly together over a drummers dry tribal rhythms. Her body language, except for basic bobbing, was arm and hand movements to signify her voices rising tones and crescendos.

title: The Other Zuckerberg
description: WHO wants a tequila shot? Randi Zuckerberg shouted over the thump of Baby One More Time, Britney Spearss breakup anthem.

title: Facebook Changes Inspire More Grumbling
description: Facebook recently redesigned its site, moving things around and adding new elements. Of course, Facebook frequently fiddles with its features, and these fixes frequently infuriate its fans.

title: A Brazen Scheme to Win The Daughter of a Count
description: The great maestro Riccardo Muti is like the butterfly in chaos theory: when he beats his baton in Europe, an opera gets performed throughout the world. In 1999 Mr. Muti revived Giovanni Paisiellos long-neglected Nina. The next thing you know it has two DVD recordings and is being put on at American conservatories.

title: Tracking Your Cars Performance (or Lack of It) by Phone
description: As a kid, I spent hours poring over my dads Road & Track magazines, memorizing performance statistics and fantasizing about Porsche Turbos.

title: An Outspoken Elder, Very Now
description: MODERN-DAY Marimekko specializes in what your average HGTV design-show host calls pops of color. How about a big flower arrangement, hand-painted, erupting all over your dress? Some blue and black tiger-striped bedsheets? Bright lunchboxes for your wee ones with elephants on them?

title: Phone Stunt Seeks Box-Office Numbers
description: When it comes to publicizing movies, a lot of stars do as little as possible: a perfunctory wave from a red carpet, a chat with Jay Leno. Then there is what Jonah Hill is doing to promote The Sitter, an R-rated comedy set for release on Dec. 9. Mr. Hill, last seen as a statistics nerd in Moneyball, is so eager to make The Sitter a success  its his first film as a solo headliner  that he agreed to an unusual request from Foxs marketing team. Fox hung posters across the country printed with Mr. Hills image, the message Need a Sitter? and phone numbers on tear-off tabs, above. About 250,000 people called, and nearly half left messages. Here comes the unusual part: Mr. Hill agreed to carry around the phone belonging to that number and randomly answer calls himself. A Fox spokesman said Mr. Hill had answered a few dozen times. On Wednesday he began returning calls. Mr. Hill, who plays an unprepared baby sitter, also recorded messages for robo-returned calls. Your voice sounds like a cat that was strangled with a pack of menthols, one version says in part. Call me back. What did Mr. Hill have to say about the gimmick? Fox said he was unavailable to come to the phone.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Oct. 20
description: Leather skirts, derby boots, and a peppy new boutique.

title: Old Shows, New Faces, Big Risks
description: While the seasons new television shows battle for survival, like baby turtles scurrying across the beach  five of them are gone already, picked off by the bad-ratings bird  theres an equally important but more quiet drama going on in prime time.

title: One Month, Too Much Fashion
description: HERE is a question that has yet to be addressed in the debate over the scheduling of fashion shows next September: Would it be such a bad thing if designers in Milan went head-to-head with designers in New York and London?

title: When Schubert Shouts Softly
description: When a musician programs a composers late works, its hard to imagine that those pieces were mostly written while the composer was still in his 20s. But the autumnal masterpieces of Schubert, who died at 31, are indeed the efforts of a young man.

title: The mobile-search market; a streaming service for British TV shows; tech news.
description: Claire Cain Miller of The Times discusses the emerging market for mobile search services and how people tend to use search engines differently on their phones compared to sitting in front of a computer. Miguel Penella, the chief executive of the Acorn Media Group, explains how his companys Acorn TV video-streaming service is bringing in a new American audience for British television shows. The weekly news roundup notes the memorial for Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, as well as the passing of audio pioneer Edgar Villchur; Research in Motions free-apps apology to its customers; and the return of a few iconic product designs. The Tip of the Week looks at ways to post to social-media sites by using text messages.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: Consumer Unit for Seniors Draws a Famous Name
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has recruited a famous name: Hubert Humphrey.

title: A Hit Makers Life and Lyrics
description: The venerable musician and record producer Nile Rodgers, wearing a bandanna tied around his dreadlocks, fade-out sunglasses and a charcoal-gray pinstripe jacket, arrived at Cafe Luxembourg right on schedule one morning last week.

title: Grease Is the Word ... Again
description: THE models at the September N. Hoolywood show were turned out as various early 1960s male archetypes, all with Brylcreem coifs. College nerds, sharkskin-suited flimflam men and West Side Story street toughs in high waters were well represented. But the leader of the pack was the greaser, in all of his popped-collar glory.

title: The Tippler
description: THE after-work scene at the Tippler, a new tavern under the Chelsea Market, is nothing if not civilized. Thirty-somethings in blazers and oxfords (for the guys) and skirts and ballet flats (for the girls) mingle over oysters and handmade cocktails, presumably discussing the goings-on at their respective advertising agencies or Web startups.

title: Putting the Winds in the Spotlight
description: Chamber works for wind instruments arent exactly rare, yet even the best of the lot turn up infrequently outside concerts mounted by dedicated wind ensembles. Among most chamber-music presenters the care and feeding of string players can seem to be paramount. Hearing any one of the four strong pieces the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening would have been a treat for wind fanciers; hearing them all was a feast.

title: The Paint Doctor Is In
description: IT begins simply enough. The living room needs a new coat of paint, perhaps a fresh start for both of you. But what about something different this time? No more off-white. Maybe a color that is bold and creative, but also educated, witty and ironic.

title: The Sniping of Partisans, This Time on the Screen
description: LOS ANGELES  At a film festival in Toronto last month, the Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein tried to bait Michele Bachmann, the Republican presidential contender, into joining him for an Iowa premiere of Butter, in which the conservative lead character looks suspiciously like a parody of Ms. Bachmann.

title: Swapping Girls Night Out for a Workout
description: JUST after 2 p.m. on a September Saturday, the heavy drinking began at Alyson Lucks bachelorette party.

title: Release Date of Bin Laden Film May Change
description: LOS ANGELES  The fuss over whether Sony Pictures and the filmmakers Mark Boal and Kathryn Bigelow were playing politics when they scheduled their hunt-for-Bin Laden film for release on Oct. 12, shortly before next years presidential election, may soon be irrelevant. Sony is planning to move the as-yet untitled film until after the election, according to two people who were briefed on the studios plans. Both said the picture is now virtually certain to appear after the election, and might not be released until early in 2013.

title: The Road to Hell, Paved With Telemarketers
description: By any definition of the word decency its been a long time since Chuck Palahniuk wrote a decent book. His lurid recent efforts, from Snuff (pornography) to Tell-All (movie-star gossip) to Pygmy (broken English from teenage foreign terrorists), have tried the patience of even his most die-hard fans. These books have been skimpy and tired enough to suggest that this Fight Club author has had all the fight drained out of him. But he shows new signs of life in Damned, a book full of tastelessly hilarious gallows humor about a teenage girl in hell.

title: Lens: Tim Hetherington
description: Lens: Tim Hetherington

title: N.B.A. Lockout Creating Uncertainty for U.S. Olympic Team
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  If the N.B.A. lockout continues, it will have a significant impact on preparations for the 2012 Olympics, Mike Krzyzewski said Wednesday. Krzyzewski, the United States national team coach, and Jerry Colangelo, the USA Basketball chairman, have discussed the matter, he said, although the uncertainty is making it impossible to plan ahead.

title: That Man Smells Familiar
description: AS nostalgia for the early 1960s persists, a handful of mens fragrances from that period are getting a second look.

title: Beauty Spots
description: October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and cosmetics companies are rallying for the cause.

title: How Does It Feel to Adapt Dylans Songs for a Cabaret Setting?
description: It may sound outlandish: a British female cabaret singer interpreting Bob Dylan accompanied by a piano instead of a guitar. But Barb Jungr, a fearless iconoclast who dives into the deepest waters of popular song to wrest exotic treasure from the ocean floor, delivered a fiery personal tutorial on Mr. Dylan at Tuesdays opening-night performance of her show Man in the Long Black Coat at the Metropolitan Room.

title: Newly Released
description: This months new fiction is not for the fainthearted. There are stonings in two books, while bodies drop in all but one. And Howard Jacobsons humor, in the one homicide-free offering, proves to be no less savage.

title: What Makes Free Will Free?
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: U.S. Benefits for Retirees to Rise 3.6% Next Year
description: WASHINGTON  Social Security recipients will get a 3.6 percent increase in benefits next year to help keep up with inflation, the first such cost-of-living adjustment in three years, the government announced Wednesday.

title: Stories Come to Life in Sound and Silence
description: Cheerful stories can be fun, but angry tales are fascinating. Thats never more apparent than in Beyond Words, a collection of sketches presented by Bill Bowers in both mime and monologue. At his nicest Mr. Bowers is a pleasant fellow relating mildly amusing yarns. Yet when he ventures into darker territory, this one-man show comes alive.

title: A House That Flows Into the Outdoors
description: In Key West, a hurricane-wrecked home is rebuilt as a private refuge.

title: A Key West House Built by a Storm
description: IN October 2005, when Hurricane Wilma ripped through the Florida Keys, Kathy Houtzs 1,000-square-foot house on Key Haven, a community just east of Key West, was practically destroyed. It was the biggest trauma I had ever been through, she said.

title: Letters
description: Opinions on Makeup

title: Market Ready
description: Q. My apartment has very little closet space. Should I add storage before I put it on the market?

title: Sales at Kartell, Blu Dot and Others
description: Display pieces, prototypes and discontinued furniture and accessories will be up to 70 percent off at De La Espada, Oct. 22 to 30 (the Atlantico tall sideboard, originally $4,715 to $5,035, will be $3,300 to $3,525); 33 Greene Street (Grand Street), (212) 625-1039 or delaespada.com.

title: Piet Hein Eek Designs at the Future Perfect
description: It was nearly a decade ago that the Dutch designer Piet Hein Eek flashed onto the scene, one in a line of stellar graduates of the Design Academy Eindhoven. For his thesis project, Mr. Eek had retooled the environmentally friendly ethos of reduce, reuse, recycle, using fine cabinetmaking techniques to transform wood scrap into high-style designs.

title: Bored With White Tableware? Call John Derian
description: Astier de Villatte, the French company known for delightfully imperfect white ceramic tableware, is adding color and graphics to its dishes, a result of a collaboration with John Derian. After almost 15 years, we were doing almost only white ceramics, said Ivan Pericoli, one of the founders of Astier de Villatte in 1996. It seemed natural to us, when we wanted to add images, to ask John, because he has a sensibility about color that is really close to ours.

title: Mxyplyzyks New Store in Jersey City
description: Mxyplyzyk has proved to be a survivor in a less-than-ideal retail climate: the home furnishings shop has occupied the same space in the West Village for nearly a decade. Last week, Kevin Brynan, who owns the store with his partner, Bill Cleary, opened a second one in Jersey City.

title: A New Magazine for Contemporary Cultivators
description: Wilder Quarterly, a gardening magazine being introduced on Monday, targets a new generation of growers and urban farmers.

title: With Open Doors, and Weary Ears
description: BUILD it, and they will come. Someone built it long before we were born, around 1900. All we did was buy this house in southern Maine, but we soon found: they will come. At the halfway mark from New York City to Mount Desert, which draws them like Chaucers Canterbury Cathedral, they will be excited that half their journey is behind them.

title: Reflections on the Israel-Hamas Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Stop-Motion Takes On New Meaning
description: Part travelogue, part pseudo-documentary self-portrait, part fable of Tinseltown disillusionment  and these are just the bad parts  Glitch in the Grid is so professionally ill-advised and personally unflattering that its almost painful to think about.

title: Religion and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Ed Koch, on 4 Mayors
description: To the Editor:

title: John Portman, Symphonic Architect
description: In the 1960s, the architect John Portman began transforming the Atlanta skyline, first with his Merchandise Mart and then, in 1967, with the famed Hyatt Regency Hotel. Considered the first modern atrium-style hotel, it had glass elevators, lighted columns and cascading fountains that created a fizzy extravaganza of space and light, or what the former New York Times architecture critic Herbert Muschamp called architecture at happy hour.

title: Biden Visits Capitol Hill to Rally Support for Jobs Legislation
description: 10:47 p.m. | Updated Back on his old stomping grounds at the Senate on Wednesday afternoon, Vice President Joseph R. Biden, Jr. outlined dire consequences if Republicans blocked a $35 billion piece of President Obamas jobs bill.

title: Seeking Taxis at Rush Hour
description: To the Editor:

title: A Disaster for Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex Charges Dropped After Victim Recants Identification
description: The New York Police Department on Wednesday dropped sex crime charges against one of two men charged in a series of sexual attacks in Brooklyn after a victim recanted her identification of the suspect, the police said.

title: Automated Stock Trading
description: To the Editor:

title: Google Announces New Data Visualization Tools for Analytics
description: In the early 1900s, John Wanamaker, a political figure and well-known merchant, coined one of the most famous quotes about advertising: Half the money I spend on advertising is wasted. The trouble is, I dont know which half.

title: Cardinals Take Game 1 of World Series
description: ST. LOUIS  After making a record 28 pitching changes in the N.L.C.S., Tony La Russa pulled the right levers with his bullpen on Wednesday night, making five more changes. They all went his way, and so the Cardinals took the first game of the 107th World Series, 3-2, in front of 46,406 at Busch Stadium. Read David Waldsteins full story here.

title: Meet Me at the Plaza
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Euro, Meant to Unite Europe, Seems to Rend It
description: PARIS  The euro was a political project meant to unite Europe after the Soviet collapse in a sphere of collective prosperity that would lead to greater federalism. Instead, the euro seems to be pulling Europe apart.

title: M.C. Hammer Announces WireDoo, a Search Start-Up
description: Among the technology entrepreneurs announcing new products at the Web 2.0 Summit in San Francisco, there was an unlikely guest: M.C. Hammer, the rapper.

title: Benefit in Radiation After Breast Cancer Surgery
description: Radiation treatment after surgery for breast cancer significantly lowers the risk that the disease will recur in the breast or spread lethally to other parts of the body over the next 10 to 15 years, researchers say.

title: A Championship Uppercut
description: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands  After 11 of the 21 rounds here Wednesday, five of the six American teams are in the top eight in their event. The last team, U.S.A-1 in the dOrsi Senior Bowl, is ninth, only 3.5 victory points behind eighth. In each event  Venice Cup, Bermuda Bowl and dOrsi Senior Bowl  the top eight qualify for the quarterfinals, starting Sunday.

title: Excerpt: 'House'
description: Charlyne Yi and Odette Annable star as new doctors on Houses team.

title: The Indoor Tree: A Tall, Green Slip of Summer
description: ADELE HAEG, age 6, looks adorable with bangs. Just not the bangs my daughter cut into Adeles long, straight hair last spring after the two sneaked into the bathroom with a pair of safety scissors. In my daughters defense, she got the idea from Betsy-Tacy and Tib, a wholesome (read: deviant) childrens book from the 1940s. As copycat barbering accidents go, I suppose, it could have been worse. Im keeping my girl away from Sweeney Todd.

title: Luongos Gambling Goes Off Ice
description: Vancouver Canucks goalie Roberto Luongo has been accused more than a few times of gambling while in net.

title: Love and Pain in Swaziland
description: The cheerleaders say it all.

title: Excerpt: 'CSI'
description: Ted Danson joined the CBS procedural this season.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Search Engines for Phones
description: How do people use search engines on mobile devices compared to those on computers? On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk podcast, Claire Cain Miller, a Times technology reporter in Silicon Valley, discusses how behavior differs. She also explains how advertisers are adapting to search-on-the-go, and how Google came to its early dominance of the mobile-search market.

title: Excerpt: Law & Order: SVU
description: Danny Pino, above with Mariska Hargitay, plays one of two new detectives on the procedural.

title: Not Much Basketball Talk at Big East Media Day
description: Notre Dames Mike Brey stood in a corner of an ornate banquet room on the ninth floor at the New York Athletic Club on Wednesday morning and attempted to talk about the Big East basketball season, even though few people seemed to be asking about it.

title: Barbara Kent, Star of Silent Movies, Dies at 103
description: Barbara Kent, one of the last surviving stars of silent films, who performed alongside Gloria Swanson, Greta Garbo and Harold Lloyd, died last Thursday in Palm Desert, Calif. She was 103.

title: Film Executive to Head San Francisco Society
description: Bingham Ray, a veteran indie film executive who helped get movies like Hotel Rwanda and Bowling for Columbine on the screen, has been named executive director of the San Francisco Film Society, the society said on Wednesday. The appointment puts Mr. Ray in charge of an organization that, among other things, runs the San Francisco International Film Festival. And it fills a post that has been vacant since Graham Leggat, the previous director, died in August. Recently Mr. Ray had been working with Lincoln Center as a consultant to its film program; with SnagFilms, for which he was scouting movies; and with New York Universitys Tisch School of the Arts, where he has been an adjunct professor. Too good to be true is how Mr. Ray described his appointment in a statement.

title: Hurry-Up Offense: Palmer Gets Going With Raiders
description: The Carson Palmer era in Oakland was just hours old when the speculation began as to how soon he would make his first appearance in silver and black. Coach Hue Jackson has delighted in stonewalling the news media, and Palmer himself, while saying all the right things  Come Sunday, Im going to do whatever they ask me to do could not help but look overwhelmed.

title: Big British Hedge Fund Takes Aim at the States
description: Founded 230 years ago near the banks of the Thames, the Man Group has transformed itself from a British barrel maker to a rum merchant to a $70 billion money manager dominant in Europe and Asia.

title: Islamist Imagines a Democratic Future for Tunisia
description: ISTANBUL  For more than three decades, Rachid al-Ghannouchi has preached that pluralism, democracy and Islam are harmonious. As his country, Tunisia, heads toward the first elections after the Arab revolts on Sunday, Mr. Ghannouchi, a renowned Islamic thinker, faces a reckoning between his principles and intentions.

title: Olympus Faces Credibility Gap
description: Olympus shares will probably languish until it comes up with some answers. The Japanese manufacturer fired its chief executive, Michael Woodford, last week and has since acknowledged effectively paying two advisers a 35 percent commission for a British acquisition in 2008. While its core business looks sound, the fear is that Olympus could be forced to take big write-downs or even delist.

title: Mitt and Begonia-gate
description: Oh, wow! Rick Perry hit Mitt Romney with the illegal immigrant landscapers!

title: Bloggingheads: Angry, Indebted Grads
description: Benjy Sarlin, left, of Talking Points Memo and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate about Occupy Wall Street and student loan debt.

title: Fitting In Exercise, Between Math and English
description: Five years ago, Richard Reiss, the physical education teacher at Public School 197 in Far Rockaway, Queens, went to the principal with a problem: not even the most athletic among his students, most of whom are poor and black or Latino, had enough endurance to run a mile.

title: L.S.U. Suspends 3 Players for Game Against Auburn
description: Top-ranked Louisiana State will be without its two best players for Saturdays game against Auburn, according to multiple reports.

title: After Arrests in Park Known for Sex, Cases Are Sealed, but Names Are Released
description: With its densely wooded trails and easy access, Saxon Woods, a county park in White Plains, had become widely known on Web sites catering to men interested in anonymous gay sex.

title: Some Cheer Border Fence as Others Ponder the Cost
description: In the debate over immigration among the Republican presidential candidates, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota signed a pledge last week to build double-fencing the entire length of the 2,000-mile border with Mexico.

title: In Bleak 70s, Salvo of Protest
description: OCCUPY WALL STREET, the protest encampment at Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, has many historical inspirations. After all, the tactic of sitting down and refusing to move was used by angry veterans marching on Washington in the early Depression years, striking automobile workers in the late 1930s and civil rights protesters in the 1960s. But there is a local precedent, one that few people remember today: the sit-ins and occupations that followed New York Citys deep budget cuts in 1975 and 1976.

title: Not Guilty of Murder; Facing $1 Million Bail
description: A Queens woman who killed her husband, shooting him 11 times, but was acquitted of murder, will be eligible again for release on $1 million bail, according to a court order issued on Wednesday.

title: Shopping for Camp Blankets and Throws
description: Tyler Hays, the founder and head designer of BDDW Furniture in SoHo, searched for blankets.

title: Camp Blankets and Throws
description: IF hes known at all, Tyler Hays is known as the founder and head designer of BDDW Furniture, the high-end furnishings store in SoHo. As it happens, Mr. Hays, 43, is also a painter and a sculptor, but he has managed to remain relatively anonymous while attracting a sizable following for his design work.

title: They Turn On the Power
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  The play that best encapsulates the revival of Stanfords football team, which has gone from 1-11 in 2006 to a national title contender in 2011, is called 97 Power. Right guard David DeCastro pulls hard to his left to bulldoze a linebacker, and left tackle Jonathan Martin, known as Moose, blocks a defensive end to clear the way for a simple inside running play.

title: Perry Says He Backs Flat Tax, Drawing a Contrast With Romney
description: Rick Perry announced his support for a flat tax on Wednesday, sharpening the contrast with his Republican rival Mitt Romney and capitalizing on popular frustration with the tax system among Republican primary voters.

title: The Fight Over How to End a War
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An unusually powerful phalanx of President Obamas top officials, charged with organizing an orderly exit from Afghanistan, will face an outwardly confident, almost defiant Pakistan during talks that open in an atmosphere of rancor here on Thursday night.

title: Its What They Asked For
description: Alabamas new anti-immigrant law, the nations harshest, went into effect last month (a few provisions have been temporarily blocked in federal court), and it is already reaping a bitter harvest of dislocation and fear. Hispanic homes are emptying, businesses are closing, employers are wondering where their workers have gone. Parents who have not yet figured out where to go are lying low and keeping children home from school.

title: Not Their Job
description: President Obamas Council on Jobs and Competitiveness has some promising job growth ideas, including ways to speed up projects in energy and infrastructure. But the 27-member council  made up mostly of corporate executives, along with a handful of investors, labor leaders and academics  has indulged in outrageous special pleading, with its assault on Sarbanes-Oxley, the antifraud law passed in 2002 in response to Enron, WorldCom and the dot-com bust.

title: Playing Politics With Womens Lives
description: House Republicans approved an egregious measure last week that would shrink access to abortion to the point of endangering womens lives.

title: Left-Handed Specialists in the Series Are Strikingly Similar
description: ST. LOUIS  For nearly 20 years, Darren Oliver and Arthur Rhodes have shared more than just job titles as major league left-handers. Since the day in 1988 when they were drafted one round apart, their paths have run parallel, and at times intertwined, as each switched from team to team.

title: Soldiers Family Led Campaign for His Release
description: MITZPE HILA, Israel  The release of Gilad Shalit took years of delicate negotiations at the top levels of the Israeli government and the Hamas militant group. But it also required an extraordinary campaign by his parents, Noam and Aviva Shalit, to build overwhelming support among Israels people and its right-leaning government to trade more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners, some guilty of heinous terrorist killings, for their son.

title: De Blasio Pushes on Information Requests
description: The New York City public advocate, Bill de Blasio, said Wednesday that he was starting an investigation into city agencies responses to the states Freedom of Information Law requests because he was concerned that the agencies were taking too long to release public information.

title: Hastening Slowly Through Fall
description: Caterpillars have begun to appear outside my mudroom door. They look barely animate and thickly pelted, like moss creeping up the door frame in individual inches. I wonder about the feel of caterpillar fur, but some natural caution keeps me from touching them. They are a great improvement over the slugs and the millipedes that crept up the door all summer long. The slugs looked like thick, muddy drops of gelatinous rain. There is no analogy for the millipedes. I pretend not to know they are there.

title: Comments on Immigration Alienate Some Hispanics
description: Today, Republican candidates are competing over who can talk the toughest about illegal immigration  who will erect the most impenetrable border defense; who will turn off magnets like college tuition benefits.

title: Winning Is Everything, or So Says a Law Firm
description: AMONG the most derided commercials on television are those by law firms that represent victims of accidents, which often feature tough-talking lawyers promising vengeance, video of car accidents and assorted mayhem, and modest production values.

title: Piri Thomas, Spanish Harlem Author, Dies at 83
description: Piri Thomas, the writer and poet whose 1967 memoir, Down These Mean Streets, chronicled his tough childhood in Spanish Harlem and the outlaw years that followed and became a classic portrait of ghetto life, died on Monday at his home in El Cerrito, Calif. He was 83.

title: Actively Engaged
description: Remember judicial activism? Of course you do. Not so long ago, Republicans lined up to denounce President Obamas two Supreme Court nominees as judicial activists before the ink was dry on their nomination papers. Writing in The Wall Street Journal right after Sonia Sotomayors nomination in May 2009, Karl Rove advised fellow Republicans that although Judge Sotomayor would almost certainly be confirmed, Republicans should nonetheless seek to score points by making a clear case against the judicial activism she represents. The next year, Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, undeterred by the fact that Elena Kagan, never having been a judge, was hard to describe plausibly as a judicial activist, explained his vote against her confirmation by saying that Ms. Kagans record shows that she supports an activist judicial philosophy.

title: My Shrink Is My Co-Author
description: When I decided to ghost write a book with my longtime psychotherapist, colleagues said, Youre crazy.

title: New Tactics and Billions to Manage City Sewage
description: The Bloomberg administration is set to commit $2.4 billion in public and private investment to applying new environmental technology to an old problem: the flow of untreated sewage and storm water into New York Citys waterways.

title: La Russas Caring Side Shows Up in the Box Scores
description: ST. LOUIS

title: On the Day After, Moving Ahead and Looking Back
description: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza Strip  He was only one of the 477 Palestinian prisoners released by Israel in exchange for a single captive Israeli soldier. But as the welcoming celebrations wound down after the swap, many men came to a refugee camp here to pay him their highest respects.

title: Authors to Get Sales Data Online From 3 Big Publishers
description: Three major publishers said on Wednesday that they would allow their authors to access book sales data directly online, a move that appeared to challenge Amazon and its continued efforts to woo authors.

title: Lottery Numbers
An Ordinary Football Game, Then a Player Dies
description: PHOENIX, N.Y.  Football coaches and school administrators at John C. Birdlebough High School congregated in a small room off the library Monday, huddling around a computer for a most painful and unusual review of game video. They examined every play that one student was involved in, assuming the role of medical examiners.

title: Westchester Man Killed His Wife and Children Before Shooting Himself, Police Say
description: CROSS RIVER, N.Y.  Late in the spring, Samuel Friedlander, by appearances a successful lawyer, seemed distraught to Kenneth Novenstern, who was representing Mr. Friedlander in his divorce from his wife, Amy.

title: Occupy the Classroom
description: Occupy Wall Street is shining a useful spotlight on one of Americas central challenges, the inequality that leaves the richest 1 percent of Americans with a greater net worth than the entire bottom 90 percent.

title: Norman Corwin, Pioneer of Radio, Dies at 101
description: Norman Corwin, one of the last living links to radios golden age, a producer and dramatist whose innovative use of sound effects and unusual narrative devices attracted new audiences to serious programming, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 101.

title: Silver Lake Group Considers Yahoo Bid
description: Potential groups of bidders for Yahoo are continuing to emerge, as suitors keep circling the faltering Internet giant.

title: Mediator in N.B.A. Talks Has Strong Sports Pedigree
description: George H. Cohen, the federal mediator who is seeking to coax, cajole and occasionally strong-arm the N.B.A. and its players into ending their 112-day showdown, would seem to have an ideal pedigree for the role.

title: Thursday: Day Four of the Crossword Contest
description: Administrivial Heads Up for Friday! The Friday, Oct. 21 crossword puzzle will be available at the normal time and place, but it will have a format that will not be available in Across Lite. However, we will be offering a PDF version that you will need to print out to solve. That version will be available here on Thursday, Oct. 20 at 10 p.m. Eastern time.

title: Bad Blood Between Perry and Romney Is Longstanding
description: WASHINGTON  The hostilities flaring between Mitt Romney and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas have been steadily rising inside both camps and may signal a new, more combative phase in the Republican presidential campaign.

title: Parking Rules in New York City
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzeret and Simhat Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Perry to Pay Jet Owners Higher Rate After Questions About Use
description: Gov. Rick Perrys presidential campaign said Wednesday that it would reimburse owners of private jets an amount in the five figures one day after facing questions about whether it underpaid for using jets owned by wealthy donors, which could mean that the campaign may have received large, unreported in-kind contributions barred by federal election law.

title: French First Lady Gives Birth to a Girl
description: PARIS  Frances first lady, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, gave birth to a girl on Wednesday evening. She is the first baby born to a modern-day French president while in office, the newspaper Le Figaro reported.

title: Its Football Weather, but Series Teams Will Adjust
description: ST. LOUIS  Several games this October have been affected by rain, forcing managers to scramble and fiddle with their rotations.

title: Sanchez and Burress Cram for Chemistry
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  There was a talented receiver, a flashy free-agent pickup, who was slowed by injuries that first training camp. His viability was questioned, as was how quickly he could establish a groove with his new quarterback.

title: At Front of Brooklyn Bus, a Clash of Religious and Womens Rights
description: It does not take long to recognize that the B110 bus in Brooklyn is not like others in the city.

title: Matthew G. Martinez, Ex-Democratic Lawmaker, Dies at 82
description: Matthew G. Martinez, a former representative from the Los Angeles area who drew attention in 2000 when, as a party-line Democrat, he angrily switched to the Republican Party for his last months in office after being defeated in a primary, died Oct. 15 at his home in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 82.

title: Theres Nothing Like a Super PAC for the Serious Contender
description: Herman Cain has a pop in the polls and the full attention of the political class, and now hes got a super PAC, too.

title: Prayers for Tibetans Who Immolated Themselves Denounced by China
description: The top two leaders of Tibets government-in-exile publicly prayed on Wednesday for the nine Tibetans who have immolated themselves over the past seven months to protest Chinas Tibet policies, provoking an angry response from Beijing, where a government spokeswoman called the prayers a promotion of terrorism.

title: Stalemate Remains on Collecting Blood Samples for H.G.H. Testing
description: Nearly two months after it had hoped to start blood testing for human growth hormone, and several days after two Congressmen announced there was a deal to begin collecting blood samples immediately, the N.F.L. and its players union remained at a standstill on Wednesday over the program.

title: France: Writer Says She Wont Sue Strauss-Khan
description: Tristane Banon, the French writer who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of trying to rape her eight years ago, said she would not pursue a civil case against him, after French prosecutors recently declined to charge him with attempted rape. Last week, prosecutors said they could not bring a case against him, given a three-year statute of limitations for sexual assault, but they said there was evidence that he had sexually assaulted Ms. Banon. On Wednesday, Ms. Banon said she would not pursue a suit because the case had proved that she was not a liar.

title: Its a Girl for the French Presidential Couple
description: Cest une fille!

title: Cards Maneuver Their Way to a Win
description: ST. LOUIS  The formula that helped Tony La Russa lead the St. Louis Cardinals to victory in the National League Championship Series proved to be just as viable in the World Series.

title: World Series Replay: Game 1
description: St. Louis hosted the opener and the Cardinals got off to a good start, beating the Texas Rangers, 3-2.

title: The Ghazal
description: I created this drink, which is named after the ancient Persian poetic form, to pair with Middle Eastern snacks. Rosewater enhances the cucumber-and-rose infusion in Hendricks gin. A good measure of fresh lime juice brightens it up with acidity, and mint adds more flavor.

title: The Classic Martini
description: Kingsley Amis and Churchill could hardly stand the stuff, but a little extra vermouth goes a long way.

title: Paillards 10 Ways
description: Chicken Scaloppine al Limone (See below for variations of this recipe.)

title: The Vesper
description: Gin or vodka? The Vesper  which first appeared in Ian Flemings novel Casino Royale  lets you have it both ways. Lillet stands in for its close cousin, dry vermouth. I normally stir rather than shake, but, in this case, I defer to James Bond.

title: Rush to Drill for Natural Gas Creates Conflicts With Mortgages
description: As natural gas drilling has spread across the country, energy industry representatives have sat down at kitchen tables in states like Texas, Pennsylvania and New York to offer homeowners leases that give companies the right to drill on their land.

title: For the Perfect Martini, Wetter Is Better
description: The most memorable martini Ive ever had was made at the bar in the Merchant Hotel in Belfast, by a charming young man named Luke. I requested it with Beefeater, straight up with a twist, and asked him not to be shy with the vermouth. As I watched Luke stir the drink patiently and rhythmically, then produce a diminutive coupe glass from the freezer, I sensed that the martini would be sublime. Expert execution is one thing, but an elegant setting and a genial bartender made my martini add up to more than the sum of its parts. A flawless cocktail fashioned by an imperious mixologist in a bar where people dont talk to one another is no fun at all.

title: Taking a Pounding
description: There are a number of reasons to pound a piece of meat madly before cooking it, though not all of them make sense.

title: Word of the Day | unravel
description: unravel \n-ra-vl\ verb

title: Radwanska Slip Gives Bartoli Hope
description: Having just won the two biggest titles of her career back-to-back in Tokyo and Beijing, Agnieszka Radwanska needed just one more win to qualify directly for the year-end WTA Championships for the first time in her career.

title: NYT Front Page for 10/20/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 10/20/2011

title: Warning by States as Tax Revenues Fail to Rebound
description: The warning by the State of Washingtons economist was unusually blunt, a far cry from the kind of dry, green-eyeshade language that often cloaks such announcements: We are in the fragile aftermath of the Great Recession, where a return to normalcy seems like a mirage in the desert  the closer we get to it, the further it moves away.

title: Knot of Worry Tightens for Fishermen
description: SEATTLE  The scientist in Canada got the results from a respected lab and held a news conference. The ice and bait man at a fish processor in Sitka, Alaska, heard the news on Facebook. Vardon Tremain read it in the newspaper while working on his trolling boat docked here in Salmon Bay.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
description: The Finance Ministry finally admitted what every economist, stockbroker and reader of the business pages has long suspected: Indias growth rate will likely fall short of 8 percent this year. The global slowdown, rising oil and commodity prices and rising interest rates are to blame, Pranab Mukherjee, Indias finance minister, said Wednesday. The lower expectations will have a major impact on the best-case-scenario budget presented earlier this year, which assumed the treasury would overflow with the proceeds of a white-hot economy (Mint).

title: Corrections: October 20
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Texas Courthouse Break-In Seen as Prank
description: SAN ANTONIO  Five young men were arrested early Wednesday morning in connection with a break-in at the Bexar County Courthouse here that raised fears of a terror plot but appeared instead to be a prank.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,471 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,795 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:

title: Pujolss Defense and Carpenters St. Louis Legacy
description: ST. LOUIS  It didnt quite get a star on my scoresheet because the ball was not hit all that hard. But the play Albert Pujols made on Michael Young to end the top of the sixth inning of Game 1 was impressive just the same. Pujols ranged to his left, across the first base line, and tossed to pitcher Chris Carpenter covering first for the out.

title: On Bus Tour, Obama Promotes Jobs  and Himself
description: President Obama wrapped up a three-city bus tour to states that could prove to be a struggle to hold onto in the 2012 election.

title: Pennsylvania: Second Woman Arrested in Case of Mentally Disabled Captives
description: The Philadelphia District Attorneys Office said it had charged the daughter of Linda Weston, the woman arrested and accused of holding four mentally disabled adults captive and stealing their Social Security checks, as a participant in the crime. The daughter, Jean McIntosh, 32, lived in the building where the four people were found over the weekend, and is being charged by prosecutors as a co-conspirator in the kidnapping and imprisonment.

title: Living Like the Other Half
description: Three weeks ago, two city-bred, upper-class aspiring entrepreneurs from Bangalore embarked on a mission: learn more about India, by subsisting for a month on what the average Indian does  just 100 rupees ($2.04) a day.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 20, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, A Ballet Star Leaps Into the Unknown.

title: Oct. 20, 1973 | Nixon Tries to Stop Investigation With Saturday Night Massacre
description: On Oct. 20, 1973, in the so-called Saturday Night Massacre, President Richard M. Nixon abolished the office of special Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox, and accepted the resignation of Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson and fired Deputy Attorney General William B. Ruckelshaus for their refusal to fire Mr. Cox.

title: News Quiz | Oct. 20, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Exotic Animal Escape
description: WHERE were wild animals including lions, tigers, bears and wolves, set loose?

title: Amid Protests, Greece Adopts New Austerity Plan
description: ATHENS  After a day of violent demonstrations against government cutbacks, Greek Socialist lawmakers on Thursday gave their final approval to a raft of tough new austerity measures, taking a critical step toward securing crucial foreign aid and averting a default.

title: Images of Libya from a Fallen Photographer
description: Judith Hetherington sat with me a few days ago. Her son Tims death certificate had just arrived.

title: Huntsmans Warning on Too Big to Fail
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Why Do You Write?

title: U.S. Officials Deliver Warning in Pakistan Over Extremists

title: Strike at Revamped Muse dOrsay Blocks Grand Reopening
description: PARIS  A strike by workers at the Muse dOrsay postponed the long-awaited reopening of the museums newly renovated galleries on Thursday. Some 34 employees, mostly security guards, staged the walkout to protest the fact that no additional workers had been recruited at the museum despite the addition of more than 21,000 square feet of display space, a museum spokeswoman said. That decision was made amid broad government cutbacks that see retiring civil servants  including museum workers  not replaced by new hires.

title: Rhode Island: Pension Rollbacks Proposed
description: Gov. Lincoln D. Chafee and the state treasurer, Gina M. Raimondo, on Tuesday proposed scaling back pension benefits for state workers and retirees in a contentious effort to reduce roughly $7 billion in unfunded obligations. The proposal would end cost-of-living increases for now, raise the retirement age and combine traditional pensions with 401(k)-type plans to shift some of the taxpayer burden to the beneficiaries. Labor unions have threatened to challenge the changes in court should they pass the Legislature.

title: Year Later, Officers Killing Confounds Colleagues

Rock music, which was almost unheard of in Taiwan before 1987, has gained in popularity in the last 15 years as a generation of musicians who came of age under a more democratic government have looked to British and American bands, from Metallica to Radiohead, for inspiration.

To make a general observation, the small-batch roasters in the Nordic countries roast lighter than the rest of the world, and Oslo roasts lighter than the rest of the Nordic countries.

title: The Real Problem With Toddlers and TV
description: Toddlers and TV is a subject that just wont go away. KJ DellAntonia wrote about it here just last week, and this week a new recommendation issued by the American Academy of Pediatrics at the groups annual meeting in Boston has revived it again. The pediatricians said that parents should limit the amount of time their infants and toddlers spend in front of any sort of screen and reaffirmed earlier research showing that theres really no such thing as educational TV or software for very young children.

Surely the much-reviled 1 percent does not consist of plutocrats in top hats or predators in blue suits, but of human beings just like the other 99 percent of us, albeit with more money and perhaps more to answer for.

title: 36 Hours in Albuquerque
description: FREE association with Albuquerque used to yield Bugs Bunny and that airport you go through to get to Santa Fe. But New Mexicos biggest city has come into its own in recent years. Thanks to tax breaks and great scenery, the TV and film industry is booming: Joss Whedons mega-budget Avengers wrapped here this summer, and next year, Breaking Bad starts shooting its fifth season with Albuquerque as a backdrop. For visitors, the sprawl can seem daunting, but it is tempered by new bike paths. On the main drag, Central Avenue, neon signs from Route 66s heyday glow over revitalized, pedestrian-friendly neighborhoods. And along the banks of the Rio Grande, lush farmland provides a quiet oasis, not to mention heirloom beans, corn and more to feed the citys vibrant organic movement.

title: For Obama, Some Vindication of Approach to War
description: WASHINGTON  For President Obama, the image of a bloodied Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi offers vindication, however harrowing, of his intervention in Libya, where a reluctant commander in chief put strict limits on American military engagement and let NATO allies take the lead in backing the rebels.

title: Basque Separatists Halt Campaign of Violence
description: LONDON  After more than 40 years of violent struggle for independence in the traditional Basque homeland in Spain and France, the separatist group ETA declared a unilateral end to its campaign of bombings and shootings on Thursday, saying it wished to seize a historical opportunity to reach a just and democratic resolution to an age-old political conflict.

title: 100 Miles From Manhattan, Feeling Both Young and Old
description: JONAS, Pa.  Rain and a gusty headwind kept me to a half days riding on Wednesday, slowing my progress home, though Im not entirely bummed about that. Its pretty here. Im about 100 miles from Manhattan, having climbed some roller-coaster hills and wound a woodsy path through Hickory Run State Park, and I expect to cross the George Washington Bridge in the middle of the day Saturday. Yeah, its about time to be back in my own bed like a settled adult and in the newsroom like a reporter with a real job.

title: Leonard Cohen to Release a New Album Next Year

title: Dirty Jobs
description: It appears that Republican claims that they can create lots of jobs by weakening environmental regulation are keying off a study from the American Petroleum Institute (pdf). There are a lot of things to critique about this study, including the fact that it actually shows a relatively small number of energy jobs, which are then blown up by assuming a large multiplier. Funny how spending can only move money around, not increase total spending, if it comes from the government, and how the multiplier is a nonsense concept when applied to government spending, but totally valid when it involves oil companies

Hes correct, of course, in saying that theyre dying because people cant afford them, and indeed there is nothing good about that. But thats a disease, and the closing of bad restaurants is a symptom, and maybe an upside of that is that people cook the casual food that theyve been going out to eat, and then recognize the advantages of doing so.

description: New accusations of criminal wrongdoing could be lodged at News Corporation executives on Friday at the companys annual shareholder meeting in Los Angeles.

title: In Trial of Political Consultant, Jury Asks, Who Is the Victim?
description: As most lawyers would concede, trying to distill a deeper meaning from jurors questions during deliberations can be a futile exercise.

title: Afghan Gun Locker: Battlefield Ingenuity, and a Weapons Longevity
description: This year, after Western journalists poured into Libya as the civilian population took up arms and lunged into war, a line of coverage on makeshift arms production and distribution found its way into many newspapers, magazines and Web sites. The New York Times was part of this, with coverage on the anti-Qaddafi forces hasty acquisition, production and fielding of all manner of repurposed arms and the vehicles to carry them. Often these weapons were poorly used. Sometimes they were fired just as indiscriminately as the weapons fired by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis troops that NATO, in its United Nations-approved bid to protect civilians, claimed to marshal international will to stop. Some of these weapons were also instrumental in the anti-Qaddafi militias eventual success, as was visible in Misurata. (For a fuller view of many of these themes, read this report on the hidden plant in Misurata, or these explainers on the dangerous repurposing of 57-mm air-to-ground rockets or 122-millimeter Grad rockets or, in this case, the knuckleheaded firing of plainly labeled inert rockets toward Qaddafi forces in Libyas mountainous west.)

title: Opera House Lights Shine Again in St. Louis
description: The lights at the Kiel Opera House in St. Louis went dark after a philharmonic performance in 1991. Unused for years, the theater reopened on Oct. 1 as the Peabody Opera House, after undergoing a $78 million restoration that began in July 2010.

title: Manager Cites Virus as Reason for Stars Withdrawal from Mets Siegfried
description: The illness that has forced has forced the tenor Gary Lehman to withdraw from the title role in the Metropolitan Operas production of Siegfried, the third installment in the companys new Ring cycle, is an energy-sapping virus, his manager said on Thursday.

title: Cover-Ups, Personal and Political
description: Boss, a series on Starz about a crooked Chicago mayor, is almost good, and it falls short for the same reason that the George Clooney movie Ides of March isnt good enough. Both are political thrillers that romanticize malfeasance, imbuing corruption with a sinister melodrama that defies common sense and cheapens the thrill of bad behavior.

title: Anna & Jordan
description: Anna Handzlik and Jordan Sekulow say it's as if their first date never ended.

title: Blending Hip-Hop and Heraldry
description: A FEW weeks before the opening of his first solo show, Herald, at the Marlborough Gallery in Chelsea, Rashaad Newsome rendered himself as a coat of arms.

title: Spring Ahead | Bras and Bandeaus
description: A snapshot of springs best trends and a hint at what youll want to wear next year.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Greece and England.

title: N.B.A. Talks Break Off, Threatening November Games
description: Negotiations to end the N.B.A. lockout collapsed again Thursday night, in spectacular fashion, with more acrimony, mistrust and fiery rhetoric, and despite the involvement of a federal mediator.

title: Democrat Is Attacked for Supporting Protesters
description: Its the time of year for candy corn and horror flicks, so mistaking a new web advertisement attacking Representative Steve Israel for a film trailer about socialist zombies would be understandable.

title: Swag the Mix Tape, Exclusive Video From Rashaad Newsome
description: For his debut solo exhibition at the Marlborough Gallery in Chelsea, Herald, the artist Rashaad Newsome didnt stop with framed works. Mr. Newsome, 31, a multimedia artist whose work blends contemporary hip-hop culture with the rules and designs of centuries-old heraldry, created a series of music videos  his contemporary coats of arms come to life.

title: TimesCast | Qaddafi and Hussein
description: The capture of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya on Thursday is reminiscent of Saddam Husseins capture in Iraq in 2003, with one key difference: Colonel Qaddafi was killed.

title: As Spain Faces a Possible Recession, Criticism of Its Central Bank Is Growing
description: MADRID  The Bank of Spain was seen as a beacon of rigor and caution at the start of the financial crisis. But now that the Spanish economy is facing the possibility of slipping back into recession, it is facing accusations of mishandling problems in the banking sector and being too slow to address the collapse in the real estate market.

title: An Unblushing Career of Undressing Women
description: BOSTON  Whats the difference between nude and naked? Degas and the Nude, at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, answers that question once and for all.

title: Romney Credits Libyan People for Qaddafis Demise
description: While campaigning in Iowa, Mitt Romney was asked Thursday in a radio interview with KSCJ in Sioux City about the news that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the former Libyan leader, had been killed in his hometown of Surt, and he praised the development

title: Citys Unemployment Rate Stays at 8.7%
description: Even with the return of more than 8,000 Verizon workers who had been striking, New York City did not add enough jobs last month to lower the unemployment rate, which remained at 8.7 percent, the State Department of Labor reported on Thursday.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Some might think a cemetery an odd setting for a celebration of life. That was certainly the reaction of HoSun Kang, assistant director and vice president of the Korean Traditional Music and Dance Institute, who said she hesitated when she was first approached to participate in Dancing Through the Light: An Autumn Celebration, a tour of Green-Wood Cemetery that opens this weekend.

title: Smile and Metaphor, Crossing Borough Lines
description: A squat, leafy tree, its trunk too broad to wrap your arms around, rises from a round patch of dirt at the center of the Brooklyn Museums fifth floor rotunda. Many years ago, apparently, it grew up through the body of a baby-grand piano, and now the tree is beginning to swallow the instrument the way farmland trees do the strands of wire fences. Miraculously the piano, tilted and, you would have thought, ruined, intermittently plays a mournful tune, its keys going up and down as if stroked by a poltergeist. The tune? Strange Fruit,  the elegiac ode to black victims of lynching made famous by Billie Holiday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Greece and England.

title: Where Art Is Childs Play
description: THE bar at 103 Charlton Street buzzed with excited chatter at its grand opening, as more than a dozen young Saturday revelers waited to get in. Joe Vena leaned over the black granite countertop, cheerfully taking orders with a New York bartenders consummate skill.

title: Over the River and Through the Hoods
description: THEY are hard to miss on the weekend. Some on mountain bikes or 10-speeds weave their way through hilly streets that even cars struggle to climb. The more serious ones ride in packs, wear colorful spandex suits and sit on high-end bikes made by Trek, Cervlo, Cannondale and others. They ride three and four across in the street, all but daring drivers to honk or worse.

title: Sothebys as a Gallery; an Ai Weiwei at Duke
description: BROWSE AND BUY

title: Finding Solace, Oceans From Home
description: Le Havre, named for the industrial port city in northern France where it takes place, is a tale of lower-depths solidarity, a stylized and sentimental fairy tale about the way the world might be, grounded in a frank recognition of the way it is.

title: Neighborhood Joint | WORD
description: A bookstore in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, strives to create a community of people who love literature.

title: Americans for Greater Inequality
description: As Rich Oppel and I wrote in an article today, the Republican presidential candidates have been steadily promoting flatter  and therefore more regressive  tax overhaul plans. Flatter taxes have of course always been the holy grail for many in the conservative base, but now such proposals seem to be gathering broader support, too.

title: Appointment Ends Impasse on Bank of Italy Leadership
description: ROME  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi made a surprise choice Thursday to take over as governor of the Bank of Italy next month, ending a prolonged impasse.

title: In Surt, Chronicle of a Death Foretold
description: Days before the frenzied jubilation at the capture and death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Mauricio Lima had been patiently  and persistently  working the streets of Surt. Though overseas interest had waned in recent days, his attention did not. He was close up and alongside fighters as they pursued their elusive target, and his images are suffused with a nuanced touch because of that.

title: Perry Capital Cuts Staff and Closes Hong Kong Office
description: The hedge fund Perry Capital is retrenching, according to two people with knowledge of the situation.

title: Live and Let Laugh: A Secret Agent Reloads
description: Some may wonder why Johnny English Reborn, the sequel to the 2003 James Bond spoof, Johnny English, starring Rowan Atkinson as a bumbling MI7 agent, was even made, seeing as the original earned a modest $28 million at the United States box office.

title: Amid Abortion Questions, Cain Steps Up Iowa Game
description: Questions from social conservatives about whether Herman Cain opposes abortion rights under all circumstances are arising anew after an interview Wednesday evening with CNNs Piers Morgan. The issue is simmering as Mr. Cain steps up his efforts to woo Iowas Republican caucusgoers  many conservative Christians  by recruiting a veteran operative to lead his campaign there.

title: Hugo Chvez Says His Cancer Is Gone
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela declared on Thursday that he had beaten cancer, less than five months after he stunned Venezuelans by revealing that he had undergone emergency surgery to remove a tumor while in seclusion in Cuba.

title: Johan Zoffany, Portraitist; Diaries of M. Louise Baker
description: 18TH-CENTURY PORTRAITIST

title: A View of Central Park, or 100 of Them
description: Betsy Pinover Schiff took some photographs that did not make it into her new book. Consider the ones from the apartment where the owner led her into the bedroom and told her, I dont want my wife to know about this.

title: On Our Radar: Massachusetts Leads Efficiency Rankings
description: Massachusetts edges out California for first place in the annual rankings from the Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy. California ranks second, New York is third, and Oregon, Washington, Vermont and Rhode Island tie for fourth place. [The Los Angeles Times]

title: Ghosts Go Retro in Paranormal Activity 3
description: Spoiler Alert: In Paranormal Activity 3, cameras are set up inside a house, doors mysteriously slam shut, bed sheets mysteriously move and things mysteriously go bump in the night.

title: Audit Flaws Revealed, at Long Last
description: With hindsight, we now know that auditors in 2007 should have been looking carefully at bank books.

title: Do You Know What I Mean? Probably Not
description: THE playwright David Henry Hwang has been in high demand in China in recent years  not for works like his Tony Award-winning M. Butterfly, which is essentially banned there, but because of his standing as the only son of Asia to be represented regularly on Broadway. In 2005 he was invited to Shanghai to discuss Broadway-style shows that might fill the lavish cultural centers under construction across the country. Yet Chinas appreciation for status symbols like Broadway and Mr. Hwang did not translate into understanding more mundane aspects of American life.

title: A New Jewel in Town
description: Eva Zuckerman, the designer of Eva Fehren, a new fine jewelry line, first started tinkering with jewelry while working for Mor Mor Rita, a high-end childrens brand. Women actually bought my stuff! exclaims Zuckerman, who put her Cooper Union fine arts background on hold for the opportunity to work for the jewelry designers Philip Crangi and, later, Monique Pan. Theyre such wonderful teachers, she says, crediting both mentors with instilling in her the importance of sustainable gems (like petrified wood and lapis lazuli stones) and innovative craftsmanship (seen in her delicate gold stackable bands and geometric rings and bracelets). And from the looks of her debut effort, this promising pupil gets a gold star.

title: Warhol in Washington
description: Two aspects of Andy Warhols art are on display in unalike but complementary shows in Washington.

title: Pop Rides the News Cycle
description: WASHINGTON  A pity that Andy Warhol, who died in 1987, couldnt be around for the social media century. With his penchant for terse utterance, he was born to tweet. As an avid scenester with an outsiders soul, he would have found Facebook the answer to a prayer.

title: Footnote
description: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, Mike Daiseys critically praised one-man show about the founder of Apple, will run an additional three weeks at the Public Theater before closing on Dec. 4, the Public announced.

title: Picassos Muse
description: A show at the Gagosian Gallery chronicling the years that Franoise Gilot and Pablo Picasso were lovers is one of many gallery exhibitions stirring excitement.

title: Stealing the Show
description: Shes almost 90 and still living very much in the present, quietly painting every day in her West Side studio. Yet Franoise Gilot  Picassos muse and lover and the mother of two of his children  is about to revisit her past.

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 21-27
description: Movies

title: Qaddafis End and Libyas Future
description: The lawless manner of Muammar el-Qaddafis death  he was apparently beaten, dragged and shot by a mob of armed men in the streets of Surt  is well-fitted to the lawless way he ruled his country. Like Mussolini and Ceausescu, he perished by the same sword that he lived by. We should regret the absence of the fair trial that even the worst criminal deserves, but its hard not to feel a certain mordant satisfaction at the ignominious way that one of recent historys genuine monsters passed to his reward. Thus always to tyrants

title: The Persona and the Palette
description: He had a sun in his head and a thunderstorm in his heart: these words used to describe the French painter Eugne Delacroix were memorized by Vincent van Gogh and could just as easily have been applied to van Gogh himself.

title: Microsoft Posts Gain Despite Soft PC Sales
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft said its net income rose 6 percent in its first fiscal quarter, but the companys results continued to reflect weak growth in PC sales.

title: Making a Judgment on Love
description: THE call came around 3:30 p.m. on a sultry Minnesota day. The hospice social worker, Cheryl, explained the situation in a rush. She had tried 15 judges, and all were either in court or otherwise unavailable. By chance, she had reached me directly.

title: Getting to Know a Sperm-Donor Dad
description: In November 2005, I wrote an article about two teenage girls, raised in different families, who discovered they are the genetic children of the same sperm donor. The girls, JoEllen Marsh and Danielle Pagano, met through the Donor Sibling Registry, a Web site that has connected thousands of half-siblings conceived through donor insemination.

title: Erin & Douglas
description: In this homemade video, Erin Darboven and Douglas Havlina reminisce over the phone about getting engaged at the end of their trip to the South Fork of the Salmon River in Idaho with a twisty tie ring.

title: Leigh & David
description: The second date proved to be the charm for Leigh Abrams and David Waterman.

title: Six Years After a Debilitating Stroke, Sharon Remains Responsive, His Son Says
description: JERUSALEM  Ariel Sharon, who suffered a debilitating stroke nearly six years ago while serving as prime minister of Israel and remains in a coma-like state, responds to some requests and, despite being fed intravenously, has put on weight, according to his son Gilad Sharon.

title: My Three Favorite Ghost Films
description: As a toddler, I was terrified of one of my fathers favorite movies, The Day the Earth Stood Still, directed by Robert Wise. I had no idea what the story was about; it was the imagery that overwhelmed me.

title: Moment of Truth for Red Bulls
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls have the Portland Timbers to thank for getting at least one albatross off their backs  Dwayne De Rosario  at least for now.

title: L.A. Reid Defends His X Factor Choices
description: The X Factor is, at this point in the show, supposed to be a competition between the four judges, each of whom is acting as a mentor to a group of contestants. But one of those judges, L.A. Reid, didnt exactly take the gloves off when asked about his opponents. In fact, he put the kid gloves on.

title: Earning Points, if Not Yet a Nickname
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  It would help if the Islanders top line had a catchy name. Then more people would take notice that not just John Tavares, but also his wingmen, P. A. Parenteau and Matt Moulson, are off to hot starts this season.

title: A New Director for Dallas Museum of Art
description: Maxwell L. Anderson, who has been director of the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 2006, has been named director of the Dallas Museum of Art. He succeeds Bonnie Pitman, who retired from the job in June.

title: Wikipedias Deep Dive Into a Library Collection
description: AMATEUR digital archivists and musical theater devotees are invited to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts on Saturday for a six-hour editathon, an event meant to improve Wikipedias musical-theater-related entries using the librarys special collections.

title: Surveying a Range of Riches
description: One size does not fit all at the annual International Fine Art & Antique Dealers Show, which is back at the Park Avenue Armory for a 23rd year. Unlike some other fairs at this space, this exposition doesnt try to rein in its more than 60 exhibitors  a group that includes specialists in arms and armor, fine jewelry and illuminated manuscripts among its purveyors of art and antiques.

title: RIM Faces a Naming Problem
description: OTTAWAWhile Research in Motion disappointed many analysts this week by offering relatively little specific or new information about the next generation of BlackBerry phones, it did make one announcement at a software conference. The new operating system for those phones will be named BBX.

title: Does Facebook Change Your Brain?
description: Those of you who responded to my female friendship post by diagnosing me with a whopper case of introversion were right on the mark: in fact, my neighbor, who specializes in such things, once told me that I was the most introverted person he had ever met.

title: Of Course, Shes Worried
description: My husbands closest friends have three children, each with a separate behavioral diagnosis (A.D.H.D., Aspergers, dyslexia). The mother spends a tremendous amount of time researching and navigating this world. Unfortunately, its all she talks about, in a stream of medical jargon. Worse, shes constantly relating their diagnoses to my childrens behavior. Are you worried hes on the spectrum? shell ask, when my 4-year-old spins in the backyard with a bubble wand. How should I deal with this? Stephanie, Boston

title: TimesCast | October 20, 2011
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was killed Thursday; comparing his capture with Saddam Hussein's; and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on Libya's hopeful future.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Oct. 21-27
description: Pop

title: A Bookstore and a Hub for Readers
description: Any bookstore can sell you a book. But if youre looking for a bookstore where you can find a date who shares your literary tastes, see a magic show, join a basketball league and have a cartoonist scrawl a tattoo on you with a permanent marker, the field narrows a bit.

title: Snakes, Spiders and Pit Bulls, Oh My!
description: Are they phobic, or are they our last line of defense?

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 21-27
description: Jazz

title: For a Bachelor Father, a Pad With a Pool
description: UPON finishing 10 years of active duty in the Army, Jeff Csoka lived and worked in New Jersey. Two years ago, after a divorce, he decided it was time to try city life.

title: A Search for Subsidized Housing, Simplified
description: A NEW interactive database developed by New York University lets renters and buyers track nearly all the privately held subsidized housing in New York City.

description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 21-27
description: Dance

title: All-Sibelius Program, With Insights From a Specialist
description: In a recent interview with The New York Times, Colin Davis said that what he strives for in conducting is to share a performance, not to impose one on the orchestra.

title: Rin Tin Tin: American Hero
description: Do dogs deserve biographies? In Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend, Susan Orlean answers that question resoundingly in the affirmative, while also asking a harder one: Can a dog deserve an Oscar? At the first Academy Awards, presented in 1929, the charismatic German shepherd who fought off gangs of villains in movies like Clash of the Wolves and Jaws of Steel won the vote count for best actor, but the Academy blinked, recalculated and gave the honor instead to Emil Jannings. Not that the public would have necessarily protested an Oscar for Rin Tin Tin. He is a human dog, one fan wrote to his trainer, human in the real big sense of the word. As for Jannings and his colleagues, there may have been some doubt. A few years earlier, Movie magazine ran a feature asking Are Actors People?

title: Rin Tin Tin
description: Forever

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 21-27
description: Art

title: With New Hope, Women Activists Keep Focus on Libya
description: Libyan exile Shahrazad Kablan was teaching school in Cincinnati when the uprising against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi began in her hometown, Benghazi. She put her house on the market and within weeks had moved to Qatar, where she hosted a taboo-busting show on the pro-rebel Libya TV.

title: A Stage Not Big Enough for a Legend
description: First, an apology all too relevant to the subject of this review. Earlier this week, in my review of the Suzanne Farrell Ballets season in Washington, I neglected to mention either the Kennedy Centers orchestra or its conductor, Emil de Cou. Both show standards higher than those we are used to hearing in New York; Mr. de Cou may now be the finest ballet conductor in America. I remembered them all the more wistfully on Wednesday when the Farrell company made its debut at the Joyce Theater, dancing to taped music.

title: Spare Times for Oct. 21-27
description: Around Town

title: Interest in Old Bank Is Repaid
description: AFTER several years doubling up with roommates in unsavory apartments in Manhattan, James Bilodeau, a musician who works for SiriusXM Radio, gave up his goal of living near his job and began looking for a place in the suburbs north of the city.

title: Woman Escapes a Cult but Not Her Own Past
description: As its title suggests, Martha Marcy May Marlene is a story of fractured identity, in which a young woman tries to negotiate incompatible versions of herself, all the while wondering who she really is. The film, Sean Durkins impressively self-assured debut feature, switches back and forth between two periods in its protagonists life  an indeterminate span when she is part of a cult in rural New York and the time just after her escape from the group, when she has found refuge with her older sister and brother-in-law in their rented lakeside vacation house.

title: Look of the Moment | Cara Delevingne
description: The Look: Yellow Jacket  a dramatic black and yellow look made all the more striking with a bit of silver jewelry and those strong, dark brows.

title: In Manhattan, the Hyundai Veloster Greets Its Public
description: On Wednesday night in Manhattans Chelsea Market, Hyundai opened a pop-up rec room devoted to its 2012 Veloster hatchback and the digital lifestyle of its mercurial target driver, the millennial.
