description: White

title: A Bookstore and a Hub for Readers
description: Any bookstore can sell you a book. But if youre looking for a bookstore where you can find a date who shares your literary tastes, see a magic show, join a basketball league or have a cartoonist scrawl a tattoo on you with a permanent marker, the field narrows a bit.

title: Negative Exposure for Kodak
description: At least Eastman Kodak didnt pin its latest turnaround effort on the fax machine. Just the same, as one securities analyst said, Wall Street worries that the once pre-eminent film company is jumping from one buggy whip business to another.

title: A Dance You Cant Get for a Song
description: Mill Neck

title: Theater Listings for Oct. 21-27
description: Theater

title: When the Roommate Has Four Legs
description: PEOPLE beg him a lot to let them have pets, Gregory DellAquila, the developer of a high-rent no-pet complex in Hoboken, acknowledges. They say, Oh, he or she is such a small little dog, and so well trained!

title: Public Radio Host Linked to Protest is Dismissed
description: A public radio host who was linked this week to antiwar and anti-corporate-greed protests in Washington, D.C., has been fired by one radio producer that employs her, but supported by another.

title: Knowing When to Refinance
description: REFINANCINGS made up 79 percent of all 2011 mortgage applications as of early October, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association, about the same level as last year but well above the 54 percent average of the last decade. Many of these applications have come from so-called serial refinancers in a constant search for the lowest possible interest rate.

title: New Leader Approved by Port Authority
description: The Board of Commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Thursday unanimously approved the appointment of Patrick J. Foye, to become the agencys new executive director.

title: Hipstamatic in Kabul
description: When Ben Lowy was in Afghanistan taking pictures for our article The Bad Guys vs. the Worse Guys, he did so using both his digital camera, to make traditional 35-millimeter photos, and the Hipstamatic app on his iPhone. Our plan all along had been to publish the 35-millimeter pictures, but once we saw what he had on his iPhone, we felt we had to use those images instead. They were more exciting and dynamic; the rich palette and high contrast brought clarity and texture and even poetry to the scenes.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 7s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: A Bank Lives On in Memory and Metal
description: Q. I recently bought a replica of a bank on eBay, and believe it was at the corner of Grand and Norfolk Streets. Do you have a turn-of-the-century source you could check?...

title: Senate Plan Seeks Foreigners to Spur Housing Market
description: What do you do when Americans just arent buying houses? A new bipartisan plan in the Senate offers one idea: Import people who will.

title: No Cellphone-Cancer Link in Large Study
description: A major study of nearly 360,000 cellphone users in Denmark found no increased risk of brain tumors with long-term use.

description: Behavior Issues in a Co-op

title: Edward A. Applebome
description: Mr. Applebome, 59, is the president and chief executive of AKRF, an environmental planning and engineering firm.

title: Charles M. Conlons Golden Age Baseball Photographs
description: Lens describes the process behind printing these pics, many of which were made using glass plates.

title: The gloves come off at the latest Republican debate, strong positions on illegal immigration may be cause for concern in the general election for some candidates, and exactly what is a Super PAC?
description: The gloves come off at the latest Republican debate, strong positions on illegal immigration may be cause for concern in the general election for some candidates, and exactly what is a Super PAC? Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, White House correspondent Jackie Calmes, and political correspondents Nick Confessore and Trip Gabriel join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: In Tripoli, Blaring Horns and Shouts of Joy
description: Tripoli, Libya

title: Plainclothes Officers Foil Robbery of S.I. Diner
description: Two plainclothes police officers on a meal break foiled an attempted armed robbery at an all-night diner in Staten Island early Thursday, the police said.

title: Shippers Are Jostling for Greater Global Share
description: AFTER a major retrenchment in the United States three years ago, DHL Express U.S. is repositioning itself with a new marketing campaign to persuade medium-size and smaller American companies to sign up for its international shipping expertise.

title: Privacy and Press Freedom Collide in University Case
description: It was bad enough for the University of Illinois when The Chicago Tribunes 2009 series Clout Goes to College exposed the existence of a clout list that over five years gave hundreds of well-connected students an edge in admissions, and led to the resignations of the university president, the chancellor of the flagship Urbana-Champaign campus and most of the trustees.

title: Promised Paradise, Then Sent to Hell
description: In the quietly wrenching Oranges and Sunshine Emily Watson portrays Margaret Humphreys, an intrepid social worker from Nottingham, England, who exposed shameful national crimes. As recently as 1967, but especially in the 1940s and 50s, as many as 130,000 children were removed from orphanages and group homes in Britain and deported to various locations in the Commonwealth, particularly western Australia. One deportee, now grown up, recalls being told at the age of 10 that he was being sent to a sunny paradise where he could pick oranges off trees.

title: Rubio Denies Embellishing Family History
description: A revised version of this post appears here.

title: Rangers Tie World Series at 1-1
description: ST. LOUIS  The Texas Rangers forced the St. Louis Cardinals to go deep into their bullpen again and hit two sacrifice flies in the ninth inning to rally for a 2-1 victory in Game 2 of the World Series on Thursday night at Busch Stadium.

title: Jobs Tried Exotic Treatments to Combat Cancer, Book Says
description: In his last years, Steven P. Jobs veered from exotic diets to cutting-edge treatments as he fought the cancer that ultimately took his life, according to a new biography to be published on Monday.

title: F.B.I. Scrutinized for Amassing Data on American Communities
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has collected information about religious, ethnic and national-origin characteristics of American communities, according to internal F.B.I. documents made public by the American Civil Liberties Union on Thursday. Citing the materials, the group urged the Justice Department to tighten restrictions on F.B.I. powers.

title: New Bottom-Line Approach Good for Cisco
Unleashing Some Havoc After a Case of Cabin Fever
description: If theres one thing to be learned from the Paranormal Activity franchise, its that invisible demons do not like to be videotaped. It makes them antsy, and before long theyre hiding in closets, sneaking into bedrooms, breaking furniture, dragging bodies across the floor and killing somebody. And they dont distinguish between VHS and high-definition digital.

title: Gel Cuts Womens Risk of Herpes, Study Finds
description: A vaginal gel that sharply reduces a womans risk of infection with the AIDS virus is even more effective against genital herpes, a much more common risk for young American women, a new study has found.

title: Fort Lean Is Already a Standout at CMJ
description: The typical misunderstanding about the CMJ Music Marathon is that its a festival devoted to indie rock. In the past, maybe, that would have been fair, but in recent years its bent at the borders, allowing for hip-hop, electronic music, sounds from around the globe and more.

description: To the Editor:

title: Barney Frank Raises Cash, From Gays and Wall St.
description: It used to be controversial that Representative Barney Frank is gay. These days, he says, it is much harder for him to be associated with Wall Street.

title: Exotic Animals as Pets: An Unregulated Risk
description: IMAGINE the panic and terror experienced by the monkeys, bears, lions and leopards that ran loose in Ohio earlier this week as they were chased and then killed by the police. Imagine the heartbreak of the police officers who were obliged to destroy the rambling menagerie. Officers are not trained to stalk big game and bring them in alive with tranquilizer darts.

title: John Bryson Confirmed as Commerce Secretary
description: The Senate voted 74-26 on Thursday to confirm the nomination of John Bryson to be the next commerce secretary, ending a months-long struggle over President Obamas choice.

title: She Was Told Shed Be a Model. Of Course.
description: A stripped-down, socially conscious drama set in the slippery world of human trafficking, Yan Vizinbergs Cargo is commendably free of cheap emotional manipulation. Instead the film leans almost exclusively on the focused performances of its two leads, who create a credibly barbed chemistry that goes a long way toward distracting us from the films low-budget deficiencies.

title: Growths Linked to Venereal Virus Are on Rise in Women
description: Precancerous growths on the genitals are becoming more common in women, particularly those in their 40s, a medical group said Thursday, reporting a fourfold increase in women over all from 1973 to 2000.

title: Hip Surgery Option Loses Key Backer
description: In another controversy involving all-metal hips, an influential group has found that there is insufficient evidence to show that an alternative technique known as hip resurfacing is as safe and effective as a traditional replacement.

title: King Krule Gargles at Glasslands
description: Archy Marshall, nowhere near the end of his teenage years, sings like hes chewing a tough piece of meat, using half his mouth to get the sounds out.

title: Our Amish, Ourselves
description: Ashland, Ohio

title: How Fame Divided Bandmates in Love
description: The Swell Season is less a musical documentary than the story of a breakup, even if its makers seem at times frustratingly determined to smother their films most valuable emotional hook. Named for the band formed by the Irish-Czech duo Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, whose starring roles in the tiny 2007 musical Once and subsequent Academy Award for the beautiful song Falling Slowly hoisted them to international stardom, the film glances back at the two-year tour that followed those events.

title: Long Pursuit of Justice Takes a Father Beyond the Law
description: PARIS  In the dark early hours of an October morning in 2009, acting on an anonymous tip, police officers in the French city of Mulhouse picked up an elderly German doctor who had been left  bound, beaten and bleeding  in a street near the municipal courthouse. The man, Dieter Krombach, had been kidnapped outside his home in Germany and secreted across the border into France, where there was a warrant for his arrest in connection with the death of a French girl nearly three decades ago.

title: In Bid to Cut Costs at Some Texas Prisons, Lunch Will Not Be Served on Weekends
description: HOUSTON  Texas prison officials last month ended the decades-old practice of serving last meals to inmates about to be executed after one man ordered an elaborate feast of hamburgers, pizza and chicken-fried steaks that he did not eat.

title: Chinese Trade Case Has Clear Targets, Not Obvious Goals
description: HONG KONG

title: Who You Are
description: Daniel Kahneman spent part of his childhood in Nazi-occupied Paris. Like the other Jews, he had to wear a Star of David on the outside of his clothing. One evening, when he was about 7 years old, he stayed late at a friends house, past the 6 p.m. curfew.

title: An Electric Car Drives an Industrys Change
description: Chris Paines Who Killed the Electric Car?, a pointed 2006 deconstruction of what happened when California tried to encourage development of alternatively powered vehicles, concluded that it was an inside job, with conspirators including automakers, oil companies and compromised regulators.

title: Citigroup Deal to Go to Judge Critical of S.E.C. Practices
description: It is boilerplate language found in nearly every settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission: A company resolves its case without admitting or denying wrongdoing.

title: Irate News Corp. Shareholders to Take Murdoch to the Woodshed
description: The annual News Corporation shareholders meeting has always been a raucous and unpredictable event.

title: Speaking for Qaddafi, Then Denouncing Him
description: On Thursday morning, when word reached New York from Libya that Muammar el-Qaddafi had taken a turn for the worse, a man in the Libyan mission to the United Nations on East 48th Street reflected on the moment.

title: Party of Pollution
description: Last month President Obama finally unveiled a serious economic stimulus plan  far short of what Id like to see, but a step in the right direction. Republicans, predictably, have blocked it. But the new plan, combined with the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations, seems to have shifted the national conversation. We are, suddenly, focused on what we should have been talking about all along: jobs.

title: An Apology for a Guatemalan Coup, 57 Years Later
description: MEXICO CITY  More than a half-century after Guatemalas elected president Jacobo Arbenz Guzman was overthrown in a coup planned by the C.I.A. and forced into a wandering exile, President Alvaro Colom apologized on Thursday for what he called a great crime.

title: Without Super PAC Numbers, Campaign Filings Present an Incomplete Picture
description: The third-quarter campaign finance filings are in. The numbers have been crunched. And now we know who is winning the 2012 fund-raising race. Right?

title: Hedge Fund Manager Expected to Plead Guilty to Insider Trading
description: A hedge fund manager from a prominent Denver family is expected to plead guilty on Friday to insider trading charges.

title: For These Men, Basketball Means Hope
description: Its impossible not to be moved watching Anne Bufords Elevate, a documentary about Senegalese basketball players given a chance to play and receive an education in the United States.

title: Label Plan Offered to Rate Food Nutrition
description: The nutrition label on the front of a box of cereal, a frozen dinner or any other food should be as quick and easy to read as the Energy Star label on a clothes washer or an air-conditioner, according to a study released Thursday that was requested by Congress.

title: Hamilton Is Playing the Postseason in Pain
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Colonel Qaddafis End
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya died as he lived  violently. We sympathize with the Libyans who suffered for so long at the hands of the ruthless dictator and are glad he can no longer hurt them. But a gruesome video broadcast on Al Jazeera  apparently showing him being dragged, beaten and then, perhaps, shot to death by armed men  is deeply troubling, if it is real.

title: A Protector of Women With a Chip on His Shoulder
description: There are an awful lot of terrorized women in Boy Wonder  so many, in fact, that the film feels like a constant assault. Their unlikely champion is Sean (Caleb Steinmeyer), a skulking 17-year-old vigilante driven by violent childhood memories of his mothers death at the hands of a carjacker. But Sean is obsessed with more than just finding his mothers killer: Hes also on a mission to finish off every misogynist in the five boroughs.

title: The Power of Positive Coaching
description: Imagine youre coaching a big soccer game, against an undefeated team that has beaten your team in all your previous matches. Your 11-year-olds are playing well and are ahead. Then, in the closing minutes, the official makes a bad call that goes against you and, because of it, you lose. After the game, the parents of your players scream at the official. The kids are disappointed, looking up at you. What do you do?

title: After Arrest of Man in Wifes Death, a Custody Fight
description: BOONTON, N.J.  When dusk descended here last Sunday, and the forum on domestic violence was over, some 200 people carrying candles marched up the hilly street to where Nazish Noorani had been killed exactly two months earlier in a shooting the police said had been set up by her husband.

title: Qaddafis Death Places Focus on Arab Springs Hard Road
description: TUNIS  Like the flight of Tunisias dictator or the trial of Egypts, the capture of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Thursday afternoon captivated the Arab world, giving a renewed sense of power and possibility. But the photographs of his bloody corpse that circulated just moments later on cellphones and television screens quickly tempered that exhilaration with a reminder of the many still-unresolved conflicts that the Arab Spring has also unleashed.

title: Romney Will Compete in Iowa, if a Bit Cautiously
description: TREYNOR, Iowa  Mitt Romney always said he would be back.

title: An Incubator of Baseball Talent
description: ST. LOUIS  Few cities resonate with as much baseball tradition as St. Louis, and few seem as doused in team colors as this city, where even the downtown fountains are spraying water tinted Cardinal rouge this October.

title: Now, Get Along Boys, or Youll Be Poor
description: O.K., so theyre not Adam, Hoss and Little Joe. But the brothers who bond while reminiscing about those Bonanza scions  and more so by riding horses, fighting bad guys and sharing some manly chuckles amid the bickering  turn out to be their own sort of entertaining fraternal threesome in the action-genre film The Reunion.

title: First as Farce, Then as Tragedy
description: The first months of the Civil War had been a series of humiliating lessons for the citizens and soldiers of the Union, highlighted by dramatic defeats at Bull Run and Wilsons Creek. The war, it was becoming clear, would be neither easy nor quick. But it was also clear that, especially among the Union Army officer corps, those lessons had not yet fully sunk in  a fact made all too clear by the Oct. 21 disaster at the Battle of Balls Bluff.

title: Two Major Hospital Groups in City Explore a Partnership
description: Two of New York Citys major hospital organizations are exploring a partnership that would give them a large share of the citys patients and make them a formidable rival for other city hospitals in tough economic times.

title: Migrants from Sanity
description: With 14 million Americans out of work, you would think somebody could answer the desperation call from farmers offering to pay $150 to anyone willing to pick fruit in the orchards of Washington State. But no, the apples hang at peak ripeness, a near-record crop, and the jobs go begging, despite radio ads and an appeal by Governor Christine Gregoire to the other Washington for help.

title: Wal-Mart Cuts Some Health Care Benefits
description: After trying to mollify its critics in recent years by offering better health care benefits to its employees, Wal-Mart is substantially rolling back coverage for part-time workers and significantly raising premiums for many full-time staff.

title: Putting a Face to a Familiar Voice
description: Early in Being Elmo: A Puppeteers Journey, a young man named Kevin Clash is seen trying to find a voice for a puppet he has made. He has the puppet say Hi over and over with different accents and inflections.

title: The Arctic and the Lessons of the Gulf
description: The Interior Department has been inching closer to approving Royal Dutch Shells ambitious plans to drill for what are believed to be huge deposits of oil in the Arctic Ocean off Alaska. In August, it approved an exploratory drilling plan for the Beaufort Sea, and two weeks ago it upheld the validity of leases in the neighboring Chukchi Sea that had been challenged by environmental groups.

title: After Making Capture in Pipe, Displaying the Trophies of War
description: MISURATA, Libya  They had the ultimate trophies of the revolution: the colonels golden gun, his satellite phone, his brown scarf and one black boot.

title: Familiar Card for Jets in the Motivation Game
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan spent five minutes Thursday awkwardly fielding questions about what he repeatedly called his unintentional slam of San Diego Chargers Coach Norv Turner earlier in the week, then pirouetted to a much more pleasant topic.

title: Florida Senator Denies Claim He Gilded His Family History
description: MIAMI  Senator Marco Rubio, a rising Republican star, confronted questions on Thursday that he had embellished his family history and misrepresented the year his parents first left Cuba for the United States.

title: A Deal to Help Foster Youths Find Housing
description: New York City has reached an agreement on a proposed settlement of a lawsuit that claims the city allows older children to leave foster care only to become immediately homeless.

title: Brothers and Champions
description: Celebrated as much for brains as for battering power, the Ukrainian brothers Vitali and Wladimir Klitschko have boxed their way from obscurity to worldwide fame with a discipline envied by many of their counterparts. Exhibiting a similar single-mindedness, Sebastian Dehnhardts Klitschko documents that journey, and if at times his mountainous subjects sound a little too self-serving, its not as if anyone were going to argue with them.

title: Friday: Day Five of the Crossword Contest
description: Administrivial Format Alert! Todays puzzle format is different, so there is no Across Lite file. Please print out and solve the PDF.

title: As Autocrats Are Toppled, Their Fates Grow More Extreme
description: CAIRO  With Arab despots toppling at an unprecedented pace since January, a range of options for the final curtain have been tested, with Libyas leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, typically, making the most dramatic exit with his gory death on Thursday.

title: Blighted Existences, Eased With Hope and Humor
description: To observe that a play about extreme suffering is also explosively funny might seem absurd. But one of the many soul-piercing truths in Sons of the Prophet, the absolutely wonderful new comedy-drama by Stephen Karam that opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater, is that life rarely obeys the rules of dramatic consistency, or, for that matter, fair play.

title: Each Family, Tortured in Its Own Way
description: Mothers come in for some serious savaging in Relatively Speaking, a reasonably savory tasting platter of comedies by Ethan Coen, Elaine May and Woody Allen that opened on Thursday night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: Lottery Numbers
Obamas Jobs Plan Is Blocked Again by Senate Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  For the second time in 10 days, the Senate on Thursday rejected Democratic efforts to take up a jobs bill championed by President Obama.

title: Blazing a Feminist, and Hall of Fame, Trail
description: Sometimes a film feels a bit too pat and yet is impossible to resist. The Mighty Macs, based on the national championship run of the 1972 womens basketball team at Immaculata College near Philadelphia, is such a film: lots of button pushing, but in the end youre glad you saw it.

title: Craig Keeps Making Pinch-Hits Look Easy
description: ST. LOUIS  The Cardinals Allen Craig spent a good part of Thursday afternoon explaining how difficult it is to pinch-hit. Yet he has made it look easy in October.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,796 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: A Teenagers Hardships, at Home and School
description: Theres something sweet about Jonathan Segals modest high school drama, Norman, despite the contrivances of its protagonists predicament and its stacking of the emotional deck. Norman Long (Dan Byrd of Cougar Town and Easy A) is a smart, sensitive and reflexively wisecracking teenager with a mother who died in a car accident and a father (the consistently reliable Richard Jenkins) whos in, yes, the terminal stage of stomach cancer.

title: Check-In at Dodge City
description: The next time youre aggravated, beltless and in your socks in the airport security line, you might consider the latest tally of loaded weapons confiscated from carry-on luggage around the nation.

title: Climate Skeptics Stay Unswayed
description: A new study designed to address critiques of climate science by skeptics has confirmed that global warming is real and that the worlds average land temperature has risen by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit since the mid-1950s.

title: Accountability in Missouri
description: It has been seven years since the Roman Catholic Churchs investigative board of laity warned that, beyond the 700 priests dismissed for sexually abusing children, there must be consequences for the diocesan leaders who recycled criminal priests through unsuspecting parishes. American church authorities have done nothing to heed this caution.

title: Masked Protector of Gotham Has His Eye on Wall Street Protesters
description: He is a tycoon, but he is also a crusader for justice: Bruce Wayne is coming to Wall Street, and how the 99 percent will receive him is the latest worry facing a beleaguered Lower Manhattan.

title: California Adopts Limits on Greenhouse Gases
description: SACRAMENTO  Fifteen months after a similar effort died in Congress, California regulators adopted a system on Thursday for combating climate change that sets limits on greenhouse gas emissions and creates market incentives to encourage oil refineries, electricity generators and other polluters to clean up their plants.

title: Support for Move to Broaden Definition of Rape
description: Police officials and womens groups on Thursday applauded a recommendation by a Federal Bureau of Investigation subcommittee that the definition of rape used by the agency be revised. The definition, written more than 80 years ago, has been criticized as too narrow, resulting in thousands of rapes being excluded from the F.B.I.s annual Uniform Crime Report. The subcommittee recommends a broader definition, to include anal and oral rape, as well as rapes involving male victims. Currently, only sexual assaults that involved force and vaginal penetration are included. The proposal is subject to approval of a full advisory board, which meets in December. Womens groups have been trying for years to get the definition changed. What Im happiest about is that such a clear consensus is emerging from law enforcement officials all over the country that this has to happen, said Carol Tracy, executive director of the Womens Law Project in Philadelphia.

title: Massachusetts: Mans Death Sentence Is Thrown Out
description: A judge in Boston threw out a death sentence on Thursday in a 2003 murder case, ruling that a juror had not been impartial. Judge Mark L. Wolf of Federal District Court found that the juror had repeatedly lied during jury selection in a way that called her impartiality into question. He said the convict, Gary Lee Sampson, was entitled to a new sentencing trial to determine whether the death penalty was warranted. Mr. Sampson pleaded guilty to murdering two men who had picked him up hitchhiking. It was the first federal case in Massachusetts in which the death penalty was imposed.

title: E.P.A. to Tighten Rules on Wastewater Disposal
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced Thursday that it would devise stricter rules for the treatment and disposal of toxic wastewater used in natural gas drilling. The agency said it planned to set standards by 2014 for the management of wastewater used in a rapidly growing drilling tactic known as hydrofracking, which involves injecting huge amounts of water to break up shale or coal bed formations and release the gas.

title: Arab Spring and Fall
description: An update on the leaders of countries where protests have turned violent.

title: Red Bulls Bring Home Final Spot in Playoffs
description: HARRISON, N.J.  On a cool autumn night, the Red Bulls were at their most crisp and intense when anything less would have been unacceptable.

title: NYT Front Page for 10/21/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 10/21/2011

title: Corrections: October 21
description: NATIONAL

title: Russia and Georgia Trade Talks Stymied
description: Talks between Georgia and Russia on Russias accession to the World Trade Organization ended with no agreement on Thursday, and little time remains if Russia is to join the organization by the end of the year. The two sides are to meet again on Tuesday, said Deputy Foreign Minister Sergi Kapanadze, who headed Georgias delegation to the talks in Switzerland. He said the discussions were stymied by Georgias request for information on trade through Abkhazia and South Ossetia, breakaway territories of Georgia that Russia has recognized as sovereign countries. American and Russian officials have said they hope to complete the accession process by the end of the year, which would require Georgias approval by mid-November.

title: Nearly Car-Free
description: Though not quite car-free, Vauban, Germany, is a highly "car-reduced" suburb.

title: World Series Replay: Game 2
description: Smart base running helped the Rangers score twice in the ninth inning of a 2-1 victory.

title: Similar Script, Different Ending
description: ST. LOUIS  For those unable to see Game 1 of the World Series on Wednesday night, the key moments of that game were conveniently replayed in striking detail on Thursday. At least that was how it seemed heading into the ninth inning.

title: Five Harlem Men Guilty in Drug-Trafficking Conspiracy
description: Five men from Harlem were convicted on Thursday of running a drug-trafficking conspiracy in a trial that examined the intricacies of what prosecutors called a gang.

title: Word of the Day | placebo
description: placebo \pl-se-()bo\ noun

title: Morris Chafetz, 87, Dies; Altered View of Alcoholism
description: Dr. Morris E. Chafetz, who played an important role in changing the public perception of alcoholism from social crime or personal failing to a disease requiring treatment, died on Oct. 14 at his home in Washington. He was 87.

title: Barry Feinstein, Photographer of Defining Rock Portraits, Dies at 80
description: Barry Feinstein, a photographer who chronicled the lives of seminal rock n roll stars of the 1960s, and who was perhaps best known for the stark portrait of Bob Dylan on the cover of the 1964 album The Times They Are A-Changin, died on Thursday in a hospital near his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 80.

title: Uganda: 2 Leaders of Protest Movement Are Charged With Treason, Police Say
description: The government is charging the ringleaders of street demonstrations this week with treason, officials said Thursday, an offense that can carry the death penalty. The police said that about 40 people had been arrested across the country since Monday, when activists tried to resume demonstrations begun in April against rising commodity prices and government corruption. The police accuse the activists of seeking to overthrow the government. Two members of the group Activists 4 Change were arraigned on treason charges on Wednesday, said Judith Nabakooba, a police spokeswoman. One of them is an assistant to the opposition leader Kizza Besigye. At least nine people were killed and hundreds arrested during protests led by Mr. Besigye this past spring.

title: After 23 Years, a Suspect Emerges and a Familys Wounds Are Reopened
description: Almost everything that Caitlin and Jesse Baker know about their mother, who was mysteriously murdered 23 years ago when they were small children, comes from memories shared by relatives and from fading family photos of the smiling, petite brunette.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
description: Reacting to the death of the Libyan dictator Muammar el-Qaddafi, Indias Ministry of External Affairs said the strife in Libya and the suffering of its people had been a matter of concern and it hoped that peace and stability would soon return to Libya (The Hindu). India abstained from the vote authorizing airstrikes against Libya in the United Nations Security Council earlier this year.

title: Perrys Super PAC Keeps Its Distance From Him
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Lines Go Up to Ferry Wind Energy to Major Cities
description: SWEETWATER  Enormous transmission towers stand beside a West Texas country road, waiting for electric wires to be strung through them. Nearby, the task of threading wires through the steel towers is already under way, as men in hard hats shift equipment into position.

title: Metro Pucks: Rangers Win in Overtime; Isles Fall to Tampa Bay
description: Ryan McDonaghs goal with two seconds left in overtime gave the Rangers a 3-2 win in Calgary on Thursday.

title: Parking Rules in New York City
description: Because of the Jewish holiday Simhat Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: In High-Crime Areas, Still Too Few Police
description: Despite Mayor Rahm Emanuels highly promoted efforts at concentrating additional police patrols in the citys most dangerous neighborhoods, many crime-ridden police districts still have fewer officers patrolling their streets than far safer areas of the city have, according to recent data obtained by The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: A Tale of 3,400 Retired Teachers and a Possible $90 Million Math Mistake
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Chinese Toddler Who Was Run Over Twice Dies
description: BEIJING  A toddler who stirred a national debate on compassion after being run over twice by vans and left lying in a market street in southern China has died a week after the incident, hospital officials in Guangzhou said on Friday.

title: Another Cant-Miss General Manager Is Hired
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Mayors Political Machine Goes Into High Gear in Quest for Full Term
description: On Sept. 14, about a dozen business and labor leaders gathered in an eighth-floor conference room in the Financial District. They met for an hour, rehearsing their strategy to assure that Ed Lee, the interim mayor of San Francisco, is elected to a four-year term on Nov. 8.

title: 20 Years After Fire, Revelation and Tribute
description: Richard Misrach has built his reputation photographing destruction, be it in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina or in the industrial area known as Cancer Alley along the Mississippi River in southern Louisiana. Twenty years ago, however, it was a disaster close to home that led him to take out his 8-by-10 large-format camera.

title: Russians Come to the Rescue of Sonomas Fort Ross Park
description: On a recent weekday at Fort Ross State Historic Park, a group of schoolchildren dressed as 19th-century Russian fur traders and American Indian otter hunters gathered around the replica of a cannon at the center of the fort. As the fuse dwindled, the children covered their ears. The cannon exploded and cheers erupted.

title: Forced From Home at 75 as Tenant Rules Bend
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: The End of Traffic Hell
description: It was Bangalores day out.

title: News Quiz | Oct. 21, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Oct. 21, 1879 | Thomas Edison Lights the Lamp
description: On Oct. 21, 1879, Thomas Edison devised a workable electric light at his laboratory in Menlo Park, N.J. A New York Times reporter visited Edison there and wrote an article about it that appeared in the paper on Dec. 28, 1879. The lamp which Mr. Edison regards as a crowning triumph is a model of simplicity and economy, he said.

title: A Masterwork Spanning 40 Years and One Island
description: This is the second of two pieces on the work of Jack Delano. Part One is here.

title: Murakamis Tokyo
description: During Sam Andersons trip to Japan for his interview with the novelist Haruki Murakami, he visited the places mentioned in Murakamis fiction as well as sites significant to Murakamis life and career.

title: The Fierce Imagination of Haruki Murakami
description: I prepared for my first-ever trip to Japan, this summer, almost entirely by immersing myself in the work of Haruki Murakami. This turned out to be a horrible idea. Under the influence of Murakami, I arrived in Tokyo expecting Barcelona or Paris or Berlin  a cosmopolitan world capital whose straight-talking citizens were fluent not only in English but also in all the nooks and crannies of Western culture: jazz, theater, literature, sitcoms, film noir, opera, rock n roll. But this, as really anyone else in the world could have told you, is not what Japan is like at all. Japan  real, actual, visitable Japan  turned out to be intensely, inflexibly, unapologetically Japanese.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 21, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the movie review, A Splintering Psyche or Omens of Disaster?

title: Qaddafi Is Dead in Libya
description: WHERE was Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi killed?WHERE did the rebellion against Colonel Qaddafi began last February?

title: How Do You Use Facebook?
description: Research shows that for students, specific ways of using Facebook  not use of it in general  correlate with some real-life behaviors like participating in extracurricular activities and even with academic achievement. How do you tend to use Facebook, if at all? Do you think the ways you use it are reflected in other areas of your life?

title: Revisiting Deng Xiaoping: A Word With Ezra F. Vogel
description: Ezra F. Vogel, author of a new biography of Deng Xiaoping, retired from Harvard University in 2000, but still lives just a few hundred yards from the campus. In an interview at his home in Cambridge, Mass., he discussed his book, Deng Xiaoping and the Transformation of China; the differing views of Deng during his rule and now; and the differences between Chinese and American politics during the opening of China to the West. Mr. Vogel talked to The Timess David Barboza. These are edited excerpts from their conversation.

title: Facebooks Impact on Student Grades
description: How does Facebook activity affect a students grades? Reynol Junco, a professor at Lock Haven University in Pennsylvania, recently set out to determine exactly that.

title: As Documentary Rolls Out, Elon Musk Considers His Revenge
description: The director, Chris Paine, called me up one day and wanted to have lunch, said Elon Musk, the Tesla Motors chief executive, in a recent telephone interview. He was discussing how he came to be featured prominently in Mr. Paines new film, Revenge of the Electric Car, which opens in New York and Los Angeles on Friday after having made the film festival rounds this year. A review of the film appeared in The Times on Friday.

title: Pitchfork Music Festival Comes to Paris
description: Since 2006, Pitchfork Media has supplemented its tastemaking music Web site with an annual music festival in Chicago. On Oct. 28 and 29, the festival will cross the Atlantic for its first full-fledged event outside the United States, importing North American, British and Scandinavian bands for French audiences, at the Pitchfork Music Festival Paris. (Though most tickets for the festival itself are sold out, they are still available for the opening and closing party events; organizers say additional tickets will be available for the nighttime, or club, sessions on the 28th.)

title: Week 7 Matchups: When the Middling Face the Mediocre
description: Colts (0-6) at Saints (4-2)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Saints by 14.The famous quote by the former N.F.L. commissioner Bert Bell  On any given Sunday, any team in the N.F.L. can beat any other  has been a source of reassurance for both fans and television programmers for decades. The leagues carefully maintained competitive balance almost guarantees that every week will feature several compelling games between high-quality, evenly matched opponents. Almost.Bell would never imagine a week like this, in which the best (the Patriots) and most fascinating (the Eagles, the 49ers) teams have byes, while the top contenders face pushovers and the mediocre slug it out with the middling. Matchups that looked good when the schedule was announced now merit double-digit point spreads. Case in point: the Colts vs. the Saints, a rematch of Super Bowl XLIV that promised to be a seesaw offensive battle, is now little more than a three-hour wake for Indianapolis and a chance to watch Sean Payton coach New Orleans from the booth instead of the sideline.Granted, Curtis Painter, like a frozen burrito under a filling station heat lamp, is slowly warming to the Colts starting quarterback job. His completion percentage has gone up every week, and the Colts offense no longer looks like an intramural team playing in a downpour. Also, Drew Brees offered hope that Payton might find a way to stand on, or slightly above, the field on the surgically repaired leg he broke in last weeks game. Im envisioning some kind of hovercraft on the sideline, Brees said. Levitating coaches: another thing that Bert Bell could never imagine. Pick: Saints.

title: The Infrastructure Twofer: Jobs Now and Future Growth
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

title: The Musical Buildings
description: Three residents of 75 and 99 Ocean Avenue, adjacent buildings in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, talk about what it is like to live around fellow musicians.

title: The Man Who Took Modernity to China
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  In 1979, just when Americans were beginning to reflect on the ascent of Japan, the Harvard sociologist Ezra F. Vogel wrote his best-selling book, Japan as Number One: Lessons for America.

title: Living in Mill Basin, Brooklyn
description: Mill Basin is a reminder of Brooklyns eclecticism. Far from the converted warehouses of postindustrial Williamsburg is this zone of lawn mowers, tool sheds, brick patios and umbrella-shaded glass tables.

title: The Early Word: Piecemeal
description: Todays Times:

title: Groupon Narrows Losses Ahead of Its Pitch to Investors
description: 6:14 p.m. | Updated

title: Spanish Construction Firm Ousts Its Chief Executive
description: Before trying a boardroom coup, it is wise to line up enough support in advance to win.

title: Can Obama 2012 Replicate Bush 2004?
description: Hell have hundreds of millions of dollars, the bully pulpit, Air Force One and high-profile supporters from Warren Buffett to Lady Gaga behind him. But President Obamas chances of re-election could come down to a single strategic question: To what degree can the history of 2004 be repeated in 2012?

title: From Jerseys on the Streets to Jerseys in Your Closets
description: We got a good reaction to our post last week about spotting soccer jerseys in New York. Nicholas Felice was the first to respond to our request for photos; thats him at right in his 2000-01 Roma jersey  the year they won the Scudetto, he made a point to add  but others had some interesting contributions, too.

title: Tim Burton Lines Up a Spot in Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade
description: While Halloween might seem to be the holiday best suited to the macabre spirit of Tim Burton, that darkly inclined director is about to put his own spooky stamp on Thanksgiving.

title: Santander to Sell Stake in U.S. Auto Financing Group
description: Spains Grupo Santander, the euro zones largest bank by market capitalization, announced a $1.15 billion deal on Friday to sell a 35 percent stake in its automotive financing unit in the United States to a group of private equity investors, as it looks to shore up its balance sheet.

title: Stress Fractures For Team Anna
description: Is Anna Hazares grand coalition of good-government activists cracking up?

title: U.N. Panel Calls for Inquiry Into Qaddafis Death
description: GENEVA  The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights called on Friday for an inquiry into the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi amid conflicting accounts of how the Libyan dictator met his end and video that appeared to show him alive after his capture.

title: The Value of Foreign Policy Victories for Obama
description: If there was one area of doubt about Barack Obama that lingered in peoples minds during  and even after  the 2008 campaign, it was how well he could handle a foreign policy crisis.

title: I.R.S. Raises Maximum Annual 401(k) Contribution
description: Updated at 9:19 a.m. to reflect revised information from the Plan Sponsor Council of America on the percentage of companies that limit 401(k) contributions below the I.R.S. maximum.

title: G.E. Profits Are in Line With Analysts Outlook
description: General Electric, the nations largest industrial company, said on Friday that it had higher net earnings for the third quarter, but price pressures in its energy business squeezed profit margins in an economic environment that the companys chief executive described as volatile.

title: For British Ex-Bankers, Life Beyond the Bailouts
description: LONDON  It has been three years since the British government bailed out Royal Bank of Scotland and the Lloyds Banking Group and nationalized the regional lender Northern Rock.

title: Jazz Was the Answer
description: On a leafy Brooklyn block, past a plain red door and down a narrow staircase, Andrea Brachfeld is curled up in a chair, head bobbing to a funky bass solo being played in a nearby room. Here in this cramped basement recording studio off the Prospect Park Parade Grounds, she is content. She is grooving. She is fulfilled.

title: Beyond Green: A Net-Zero College Community
description: Designing buildings that leave a lighter imprint on the environment has become the de facto standard these days. The target for many is zero net energy use, meaning that a building makes as much energy as it uses over the course of a year.

title: A New Video Role for Groupons C.E.O.
description: Andrew Mason, Groupons 30-year-old founder and chief executive, is all grown up.

title: Verizon Profit Jumps
description: Verizon Communications, the nations second-largest telephone company, said on Friday that its profit doubled during the last quarter, bolstered by customers attracted by its portfolio of iPhone and Android devices.

title: Weekend TV Guide: Oct. 22-23: Seven Reasons to Stay Inside
description: There is a delightful scent of autumn in the air. Not too hot, not too cold  you can feel that late October snap and the extra burst of brightness and color and energy that comes with it.

title: Thai Prime Minister to Take Command of Flood Control Efforts
description: BANGKOK  Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra said Friday that she would take direct command of flood control in Thailand as Bangkok took the risky step of opening its floodgates and as criticism of the government mounted after days of disorganization and conflicting messages.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Narrowing Losses, Groupon Seeks $16 to $18 a Share in I.P.O. | Groupon reported nearly breaking even in its third quarter, an important milestone as it prepares the final leg of its long journey toward an initial public offering.

title: Bain to Buy Japanese Restaurant Chain from Nomura
description: The private equity giant Bain Capital agreed to buy Skylark, a Japanese restaurant chain, from Nomura Holdings and other investors for $2.1 billion on Friday, in one of the countrys largest private equity deals since the financial crisis.

title: Macarthur Coal Shareholder Backs Peabody Bid
description: Peabody Energy, the American coal company, moved one step closer to acquiring Macarthur Coal on Friday after the Australian firms largest shareholder backed Peabodys $4.9 billion takeover offer.

title: Friday Reading: Large Study Finds No Cellphone-Cancer Link
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wnallet.

title: Puerto Ricos Plan for Gas Pipeline Has Many Critics
description: PORTUGUES, P.R.  It is his retirement refuge, a tiny house in the Central Mountain Chain, surrounded by banana and orange trees, coffee bushes and the melody of coqu frogs.

title: Live From New York, Its Steve Schwarzman
description: Stephen A. Schwarzman has been many things, including a mergers banker, a private equity mogul and philanthropist.

title: 5 Things to Watch for at the News Corp. Shareholders Meeting
description: News Corporation shareholders will have the chance to confront Rupert Murdoch, the companys chairman and chief executive, later Friday. The annual meeting, in Los Angeles, marks the first time investors have had the opportunity to question Mr. Murdoch since a phone-hacking scandal at the British newspaper unit humbled the company over the summer.

title: Spotted on the Street | Georgia Fowler
description: The Girl: Georgia Fowler, a model at IMG Worldwide. She also studies psychology.The Place: Lower Broadway between Vesey and Barclay Streets.

title: The Thrill of Defeat for Sports Fans
description: It will provide little solace to wounded fans of the Boston Red Sox, who recently endured the most catastrophic late-season choke in baseball history, to know that their misery has been mathematically quantified: 278 million to 1. Those are the odds of the Red Sox blowing a nine-game lead (which they did) and missing the baseball playoffs entirely (which they did) in the precise fashion in which they did it, as calculated by Nate Silver in The Times.

title: Building a House of Wax in Cleveland
description: In the heart of postindustrial Cleveland, in one of those cheery urban-reclamation areas with freshly painted brick buildings and almost unnaturally green lawn spaces, youll find Gotta Groove Records, one of around 20 plants in the United States that still press vinyl. On the day I visited, the guts of this converted elevator factory were packed with hissing, clanking vintage record presses, and the walls were lined with band fliers and colored LPs. A dry-erase board at the far end of the shop displayed the days jobs, Tom Waits and Tim Buckley among them.

title: In-Flight Entertainment
description: On a recent flight, my colleague was seated next to an employee of our major competitor. My colleague realized this when the fellow began writing e-mails about possible problems with a significant new product. Is it ethical for us to capitalize on this fellows stupidity? B.C., NEW JERSEY

title: Life During Wartime
description: After more than 30 years of war, Afghanistans special tragedy  its wonder  is that the obstinate violence no longer represents an assault on daily life.

title: Wouldnt It Be Cool if Shakespeare Wasnt Shakespeare?
description: Was Shakespeare a fraud? Thats the question the promotional machinery for Roland Emmerichs new film, Anonymous, wants to usher out of the tiny enclosure of fringe academic conferences into the wider pastures of a Hollywood audience. Shakespeare is finally getting the Oliver Stone/Da Vinci Code treatment, with a lurid conspiratorial melodrama involving incest in royal bedchambers, a vapidly simplistic version of court intrigue, nifty costumes and historically inaccurate nonsense. First they came for the Kennedy scholars, and I did not speak out, because I was not a Kennedy scholar. Then they came for Opus Dei, and I did not speak out, because I was not a Catholic scholar. Now they have come for me.

title: From Russia With Lies
description: In the summer of 1973, when I was 18, I camped on a Black Sea beach with a Ukrainian boy named Boris, whose blue eyes and sun-bleached hair made my knees wobble every time I looked in his direction. Had my mother discovered this transgression (I was supposed to be vacationing at my girlfriends familys dacha), I would have felt a shame greater than what befell me six years later, when I betrayed my country by marrying an American and leaving Russia. But that summer, the Crimean sun, the turquoise sea and Boriss cinnamon tan led me astray into the adult world of vranyo.

title: Taken by Pirates
description: Thanks to Jeffrey Gettleman, who continually sheds light on the tragedies and injustices in this corner of the world. I appreciate how he also highlights the good fight that many Somali people are undertaking as they make the best of an incredibly complicated situation. As Gettleman highlights in this article, the Somali situation is more about economics than about religious extremism. Economic desperation causes people to do crazy things. This is true in every country of the world.

title: Spalding Gray
description: The Dark Prince of Downtown, in large part about Grays romantic and professional relationship with the theater director Elizabeth Le Compte, fails to mention that Le Compte is one of the foremost theater directors of our time. She changed and continues to change the form of theater, and all theater looks different because of her work. Gray ultimately found his storytelling voice through her directing  another bit of history that is incorrectly characterized. Readers of this article will think Liz serves primarily as Grays girlfriend, who directs theater on the side. If this were the story of the lover of a male director, we daresay he would not be depicted in this narrative as a foil, mother or handmaiden.

title: Can Cancer Ever Be Ignored?
description: The article Can Cancer Ever Be Ignored? reveals a nightmare of sloppy science. P.S.A. testing poses zero risk. It is not invasive, not radioactive, not even expensive. It is treatment that poses risk. Failing to distinguish between these two entirely different things is bad medicine, bad policy, simply bad thinking. Obviously, we have lots of work to do. We should be searching for better treatment options, better ways of distinguishing between aggressive and nonlethal cancers, better ways of identifying high-risk patients. But advising men not to be screened accomplishes nothing, except to relieve physicians of their responsibility to inform patients fully and treat them appropriately.

title: Bad Times on Wall Street, Boom Times for Kevin Spacey
description: It is not very likely that an economist will ever win a Nobel Prize for tracking the correlations between movie-star careers and the business cycle, but if anyone were to take up this area of research, Kevin Spacey would offer an especially challenging case study. His initial rise coincided with the 90s boom, but for most of the Bush bubble years he was out of sight, doing theater in England. Now  call it happenstance or dialectics  his comeback has arrived more or less simultaneously with the global crisis of capitalism.

title: Kashmir to Lift Reviled Security Law
description: NEW DELHI  A much-despised law that suspends basic rights and shields security forces from prosecution in the disputed province of Kashmir will be lifted in some areas in the next few days, officials said Friday.

title: Occupying Boston and Beyond, With Tent Libraries for All
description: BOSTON  This city, home to the nations first major public library, has a new and somewhat grittier reading nook. Housed in a green military tent, the library at the Occupy Boston encampment in Dewey Square is overflowing with scholarly tomes that have no due dates or late fees.

title: CMJ Day 3: Twitter Reviews of Freshkills, AraabMuzik and More
description: Its Day 4 of the CMJ Music Marathon and critics from The Times arent slowing down. Last night, @joncaramanica and @jonpareles covered the gamut of offerings in Brooklyn and the Lower East Side. But we cant be everywhere. This year, weve invited readers to join us in appraising CMJ shows on Twitter.

title: Readjusting Our Eye, Again
description: Revolutions with the sidearm of the Internet expose much, not least perfidy. The Telegraph in London has a fascinating obituary of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi  serious, dryly funny  that contains the observation that the Libyan leader looked like a parody of Sixties radical chic. It was those craggy features and retro blue-tinted shades. Colonel Qaddafi was no joke, but we once laughed (as the obituary noted) at his outlandishness. For a trip in 2002, to South Africa, his entourage consisted of a personal jet, two transport planes, a container ship filled with buses and goat meat, $6 million in petty cash and 400 security guards. Well, no more.

title: A Mitzvah Behind the Price of a Soldiers Freedom
description: On the Sabbath morning of Nov. 5, less than three weeks after the release of Sgt. First Class Gilad Shalit in a prisoner exchange between Israel and Hamas, Jews in synagogues throughout the world will read a Torah portion concerning Abrahams early journeys. The text recounts how invaders conquered the city of Sodom, taking Abrahams nephew Lot as a captive, and the way Abraham raised an army to rescue him.

title: Fill-In | Corn Mazes
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the article Builders of Corn Mazes Hope to Lose Visitors, and One Actually Did.

title: Beef Will Be Whats for Dinner for a Long Time, Panelists Say
description: Have you been persuaded that beef is waning on the American plate because its too destructive to the ecosystem, too hormone-pumped and too corn-fed artery-clogging?

title: What Were Reading
description: Serious Eats: Those crazy kids find a Coke Freestyle machine and try all 127 possible flavor combinations. Fidgety behavior and tooth decay ensue.  Eric Asimov

title: Pesto Dishes Without the Pasta
description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman has pulled out the hand blender to whip up extra batches of pured basil to be frozen and enjoyed in various pesto dishes all winter.

title: Mother of Toddler Who Was Run Over Says Microblog Is a Fake
description: A 2-year-old girl who was hit by a van and then ignored as she lay writhing in the middle of a busy market street in China died on Friday of her injuries, as my colleague Michael Wines reports.

title: With Bamboo Roofs and Plywood Walls, Williamsburg Is Transformed for Sukkot
description: It is possible, in many parts of New York, to pass through autumn unaware of the Jewish festival of Sukkot. It is, however, impossible to pass through Brooklyn neighborhoods like Williamsburg, Crown Heights and Borough Park without knowing that the eight-day harvest holiday is under way.

title: Chlo Sevigny Has, What Else, More Secrets in a New Television Series
description: It seems you cant have a Chlo Sevigny project without a character or characters trying to hide a shocking secret, whether its a lover who disguises her gender (in Boys Dont Cry) or a polygamist family concealing its multiple marriages (on the HBO series Big Love). So try to sound surprised when you learn that there are a couple of unexpected twists to the character that Ms. Sevigny plays in her latest project, at least one of which is strongly hinted at in its title. In Hit and Miss, a new series that will be shown on the satellite service DirecTV, she portrays a character named Mia who is a hired assassin as well as a pre-op transsexual. When Mia learns shes had a son by an ex-girlfriend who is dying of cancer, she is forced to mix her killer instincts with her newly acquired maternal ones (hey, thats what it says in the press release).

title: On Our Radar: Living Fossil Is Younger Than Thought
description: Modern-day cycads that were assumed to have existed when dinosaurs roamed the earth over 200 million years ago are actually far younger, researchers report. [The Times of London]

title: U.S. and U.N. Demand Details From Libyan Leaders on How Qaddafi Died
description: MISURATA, Libya  International calls mounted Friday for Libyas interim leaders to provide a fuller accounting of the final moments before Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis violent, messy death, as new videos circulated that showed him and his son Muatassim alive, apparently while in the custody of the former rebels.

title: The Fisker Karmas 20 M.P.G. Sticker: A Scarlet Letter?
description: With its range-extender gasoline engine engaged, the Fisker Karma plug-in hybrid was rated this week by the Environmental Protection Agency at just 20 miles per gallon. The E.P.A. figure was first reported by the blog GreenCarReports.com.

title: The Protester and the Goldman Chief
description: In the latest installment of DealBooks animated series, Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, is confronted by a protester from Occupy Wall Street.

title: Trying To Unwarp The Debate
description: I visited Zuccotti Park yesterday. Michael Moore gave a short speech, transmitted by the human microphone. I gather that right-wingers are claiming that OWS is anti-Semitic; someone forgot to tell the excellent Klezmer band.

title: Full House for Annual Advertisers Conference
description: The Association of National Advertisers, whose members are the chief marketers of the nations leading companies, is looking to set another record for attendance at its annual conference.

title: A Memoir From Mr. Broadway, With an Assist From Mrs. Broadway
description: Pat Schoenfeld, the widow of the powerful Broadway theater owner and producer Gerald Schoenfeld, has completed work on his forthcoming memoir, Mr. Broadway: The Inside Story of the Shuberts, the Shows and the Stars, which is set to be published in April by Applause Books. As the longtime chairman of the Shubert Organization, Mr. Schoenfeld, along with his business partner Bernard B. Jacobs, provided homes to some of the greatest Broadway hits, including A Chorus Line, Cats, Les Misrables, and The Phantom of the Opera.

title: The Timess Battista Answers Questions
description: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The New York Times, answers questions from readers.

title: More People Who Cant Handle The Truth
description: If you follow this blog regularly, youll know that whenever I present data  and I do present a lot of data  right-wingers will complain of cherry-picking. They never have a clear example of how I should do things differently  or if they do, its always obviously wrong. But what they really mean is that they wont accept data that doesnt tell them what they want to hear.

title: I May Be Dumb, But Im Not Stupid
description: Or something like that. The usually very insightful Kantoos seems to have missed what people like me are actually saying about the need for emergency funding in Europe.

title: Leading Off: Rangers Go Bold, Just in Time
description: The top of the ninth inning of Game 2 of the World Series was such a tiny sliver in an otherwise unremarkable game. Sure, the starting pitchers performed admirably amid reports that their profession was as obsolete as the iPhone 2, but by the time Albert Pujols polished off the last of his fruitless four at-bats, well, hanging with the action was getting tougher with every pitch.

title: Can Powerful Women Change the Workplace?
description: The New York Timess otherwise distressing article  today on the very real possibility that, in 2012, womens representation in the Senate may shrink for the first time in a generation did contain one real bright spot: Senator Patty Murray of Washington State, elected in the much-vaunted Year of the Woman in 1992, reflected on the contrast of then and now:

title: On Climate, Ethics, Cow Burps and the Dalai Lama
description: Early this week, I heard through some e-mail traffic that 10 climate, behavioral and environmental scientists and scholars were meeting with the Dalai Lama to discuss ecology, ethics and interdependence  a mix at the core of this blog. The meeting is part of a continuing series of discussions on the interface between contemplative and scientific approaches to humanitys challenges. Heres one of a string of taped segments:

title: Dry Leaves, Dead Timber and Enticements for Migrating Birds
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week.

title: Leaving Bosnia (and Not)
description: There is a long and important history of memoirs and fictions, and hybrids of the two, that address the aftermath of war. Shards, the impressive first novel by Ismet Prcic, finds inventive ways to interrogate the anguish of enduring and then escaping Bosnia during the war of the 1990s.

title: Up Front: Dana Spiotta
description: In her most recent novel, Stone Arabia, Dana Spiotta used multiple voices and narrative devices to explore the slipperiness of identity and the capriciousness of memory. So too does the novel she reviews in this weeks Sunday Book Review: Shards, by Ismet Prcic, about a young mans experiences of the Bosnian war and his mental breakdown in its aftermath. Spiotta said via e-mail that she was interested in Prcics attempt to find an expressive form for a consciousness in crisis. How, she asked, does a writer describe a broken mind without reducing it to something false or reassuringly conventional? Memory is not particularly linear  it is associative, repetitive, subjective and porous. But the writer needs to convey disorder and dysfunction without making the novel itself disorderly or dysfunctional.

title: The Better Angels of Our Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: Primary Sources
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution of Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: The Design of Symbols
description: We see them in airports, hospitals and government buildings, in waiting rooms and bathrooms, on exits and entrances: schematic silhouettes of men, women and children. The graphic icons are characterized by a no-frills, geometric style that is immediately recognizable and decipherable wherever theyre found. But while the symbols are ubiquitous, few people know where they had their origins.

title: Fashion to the Rescue
description: Thinking of fighting crime but dont know what to wear? The solution may be found at the spring 2012 collection for superheroes presented by the Brooklyn Superhero Supply Co. The event, on Oct. 24 at 9 p.m. at the Ace Hotel, is a benefit for 826NYC, a nonprofit literacy organization. The contributing designers  Christian Joy, Opening Ceremony, United Bamboo, Matt Singer, Jack Spade, Renata Morales and Complex Geometries  were asked to come up with crime-fighting attire, which left the possibilities just about endless. Theres a lot of flexibility as to what a superhero will wear, says Joan Kim, the director of education at 826NYC. The Incredible Hulk just wears shorts. Some wear different accessories, some wear capes. The seven outfits will be sold at silent auction. Other designers, including Marc Jacobs and Stella McCartney, have donated pieces for the auction and raffle ($20 per ticket). Tickets are $75 for general admission, or $150, which includes an 8 p.m. cocktail party and five raffle tickets.

title: Charles Fraziers North Carolina Gothic
description: Among James Fenimore Coopers many literary offenses, Mark Twain charged, was surplusage. The words undue thickness perfectly matches its meaning. It also feels of a piece with Coopers own prose, and likewise Charles Fraziers: elegantly archaic-sounding, rough-cut and contrived.

title: Alan Hollinghurst Imagines a Fallen Poets Literary Afterlife
description: Alan Hollinghursts novels  a distinguished body of work, both daring and fastidious  have often set out to see Britains modern, decriminalized gay life against the dangers and excitements of earlier decades. The Swimming Pool Library, to take one example, showed its uninhibited young protagonist, William Beckwith, making up his mind whether or not to write the biography of the much older and necessarily more furtive Lord Nantwich. The decision-making allowed one era to resonate against the other, in a novel whose contemporary narrative voice allowed older gay literary sensibilities, like E. M. Forsters and Ronald Firbanks, to enter through echo and allusion.

title: Moby-Dick: A Display of Book Covers
description: White whales abound in this book cover collection of Herman Melvilles masterwork.

title: How to Read Moby-Dick
description: Its a hard sell Nathaniel Philbrick has undertaken in Why Read Moby-Dick? The novels plot has been recycled for decades, inspiring films, radio dramas, cartoons, comic books, a television mini-series, a couple of heavy metal albums, a music video and a rap rendition. How many potential readers approach the masterwork of Herman Melville without already knowing the story of Captain Ahab and the white whale? Any? And why would such an overly exposed audience embrace a work of such heft, especially as almost every edition carries the added weight of ponderous academic commentary? Moby-Dick would appear to be one of those unfortunate books that are taught rather than enjoyed.

title: Consultant Guilty of Grand Larceny and Money Laundering
description: Updated, 12:40 p.m. | John F. Haggerty Jr., a Republican political consultant accused of stealing $1.1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during Mr. Bloombergs 2009 re-election campaign, was found guilty of second-degree grand larceny and second-degree money laundering by a jury in Manhattan on Friday morning.

title: News Corp. to Pay $3.2 Million to Murdered Girls Family
description: Hours before Rupert Murdoch, chairman and chief executive of News Corporation, faces shareholders at the companys annual meeting, the company announced Friday that it would pay $3.2 million to the family of Milly Dowler, the murdered British teenager whose phone was hacked by News Corporations News of the World tabloid.

title: The Radical Entertainment of Harry Belafonte
description: Here is a gorgeous account of the large life of a Harlem boy, son of a Jamaican cleaning lady, Melvine Love, and a ships cook, Harold Bellanfanti, who endured the grind of poverty under the watchful eye of his proud mother and waited for his chances, prepared to be lucky, and made himself into the international calypso star and popular folk singer, huge in Las Vegas, also Europe, and a mainstay of the civil rights movement of the 60s, a confidant of Dr. Kings, who lived for years in a U-shaped 21-room apartment on West End Avenue, but never forgot what he ran so hard to escape from, the four or five families squeezed into a few rooms, the smell of Caribbean food cooking, the shared bathroom, his father drunk, yelling, blood on his hands, beating his mother, and a terrible claustrophobic closet of fear.

title: The Women of Masada
description: You could call it a hoopla sandwich. On the back cover, a blurb from a famous, widely respected author describing the novel as a major contribution to 21st-century literature. On the jacket flap, a publishers summary proclaiming this book to be the writers masterpiece. Yet in between, instead of a gripping work of fiction that lives up to this praise, is a long novel full of middling descriptions, hackneyed characters and histrionic plot twists.

title: How Deng Did It
description: Two mighty rhetorical questions conclude this enormous biography of Deng Xiaoping (1904-97): Did any other leader in the 20th century do more to improve the lives of so many? Did any other 20th-century leader have such a large and lasting influence on world history? The answers emerge from this comprehensive, minutely documented book, but not as predictably as Ezra F. Vogel, a Harvard University emeritus professor of social sciences, assumes.

title: Jos Saramago Goes Back to Genesis
description: God is a petulant, small-minded tyrant in Jos Saramagos final novel. Its protagonist, Cain, is sympathetic, a picaresque hero. But that description may give the wrong idea by implying ponderous qualities indicated by the phrase village atheist. Like that other largehearted, blasphemous comedian, Mark Twain, Saramago takes an alert interest in actual villages, and in the various villages of the mind. He perceives those literal and figurative human settlements as horrifying yet funny, a perspective that is the opposite of provincial.

title: Hitlers Last Gasp
description: By the morning of April 18, 1945, the war in Ansbach, a picturesque town in southern Germany, was just about over. With the Wehrmacht in retreat and the United States Army a few miles away, surrender seemed the only option. But Ansbachs military commander, a middle-aged air force colonel named Ernst Meyer, was determined to fight to the bitter end. In an effort to avert a catastrophe, Robert Limpert, a 19-year-old theology student, destroyed what he thought were the phone lines between the town and local army headquarters. Turned in by two members of the Hitler Youth, Limpert was arrested, summarily tried and publicly executed while a crowd of his fellow citizens, some cheering, most silent, looked on. A few hours later, after Meyer had fled and Ansbach was captured without a fight, American troops cut down Limperts body from where it had been left hanging in the town hall square.

title: Recreating the Horrors of Nanjing
description: Ha Jin has a talent for first lines. Consider these, from his latest novel, Nanjing Requiem: Finally Ban began to talk. For a whole evening we sat in the dining room listening to the boy.

title: What the Generals Did to Egypt
description: On the morning of Feb. 11, 2011, hours before Hosni Mubarak submitted to the millions of his subjects clamoring for his resignation, a half-dozen retired generals sipped coffee poolside at the Gezira Club, kitted up for tennis and contemptuously dismissed the demonstrators in Tahrir Square. Who do they represent? scoffed a man who until recently had worked in state security. They are loud, but dont forget there are 79 million Egyptians who are not in Tahrir Square. They are the majority.

title: Second Time Is No Charm as Netrebko Cancels Carnegie Hall Recital
description: The soprano Anna Netrebko has once again canceled her New York recital debut, which was scheduled for Carnegie Hall next Wednesday.

title: The Improbably Bright Future of Myanmar
description: As economies and societies all around them have flourished, two countries have been strikingly left out of the East Asian boom of the past generation: North Korea and Myanmar. The strategic importance, internal miseries and governing oddities of North Korea are obvious and frequently in the news. Myanmar, by contrast, is rarely mentioned. When it does appear, it is usually as the object of some new calamity  like the 2008 cyclone that killed over 100,000 people, many of them perishing after Myanmars benighted military rulers refused outside aid  or as the setting for dramas involving Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize winner whose party triumphed in the 1990 national elections but who has spent most of the years since then under house arrest.

title: Inside the Head of Joan of Arc
description: On Dec. 22, 1905, an Onion-like headline ran in The New York Times: Joan of Arc Appears to Startle Mark Twain. The article described how the hosts at a dinner in Twains honor had arranged for a model to arrive dressed as Joan. (Twain had long been entranced by her, and had even written a novel called Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc.) When she entered the room, the author had every appearance of a man who had seen a ghost. When he recovered, Twain said to the assembled guests: I studied that girl, Joan of Arc, for 12 years, and it never seemed to me that the artists and the writers gave us a true picture of her. They drew a picture of a peasant. . . . But they always missed the face  the divine soul, the pure character.

title: Inside the List
description: VESTED INTERESTS: Last fall, Jonathan Franzens glasses were stolen off his face at a London party for his novel Freedom. Jeffrey Eugenides may be tempting similar literary vandalism if he doesnt button up the vest he was recently seen wearing on a big billboard in Times Square advertising The Marriage Plot, which hits this weeks hardcover fiction list at No. 2. But at least the vest would be able to send news of its whereabouts, thanks to the Twitter feed @EugenidesVest, which started posting updates from its location On Jeffreys Torso on Oct. 13. In addition to grumbling about being stiffed by a certain prize committee (Jeff tells me hes been having some trouble with the National Book Awards. Something about fiction finalists and the number six.), the vest seemed none too happy with a rather tart review of The Marriage Plot that appeared recently in these pages. Theres no predicting where William Deresiewiczs wardrobe will go, the vest declared. But I see bikini thongs in his future.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE MARRIAGE PLOT,  by Jeffrey Eugenides (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Eugenidess novel, which deftly renders the patter of college intellectuals and the sweet banter of courtship, is particularly astute about the uncertainties awaiting after graduation.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MINDS EYE,  by Oliver Sacks (Vintage, $15.) In these graceful essays Sacks, a practicing neurologist, explores our potential to adapt in the face of disability  among his case studies is an accomplished musician who loses the ability to read music  and describes his own ordeal with ocular cancer.

title: Dwight Macdonalds War on Mediocrity
description: The late, great literary and social critic Dwight Macdonald (1906-82) was on the receiving end of some of the best literary insults of the 20th century. Gore Vidal said to him, You have nothing to say, only to add. Leon Trotsky reportedly declared, Every man has a right to be stupid, but comrade Macdonald abuses the privilege. Paul Goodman cracked, Dwight thinks with his typewriter.

title: Looking to the Children for Guidance in Afghanistan
description: It is a truism that children represent the future, but here in Afghanistan, that future is a very uncertain one. I have interacted with Afghan children as much as possible during the first half of my yearlong tour in eastern Afghanistan and am just as uncertain about the future of this country as when I arrived. While they have provided some of my best memories and most optimistic moments, they also have given rise to some of my deepest despair. While my experiences are by no means authoritative, I offer them as an imperfect window into Afghanistans future.

title: Q. and A. | How Facebook Use Correlates With Student Outcomes
