description: Is Facebook a worthless waste of time for students? Does it steal time and energy that they would otherwise spend on homework? Is it focusing their attention on trivia, facilitating unhealthy interactions with peers and teachers, and turning their minds to jelly?

title: Ingenuity, Gowns and Mail in Washington
description: Admirers of Andy Warhol can get a double dose of the art provocateur in Washington this fall. The National Gallery of Art will explore his take on sensational tabloid news, and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden will take in his vibrant, but enigmatic, interpretation of abstract impressionism.

title: Off the Charts: In Apparel, Inflation Is Back
description: American apparel prices, which fell rapidly early in this century and then stabilized, have begun to rise. The top two charts show consumer prices for apparel compared with late-1991 levels, and annual changes in the index. The fall in prices came as the balance of payments deficit became extremely large, as shown in the bottom chart.

title: The End of Cheap Chinese Goods
description: The great Chinese-led deflation in goods prices may have come to an end.

title: Hotels With Things That Go Bump in the Night
description: Do you believe in ghosts? Or maybe you just have an appetite for the eerie? Some hotels capitalize on what they used to keep hush-hush: rumors of haunting. Heres a Halloween sampler:

title: Inflation Out of Sight
description: Since the Great Recession began in December 2007, the overall consumer price index is up 7.5 percent, or 1.9 percent a year. But there are plenty of people who insist that the figure must understate actual inflation, citing their own impressions from visits to stores.

title: Reflections as the 55 Turns 57
description: The car reviewed for this weeks Behind the Wheel article, a 1955 Chevrolet Bel Air convertible, belongs to Paul Stenquist, a frequent contributor to the Automobiles section.

title: Then and Now
description: Matching photographs of people who live in their childhood homes, as children and as adults.

title: N.B.A. Labor Strife Now a War of Words
description: Cant we all get along?

title: Climate Study Does Not Placate Skeptics
description: As we noted on the blog on Thursday, a new study intended to address critiques of climate science by skeptics has confirmed that global warming is real and the worlds average land temperature has risen by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit since the mid-1950s.

title: News Corp.s Annual Shareholders Meeting
description: We live-blogged the annual News Corporation shareholders meeting.

title: To Greece in a Speedboat
description: MY friend Sonia, an inventive and gifted cook, splits her time between Hells Kitchen and the isle of Syros in the Cyclades. Whenever I want to whip up anything Greek, she is my go-to source. So when I had a hankering for moussaka, I called her.

title: China Charges Protectionism in Call for Solar Panel Tariffs
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government Friday condemned a demand by the American solar panel industry for steep tariffs on solar panels shipped to the United States from China.

title: The Toys Are Gone, but Its Still Home
description: DAN GEIST, 44, grew up in a one-bedroom apartment in Morningside Heights, the only child of artist parents who had arrived as renters in the late 60s. He pedaled his tricycle around the living room and swung from a tension bar in a doorway. From babyhood on he gazed from his bedroom window at a tapestry of brick, a view that looked especially moody on rainy mornings.

title: Moussaka the Traditional Way
description: In A Good Appetite, I write about a shortcut moussaka, above  a Greek friends quicker, easier version of the classic recipe.

title: Applicants Privacy Is at Heart of Lawsuit in Illinois
description: To what extent does federal law protect the privacy of a college applicants personal information?

title: Taking the Protests to the Art World
description: The Occupy Wall Street movement took on the art world, sort of, this week, with a splinter group, Occupy Museums. Convened on Thursday evening through a Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr posts, about 20 people made their way from the Museum of Modern Art to the New Museum to a downtown gallery, protesting what they say is the conflation of art and commerce, the snobbery of the art market and high ticket prices at museums, which they called the temples of the cultural elite.

title: Volcker Rule, Once Simple, Now Boggles
description: When Paul Volcker called for new rules in 2009 to curb risk-taking by banks, and thus avoid making taxpayers liable in the future for the kind of reckless speculation that caused the financial crisis and resulting bailout, he outlined his proposal in a three-page letter to the president.

title: Stage Version of Shakespeare in Love Moving Ahead
description: Shakespeare in Love, the 1998 romantic comedy that won seven Academy Awards, including best picture and acting honors for Gwyneth Paltrow and Judi Dench, is the latest film being eyed for adaptation to the stage. Two leading producers, Disney Theatrical Productions and the British impresario Sonia Friedman, have been holding meetings with the playwright Tom Stoppard  who shared an original screenplay Oscar for Shakespeare in Love with Marc Norman  and the director Jack OBrien about the project, according to theater executives familiar with the creative discussions.

title: Spring Ahead | The Head Scarf
description: A snapshot of springs best trends and a hint at what youll want to wear next year.

title: A Risky Investment, Made Unwittingly
description: ALLEGATIONS of financial fraud have, unfortunately, become all too common in this economic downturn. But one of the latest seems worth particular note since it involves a former national chairman of the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, who pushed the group to adopt a policy that requires members to act in the best interests of their clients and to disclose any conflicts of interest.

title: The Caucus | The Web Video Primary
description: Oct. 21, 2011 - Some of the fiercest back and forth of the campaign is taking place in Web videos but will soon come to TV screens. Also, a report on Mitt Romney's tentative return to Iowa.

title: Five Minutes at CMJ With Pterodactyl
description: ArtsBeat will be talking to some of the acts that are in New York this week to play the CMJ Music Marathon.

title: Islands Inhabitants? Clearly Not Natives
description: MOST of the classic horror films of the early 1930s have been released and rereleased on home video to the point of surfeit and beyond. But one, in many ways the most disturbing, has remained elusive: Erle C. Kentons 1932 Island of Lost Souls, an adaptation of H. G. Wellss novel The Island of Dr. Moreau so extreme in its effects that Wells himself denounced it. The film was banned in Britain until 1958, when the censors finally passed it with an X rating.

title: Before You Hand Over Your Money for Investing
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about a Seattle investment adviser who is accused of committing securities fraud when he put his clients money into investments in private companies without their consent. One reason that Paul wrote about the case is that the adviser, Mark Spangler, is a former chairman of the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, a group that requires its members to act in their clients best interests.

title: Steve Jobs Biography: A Scorecard of Put-Downs
description: Every authorized biography includes some score-settling by its subject. Steven P. Jobs, the late Apple co-founder and subject of Walter Isaacsons new book, Steve Jobs, proves no different.

title: Caucus Video: The Web Video Primary
description: Some of the fiercest back and forth of the campaign is taking place in Web videos but will soon come to TV screens. Also, a report on Mitt Romneys tentative return to Iowa.

title: Weekend Fare
description: More than 300 varieties of sakes, many which are usually unavailable in the United States, will be poured for tasting Friday from 6 to 9 p.m. at the Joy of Sake event being held at the Altman Building, 135 West 18th Street (Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue), in Chelsea. Tickets are $90 in advance, available online, or $100 at the door.

title: Rescued by Design
description: IJOINED the line to get into the United Nations the other day, fiddling with my iPhone before shuffling through security. The couple in back (he was toting an iPad) mused about what a design guru Steve Jobs had been. They headed toward the information desk and I toward Design With the Other 90 Percent: Cities, an infelicitously titled but inspired show organized by the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum and now installed (since the museum is closed for renovations) in the United Nations visitors lobby.

title: Present Company Included
description: ONCE upon a time, in the magical land of ballet, a company was born. The brainchild of the hottest choreographer of the day and a charismatic former ballerina, the fledgling troupe burst onto the worlds grand stages, promising to haul classical ballet into the contemporary realm.

title: Bridgewaters Dalio: I Think I Did Everything Right
description: Ray Dalio, the founder of Bridgewater Associates, didnt used to do many media appearances. But a series of big magazine profiles that focused on the intense culture of his Connecticut-based hedge fund seem to have eased the billionaire out of his shell.

title: In Liverpool, New Cool on the Waterfront
description: A downtown revitalization has brought cultural vigor to the waterfront.

title: Big Ticket | Park Ave. Co-op Is Sale of Week
description: The most expensive apartment sale of the week in Manhattan, according to property records, was a 15-room, 6-bedroom co-op at 625 Park Avenue that had an asking price of $29.75 million  although the final sale price could not be confirmed before publication.

title: Susan Orlean on her book, Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend; Steven Heller discusses his latest Visuals column; best-seller news.
description: This week, author Susan Orlean explores the life of a canine icon in her book, Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend; Steven Heller talks about his latest Visuals column; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Fennel Fills In for Salads in Fall
description: THOUGH the colorful salads of summer (remember tomatoes, cucumbers, and peppers?) are justly loved, a salad in autumn  or any cold season  is a thrill. Leafy salads have their place, yes, but so do salads with no leaves or minimal leaves. Cooked vegetables make fine salads this time of year, bathed with oil and vinegar. Think beets, potatoes, carrots, artichokes. But raw vegetables can make salads that are fresh and crisp.

title: Romneys Premature Perry Panic
description: Mitt Romney has run a smooth, low-drama campaign so far, but its aggressive posture toward Rick Perry within the past week leaves me wondering about his strategic choices.

title: Fox Outbids ESPN for World Cup Rights
description: Fox and Telemundo, the Spanish-language network that is a division of NBC Universal, won the American television rights to broadcast soccers World Cup in 2018 and 2022, according to soccer and television officials.

title: U.S. Troops to Leave Iraq by Years End, Obama Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced on Friday that the last American soldier would leave Iraq by the end of this year, drawing to a close a divisive eight-year war that cost the lives of more than 4,400 troops, defined the presidency of George W. Bush, and helped ignite his own political rise.

title: Brush Up Your Shakespeare, or Whoever
description: LOS ANGELES

title: At CMJ, a Critics Imagination Come to Life, Out of Alabama
description: Imagine a CMJ buzz band not built around some cool-headed concept involving noise or irony or ambiguities or primitivism. Imagine a band not trying to make a fashion or anti-fashion statement. Imagine a band whose vocals arent just something to put up with because thats the songwriter singing. Imagine a band named after a place that actually comes from that place. And imagine a band whose New York City debut left a CMJ Music Marathon audience literally screaming for joy.

title: Clinton Widens Audience in Pakistan, but Sticks to Tough Message
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton invited questions from a selected group of Pakistanis here on Friday, a woman in the audience humorously captured the essence of a very troubled relationship, at least from Pakistans point of view.

title: BPs Plan for Drilling in the Gulf Is Approved
description: HOUSTON  The Obama administration on Friday took another step toward allowing BP to return to the Gulf of Mexico, approving the first oil drilling plan for the company there since the explosion that sank the Deepwater Horizon rig more than a year ago.

title: Turning a Loft Into Something Cozy
description: Heather Chaplin has worked hard to turn her loft in Park Slope, Brooklyn into a cozy, ladylike home.

title: How to Tame a Loft: Add Lace, Talk Trollope
description: THE story of Heather Chaplin and her loft in Park Slope, Brooklyn, started auspiciously. Ms. Chaplin, a writer, and her husband, Aaron Ruby, a graduate student in philosophy, had been a couple since 1993. In 2000, the year they married, they spent $400,000 on an 1,800-square-foot loft in a building soon to be erected on 11th Street near Sixth Avenue.

title: Fees Help Drive Working Poor From Banks
description: 3:22 p.m. | Updated Due to technical difficulties, this post was published with the wrong date. It was published on Oct. 27.

title: Trailer: 'Dragonslayer'
description: A preview of Tristan Patterson's documentary "Dragonslayer," about the skateboarder Josh Sandoval, a k a Skreech.

title: Oct. 23  29
description: Theater

title: When Bach Laid Bare His Own Soul
description: ON the cover of his recent recording of Bachs partitas and sonatas for unaccompanied violin Sergey Khachatryan is shrouded in darkness, head tilted back, eyes raised piously and hands pressed together above his instrument. The image is an apt representation of the reverence that musicians, scholars and listeners often bring to a discussion of these monumental works.

title: Still Wondering If Liszt Was Any Good
description: ON Oct. 22, 1811, Franz Liszt was born in the Hungarian (now Austrian) village of Raiding. His bicentenary follows hard on the heels of Chopins, last year, and anticipates Wagners and Verdis, in 2013.

title: Obama Announces Troops Will Come Home From Iraq by Years End
description: President Obama announced that the United States has fulfilled its commitment in Iraq and will bring all American troops home by the end of the year. As promised, the rest of our troops in Iraq will come home by the end of the year, Mr. Obama said.

title: Evan Wolfson and Cheng He
description: EVAN WOLFSON can recall being 10 or 11 when, while watching television with his mother, he turned to her and told her he didnt think hed ever get married.

title: What Is a Banker Worth? Here Is One Answer
description: It has been argued in certain circles that Wall Street is worthless. Unproductive. Devoid of social value.

title: NBC Sports May Leave Rockefeller Plaza for Connecticut
description: NBC Sports may be heading out of its long-time home at 30 Rockefeller Plaza in New York.

title: London Protesters Asked to Leave St. Pauls Cathedral
description: LONDON  Less than a week after they set up camp in Londons financial district, British anticapitalist protesters have been asked to leave.

title: Retirement Funds Built for Skittish Times
description: You must unlearn what you have learned.

title: Theater Talkback: I Could Read a Book
description: You might expect that someone who spends his time watching, writing about, living and breathing theater 52 weeks a year would prefer to turn to other subjects when it comes to the pastime of leisure reading. Perhaps some molecular biology? And its true that for sheer diversion, or post-season recovery, I do try to avoid books that feel like homework. My new discovery  and obsession  is the British writer Angela Thirkell, who wrote more than a dozen frothy light comedies about English country life, many set in Anthony Trollopes fictional Barsetshire.

title: Look of The Moment | Kate Bosworth
description: The Look: Electric Lady  Southern California palms are the perfect backdrop for zebra stripes and a sunny, citrus yellow combo. A brown pencil skirt and coral lipstick complete the tropical palette.

title: Rawls on Wall Street
Qaddafis Faustian Bargain
description: Editors Note: Since the start of the Libyan revolution, Robert F. Worth has written two stories for the magazine. The first, On Libyas Revolutionary Road, was published in April; the second, The Surreal Ruins of Qaddafis Never-Never Land, appeared in our Sept. 25 issue. Since the news broke of Qaddafis death, Worth has been reporting for the paper, but took time out to put together these thoughts below:

title: 1969 Chevrolet Blazer Commercial
description: The Blazer was introduced as a blend of car and truck.

title: For Those With Less, One Less 9 From Cain
description: Herman Cain, who has said simplicity is one of the greatest virtues of his 9-9-9 tax plan, added an asterisk on Friday.

title: DirecTV and News Corp. at Odds Over Fees
description: Another battle between a cable channel owner and a major distributor has spilled into public view.

title: Pimco, Yoda and Some Big Retirement Savings Questions
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I look at Pimcos fledgling effort to break into the target-date fund segment of the mutual funds industry, an area dominated by Vanguard, Fidelity and T. Rowe Price, which sell these funds to administrators of 401(k) and similar workplace retirement plans.

title: New Vistas for Burmese Artists
description: OH, please let me go to heaven!

title: A New Destination for Food and Art in Sonoma
description: CLOSE to midnight one Saturday in Sebastopol, in Sonoma County, California, fog rolled in from the nearby Pacific Ocean, encompassing the town in thick, cool mist. Inside an old apple cannery, though, revelers were in a different sort of haze  one produced by the cacophonous sounds of a funk band.

title: Hotel Review: Bella Sky Comwell in Copenhagen
description: THE UPSHOT

title: New Design on Croatias Coast
description: THE coastal town of Rovinj, on the undulating Istrian peninsula of Croatia, is no stranger to tourism, in large part thanks to its lush natural surroundings. Its fir-forested campgrounds are packed with R.V.s bearing Austrian and German plates. Its rocky coves are claimed by staycationing Croatians slipping in and out of the cerulean Adriatic.

title: Searching for Flights
description: Searching for Flights

title: A Man, a Bike and 4,100 Miles
description: IF you can be said to be hurrying on a cross-country bicycle trip, for about two weeks I hurried to Pittsburgh. I pushed through some dreary weather in Michigan and Ohio, climbed the roller-coaster foothills of the Appalachians and battled traffic and chewed up roads as I entered the city. From there, though, with the end of a ride that began almost three months ago looming, I slowed down and started on an oblique route home.

title: Coast-to-Coast
description: As the author hits the homestretch of his cross-country cycling trip, the final miles beckon and loom.

title: Ode to Autumn Salad
description: I always want salad, maybe even more so this time of year. But the season is changing, and so are the ingredients in my salad bowl. Right now, there is fragrant, crisp fennel bulb available, so in this weeks City Kitchen, were making the simplest fennel salad imaginable, dressed with olive oil and lemon.

title: Tim Burton Balloon to Spook Macys Parade
description: Halloween may be just around the corner, but its another holiday, Thanksgiving, thats looking spooky.

title: American Forces in Iraq and Afghanistan
description: Interactive chart of American troops in Iraq and Afghanistan since 2001.

title: Rangers Win Carries Fox
description: While final Nielsen numbers were not immediately available on Friday, preliminary estimates suggest that Game 2 of the World Series between the Texas Rangers and the St. Louis Cardinals carried Fox to an overall ratings victory on Thursday night in all categories. A pitching duel capped by a ninth-inning Texas comeback drew in more viewers as the night went on with the Rangers ultimately winning, 2-1.

title: Hints of Apple Plans in Jobs Book
description: 3:03 a.m. | Updated Adding one other future business opportunity mentioned in the Jobs biography.

title: Going to an Art Fair: What It Takes
description: Art Basel Miami Beach officially rolls into southern Florida on Dec. 1 this year, marking its 10th incarnation with more art and more flair than ever. When the show started in 2002, no one knew whether it would secure a place on the art circuit. But the jitters of planting a prestigious art fair in a place known mostly for beaches and bars faded within minutes of the V.I.P. opening. Collectors from all over the map showed up, and browsers and partiers soon followed.

title: Living In | College Point, Queens
description: A Queens neighborhood with lots of natural beauty has at times been the victim of its geographical remoteness.

title: Attention, Shore Lovers
description: AS a name, College Point is something of a head-scratcher. Like Bowling Green or Canal Street, it is the kind of name that may once have been apt but seems now to have little bearing on reality.

title: Design for the Poor. (And Yes, This Is Serious.)
description: I write in Sundays Arts & Leisure section about an ambitious and excellent design show devoted to what might seem like an unlikely topic: improving slum conditions in some of the poorest parts of the world.

title: Pitching Green
description: A video from Safeco Field, home of the Seattle Mariners, where teaching fans about composting their beer cups isnt always easy.

title: Dinah Shore and the 1953 Chevrolet
description: Dinah Shore was the voice of Chevrolet for years.

title: Are Dead Trees More Combustible Than Live Ones?
description: As Justin Gillis explained at length in an Oct. 1 article, huge tracts of forest are dying across the West and around the world as a result of infestations and other phenomena that many link to climate change. A big question for those who manage forests is how these millions of acres of dead trees will respond to wildfire.

title: At Brooklyn Borough Hall, a Banner for Libyans
description: Few are the occasions in life that do not warrant celebration by the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz.

title: 1962 Chevrolet Corvair
description: The Corvair was a promising small car for General Motors.

title: Recession-Ravaged Yards, Inviting Skaters to Drop In
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Police Reports on Zanesville, Ohio, Reserve
description: The Muskingum County Sheriffs Department released police reports dating back to 2004 detailing the departments interactions with Terry Thompson, and his wife, Marian.

title: Corporate Governance Issues Grow More Complex
description: Its time to take stock of the corporate governance movement.

title: Netflix Says Stop the Presses!
description: Since taking over in March, writing the Talk Q. and A. hasnt been exactly what you could call a white-knuckle experience. Since the pages of The New York Times Magazine close more than a week before they hit newsstands, we cant outrun the news. So this weeks interview with the C.E.O. of Netflix, Reed Hastings, provided some rare deadline drama. On Oct. 6, just as we were putting the finishing touches on the interview for the Oct. 16 issue, I got an e-mail from Netflix with the subject line URGENT. If the magazine ran the interview with Hastings as planned, The New York Times would look foolish. My contact refused to offer me any specifics about what was afoot, but he said I would understand early the following week. He was good on his word. The initial interview  in which Hastings provided his justification for spinning off the disc-only service of his company into Qwikster  would have made us look pretty dopey had we published almost a week after Netflix announced that it was ditching Qwikster altogether. So we quickly put moved up our Melissa McCarthy interview to run in Hastingss place. Hastings talked to me three days after the Qwikster mercy killing and I drew the entirety of this weeks column from that one interview. But heres one exchange from that earlier interview thats worth rescuing.

title: Spring Ahead | Digital Prints
description: A snapshot of springs best trends and a hint at what youll want to wear next year.

title: Friendly and Free (and Going Across the Country)
description: A free ride and a friendly driver arent necessarily what New Yorkers who travel by taxi expect. But thats exactly what the author and television personality Leon Logothetis will be offering on Monday, as he begins an 11-city, 21-day cross-country road trip.

title: Famous Fans Name Their Favorite Chevys
description: THE Times asked several noted car enthusiasts to name their favorite Chevys of all time. Here are their selections:

title: A Century of Chevy, From Cheap Date to Americas Sweetheart
description: Its Impalas dropped us off at school. Its pickup trucks hauled our produce on the farm. Its Corvette sustained our sports car fantasies through the boredom of high school algebra class. Earlier than almost any other automotive brand, Chevy created a palette of vehicles that ranged from the small and thrifty to the sleek and sporty to the large and smartly trimmed.

title: A Fabulously 50s Way to See the U.S.A.
description: Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: 1967 Chevrolet Camaro
description: The Camaro competed with the success of the Ford Mustang.

title: Restoring an Old Farm Tractor Yields a Championship for a Texas Teenager
description: As the Texas Rangers head home for Game No. 3 of the World Series, one young Texan is already returning from the Midwest a champion.

title: Yankees Caps Appear in Odd Places, Including Libya
description: Ball caps travel far and wide. They do far more than keep the sun out of your eyes or the cold off your head. Ball caps are a statement.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 35
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the city was going to start taking a harder line on demonstrators camping out in Zuccotti Park and insist on marching permits. [Daily Politics]

title: Making Sure No Guest Is Forgotten
description: ON a recent Saturday evening at the Harold Pratt House in New York, Terry deRoy Gruber stood on a ladder and peered through the lens of a 25-pound wood-framed camera perched atop a 10-foot tripod.

title: Five Minutes at CMJ with Bleached
description: ArtsBeat will be talking to some of the acts that are in New York this week to play the CMJ Music Marathon.

title: Richards Gets His Own Goal, and More
description: Dane Richards did score a goal on a header after all.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, Yemen, Libya and Australia.

title: Restoring Natural History
description: The Hall of North American Mammals at the American Museum of Natural History is getting an unprecedented makeover.

title: Contemporary and Boston, Opposites No Longer
description: Theres one thing Ive heard over and over again here, says Edward Saywell, the top contemporary art curator at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, who is showing off works by Ellsworth Kelly, Kara Walker, Cindy Sherman and other contemporary artists in his domain, including many new ones. They say, This cant be Boston, and I say, Yes, it really is.

title: Selling the Sparkle as the Stars Twinkle
description: No auction this season is likely to generate headlines like those from the sale of Elizabeth Taylors gems. Her own fascination with jewels and mens fascination with the violet-eyed actress helped her assemble one of the worlds great collections, many pieces replete with romantic history, like La Prgrina, a 500-year-old pear-shaped pearl that she had Cartier fashion into a necklace with rubies and diamonds, and the wedding bands from her two marriages to Richard Burton.

title: Art and Culture to Admire, and Wrap Up for the Holidays
description: Museums are not just about learning and culture. Increasingly they are becoming shopping places for the committed consumer. As the holidays approach and New Yorkers are overwhelmed with family, friends, gift-buying and entertaining, museum gift shops are an obvious stop.

title: Performance, Indoors and Out
description: Live performance will be erupting, and possibly disrupting, New York for three weeks starting Nov. 1, when Performa 11, a  performance art biennial, begins its fourth season. The events, mostly free and including a shamanistic dating show at El Museo del Barrio and a medieval-style rap joust at Marlborough Chelsea, will take place in theater, gallery and museum spaces as well as curbside.

title: For Photos, Collector Casts a Global Net
description: If Jo Ractliffes star has risen on the international art circuit during the last year, it is in many ways because of the support of the German collector Artur Walther.

title: Extreme Museum: The Rigors of Contemplation
description: The questions have been grievous, the moral issues weighty. How far should I be prepared to go in the pursuit of high-minded criticism of exhibitions and museums? Was I obligated to munch on the Cajun-fried crickets offered at New Orleanss Insectarium in order to get the full flavor of the place? Were my perceptions off kilter if I was the only visitor to an exhibition about the history of tattoos in Philadelphia who didnt have one of his own? Was I being unfair to Coca-Colas self-celebratory museum in Atlanta because I found the highlights were soda samples it offered from around the world? Was I overly fair to the Creation Museum in Kentucky, which treated the Bible as natural history and natural history as myth, when I marveled at its skewed alternate universe?

title: Rendezvous With Art and Ardent
description: With so many museums, exhibits, art galleries and lectures to choose from every day, how does a busy young arts professional keep up? For Francesca Merlino and about two dozen of her colleagues who work for museums and arts groups in New York City, its following each others 140-character updates on Twitter and the hashtag, #artstech.

title: Staying Up Late at Museums
description: Darcey Howard had her reasons for showing up at the Rubin Museum of Art in her pajamas. Seeing the Himalayan paintings and multilayered manuscript pages was not one of them.

title: Museum Mind
description: Edward Rothstein reflects on the hazards of being an art critic.

title: Islamic Objects of Desire
description: Despite the current trend for abbreviated titles and short, snappy messages, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is calling its majestic suite of 15 newly renovated spaces, which open on Nov. 1, the New Galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia. Its a mouthful but an intentional one. The curators there are trying to underscore the diversity, richness and interconnectedness of the arts that reflect a melting pot of different cultures.

title: Latin American Art, Rediscovered Again
description: In November, the Art Dealers Association of America will start its new season of collector forums with Latin American Art in Global Collections at the Morgan Library and Museum. The panel will be timed to the Pinta, a Latin American Art fair now in its fifth year that coincides with Christies and Sothebys Latin American art auctions. Also next month, the Museum of Modern Art will open an exhibition devoted to Diego Riveras murals. Five years ago, the museum appointed its first curator of Latin American art.

title: Beneath an Abstract Painting, a Mystery Is Revealed
description: Preserving and cleaning paintings at a museum is often a relatively straightforward, not to say dull, affair. But sometimes a compelling flesh-and-blood story awaits beneath a layer of oil and varnish.

title: New Yorks City Kids, Across the Centuries

title: Giving Up the Guilty Pleasure of Toddlers & Tiaras
description: Anderson Cooper invited some of the stars and their mothers of the TLC reality series Toddlers & Tiaras onto his daytime talk show yesterday. If you missed the broadcast and are, as Ive been, quasi-obsessed with T&T, you can catch a few riveting scenes on his Web site.

title: Denver Hedge Fund Manager Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
description: A Denver hedge fund manager pleaded guilty on Friday afternoon to insider trading charges. Appearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Drew K. Bo Brownstein admitted to netting nearly $2.5 million in illegal profits after trading on an insider stock tip about a pending acquisition of Mariner Energy by the Apache Corporation.

title: Europeans Seek Bold Debt Deal, Despite Differences
description: PARIS  European leaders were struggling on Friday to craft a bolder solution to the regions financial crisis, despite clear signals from French and German officials that they have sharp differences heading into an important weekend summit meeting in Brussels.

title: African Union Peacekeepers Killed in Somalia Battle
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  As Islamist militants displayed scores of blood-soaked bodies, the African Union on Friday acknowledged that its peacekeeping force in Somalia had sustained heavy casualties in its battle against the Shabab, the deadly insurgent group squaring off against a multipronged assault by troops from Kenya, Uganda, Burundi, the Somali government and local militias.

title: Bachmanns N.H. Campaign Manager Confirms He Is Leaving
description: UPDATED 4:50 p.m. Jeff Chidester, the New Hampshire campaign manager for Representative Michele Bachmann, confirmed Friday afternoon that he was leaving the campaign, capping an unusual day of mixed signals that revealed a breakdown in communication between Mrs. Bachmann and her New Hampshire staff.

title: At Loi, the Compass Points to Greece
description: When Maria Loi, a vivacious, entrepreneurial Greek chef, restaurateur, cookbook writer and teacher, came to New York this summer, she talked a great deal about how her restaurant, Loi, which is opening tonight, would show the city how Greek food should be prepared.

description: In Sundays Book Review, Jennifer Schuessler reviews Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend by The New Yorker writer Susan Orlean. title: Spot the Other Artistic Giant on the Cover
description: In this weeks magazine, Sam Anderson delves into the bewitching universe of the literary powerhouse Haruki Murakami, whose new book, 1Q84, will be released in North America on Oct. 25. Before you become completely distracted by Murakamis unforgettable characters and layered cultural references, take a moment to notice the photographs contributed by a second artistic giant  the acclaimed Japanese photographer Nobuyoshi Araki. He took the gorgeous, tightly-focused black-and-white portraits of Murakami.

description: Last Saturday, I saw what I bet was the first reality fashion show of the 21st century at New Yorks first Tweed Run. The event was a bicycle ride in which people dressed in the style of 1930s.

description: WASHINGTON  For all its success, NATOs intervention in Libya had several significant flaws that highlight why future offensives, against a stronger adversary, could be far more difficult.

title: His Life After Riverdance Is a Braid of Traditions
description: Near the end of his solo show Out of Time, the Irish step dancer Colin Dunne shares some old video of himself. In it he is a world champion. He is on television. He is 10. He responds awkwardly to stock questions. He holds up his chin as he dances expertly, stiff and orthodox. The moment is awfully cute, but also disturbing in context. You worry about what will happen to that boy, and what already has.

description: Six cases of childhood measles have been reported in Brooklyn over the last two weeks, the New York City health department said Friday, contributing to a spike in measles cases this year.

title: Flaunting Virtuosity (and More)
description: The 24-year-old Chinese pianist Yuja Wang is not above flaunting her uncanny virtuosity. A video of her effortless performance of a seemingly impossible transcription of Flight of the Bumblebee has gone viral on YouTube. And though she comes across onstage as somewhat shy, Ms. Wang has a flair for fashion.

The 55 models were a breakthrough in styling, performance and refinement that set the stage for Chevys starring role in American life for decades.

title: Lovelorn and Seeking a Bailout for the Heart
description: THOSE who think that love and protest politics are mutually exclusive are encouraged to view the YouTube video from Occupy Wall Street of a young man on bended knee in Zuccotti Park proposing marriage (Deb, will you occupy my life?) to his girlfriend. The following poems about the romantic repercussions of the demonstrations were found this month in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; the titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

title: After a Quake, 2 Yardsticks for Nuclear Inspectors
description: Once the dust had settled after the Aug. 23 earthquake centered in Mineral, Va., the tweet-length description of the problem at the North Anna nuclear plant was that the ground motion was bigger than what the reactors were designed to deal with, which is highly unusual.

title: Ohio Governor Signs Order Seeking to Curb Animal Cruelty
description: Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio signed an executive order on Friday that he said might have prevented the man accused of releasing dozens of tigers, lions and other animals this week from being allowed to keep the animals because of his history of animal cruelty and neglect.

title: Protesters of Police Stop-and-Frisk Practice Are Arrested
description: About 30 people, including the civil rights campaigner and Princeton professor Cornel West, were arrested Friday outside a police station in Harlem during a protest of the police practice known as stop-and-frisk.

title: From Walden Pond to the Olympics, Swimmer Thrives in Open Water
description: CONCORD, Mass.  Wading into Walden Pond, Alex Meyer did not exactly find an idyllic sanctuary, a spot where ones solitude is broken only by birdsong.

title: All for One, and Then Maybe a Sequel
description: The campy new screen adaptation of The Three Musketeers has all the reality and visceral excitement of a $75 million literary theme park dotted with fancy villages heavily patrolled by security. In the screenplay by Alex Litvak (Predators) and Andrew Davies (the television adaptation of Little Dorrit), the historical re-enactors of European life in the 17th century speak a wooden dialect that is half flowery mumbo-jumbo from countless swashbuckling Hollywood pseudo epics, and half contemporary slang. Although I dont remember hearing the word dude, it might have slipped in.

title: Improving How We Care for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Ways to Fix a Slow PC
description: It seems to happen to most Windows users: You buy a new desktop or laptop PC. It runs fast. But a few months later, youre sure its slower than it used to be. Ask for help on the Internet or in real life, and you usually get one of two answers: you must have downloaded a virus, or you need to defragment your hard drive. Bad advice. You probably dont have a virus, and Windows doesnt need you to run the defragmenting tool yourself these days. Your problems lie elsewhere.

title: TimesCast | Watching Qaddafi Footage
description: October 21, 2011 - Gruesome videos of Col. Qaddafi's capture are replaying on TV and on the web. Stuart Fischoff, a psychologist who specializes in media research, explains why many can't turn away.

title: This Sunday: Doorstops! Doorstops! Get Your Doorstops Here!
description: There are two big books sitting on my desk, and if I were the kind of editor I dream of being, Id have read them both already. As it is, I can only claim to have read the shorter of the two volumes, Daniel Kahnemans Thinking Fast and Slow, which is only 418 pages (not including appendices and index), a twee little thing compared to Haruki Murakamis 925-page beast 1Q84.

title: Why State Senator Alesi, Supporter of Gay Marriage, Voted No in 09
description: Last week, a panel discussion at The New York Times offered an unusual insiders view of the fight for passage of a bill legalizing same-sex marriage.

title: Running Out of Bandwidth
description: AT a time of slow economic growth and declining competitiveness, wireless technology remains a shining example of innovation. In the last 10 years, wireless communications companies in the United States have invested hundreds of billions of dollars and unleashed a torrent of new products.

title: Puerto Ricos Proposed Via Verde Pipeline Faces Strong Opposition
description: Critics say a proposed natural gas pipeline across Puerto Rico will cause too much environmental damage.

title: TimesCast | U.S. Withdrawal from Iraq
description: October 21, 2011 - President Obama announces the withdrawal of all American troops from Iraq by the end of the year.

title: Another Month, Another Premiere
description: PHILADELPHIA  Does a month go by without some kind of premiere by the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky? In April the Bolshoi danced the world premiere of his three-act Lost Illusions; in May American Ballet Theater presented the world premiere of Dumbarton, and in June, its first New York performances of his full-length Bright Stream; in July the Mariinsky Ballet gave New York its first view of his Anna Karenina and Little Humpbacked Horse; and in September the Paris Opera Ballet gave the world premiere of Psych, based on the Greek myth. On Thursday the Pennsylvania Ballet presented the North American premiere of Mr. Ratmanskys Jeu de Cartes. It would be nice to think the guy took August off as a well-earned vacation, but I wouldnt bank on it.

title: Guys Guy, Keeping the Kegs Flowing
description: At the rate Nashville is emasculating, you can practically call Dierks Bentley one of the tough guys these days. Hes not a fighter, or a self-loather, or much of a mean talker, but theres a steady flow of insouciance running through his songs, a sense of lawlessness as experienced by someone who is very mindful of the law, and would like to dodge it just a bit, if thats O.K. with you.

title: Timescast | NATO's Libyan Legacy
description: As NATO's mission in Libya is complete, did it meet or exceed its mandate?

title: Nightclubs to Nightcaps: Celebrating a Genre
description: The resilience of the New York Cabaret Convention, the annual showcase of nightclub talent from around the country that is celebrating its 22nd year, speaks for itself. That longevity may be the surest sign in an unstable economic climate that the citys venerable but fragile cabaret tradition is not about to bite the dust.

title: Excerpt: 'Once Upon a Time'
description: The new ABC drama is based on fairy tales.

title: Maazel, a Baton From the Past, Returns for a Visit to the Philharmonic
description: The return of Lorin Maazel to the New York Philharmonic podium for the first time since his departure as music director in 2009 has been a dull blast from the past.

title: Google Said to Add Social Element for Music
description: Googles plan for an MP3 store to rival iTunes and Amazon.com will be connected to its social network, Google+, and will allow users to share the music they buy with friends, according to four people with knowledge of Googles plans.

title: Excerpt: 'Grimm'
description: The new NBC series is about a detective with supernatural powers.

title: The Enchanted Forest, in Sunshine and Shadow
description: Maybe the networks knew it wasnt going to be a fairy-tale fall season  unless they made it so! That could explain the premieres of two series within a week  ABCs Once Upon a Time, on Sunday, and NBCs Grimm, on Friday  that are explicitly inspired by the Brothers Grimm and the folklore they collected.

title: Fox and Telemundo Win U.S. Rights to World Cups
description: For a record sum of about $1 billion, Fox and the Spanish-language network Telemundo won the rights to broadcast the 2018 and 2022 World Cups in the United States, television executives said Friday, demonstrating the steady and diverse growth of soccer in America.

title: Woman Trying to Shield Children Is Killed by Gunman
description: A mother picking up her child was shot to death across the street from a school in Brownsville, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon as she tried to protect several children from a gunman on a rooftop who opened fire on a group of rivals on a crowded street, the police said.

title: Facing an Impossible Contract
description: VELDHOVEN, The Netherlands  With only three rounds of the qualifying stage remaining, all six United States teams look likely to make the quarterfinals at the world team championships, which will begin on Sunday.

title: Bloggingheads: Obama's Nixon Moment
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Matt Lewis of The Daily Caller debate about Qaddafi's death and Obama's foreign policy.

title: Republican Plan Would Not Help Economy, Firm Projects
description: Senate Republicans proposed jobs package would not reduce unemployment or spur the economys growth in the next year or two, according to a leading economic forecasting firm that has predicted that President Obamas plan would achieve both goals.

title: Out From Behind the Counter
The Ugliness Started With Bork
description: On Oct. 23, 1987  24 years ago on Sunday  Robert Borks nomination to the Supreme Court was voted down by the Senate. All but two Democrats voted nay.

title: Seeds for New York: The Lawn Guy
description: A SEED, to most people, is an inscrutable thing, a closed box waiting to be unpacked. But for Ed Toth, the director of New York Citys native plant center on Staten Island, it is a wide-open window, with a view stretching back to the last Ice Age and forward into the future.

title: Ruling Backs Forest Service in Limiting Roads in the Wild
description: DENVER  More than a decade after the Clinton administration proposed cordoning off tens of millions of acres of public lands in the West from road development, setting off a ferocious debate about wilderness and human uses of the land, a federal appeals court in Denver upheld the governments authority on Friday in a sweeping rejection of the opposition.

title: At a Polite CMJ, Trash Talks Aggression Is a Relief
description: Some things happen at Trash Talk shows that dont happen at other CMJ shows. Theirs is the show most likely to start at an insanely late hour, the show where you are most likely to get punched in the head by the lead singer, the show where you are most likely to receive a flier marked #OCCUPYCMJ bemoaning the stranglehold of corporations over various aspects of the music business, from retail outlets to radio to touring.

title: Bachmanns Lack of Big Donors Could Hinder Campaign
description: There is a reason candidates court big donors. Yes, they have more money. But more important, the net share of their donations is far greater than from low-dollar donors.

title: Battle of the Borders
description: It is probably safe to bet that the tradition of heated arguments over immigration began millennia ago, when the first country drew a line in the sand. But the past week in the United States of America has been a hot one, at least by any recent comparison.

title: Turkey and Iran Agree to Cooperate Against Kurdish Rebels on Borders
description: Turkey and Iran agreed Friday to cooperate against separatist Kurdish violence along their borders, while thousands of Turkish troops began the second day of a major offensive against Kurdish rebels in southeastern Turkey and Iraq. Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu, speaking at a news conference with his Iranian counterpart, Ali Akbar Salehi, said Turkey and Iran would share intelligence and convene a joint security council. We will work together in a common action plan until we entirely eradicate this threat of terrorism, Mr. Davutoglu said.

title: Raiders Saying Little About Immediate Plans for Palmer, Who Faces Obstacles
description: ALAMEDA, Calif.  The sound bite was fun, and that is surely why it was heard so often on radio shows and television news reports after the Oakland Raiders completed their trade for Carson Palmer.

title: Senate, at Least for a Day, Gets Back to Legislating
description: WASHINGTON  As if compensating for months of inaction, the Senate kicked into gear around midnight Thursday and kept working early Friday as it shelved another piece of President Obamas economic agenda and, in a bold experiment, tried using traditional legislative give-and-take to move a spending bill for half a dozen cabinet departments.

title: Malis Regional Rhythms and Ambitious Math-Rock
description: Crooked Fingers

title: Spycraft Dispensed With Appropriate, Deliberate Speed
description: DO you know whats killing Western democracy, George? Greed. And constipation. Moral, political, aesthetic. I hate America very deeply. The economic repression of the masses institutionalized.

title: Manfred Gerlach, East German Head of State, Dies at 83
description: Manfred Gerlach, East Germanys last head of state and the first politician outside the ruling Communist Party to hold that position, died on Monday in Berlin. He was 83.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Officials struggled to address the European debt crisis; the cause of the listeria outbreak linked to tainted cantaloupe was pinpointed; and Apple paid tribute to Steve Jobs with song and speech.

title: Back to Chevys Future
description: The 1955 Bel Air signaled a turning point for Chevrolet, bringing style and class to the low-price market.

title: Tough Sell
description: How does it feel to be Dick Cavett?

title: A Diverse City? In Some Ways, Anything But
description: New Yorkers take an imperious pride in the belief that our city is better than other cities  fairer, obviously, and more embracing than a place like, lets say, Kansas City. New Yorkers dont actually need to visit Kansas City to convince themselves of this. These beliefs are self-sustaining, fed by a collective egotism and impervious to contravening realities. In matters of race, our arrogance increasingly seems misplaced.

title: Driven By His Past, a Coach Connects
description: MADISON, Wis.  The morning after Coach Bret Bielema led Wisconsin to one of the biggest wins in his programs history, an Oct. 1 blowout of then-No. 8 Nebraska that confirmed the Badgers status as a national title contender, he began crying in his office.

title: Whats a Love-Struck Pimp to Do?
description: Women  cant live with em, cant live without em.

description: With his rebuke Thursday of President Obamas handling of the housing crisis, Representative Dennis Cardoza of California joined an increasingly vocal chorus of House Democrats criticizing the presidents efforts.

title: Humming to Higher Ed
description: The season is upon us. Squirrels are collecting their winter nuts, the geese are flying off in formation, the hummingbirds headed south  and how the heck do they do that, anyway? Also, the high school seniors are beginning their long college visitation treks, which appear to take longer and require even more effort than that hummingbird thing.

title: Senate Panel Approves Bill That Rewrites Education Law
description: Legislation rewriting the No Child Left Behind education law finally gained traction this week, and the Senate Democrat whose committee passed the bill said on Friday that progress became possible because lawmakers were irritated by the Obama administrations offering states waivers to the laws key provisions.

title: Santander to Sell Stake in U.S. Auto Financing Group
description: Grupo Santander, the Spanish bank that is the euro zones largest bank by market capitalization, announced a $1.15 billion deal on Friday to sell a 35 percent stake in its automotive financing unit in the United States to a group of private equity investors, as it looks to shore up its balance sheet. Under the terms of the agreement, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Centerbridge Partners and Warburg Pincus will invest a combined $1 billion for a 25 percent share in Santander Consumer USA. Dundon DFS will pay $150 million for a 10 percent stake in Santander Consumer USA.

title: Social Media Raise Curtain on Staged Event in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  At about 4 p.m. on Thursday, Russias president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, stepped into a packed lecture hall at Moscow State Universitys venerable journalism department. Applause washed over him, proof that progressive, social media-savvy young people still look to him as a standard-bearer.

title: MI5 References Emerge in Phone Hacking Lawsuit

title: Wall St. Protest Isnt Like Ours, Tea Party Says
description: At a Republican candidate forum outside Fort Worth last week, a Tea Party activist turned Senate candidate proclaimed the Occupy Wall Street protesters unemployed, uneducated and uninformed. To which the conservative radio host moderating the panel added, mirthfully, This is the first occupation many of these people have seen in years.

title: Senator Bakers Waveless Shore
description: Edward Dickinson Baker, a close friend and sometimes political rival of Lincolns, had no fear of war. In 1832, he left his fledgling law practice in Illinois to participate in the Black Hawk War, and, in 1846, he resigned his Illinois Congressional seat to serve as a colonel of the Fourth Illinois Infantry in the Mexican War.

title: Why Not The Worst?
description: Im doing a fair bit of research before heading off to Iceland next week, and I thought it might be worth explaining why this tiny nation is so interesting. The thing is, its not for the expected reason.

title: End Date for Iraq
description: President Obamas announcement on Friday that the last American soldier will leave Iraq by years end signals a welcome end to a war that was started under false pretenses and went on far too long  killing more than 4,400 Americans and many more thousands of Iraqis and costing $1 trillion over nearly nine years.

title: Postseason Pinch-Hit Star, Three Games Running
description: In perhaps the most famous pinch-hitting moment in postseason history, Kirk Gibson of the Los Angeles Dodgers limped into the batters box against Dennis Eckersley of the Oakland As in Game 1 of the 1988 World Series. Despite a badly injured knee, and despite facing the games most dominant reliever, Gibson was able to put a charge into a 3-2 pitch, hitting a two-run homer to right field that gave the Dodgers a 5-4 victory.

title: 400 Years of Artifacts Enrich a Book
description: With the holiday season soon upon us, you might want to order one of these coffee table books for a friend who loves New York:

title: Expert Says Quakes in England May Be Tied to Gas Extraction
description: A British seismologist said Friday that two minor earthquakes in northwestern England appeared to correlate closely with the use of hydraulic fracturing, a method of extracting natural gas from wells that has raised concerns about environmental and seismological risks in the United States.

title: John M. Blum, Historian of Presidents, Dies at 90
description: John M. Blum, an influential historian of the American presidency whose 1954 biography of a maligned Theodore Roosevelt was pivotal in establishing the 26th presidents reputation as one of the countrys great chief executives, died on Monday at his home in North Branford, Conn. He was 90.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 4 WISCONSIN AT NO. 15 MICHIGAN STATE8 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

title: Jury Convicts Consultant of Stealing Campaign Money From Bloomberg
description: A Republican political consultant was convicted on Friday of stealing money from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg after a trial that lasted nearly a month and at times cast an unflattering spotlight on the mayors campaign-spending habits and the murky world of political operations.

title: Brunch, Books and Family Time
description: The conductor Fabio Luisi had been pinch-hitting on a semi-permanent basis for James Levine, the Metropolitan Operas music director, who has been plagued by health problems; last month Mr. Luisi, 52, was named principal conductor. A native of Genoa, Italy, and a veteran of major posts in Vienna, Leipzig and Dresden, he moved last season into an apartment on West 96th Street, just off Central Park, after finding himself increasingly in New York. He lives there with his wife, Barbara Luisi, and their son, Aldo, 13; Mr. Luisis two other children are grown and studying abroad.

title: Sexual Harassment 20 Years Later
description: Twenty years ago this month, Anita Hill stepped into the glare of the national spotlight, testifying before the all-male Senate Judiciary Committee about the vulgar sexual advances she said she endured a decade earlier while working at two government agencies for Clarence Thomas, the nominee to the Supreme Court.

title: Lunch, Landfills and What I Tossed
description: IT was warm and sunny on a recent Tuesday and the lunchtime crowd in Bryant Park was in full swarm. Hundreds of Midtown workers sat on the grass or at round outdoor tables sunbathing, talking on cellphones and typing away on laptops.

title: Governor Cuomos Choices
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has shown little interest in the challenges facing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs New York City area subways, buses and commuter trains, or the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which manages the areas ports, airports, bridges and tunnels.

title: Occupy-apalooza Strikes a Chord
description: Thursday night I spoke to a young woman in Brooklyn who was having dinner and planning the next day. Between a morning boot camp workout at the local Y.M.C.A. and an evening meeting with friends for drinks, she was planning her first trek to Zuccotti Park to take part in the Occupy Wall Street protests.

title: Correspondents Reflect on the War in Iraq
description: Correspondents who covered the war in Iraq are reflecting on their time there on the day that President Obama announced that American soldiers would leave Iraq by the end of the year, ending a nearly nine-year military engagement. The president appeared to leave open the possibility that a deal could still be negotiated to allow military trainers to work in the country, though it would likely be a limited number.

title: Will Mrs. Merkel Wake Up in Time?
description: Helmut Schmidt, Germanys 92-year-old former chancellor, sent a pointed message to his present-day successor, Angela Merkel, this week. Shortchanging Europe damages Germany, he warned in a speech in Frankfurt. Of course the strong should help the weak, he said, just as Germany was helped by America after World War II.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Peacocks Then and Now

title: Double-Play Duo Drives Rangers in the Field and Atop the Lineup
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  On the Texas Rangers team bus after Game 2 of the World Series on Thursday night, Elvis Andrus and Nelson Cruz decided it was time to see the play everyone was talking about.

title: Correction Officers Plead Guilty in Assault Case
description: Two former New York City correction officers accused of orchestrating a scheme in which inmates at a juvenile detention center used threats, extortion and vicious beatings to keep other inmates in line pleaded guilty on Friday to related crimes.

title: Private Schools in Suburbs Tap Manhattan Market
description: Finally, Manhattan parents can apply to a private school this fall that does not require their 4-year-olds to undergo intelligence testing or solicit donations for the building fund. Tuition is $20,000 annually, half the cost of some other private schools.

title: Saturday: The Meta-Challenge
description: Administrivial Contest Rules Alert! All the puzzles this week, from Monday to Saturday, have been created by one person, Patrick Berry. Have your solutions handy, because the Saturday puzzle conceals a meta-challenge involving the solution grids of all six.When you have the answer to the meta-challenge, e-mail it to: crossword@nytimes.com. Please do not post your answers here on the blog and please do not mail them to me! Only answers e-mailed to the above address will be considered.Twenty-five correct solvers, chosen at random, whose entries are received by 6 p.m. Eastern time Sunday, Oct. 23, will receive copies of Will Shortz Picks His Favorite Puzzles: 101 of the Top Crosswords From The New York Times. Only one entry per person, please. The answer and winners names will appear on Friday, Oct. 28, at nytimes.com/wordplay.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: October 22
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Cries of Anti-Semitism, but Not at Zuccotti Park
description: Among the hodgepodge of signs that have sprouted in Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, one man in jeans and a baseball cap has been carrying placards that shout their suggestions: Google: Jewish Billionaires and Google: Zionists control Wall St.

title: Despite Difficult Talks, U.S. and Iraq Had Expected Some American Troops to Stay
description: BAGHDAD  President Obamas announcement on Friday that all American troops would leave Iraq by the end of the year was an occasion for celebration for many, but some top American military officials were dismayed by the announcement, seeing it as the presidents putting the best face on a breakdown in tortured negotiations with the Iraqis.

title: Women in Love, Leaping Into Elevator Shafts
description: Judging by her new work, which explores what it means to be a woman in love  its cheeky title is simply the One  it just wouldnt do to describe Lyndsey Karr as the romantic type. As a pair of women, more often naked than not, takes the audience on a trip to three sites within the Chocolate Factory, Ms. Karr, with deadpan whimsy, both demonstrates and ridicules archetypes of the besotted.

title: Given a Second Chance, a Jets Linebacker Wraps It Up
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Twenty-four days after the Jets cut him, Aaron Maybin returned to the team Sept. 28 as pretty much the same player: a relentless and boisterous pass-rushing outside linebacker equipped with no mute button.

title: Mets to Play Yankees in Spring Training
description: After a 16-year hiatus, the Mets and Yankees will resume playing spring-training games against each other next March, said a Yankees official who declined to be identified. The teams are tentatively scheduled to play games at each others complexes in Port St. Lucie and Tampa.

title: With Talks at a Halt, Silence Reigns
description: The hotel conference rooms had been vacated, perhaps turned over to a dental convention, or a cosmetics fair, or a symposium on gastroenterology. The charts devoted to BRI and luxury-tax thresholds had been packed up for another day, another meeting, another hotel.

title: Making the iBio for Apples Genius
description: After Steve Jobs anointed Walter Isaacson as his authorized biographer in 2009, he took Mr. Isaacson to see the Mountain View, Calif., house in which he had lived as a boy. He pointed out its clean design and awesome little features. He praised the developer, Joseph Eichler, who built more than 11,000 homes in California subdivisions, for making an affordable product on a mass-market scale. And he showed Mr. Isaacson the stockade fence built 50 years earlier by his father, Paul Jobs.

title: A Modern Setting for Authentic Italian
description: MY lasting impression of Pranzi formed as I emerged from its formal ristorante, on the ground floor of the Trump Tower at City Center, to exit through its informal enoteca. In the jam-packed front room, a D.J. sporting French nautical stripes and tinted glasses was pushing his fun agenda from the keyboard of his bright orange Apple laptop, and the crowd  in fine spirits on a Thursday night  was loving it. We lingered for a minute, smiling, then a young man in a svelte suit held the door and with a little flourish of his hand, thanked us in the nicest way for coming.

title: Missing Several Stars, and Also One Juror
description: Ive been at this job for 10 years, and this is the first time this has ever happened, a publicist said to Nocturnalists correspondent near a red carpet so bereft of celebrities that we were looking for a rolling tumbleweed to interview.

title: Where the Seafood Can Go On and On
description: GIVEN the high cost of seafood, all you can eat is not a phrase I expect to see at a place that serves good sushi. Mahzu Japanese Restaurant, where the all-you-can-eat special is offered on Sundays for $19.99, is an exception.

title: A Bolvar Ready to Fight Against the Bolivarian State
description: CARACAS, Venezuela

title: A Welcoming, Affordable Discovery
description: A CASUAL neighborhood spot with delicious yet affordable food: That is what the owners of Bistro 25 had in mind for their restaurant, which opened in January in Sayville. Michael Turner and his partner in the venture, Brian Shuren, who is also the chef, have realized their vision. My only complaint is that Bistro 25 is not in my neighborhood.

title: Authentic Greek Fare, but Distinctly New Jersey
description: THE blue sky and sea on the cover of Mikonos Restaurants menu seem to promise, if not a transcendent dining experience, one that calls to mind the heat and keen light of the Mediterranean. However, the interior of this restaurant in Ewing, with a sunroom addition that makes up most of the dining room  dimly lighted in the evening  says New Jersey.

title: Virginia: Nuclear Reactors Expected to Reopen Soon
description: The North Anna nuclear reactors in Mineral, the only ones shut down by the Aug. 23 earthquake on the East Coast, will probably be allowed to reopen within weeks, a senior official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Friday. After a two-month, $21 million inspection, staff engineers told the commission at a two-hour briefing that the plant suffered only cosmetic damage. The limited damage led the plants operator, Dominion, and the commission to debate whether their standard for measuring a quakes strength  based simply on ground motion  was the best one. That measure indicated that the ground motion on Aug. 23 exceeded what the reactors were designed for. But when engineers measured the quake by the total amount of energy it delivered, the quake was far too weak to produce significant damage. (The energy measure is based on both the shaking and its duration.) Most of the cosmetic damage found at the plant was limited to concrete, Dominion said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,797 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following American this week:

title: In Cleveland, a Circle Is Completed
description: BEREA, Ohio  Inside his office at the Cleveland Browns headquarters, Coach Pat Shurmur considered the connections, the threads that unite three men.

title: Senator Lashes Out at Critics Who Say He Embellished His Familys Story
description: MIAMI  Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a charismatic Republican whose name has circulated recently as a possible vice-presidential candidate, lashed out on Friday at those who accused him of embellishing his familys history.

title: The Aesthetics of Functional Pottery
description: THE works of several of the artists who pinched bowls and other forms in the Earth exhibition at the Arts Exchange in White Plains are also included in American Craft Week @ The Peekskill Clay Studios. This show presents predominantly functional pottery that illustrates the breadth of aesthetic effects that can be achieved using different conceptual and technical approaches.

title: What the Earth Gives, and What It Inspires
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: A Rangers Fan Whos Hard to Top
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  At 7 feet, Dirk Nowitzki likely stands as the biggest fan of the Texas Rangers. And like any truly obsessed follower, Nowitzki refers to his favorite team in the first person plural.

title: In Friends Suggestive Notes, Hints of Future Power
description: So much of whats on offer at CMJ is raw material  maybe the bands got it all figured out, more likely it doesnt. If it doesnt work, maybe itll try again next year. Maybe itll reinvent itself, or break up and reconfigure before trying again.

title: Changing Clothes for Love and Survival
description: The way things are going, William Shakespeare may soon be known as a writer of musicals. Last month, the Two River Theater Company in New Jersey opened a production of Much Ado About Nothing with at least three songs, accompanied by cast members on various musical instruments. Now along comes the Westport Country Playhouses very pretty, very funny and very lilting production of Twelfth Night, or What You Will.

title: Mental Health Advocates Face an Uphill Battle
description: The way America spends its resources sometimes infuriates Jennifer Humbert of Crete, a social worker and suburban mother of two children who have mental health issues.

title: Slowly Making a Name for Themselves
description: The lot of a Rangers fan has never been an easy one.

title: Trash Reinvented
description: Stony Brook, N.Y.

title: Fake Lawyers and Notaries Prey on Immigrants
description: On May 6, just hours before his asylum hearing, Mario de la Rosa, a Mexican immigrant living in Waukegan, waited in the parking lot of a CVS pharmacy for the person representing him in his case, Margaret Carrasco, to arrive. She never did.

title: Dinner at Moms, With All the Emotional Trimmings
description: Jericho is a play about Sept. 11. It is also a traumatic-Thanksgiving-dinner-with-the-family play and a play about being Jewish. All in all, it is a lovely, humorous work with laughs that resolve into a meditation on the pains and satisfactions of living after a tragedy.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Spring Rivalry to Resume
description: After a 16-year hiatus, the Mets and the Yankees will resume playing spring-training games against each other next March, said a Yankees official who declined to be identified. The teams are tentatively scheduled to play games at each others complexes in Port St. Lucie and Tampa.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: D.E.A. Bans Chemicals Used in Bath Salts
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration took emergency action on Friday to ban three synthetic stimulants used to make productsthat are marketed at head shops and on the Web as bath salts, but are actually used as recreational drugs that mimic the effects of cocaine, LSD and methamphetamine.

title: American Who Killed for Iran in 1980 Resurfaces to Comment on Alleged Plot
description: When the Justice Department announced last week that an undercover agent in Mexico had disrupted an Iranian plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador in Washington, using members of Mexican drug cartel recruited by a used car salesman, officials in Tehran dismissed the charges as fiction, and several prominent American experts on Iran also expressed their doubts.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Kashmir: An inquiry by an RTI activist found that the University of Kashmir has spent more than 2.16 crore Indian rupees, or 21.6 million (about $400,000), on vehicles for the university staff but has disbursed only 59 lakh rupees, or 5.9 million, towards student scholarships and fellowships in the last five years. The report said that 36 vehicles, mostly SUVs, were purchased, including a bulletproof car, which was bought for 9.25 lakh rupees (about $20,000)(Kashmir Live).

title: Why I Left India (Again)
description: The Hindi movie on my return to India flight on Dec. 13th, 2006 was Swades (literally: My country, a story about a patriotic NASA engineer who returns to India to help improve his homeland).

title: Another Productive At-Bat for a Golden Age
description: Charles M. Conlon has been deemed  on Lens, if not elsewhere  the greatest baseball photographer. From 1904 to 1942, Mr. Conlon shot some 30,000 pictures of Americas pastime. In 1993, The Sporting News published Baseballs Golden Age, a collection of his work.

title: On Revis and Sweetness
description: Two media-related items to chew on this morning:

title: Damage From Falling Satellites? Insurance Will Cover It
description: Just last month, an old NASA satellite plummeted to Earth and disintegrated. Now space buffs are keeping an eye on the retired German scientific satellite ROSAT, which is expected to crash and burn sometime this weekend.

title: How to Get All Your Apps Everywhere
description: A particular problem for people who have bought a lot of iOS apps is getting them all consolidated across desktops, laptops, phones and tablets.

title: Five Minutes at CMJ With Nikki Lane
description: ArtsBeat will be talking to some of the acts that are in New York this week to play the CMJ Music Marathon.

title: The 161st Manchester Derby
description: Roy Keane remembers his first as if it were yesterday.

title: Sharing Audio on Pods, Pads and Phones
description: The iPad is a great way to watch movies on, say, a plane trip. But if you are traveling with someone, you endanger your domestic bliss by hogging the entertainment and walling yourself off (Sorry, dear, youll have to amuse yourself by re-reading the SkyMall catalog while I watch Bridesmaids.)

title: 30 Seconds With Shaquille ONeal: Off the Court, but Still Going at Full Speed
description: Shaquille ONeal was in Manhattan the other day, dunking, grabbing rebounds and even making his free throws. After announcing his retirement in June, was he preparing for a comeback after the lockout? No, that was the virtual Shaq; the real ONeal was controlling his moves on the new digital download of EA Sports NBA JAM: On Fire Edition. ONeal, an analyst on TNT, was hopeful there would soon be real N.B.A. games.

title: European Wage Update
description: A followup on my last Iceland post. A key point there was that nominal wages are downwardly rigid  its very hard to cut them even if your country clearly has costs that make it uncompetitive. Thats why internal devaluation is so difficult a strategy as compared with, well, devaluation devaluation.

title: Cap and Trade: Sweating the Small Stuff
description: One thing built into a politicians DNA is a sense of occasion. Regulators tend to lack that gene.

title: Theres A Hole In The Bucket
description: The torments of the euro would be funny if they werent so tragic. At this point the urgent need is for a big Panzerfaust  a bailout fund big enough to head off a self-fulfilling liquidity crisis for Italy. But such a fund would be backed by the credit of the euro areas remaining AAA governments, basically Germany and France  yet at this point the euro situation has deteriorated sufficiently that taking on another commitment would undermine French credit. Theres a hole in the bucket, and every attempt to fix that hole ends up being stymied because, well, theres a hole in the bucket.

title: An Insurance Company With An Army
description: I gather, from what Ive been reading and hearing in various places, that the right-wing line is that its all Solyndra  that your tax dollars are going to pay for vast numbers of wasteful projects.

title: Russia Will Bar Some U.S. Citizens in Retaliation
description: MOSCOW  Russias Foreign Ministry announced Saturday that it confirmed a list of American citizens it will bar from entering Russia, in a retaliatory move against the United States adoption of the so-called Magnitsky list, which imposes sanctions on Russian officials who have been linked to the 2009 death of the whistleblower Sergei L. Magnitsky.

title: I Never Wanted to Be a Manager. But Ive Learned.
description: This interview with  Selina Lo, president and chief executive of Ruckus Wireless, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: How Mr. Volcker Would Fix It
description: AMID all the minutiae of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul, its easy to lose sight of the big question: will consumers, investors and the economy be safer?

title: Unreasonable, Maybe, but Its on a Social Mission
description: DANIEL EPSTEIN wants to get one thing straight: He is an unreasonable man. Happily, proudly unreasonable. Entrepreneurs who want to change the world, he says, have got to be a little crazy.

title: The Little State With a Big Mess
description: CRANSTON, R.I.

title: Four Nations, Four Lessons
description: AS the economy languishes, politicians and pundits are debating what to do next. When we look around the world, its hard to find positive role models. But as we search for answers, it is useful to keep in mind those fates that we would like to avoid.

title: It Guards the Markets, but What About Itself?
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission oversees the nations financial markets. But has it unwittingly compromised its own employees financial information?

title: Variety: A Spooooky Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Im still catching my breath from the Crossing Words contest, so while Im mopping my brow, have fun with this nearly-Halloween Acrostic by our own gorious constructors, Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.

title: Live Analysis: Third Saturday of October
description: Paul Myerberg and The Times Jere Longman will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can alsofollow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: Raised on the Web, but Liking a Little Ink
description: ON a trip to an indie bookstore in Brooklyn in the summer, I came across a curious creation: a small, black-and-white publication that consisted entirely of snapshots of Lindsay Lohan, known for her movie roles in Mean Girls and The Parent Trap, and, more recently, for her well-publicized courtroom appearances.

title: Appetite for Catch and Release Is Tempered
