description: LEENANE, Ireland  After my years of faithfulness (well, almost) to the religion of catch-and-release fishing in the United States and Canada, I found it heretical to be told that the salmon I caught would have to be killed.

title: Man Climbs Joie de Vivre Sculpture in Zuccotti Park
description: A Canadian man climbed up a red sculpture in Zuccotti Park early on Saturday and perched there for several hours before the police brought him down, the authorities said.

title: Spy Agency in Kabul Denies Claim of Abuse
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans embattled spy agency absolved itself of any wrongdoing on Saturday in the case of a wandering Islamic preacher detained by intelligence officials who ended up in a hospital this month, fading in and out of consciousness and seemingly near death.

title: European Finance Ministers Shaping Greek Rescue and Effort to Aid Banks
description: BRUSSELS  European finance ministers said on Saturday that they were near a deal to strengthen capital reserves for their troubled banks  the first part of a package of measures meant to stem the worsening European debt crisis.

title: Stepping Into Raiders Void, a Coach Makes a Bold Deal
description: Marvin Lewis dropped his cellphone in his driveway last Sunday morning, a few hours before his Cincinnati Bengals beat the Indianapolis Colts, shattering the screen and shielding him from the tidal wave of text messages to come.

title: In His Last Days, Qaddafi Wearied of Fugitives Life
description: MISURATA, Libya  After 42 years of absolute power in Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi spent his last days hovering between defiance and delusion, surviving on rice and pasta his guards scrounged from the emptied civilian houses he moved between every few days, according to a senior security official captured with him.

title: Prince Sultan bin Abdel Aziz of Saudi Arabia Dies
description: CAIRO  Prince Sultan bin Abdel Aziz, the heir apparent to the Saudi throne and one of the kingdoms most powerful princes until illness sapped his strength in recent years, has died, raising complex succession issues at a time of political turmoil in the region.

title: Banks Collapse in Europe Points to Global Risks
description: As Europes debt crisis has deepened, a recurring question is how much risk it poses to the United States economy, and especially American banks.

title: Pete Seeger Leads Protesters, on Foot and in Song
description: The Occupy Wall Street protests have drawn their share of musical supporters over the past few weeks. On Friday night, Pete Seeger lent his voice to the cause, though the protesters had to go uptown to hear it.

title: A Love Story Affirmed Life in Time of War
description: They met in the Weapons Room, where sports receptions were held in those days.

title: The Start-Up Advantage
description: IM from Calgary, Alberta. My mother was an artist and my father was an economist until they changed careers and became a design/build team. I grew up watching them build homes.

title: Signs of Abuse at Institutions, Despite Settlement
description: MEXIA  At the Mexia State Supported Living Center, on the sun-bleached site of a former World War II prisoner of war camp an hour east of Waco, residents with profound disabilities and behavioral problems spend their days doing repetitive chores: sticking paper into shredders, folding towels, sorting nuts from bolts. And, in some cases, being physically abused, despite a sweeping federal settlement signed in 2009 to prevent it.

title: For the Jets Cromartie, Knowledge Can Damage
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Antonio Cromartie, the Jets mercurial cornerback, does not have peaks. He has Himalayas. Cromartie does not have valleys. He has canyons. And some are indeed grand.

title: Dugout Phones: Last Bastion of the Landline
description: The seed-strewn dugouts of baseball stadiums around the country may very well end up the final bastions of corded communication in this wireless era.

title: A Golden Touch Without the Glitter
description: SHES not the Ronson who dated Lindsay Lohan. Thats her fedora-wearing fraternal twin, Samantha, a celebrity D.J. and singer. Shes not the Ronson who in 2008 won three Grammys, including one for producer of the year for working with Amy Winehouse. Thats her brother Mark, the recently married record producer.

title: CMJ: Day 4 Twitter Reviews of Dum Dum Girls, Walk the Moon, Metronomy and More
description: Its Day 5 of the CMJ Music Marathon and critics from The Times arent slowing down. @joncaramanica and @jonpareles did their best to hit the most promising shows. But we cant be everywhere. This year, weve invited readers to join us in appraising CMJ shows on Twitter.

title: Gotye Fans Turn Out to Sing Along
description: A hit is a hit; a market boundary, in the digital era, is permeable.

title: Old-School in Silicon Valley
description: While other schools around Silicon Valley brag about their wired classrooms, the Waldorf school is a throwback, with blackboards and colorful chalk, bookshelves with encyclopedias, and wooden desks filled with workbooks and No. 2 pencils.

title: No True Sense of History Without a Sense of Place
description: Among the games people play, baseball is distinguished by the preservation of landmark numbers  56, .367, 2,632, 4,256. But Major League Baseball does precious little to preserve the places where the game once breathed.

title: A Silicon Valley School That Doesnt Compute
description: LOS ALTOS, Calif.  The chief technology officer of eBay sends his children to a nine-classroom school here. So do employees of Silicon Valley giants like Google, Apple, Yahoo and Hewlett-Packard.

title: Technology, Schools and a Big Black Bug
description: I was on a hike in August when one of my hiking companions bent down to the dusty path to examine a thumb-size black beetle. My fellow hiker, Harry Barker-Fost, stared at the chunky insect as it crawled onto his hand and then over and around his forearm for the better part of three minutes.

title: In Memoir, Rice Tells of Clashes With Cheney
description: WASHINGTON  Condoleezza Rice clashed repeatedly with Vice President Dick Cheney over what to do with captured terrorism suspects and at one point even threatened to resign when she felt circumvented, according to a memoir of her time in Washington, due out next month.

title: The Tale of the Dueling Economists
description: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES and Friedrich Hayek. The names conjure opposing poles of thought about making economic policy: Keynes is often held up as the flag bearer of vigorous government intervention in the markets, while Hayek is regarded as the champion of laissez-faire capitalism.

title: The Sunny Side of Doom and Gloom
description: SINCE the market ran into serious trouble during the summer, the Standard & Poors 500-stock index has clawed its way back to the 1,200 level on four separate occasions. On the first three runs, the rallies quickly lost steam amid fresh sets of worries about the global economy.

title: But, And, Why
description: Every once in a while I get correspondence from someone chiding me for the way I write  in particular the informality. I received one the other day complaining about sentences that begin with but or and. There is, however, a reason I write this way.

title: Should 65 Be Your Magic Number?
description: Q. In a few years, you will reach the traditional retirement age of 65. You arent sure if you want to keep working past that age. What factors should you weigh?

title: Nevada G.O.P. Relents on Early Primary
description: The Nevada Republican Party decided on Saturday to push back the date of its presidential caucuses to Feb. 4, a move that brings a sense of order to an otherwise chaotic primary calendar and keeps New Hampshire from scheduling its voting before the New Year.

title: Japans Standardized Baseballs Are Popular With Pitchers
description: TOKYO  Unlike Major League Baseball, for whom Rawlings has been the official supplier of baseballs since 1977, Japans top league has long used multiple manufacturers.

title: Lindsey Vonn Wins Giant Slalom and Completes Sweep
description: For all the races, titles and medals Lindsey Vonn has won in her ski racing career, she had never won a World Cup giant slalom. But with a daring and aggressive finish Saturday in Slden, Austria, Vonn won the season-opening giant slalom and became the fifth woman to win a race in all five World Cup disciplines.

title: Letters: The Power of Pink and the Cancer Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Spending, Taxes and the Infrastructure
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Of Errors and Calories
description: To the Editor:

title: Stern Must Balance N.B.A.s Viability and Visibility
description: From 2003 through 2007, I was the commissioner of the National Basketball League of Australia. Although my league was a fraction of the N.B.A.s size, I faced many of the same challenges Commissioner David Stern has dealt with for the past 27 years: pressure-packed labor negotiations, antagonized player and referee unions, unhappy owners (who overpaid players and lost money annually), demanding corporate sponsors, ratings-conscious television partners, scathing news media criticism and unhappy fans who were convinced that teams they disliked were cheating.

title: A Struggling Football League Skips a Beat and Crowns a Champion
description: VIRGINIA BEACH  Fans can be forgiven if they missed the United Football League championship game Friday night: the game sneaked up on the league as well.

title: Hollywood on Wall Street
description: WHAT enormous comfort it must give the Occupy Wall Street protesters to know that celebrities feel their pain.

title: The Saudi Ambassador of Sangfroid
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Inevitable Nominee
description: FOR the next three months, the political press will engage in an extended masquerade, designed to persuade credulous readers and excitable viewers that the Republican presidential nomination is actually up for grabs.

title: One Country, Two Revolutions
description: I take no pleasure in seeing anyone lose a job, but I cant say that the recent headlines showing that Americas biggest banks have been losing money on their trading operations, and are having to radically shrink as a result, are entirely bad news for the country. Over the last decade, Americas banking sector got pumped up by steroids  in the form of cheap credit and leverage  every bit as much as Major League Baseballs home run hitters. And if one result of the downsizing of Wall Street is that more of Americas best and brightest math and physics students decide to go into science and real engineering rather than financial engineering, the country will be a whole lot better off.

title: The Man Who Stayed Behind
description: IN the last few months, as you and I have been fretting about the economy or moaning about the weather, Ryan Boyette has been living in a mud-wall hut and dodging bombs in his underwear.

title: Peddling Fear
description: At one oclock in the morning Friday, in one of its rushes to get out of work and back to fund-raising, the Senate took up a measure to strip the Justice Department of the power to charge and try any non-American terrorism suspect captured anywhere in the world.

title: U.S. Scales Back Diplomacy in Iraq Amid Fiscal and Security Concerns
description: BAGHDAD  Beyond the final withdrawal of troops that President Obama announced Friday, Americas fiscal troubles are dictating a drastic scaling back of plans for diplomatic, economic and cultural programs once deemed vital to steadying Iraq, building a long-term alliance and prying the country from Irans tightening embrace.

title: The Paradox of the New Elite
description: Alexander Stille is a professor of international journalism at Columbia.

title: A Pack of Nascar Drivers Is Ready to Break Out of Johnsons Shadow
description: Jimmie Johnson hinted at vulnerability two races into the Chase for the Sprint Cup, as less-than-dominating finishes left him well behind the points leaders. Just as the doubts were raised, Johnson seemed to dismiss them with a second-place showing at Dover and a victory at Kansas that reminded everyone why he was nicknamed Five-Time.

title: A Drivers Death Raises Questions About IndyCars Leader
description: In the wake of Dan Wheldons death at a race in Las Vegas last Sunday, IndyCar officials have been all but silent. No formal statements, beyond an expression of regret and a pledge to investigate themselves. Certainly no news conferences to answer questions about the propriety of the race, which was held at a fast track not truly built to stage such an event.

title: Knicks Reed: Forever a Captain Among Men
description: 11:17 p.m. | Updated Those familiar with the career of the Knicks legend Willis Reed would not be surprised by his recent take on the N.B.A. lockout and the costly cancellation of early season games.

title: Right, Less Might
description: Sam Tanenhaus is the editor of The New York Times Book Review.

title: Who Needs Stability?
description: Bankers in this country are not letting up on their campaign to undercut the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, which is supposed to curb risky behavior and lessen the chances of another meltdown. They are also eagerly joining their overseas brethren in a similarly fierce campaign against new international rules that would require banks to gradually increase the amount of capital they must keep in reserve to cushion against future crises.

title: Drilling Down on the Family Farm
description: Seamus McGraw is the author of The End of Country.

title: Me and Mrs. Nixon
description: Ann Beattie is the author of the forthcoming Mrs. Nixon: A Novelist Imagines a Life.

title: Talking Their Way Out of a Population Crisis
description: Helen Epstein is the author of The Invisible Cure: Africa, the West and the Fight Against AIDS.

title: Will Dropouts Save America?
description: Michael Ellsberg is the author of The Education of Millionaires: Its Not What You Think and Its Not Too Late.

title: Even Worse Than Citizens United
description: The Justice Department is right to defend as essential the century-old ban on direct corporate contributions to political candidates for federal office. In a brief to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, the lawyers challenge a wrongheaded ruling by Judge James Cacheris of Virginia, arguing that the ban serves the governments strong interest in preventing political corruption.

title: Happy Birthday iPod!
description: Daniel J. Levitin, a neuroscientist at McGill University, is the author of This Is Your Brain on Music: The Science of a Human Obsession.

title: Boomer on Board
description: Many drivers like to pay a little extra to profess their loyalty to causes on their license plates, when a bumper sticker is not enough. Massachusetts, a typical state, has specialty plates for the Red Sox, the Celtics and the Bruins, Cape Cod and its islands, children, fish and wildlife, cancer research, right whales and the Olympic spirit.

title: Clarence Thomass Brand of Judicial Logic
description: Justice Clarence Thomas was sworn in to the Supreme Court 20 years ago today. After two decades on the bench, he remains a legal outlier even on the conservative court. The results he reaches are often radical, and where his ideas come from even more so.

title: Amy Hamburger
description: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

title: Covering Its Own Backyard
description: RICHARD AURELIO counts himself as an old-school newspaper reader. After a varied career as an editor at Newsday, a deputy mayor under John V. Lindsay and the Time Warner executive who founded the all-news New York One cable channel, Mr. Aurelio laments a change he sees in how The New York Times handles local coverage.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Diversity on Campus
description: A letter writer suggests using economic status rather than race as a factor in college admissions. Readers offer their views.

title: Wearing Bike Helmets
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Is Considering Fuel Depots in the Skies
description: By considering a proposal to put filling stations in the sky, NASA is looking to accelerate plans to send astronauts to distant destinations.

title: Its All Connected: An Overview of the Euro Crisis
description: A visual guide to the growing debt crisis.

title: The Man Who Stayed Behind (in Sudan)
description: My Sunday column is about Ryan Boyette, an American aid worker who stayed behind in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan to bear witness to atrocities there, when virtually everyone else evacuated. I thought you might like to take a look at Ryan, so here are a couple of photographs.

title: Assessing the Redistricting Outlook
description: Which states have redistricting-related legal challenges and forecasts on each partys likely net gain in Congressional seats.

title: Measurement and Its Discontents
description: Robert P. Crease is a professor of philosophy at Stony Brook University and the author of World in the Balance: The Historic Quest for an Absolute System of Measurement.

title: Sticky Fingers, Male and Female
description: Rachel Shteir is the author of The Steal: A Cultural History of Shoplifting.

title: Battles to Shape Maps, and Congress, Go to Courts
description: The once-a-decade process of redrawing Congressional districts is moving from the smoke-filled back room to the courtroom. Lawsuits related to redistricting have been filed in more than half the states, asking judges to decide issues that include whether the new maps take partisan gerrymandering too far or discriminate against minority voters.

title: Battle for Libya | October 22, 2011
description: Libyas new leaders will declare liberation on Sunday, officials said, a move that will start the clock for elections after months of bloodshed that culminated in the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the longtime dictator.

title: After a Gas Explosion, Cleaning Up and Feeling Lucky
description: Phyllis Laughlin brought her 88-year-old mother, Noreen Clayton, to watch the destruction. It gets her out, Ms. Laughlin said. This is better than sitting around looking at the living room.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Even the Worlds Best Players Struggle After a Timeout
description: Tournament play after a long layoff is not easy, even for elite players. They can forget what they know about openings or fail to stay up to date. A larger obstacle is the crucible of competition: the pressure can be intense, and the mind and body have to be reconditioned.

title: Meanwhile, Greece
description: At this point Greece almost seems like a sideshow. Yet the scale of its coming default matters, especially with some players still denying that such a default is conceivable. So I would be remiss not to mention the awesomely depressing report of European Commission economists, which is marked strictly confidential but has, of course, gone viral.

title: Awaiting Tunisias Vote
description: Tunisians prepared to vote on Sunday in the first election since the Arab Spring.

title: Sunday: Take It From the Top
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  The Crossing Words Contest of 11 is now over, but you can still e-mail your answers to crossword@nytimes.com until Sunday at 6 p.m. Eastern time. The consensus seems to be that people loved the puzzles, and the meta-challenge was the piece de resistance. Stay tuned for the second part of an interview with constructor extraordinaire Patrick Berry that I will be running shortly after the Monday puzzle goes live.

title: Financing Questions Shadow Tunisian Vote, First of Arab Spring
description: TUNIS  As Tunisians prepare to vote on Sunday in the first election of the Arab Spring, the parties and their supporters have ramped up a bitter debate over allegations about the influence of dirty money behind the scenes of the race.

title: Cain, Now Running as Outsider, Came to Washington as Lobbyist
description: WASHINGTON  Herman Cain, the Republican presidential candidate with the sharp wit and easy-to-remember tax plan, is a cancer survivor, radio host and former chief executive of Godfathers Pizza. On the campaign trail, he talks up his business experience, casting himself as a problem solver and Washington outsider.

title: From Mosque to MASH Unit in Yemeni Crisis Zone
description: SANA, Yemen  The calm inside the mosque quickly turned to mayhem as the first victim of a deadly attack on a protest march was brought in on a stretcher. The young man grasped at his abdomen with bloodied hands.

title: Voracious Mice Scramble Food Chain on Californias Farallon Islands
description: Winter after winter, burrowing owls have been overstaying their traditional migratory visit to the storm-swept Farallon Islands, dining on the petrels that have returned to breed. The attacks have taken a heavy toll on the petrels, a native bird that breeds slowly on the small, rocky islands.

title: Jubilant Fighters Return to Cradle of Libyas Revolt
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Veterans of the decisive battle for Surt streamed into this eastern Libyan port city on Saturday to a raucous heroes welcome, firing round after round into the air and yelling greetings to a jubilant crowd that jammed the entry-point to a main boulevard into town.

title: The NBA Lockout
description: William C. Rhoden discusses the NBA lockout.

title: Video: The N.B.A. Lockout
description: William C. Rhoden discusses the NBA lockout.

title: Fathers Quest for Justice Ends in Paris Guilty Verdict
description: A Paris court on Saturday convicted a German doctor of manslaughter in the 1982 death of his stepdaughter, bringing to a tentative close a 29-year crusade by the girls father to see the doctor brought to justice.

title: Finding a Life That Fits
description: Keris Myrick, who has been diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder and obsessive compulsive disorder, finds ways to manage her illness.

title: Turkey Says It Killed 49 in Battling Kurd Rebels
description: ISTANBUL  More than 49 Kurdish insurgents were killed in the first two days of a new Turkish military offensive against P.K.K. rebels in southeastern Turkey and northern Iraq, the military said Saturday.

title: World Series Game 3: Cardinals 16, Rangers 7
description: Tom Spousta and others will provide commentary and live analysis of Game 3 of the World Series between the Texas Rangers and the St. Louis Cardinals from Rangers Ballpark in Arlington.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, October 23
description: With the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya on Thursday and President Obamas announcement on Friday that all United States troops would be out of Iraq by the end of the year, many are wondering what these developments will mean for American interests.

title: Memoir About Schizophrenia Spurs Others to Come Forward
description: Researchers have long wondered how some people with schizophrenia can manage their symptoms well enough to build full, successful lives. But such people do not exactly line up to enroll in studies.

title: A High-Profile Executive Job as Defense Against Mental Ills
description: PASADENA, Calif.  The feeling of danger was so close and overwhelming that there was no time to find its source, no choice but to get out of the apartment, fast.

title: Maybe, After Eight Years of the Blahs, a World Series to Shout About
description: Arlington, Tex.

title: L.S.U. Is Not Slowed on Road to Showdown
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  College footballs version of a regular-season Super Bowl is set.

title: Looking for Love in Like Crazy
description: Drake Doremus, the director of Like Crazy, talks about crafting his film.

title: Corrections: October 23
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Successes Overseas Are Unlikely to Help Obama at Home
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas announcement that the last American soldiers will leave Iraq by the end of this year capped a momentous week in which he could also take credit for helping dispatch one of the worlds great villains, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Many in Sub-Saharan Africa Mourn Qaddafis Death
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  While Libyas former rebels and many Western nations welcomed the end of the countrys long and brutal dictatorship, many sub-Saharan Africans are mourning the death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, celebrated as much for his largesse as for his willingness to stand up to the West.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 22
description: The day in sports included rugby, swimming, figure skating and the World Cup giant slalom.

title: Cuts Threaten to Close Center for Crop Safety in South Texas
description: Within 80 miles of Weslaco, there are nine bridges linking the United States and Mexico. Tons of agricultural products move between the countries each day: vegetables from Mexico and cantaloupes from Central America arrive in Texas while beef and grains are sent to Mexican markets and beyond.

title: 2nd Place in the Division, and in the Heart of Texas
description: Jason Cohen writes a column for the Texas Report.

title: The Days Best in College Football
description: ZACH COLLAROS The senior Cincinnati quarterback threw for three touchdowns and ran for two more in the fourth quarter, helping Cincinnati come from behind in the closing minutes to stay atop the Big East standings with a 37-34 victory against host South Florida. Collaros finished 26 of 41 passing for 389 yards.

title: Navigating Public School Admissions, With a Consultants Help
description: Armed with tote bags for the handouts awaiting them, thousands of Chicago parents shuffled through display tables adorned with brightly colored posters as they faced the daunting task of selecting schools for their children.

title: Bringing Out the Superhero Side of Mr. Mom
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Lab Fight Raises U.S. Security Issues
description: Synthetic biology  which includes the development of fuels, organ tissue and tumor-destroying bacteria  became a focus of government and law enforcement agencies after 9/11 and the anthrax attacks that quickly followed it. The fields extraordinary promise, a presidential commission concluded in December, is accompanied by potential risks to humans and the environment.

title: Rejected Ads for Sex Workers Find Venue
description: After being rejected by two billboard companies for failing to meet community standards, an ad campaign advocating sex workers rights is running on 50 Muni buses in San Francisco.

title: Lottery Numbers
Outlaw Art
description: The penitentiary at San Quentin opened on a rocky North Bay promontory in 1852, and rehabilitation and educational programs for inmates were introduced in the 1940s. Inside the prison hobby shop, a plain room just outside the gates, the walls are lined with paintings and prints, and the display cases are filled with jewelry, leather goods and other pieces made by the inmates.

title: Police Seeking Suspect in Series of Sexual Assaults in Queens
description: A series of sexual assaults in southeastern Queens was identified on Saturday as a pattern of crimes that the police believe was committed by a single suspect.

title: College Football Replay: Oct. 22
description: Oklahoma State ended Missouris home winning streak and Clemson and Arkansas rallied for victories.

title: Abortion Takes Center Stage at Iowa G.O.P. Forum
description: DES MOINES  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas sought to win over social conservative voters in Iowa on Saturday night as he drew a distinction between his opposition to abortion with the views of his leading Republican rivals and declared, Being pro-life is not a matter of campaign convenience; it is a core conviction.

title: From Mosque to Clinic in Yemen
description: Volunteers have turned a mosque in Yemens capital, Sana, into a clinic to treat wounded protesters.

title: Panetta to Meet With Southeast Asian Defense Ministers
description: BALI, Indonesia  Defense SecretaryLeon E. Panetta is on the Indonesian resort island ofBali on Sunday for meetings with defense ministers from 10 Southeast Asian nations. Worries about Chinas military buildup in the Pacific will be high on the agenda.

title: Spartans Get Final Highlight in Edging Badgers
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  In a game that had all the markings of a regular-season college football classic, it was the final, crazy play, in Saturday nights meeting between No. 4 Wisconsin and No. 15 Michigan State that will long be remembered.

title: M.L.S. Playoff Possibilities: Final Chapter (Updated)
description: The result of Sunday nights Houston-Los Angeles match (7 p.m. Eastern, Galavision), the last regular-season match of the Major League Soccer season, will settle the postseason matchups.

title: Pujols Has His Moment, Over and Over
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As the setting of this World Series shifted south, from the gray chill of Missouri to the terra cotta warmth of Texas, there was a sense that the character of the games themselves would be altered drastically, too.

title: Building a Railroad and a New Life on the Frontier
description: CALGARY, Alberta

title: At First, Fireworks Over the Umpiring
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: World Series: Game 3
description: The Cardinals beat the Rangers, 16-7, to take a 2-1 lead in the World Series.

title: Top 25 Roundup
description: 1. L.S.U. (8-0) beat No. 19 Auburn, 45-10

title: Awaiting Tunisias Vote
description: Tunisians prepared to vote on Sunday in the first election since the Arab Spring.

title: Football Needs Drastic Changes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Elbowing Is Real, but the Rosters Begin Online
description: On a recent night at Public School 116 in Manhattan, two doctors walked onto the basketball court wearing scrubs while an insurance salesman who was waiting to get into the game sat on the sidelines discussing policy rates.

title: Amanda Wolbrom, Michael Roston
description: Amanda Gail Wolbrom and Michael Stuart Roston were married Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Museum. Rabbi Carie Carter officiated.

title: Allison Fishman, Aaron Task
description: Allison Lee Fishman, the daughter of Trudy M. Fishman and Marshall M. Fishman of Supply, N.C., was married Saturday evening at her parents home to Aaron Lowe Task, the son of Josie Zeman of Montclair, N.J., and Ted Task of West Palm Beach, Fla. David W. Sears, a minister affiliated with the Light and Energy Workers Association, a spiritual organization in Greensboro, N.C., led a ceremony with Jewish traditions.

title: Julianna Smoot and Lon Johnson
description: Julianna Skinner Smoot and Lon Barton Johnson were married Saturday in Northport, Mich. The Rev. Thomas H. John Sr. performed the ceremony at the Northport Indian Mission United Methodist Church, where he is pastor.

title: Rena Gower, Gregory Stein
description: Rena Michelle Gower, the daughter of Susan C. Gower and J. Michael Gower of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening in Brooklyn to Gregory Ross Stein, the son of Laura A. Stein and Gilbert S. Stein of Old Brookville, N.Y. Rabbi John S. Friedman performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Christine Fritz, Andrew Lloyd
description: Christine Pinckney Fritz, a daughter of Elizabeth Foxworth Fritz and H. Laurence Fritz Jr. of Spartanburg, S.C., was married Saturday evening to Andrew Richard Lloyd, a son of Leslie Werner Lloyd and Kevin R. Lloyd of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Clay Howard Turner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Spartanburg.

title: Caroline Perkin, Jos Los Arcos
description: Caroline Suydam Perkin and Jos Luis Los Arcos Nagore were married Saturday evening at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Ugo Nacciarone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with Canon John B. Andrew, an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: Bill White and Bryan Eure
description: Bill Bryan White and Joseph Bryan Eure are to be married Sunday evening at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York. The lawyer David Boies, whose clients have included opponents to the Proposition 8 ban on same-sex marriage in California, is to officiate; he became a Universal Life minister for the ceremony.

title: Kathryn Camp, Westray Battle III
description: Kathryn Elizabeth Camp and Lt. Turner Westray Battle III were married Saturday by the Rev. Robert Hennagin at St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Boca Grande, Fla.

title: Thomas Crowder, Patrick Gegen
description: Thomas Mitchell Crowder and Patrick Antoine Gegen were married Friday at the Astor Center, an event space in New York. The Rev. Ann M. Kansfield, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Jacquelyn Brewer, Peter Manes
description: Dr. Jacquelyn Michelle Brewer and Dr. Richard Peter Manes were married Saturday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Dallas. The Rev. Scott R. Pilarz, a Roman Catholic priest and the president of Marquette University, performed the ceremony.

title: Layla Parast, Jay Bartroff
description: Layla Mosamma Parast and Jay Lindley Bartroff are to be married Sunday at Smog Shoppe, an event space in Los Angeles. Larry M. Goldstein, a Universal Life minister and a colleague of the bridegroom at the University of Southern California, is to officiate.

title: Leah Wool, Joshua Holbreich
description: Leah Beth Wool and Joshua Holbreich are to be married Sunday at the Royalton Mansion, an event space at the Roslyn Country Cub in Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Neil Kurshan is to officiate.

title: Ilene Tannen, Alan Schwartz
description: Ilene Beth Tannen and Alan Victor Schwartz are to be married Sunday afternoon by Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Kimberly Masius, Gregory Frezados
description: Kimberly Morris Masius and Gregory Andrew Frezados were married Saturday evening in Chicago. Marguerite H. Griffin, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Womans Athletic Club.

title: Milano Miodini, Robert Buckley
description: Milano Miodini and Robert E. F. Buckley were married Saturday evening at St. Bartholomews Church in New York. The Rev. Lynn Sanders, an Episcopal priest and the churchs associate rector, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Joseph Wiley Cooper, also an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: Jackie Kucinich and Jared Allen
description: Jackie Kucinich, the daughter of Sandra K. Horn of Columbus, Ohio, and Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Cleveland, was married Saturday to Jared Louis Allen, a son of Dr. Edward A. Allen of Fitchburg, Mass. The Rev. John F. Wiley, a minister of the Church of Gospel Ministry, officiated at the home of the brides father in Washington.

title: Hilary Hartman, Benjamin Mossberg
description: Hilary Elizabeth Hartman, a daughter of Karen and Jack Hartman of Rome, is to be married Sunday evening to Benjamin David Mossberg, a son of Marjorie Golden-Mossberg and Sheldon Mossberg of Columbia, Conn. Rabbi David Shneyer is to officiate at the Briar Patch Bed and Breakfast in Middleburg, Va.

title: Allison Levine and Michael Stillman
description: Allison Kaye Levine, the daughter of Arleen B. Levine of New York and the late Paul E. Levine, was married Saturday evening to Michael Jason Stillman, the son of Donna Stillman and Alan N. Stillman, also of New York. Judge Richard Clifton of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, whose chambers are in Honolulu, officiated at the Lodge at Koele, a resort in Lanai City, Hawaii.

title: Alexis Foucek and Anthony Tse
description: Alexis Rose Foucek and Anthony Kah-Ming Tse were married Saturday evening at Saucon Valley Country Club in Bethlehem, Pa. Rabbi Roger Ross officiated.

title: Pamela Simpson and Kevin Nichols
description: Pamela Brooke Hunter Simpson and Kevin Christopher Nichols were married Saturday evening at St. Francis in the Fields Episcopal Church in Harrods Creek, Ky. The Rev. Robert T. Jennings performed the ceremony.

title: Anna Handzlik, Jordan Sekulow
description: Anna Jean Handzlik, the daughter of Barbara Jean Handzlik of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., and Jan L. Handzlik of Manhattan Beach, Calif., was married Friday evening to Jordan Adam Sekulow, a son of Pamela McPherson Sekulow and Jay Sekulow of Washington. The Rev. Robert L. Schenck, a minister of the Evangelical Church Alliance, officiated at the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington.

title: Kathryn Dineen and Alexander Lawton
description: Kathryn Patricia Dineen, the daughter of Patricia Jaquith Dineen of West Springfield, Mass., and the late Gary Dineen, was married in Chatham, Mass., Saturday to Alexander Waye Lawton, a son of Sandra Waye-Lawton and Robert Lawton of Sudbury, Mass. The Rev. Kathleen Geagan Ryan, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Chatham Bars Inn.

title: Sarah Hargrove, Courtney Mitchell
description: Sarah Barnes Hargrove and Courtney Patrick Mitchell were married Saturday evening at the First United Methodist Church in Huntsville, Ala. The Rev. Coy Hallmark, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Erin Darboven, Douglas Havlina
description: Erin Gilmore Darboven and Douglas William Havlina were married Saturday afternoon at Sal J. Prezioso Mountain Lakes Park in Lewisboro, N.Y. The Rev. Gwyneth MacKenzie Murphy, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Yates, Anthony Keizner
description: Elizabeth Anne Yates and Anthony Ian Keizner were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell a member of the office of the New York City clerk, officiated. On Saturday, the couple had another ceremony at the Inn at Perry Cabin in St. Michaels, Md., where Niclas Kvarnstrom, a friend of the bridegroom who is a counselor at the Swedish Mission to the United Nations, led the couple in vows that they wrote.

title: Gwendolyn Sommer, Charles Heck
description: Gwendolyn Solmssen Sommer and Charles Bennett Heck are to be married Sunday at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in New York. Marcia Aronoff, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Outlook magazines issue this week is an anniversary special about Indias much discussed youth. In the lead essay, Akash Kapur, who previously wrote the International Herald Tribunes Letter from India, says the youths optimism and self-assuredness, their faith in the future, have come to sand, metonymically, for a nation that is itself regularly rates, in surveys and opinion polls, as among the most optimistic and self-assured in the world. The special also includes interesting features about young Indian politicians, journalists, entrepreneurs and the cosmetics business.Tehelka has a story on the plight of residents of Delhi slums who have been evicted to make way for shopping malls, apartments and other new developments. Many of the evicted residents have ended up in worse conditions further away from the city, the piece argues, because local authorities have not made any provision for low-cost housing. One evicted resident tells the magazine: For the government, we are like cattle who have strayed into their fields uninvited.

title: Wrong Place, Wrong Timing for Napoli in Game 3
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Mike Napoli usually watches a game unfold from behind a catchers mask, but his view at first base was crystal clear when it came to the tag he applied on Matt Holliday.

title: African and Latin Beats at Prague Festival
description: An up-and-coming festival dedicated to Latin and African dance moves kicks off in Pragues Old Town on Nov. 2. Heading into its second year, the Afro-Bailar Festival is taking over the Latin dance club Palanca on the fifth floor of the newly renovated Kotva department store (Namesti Republiky 8; www.palanca.cz), with a solid offering of international dance performances and workshops. There will be a little of everything, from salsa, reggae and tango to the sweet rhythmic beats of Africas popular kizomba, mbalax and semba music.

title: Chargers at Jets: Matchup to Watch
description: Chargers (4-1) at Jets (3-3), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Gale Gillingham, a Packers Hall of Famer
description: In the era before offensive linemen were allowed to open their hands and extend their arms, for both run and pass blocking, Gale Gillingham was an unusual combination of power and technique. Gillingham died on Thursday at his home in Minnesota. He was 67. A few thoughts:

title: For Pujols, a Game for the Ages
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: For New Zealand, a Rugby World Cup on Home Soil
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  Twenty-four years of Rugby World Cup pain and misery melted away for New Zealand on Sunday.

title: A Salmon Virus: Where Do We Go From Here?
description: If anything is certain about the recent discovery of infectious salmon anemia in two wild juvenile salmon in British Columbia, it is the extent of the uncertainties. Questions range from whether its discovery will be confirmed in additional laboratory tests to whether it has spread widely to how to contain it. Filling in the unknowns is the first order of business.

title: Many Die as Eastern Turkey Is Jolted by Quake
description: ISTANBUL  At least 138 people were killed and about 350 were injured after a powerful earthquake struck eastern Turkey, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in a news conference early Monday. The death toll was expected to rise, perhaps significantly, with many people reported to be stuck beneath dozens of collapsed buildings.

title: Deck Chairs, Titanic
description: OK, yes, European banks do need more capital. But their problems are a symptom of the underlying sovereign debt problem, which can only be resolved, if at all, with ECB lending AND a commitment to reflate. Without that, the losses on sovereign debt will blow right through any amount of newly raised bank capital.

title: Afghan President Says His Country Would Back Pakistan in a Clash With the U.S.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Days after he stood with Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and accused Pakistan of harboring his countrys enemies, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan said this weekend that his country would support Pakistan if it ever went to war with the United States.

title: Paul Leka, a Songwriter of Na Na Hey Hey, Dies at 68
description: Paul Leka, a songwriter and producer who worked with many recording stars but who was best known for writing the chanting chorus of Na Na Hey Hey (Kiss Him Goodbye), a No. 1 hit in 1969 that was reborn in the 1970s as a sports arena anthem, died on Oct. 12 in a hospice near his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 68.

title: U.S. to Sustain Military Power in the Pacific, Panetta Says
description: BALI, Indonesia  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said on Sunday that despite hundreds of billions of dollars in expected cuts to the Pentagon budget, the United States would remain a Pacific power even as China expanded its military presence in the region.

title: Manchester Massacre
description: Blue Sunday in Manchester.  City blue.

title: Clinton Defends Iraq Withdrawal Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday strongly defended President Obamas plan to withdraw combat troops from Iraq by the end of the year and issued a pointed warning to Iran not to underestimate the United States commitment to stability in the region.

title: Viewing Qaddafi's Body
description: Hundreds of Libyans from all over the country traveled to get a look at the body of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Tunisians Vote in a Milestone of Arab Change
description: TUNIS  Millions of Tunisians cast votes on Sunday for an assembly to draft a constitution and shape a new government, in a burst of pride and hope that after inspiring uprisings across the Arab world, their small country could now lead the way to democracy.

title: Palestinian Bid for Full Unesco Membership Imperils American Financing
description: PARIS  The Palestinian bid for full membership in Unesco  the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization  has put both Washington and the organization into an urgent bind.

title: Paranormal Activity 3 Has Record Opening Weekend
description: North American moviegoers were in the mood to be scared over the weekend, powering the micro-budgeted Paranormal Activity 3 to a stronger-than-anticipated $54 million in ticket sales. That total, easily enough for No. 1, prompted Paramount Pictures, the studio behind this wildly successful horror franchise, to shriek with delight, or at least superlatives. (According to Paramount, the opening weekend total for Paranormal Activity 3, which cost just $5 million to make, is the biggest in history for a horror film  not accounting for inflation.) The studio partly attributed strong sales to strikingly positive reviews, which helped draw more moviegoers in their 30s and 40s.

title: Biden Wont Rule Out 2016 Bid for President
description: In the upcoming 2012 election, Joe Biden will rally around the flag of President Barack Obama, but in 2016? He just might run for president himself  again.

title: Victory Exalts a New Master of Manchester
description: MANCHESTER, England  The sign said Old Trafford welcomes supporters of Manchester City, but in the stadium, it did not feel that way.

title: Revolution Won, Top Libyan Official Vows a New and More Pious State
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  The leader of the transitional government declared to thousands of revelers in a sunlit square here on Sunday that Libyas revolution had ended, setting the country on the path to elections, and he vowed that the new government would be based on Islamic tenets.

title: Touring the Fringes, the Final Hours of CMJ
description: I made the decision to spend the final day of this years CMJ festival on the fringes, at several of the symbiotic, or parasitic, events that pop up during CMJ week to take advantage of the sheer number of musicians stalking the city with an hour to spare. First, there was the Fader Fort, thrown by the Fader magazine and Fiat. That was followed by a Converse-sponsored showcase of hip-hop and hardcore at Santos Party House. After that, I closed the night at the New Museum, at a party organized by the Pitchfork spin-off site Altered Zones. All times are approximate. All feelings are not.

title: Video From the Quake Zone in Turkey
description: Updated | Monday | 9:29 a.m. After a powerful earthquake struck eastern Turkey on Sunday, video posted online showed collapsed buildings and widespread panic.

title: Designing for Safety in Turkey and Other Earthquake Zones
description: Oct. 24, 5:32 a.m. | Updated The latest earthquake in Turkey  that countrys strongest in a decade  provides a fresh reminder of the deep vulnerability created by weak building designs in the worlds crowded seismic danger zones. There will be more horror to come there and in other places prone to powerful quakes.

title: European Leaders Deal Directly With Debt Dilemma
description: BRUSSELS  With a new sense of urgency, the leaders of the 27 European Union nations grappled directly on Sunday with their thorniest financial and economic problems, and made progress that they promised could yield a complete package of measures within days.

title: Perry Comments Raise Birther Flap Again
description: New comments by Rick Perry in Parade magazine have revived the issue of whether the Texas governor believes that President Obama was born in the United States.

title: Personal Eco-Concierges Ease Transition to Green
description: They will run your errands by bicycle, recommend a spa that gives vegan manicures or buy organic clothes for you and your dog. They will even book you a dream vacation and buy the appropriate carbon offsets.

title: More Grim Euro Thoughts
description: It now appears that as of today European leaders have boldly agreed to  announce something or other later in the week.

title: Jets Revive Their Offense and Their Attitude
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In a far corner of the Jets locker room Sunday, where tumult and turmoil once reigned, linebacker Calvin Pace peddled optimism. He spoke of keeping faith, of confidence, of keeping that train moving to Indianapolis  the site of Super Bowl XLVI. In two weeks, the Jets have been transformed.

title: Kenya Says Western Nations Join Fight in Somalia, as U.S. Denies Role
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Foreign military forces have joined the offensive against the Shabab militant group in Somalia as Kenyan troops advanced toward the rebel stronghold of Kismayu from two different directions, Kenya said Sunday.

title: Masters at Giving People the Creeps of the Kind That Keep on Creeping
description: The best work in dark fantasy and horror fiction these days is being published by small presses, haunted literary boutiques established (mostly) in out-of-the-way places.

title: Tunisia Votes
description: David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Soussa, Tunisia, where the first democratic elections since the beginning of the Arab Spring are underway.

title: The Enabling Violation of International Adoption
Republicans Turn Judicial Power Into a Campaign Issue
description: WASHINGTON  Republican presidential candidates are issuing biting and sustained attacks on the federal courts and the role they play in American life, reflecting and stoking skepticism among conservatives about the judiciary.

title: A Card Game Played With High Stakes
description: When you arrive at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in the East Village, the usher hands you a program and a few extra photocopied sheets. One shows a familiar face: that of the usher himself, the playwright-director-actor Rome Neal, currently playing Thelonious Monk in a one-man show at the Moldy Fig, a jazz club a few blocks away. Hes also happy to point you toward the bathroom, which is plastered with posters for Rome Neals Banana Puddin, a monthly jazz jam session and open-mike night at the poets cafe.

title: Family Dysfunctions and the Duct Tape Dtente
description: In the people-behaving-dysfunctionally genre of reality television youre likely to see almost anyone wander across the screen in addition to the loony stars: their relatives, their hairstylists, their therapists. But theres one type of person you almost never see, because to put such a person on camera would undercut the fly-on-the-wall conceit behind these shows: a member of the crew doing the filming.

title: Do Good Debaters Make Good Presidents?
Women in Love Leap Into Elevator Shafts
description: Judging by her new work, which explores what it means to be a woman in love  its cheeky title is simply the One  it just wouldnt do to describe Lyndsey Karr as the romantic type. As two women, more often naked than not, take the audience on a trip to three sites within the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens, Ms. Karr, with deadpan whimsy, both demonstrates and ridicules archetypes of the besotted.

title: 60s Soul-Jazz Filtered Through a Quiet Storm
description: George Benson comes from the school of jazz in which you play frantic bebop guitar solos in long phrases over tight disco beats, sing love ballads, mug through exaggerated voices, provide your own canned laughter, tell stories about Miles Davis and James Brown and, like a ventriloquist, say Shut up to your instrument. Its the school of jazz in which your keyboardist uses synthesizer settings to conjure the flutes and woodwinds that arent there  even playing an entire solo in fake-flute tones  and your showman drummer plays hammer-blow downbeats and moth-wing cymbal touches.

title: A Double Turns Double-Edged
description: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands  At the world championships here, after 48 boards of the 96-board quarterfinals, the six United States teams are locked in close battles.

title: Apples Lower Prices Are All Part of the Plan
description: Something unexpected has happened at Apple, once known as the tech industrys high-price leader. Over the last several years it began beating rivals on price.

title: American Symphony Orchestra
description: Carnegie Hall

title: American Composers Orchestra
description: World Financial Center

title: Monday: Living Off the Land
description: Administrivial Delay: Due to unforeseen circumstances, my wrap-up of the Crossing Words Contest and the second part of my interview with Patrick Berry will run on Monday.

title: A Fresh Reading of The Breakfast Club
description: Fans of The Breakfast Club were in luck on Thursday as the Los Angeles County Museum of Art hosted a high-profile table reading of that quintessential 1985 film about teenagers and their stereotypes, Entertainment Weekly reported on its Web site. Instead of the original stars from the film, a different group of actors joined for the occasion. Jennifer Garner played the popular Claire (Molly Ringwalds part in the movie), James Van Der Beek was Andy the jock (Emilio Estevez), Patton Oswalt was the nerdy Brian (Anthony Michael Hall), Mindy Kaling was the misunderstood Allison (Ally Sheedy), and Aaron Paul was the school-detention lifer Bender (Judd Nelson).  J. K. Simmons and Michael Chiklis were the only two (fictional) adults in the room, portraying Carl the janitor and the hard-line teacher Mr. Vernon. The event was the brainchild of the director Jason Reitman (Juno, Up in the Air). I needed a film that was in a contained location with not too many characters, that was funny, that was populous, that had a great script that the audience would have a relationship with, Mr. Reitman told Entertainment Weekly. He also said he would soon announce five additional readings of different movies to benefit Film Independent, an organization that supports independent film projects and artists.

title: A Designer Without the Flash
description: Charlotte Ronson, decidedly less flashy than her twin, the D.J., has quietly evolved into one of the most successful retail entrepreneurs of her generation.

title: Group Says Newspapers Arent Dead, Theyre Alluring
description: With more people getting their daily dose of news online through blogs and social media sites, traditional newspapers have gotten short shrift. Print is dead or dying, say media experts, and advertising cant keep pace.

title: For Black Coaches in the N.F.L., Still a Steep Road to the Top
description: When Al Davis hired Art Shell as the head coach of the Los Angeles Raiders in 1989, Clarence Shelmon was a 37-year-old running backs coach at the University of Southern California.

title: Dallas Museum Lands New Director
description: Maxwell L. Anderson, who has been director of the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 2006, has been appointed director of the Dallas Museum of Art. He succeeds Bonnie Pitman, who retired from the job in June. Mr. Anderson is a well-known figure, having run the Whitney Museum of American Art from 1998 to 2003, when he resigned after disagreements with its board. During his tenure at the Indianapolis museum attendance has more than doubled, to 450,000 visitors annually. Mr. Anderson introduced innovative Internet-based tools to engage the public, including a dedicated video channel for art and artists and a dashboard that provided users with real-time statistics, like the number of visitors that day. In June 2010 the Indianapolis Museum of Art opened 100 Acres: The Virginia B. Fairbanks Art & Nature Park, among the largest contemporary art parks in the country. Mr. Anderson is to begin his new job on Jan. 9.

title: Metro Pucks: A Week of Underachievement, and a Bit of Cheating
description: Our weekly review of the performances of the three local N.H.L. teams.

title: Suddenly Two Bosses Leave the Show Boss
description: Something unusual happened to the political drama Boss at the end of September: Starz ordered a second season before the first season had begun. Then on Saturday, the day after the premiere, Deadline Hollywood reported that two of the executive producers of the series, Richard Levine and Lyn Greene, were leaving before work started on the second season. They had shared the post of show runner for the first season. Deadline Hollywood reported that Starz and the shows producer, Lionsgate, were seeking replacements. The creator of Boss, Farhad Safinia, will remain, as will four other executive producers, including Kelsey Grammer, who stars as a tyrannical Chicago mayor.

title: Even in Jerusalem, Thoughts Stray to Zuccotti Park
description: For Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the specter of Occupy Wall Street looms large  even in Jerusalem.

title: Anticipating Big Growth at Tesla
description: Tesla Motors makes pure electric cars, but its valued like a hybrid. Quarterly numbers  due in the coming weeks  hint at its ability to hit manufacturing targets. But Silicon Valley-style growth is central to the story.

title: With Eye on Beloved Rangers, Orchestra Plays On
description: DALLAS  They stood anxiously in tuxedo tails and black evening gowns  violinists, oboists and cellists packed three deep, craning to catch a glimpse of the wall-mounted television in the musicians lounge as St. Louis Cardinals pitcher Kyle Lohse looked in for the sign.

title: Charles Hamm, Author on American Popular Music, Dies at 86
description: Charles Hamm, who helped establish the field of American popular music history with two books that have become standard texts, died on Oct. 16 in Lebanon, N. H. He was 86.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include S.& P./Case-Shiller Home Price Index and consumer confidence (Tuesday); durable goods orders and sales of new homes (Wednesday); third-quarter gross domestic product and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and personal income, personal spending, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey and pending home sales (Friday).

title: Euro Flails but Art Fair Flourishes
description: PARIS  The mood was unexpectedly buoyant at the Grand Palais here on Thursday, the opening day of the 38th International Contemporary Art Fair, even as European leaders were desperately dashing around the Continent trying to save their common currency.

title: India and Pakistan Sidestep a Crisis
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A potential military and diplomatic crisis was averted Sunday after an Indian Army helicopter that had strayed into Pakistans airspace and was forced to land by its military was allowed to return home, according to Pakistani officials.

title: Questioning Privacy Protections in Research
description: Hoping to protect privacy in an age when a fingernail clipping can reveal a persons identity, federal officials are planning to overhaul the rules that regulate research involving human subjects. But critics outside the biomedical arena warn that the proposed revisions may unintentionally create a more serious problem: sealing off vast collections of publicly available information from inspection, including census data, market research, oral histories and labor statistics.

title: At London Theater, a Celebration of Biblical Proportions
description: Gods terse first line in the Book of Genesis  Let there be light  was ready-made for the Twitter generation. If only the rest was as crisp, the British novelist Jeanette Winterson recalled thinking, as she began to reckon with that first book for a new theatrical project on the King James Bible. And then it hit her: Maybe Gods wisdom would crackle for a modern audience as Twitter posts of 140 words or less.

title: Broadway Debut After a Life of Opera
description: The ageless mezzo-soprano Rosalind Elias had never heard a note of Stephen Sondheims score for Follies when her agent first approached her about auditioning for the small, poignant role of Heidi Schiller, which she is now playing to acclaim in the popular revival at the Marquis Theater on Broadway.

title: A Glut of Bands, Amid a Fog of Blaring Sound
description: A big part of this years CMJ Music Marathon  the 31st annual showcase for mostly new, mostly independent music presented by what began as College Music Journal  went by in a haze.

title: Investigate Stop and Frisk
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Fluoridation
description: To the Editor:

title: World Series Game 4: Rangers 4, Cardinals 0
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  With his team in need of a win and his bullpen in need of some rest, the Rangers Derek Holland rose to the occasion, allowing just two hits over eight and a third innings as the Rangers beat the Cardinals, 4-0, to tie the World Series at two games apiece.

title: Inside CMJ
description: A look at some of the acts that were part of the 31st CMJ Music Marathon.

title: Shifting Attitudes on Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Romney, Once a Critic, Hedges on Flat-Tax Plans
description: As several leading Republican presidential candidates embrace a flat tax as a core campaign position, one contender stands out in not doing so: Mitt Romney, who has a long record of criticizing such plans and famously derided Steve Forbess 1996 proposal as a tax cut for fat cats.

title: In a Gloomy Economy, TV Sitcoms Are Making a Comeback
description: In television, funny is money again.

title: State Investigates Thefts of Prescription Pads at Hospitals
description: An unknown number of blank prescription forms have been stolen from New York City hospitals over the past several years in what investigators believe is a scheme by gang members to make money from addicts desperate for prescription painkillers.

title: Anna Bolena
description: Metropolitan Opera

title: Kerley Making the Jets Forget About Mason
description: A quick look at the Jets 27-21 victory over San Diego:

title: Seven Billion
description: ONE week from today, the United Nations estimates, the worlds population will reach seven billion. Because censuses are infrequent and incomplete, no one knows the precise date  the Census Bureau puts it somewhere next March  but there can be no doubt that humanity is approaching a milestone.

title: Small Isnt Always Beautiful
description: Washington

title: From Newsstand to Cooktop
description: For the celebrity chefs Emeril Lagasse and Wolfgang Puck, the kitchen counter is about to grow more crowded with a new set of culinary tools.

title: Well-Known Felon Still Draws a Crowd, but Louisiana Has Moved On
description: CROWLEY, La.  If the test of a first-rate intelligence, as F. Scott Fitzgerald claimed, is the ability to hold two opposing ideas in the mind at the same time, there was the whiff of brilliance amid the scent of barbecue and fry-grease at the 75th International Rice Festival.

title: More Jobs Predicted for Machines, Not People
description: A faltering economy explains much of the job shortage in America, but advancing technology has sharply magnified the effect, more so than is generally understood, according to two researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: The Hole in Europes Bucket
description: If it werent so tragic, the current European crisis would be funny, in a gallows-humor sort of way. For as one rescue plan after another falls flat, Europes Very Serious People  who are, if such a thing is possible, even more pompous and self-regarding than their American counterparts  just keep looking more and more ridiculous.

title: A Prodigal Daughter Returns Home
description: Audra McDonalds Carnegie Hall concert on Saturday evening had the feel of a homecoming celebration for a prodigal daughter: in an unbroken wave of adoration, all was forgiven. Ms. McDonalds crime, if there was one, was her temporary abandonment of musical theater for television. For four seasons, while playing Dr. Naomi Bennett in the ABC series Private Practice, she more or less disappeared from music.

title: Battle for Libya | October 23, 2011
description: The leader of Libyas transitional government declared to thousands of revelers in Benghazi that Libyas revolution had ended, setting the country on the path to elections.

title: Jobs Plan Stalled, Obama to Try New Economic Drive
description: WASHINGTON  With his jobs plan stymied in Congress by Republican opposition, President Obama on Monday will begin a series of executive-branch actions to confront housing, education and other economic problems over the coming months, heralded by a new mantra: We cant wait for lawmakers to act.

title: After Top 2, Oklahoma St. Has Inside Track
description: The losses by national title contenders Wisconsin and Oklahoma threw the Bowl Championship Series race into a tizzy. College football, after a few weeks heavy on chalk and light on thrillers, re-emerged as the unpredictable and parity-laden beast that had driven the sports popularity and television ratings the past few years.

title: Robert Pierpoint, 86, Dies; CBS News Correspondent
description: Robert Pierpoint, the CBS News correspondent who brought a human-interest touch to coverage of the Korean War and later reported on six presidents, from Dwight D. Eisenhower to Jimmy Carter, died Saturday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 86.

title: Redemption Is in Burresss Sizable Reach
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Crucial Test for Nokia as Latest Smartphones Arrive
description: BERLIN  When Stephen Elop, the chief executive of Nokia, introduces the companys first phones bearing Microsoft Windows Phone software Wednesday, he will probably be met with equal parts good will and skepticism.

title: Economy Casts Shadow on Advertisers Forum
description: Phoenix

title: Kirchner Achieves an Easy Victory in Argentina Presidential Election
description: BUENOS AIRES  President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner of Argentina cruised to re-election on Sunday, riding a wave of economic prosperity in her quest to continue the political dynasty begun by her late husband, former President Nstor Kirchner.

title: No Holiday
description: Big business has clearly decided that the economic crisis is too important to waste. While Washington debates how to create jobs and cut the budget deficit, major corporations  read major campaign contributors  are pushing Congress for an enormous tax cut on corporate profits. Lawmakers seem all too eager to grant their wish.

title: In College, Working Hard to Learn High School Material
description: In June, Desiree Smith was graduated from Murry Bergtraum High. Her grades were in the 90s, she said, and she had passed the four state Regents exams. Since enrolling last month at LaGuardia Community College in Queens, Ms. Smith, 19, has come to realize that graduating from a New York City public high school is not the same as learning.

title: Sports Replay, Oct. 23
description: A look at the day in sports worldwide: the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand; the Pan American Games in and around Guadalajara, Mexico; and N.F.L. games in the United States  and London.

title: What Kind of Government?
description: The F.B.I.s reputation has been seriously stained by the James (Whitey) Bulger case and its disclosures that the agency protected murderers to use them as informants against the Mafia.

title: 2 Japanese Bankers at Heart of Olympus Fee Inquiry
description: For two decades, a pair of Japanese bankers toiled away in relative anonymity on Wall Street, hopping from firm to firm.

title: At Elite Schools, Easing Up a Bit on Homework
description: It was the kind of memo that high school students would dream of getting, if they dreamed in memos.

title: Empty Fields Fill Urban Basins and Farmers Pockets
description: BRAWLEY, Calif.  Three generations of Al Kalins family have worked their 2,000 acres of carrots and sugar beets, wheat and alfalfa for almost a century in the Imperial Valley, a scorching swath of Southern California desert that was unfit for farming until water from the Colorado River was diverted here in 1901.

title: Californias Persistence
description: California has a long and productive history as a leader in environmental policy, requiring cleaner cars and power plants and more energy-efficient appliances. The state continued to break new ground last week when it unveiled the countrys first comprehensive, statewide cap-and-trade system to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change.

title: Environmental Features in Science Campus Plans
description: If Cornell University were to win the citys competition to build a new science graduate school, it would install on Roosevelt Island almost four acres of solar panels, 500 geothermal wells, and buildings with the rare distinction of generating as much power as they use.

title: Reward at Either End of Money List
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  There was a time when Justin Leonard stalked the greens the way an eagle-eyed Luke Donald did on Sunday en route to winning the last official PGA Tour event of the year.

title: Why Not Occupy Newsrooms?
description: Almost two weeks ago, USA Today put its finger on why the Occupy Wall Street protests continued to gain traction.

title: Records and Wins for Houston Quarterback
description: The off-campus garage apartment that Houston quarterback Case Keenum and his wife, Kimberly, share is so modest that it does not have a full number in its mailing address. The Keenums lovingly refer to their home as the Half, a cozy starter spot.

title: Two Cheers for the Malaria Vaccine
description: A vaccine to protect children against malaria has been shown moderately effective in a large clinical trial  an achievement that could save millions of lives. The vaccine, known as RTS,S and made by GlaxoSmithKline, is the first ever to be shown effective against a human disease caused by parasites. When tested in 6,000 infants ages 5 to 17 months in seven sub-Saharan nations, it reduced the risk of infection with severe malaria by 47 percent during the year after the shots, far less than the 90 percent efficacy rate typically sought for other vaccines. And there are other big hurdles still to surmount. There are hints that the protection may wane over time and results from administering a booster shot wont be known until 2014. Side effects could pose a problem; seizures and fevers were higher among children given the vaccine.

title: Apple Posts Video From Steve Jobs Tribute
description: Apple has posted a video of a tribute to Steven P. Jobs, the companys co-founder, that took place last week at the Apple campus in Cupertino, Calif. (The video must be viewed in the Safari Web browser.)

title: Tebow Wills Broncos to Win With His Late-Game Play
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  It seemed as if everyone in the stadium knew what play the Denver Broncos would run on the 2-point conversion that would tie the game with 17 seconds to play. For 55 minutes, Tim Tebow had barely looked like a functioning N.F.L quarterback. He took sacks and threw poorly. He was hesitant and overwhelmed.

title: Palmer Struggles in Raiders Debut, but Provides Glimpses of Promise
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The cheers from the home fans began to pick up about two minutes into the third quarter Sunday, which seemed strange only because the Kansas City Chiefs were ahead by 14 points and driving at the time. Then again, at that point, many of the Oakland Raiders followers were no longer watching what was happening on the field anyway.

title: My Kingdom for a Map
description: The Battle of Balls Bluff does not loom large in our memory of the Civil War. Yet it was the second-largest battle in the eastern theater in 1861 and a complete rout of Union forces. James Morgan, an expert on the engagement, has described it as an accidental battle that resulted from erroneous intelligence. But it also reveals something about the wartime role of maps.

title: A Hearing Aid That Cuts Out All the Clatter
description: After he lost much of his hearing last year at age 57, the composer Richard Einhorn despaired of ever really enjoying a concert or musical again. Even using special headsets supplied by the Metropolitan Opera and Broadway theaters, he found himself frustrated by the sound quality, static and interference.

title: Panettas Pentagon, Without the Blank Check
description: WASHINGTON  Tan and ruddy-faced, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta took his seat in a hearing room one morning this month ready for battle. The enemy, he warned lawmakers ominously, was a blind, mindless one that could badly damage our capabilities and truly devastate our national defense.

title: Tech Giants Sizing Up Yahoo Bid
description: As a host of potential bidders circle Yahoo, several of Silicon Valleys biggest companies are considering whether to jump into the fray themselves.

title: Leon E. Panetta, in His Own Words
description: In two extensive interviews, Leon E. Panetta talked about his long career in Washington, his role as the C.I.A. director who oversaw the raid that killed Osama bin Laden and the challenges confronting him as President Obamas new secretary of defense:

title: Investors Wait Warily for Europe Bank Rescue
description: After negotiating through the weekend in Brussels in search of a comprehensive solution to the Continents sovereign debt crisis, European leaders reported progress on the framework of a broad rescue package.

title: A Grass-Roots Newscast Gives a Voice to Struggles
description: Hours after Amy Goodman, the host of the grass-roots newscast Democracy Now!, was arrested in Minnesota in 2008 while trying to cover protesters at the Republican National Convention, she was sitting in a network news studio above the convention floor, when a producer said: I dont get it. Why wasnt I arrested?

title: A Princess Visits Queens; Queens Is Impressed
description: Eutha Earl cleared her schedule. She wore her Sunday best. She even barred her son from visiting her apartment in Queens, saying he might distract her from her preparation.

title: One Charger Doesnt Go Down Quietly
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The verbal jousting that accompanied the Jets game Sunday did not end at kickoff. It continued after their 27-21 victory, in the Chargers locker room, where tight end Randy McMichael sounded rather unimpressed with the Jets defense.

title: Studying Successful People With Mental Illness
description: Its long been thought that people with severe mental illness had limited opportunities for work, and many are advised to take on simple, low-stress jobs so as not to exacerbate their symptoms. But now researchers are studying high-functioning people with schizophrenia and its close cousin, schizoaffective disorder.

title: Slaughter of Horses Goes On, Just Not in U.S.
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  The closing of the countrys last meat processing plant that slaughtered horses for human consumption was hailed as a victory for equine welfare. But five years later just as many American horses are destined for dinner plates to satisfy the still robust appetites for their meat in Europe and Asia.

title: A Note to Our Readers
Antonio Cassese, War Crimes Law Expert, Dies at 74
description: Antonio Cassese, a prominent Italian jurist who helped found two international war-crimes tribunals and who was often described as the chief architect of modern international criminal justice, died early Saturday at his home in Florence, Italy. He was 74.

title: Jerzy Bielecki Dies at 90; Fell in Love in a Nazi Camp
description: Jerzy Bielecki was 19 years old, Roman Catholic and suspected of being a member of the Polish resistance when he was arrested by the Nazis in June 1940 and transported to Auschwitz, where the number 243 was tattooed on his arm.

title: In Race to Replace Him, Lieberman Again Has Liberals Shaking Their Heads
description: WASHINGTON  A few months ago, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, an independent from Connecticut who is allied with the Democratic majority in the Senate, had a surprising guest at his office: Linda E. McMahon, the former wrestling mogul who is seeking the Republican nomination for Mr. Liebermans Senate seat, now that he is retiring.

title: The Wedding as Spectacle, Bearing a Message
description: If most New Yorkers have probably not heard of the couple who celebrated their wedding in spectacular style on Sunday evening, thats because most New Yorkers are not celebrities, mega-wealthy or ultrapowerful.

title: Booksellers Through the Ages
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Tensions Persist Over a Man Long Missing
description: ELLENVILLE, N.Y.  The flier was bright red with a photograph and a few lines of text: Candlelight Vigil For Joe Helt, it read. 24 Years Is Too Long!

title: Potential New Saudi Crown Prince Seen as Hard-Line but Pragmatic
description: CAIRO  With the presidents of Egypt and Tunisia tumbling and much of the region churning this past February, Prince Nayef bin Abdul Aziz, the veteran Saudi interior minister who is expected to be elevated to crown prince this week, swept into a private Riyadh home where he had summoned leading editors and columnists to dinner.

title: Does Tim Tebow Look Like an N.F.L. Starter to You?
description: Just to be clear: Matt Prater won Sundays Broncos game with a 52-yard field goal in overtime. Tim Tebow did not snap for it, hold for it or kick it.

title: Steve Jobss Search for His Father
description: A Sunday night interview on 60 Minutes with Steve Jobss biographer, Walter Isaacson, included audio recordings of Mr. Jobs describing a remarkable moment in his life: an accidental encounter with his biological father.

title: Jets Replay: Week 7 vs. Chargers
description: Plaxico Burresss three touchdowns lead the Jets to a 27-21 win over the Chargers.

title: Events Erode Hope of a Tax Overhaul Before Election Day
description: WASHINGTON  Even in good times, tax reform poses steep political challenges. And these arent exactly good times.

title: World Series Replay: Oct. 23

Whether in South America, the Adirondacks, the Serengeti or Asia, theres enormous logic in finding ways to mesh human livelihoods and wildlife that dont involve fences. The card was prompted indirectly by my recent coverage of raids of Gibson Guitar facilities under environmental laws. His dispatch is below (Ive added some contextual links):

title: Domebound
description: In 1948, the architect and inventor Buckminster Fuller gathered a group of his students at Black Mountain College to build a life-size geodesic dome. The dome was a flop. It succeeded, however, in planting the seed for the sculptor Kenneth Snelson, a student of Fullers, to develop the principle of tensegrity that would allow Fuller to build a dome for the United States Pavilion at Expo 67 in Montreal. For the Performa 11 biennial (11.performa-arts.org), the Los Angeles artist Liz Glynn will retrace Fullers steps, pratfalls and all. Part 1 of her performance  a loosely choreographed re-enactment of Fullers failed attempt  takes place on the first Sunday of the biennial in locations throughout New York City, including Times Square; for Part 2, 25 volunteers will assist in building a dome. Whether it will stand remains to be seen. But Glynns cast-concrete dome sculptures (above), on view at the Performa Hub through Nov. 21, are objects of perfection of which even Fuller might have approved.
