title: Hidden Gem
description: Ten years is the length of an average commercial lease, but its also, as the designer Ted Muehling has discovered, the approximate life span of a neighborhood. Back in 2001, Muehling moved his storefront workshop from a formerly desolate block on Greene Street to Howard Street  at the time SoHos final frontier. But when a Mondrian hotel went up nearby, so did Muehlings rent, and the designer moved on once again. His new store, on White Street in TriBeCa, is grander in proportion and there is more selling space, but also more space for Muehling to display the many things he collects and that inspire him, from natural wonders like seashells or insects to the work of his partner, the artist Mats Gustafson, or that of his friend Jan Baracz, who carves bellybuttons into large stones. And while his workrooms are smaller, for the first time Muehling has a little studio all his own  an attic tucked into a mezzanine under a skylight in the back. The timing could not have been better. With his product collaborations with Nymphenburg and Steuben winding down, Muehling is eager to get back to making jewelry. On a recent morning, a pair of canaries twittered joyfully, and an installation of monarch butterflies on a dried mullein stem was magically animated by a breeze from the air-conditioner. As with his previous store, this one is livened by sounds from behind the scenes  the bang of metal on metal, the murmur of NPR  evidence that this is a place where things are made and not just sold. Its the kind of neighborhood place, Muehling points out, where you can walk in and theyll make a new wire for your earring if you dont mind waiting 20 minutes.

Detachment would be healthy for all concerned  no one likes the boss hanging around all the time, and the boss could concentrate on neglected parts of his restaurant (and his life).

description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  Goalkeeper Frank Rost, 38, is the oldest player on the Red Bulls roster (and also one of the tallest at 6 feet 5 inches).

title: A To-Do About a Surprise Much Ado From Joss Whedon
description: 3:28 p.m. | Updated

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 24
description: The Pan American Games continued in Guadalajara, Mexico, with events like wrestling, weight lifting and field hockey.

title: Notes From the Underground | Lightyear
description: Lightyear, the artist formerly known as Lauren Zettler, celebrated the release of her new EP, All of the Miles, with an intimate performance at Flux Studios. Zettler alternated between the piano and acoustic guitar, leading a small band and two backup vocalists through a string of airtight pop-folk numbers. Well produced and thoroughly rehearsed, Lightyear is a solidly professional act from an accomplished songwriter who should soon be mentioned in the same breath with the likes of Meiko, Feist and Regina Spektor.

title: My Three Favorite Appetizers, I Think
description: My three favorite appetizers vary by day, by week  even by moment. I like too many of them. Maybe its because appetizers are a tease. Or maybe its because youre at your hungriest when you eat them. It seems like there are an awful lot of good ones out there. All the better to experiment. If they dont turn out perfect, so what? Theyre not the main course.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Thailand, Turkey, Libya and Cuba.

title: Good Times Gone Bad: The Right to Harm Ourselves
description: A sports arena is a symbol of rousing good times; so is an open bar. Both are also reliable harbingers of medical disaster. And as two new books make clear, when one mans sport is anothers undoing (or merely his own), decades may be lost in bitter disagreement over what is to be done.

title: The Divergent Fortunes of Saab and Volvo
description: TROLLHATTAN, Sweden  On a gloomy, rainy afternoon, Rafael Hernandez strained through his exercise routine, preparing for the day that he would return to work at the local Saab auto plant.

title: Korean Grilling on Glass, at Kristalbelli
description: Coming to Midtown before Christmas: Kristalbelli, Manhattans latest entry in the global quest to make Korean barbecue upscale, not just popular. Its chef, David Shim, has worked at Gramercy Tavern, LAtelier de Joel Robuchon and Veritas. He promises Wagyu beef, organic vegetables, pork belly and the usual prize morsels for grilling.

title: Tale of Two Swedish Carmakers
description: Volvo and Saab face vastly different outlooks, partly because of their diverging histories under their former American owners, but also because one company found a deep-pocketed rescuer and one did not.

title: Perry to Begin Ad Campaign in Iowa
description: Read the complete report on Mondays changes to Rick Perrys campaign strategy.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Thailand, Turkey, Libya and Afghanistan.

title: Big Deal | Alec Baldwin Buys a Penthouse in the Village
description: Oct. 28, 5:21 p.m. | Updated

title: For a Night, Baseball Beats Football in the Ratings
description: Perhaps it was the 62-7 score, or the increased competition from other networks or an overall lack of interest in a match-up  a rematch of Super Bowl XLIV  between the New Orleans Saints and a Peyton Manning-less Indianapolis Colts team. Whatever the reason, preliminary estimates from Nielsen suggest that Sunday Night Football on NBC posted its lowest rating in nearly three years. It was not the No. 1 program of the night in total viewers or in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. That claim goes to Game 4 of the World Series, in which the Texas Rangers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-0. That baseball game averaged 15.2 million total viewers.

title: Street Style: Capes and Vests
description: The best of readers street fashion photos for the week of Oct. 17.

title: New Unease for Europes Rescue Plan
description: FRANKFURT  As officials worked on Monday to iron out details of a plan to solve the European debt crisis, fears were growing that the result might be another example of European leaders doing less rather than more. And concerns are that it may not be enough.

title: Original Model Ts | David Reinfurt
description: No. 9 in a series of original artworks.

title: Schwarzmans Roast, in Its Entirety
description: Last week, we brought you highlights from a speech given by Stephen A. Schwarzman, the Blackstone Group co-founder, at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner. In the roast, which was widely circulated on Wall Street, Mr. Schwarzman lampooned, among others, Rupert Murdoch, Brian T. Moynihan and himself.

title: Founder Says WikiLeaks, Starved of Cash, May Close
description: LONDON  Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said on Monday that his Web site could be forced to shut down by the end of the year because a 10-month-old financial blockade had sharply reduced the donations on which it depends.

title: In Phone Hacking Inquiry, a Renewed Focus on Executives
description: LONDON  The focus on Rupert Murdochs senior executives in the wake of the News of the World phone hacking scandal intensified on Monday as his former right-hand man was questioned by lawmakers and his son James was summoned to give further testimony next month.

title: Haunting Ideas: Halloween in the Classroom and On the Street
description: This audio slide show, celebrating Halloween in Manhattan, is from October 2010, and is part of the On the Street series reported and narrated by Bill Cunningham, a journalist who is in his early 80s and has worked for The New York Times since the 1970s.

title: Particles Faster Than the Speed of Light? Not So Fast, Some Say
description: Does E still equal MC squared?

title: Surgery Forces Mayer to Cancel Concerts and Postpone His Album
description: John Mayer, the singer and songwriter, has undergone surgery to remove an inflamed growth on his vocal cords that forced him to cancel several concerts and postpone the release of a new album, he wrote on his Tumblr blog.

title: Modest Farmer, Managing Mogul
description: The National Fantasy Baseball Championship, a contest paying a top prize of $100,000, draws an elite collection of contestants: computer geniuses, deep-pocketed stockbrokers and money managers, maybe a young man or woman looking to be the next Billy Beane or Theo Epstein.

title: Drugs to Treat A.D.H.D. Reach the Preschool Set
description: Ruth Grau was first told her son had attention deficit hyperactivity disorder when he was 3. The idea of medicating him was anathema to her, so she and her husband tried an alternative approach: exercise, occupational therapy and a diet free of junk food  no sweets, no dairy, no processed food.

title: Rays Pizza, the Rays Pizza, Will Close on Sunday
description: Fifty-two years and countless oven-hot pies later, Rays Pizza  the Rays Pizza  will serve its last slice on Prince Street on Sunday.

title: Yoga and Stretching Equally Effective for Back Pain
description: Weekly yoga classes relieve symptoms of low back pain about as well as intense, regular stretching sessions, a new study shows.

title: Midlife Weight Loss Cuts Heart Risk
description: Being overweight as a teenager carries a greater risk of being an overweight adult, along with an increased risk of dying of heart disease. But overweight adolescents who slim down in middle age may lower their risk, a new study shows.

title: Abu Dhabi Guggenheim Construction Delayed
description: Plans to award a major construction contract for concrete work on the Guggenheim museum planned for Saadiyat Island in Abu Dhabi have been temporarily suspended, the Associated Press has reported. But officials from the Tourism Development and Investment Company, which is  building the large cultural district in the Emirati capital that the Guggenheim will be part of, said another major museum there  a branch of the Louvre  is on track to open in late 2013.

title: Mammograms Role as Savior Is Tested
description: Has the power of the mammogram been oversold?

title: A Transcendence Anchored in Bach
description: When Lincoln Center introduced its White Light Festival last year, it described it as an exploration of spirituality in music. But the definition was diffuse: where the music was overtly secular, listeners were encouraged to think about the spiritual core of all great art. That was fine advice, but the works Lincoln Center assembled did not really amount to a coherent festival.

title: Stages and Survival (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fleeting Space Mission (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Time, Not TV Time (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Running With the Pack (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lens: Libya
description: Lens: Libya

title: Cameron Faces Internal Revolt Over European Policy
description: LONDON  After being berated by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France at a rancorous European summit meeting over the weekend, Prime Minister David Cameron on Monday faced an all-out rebellion from members of his own party over whether Britain should even be part of the European Union.

title: Childbirth as Performance Art
description: Here are a few things you can go see at Brooklyn art galleries this week: urban tapestries, black-and-white photography, or if you time it right, Marni Kotak giving birth at the Microscope Gallery in Brooklyn.

title: Timescast | October 24, 2011
description: A moderate Islamic party appears to win Tunisias first free election; the search continues for survivors of Turkeys earthquake; and financial troubles could shutter WikiLeaks.

title: Bees Migration Holds Clues to Geologic History
description: Two new bee species shed light on Panamas history as a land bridge between South and Central America, scientists are reporting.

title: In Brooklyn, a Quaint Block and a Symbol of Blight
description: Warren Street between Bond and Nevins offers many of the things well-off buyers seek in Brownstone Brooklyn: a pastoral, leafy feel; long rows of 19th-century town houses; proximity to transportation and charming little restaurants; young families on the block.

title: Disposable Chopsticks Strip Asian Forests
description: Festival season in Japan is a sensory delight. Taiko drums bang while fireworks blaze overhead, delighting kimono-clad onlookers. Perhaps most central to the Japanese festival experience, though, is the food: sizzling meat on a stick, octopus balls and globs of at least four kinds of noodles are only a few of the delicacies on offer.

title: Smooth Desert Boulders May Be Quakes Work
description: Across the Atacama Desert in Chile are thousands of peculiar boulders that look as if they were rubbed smooth across their midsections.

title: MyCityWay  Not Just for Tourists
description: Part city guide, part virtual dashboard, MyCityWay aggregates useful information into one convenient place: your mobile device. Available for more than 40 markets around the globe, each app is a comprehensive travel, reference and city-service guide wrapped into one. The free apps are available for iPhone, Android and Blackberry.

title: Critics Picks: 25th Hour
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Spike Lees drama about a man preparing to go to prison.

title: District Attorney Wont Drop Charges Against Protesters
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office will not summarily dismiss the charges against some 300 Occupy Wall Street protesters who were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct during rallies on the Brooklyn Bridge and at Union Square, a lawyer for the protesters said Monday.

title: Israel Reaches Deal for Release of an American Held in Egypt
description: JERUSALEM  Israel announced Monday that it had reached an agreement with Egypt, with American assistance, for the release of Ilan Grapel, an American law student from Queens who also holds Israeli citizenship.

title: Debt And Devaluation
description: Icelands condition can at best be described as not as bad as it could have been. Im getting a lot of correspondence, in particular, about the problem of household debt. During the boom Icelandic citizens borrowed quite a lot, often with loans that were either euro-denominated or indexed to inflation. With the krona depreciated and real wages lower thanks to higher import prices, this leaves a lot of people in debt distress.

title: Next for Newport Preservation: Gilded-Age Beeches
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  In the Gilded Age, the rich built marble palaces here, surrounding them with exotic trees they acquired with the same ardor they brought to assembling their fabulous collections of art.

title: For iPhones, a Central Park Soundtrack
description: When that great emerald and hilly patch at the center of Manhattan first opened, music was limited to brief concerts under the Naumberg Bandshell. Today, of course, Central Park is fixed in sonic history  landmark rock shows, global benefits, swanky midsummer soirees  so diverse that any attempt to fuse the parks streams, forests and rock faces into a single musical experience seems almost futile.

title: Wired Textiles for a Phone as Useful as the Shirt on Your Back
description: John Volakis wants to make the world hands-free.

title: Hope For HARP
description: Most quick reactions to the new Obama housing proposal have been fairly dismissive, arguing that it would provide only a small boost. I dont have an opinion yet, because I havent had time to work through the details  and on this kind of thing, the devil is very much in the details. (Does that make it another 666 plan?)

title: Lions Dream Season Suddenly Less Dreamy
description: The Detroit Lions are falling back to earth, with their red-hot 5-0 start now down to a 5-2 record, and they are now facing accusations of taunting by an opponent and a possible foot injury to starting quarterback Matthew Stafford.

title: Hendra and Nipah: Antibody Treatment for 2 Deadly Viruses Shows Promise in Tests and an Emergency
description: A treatment using human antibodies against two of the scariest new viruses has protected monkeys in tests, researchers reported last week.

title: Morgan Stanley Sells Mortgage Servicer
description: Morgan Stanley has sold its mortgage servicing company, a deal that will net the Wall Street firm $59.3 million in cash.

title: How Revolutionary Tools Cracked a 1700s Code
description: It has been more than six decades since Warren Weaver, a pioneer in automated language translation, suggested applying code-breaking techniques to the challenge of interpreting a foreign language.

title: At Broadway Box Office This Fall, the Plays the Thing
description: Ticket sales for straight plays on Broadway were notably strong last week, according to theater box office data released on Monday, with most of those non-musical productions making gains in their grosses in an otherwise flat week for Broadway. Indeed, money-wise, new straight plays are poised to have one of their best fall seasons on Broadway in recent years.

title: Sentence of the Month, Juggernauts Edition
description: In an effort to catch up after our recent debilitating case of Sentence Blindness, here are the belated candidates for Septembers Sentence of the Month:

title: A Clear Channel for the Hearing-Impaired
description: A technology widely used in public places in Northern Europe has the potential to transform the lives of tens of millions of hearing-impaired adults in the United States, The Times reported on Monday.

title: The chambered nautilus fights for its life, talking to your shirt and the long-term battle over long-term care.
description: The chambered nautilus fights for its life, talking to your shirt and the long-term battle over long-term care.

title: A Challenge to Conventional Wisdom on Small Business and Jobs
description: Jared Bernstein, who was until May Vice President Joe Bidens top economic adviser, published an article on the Op-Ed page of Mondays Times that challenges much of the orthodoxy about small business in the United States. He argues that small businesses really dont employ the majority of Americans, and that they dont create the majority of new jobs.

title: Clashes With Kurds Are Pushing Turkey Back Toward Conflict
description: CIZRE, Turkey  Thousands of people filled the streets of this dusty town near the borders with Syria and Iraq on Sunday to mourn the death of a local heroine, a commander in a mountaintop training camp for Kurdish militants seeking autonomy for the countrys largely Kurdish southeast.

title: Former American Idol Now the Voice of Vengeance
description: KELLY CLARKSON

title: TimesCast | Moderate Islamist Victory
description: October 24, 2011  A moderate Islamic party appears to be the big winner in Tunisias first elections for an assembly to shape its new government.

title: Retirement Plan Providers Can Now Offer Own Advice
description: Some big retirement plans offer investors the chance to hire an independent adviser that can help them choose their investments. But your plan provider will soon be able to offer the advice itself, as long as it meets rules issued recentlyby the Department of Labor.

title: TimesCast | WikiLeaks Financial Woes
description: Julian Assange says a lack of donations could shutter WikiLeaks by years end.

title: Lens: Pete Muller
description: Lens: Pete Muller

title: ING Direct Drops Rate on Its Savings Account
description: The foreseeable future may already be here, it seems.

title: TimesCast | Turkeys Deadly Earthquake
description: A day after a devastating earthquake shook Eastern Turkey, the search for survivors continues.

title: New Leader for Liberal Research Group
description: A veteran of the Obama and Clinton administrations, Neera Tanden, will be taking over as president of the Center for American Progress, a research organization that represents the views of the presidents more liberal, and somewhat disaffected, base.

title: Leading the March to a Mystical Place
description: Lincoln Centers monthlong White Light Festival is back for its second year. As before, the focus of the event is a little blurry. In the words of Lincoln Centers artistic director, Jane Moss, White Light is an exploration of music and arts power to reveal dimensions of our interior lives. The programs offer a spectrum of artistic expression that moves us inward and expands our spirit.

title: A Look With Fangs
description: At Carine Roitfelds bal des vampires in Paris this month for her book Irreverent, the hostess and guests, like the model Anja Rubik, in a gothic lace-up velvet number, showed that high-fashion vamp calls for skillfully smudged eyes. Start by lining inside and underneath the lash line, then the entire lid with black pencil, the makeup artist Kristin Hilton advises.

title: Scenes from BlizzCon
description: The annual event celebrating the video game company Blizzard Entertainment took place in Anaheim, Calif., last weekend, drawing more than 26,000 attendees.

title: Best Friends, in Fantasy and Reality
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  More than 26,000 people from 50 states and 49 countries arrived here last week for BlizzCon, the annual self-celebration by Blizzard Entertainment, perhaps the most revered video game company in the world.

title: DNC Ad Goes After Romney in Arizona
description: The Democratic National Committee will on Tuesday begin its biggest sustained advertising campaign against a Republican presidential candidate so far this year, with a spot attacking Mitt Romney in the state of Arizona, traditionally Republican territory that President Obamas advisers hope to bring into their victory column next year.

title: Romeo Meets Radiohead in a Love Story of Twitches
description: Heres the pitch: a ballet of Romeo and Juliet. Sure, thats been done before, but this is contemporary, set to songs by Radiohead, sure to appeal to a youthful demographic. And get this: Juliet doesnt kill herself. The whole love story comes through her flashbacks. This thing is stripped-down, chic, just Juliet in a corset and six men in suits without shirts. It doesnt take up your whole evening, either. An hour and youre out.

title: Yes, Those Are Tom, Becky and Huck Leaping
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  On Thursday I was exploring Americas oldest grand opera house still used for its original purpose, the Academy of Music in Philadelphia. Over the weekend I was discovering its newest auditorium for opera and ballet, the Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts here in Kansas City.

title: Critics Picks Video: 25th Hour
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Spike Lees 2002 film 25th Hour. It stars Edward Norton as Monty Brogan, a man experiencing his last day of freedom before going to serve a long prison sentence. It tracks him as he says his goodbyes and takes care of some unfinished business. 25th Hour features a strong ensemble cast, including Brian Cox, Barry Pepper, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Anna Paquin and Rosario Dawson as Montys girlfriend. But the real love interest, Mr. Scott says, is New York City itself. The film takes in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks and it captures, better than any other movie, the mood of raw shock and grief that blanketed the city in those months. Have you seen 25th Hour? Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

title: Protesters Briefly Take Over a Gallery
description: The boundaries of Occupy Wall Street expanded beyond Zuccotti Park over the weekend, as a splinter group briefly took over an art gallery in SoHo.

title: Still No Relief in Sight for Long-Term Needs
description: WASHINGTON  The law that many Americans had hoped would transform the nations dysfunctional system of long-term care for the swelling ranks of people with disabilities and dementia quietly died this month, a victim of its own weaknesses, a toxic political environment and President Obamas re-election campaign focus on jobs.

title: Houdini Returns. (Of Course.)
description: Even in death, Harry Houdini has been hard to pin down.

title: Perry Adds Veteran Advisers to Campaign
description: Read the complete report on Mondays changes to Rick Perrys campaign strategy.

title: Tagliolini With Chicken Livers and Fennel
description: With Rosso di Montalcino wines, my appetite turns to chicken livers. Their edge of bitterness tamed by salt seems to be on the same wavelength as the wines. In Tuscany, chicken liver crostini, often seasoned with anchovies, are a typical palate awakener. I gave my chicken livers a bit more heft, with a flat noodle pasta, using black olive paste for salty bite. This dish can be a dinner party first course  the primi, as they say in Italy  to be followed by a more substantial main dish, perhaps served with a Brunello. Or the pasta and the Rosso can stand on their own for a simpler dinner in the American style.

title: Pure Montalcino, Minus the Wait
description: IN retrospect, what was all the fuss about? Here sat the wine panel, having tasted 20 bottles of Rosso di Montalcino, reveling in the unmistakable earthy, dusty flavors of pure sangiovese. With their winsomely bitter, citrus-tinged cherry flavors, these wines were soulful and elemental, like good trattoria food. They wanted less talking and more drinking.

title: Q&A: For Sisters, Hawaii May Beckon
description: Q.

title: Lens: Turning Point  John Minchillo
description: Lens: Turning Point  John Minchillo

title: Two-Sided Man Gets Two New Biographies
description: In a remarkable account of a meeting he had with Charles Dickens in 1862, Dostoyevsky recalled that the British novelist told him: All the good simple people in his novels, Little Nell, even the holy simpletons like Barnaby Rudge, are what he wanted to have been, and his villains were what he was (or rather, what he found in himself), his cruelty, his attacks of causeless enmity toward those who were helpless and looked to him for comfort, his shrinking from those whom he ought to love, being used up in what he wrote. There were two people in him, he told me: one who feels as he ought to feel and one who feels the opposite. From the one who feels the opposite I make my evil characters, from the one who feels as a man ought to feel I try to live my life. Only two people? I asked.

title: Korean Pop Machine, Running on Innocence and Hair Gel
description: Think of the work required to make just one Justin Bieber. The production, the management, the vocal training, the choreography, the swagger coaching  all that effort to create one teen-pop star in a country thats still starving for them. South Korea has no such drought, thanks to several companies that specialize in manufacturing a steady stream of teenage idols, in groups of various configurations. One of the longest-running of these companies is SM Entertainment, which on Sunday night hosted SM Town Live, a sold-out showcase at Madison Square Garden for several of its acts, any one of which any American reality-TV talent show or major-label A&R department worth its salt would be thrilled to have discovered.

title: Poverty in the Suburbs
description: Metro areas where the share of poor people living in the suburbs crossed the 50 percent mark between 2000 and 2010.

title: TV Struggles to Bring War Zones to Americans
description: Hollywood has brought the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq home for American filmgoers in sometimes stunning, painful detail in recent years. Lions for Lambs featured stars like Tom Cruise and Meryl Streep. The Hurt Locker won the Oscar for best picture. Restrepo and other documentaries wowed reviewers.

title: Netflix Loses Subscribers, Though Earnings Rise
description: Netflix said Monday that it ended the third quarter of the year with 23.8 million subscribers in the United States, a loss of 800,000 in three months, representing a notable decline after years of consistent growth.

title: A Camera Narcissus Could Love
description: Samsung is offering a new camera that Narcissus might love almost as much as he loved himself.

title: Obama Campaign Experiments With Tumblr for 12
description: Its no secret that President Obamas victory in 2008 was helped by his adoption of Twitter and other social media platforms. For 2012, Republicans and other politicians are flocking tothese services too, hoping to spread the party gospel 140 characters at a time.

title: Murdochs Sons Rebuked by News Corp. Shareholders
description: News Corporations independent shareholders voted largely against reinstating Rupert Murdochs sons James and Lachlan to the company board, according to a tally the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.Although the Murdoch familys control of a large percentage of voting shares all but guaranteed that all 15 board members would be re-elected after a contentious shareholder meeting on Friday, the detailed tally showed widespread opposition to the roles of James and Lachlan Murdoch.

title: When Video Killed Radio Stars
description: Like almost everyone who was a teenager in the early 1980s, when the Music Television network first went live on cable, I wanted my MTV. Id glue myself to the channel for hours, losing body mass, muscle control and self-esteem, the way my son gives himself over to video games today. MTV demanded that you linger in front of it for entire afternoons, because it tucked its few good videos amid so many horrible ones. You had to learn Zen couch potato patience.

title: China: Video of Monks Protest Released
description: A video of a Tibetan monks attempt to kill himself last month by self-immolation to protest Chinese policies has been released. The video was given anonymously to The Associated Press and released Sunday. It shows a monk, Lobsang Konchok, lying in a street in the town of Aba, in Sichuan Province, with his robes and shoes partly burned off. Security officers and a police car are visible in the background. The monk set himself on fire on Sept. 26 but lived. Nine Tibetans have set themselves on fire this year in Sichuan, and at least five have died.

title: Nurturing Start-Ups in Brazil, With a Nod to Silicon Valley
description: CAMPINAS, Brazil  When the investment firm Monashees Capital first called Juliano Ipolito, the co-founder of an online handicrafts marketplace, he assumed that he would have to visit the firm in So Paulo.

title: Florida: Judge Blocks Welfare Drug Tests
description: A federal judge on Monday temporarily blocked a far-reaching Florida law that requires public assistance applicants to take a drug test, saying the law probably violates a constitutional ban on unreasonable search and seizure. The law, which took effect in July, is the only one in the country that requires people receiving cash assistance through welfare to pass a drug test. The applicants must pay for the test themselves but are reimbursed if they test negative. A similar law in Michigan was struck down as unconstitutional a decade ago. In her ruling, Judge Mary S. Scriven of Federal District Court in Orlando said that there was no special need for the state to require drug tests and that it should stop, at least until the court made a final determination in the case. The court concludes that preliminarily enjoining what appears likely to be deemed an unconstitutional intrusion on the Fourth Amendment rights of applicants serves the public interest, Judge Scriven said. The ruling stems from a lawsuit filed by Luis Lebron, a Navy veteran, and the American Civil Liberties Union of Florida.

title: Ukraine: New Test for Ex-Premier
description: The general prosecutors office on Monday said that it had reopened another criminal case against Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the opposition leader and a former prime minister. Ms. Tymoshenko is already serving a seven-year sentence on charges that have been condemned in the West as politically motivated. The reopened case, which dates back 15 years to her tenure as head of United Energy Systems of Ukraine, alleges that she embezzled about $3 million from the federal budget and evaded paying about $2.5 million in taxes. The case was closed in 2005, after Ms. Tymoshenko became prime minister. The announcement further dims hopes that she will be released and allowed to take part in 2012 parliamentary elections, which European leaders have said is a precondition for completing free trade and association agreements between Ukraine and the European Union.

title: Trading Company Will Pay $1 Million to Settle S.E.C. Case
description: Pipeline Trading Systems, an alternative trading platform, will pay $1 million to resolve regulatory claims that it failed to provide the confidentiality and liquidity it advertised to customers.

title: Live Analysis of World Series Game 5: Rangers 4, Cardinals 2
description: Their swagger was undeniable, their energy inexhaustible. And how confident must the Texas Rangers feel after taking down the St. Louis Cardinals with a two-run eighth inning that gave them a 4-2 victory Monday night in Game 5 of the World Series.

title: Can Science and Faith Exist Together?
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia: Questions for Ex-Mayor
description: Yuri M. Luzhkov, Moscows former mayor, said Monday that he had been summoned for questioning in an embezzlement investigation of the Bank of Moscow, which is suspected of illegally funneling money into his wifes personal accounts. Mr. Luzhkov, who was fired last year after running afoul of the Kremlin, told the Interfax news agency that he was being singled out for criticizing the authorities in a recent radio interview. Investigators have accused the banks former chief executive of illegally issuing a loan of more than $400 million to a shell company linked to Mr. Luzhkovs wife. The couple, who are currently outside Russia, have denied any wrongdoing, and no charges have been filed against them.

title: Q&A: Darn You, Mac OS X AutoCorrect
description: Q.

title: The Entry Count and the Drawing
description: SPECIAL POST  Many readers have asked about the number of entries received in Patrick Berrys Crossing Words Contest and how the drawing was to be made. I dont know if this is some sort of record for a puzzle contest, but I was impressed not only by the sheer volume of entries but by how smart you all are. Approximately 96% percent of you submitted the correct answer, so pat yourselves on the back for outwitting Mr. Berry.

title: Declining to Criticize, IndyCar Drivers Discuss Safety With Top Racing Officials
description: As an IndyCar Series investigation continued into Dan Wheldons fatal accident Oct. 16 at Las Vegas, series officials met for three hours Monday with about two dozen drivers in Indianapolis to discuss ways to avoid catastrophic crashes.

title: Drilling in Fast-Growing Areas Ushers in New Era of Tension
description: DENVER  The pattern is clear in the oil and gas business: drilling fields are going into new places. North Dakota, better known for growing wheat, is now booming with rigs. Fort Worth has upward of 2,000 gas wells right in the city itself, with most of that growth within just the last five years. Pittsburgh, facing the prospect of urban drilling, forbade it last year by a vote of the City Council.

title: Herbert A. Hauptman, Nobel Laureate, Dies at 94
description: Herbert A. Hauptman, a mathematician who shared the 1985 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with the chemist Jerome Karle for their development of revolutionary methods for determining the structure of molecules vital to life, died on Sunday in Buffalo. He was 94.

title: Playing the New Bjork Album, and Playing Along, With Apps
description: Since Thomas Edison invented the phonograph, there has been only one way to listen to recorded music: Listen to it. That is, to consume passively a precise sequence of sounds exactly as they have been arranged. But what if, in addition to songs, a musician provided intuitive, creative tools that let you control the basic components of the music itself? What if the musician joined with programmers and visual artists to turn the songs into encompassing interactive experiences? What if listeners were to become participants?

title: Bigger Grants for Athletes Are Discussed
description: WASHINGTON  The N.C.A.A. president, Mark Emmert, said Monday that he supported a proposal that would let conferences increase grants to athletes by about $2,000, a move that critics say would escalate the financial disparity in college sports.

title: U.S. Pivots Eastward to Address Uneasy Allies
description: YOKOTA AIR BASE, Japan  China was never mentioned, but when a sailor in the Japanese Navy asked Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta here on Monday whether the United States planned to cut back its forces in Asia, Mr. Panetta knew exactly what he meant.

title: Pennsylvania: Governor Declares Emergency
description: Gov. Tom Corbett on Monday declared a fiscal emergency in Harrisburg, which allows him to assume financial control of the city and name the states first municipal receiver. Empowered by legislation he signed on Thursday, Mr. Corbett, left, said the capital citys fiscal distress warranted such action. The Harrisburg City Councils failure to enact a recovery plan in order to deal with the citys distressed finances has led me to declare a fiscal emergency, Mr. Corbett, a Republican, said in a news release. This action ensures that vital services will continue and public safety will be protected. Mr. Corbett can now direct city and state officials to comply with his plan to ensure that debt obligations and payroll expenses are met. A receiver can be named in 30 days if officials fail to devise a full recovery plan that is acceptable to the state. This month, Harrisburg became the first state capital in at least 40 years to file for bankruptcy protection.

title: Custody Deal for 2 Families After Killing
description: The two families fighting for custody of two young boys whose mother was killed in New Jersey this summer will share the children for now, according to a temporary agreement approved on Monday by a Family Court judge in Brooklyn.

title: How Netflix Lost 800,000 Members, and Good Will
description: Reed Hastings was soaking in a hot tub with a friend last month when he shared a secret: his company, Netflix, was about to announce a plan to divide its movie rental service into two  one offering streaming movies over the Internet, the other offering old-fashioned DVDs in the mail.

title: Lectern Gone, Romney Finds More Success

Giuliani. A room packed with highly paid media consultants and senior officials barked suggestions as they flipped through a white binder filled with policy positions. Over time, one aide said, the binder grew to resemble the Manhattan White Pages.

title: Turkeys Struggles to Avoid Recession
description: The human cost of this weeks earthquake comes as Turkey fights to keep its once-booming economy on track. Ankara is playing a high-risk game by intervening in markets to shore up its currency and lacks the reserves to do so. Turkey will struggle to avoid adopting higher interest rates to shore up its currency, the lira, even though that may push a previously overheating economy toward recession.

description: Texas Instruments, the maker of analog semiconductors, forecast lower fourth-quarter sales than some analysts had estimated, indicating that demand for electronic components remained sluggish.

title: A Good Approach on Wall Street
description: After more than a month of the Occupy Wall Street encampment at Zuccotti Park, the complaints are mounting. Mayor Michael Bloomberg, perhaps reflecting the irritation of his former colleagues on Wall Street, has said the Constitution doesnt protect tents. It protects speech and assembly. And he suggested last week that the city would start enforcing city rules on marches by the protesters unless they have the required permits.

title: One Win for the Forests
description: The environment and its allies have not had many victories recently, but there was a big one on Friday when the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit upheld the roadless rule  a Clinton administration regulation barring new road-building on 50 million acres of the national forests. The timber industry, off-road vehicle users and other commercial and political interests have long battled the rule, which will establish essential protections for the forests and the clean water, wildlife habitat and recreational opportunities they provide.

title: The Purchase by Blood
description: Two cousins, on the field at battles start, catch each others eye, salute, and then  when next I looked, Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. writes of his cousin, James Jackson Lowell, he was gone. At Cedar Mountain, Capt. Henry Sturgis Russell is captured because he has stayed to tend the wounds of his friend, Maj. James Savage. But once in Confederate hands the two are parted: Russell is exchanged while Savage begins the slow decline that will end in his lonely death at the hands of incompetent surgeons in a Confederate hospital.

title: U.S. Agencies Infiltrating Drug Cartels Across Mexico
description: WASHINGTON  American law enforcement agencies have significantly built up networks of Mexican informants that have allowed them to secretly infiltrate some of that countrys most powerful and dangerous criminal organizations, according to security officials on both sides of the border.

title: Perry Readies Flat-Tax Plan and Expands His Staff
description: SIMPSONVILLE, S.C.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is taking significant steps to redefine his candidacy as his battle for the Republican nomination intensifies, including unveiling a tax overhaul plan that would give people the option of paying a 20 percent flat tax on income.

title: Revisiting Night of Taunts, Punches and Injuries

title: Before Qaddafis Death, U.S. Debated His Future
description: WASHINGTON  Last Wednesday evening, the White House convened a 90-minute meeting to tackle a looming, delicate question: What should be done with the Libyan dictator, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, if he were captured alive, either in Libya or in a neighboring country?

title: The Biographers Dilemma
description: I was halfway through Walter Isaacsons new biography of Steve Jobs when I suddenly went searching through my bookshelf for the book he wrote about Benjamin Franklin. I had read the latter biography when it came out in 2003, and I remembered it fondly. I was trying to figure out why Steve Jobs, despite being full of new information about the most compelling businessman of the modern era, was leaving me cold.

title: Tuesday: Bad Childs Stocking Filler
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Its nice to welcome back C. W. Stewart, not just because shes the second female constructor in a row this week, but because we havent had a puzzle from her since June (Across Lite, Solution, blog).

title: On the Road to Relief
description: At long last, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-run mortgage companies, have issued new rules to allow millions of underwater borrowers, who are current on their payments, to refinance their high-rate mortgages into lower-rate loans. President Obama, who pushed for the changes, rightly emphasized the benefits in a speech on Monday in Las Vegas, a city ravaged by foreclosures. Refinancings will lower monthly payments, reduce the likelihood of default and boost consumer spending.

title: From Brooklyn Office, Mixing Clout and Charity
description: When one of the biggest real estate developments in Brooklyn was stalled two years ago, its owner turned to the city government for help, seeking $20 million in financing. Nearly 50 projects were applying for a small number of aid packages at the time, but this one, City Point, had a prominent supporter.

title: Woman Sentenced in Effort to Smuggle Scopes to Russia
description: She would always be the other Anna, her alleged criminal misdeeds and her personal life not quite the measure of the Anna who came before her.

title: Numberplay: From Sledgehammer to Scalpel
description: A few weeks ago, we celebrated the Rubiks Cube. One of the things that I find fascinating about the Rubiks Cube is that, even though a single move changes the position of 8 cubies, you can string together a series of moves such that you can change the orientations of exactly 2 cubies (the quarks and anti-quarks we mentioned), leaving the rest of the cube completely unchanged. Even though we move an ensemble of eight different cubies at a time, we are able to precisely cancel the motion of all of the other cubies we moved, and hone in with surgical precision on the two we are interested in. Using sledgehammer moves, we are able to create a scalpel!

title: While Veterans Wait
description: The Veterans Affairs Department has devoted much effort and money to improve and expand its mental health care, especially for those coming home from Iraq and Afghanistan with post-traumatic stress disorder and brain injuries. But continuing reports of drug dependency, suicides and suicide attempts among veterans and active-duty soldiers suggest that urgent needs remain vast and unmet. So do persistent accounts from veterans who say they spend months waiting for mental health care.

title: 15-Year-Old Held in Rape Attempts in Queens
description: A 15-year-old Queens youth has been arrested on charges that he tried to rape two women this month, part of what the authorities say is a pattern of five attacks in the boroughs southeastern section that began in late September.

title: Outside Cleveland, Snapshots of Povertys Surge in the Suburbs
description: PARMA HEIGHTS, Ohio  The poor population in Americas suburbs  long a symbol of a stable and prosperous American middle class  rose by more than half after 2000, forcing suburban communities across the country to re-evaluate their identities and how they serve their populations.

title: Revisiting the Daisy Ad Revolution
description: It was the most negative political ad in American history. The adorable petal-picking, tow-headed tot who now approaches middle age has few regrets about her role in a commercial that revolutionized campaign politics. Its only been in the last few years, says Monique Luiz, that she has realized the importance of this iconic ad.

He likes crushing the ants in Ant Smasher, and improving his swing in the golf app. But he is no app addict: when the one featuring Grover from Sesame Street does not work right, Jaden says, Come on, iPad!  then wanders happily off to play with his train set.

title: From a Farm Stand, New and Old Insights
description: Living in a cabin in the woods with three boys, two cats and a flexible schedule means every day is different. But theres one constant to my weeks. On Thursday afternoons, I know Ill be in a town 30 minutes away standing under a white awning and waiting in line.

title: In Week 7, Passing Defenses Continue to Show Pop
description: Last week, I wrote that the monster passing numbers from the first five weeks took a serious body blow in Week 6, evidenced by a huge decline in passing touchdowns. The knockout punch was delivered in Week 7. After teams averaged over 240 passing yards per game through the first six weeks of the season, the 26 teams playing in Week 7 combined for only 4,997 passing yards this past weekend, a paltry 191 yards per game. Nowhere was this more evident  on Sunday  than in Cleveland, as the Seahawks and Browns put on a pitiful display. The Browns and Seahawks combined for 435 yards and 9 points. It was the worst display of offense in a game not affected by severe weather in over a decade. The Colt McCoy pass attempt watch marches on: he threw 35 passes in a game in which the Browns allowed only 137 yards and 3 points.

title: Tuesday Reading: Reassessing the Role of Mammograms
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Flood Defenses Are Overrun in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK  Bangkoks flood defenses continued to fall on Wednesday as floodwaters pressed farther into the city after forcing the closing of the domestic airport. Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra warned that there could be as much as five feet of flooding in some areas.

title: NATO to Lead on Libya Ties, Panetta Says
description: TOKYO  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta declined on Tuesday to say whether the United States would have a future military relationship with Libya and instead said he would take cues from allies in Europe.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Groupons Latest Valuation Raises Doubt | Back in 1999, Barrons ran an article that was a virtual indictment of Amazon. It questioned the companys ability ever to turn a profit, argued that Amazon was spending far too much money on marketing and suggested that the company was using misleading accounting metrics.

title: Amazon, Hot and Cold
description: After the close of the stock market Tuesday, Amazon.com will announce its third-quarter results. Analysts are predicting yet another revenue blowout, up 44 percent compared with last year. Amazons torrid growth more than 15 years after its founding makes it an object of envy and fear across the retail world. It is now a $100 billion company, about 12 times the value of Sears.

title: Now Viewing | Cecil Beatons New York
description: What was Manhattan for the wildly ambitious, talented and tirelessly self-promoting 24-year-old Cecil Beaton, but a candy box of opportunities, just waiting to be picked? And pick them he did, over the course of some five decades, in a peripatetic career that saw him cross-pollinating the social and cultural elites of the Old and New Worlds, and applying his protean gifts to everything from fashion photography and portraiture to illustration to stage and costume design. Cecil Beaton: The New York Years, curated by Donald Albrecht and opening today at the Museum of the City of New York, includes vintage fashion prints and a wide range of portraits, from Marilyn Monroe (cajoled into relaxation in Beatons Ambassador Hotel suite) to the very young Mick Jagger to Wallis Simpson and the aging Greta Garbo (one of the photographers rare heterosexual liaisons). Together with drawings, theatrical designs and other ephemera, they illuminate this English dandys astonishingly productive and long-lasting engagement with the booming cultural metropolis that was Manhattan at midcentury.

title: ArcelorMittal Backs Out of Bid for Macarthur Coal
description: ArcelorMittal, the worlds largest steel manufacturer, announced on Tuesday that it was pulling out of a $4.9 billion joint bid with Peabody Energy to acquire Macarthur Coal of Australia.

title: As Newark High-Rise Loses Aid, Fear Sweeps Through Its Tenants
description: When it opened in 1971, Carmel Towers in Newark was a model of the sort of high-rise urban development that the federal government was encouraging through generous subsidies. Now, federal officials are cutting off financial aid to the buildings landlord, leaving hundreds of residents fearing that they could soon be evicted.

title: 10 Questions for Rick Perry
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is seeking to jump-start his Republican presidential campaign by proposing a new tax system: a 20 percent flat rate on individual and corporate income, down from the current 35 percent top rate, and elimination of existing taxes on estates, capital gains and dividends. He sat down with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC to discuss the plan, his challenge to a Republican rival, Mitt Romney, and other issues. What follows is a condensed, edited transcript of their conversation.

title: Irish Reality Check
description: There have been a number of articles and blog posts lately claiming that Ireland is over the hump, that its all coming right; see for example this recent piece by Henry Kaspar. But I was checking to see if it was still true that Icelandic CDS prices  the cost of insuring against default  were much lower than Irelands. And given what weve been hearing, the Irish CDS story comes as something of a shock:

description: The Guardian: Jamie Oliver, a.k.a. Sisyphus, is growing concerned that the British government is backsliding on its commitment to better school lunches. Jeff Gordinier

title: Online Account Opening Isnt as Easy as It Looks
description: If youve ever tried  and failed  to open and fund an online checking account, youre not alone. A new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds that only a little more than half of consumers who try to do so are successful.

title: Shakespeare Trust Hides Playwrights Name to Protest Anonymous
description: The Shakespeare Birthplace Trust had no apparent problems with Roland Emmerichs previous movies about genocidal space aliens, apocalyptic solar flares and life in prehistoric times. But when Mr. Emmerich messed with Shakespeare, thats where the trust drew the line  right through the name of the playwright it is set up to protect.

title: Playtime With Cats, at Any Distance
