title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
description: The head of the agency that manages travel for Kiran Bedi severed ties with her nongovernmental organization, India Vision Foundation, on Tuesday. Anil Bal, proprietor of Flywell Travel, claimed that the controversy over the inflated travel invoices furnished by Ms. Bedi had unnecessarily tarnished his reputation. Mr. Bal, a founding member of the foundation, also resigned as trustee of the organization (The Indian Express).Prime Minister Manmohan Singh was skeptical of the July 2005 nuclear agreement with the United States in the run-up to the joint statement declaring the pact, a new book by former U.S. Secretary of State Condelezzaa Rice claims. Mr. Singh was wary about the impact of the deal on domestic politics, Ms. Rice writes in her upcoming memoir In No Higher Honor. The then-foreign minister, Natwar Singh, was far more adamant about the deal  called the U.S.-India Civil Nuclear Cooperation  and worked with U.S. officials to persuade the prime minister it was a good idea (Hindustan Times).

title: X Factor Watch: Squabbling and Dancing (and Some Singing), All of It Live
description: Some welcome testiness finally worked its way into The X Factor on Tuesday night, but so did lots of unwelcome choreography, headache-inducing lighting and overorchestration. Some of the singers in this live show were more or less swallowed up by their absurdly excessive production numbers as The X Factor abandoned its roots as a singing competition and turned into something resembling a bad Broadway musical.

title: Corrections: October 26
description: NATIONAL

title: Panetta Says North Korea Remains a Serious Threat
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta on Wednesday called North Korea a serious threat and told American and South Korean troops here that they were on the front line of defense.

title: Criminal Charges for Gupta, Ex McKinsey Head
description: United States prosecutors are expected to file criminal charges Wednesday against former McKinsey head Rajat K. Gupta, in connection with the Galleon Group insider trading case, The New York Times DealBook reports.

title: Oct. 26, 1994 | Peace Between Israel and Jordan
description: On Oct. 26, 1994, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and Prime Minister Abdel Salam Majali of Jordan signed a peace treaty in a ceremony attended by President Bill Clinton.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 26, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article, Incentives for Advanced Work Let Pupils and Teachers Cash In.

title: News Quiz | Oct. 26, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: A Firecracker-Free Diwali?
description: For most people, Diwali festivities are incomplete without the crackling of firecrackers. And almost everyone has a favorite, ranging from the innocuous phooljhadi, or sparkler, to the rocket, which usually fails to live up to its name, hissing into the sky with fierce intensity only to fall flat on the ground within minutes. And then there is the pernicious-sounding bomb, whose name says it all. They come in different shapes and sizes but the firecrackers have one thing in common: they unleash an ear-splitting bang when they are set ablaze.

title: Casing Swiss Banking Secrets
description: With billions of dollars shrouded in secrecy  and protected by armed guards and vaults  the best Mark Henley could hope for in Switzerland was to subtly stake out his targets.

title: How Ready Are We for Bioterrorism?
description: A few days after 9/11, a retired Air Force colonel named Randall Larsen entered the northwest gate of the White House, crossed a courtyard to the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, stepped through the front door and stopped dead in his tracks.

title: Disposables and Deforestation
description: WHAT is the the quintessential cutlery choice throughout most of Asia?WHAT, according to this article, are some of the things Asian countries have done or encouraged to cut down on the use of disposable versions of these utensils?

title: At Olympus, Western Questions for Old-School Ways
description: TOKYO  One was a rising star at Olympus, a Briton who shocked his colleagues by leapfrogging scores of executives to become the companys first non-Japanese president.

title: What Have You Made Yourself?
description: We borrow this question from a teacher at the Bertie Early College High School in Windsor, N.C., who asks her students to name the last thing they have made themselves, even if it is as simple as cookies, to get them thinking about design. What have you made yourself, recently or at any time in your life? Do you like making things by hand? Do you wish your school had a design or building course?

title: Was Qaddafi Overpaid?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Bucking Trends, Tesla Goes It Alone on Plug Design
description: LOS ANGELES, Calif.  Nobody would accuse Tesla Motors, the electric-vehicle manufacturer, of being a conventional company. Its nonconformist tendencies are showing again as it builds charging solutions for the Model S, the sedan expected to go on sale in mid-2012.

title: Mophies Recharger Does More With Less
description: See, this is nice.

title: Sating an American Sweet Tooth in Prague
description: Cool Ranch Doritos, Mountain Dew, Milk Duds, chocolate cupcakes with sprinkles. None of these are easy finds in Prague. Over the past decade, however, a handful of specialty shops have popped up to help satisfy the citys voracious sweet tooth, with a focus on American-made goodies.

title: The Early Word: Anxiety
description: Todays Times

title: Day of IMFamy
description: Im in Iceland for this IMF-sponsored conference; they say it will be webcast live, but no link yet  probably it will be on the conference page, as linked above.

title: 3 More Quake Survivors Pulled From Rubble in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Rescue teams extracted three more survivors from the rubble of Sundays earthquake in eastern Turkey, news agencies reported, as the death toll hit 481 and as snow began to fall, probably complicating any further rescue attempts and adding to the misery of homeless survivors.

title: The Amnesiac Economy
description: Mark Thoma sends us to John Cassidy on the absence of really new ideas in this crisis  largely because we didnt need new ideas, all we needed for the most part was to remember things that we somehow forgot.

title: Onion
description: OK, for those wondering:

title: The Next Death-With-Dignity Battleground
description: Most fall weekends, you can find Randee Laikind buttonholing people at the Shelburne Falls Market in western Massachusetts, or wielding her clipboard on the town common in nearby Greenfield or Amherst.

title: Arctic Predators, Caught in the Act
description: Arctic Alaska is often described as our countys last great frontier, with its bitterly cold winters, Inupiat Eskimos on the hunt and caribou roaming the open tundra. At the same time, there is the reality of change, with oil drilling advancing, polar bears imperiled and the regions snow pack threatened by global warming.

title: Week 7 Film Review: Roethlisberger Buys Time
description: A closer look at some of the matchups in Week 7, with the benefit of film review:

title: Occupy Wall Street? Who Will Occupy Main Street?
description: Lots of people enjoy saving money by shopping online. The prices are often lower, and in many cases there is no sales tax and little or no shipping charge. But while free market forces prevail, there are growing problems with the after-effects of this market shift to Internet sales.

title: How a Sonnet Made a Statue the Mother of Exiles
description: When the Goddess of Liberty was given to the United States, its donors agenda was to burnish Frances republican roots after the oppressive reign of Napoleon III and to celebrate the two nations commitment to the principles of liberty.

title: Floods Force Thailand to Move Prison Inmates
description: BANGKOK  Hundreds of inmates were evacuated from prisons around Bangkok on Wednesday, and residents stocked up on food or made plans to leave the city as officials warned of severe flooding throughout much of the capital in the coming days.

title: There Posts the Neighborhood
description: Facebook has reconnected far-flung friends and family, and LinkedIn gives people a way to stay in touch with professional contacts. Nextdoor is the social network for people near enough to each other to borrow a cup of sugar.

title: Ford Motor Reports 10th Profitable Quarter, and May Restart Dividend
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company on Wednesday said profit fell 2 percent in the third quarter, to $1.65 billion.

title: A Fierce Battle Ahead for the House
description: Could control of the House of Representatives really flip back to the Democrats next year?

title: With New Smartphones, High Hopes for Nokia and Microsoft Union
description: LONDON  Nokia, the Finnish cellphone maker, introduced two smartphones on Wednesday, the first fruits of its alliance with Microsoft, in a bid to curb its declining market share.

title: Rate Decision: An End to Lazy Banking?
description: By tradition many Indians consider it auspicious to spend money during Diwali on things like clothes, jewelry and homes. This year, however, some Indians may be thinking about saving, instead.

title: Wednesday Reading: HPV Vaccine Endorsed for Boys
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

description: Updated at 3:02 p.m., to add a link to more student loan information on The Choice blog.

description: Prism Skylabs, a San Francisco-based start-up, is in the recycling business.

description: In the first television ad of his campaign, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas promises to create at least 2.5 million jobs as president, in part by loosening regulations on oil drilling and other energy exploration.

title: Giving Subway Riders the No-Bin Treatment
description: An old friend named Bob was a serious Roman Catholic, and though he harbored no bias against other religious denominations, he could not contain himself when presented one day with a suggestion that he found singularly awful. Thats the worst idea since the Reformation, he blurted out.

title: A One-Page Form to Compare College Aid Offers
description: In its latest effort to simplify consumer finance, the new federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has teamed up with the Department of Education to create a one-page financial aid shopping sheet.

title: Euro Zone | Film and Fitness in Rome
description: The International Rome Film Festival, which starts Thursday and runs until Nov. 4, may not have the panache of Cannes or Venice. But what it lacks in star power, it usually makes up for with content and, of course, location. This year, Charlotte Rampling will attend for The Eye of the Storm, a film also starring Geoffrey Rush about a fading beauty planning her own death. Maggie Gyllenhall and Rupert Everett are in town to promote Hysteria, a film about the history of the vibrator; and Richard Gere will collect an honorary acting award.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: U.S. Is Set to Charge Major Executive in Trading Case | Federal prosecutors are expected to file criminal charges on Wednesday against Rajat K. Gupta, the most prominent business executive ensnared in an aggressive insider trading investigation, according to people briefed on the case.

title: What Were Reading
description: Grist: To protest chocolate companies continued use of cacao from countries that use forced child labor, Reverse Trick or Treaters will hand Fair Trade chocolates back to adults.  Nick Fox

title: Amy Winehouse Died After Drinking Too Much Alcohol, Coroner Says
description: 10:52 a.m. | Updated

title: With Bloomberg Leading the Band, City Center Reopens
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is the best conducting mayor I have seen. Though technically, that should be better, since Ive seen only two.

title: Shares Rise as Europe Meets on Debt Crisis
description: Stocks rose on Wednesday as companies reported solid earnings and investors cautiously watched the results from a summit meeting in Europe to address the sovereign debt crisis.

title: A Reconfigured Energy Sector
description: In todays special Energy section, Clifford Krauss examines the potential for exploiting a new generation of unconventional fossil fuels with the aid of new technologies.

title: The Choice at the College Board Conference
description: The annual conference of the College Board, the organization that oversees the SAT and the Advanced Placement program, among other critical components of the college admissions process, kicks off Wednesday in New York City.

title: Europe Agrees to Basics of Plan to Resolve Euro Crisis
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders, in a significant step toward resolving the euro zone financial crisis, early Thursday morning obtained an agreement from banks to take a 50 percent loss on the face value of their Greek debt.

title: A Carbon Culprit: Rivers and Streams
description: The amount of carbon dioxide being released from streams, rivers and lakes is probably being undercounted by scientists modeling the earths carbon budget, a new study suggests.

title: Transmission Woes Addressed by Ford, but Too Late for Consumer Reports
description: 11:29 a.m. | Updated

title: Petula Clark Heading to Midtown
description: Petula Clark, the British singer and actress best known for her hit Downtown, will make her first appearance at a New York City nightclub since the 1970s early next year, her publicist said. Ms. Clark, who is 78, lives in Switzerland and has not played New York for decades. She will appear at Feinsteins at Loews Regency on Park Avenue at 61st Street from Jan. 24 to Feb. 4, performing her hits, including I Know a Place and My Love, as well as songs from musicals she appeared in, both onstage and screen.

title: For Climate Scientists, a Dive Into Alphabet Soup
description: For journalists, climate science can be a challenge in and of itself. The uncertainties, the dueling algorithms, the long horizons involved in predicting how climate change could unfold  all of this conspires against a reporter trying to report the relevant news in a clear and accessible way.

title: A One-Page Form to Compare Student Aid Offers
description: Our colleagues at The Timess Bucks blog write this morning about the efforts by the new federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Department of Education to create a one-page financial aid shopping sheet. As Ann Carrns writes on Bucks: The idea here is that a single sheet of basic information would help students and their families better understand the amount of financial aid they qualify for, and compare aid packages offered by different colleges and universities before deciding which school to attend. Be sure to take a look at a draft of the sheet.

title: Squirrel Mascot Flying In for Game 6
description: Mike Tanier will provide Bats with updates on less than important developments from the World Series.

title: Poes Cottage, Weak and Weary No More
description: It was a poor mans house, with tiny rooms and low ceilings when Edgar Allan Poe lived there more than 160 years ago, when residing in what later became the Bronx meant breathing fresh country air.

title: The Student Loan Proposal: What It Might Mean for You
description: Bloggers Note: Tamar Lewin writes on The Timess Web site on Wednesday that President Obama will announce new programs to lower monthly loan payments for some students graduating next year and thereafter and to let borrowers who have a mix of direct federal loans and loans under the old Federal Family Education Loan Program consolidate them at a slightly lower interest rate. Mark Kantrowitz, the publisher of the financial aid Web sites finaid.org and fastweb, was asked by The Choice to write a quick essay explaining what the proposal might mean for applicants this year, and in the future, for current students and recent graduates.  Jacques Steinberg

title: Pujols Wont Find Unconditional Love Anywhere Else
description: St. Louis

title: Airlines Holiday Tidings
description: AS the holidays approach, many people are finalizing their travel plans and bracing themselves for the usual crowds, long security lines and inevitable delays.

title: Search for Lost Girl Puts Spotlight on Mothers Past
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Fliers have been posted on storefronts. Detectives have gone door to door. An Amber alert has been issued to sound the alarm that a girl is missing.

title: City and Landscape
description: Jean Nouvel, the French architect, received architectures top honor, the Pritzker Prize.

title: Protest Songs for Young Dissenters
description: No time to take your grade schooler down to the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations (or their local incarnation) but on board with the general vibe? Two new picture books speak to our current hard times, each with a protest song at its heart.

title: The Naughty Necklace
description: RISING hemlines get all the attention, but what about necklines? Theyre one of the few things on the rise lately, reaching a recent high  on shirts buttoned all the way to the chin  on spring 2012 runways at Jason Wu, Cline and Dior. It makes a kind of sense, then, as the eye moves north of the collarbone, that chokers, those much maligned neckpieces synonymous with the 1990s, would stage a comeback.

title: Liviu Ciulei, a Daring Theater Director, Dies at 88
description: Liviu Ciulei, who was voted best director at the Cannes Film Festival in 1965 and who led the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis in the 1980s, when it won a Tony Award, died on Tuesday in Munich. He was 88.

title: Channel Surfing: Fires of Faith on BYUtv
description: You may never have heard of BYUtv, but its in the midst of broadcasting a smart three-part series on the creation of the most influential book the Western world has ever seen, the King James Bible.

title: Updates on Occupy Protests Nationwide
description: After a night of violence in Oakland, Calif., where police officers fired tear gas at protesters affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street movement, The Lede is following the response of demonstrators in cities across the country on Wednesday.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

title: Daniel B. Burke, Leading Media Executive, Dies at 82
description: Daniel B. Burke, who helped engineer the acquisition of the American Broadcasting Company by Capital Cities, one of the boldest corporate takeovers of the 1980s, and went on to become chief executive of the merged company, died on Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 82.

title: Big 12 Might Admit Louisville, Not West Virginia
description: West Virginia University athletic officials spent most of Tuesday preparing to leave the Big East Conference for the Big 12. The Mountaineers athletic director, Oliver Luck, was so sure of the move that he tipped off Big East colleagues Monday night and told staff members Tuesday.

title: Maos Rockets and the Eastern Afghan Border War, Part I
description: Cold War Weapons and Afghanistans Unending Fight

title: I.V.F. Without the Risk of Multiple Births?
description: A few years ago, a friend, who, like many of our peers, got started late in the baby game and ended up going the in vitro fertilization route, told me she was pregnant with twins. Theyd used two embryos to maximize the chance of getting pregnant, and both had taken. But they didnt want twins. The next time I saw her, she had one baby.

title: State Officials Have Frequently Overruled Local Boards Rejection of Liquor Licenses
description: Community Board 3 is often seen as the party pooper of the downtown dining and drinking scene, regularly voting to oppose new liquor licenses for restaurants and bars in the East Village and Lower East Side.

title: Millepied Retires From City Ballet
description: Benjamin Millepied, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, has retired and plans to focus on his choreography, the company announced on Wednesday. Mr. Millepied, 34, originally from Bordeaux, France, and known to many non-balletomanes as the choreographer for the Oscar-nominated movie Black Swan, joined the company in 1995 after training at City Ballets affiliated School of American Ballet. He was promoted to principal in 2002 and originated roles in ballets by Jerome Robbins, Peter Martins, Christopher Wheeldon, Alexei Ratmansky and others.

title: Spooky Sketches | Mandy Coon
description: T challenges 10 designers to turn everyday objects into killer Halloween costumes.

title: When Should a Small Business Hire a Finance Chief?
description: At Quickoffice, which sells software that allows users to create and edit documents on mobile devices, Alan Masarek always enjoyed getting deep into the numbers of his business  almost as if he were chief financial officer instead of chief executive.

title: Like the Best Zombies, VHS Just Wont Die
description: FOR horror fans like Evan Husney, a movie that looks like its been art-directed to death is a real killer.

title: Rule Allows U.S. a Close Look at Big Hedge Funds
description: WASHINGTON  Large hedge funds, the very private investment outfits that borrow money to magnify their big financial bets, will be required for the first time to report detailed information on their investments and borrowings under a rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday.

title: Yes, Mitt Romney Backs Efforts to Limit Unions in Ohio
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  Mitt Romney on Wednesday reaffirmed his support for efforts to crack down on unions in Ohio, apologizing for causing confusion by appearing to waffle on the issue in that state a day earlier.

title: In Fight Against Securities Fraud, S.E.C. Sends Wrong Signal
description: Back when the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission was doing its work, I would check in periodically with someone who worked there to find out how it was going.

title: Have You Tried to Hire a C.F.O.?
description: In a small-business guide weve just published, Alan Masarek talks about how he decided it was time for his business to hire a chief financial officer.

title: Libyas Interim Leader Asks NATO to Stay Through the End of 2011
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Libyas interim leader said Wednesday that he had asked NATO to prolong its air patrols through December and add military advisers on the ground, despite his official declaration on Sunday of the countrys liberation after the killing of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Study: Yaz Has Higher Risks of Blood Clots
description: A new study of 1.3 million Danish women over nine years adds to the evidence that some newer birth-control pills, including the best-seller Yaz, have a higher risk of causing potentially dangerous blood clots.

title: Chelsea Market Halloween Display Raises Hackles as Well as the Dead
description: A gray zombie baby chews on a severed human hand. A demonic toddler stares out with bright red eyes that in a horrifying twist, perfectly match the bows in her pigtails. A grandfatherly man with blood pouring from his mouth relaxes on a wooden chair, a pink teddy bear and a white-eyed, fang-baring baby resting in his lap.

title: Yale Press to Publish Forgotten Eugene ONeill One-Act in Book Form
description: In 1912, the 24-year-old Eugene ONeill tried to kill himself with an overdose of Veronal, but botched the job and was found unconscious by friends. He later wrote about the experience in an autobiographical one-act play, Exorcism, which ends with the ONeill character, Ned Malloy, experiencing a kind of resurrection. The Past is finally cremated, he says. I feel reborn, I tell you.

title: Big Hair and Bad Blood: VHS-Era Horror Obscurities From A to Z
description: For a certain subset of horror fan, the high quality of Blu-ray is unwatchable compared with the painfully grainy-hazy look of VHS (especially do-it-yourself titles that look like they were made over a weekend in some guys backyard). In recent years, small distributors and a few majors have released 1980s horror movies, mostly of the schlock variety, on special-edition VHS tapes as well as on DVD.

title: Early Snow Turns Colorados Fall Foliage to Winter White
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  A heavy, out-of-season winter storm slammed into Colorado and southeast Wyoming on Tuesday night, delivering in one roundhouse punch more snow than the Denver area typically gets in all of October. The piling on then continued through Wednesday, with a total of 12 to 14 inches falling in some places in foothill communities like this one, west of Denver, and even more in the higher peaks and passes of the Rockies.

title: Will You Give Your Son the HPV Vaccine?
description: A federal panel has recommended that boys be given the vaccine for human papillomavirus, or HPV. But will parents agree to it?

title: For This Menace, Only One Thing to Do: Ready, Aim, Fireworks!
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind.

title: The Truth Has A Well-Known, Well, You Know
description: Greg Sargent takes us to Paul Ryans latest speech, in which Ryan expresses outrage over what President Obama is saying:

title: Ladies Day: FIFAs List of 10 for Womens Player of the Year
description: Will this be the year that Marta will be dethroned as the winner of FIFAs womens world player of the year? Marta, a skillful Brazilian, has won the award for the past five years and was among the 10 players nominated Wednesday for this years award.

title: Vain Glorious | Prieto Select
description: An unlikely beauty director at best, Im the girl who  horrors  doesnt take off her mascara at night (if Im even wearing any) and never mastered the fine art of foundation. I do have a couple of guilty pleasures, like an occasional cat eye or a sweep of blue eye shadow, but my application skills are next to nil. Whats more, I barely know how to wield a hair dryer or flat iron. If I dont have time to run to Orlo or Garren, Im sunk.

title: Wild-Eyed Theorists In Pinstripes
description: In what amounts to a perfect followup to my post on the amnesiac economy, Paul De Grauwe takes the ECB to task for refusing to do what is necessary to save the euro, and taking refuge in a very narrow definition of its role.

title: Bus Operator Denies Discriminating Against Women
description: A bus company that transports primarily Orthodox and Hasidic Jewish passengers between Williamsburg and Borough Park in Brooklyn has denied that it discriminates against female passengers by compelling them to sit at the rear of the bus.

title: Irish Election Shows Signs of Erasing Boundaries
description: GALWAY, Ireland  On an autumn evening beside the storied beauty of Galway Bay, with a chilly gust blowing off the Atlantic, Martin McGuinness breezed into a popular tourist hotel that looks out across the bay with the air of a man who has found a measure of peace after a lifetime gripped by Irelands troubled past.

title: Critic of South Korean Leader Elected as Seoul Mayor
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A civic activist and vocal critic of President Lee Myung-bak rode a growing call for political change to become mayor of the South Korean capital, Seoul, winning a poll widely seen as a bellwether for the presidential election in December next year.

title: Showtime Thriller Homeland Secures a Second Season
description: Orange alert! The Department of Homeland Security may have retired its color-coded terrorism alert system, but the pervading sense of paranoia that it represented isnt going away, and neither is Showtimes hit series, Homeland. On Wednesday that cable channel said it had ordered a second season of Homeland, its serialized thriller about a dogged if possibly paranoid C.I.A. officer (played by Claire Danes), a recently released American prisoner of war (Damian Lewis) who may be a sleeper agent for Al Qaeda, and Mandy Patinkins epic beard. (O.K., the beard is not as crucial to the story, but some of us still find it fascinating.)

title: The Caucus | A Tough Number for Obama
description: Oct. 26, 2011  A look at one especially challenging result for President Obama in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: The Crow Patrol
description: Terre Haute, Ind., shares a problem with Auburn, N.Y., and Lancaster, Pa.: Crows. Lots and lots of crows.

title: Caucus Video: A Tough Number for Obama
description: A look at one especially challenging number for President Obama in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Also, Mitt Romney is the endorsement frontrunner, but how much will it help him?

title: Cuomo Warns of Chaos if Redistricting Fight Goes to a Judge
description: As the process of redrawing legislative boundaries heads to the courts in many other states, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday said that he hoped to avoid that outcome in New York, warning that chaos would ensue if a judge was forced to sort out the states redistricting procedures.

title: Boeing Posts Strong Profit but Cuts Delivery Forecast
description: Boeing said Wednesday that its third-quarter earnings topped estimates and projected that its new 787 Dreamliner would earn at least a low, single-digit profit from sales of the first 1,100 planes.

title: Returning for a Breeders Cup Overflowing With Story Lines

Judy Battista, The Timess N.F.L. reporter, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. title: F.T.C. Claims Abusive Tactics by Two Debt Collection Firms

But recently, the Federal Trade Commission moved to shut down two California-based operators that handled collections nationally, including one that is accused of using tactics so egregious that they resemble scenes from a film noir script.

title: My Three Favorite Tumblrs

In this lesson, students use statistical analyses and quantitative evaluations to get the edge in fantasy football. By looking at data, measuring matchups and making projections, students put their analytic skills to the test in fantasy sports competitions.

title: Defectors Claim Attack That Killed Syria Soldiers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A force of Syrian Army defectors claimed responsibility for a Wednesday attack that killed a military officer and eight soldiers in central Syria, another signal that disaffected troops are taking a larger role in the antigovernment uprising and pushing it into more violence after months of a brutal government crackdown.

description: ACTORS often make cameo appearances in novels, and the theater frequently serves as a bloodstained backdrop for murder mysteries. Yet excellent novels about the art of acting will scarcely fill a shelf. In addition to Lucky Break, here are five of the best in English.

title: The Controversial Cartoons of Pi San
description: Controversial animations from the Chinese blogger Pi San.

title: Where an Internet Joke Is Not Just a Joke
description: The cellphone vibrated softly, insistently, echoing off the whitewashed walls of the artists studio. It was a Sunday morning in early April, and Wang Bo  an Internet animator better known to his legions of online fans by his nickname, Pi San  ignored the call at first. He wanted no intrusions. A compact 40-year-old with short-cropped hair and arched eyebrows that give him a look of permanent bemusement, Pi San is most famous for creating a mischievous cartoon character named Kuang Kuang, but he earns money by making animations for corporations, and he was on a deadline. Pi San had bicycled to his studio in a defunct factory building on the outskirts of Beijing that morning, hoping to finish up some work in peace. But the buzzing of the phone didnt stop.

title: Afghan Leaders Invitation Could Reopen Doors for Former U.S. Commander
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai has invited retired Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, who led NATO troops here in 2009 and 2010, to Afghanistan, and General McChrystal plans to make the visit in the next few weeks, Afghan and American officials said.

title: Sister Slips Away, Under Her Cameras Gaze, in Update of Bergman
description: The blood has been drained from Ingmar Bergmans Cries and Whispers in Ivo van Hoves clinical stage adaptation of the celebrated film, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the Next Wave Festival. The saturated reds that were a stylistic hallmark  and a symbolic one  of Bergmans movie are nowhere to be seen in Mr. van Hoves cooler, more diffuse examination of the agonies of a womans death and its impact on her two sisters and the devoted maid who attends her.

title: Some Losers in Consumer Reports Reliability Survey Are Winners in Showrooms
description: The Consumer Reports Annual Auto Reliability Survey, released on Tuesday afternoon, is intended to provide shoppers with a sense of the projected reliability of new models. But as the sales of some new cars indicate, a poor showing in the study does not translate to poor performance in the marketplace.

title: Study Shows Why Its Hard to Keep Weight Off
description: For years, studies of obesity have found that soon after fat people lost weight, their metabolism slowed and they experienced hormonal changes that increased their appetites. Scientists hypothesized that these biological changes could explain why most obese dieters quickly gained back much of what they had so painfully lost.

title: Bloomberg Conducts

title: A Welcome Windows Phone

Its new software contains what the company says are hundreds of new features. The most eye-popping enhancement is speech recognition: you can tell this new phone to call someone, text someone or give you driving directions.

title: Edible Selby | Boon Boxes
description: As the creative director of Chez Panisse, the Kyoto, Japan-born chef Sylvan Mishima Brackett learned a thing or two about catering intimate events with lan. Add to this his mothers down-to-earth cooking and the artful presentation at the restaurants where he apprenticed in Japan, and youve got the influences behind Peko-Peko, the catering business Brackett opened in 2008. I wanted to cook food that was relaxed and delicious and easy to appreciate, he says. Brackett has gained a following with his seasonal bento  dishes include pickled plum, Dungeness crab rice and miso-cured black cod  delivered in bamboo husk boxes. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Kenyan Motives in Somalia Predate Recent Abductions
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Kenyan government revealed on Wednesday that its extensive military foray into Somalia this month to battle Islamist militants was not simply a response to a wave of recent kidnappings, as previously claimed, but was actually planned far in advance, part of a covert strategy to penetrate Somalia and keep the violence in one of Africas most anarchic countries from spilling into one of Africas most stable.

title: Pauline Kael: A Life in the Dark
description: In addition to her growing dissatisfaction with the run of new movies, Pauline was not particularly happy with her situation at The New Yorker. She continued to do battle with William Shawn over tone and language in her copy, and after more than ten years of the same arguments, she was suffering from battle fatigue. Shawn, for his part, was just as exasperated as he once had been about Paulines insistence on using sexual and scatological language that he deemed inappropriate for the magazine. Their arguments had lost none of their sting over the years; as always, Pauline seemed to enjoy pushing Shawn to the limits, trying to find a crack in his gentlemanly decorum. I can remember a couple of times, at least, seeing him turn so red when they would start arguing, remembered William Whitworth, who served as Paulines immediate editor for a time in the 1970s. She would never let it go. Shawn had had a heart attack, and I thought a couple of times that he might fall over on the floor right there in the office. She was the only person in the process whodidnt treat him the way the world of journalism did, and the way the rest of us did, as a very special little person  which he was. She treated him like one of the guys and talked to him that way, with a lot of wisecracks.

title: Trial Run
description: REMOVING nail polish, at least with solutions containing acetone or similar solvents, is a smelly business (and can be irritating to skin and lungs, according to the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit advocacy group).

title: The 70s, as Dramatic as a Movie
description: At the imperial zenith of her career, Pauline Kael labeled a film the most virtuoso example of sophisticated kaleidoscopic farce that American moviemakers have ever come up with. This was in the midst of the 1970s, a period that Kaels sharpest protg, James Wolcott, now calls the feudal age of film criticism. That era is due for new scrutiny with the publication of three new books about the period. Each has a lot to say, though none entirely explain Kaels heady assessment, above, of the 1975 film Shampoo.

There are no teasers about whats inside, just a quote from Ms. Wixson that suggests she will never be known as the Joan Didion of her trade.

Gupta on conspiracy and securities fraud charges presents the Justice Department with new challenges it has not faced in prosecuting other cases involving insider trading by the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam. Wiretaps of Mr. Rajaratnam played a key role in his own conviction, but whether they will be admissible in court against Mr. Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director, will be a key point that could tip the balance of the case.

At the University of Southern California, he shredded his knee while playing football.

Whatever ones take on Mr. Kwieciens portrayal of a role he considers his calling card, his performance was a triumph of physical rehabilitation and artistic determination.

description: A 10,800-square-foot house built on 120 acres in a sleepy village serves as a second home for a British couple.

title: Seduction of Melody and Hint of Anger
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra and its audience are counting the months until next fall, when Yannick Nzet-Sguin takes over as music director. But Charles Dutoit, who holds the quaint title of chief conductor through the end of this season, brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening and showed that it has by no means languished during his watch. Section for section, and as a unified whole, the ensemble produces a magnificent sound. And when Mr. Dutoit is in his element, in music that demands coloristic breadth, precision and high voltage, the orchestra can be hard to match.

title: For High School Seniors, a Jacket to Keep Them Strong
An American Minoritys Road to Rights
description: It may be the least-publicized revolution of our time but the one whose impact ultimately reaches the furthest, affecting the way our buildings and buses are built, the way our schools are structured, the way our businesses conduct hiring and outfit their work stations. Its the disability-rights movement, and Lives Worth Living, a Thursday Independent Lens on PBS, reconstructs how it emerged and eventually pushed through the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990.

title: Look Whos Trashing Jersey Shore Now

The products of heavy metal, collapsed family structures and inertia, theyre mischievous and susceptible, and not gumptious enough for real misbehavior.

title: Massachusetts: M.I.T. Freshman Is Found Dead
description: A freshman at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, whose father is a Nobel-winning scientist on the faculty, was found dead in his dormitory room, the university said Wednesday. The death of the student, Satto Tonegawa, son of Susumu Tonegawa, is under routine investigation by the state police and the Middlesex County district attorneys office. There is no indication that there was foul play, said Cara OBrien, a spokeswoman for the district attorneys office. Susumu Tonegawa, director of the Riken-M.I.T. Center for Neural Circuit Genetics, won the 1987 Nobel Prize for medicine or physiology. His son Satto, a prize-winning pianist, grew up in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Last month an M.I.T. sophomore, Nicolas E. Del Castillo, was found dead in his dorm room, a death that was ruled a suicide.

title: Maple Leafs and Their Star Player Give Toronto Fans Reason for Hope
description: It is an old gag in championship-starved Toronto: Go Leafs go ... and take the Blue Jays, Argonauts and Raptors with you. Thats a bit harsh  the Argonauts last won a title in 2004, the Blue Jays in 1992 and 93  but the joke is really aimed at the team that matters most in Toronto, the Maple Leafs, who have not lifted the Stanley Cup since 1967.

title: After 16,000 Miles, the Rangers Skate on Home Ice
description: When Rangers fans enter Madison Square Garden on Thursday for the first sports event at the newly renovated arena, they will find better sightlines, some upper-bowl seats seemingly cantilevered over the ice, interior corridors at least twice the width of the narrow old ones, luxury suites that look like Manhattan apartments, many more restrooms  in short, a vastly improved building.

title: Tuesdays With Nan Goldin
description: Thursdays Arts pages feature Randy Kennedys interview with Nan Goldin, who is known for her photographs of life lived at full tilt, of addiction and physical abuse, of friends and lovers ravaged by AIDS and other afflictions, as Mr. Kennedy writes.

title: All That Authenticity May Be Getting Old
description: LIKE so many others her age, Casey Barber, 33, furnished her home with affordable basics from major retailers, pieces like that requisite Ikea table that is still making the rounds after all these years, she said.

title: Ruth Madoff Says Couple Tried Suicide in 2008
description: On Christmas Eve 2008, two weeks after Bernard L. Madoff confessed to running historys largest Ponzi scheme, he and his wife, Ruth, attempted suicide in their Manhattan penthouse.

title: Movie for a Rained-Out Ballgame
description: ST. LOUIS  How to spend a rained-out night off in the World Series? Tony La Russa, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, said he planned to see Moneyball, the movie about Oakland Athletics General Manager Billy Beane.

title: An Eternal Optimist Plumbs Some Demons
description: A professional Pollyanna is how Amanda McBroom, the Los Angeles cabaret singer and composer of The Rose, cheerfully described herself on Sunday evening at the Metropolitan Room in her new show, Strange Days. Ms. McBroom, accompanied on piano by her longtime songwriting collaborator, Michele Brourman, fortified that image with a sturdy rendition of A Cockeyed Optimist.

title: Sketching Out Euripides and Mother-Son Dynamic
description: The story has been told a few times now, but it bears repeating: Four years ago the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon struck out on his own, leaving the safety net of the New York City Ballet, where he was resident choreographer. With the former City Ballet principal Lourdes Lopez he created Morphoses/The Wheeldon Company, which was intended to be a dynamic home for artistic collaborations.

title: In Spain, Creating a Back-to-the-Land Experience
description: CASARES, Spain  The curvy drive from the sleepy Andalusian village of Casares to Chris and Lisa Stones mountainside vacation home should take about 10 minutesunless a herd of goats ambles across the road.

title: Chrysler Workers Approve Pact That Adds 2,100 U.S. Jobs
description: DETROIT  The last of the major automaker labor contracts was ratified on Wednesday when officials of the United Automobile Workers union announced that employees at Chrysler had approved a four-year agreement.

title: A Phone App to Keep Fans in Touch
description: Most sports events occur in stadiums or arenas, with defined boundaries and seats around the playing field. Marathons are different: runners race past the fans who line sidewalks, only to be replaced by more runners.

title: Spending a Night With Ghosts Where Legislators Roam
description: ALBANY  In a black bowler hat and flowing frock coat, Stuart Lehman stands out at the Capitol. It is just past 5 oclock, and around him state workers hustle toward the doors.

title: American Cultural Group to Visit China
description: This is not your average cultural exchange. There are no obscure acrobatic troupes and no awkward high school students.

title: Neglected Children, Messy Houses and Guilt
description: In case you missed it, the Working Mother Research Institute surveyed 3,781 women and issued a report called What Moms Choose. It quantifies a lot of things we know, and a few that we dont. Here are a few statistics to throw out over dinner, if you belong to one of those families who have civilized, discussion-based dinners (I tell myself that will happen when the children are older):

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,473 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,805 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Record $20 Million Gift to Help Finish the High Line Park
description: Many visitors to the High Line, the popular park that wends above street level on the West Side of Manhattan, stop at its northern terminus and peer wistfully through a chain-link fence at the as-yet unreclaimed half-mile segment to the north. Until this week, the nonprofit conservancy that operates the High Line still needed to raise $85 million to finish the park and maintain it.

title: Rebels Said to Find Qaddafi Tie in Plot Against Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  When Tripoli, the Libyan capital, fell, rebel fighters found secret intelligence documents linking Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to a plot by former members of Saddam Husseins military and Baath Party to overthrow the Iraqi government, according to an Iraqi official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

title: Merrill Markoes Cast of Characters
description: The veteran comedy writer and author of a new book of essays, Cool, Calm & Contentious, has filled her Malibu, Calif., home with unusual statues, portraits and more.

title: Angela Adamss New Collection
description: Pathways, Angela Adamss new collection of rugs, is made up of what the designer calls organically shaped pieces with patterns that arent immediately recognizable. Three of the tufted wool designs (Garden, left; Stream; and Woods) were inspired by Ms. Adamss nature walks, and each is intentionally uneven, much like a natural landscape.

title: Pieces Inspired by the Runway
description: Tina Frey, a San Francisco-based designer, started her company four years ago in her living room, making cast-resin tabletop items influenced by fashion. A lot of my inspiration in terms of design and color is influenced by what I see on the runways, she said.

title: Sales at Buck House, Jensen-Lewis and Others
description: Buck House is taking 25 percent off all furniture and accessories Thursday, from 5 to 8 p.m. (a 1950s Italian brass and marble occasional table, originally $1,600, is $1,200); 1318 Madison Avenue (93rd Street), (212) 828-3123 or buckhouse.com.

title: Hipcycle, a Place for Repurposed Goods
description: Andrew Sell, pictured, who recently started Hipcycle.com, said his ambition is for it to become the Amazon of upcycled products. If Hipcycle doesnt yet have the sales or range of products of the online retail giant, its merchandise is at least more novel.

title: Americana, Italian Style
description: The idea behind Lance was the merging of two cultures, said Stefano Bruni, an Italian native who started the furniture and accessories company with his American fiance, Anne Arnold, earlier this year. Americans have powerful symbols that Italians love, like a flannel shirt, a Hudson Bay blanket, a pair of jeans. These are age-old American traditions that inspired our line.

title: Childproofing: Crawling Your Way to Safety
description: AFTER we closed on our new house 10 years ago, we stopped by with the kids  ages 2, 8 and 12  to show them the place. We were there for no more than 15 minutes when we heard a loud pop just behind us and looked, in horror, to find our 2-year-old holding a key pointed at an outlet.

title: The Carpenters Carpenter
description: LARRY HAUN, who turned 80 in May, grew up on the wind-blown Nebraska plains, in a balloon-framed wood house with no insulation, electricity, running water or central heating. His first constructions were a little house, a wagon and some shelves he made with orange crates and a curved-claw hammer.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. Will installing stone countertops in my kitchen increase the homes value?

title: Merrill Markoe on Puppets and Monkey Portraits
description: Merrill Markoe, the veteran comedy writer who helped David Letterman develop the format for his late night television show in the early 1980s and who, for a time, was the shows head writer as well as Mr. Lettermans live-in girlfriend, has a book of essays, Cool, Calm & Contentious, out next week. The theme of the book, she said, may be being with crazy people in crazy situations. In fact, many of the essays are not only crazy-funny, but crazy-heartbreaking. Ms. Markoe, who grew up in Miami and San Francisco and intended to be a painter, writes about the narcissistic mother who belittled her work and a sexual attack when she was a 19-year-old art school student at the University of California, Berkeley, in the 1960s. And while she has been discreet about her relationship with Mr. Letterman, declining interviews when he was blackmailed for having an affair with a staff member a couple of years ago, she has a good deal to say about a fellow who sounds a lot like him here, although she calls the man in question Bobby.

title: Akamai President Steps Down and Is Said to Want Top Job at Yahoo
description: If Yahoo wants him, David Kenny is available.

title: Pipeline Plan Stirs Debate on Both Sides of Hudson
description: A debate that pits energy needs against safety risks is playing out in the New York region as federal officials weigh approval of a natural gas pipeline that would terminate in the West Village in Manhattan.

title: Clearing Up Some Confusion About the New Federal Student Loan Rules
description: On Wednesday, President Obama introduced two changes to the federal student loan program that could affect several million borrowers. The broad outlines of his plans to encourage loan consolidation and assist people who are struggling financially are reasonably clear.

title: Rainout Leaves Time to Tinker With Rotations
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Nightmare on the Subway
description: Sunday Metropolitan Haunting...

title: Dictators Get the Deaths They Deserve
description: San Francisco

title: Crony Capitalism Comes Home
description: Whenever I write about Occupy Wall Street, some readers ask me if the protesters really are half-naked Communists aiming to bring down the American economic system when theyre not doing drugs or having sex in public.

title: Officers Get 7 Years for Killing That Helped Inspire Egypts Revolt
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court sentenced two police officers to seven years in prison on Wednesday for the beating death of a 28-year-old man whose killing helped set off the Egyptian revolution.

title: In Brooklyn, Space and Light Meet Woodwork
description: PROBLEM: You like Midcentury Modern furniture and bright colors. But the dining room in your old house has its original walnut panels. It is formal and dark, and your husband does not want to paint it.

title: Coaxing a 1910 Town House Into Midcentury Modern
description: A dark Brooklyn home with period wood paneling gets a contemporary look.

title: A City Where Campaign Posters Can Promote Past Arrests
description: The next New York mayoral election is two years away, but prospective candidates are already busy raising money, lining up endorsements and, in some cases, burnishing their rap sheets.

title: Deep Backlog Is Detailed at Citys Bias Watchdog
description: New York Citys watchdog on discrimination issues has fallen so far behind on its workload that it should consider private financing to compensate for chronic budget cuts, according to an audit from the city comptroller, John C. Liu.

title: Detective Tells of Fatal Shots Fired at Car
description: Looking through the side window of Sean Bells crashed car, the detective grew alarmed as he saw a passenger reach for something. Then the mans arm began to rise toward him. The detective said he surmised there was a gun at the end of that arm.

title: Europes Debt Threatens MF Global, and Corzine
description: Jon S. Corzines return to Wall Street has run into a wall of turbulence.

title: When Secrets Arent Safe With Journalists
description: Washington

title: Romney Appears to Waver on Ohio Anti-Union Rules
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  Mitt Romneys critics are quick to accuse him of being a flip-flopper on important issues, part of an effort by Democrats and his Republican rivals to establish him as a politician without a core.

title: China Reins In Entertainment and Blogging
description: BEIJING  Political censorship in this authoritarian state has long been heavy-handed. But for years, the Communist Party has tolerated a creeping liberalization in popular culture, tacitly allowing everything from popular knockoffs of American Idol-style talent shows to freewheeling microblogs that let media groups prosper and let people blow off steam.

title: N.B.A. Negotiations Yield a Glimmer of Hope for Full Season
description: Optimism, a rare visitor in N.B.A. circles in recent months, crept back into the room on Wednesday  slowly, cautiously and with muted fanfare. The lockout is not over, and a labor deal is not yet in reach. But it may be on the horizon by the weekend.

title: So Much for the Nativists
description: Heres a Capitol riddle for you: Representative Lamar Smith, one of the most reflexively anti-immigrant hard-liners in Congress, is sponsoring a bill to flood the agriculture sector with up to half-a-million visas for guest workers. Understand why and youre well on your way to unpacking the nations dysfunctional relationship with undocumented immigrants.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Wrong Fix for No Child Left Behind
description: The revised No Child Left Behind Act that passed out of the Senate education committee last week goes too far in relaxing state accountability and federal oversight of student achievement. The business community, civil rights groups and advocates of disabled children are rightly worried that the rewrite of the law would particularly hurt underprivileged children.

title: Some Cities Begin Cracking Down on Occupy Protests
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  After weeks of cautiously accepting the teeming round-the-clock protests spawned by Occupy Wall Street, several cities have come to the end of their patience and others appear to be not far behind.

title: James Lanes Revenge
description: When James H. Lane led his brigade of Kansas troops into the town of Osceola, Mo., on Sept. 22, 1861, he seemed to answer a prophetic question posed by George Miller, a Missouri minister, earlier that year. When a young Missourian told the minister he was glad of the advent of national civil war, as Missourians want a chance at Kansas, Miller replied, Does it not occur to you that it would also give Kansas a chance at Missouri?

title: Home Is Where the Jamba Juice Is
description: This month, Townies goes out of town, to the other side of the continent  Los Angeles.

title: New Yorks Redistricting Charade
description: New Yorks legislative redistricting committee is holding public hearings around the state, but the exercise is a sham. The new political districts are being drawn in secret for one overriding purpose: to protect party majorities and incumbents, often for life.

title: For Occupy Protesters and Police, Frustrations Mount
description: After a confrontation in Oakland on Tuesday night, frustrations are mounting for both the Occupy demonstrators and law enforcement in cities around the country.

title: The Only St. Louis Pitchers Name That La Russa Got Right
description: ST. LOUIS  In all the confusion regarding the string of names that were botched and misconstrued in Game 5 of the World Series on Monday, the only one that was accurately conveyed from the dugout to the bullpen was the one that Cardinals Manager Tony La Russa and many others have had the most trouble pronouncing.

title: A Stunning Fall From Grace for a Star Executive
description: Last year, Rajat K. Gupta delivered a commencement speech at the Indian School of Business, a graduate school in Hyderabad that he helped start.

title: More Questions About Mammograms
description: Two years ago, a group of outside experts who advise the federal government raised a furor when it suggested that mammography screening to detect breast cancer early, when it is theoretically most treatable, should be scaled back. Now a new analysis published in the Archives of Internal Medicine, a journal of the American Medical Association, has found that while some women have their lives saved by mammograms, a vast majority found to have tumors do not benefit  probably because they have slow-growing cancers that would never have killed them or could have been treated at a later stage, or they have aggressive cancers that are deadly even if detected early.

title: Irans Power Struggle Goes Beyond Personalities to Future of Presidency Itself
description: WASHINGTON  An unusual proposal by Irans supreme leader to eliminate the position of president has highlighted an increasingly bitter struggle within the countrys political elite, as the leader and his allies continue to try to undercut the powers of Irans ambitious president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

title: In High Schools, a Critical Lens on Food
description: A commercial for McDonalds fish sandwiches played in a classroom at Park Slope Collegiate one day last month as part of a class called the Science of Food. It was clear that many students had seen the ad  several sang along with the jingle  but this was the first time they had been asked to critique it.

title: Stanfords Estimated Cost for Science School Doubles
description: Stanford Universitys proposed graduate school of science on Roosevelt Island carries a $2.5 billion price tag, the university said Wednesday, more than double its estimate just weeks ago.

title: As Cain Promotes His Management Skills, Ex-Aides Tell of Campaign in Chaos
description: If Herman Cain feels his management skills are up to any challenge, some of his former staff members think he should have started with the disorder in his own campaign.

title: Telling Court of a Scheme to Sell Arms to Terrorists
description: A Russian man accused of being a weapons trafficker was ready, willing and able to provide arms, training, money-laundering services and even political assistance to a terrorist organization that he believed planned to kill United States citizens, a former associate of his testified on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: After Carriage Horse Dies, Mayor Rejects Calls for Ban
description: Days after a carriage horse collapsed and died in Midtown, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday dismissed calls for a ban on the carriage industry, saying he could not imagine why anybody wants to destroy something that is part of New Yorks heritage and that tourists love.

title: New Offer for Sabathia in the Works
description: ST. LOUIS  The Yankees are close to completing a new contract proposal for the left-hander C.C. Sabathia, which they intend to present to him before he can opt out of his current contract, according to a baseball executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

title: Thursday: Visibly Scared Out of Ones Wits
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Theres a lot to like in this puzzle, but perhaps my favorite part is that it allowed me to draw little pictures of ghosts inside some of the squares of this rebus. That wasnt a completely original idea. Jeffrey Schwartz, second place winner of the 2011 Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament, drew them during the championship round and I thought that was a lot more fun than trying to cram the word GHOST into each square. Congratulations as well to champion Robert Mackey and third place winner Elaine Lippman.

title: Absolut Celebrates Its 30 Years of Marketing to Gay Consumers
description: MARKETERS like to mark milestones, whether it is the 50th anniversary of the debut of The Dick Van Dyke Show, the 125th anniversary of the introduction of Coca-Cola or the 150th anniversary of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Now, a brand is about to celebrate something that typically passes unnoticed: the 30th anniversary of a media placement.

title: A Nuanced Take in the Debate Over the Value of a Liberal Arts Diploma
description: In a hotel ballroom trimmed with electric purple lights, this years College Board conference in New York City formally kicked off on Wednesday afternoon with a keynote address from the president of the University of Chicago, Robert J. Zimmer.

title: Lawyer Opposing Health Law Is Familiar Face to the Justices
description: WASHINGTON  It would be hard for any lawyer to fathom a more riveting caseload than the one Paul D. Clement carried during his seven years in President George W. Bushs Justice Department.

title: Changes in Black Voter Turnout
description: Black voters share of the electorate compared with share of population.

title: Black Voters Support for Obama Is Steady and Strong
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Abdul Malik seems the prototype of a disenchanted Barack Obama voter.

title: Nuances Nuanced Numbers
description: Getting machines to understand speech is a hot technology. Nuance Communications is a powerhouse in the field. Analysts even suspect that Nuance, which has a market capitalization of nearly $8 billion, has licensed technology to Apple for the new iPhone 4S, though neither company will confirm that. But Nuances sky-high valuation multiple is a stretch.

title: Little Team Back on Top in Spain
description: After spending fewer than 24 hours in second place in the Spanish league following Barcelonas 1-0 win at Granada on Tuesday, Levante vaulted back into the top spot Wednesday courtesy of a goal by Ruben Surez in injury time that enabled the small club from Valencia to score another big victory, 3-2 against Real Sociedad. It was Levantes seventh consecutive win. Real Madrid jumped over Barcelona and into second place on the strength of its 3-0 win against visiting Villarreal.

title: Perry Says Hell Be a Job Creator
description: The presidential campaign of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas started running its first television advertisement on broadcast and cable television in Iowa on Wednesday.

title: Player Ratings: Dallas (0), Red Bulls (2)
description: The Red Bulls passed the first hurdle and get to play on for at least another week.

title: Walcott Pledges Measures to Increase Parents' Involvement
Employee Pleads Guilty in Fatal Crane Collapse
description: A former employee of a company that owned a crane that collapsed two years ago on the Upper East Side and killed two people has pleaded guilty to criminally negligent homicide and agreed to testify against his former boss.

title: Butternut-Squash Bisque
description: 3 tablespoons unsalted butter

title: Eleven Madison Park Granola
description: 2 34 cups rolled oats 1 cup shelled pistachios 1 cup unsweetened coconut chips 1/3 cup pumpkinseeds 1 tablespoon salt 12 cup light brown sugar 1/3 cup maple syrup 1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil 34 cup dried sour cherries.

title: Red Bulls Cash In on Playoff Chance
description: FRISCO, Tex.  The Red Bulls were riding a wave of momentum last week as they became re-energized just in time to salvage a spot in the M.L.S. playoffs. Still, their captain, Thierry Henry, had issued a warning that the team needed to play better if it expected to beat F.C. Dallas.

title: George L. Sherry, Envoy and Well-Known Voice at U.N., Dies at 87
description: George L. Sherry, a former United Nations official who helped calm crises around the world  a role that evolved from his time as the leading rapid-fire translator of speeches by Russian diplomats in the organizations early days  died in Manhattan on Friday. He was 87.

title: Liquid Nitrogen Optional
description: Eleven Madison Park is a grand and airy urban palace of a restaurant in the Metropolitan Life North Building at the foot of Madison Avenue. The dining room has wide marble floors and soaring, double-height ceilings, and huge windows that overlook the leafy acres of Madison Square Park. It is among the most beautiful restaurants in the world.

title: Teaching Doctors to Be Mindful
description: It was 6:40 in the morning and nearly all of the doctors attending the medical conference had assembled for the first session of the day. But there were no tables and chairs in sight, no lectern, no run-throughs of PowerPoint presentations. All I could make out in the early morning darkness were the unmoving forms of my colleagues, cross-legged on cushions and raised platforms, eyes closed and hands resting with palms upward in their laps.

title: Can Romance Be Reduced to Pronouns?
description: Behavioral scientists have long known that humans, whether in the schoolyard or in a dimly lighted bar, have a tendency to subconsciously mimic the sounds, style and movement of others. Recent research, however, shows that this mimicry also extends to how we speak and write. Even the least important words we choose can say a lot about us.

title: Herman Cain, Outlier
description: Herman Cain, the Georgia businessman who has never held elected office, is tied for the lead in national polls of Republican voters  or perhaps even slightly ahead of Mitt Romney, as he was in Tuesday nights New York Times/CBS News poll. Mr. Cain has also led in most recent polls of the Iowa caucuses and the South Carolina primary, has taken the lead in Ohio, and is close to Mr. Romney in Florida. If all you had to go on was the polls, you might think that Mr. Cain was the favorite to win the Republican nomination.

title: Corrections: October 27
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Word of the Day | gall
description: gall \gl\ noun and verb

title: An Occupy Wall Street March to Support Those in Oakland
description: Hundreds of protesters in New York City marched on Wednesday night to show solidarity with protesters in Oakland, Calif., where the police used tear gas to disperse crowds a night earlier. About a dozen demonstrators were arrested in New York, the police said.

title: NYT Front Page for 10/27/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 10/27/2011

title: Thousands Flee Bangkok as Flooding Spreads
description: BANGKOK  With government officials saying there was nothing more they could do to protect the capital from devastating flooding, tens of thousands of people were fleeing Bangkok on Thursday, jamming train and bus stations and clogging the southern highways out of town.

title: Cities Begin Cracking Down on Occupy Protests
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  After weeks of cautiously accepting the teeming round-the-clock protests spawned by Occupy Wall Street, several cities have come to the end of their patience and others appear to be not far behind.

title: Ra.One Dazzles and Disappoints
description: Bollywoods most expensive movie to date, Ra.One, is an entertainment machine set to dazzle Rachel Saltz writes in a New York Times review of the movie.

title: Oct. 27, 1904 | New York City Subway System Opens
description: On Oct. 27, 1904, the first rapid transit subway, the Interborough Rapid Transit (I.R.T.), opened in New York City. The line ran approximately nine miles from City Hall north to Grand Central Station, then west to Times Square and up the West Side to 145th Street.The New York Times described the excitement among city dwellers for the subways opening: For the first time in his life Father Knickerbocker went underground yesterday; went underground, he and his children, to the number of 150,000, amid the tooting of whistles and the firing of salutes, for a first ride in a subway which for years had been scoffed at as an impossibility.

title: Greeks Applaud E.U. Agreement to Cut Debt
description: ATHENS - George Papandreou, the Greek prime minister, on Thursday hailed his countrys latest bailout as marking a new day for Europe and for Greece, after European Union and International Monetary Fund officials reached a deal under which banks would write off 50 percent of the face value of their Greek debt, a major step toward working out an overall deal to safeguard the euro.

title: News Quiz | Oct. 27, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: No More Mr. Nice Guy
description: Theres a scene in your new Starz show, Boss, when, as Mayor Tom Kane of Chicago, you open a package containing the ears of an activist who has been causing you trouble. Then you nonchalantly grind them up in your garbage disposal. Something tells me youre more like this guy than Frasier Crane.

title: Lynda Barry Will Make You Believe In Yourself
description: Dorie Cox left her little house by the Fort Lauderdale airport at 7:15 a.m. on a Wednesday morning this past summer to take a three-train journey to Miami. The Tri-Rail zipped along beside I-95 into the city; the Metrorail took her past the hospital where her best friend died; the elevated Metromover looped, conductorless, around downtown and dropped her off at Miami Dade College.

title: Mr. Hoenig Goes to Washington
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Beyond the Fringe of Protest
description: Nina Berman was intrigued by the idea of protest in this age, so when she heard about a nascent uprising that was gaining national momentum, she had to check it out.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 27, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, For Pujols of St. Louis, a Night for the Ages.

title: Tiny Treats
description: WHAT kinds of miniature sweets are popping up around New York and in the mass market?

title: Icelands Saga
description: Were underway now. Live webcast here.

title: Diwali in the Big Apple
description: If there was any doubt that Diwali had become a well-entrenched event on New York Citys multicultural calendar, it was erased some time ago.

title: Oil Industry Hums as Higher Prices Bolster Quarterly Profits at Exxon and Shell
description: HOUSTON  Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell reported robust profits on Thursday for the third quarter based on higher oil prices and better refining margins.

title: Aid Arriving in Turkey Quake Area
description: ISTANBUL  An Israeli plane carrying emergency housing led a flow of international aid into the quake-stricken area of eastern Turkey on Thursday, as two more people were pulled alive from the rubble.

title: Do You Trust Your Government?
description: A new poll found that Americans distrust of government is at its highest levels in history. Anger resulting from a grim job market and growing economic inequality has fueled protest movements from Occupy Wall Street to the Tea Party, and Americans approval of Congress has dropped to 9 percent. Do you still have faith in the American government? Why or why not?

title: Santanders Profit Fell 13% in First 9 Months of 2011
description: Banco Santander on Thursday reported a net profit in the first nine months of the year that was below expectations, as Europes deteriorating economic situation offset the companys expanding business in the Americas.

title: On Halloween Weekend, Exploring Londons Scary Side
description: Theres more to the dark side of the English capitals history than that of the Tower of London. Around Halloween the city will come alive (so to speak) with the dead, as ghosts, ghouls and witches take to the streets for a weekend of spine-chilling revelries, from Oct. 29 to 31.

title: N.F.L. Week 8 Game Probabilities (Intangibles Are Baked In)
description: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.

title: The Early Word: Numbers
description: In Todays Times:

title: Ericsson to Sell Stake in Handset Venture to Sony
description: 6:52 p.m. | Updated

title: Shares Jump on European Deal to Solve Debt Crisis
description: World financial markets powered higher on Thursday in the giddy hope that Europes plan to solve its sovereign debt crisis would finally lift the uncertainty over the global economy and markets. In the United States, a sharp jump in stocks continued what has become the biggest monthly rally in 37 years.

title: How a Doctors Web Site Can Generate More Business
description: Last week, my post asked whether visiting a service providers Web site made you want to use the service.

title: Study Finds That Immigrants Are Central to Long Island Economy
description: Immigrants, those who are here legally and illegally, are important contributors to the economy on Long Island and are a relatively affluent group, according to a report to be released on Thursday.

title: Dropbox Bids to Find Entry in Businesses
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Perhaps it should not have surprised corporate information technology departments that employees would use Dropbox, a service for easily sharing files among different devices by storing them in the cloud. But that did not mean they loved the idea of confidential files on a service they could not control.

title: Cellphone Ban Is a Tale of Two City Schools
Making Restaurant Recommendations Smarter
description: One of the neat tricks of the new iPhone 4S is how Siri, its virtual assistant feature, taps into the restaurant database of Yelp to recommend local dining options. When I ask Siri, Whats the best place to get dessert nearby, it grabs a list of a dozen purveyors of sweetness in my area, ordered by their Yelp ratings.

title: Toronto Bans Shark Fin Sales

With the so-longs and the take cares, Mr. Reed tacked on: Lets make a record together. It was no throw-away.

title: Paper Trail
description: Print may be dying, but not in the design world. The exhibition Archizines, at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London from Nov. 5 through Dec. 14, features 60 contemporary architecture magazines, fanzines and journals from more than 20 countries. The shows curator, Elias Redstone, who writes the London Underground column for Ts blog, The Moment, collected the publications on his travels, compiling them first as an online project (archizines.com), with art direction by Folch Studio in Barcelona. But an exhibition of the print versions makes perfect sense: the power of the Internet notwithstanding, its more fun to turn real pages than digital ones.

description: In a sign that New York State may have to slow down a bit before authorizing a new kind of natural gas drilling, an advisory panel is delaying its recommendations on how the state should pay for new staff members to enforce regulations on the drilling operations.

title: Who Benefits From Extra Day Off?
description: While the baseball world spends the day contemplating which team benefits from a washed out night in the World Series, there are many pluses in a days delay before Game 6. You can almost picture the Cardinals scrambling to install a new wireless bullpen phone system, with Tony La Russa wandering around Busch Stadium saying, Can you hear me now? The Rally Squirrel has another day to improve his first-to-third time. The Rangers can spend time being even pickier on what kind of Champagne they will stash in their clubhouse for a potential celebration. Is it better to spray oneself with ultra brut or demi-sec? Or perhaps a nice prosecco?

title: Art Forgers Whose Victims Included Steve Martin are Sentenced
description: A group of art forgers who sold falsely attributed oil paintings to art collectors, and whose victims included the comedian Steve Martin, were sentenced on Thursday by a court in Cologne, Germany, Bloomberg News reported. Wolfgang Beltracchi, the leader of the ring, which since the 1990s sold dozens of fake paintings said to be made by artists like Heinrich Campendonk, Fernand Lger and Max Ernst, was given a six-year sentence; his wife, Helene, was sentenced to four years while her sister, Jeanette, received a 21-month suspended sentence. Otto Schulte-Kellinghaus, a fourth member of the ring, was sentenced to five years.

title: No Highway Therapy for Pepper-Spray Commander
description: When imperfect police officers are caught and punished, they sometimes receive a form of discipline known colloquially behind the Blue Wall of Silence as highway therapy.

title: Drifting Along, Tumbleweeds Are Piling Up Across Plains
description: CIMARRON, Kan.  The ubiquitous swerving and darting forms making their hopscotch journey across the landscape here in recent days are part of one of the most storied  and least celebrated  natural migrations on the Great Plains.

description: Sure, tailgate party menus can be as simple as a disposable grill and a package of hot dogs. The more serious, though, seem lacking without some all-out BBQ. Enter Tammy Herchel this week and her Superawesome Sweet and Spicy Smoked Ribs. Herchel, a Florida Gators fan, promises a happy pregame meal, and offers some tips to satisfy every rib-loving palate.

title: A New Sleeping Beauty, Courtesy of Matthew Bourne
description: LONDON  He has turned his hand to Swan Lake, The Nutcracker, La Sylphide and Cinderella, but Matthew Bourne isnt done yet rethinking the ballet classics. At a news conference at Sadlers Wells on Wednesday, he announced that he would create a new Sleeping Beauty for Christmas 2012 as part of a yearlong celebration of the 25th anniversary of his company, New Adventures.
