Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Qaddafi Son Maintains Innocence as Criminal Court Cites Indirect Talks
description: The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court at The Hague said Friday that he had been in indirect contact with Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the fugitive son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his onetime heir apparent, about turning himself in to face trial before the court.

title: Hitches Signal Further Difficulties for Euro Zone
description: Sobriety displaced euphoria in Europe on Friday as signals that the debt crisis was far from over, like higher borrowing costs for Italy, deflated a market rally that had followed a show of resolve by European leaders.

title: 9/11 Memorial Leaves Its Mark on the Subway, All Rights Reserved
description: There are branded stations in the subway system. And branded cars. It was probably only a matter of time before there were branded signs, too.

title: Goodbye Lasix, and Good Riddance
description: Beginning with the 2012 Breeders Cup, 2-year-olds will not be administered medication hours before they race for the first time in decades. The regulators of racing have seen the light from the horse and rider perspective. Extensive studies clearly indicate that drugs cause more trouble for racehorses and their riders than they alleviate. Lasix jurisdictions have significantly more breakdowns than jurisdictions where Lasix is not allowed. No prerace Lasix means no attending veterinarians with loaded syringes in the stall injecting the horses with drugs hours before they run. The dangerous and dubious charade of medicating racehorses before they compete is coming to a welcome end.

title: Goldman Adds a Board Member
description: The members of Goldman Sachss board of directors, who sit atop one of the highest perches on Wall Street, now number an even dozen.

title: At the Met, a New Vision for Islam in Hostile Times
description: Over the past decade, many Americans have based their thoughts and feelings about Islam in large part on a single place: the blasted patch of ground where the World Trade Center once stood. But a rival space has slowly and silently taken shape over those same years, about six miles to the north. It is a vast, palacelike suite of rooms on the second floor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where some of the worlds most precious Islamic artifacts sit sequestered behind locked doors.

title: Shares Settle After Rally Over European Debt Deal
description: Stocks in the United States eased back on Friday from their biggest monthly rally in decades, ending relatively flat as the euphoria over Europes plan to address its sovereign debt crisis eased.

title: Peter Jackson Says Hell Help One of the West Memphis Three Seek a Pardon
description: At a news conference on Friday in New Zealand Peter Jackson, the director of the Lord of the Rings trilogy and a coming two-part film adaptation of The Hobbit, said he was working with one of the recently released Arkansas men known as the West Memphis Three to help get him exonerated of the crimes for which the three spent nearly 20 years in prison.

title: A Spotlight Now Shines on Italy
description: It finally dawned on me this week that the value of my retirement account might depend on Silvio Berlusconi.

description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first 12 paragraphs of the article From Last Strike to Game 7.

description: Updated, 3:03 p.m. | Firefighters went into Zuccotti Park early Friday morning and removed six generators and 13 cans of gasoline, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on his weekly radio program. Protesters handed the materials over voluntarily, and there were no arrests.

description: A look back at some the actresss film roles.

title: Judy Battista Answers Readers N.F.L. Questions
description: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The New York Times, answers questions from readers.

title: Leading Off: How Many Ways to Say Wow?
description: So Game 6 of the World Series was full of enough thrills for a year of amusement park visits, the crazy, sloppy humanness of the first six innings followed by the wild, whose-turn-is-it-to-be-a-superhero final innings that seemed able to go on forever until David Freeses towering, preposterous home run dropped onto the lawn beyond Busch Stadiums center-field fence. It left only one question remaining:

title: Strong Enough to Play the Heavy
description: THERE may be women in Hollywood more beautiful than Charlize Theron, though its hard offhand to think who might qualify, and even harder to think of one who relies less on her looks. Ms. Theron, whose new film, Young Adult, directed by Jason Reitman, opens on Dec. 9, is a genuine star  with an almost Marilyn-like glamour  and yet she goes about her work as if she were a character actress. From one movie to the next she seldom looks the same, and not just in the ones where she has obviously transformed herself. To play the serial killer Aileen Wuornos in Monster (2003), for example, she put on 40 pounds, shaved her eyebrows and wore prosthetic teeth.

title: Rethinking That Special Relationship Between the U.S. and Britain
description: Every four years, as the American people embark on the task of electing a president, Europeans are reminded that they simply dont understand America. At least I dont, and I like to think that I know the United States better than many Englishmen.

title: Occupational Hazard
description: I support Occupy Wall Street and am appalled by the behavior of the corporations theyre rallying against. While I do not work on Wall Street, my small start-up is financed primarily by one of the biggest Wall Street companies. Am I a hypocrite who should resign immediately? ANONYMOUS, NEW YORK CITY

title: Steve Jobs: Vampire. Bill Gates: Zombie.
description: As Halloween approaches, we find ourselves awash in dead people. Lots and lots of dead people, though not all dead people are dead in the same way.

title: The Orchestral Maneuvers of John Maus
description: The music of John Maus evokes an urbane 80s vibe so convincingly that you practically expect him to exist in some neon-drenched video from the dawn of MTV. Instead, Maus lives in a rented ranch house next to a cow pasture two and a half hours south of Minneapolis. Apart from a keyboard and some recording gear stacked in a corner of the study, Mauss spare cabin looks like the lair of a lonely grad student desperately trying to finish a dissertation on the concept of inoperative community. Which, in fact, it is.

title: Trailer: 'War Horse'
description: A preview of "War Horse," directed by Steven Spielberg.

title: Does Anyone Have a Grip On the G.O.P.?
description: [Matt Bai] really delves into the whole schism between the Tea Party and the Republican establishment. But in the course of it, he talks about what is the Republican establishment and that the establishment believes now that they are co-opting the Tea Party, [who] are really only the kind of radicals who have always come to town with a fiery new idea and then become co-opted. But Bai, in the reporting of this, really shows that there are major differences between former radicals who came to Washington and then got tempered by money and time and victories and defeats, and that [Tea Party members] are in fact a new breed who are . . . almost humorlessly addicted in a sense to the whole idea of antigovernment. . . . A sort of reverse takeover could be going on.

title: Trailer: 'The Adventures of Tintin'
description: A preview of "The Adventures of Tintin," directed by Steven Spielberg.

title: Hard Times for Gay Retirement Havens
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Like so many others who have settled here, Janice Gaynor and her partner, Barbara Cohn, wanted to retire somewhere where they could be themselves, whether that meant holding hands in public or making decisions about each others end-of-life health care.

description: Sister, open for us.

description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman explains the art of poaching an egg. She writes:

title: Celebrating Wine in Alto Adige
description: Italy has much to entice the intrepid oenophile. Tuscany and the Piedmont tend to rule the roost when it comes to wine, but it is the German- and Italian-speaking region of Alto Adige that hosts one of Europes most prestigious wine events: the Merano Wine Festival, which celebrates its 20th anniversary this year, Nov. 4 to 7.

title: Lotus Recalls 5,000 Elise and Exige Models for Oil Leak
description: Lotus is recalling about 5,000 of its 2005-6 Elise and Exige models because an oil line may come loose, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

description: Updated 2:00 p.m.: Clarified the timing of Logitechs software updates for Google TV.

title: Gary Johnson to Get His Name on the New Hampshire Ballot, Just in Time
description: UPDATE 12:41 p.m: He made it! Gary Johnson filed for the New Hampshire Republican presidential primary, arriving at 11:15 a.m. to formally add his name to the states ballot.

title: Was It the Greatest World Series Game Ever?
description: So where exactly does Game 6 of the 2011 World Series rank in baseball history?

title: The Bolshoi Theater Reopens
description: After six years of renovation and reconstruction, the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow reopened.

title: Long-Awaited Climate Satellite Lifts Off
description: Five years after its original launch date, a new observation satellite lifted off on Friday in California with a new generation of observation tools critical to weather forecasters and climate scientists alike.

title: New Build | The Tel Aviv Museum of Art
description: It isnt every day that Tel Aviv gets a piece of architecture worth writing home about. In fact, one of the easiest arguments to win in the Middle East might be that Tel Avivs urban core has not sprouted a truly remarkable structure in the more than half a century since the Bauhaus inkwell  which left its curvilinear imprint on hundreds of buildings in The White City  began to dry up. But with the completion of the Herta and Paul Amir Building at the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, opening on Wednesday, things are set to get noticeably whiter and brighter. The new wing, designed by the Cambridge, Mass.-based architect Preston Scott Cohen (who is also chairman of the architecture department at Harvard University), looks a bit like an elongated Rubiks Cube doused with bleach. The gleaming white parabolas of the facade are composed of 465 flat, interlocking, precast concrete panels of different shapes and sizes. The buildings three floors are linked to two more below grade by an 87-foot-high, top-lit atrium, a lightfall that will shine on the worlds largest collection of Israeli art. The buildings confident yet supple geometries provide a nifty counterpoint to the museums main building, a 1971 Brutalist number by the Israeli architect Dan Eytan (who also designed Israels decidedly unfussy Dimona nuclear reactor). Next to that chunky monkey, Cohens creation is pure pizazz. Fittingly, in honor of the buildings inauguration later this month, the city of Tel Aviv has declared 2012 to be Art Year, culminating in a four-day blowout Art Weekend March 21-24.

title: Why Everybody Knows His Name
description: Amsterdam

title: A Rainy Night of Stars, and a Laurel
description: Thursday night was the Fashion Groups annual party, at Cipriani Wall Street, a journey of 1,000 miles (it seemed). Everyone was packed into the former bank, unaware that in an hour or so we were going to be served this large, brown, rectangular hunk of ground lamb with a side of scalloped potatoes. I had just come from celebrating the season with a pumpkin pie bake-off at the office, so the lamb thing was a definite freakout, a no-go. Raf Simons, one of the evenings honorees, made a tidy joke at the podium about the gravy stain on his tie. Awards were also given to Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte, Giambattista Valli, Andrew Rosen, Daphne Guinness, Lauren Bush and Wanda Ferragamo. Steve Sadove, the chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue, and Ronald Frasch, the stores president, were the designated superstars, with Mr. Frasch making a funny speech about golf, competition and why he loves his job.

title: Cameron Crowe Gets Out of the House
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Rangers Early Season Troubles Show Lack of Speed
description: After the Rangers lost their home opener, 4-2, to Toronto Thursday night, Coach John Tortorella said his team was mentally and physically lethargic. This may be true, but there could be another reason why they have spent so much of the early part of this season chasing the puck around the rink. Tortorellas team is hardly a collection of fleet skaters.

title: Good News and Bad on Long-Term Care
description: Desperately searching for any crumb of good news about long-term care, now that the Class Act appears dead, I was glad to get an e-mail from Jesse Slome, executive director of the American Association for Long-Term Care Insurance, pointing out that the I.R.S. is going to allow slightly higher tax deductions in 2012 for the smattering of people who have bought private long-term care policies.

title: Forget the Art House; Hes Making Blockbusters
description: WHEN you present a comedy achievement award to Brett Ratner, as the Friars Club did on a recent Saturday night in Manhattan, who shows up for the ceremony? You get the entrepreneur Russell Simmons and the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman, who roasted Mr. Ratner for his tastes in fashion models and baggy pants; Michael Barker, co-president of Sony Pictures Classics, who praised Mr. Ratners omnivorous cinematic appetite; and Richard Belzer, the comedian and Law & Order: SVU star, who briefly summoned the Friars Club abbot Jerry Lewis on his cellphone.

title: Weekend TV Guide, Oct. 29-30: Decision Time
description: If Jurgen Klinsmann holds true to form, he will announce his rosters for the upcoming friendlies against France and Slovenia on Thursday or Friday of next week. That means that this weekend most likely represents Klinsmanns last opportunity to see a full slate of games featuring prospective United States national team players before he sets his squad.

title: On Eve of Inaugural Formula One Indian GP, Teams Revved Up Their Simulators
description: The Formula One series is racing in India for the first time this weekend. But long before teams arrived at the barely completed Buddh International Circuit on Thursday, they prepared for the grand prix, scheduled for Oct. 30, the same way they did for the first-ever Korean Grand Prix last year and the first-ever Abu Dhabi Grand Prix in 2009: They ran laps in the simulator.

title: Judge Signs Off on Settlement for Black Farmers
description: A federal judge in Washington has granted final approval for a $1.25 billion settlement by the Agriculture Department for African-American farmers longstanding claims of racial discrimination.

title: If Nobodys Watching, Why Is Everyone Talking About It?
description: Mike Tanier will provide Bats with updates on less-than-important developments from the World Series.

title: Memorable World Series Games
description: Memorable moments from some of the most memorable World Series games include Carlton Fisks game-ending home run for Boston in 1975 and and Joe Carters series-ending home run for Toronto in 1993.

title: Reader Idea | A Class on the Media and Society
description: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

title: Coalmines And Military Keynesians
description: Ah, so now we have a new principle of economics: government spending cant create jobs, but cuts in government spending can destroy jobs  as long as the jobs are in the defense sector

title: Spooky Sketches | Suno
description: T challenges 10 designers to turn everyday objects in to killer Halloween costumes.

title: Shots Fired at U.S. Embassy in Bosnia
description: Updated | 5:22 p.m. A gunman fired shots at the United States Embassy in the Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, on Friday.

title: Bombing Reported in Tibet
description: BEIJING  A bomb possibly set by Tibetan independence advocates damaged a municipal building in a town in eastern Tibet this week, according to a report on Friday by Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London.

title: Samuel Becketts Midgame
description: Samuel Barclay Beckett was born in Foxrock, south of Dublin, in the spring of 1906  theres a dispute about the precise date; he died in Paris on Dec. 22, 1989. Over a period of 60 years, he wrote more than 15,000 letters. The editors of The Letters of Samuel Beckett plan to publish, in four volumes, their choice of about 2,500 letters in full, and to cite a further 5,000 in their copious annotations. The letters in French are given in the original, then translated into English. The first volume, the letters of 1929-40, was published in 2009.

title: College Application Essay as Haiku? For Some, 500 Words Arent Enough
description: Penn Weinberger had grown attached to his college admissions essay. The topic  coping with a brothers attention deficit disorder  was important to him. The anecdotes clicked. The characters had dimension. The meaning, as his teachers at Hunter College High School had long advised him, was shown, not told.

title: What Spalding Gray Left Us
description: In Swimming to Cambodia  the monologue that made Spalding Gray (relatively) famous, about the time he spent in Thailand playing a small role in The Killing Fields, the film about the Cambodian genocide  Gray tells a strange, disconcerting story about the death of Thomas Merton. Merton, the Trappist monk celebrated for his devotion to an eloquently spiritualized silence, was a hero of mine because he knew how to shut up, Gray, the compulsive verbalizer, tells us.

title: Your Common Application Essay, Uncut
description: As early-admissions deadlines bear down next week, many high school seniors and their college admissions advisers are grappling with the 500-word limit the Common Application reinstated on personal statements this spring.

title: Murder at the Least Expected Moment
description: Some of the more memorable literary perpetrators of homicide are driven not by psychotic fixations on pentagrams or by what happened to them in a foster home in 1972 but by what they perceive as simple practicality. This is true of a character as conscience-free as Patricia Highsmiths Tom Ripley and as conscientious as Jean Vale Horemarsh, the mild, seemingly ordinary ceramist at the center of the Canadian writer Trevor Coles Practical Jean, a tidy social comedy with some very dark dimensions.

title: A Writer of Slasher Books Finds More Than a Muse
description: Helen Oyeyemis captivating new novel, Mr. Fox, begins with a jaunty spirit and a sense of play. We meet Mr. Fox; he is a writer of slasher books, and he has an assistant, a woman named Mary whom he conjured in a trench during his days fighting in World War I. He also has a wife, Daphne. At some point or other, all three of them write.

title: On the Road to Harpers Ferry
description: Early one morning in the mid-1990s a squad of Civil War re-enactors wandered into Tony Horwitzs front yard in rural Virginia. He grabbed some mugs of coffee and went out to meet them. They were ordinary guys  a salesman, a forklift operator, a waiter  who were so devoted to reliving the war that one re-enactor had learned how to bloat himself to look like one of the corpses that litter Mathew Bradys famous battlefield photos. Horwitz had found his muse.

title: James Madison, the Father of Politics
description: No one would ever have mistaken James Madison for George Washington. Short, scrawny and sickly, he suffered from a hypochondria that convinced him he would lead neither a long nor a healthy life. He was a miserable public speaker who tended to lapse into inaudible mumbling, and well into his career as a politician, he continued to shrink back in horror at the idea of going out on the stump and putting on an electioneering appearance.

title: Death Valley: Three Million Acres of Weird
description: ITS just before midnight on the edge of Death Valley and Im standing in a dark room in the Amargosa Opera House and Hotel with five people who are certain that were talking to ghosts.

title: Death Valleys Ghost Towns
description: One of the lowest, most arid places on earth, Death Valley has more ghost towns than actual ones.

title: West Virginia Wants Out, but Big East Wont Let Go
description: A day of celebration turned into a day of confusion and uncertainty for West Virginia.

title: A Plague of Urban Undead in Lower Manhattan
description: A literary novelist writing a genre novel is like an intellectual dating a porn star. It invites forgivable prurience: What is that relationship like? Granted the intellectuals hit hanky-panky pay dirt, but whats in it for the porn star? Conversation? Ideas? Deconstruction?

title: The Joyful Side of Translation
description: The theory of translation is very rarely  how to put this?  comical. Its mode is elegy, and severe admonishment. In the 20th century, its great figures were Vladimir Nabokov, in exile from Soviet Russia, attacking libertines like Robert Lowell for their infidelities to the literal sense; or Walter Benjamin, Jewish in a proto-Nazi Berlin, describing the Task of the Translator as an impossible ideal of exegesis. You can never, so runs the elegiac argument, precisely reproduce a line of poetry in another language. Poetry! You can hardly even translate maman. . . . And this elegiac argument has its elegiac myth: the Tower of Babel, where the worlds multiplicity of languages is seen as mankinds punishment  condemned to the howlers, the faux amis, the foreign menu apps. Whereas the ideal linguistic state would be the lost universal language of Eden.

title: Caliphs, Crusaders, and the Bloody History of Jerusalem
description: If I forget thee, O Jerusalem, declares the Psalmist, may my right hand forget its cunning. He neglects to mention that remembering Jerusalem is no picnic either. In Jerusalem: The Biography, Simon Sebag Montefiore unleashes so many kings, killers, prophets, pretenders, caliphs and crusaders, all surfing an ocean of blood, that the reader may begin to long for redemption, not from the book, which is impossible to put down, but from history itself.

title: What Makes Spielberg Jump?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Examining Pop Cultures Heroes, and Himself
description: It is something of a surprise that one of the best magazine profiles of the last decade is about Axl Rose. But such is the work of John Jeremiah Sullivan, who can take pretty much anything you never thought youd want to read about respectably (Axl Rose, Real World) or anything you never thought youd want to read about at all (a Christian-rock festival, long-forgotten naturalist loons), and make of it the sort of essay-world you just want to dwell inside. Sullivan seems able to do almost anything, to work in any register, and not just within a single piece but often in the span of a single paragraph. Here, for example, is his first sketch of Rose in person, which can only be quoted at length:

title: Clip: 'Immortals'
description: In this scene from "Immortals," Zeus responds wrathfully to Ares's disobedience.

title: A Novel of Competing Actors Following the Call of the Stage
description: Esther Freud was an actress before she became a novelist, and as we can guess from the title of a droll essay about her acting careers high point, I Was an Alien in Doctor Who,  the change was an excellent move. Shes a superbly gifted writer, with a touch so light shes often undervalued. Freuds seventh novel, Lucky Break, which follows a group of actors for nearly 15 years  from their first day at drama school until theyre ready for Botox  may not be her most ambitious, but its her most breezily charming and typically shrewd, and comes with a new satirical edge.

title: The Short, Unsuccessful Life of the American Book Awards
description: On Nov. 16, literary types will put on their evening wear, gather in a Manhattan ballroom and clap politely for the presentation of this years National Book Awards. Its the publishing industrys biggest awards ceremony  and its best excuse to party  but it remains a subdued affair. Last years jolt of celebrity came from a jeans-wearing Patti Smith, whose Just Kids won the nonfiction award. Far more typical was the fiction prize, which went to the little-known Lord of Misrule, by Jaimy Gordon. It would have been a shocking choice if the National Book Awards werent known for this sort of thing. Theyre awards for insiders.

title: Ambrose Bierce: The Man and His Demons
description: The definition of ghost, n in Ambrose Bierces puckish Devils Dictionary is the outward and visible sign of an inward fear, and although Bierce was not an entirely reliable lexicographer, his authority on this subject is beyond question. He knew more than any man should about both inward fears and their outward and visible signs. And he was at least arguably the most powerful American writer of horror fiction between Poe and Lovecraft. (Henry Jamess supernatural tales are in a class by themselves.) In his career Bierce wrote more than 40 spooky stories, most of them about ghosts, along with a fair number of short narratives  some true, some fanciful  about the horrors of war. All his tales, both the ones about soldiers and the ones about the haunted and the haunting, are steeped in loneliness and dread, which he evokes with the precision of someone familiar with their every nuance. A fat new Library of America volume, Ambrose Bierce: The Devils Dictionary, Tales, and Memoirs ($35), collects the best of his work, and almost every page has something to give you the chills, though not always, perhaps, in the way the author intended.

title: Editors Choice
description: RIN TIN TIN: The Life and the Legend,  by Susan Orlean (Simon & Schuster, $26.99.) The story of the soulful German shepherd, born on a World War I battlefield, who conquered Hollywood and became a family-friendly symbol of cold war gunslinging.

title: Paperback Row
description: MARY ANN IN AUTUMN,  by Armistead Maupin (Harper Perennial, $14.99.) The characters from Maupins Tales of the City series  which began in 1974 as a serial about a young Midwesterner in San Francisco named Mary Ann Singleton  are reunited in this tenderhearted novel. Twenty years have passed since Mary Ann left family and friends in San Francisco to pursue a television career in New York, but personal calamities have driven her back.

description: The detection of infectious salmon anemia, a lethal virus, in two juvenile wild sockeye salmon in British Columbia has reinvigorated a long-running debate about the sustainability of the aquaculture industry, particularly salmon farms.

title: Epic Game 6? You Bet

description: Rajat Gupta was rich by almost any standard. He just wasnt rich compared with many of the people who surrounded him. He knew it, and he didnt seem to like it.

description: NEW DELHI  Walking through the crowded, chaotic streets of Old Delhi, one is confronted with a thousand distractions  auto rickshaws, motorcylces and cars moving everywhere; fruit vendors, trinket sellers, and all manner of buildings and monuments.

title: Adele to Have Surgery on Vocal Cords
description: Adele, the British soul singer who has dominated the music charts in the United States and Britain all year with her album 21 (XL/Columbia), will undergo surgery to repair her vocal cords and has canceled her scheduled concerts for the rest of the year, Columbia Records announced.

title: Inside the List
description: ZOMBIES CROSSING: A week ago, all Colson Whitehead had to brag about was a bunch of well-reviewed books, a spot on various unofficial best-young-writer lists and 93,589 Twitter followers. Now, with Zone One, he has his first bona fide best seller. Whitehead has written books about an elevator inspector (The Intuitionist), a terminally ironic P.R. junketeer (John Henry Days) and, in 2009s Sag Harbor, someone who seemed an awful lot like a young Colson Whitehead. So why a novel about zombies, or rather  the Z word never appears in the book  about a depressed young man named Mark Spitz charged with clearing generally pathetic skels out of some of the most valuable real estate in postapocalyptic New York?

title: Cut From the Same Cloth
description: When he was younger, and poorer, Jonathan Becker, the photographer whose wonderful portraits have appeared in Vanity Fair for three decades, had his suits custom made by an English tailor in Argentina who charged him about $60. While working on a book in London about 12 years ago, he decided to have them made at Anderson & Sheppard, the Savile Row tailor, on the recommendation of Graydon Carter and Fran Lebowitz.

description: William C. Rhoden discusses Game Six of the World Series.

When applied correctly, the sparkly stuff can impart a bright, youthful energy to any look, without being juvenile. Here, the Dior celebrity makeup artist Ricky Wilson explains how.

The leader of a Tea Party group has called on Mrs. Bachmann, the founder of the Tea Party Caucus in Congress, to quit the presidential race because every day the campaign flounders, it risks hurting the credibility of the movement.

The six-week-old movement has several Web sites to promote various perspectives. But just who are these protesters? What is their political ideology? Do they have jobs?

description: WASHINGTON  Representative Tim Griffin, a Republican freshman from Arkansas with a university in his district, supports legislation that would make it easier for foreign math and science professionals to get legal residency.

description: Winning is the point, of course, but there is no shame in finishing second in a Breeders Cup race. Zenyattas whisker-thin loss to Blame in last years Classic certainly is a case in point. It did nothing to diminish significantly her stature as a champion and her eventual designation as Horse of the Year.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Fans of Burgundy wines have two events to choose from on Friday. The first is a six-course dinner featuring Burgundy wines, bourbons and game to benefit the Days of Taste program of the American Institute of Wine and Food, which works to improve childrens food, at 6:30 p.m. at Beacon, 25 West 56th Street (Avenue of the Americas). Tickets are $100 for members of the institute and $125 for the general public. For a taste of nearly a dozen different wines from the Burgundy region, sign up for a 7 p.m. tasting class at the Institute of Culinary Education, 50 West 23rd Street (between Fifth and Sixth Avenues), in Chelsea, (212) 847-0700. Bernard Sun, corporate beverage director of the Jean-Georges Vongerichtens restaurants, leads the class, which is $90 per person.

title: Occupy Wall Street Struggles to Make the 99% Look Like Everybody
description: Updated, Oct. 31 | Two weeks into Occupy Wall Streets takeover of Zuccotti Park, a group of Bronx community organizers and friends rode the subway down to Lower Manhattan to check out a movement they supported in principle.

description: MADRID  Comments by former activists linked to ETA, the Basque separatist group, suggest that much work remains in order to translate ETAs recent pledge to end its violent struggle for independence into a full-fledged peace agreement with the next government in Madrid.

description: A slide show of images of the renovated theater.

title: Czar-Worthy Finery, Refurbished For a Modern Era
description: The Bolshoi Theater is filled with as much drama as any of the great operas and ballets that have graced its stage. The Bolshoi company originated in Moscow in 1776 for masquerades during the reign of Catherine the Great. After an earlier home burned down, the current theater opened on the same site in 1825 as the Imperial Bolshoi Theater of Moscow.

title: Another Scandal Unsettles Corporate Japan as Paper Maker Accuses Ex-Chairman
description: TOKYO  It is the second wild boardroom drama to shake up corporate Japan in days: the countrys leading tissue maker, Daio Paper, said on Friday that it would file a criminal complaint against its former chairman, accusing him of illicitly borrowing $140 million in company money and channeling some of it to a Las Vegas casino company.

title: On Our Radar: Flooding in Bangkok
description: Runoff equivalent to 480,000 Olympic-size pools is pushing its way south through Bangkok. The high tide on Saturday will put extreme pressure on Bangkoks elaborate system of dikes and other flood defenses. [CNN]

description: A selection of breakthrough performances from the holiday season.

title: At Lever House, Public Is Always Welcome. Except This Sunday.
description: Any day is a fine day for visiting the garden courtyard of Lever House at 390 Park Avenue, that midcentury Modernist Mad Men masterpiece that was beautifully rejuvenated a decade ago. Any day, that is, but one.

title: British Monarchy Scraps Rule of Male Succession in New Step to Modernization
description: LONDON  The 16 countries that recognize the British monarch as head of state struck a historic blow for womens rights on Friday, abolishing male precedence in the order of succession to the throne. But the possibility of a Catholic monarch will have to wait, nearly 500 years after Henry VIII broke with Rome.

title: A Bouquet of Offerings to Test Uncertain Waters
description: DESPITE the overstuffed catalogs and upbeat marketing campaigns, its been a nerve-racking six months in the auction world. With all the uncertainty surrounding the financial markets, putting together the important November auctions has been a challenge for Sothebys, Christies and, to a lesser extent, Phillips de Pury. Those considering selling are wondering if the assets on their walls are safer there than the stocks in their portfolio. And collectors sitting on cash and eager to buy are asking themselves, At what price?

title: Offerings To Test Uncertain Waters
description: The fall auction season features a conservative mix of works by tried-and-true artists.

title: Another View: A Simpler Rein Than the Volcker Rule
description: Claire A. Hill and Richard W. Painter are professors of corporate law at the University of Minnesota Law School.

description: Images from Tarsem Singhs action adventure film.

title: Its Gods vs. Mortals, and It Isnt Pretty
description: THE gods may not be crazy, but they can certainly get a little angry. Some of their fury is on display when their turf is threatened in the film Immortals, a new interpretation of Greek mythology that blends dramatic landscapes with aggressive action, all in 3-D.

title: As Casino Opens Its Doors, Pent-Up Demand Is Released
description: Shortly after 1 p.m., when the doors of New York Citys first casino, next to the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, opened to the public, Kim Franklin, 45, from East New York, Brooklyn, brushed past a security guard, extended both arms to ensure that no one behind her in line could pass and broke into a jog as she approached the escalators.

title: Trick or Treat, Wall Street Style
description: This weekend, thousands of Americans will cobble together Wall Street-themed costumes in preparation for Halloween. (Pre-emptive note: dressing in a suit and tie and labeling yourself The One Percent is not as clever as you think.)

title: Photo Replay: Oct.28
description: The Pan American Games continued in Mexico and many of the worlds best snowboarders and freestyle skiers performed in London.

title: Accused Picasso Thief Pleads Guilty
description: Mark Lugo, the Hoboken, N.J., man who was charged this summer with stealing a Picasso drawing from a San Francisco art gallery  and whose lawyer said at the time that he planned to plead not guilty  has now pleaded guilty to grand theft, the BBC reported.

title: November Release Schedule
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: Protests Turn Violent in Tunisian Town That Sparked the Arab Spring
description: In Sidi Bouzid, the Tunisian town seen as the birthplace of the Arab Spring, crowds of angry protesters on Friday burned a government building, a day after video emerged of men ransacking the local office of Ennahda, the moderate Islamist party that won a plurality of seats in this weeks parliamentary elections.

title: 1894 Roper Motorbike Aims at World Auction Record
description: Its not the first-ever American motorcycle. That distinction belongs to its older brother, the original 1869 Roper steam velocipede residing in the Smithsonian Institution. But it may earn a superlative all its own.

title: St. Louis Brewers Think Small
description: IN the late 1800s, St. Louisans flocked to brewery gardens to drink, play and socialize. Most were immigrants accustomed to beer as part of daily life, as vital as bread. Out of this enthusiasm arose Anheuser-Busch, perhaps the best-known large-scale brewery in the country. No matter its size, locals have remained loyal to the hometown company.

title: Letters: Tales From the Safari
description: To the Editor: Regarding For Now, Its a Cheaper Safari (Practical Traveler, Oct. 23), my self-drive safari to Namibia in November 2008 was an incredible experience. We arranged lodging but drove ourselves. We found our experience to be less crowded and also less expensive than a standard safari trip. ELIZABETH McCOURT

title: Hotel Review: Tune Hotel in London
description: THE UPSHOT

title: A Gothic Tour of Italy
description: VISITORS to Italy tend to seek its sunny, Dionysian side  vino, pasta, opera, cinquecento art, George Clooney on a Vespa. But, like a chilly draft on a hot day, Italys gothic angle offers intimations of darkness that make a moment on the piazza even more delicious. Consciously or not, anyone sipping prosecco at sunset in Rome or Naples savors an extra spoon of dolce in their vita thanks to the contrast between the beauty of the present and the proximity of catacombs, ruins and sites of ancient suffering.

title: Frank Lloyd Wrights Wisconsin
description: WHEN I told my friends that I was planning a family vacation in Wisconsin, I received either blank stares or teasing comments about the admittedly unsexy specialties for which the state is known. There was mention of cows and cornfields and cheese curds. Yet Wisconsin is also Frank Lloyd Wright country, the place where he was born and reared and to which he kept returning. To travel there is to marvel at the contrast between the calm landscape and the delirious inventiveness of his work.

title: In Anhui, China, Centuries-Old Charm
description: JUST 250 or so miles to the west of the gleaming high-rises of Shanghai sits a window into a world hundreds of years old. Despite the dramatic upheavals brought by war, the Cultural Revolution and industrialization, the hamlet of Xidi, in the mountainous province of Anhui, along with other villages in the area, has managed to remain largely untouched since the late Ming and early Qing dynasties, starting hundreds of years ago. Wander the narrow, labyrinthine lanes and peek into the open-air courtyards of grandiose homes, with their wooden lattice windows, rock gardens, watercolors and calligraphy scrolls, and it can feel as if you are slipping back in time to the days of the Chinese emperors.

title: Harlem of South Revived in Richmond, Va.
description: In Jackson Ward, new galleries and shops recall the heyday of an earlier era.

title: Chinas Anhui Province
description: As more and more Chinese move to cities, the small villages of Anhui west of Shanghai offer a respite.

title: On Frank Lloyd Wrights Trail in Wisconsin
description: In Wisconsin, marvel at the inventiveness of the architects work.

title: Exploring Italys Macabre Past
description: Italys gothic angle offers intimations of darkness that make a moment on the piazza even more delicious.

title: Leading Actresses to Bow Out of Spider-Man in November
description: The two lead actresses in the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, who muddled through months of backstage drama and script changes last winter, will leave the show in November when their contracts expire, the producers said on Friday.

title: Greek Anger on Debt Agreement Is Focused Especially on Germany
description: ATHENS  Every Oct. 28 Greece celebrates Oxi Day, or No Day, a national holiday commemorating Greek resistance to the Axis powers during World War II. On Friday, those celebrations took on a greater weight. As Greeks suffer from harsh austerity measures, there is growing popular sentiment here that the country has ceded key parts of its sovereignty, and its pride, to its foreign lenders.

title: December/January Release Schedule
description: DEC.

title: A Riveting Glimpse of a Vanished Bird
description: Two feet tall, the imperial woodpecker of Mexico once reigned as the largest woodpecker in the world. But aggressive logging and even poisoning by the lumber companies in its Sierra Madre habitat is thought to have driven the bird into extinction sometime in the mid-20th century.

title: Lotsa Links
description: Great graphic about menhaden (bunker) from the Pew Environmental Group. Really gets the message across: stop overfishing!

title: London Underground | Animal Estates, London Edition
description: Designers are used to designing for people, but what if the client was an animal? Im not talking about designing a kennel for your dog, but rather homes for all the animals that are native to our cities, yet which are often forgotten. Can the birds and the bees, the kestrels and the beetles, all be accommodated in the concrete jungle? This is what the artist Fritz Haeg is encouraging us to think about at the Animal Estates London HQ: Urban Wildlife Client Services.

title: The History of the World in 100 Objects
description: A group of curators aimed to tell the history of the world through 100 objects culled from the British Museums collections.

title: Toys R Us Gets Nostalgic for Christmas
description: Each Christmas shopping season, toymakers and retailers like to bring back vintage playthings, the better to appeal to parents  and grandparents  whose nostalgia for their own childhoods informs their buying decisions. For Christmas 2011, Toys R Us is bringing back vintage advertising.

title: Stuff That Defines Us
description: London

title: C K Swett Shakes Up Auctioneering
description: C K Swett has emerged as one of the most prominent celebrity auctioneers on New Yorks busy charity circuit.

title: CW Network in Deal to Put Shows on Hulu
description: The CW Network is on a digital licensing tear. On Friday, the network, jointly owned by CBS Corporation and Warner Brothers Entertainment, announced a five-year deal to put CW shows on the Internet streaming service Hulu.

title: Brown Still Longs to Coach in N.B.A.
description: Like a moth toa flame, Larry Brown cant seem to stay away from basketball. Brown, 71, last coached the Charlotte Bobcats, who either resigned or was fired, depending on the story, last season.

title: Vertex Bests Merck in New Hepatitis C Drug Sales
description: Updated: 4:45 p.m. In the closely watched bout between two new hepatitis C drugs, its a knockout in the first round.

title: Liu Hires Ex-Attorney General to Review His Campaign Finances
description: Facing pressure to explain apparent irregularities with his campaign fund-raising practices, John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, said Friday that he had hired a former state attorney general to review his books.

title: Favorites of the Season, Cherished All Year
description: The Nightmare Before Christmas (1993)

title: Parm, the Torrisi Spinoff, Opens in Days
description: This offshoot of Torrisi Italian Specialties, opening on Nov. 7, taps the same Italian-American vein as the parent restaurant, but in a more familiar way. The new place, done with cute retro wallpaper, will serve chicken francese, baked ziti, garlic bread, an Italian Thanksgiving turkey dinner and sandwiches or platters of eggplant parm and meatball parm, refined in the hands of the chef-partners, Mario Carbone and Rich Torrisi. It will have a small takeout counter in the front, seats at the bar (a full bar this time), and tables for 30 in back.

title: On Gawa, Swiftlets, Parasites and Limestone
description: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

title: A Reality Check on Ambitious Climate Targets
description: An interesting commentary published in Nature this week explores what it would take to achieve Californias ambitious plan to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases 80 percent below 1990 levels by 2050. It is worth exploring here because it holds lessons that apply far beyond that state.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Happy Halloween
description: Our paperback list has the perfect book for this trick-or-treating season. Batman: The Long Halloween, at No. 9, is a new edition of one of Batmans greatest adventures, with extra pages previously available only in a hardcover version. The story, written by Jeph Loeb and illustrated by Tim Sale, is set in the early days of Batmans career. Gotham City is overrun with mobsters, and the colorful freaks that make up the heros rogues gallery are just starting to emerge. The mystery, originally told over 13 issues, centers around a murderer named Holiday, who strikes on a special day each month  whether its Christmas, Mothers Day or Independence Day. He does not get a lot of panel time, but one of the creepiest moments comes from Calendar Man, who is housed in Arkham Asylum and does not enjoy the fact that another villain is stealing his motif of date-based crimes.

title: Before Twitter, Name-Dropping Self-Promotion
description: IN 1801 a composer and cellist named Andreas Romberg decided to dedicate a set of string quartets to Haydn. This dedication will surely not be unappreciated by you, Romberg wrote excitedly to his publisher, as it will doubtless promote the sale of the work. Now tell me if we dont understand our public  or rather, the world!

title: Many Points of Entry to Music
description: LEON KIRCHNER, who died at 90 in 2009, was best known as a searching, formidable and vividly intuitive composer. But he was as complete a musician as America produced in the mid-20th-century: an excellent pianist, a probing conductor and a revered (if intimidating) teacher at Harvard. Students like Yo-Yo Ma and Alan Gilbert passed through his legendary seminar in the analysis and performance of chamber music.

title: MF Global Put Up for Sale, This Weekend Only
description: 8:13 p.m. | Updated

title: The Shoe Leather Never Wears Thin At This Cop Shop
description: IF ever a television series captured the gritty essence of police work, it wasnt Dragnet, with its just-the-facts dispassion, or Hill Street Blues, with its urban blight, or any version of Law & Order, with its gruesome crimes.

title: The Puppets Take Manhattan
description: Occupy Wall Street prepares giant puppets for the Halloween parade.

title: Gunman Fires at U.S. Embassy in Sarajevo
description: A gunman identified by Bosnian news reports as a radical Islamist fired an automatic rifle at the American Embassy in downtown Sarajevo on Friday, wounding a guard and paralyzing the city during the afternoon rush hour before a police SWAT team wounded and arrested him.

title: A Playful Occupy Halloween Trots Out the Puppets
description: As its grown, Occupy Wall Street has spawned many splinter groups  from Occupy Education to Occupy Museums. This week another, perhaps more playful, faction emerged: Occupy Halloween  because the top 1% shouldnt get all the candy, as its slogan goes. A few days before Halloween, in a rented studio in Brooklyns Dumbo neighborhood, volunteers were busy assembling costumes and puppets for the Village Halloween parade, and for several pop-up events to take place around the city on Monday.

title: Beninese Yelps, Norwegian Tongue Clacks
description: El Rego et Ses Commandos

title: Pounding the Pavement, Beyond Manhattan
description: NEW YORKERS have been fleeing Manhattan in search of more affordable housing for so long that just about every neighborhood in the other boroughs has been anointed the citys next great destination for bargains.

title: The Best Investing Advice? Maybe Not the Conventional Method
description: WITH the stock market so volatile lately, investors have been asking how to ride out the swoons and maybe even outperform the major indexes. The answers  at least according to an analysis by one firm  do not necessarily conform to accepted wisdom.

title: On Debates, Put Perry Down as a Maybe
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Will he or wont he? Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who suggested this week that it might have been a mistake to attend all the Republican debates and that he might not participate in some coming ones, now says he could be open to attending more.

title: Fresh Face and a New Identity
description: The Chrysler 200, in both its convertible and sedan forms, represents a significant step forward from its predecessor, the Sebring. But thats not saying much.

title: A White Halloween? You Might Not Be Dreaming
description: Either the calendar seems wrong or the forecast, but no, it really is true: snow is expected to fall on New York City on Saturday, and  at least for a while  stick.

title: New DVDs to Warm Your Toes By
description: Winnie the Pooh (2011)

description: Photographs from Libya, Thailand, Turkey and Sri Lanka.

title: Coming Soon
description: Images from some of the films coming this holiday season.

title: In California, a Final Exam for Heavy-Duty Hybrids
description: Hybrid technology is working its way off road, and two heavy-duty earth movers, a bulldozer and tracked excavator, are preparing for large-scale emissions tests in California.

title: Labour Party Leader Set to Win Irelands Presidential Election
description: DUBLIN  Michael D. Higgins, a veteran politician and author, was on course Friday to score a come-from-behind win in the race for president of the Irish Republic as his main rivals conceded defeat before the final tallies were counted.

title: TimesCast | October 28, 2011
description: Greeks celebrate sovereignty, while questioning their dependence; Rick Perry may skip some debates; and Britain takes steps to modernize the monarchy.

title: Cardinals Comeback Fuels Fox Victory
description: On Thursday, at least in terms of television ratings, the World Series was the only game in town. Fox easily won the night in all categories thanks to the St. Louis Cardinals remarkable extra-inning comeback 10-9 victory over the Texas Rangers in Game 6. CBS came in second despite seeing drops across the board, with The Big Bang Theory leading all other scripted programs at 14.3 million total viewers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Thailand, Turkey and Sri Lanka.

title: A Different Sort of Investment Strategy
description: In this weeks Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about an analysis of over two decades of data on the performance of some 300 mutual funds. The idea was to determine which funds outperformed a benchmark  in this case, the Vanguard S.&P. 500 Index Fund  over that time.

title: Books Unbound
description: Is any form of traditional media under more assault than the book? For half a millennium, it was happily contained between covers: easily understood by a child, disposable, nearly indestructible, demanding minimal energy, a triumph of economy and form. The Internet has upended all that, of course. Yet the strongest impression from several of the sessions at the Books in Browsers conference in San Francisco over the last two days is that while the off-line book might be dying, the online book has yet to be born.

title: China Has Homemade Supercomputer Gain
description: China has made its first supercomputer based on Chinese microprocessor chips, an advance that surprised high-performance computing specialists in the United States.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: DealBook, a well-known early riser, fell asleep before the seventh inning Thursday night, so we know how it feels to miss out on exciting developments.1 If youre the type who worries about missing the latest deal talk, take a quick look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Touch of Evil: Eli Roth Recreates Infamous Experiment for Discovery Channel
description: The horror filmmaker Eli Roths gory Hostel helped to define a subgenre often referred to as torture porn. As an actor in the World War II revenge fantasy Inglourious Basterds, he played a vigilante soldier who beat Nazis to death with a baseball bat.

title: From Not So Good to Not So Bad
description: TESTED 2011 Chrysler 200 Limited

title: Released From Rehab, but Still a Bit Unsteady
description: AS Chrysler has tried to rescue its aged product lineup from the ravages of cost-cutting, bankruptcy and general neglect, some models have needed more radical surgery than others. The deficiencies of the Sebring convertible, for instance, were so encompassing that its upgrades included a new name. Say hello to the 200 convertible.

title: Cardinals Wont Have Holliday for Game 7
description: ST. LOUIS  Not only is Matt Holliday not starting Game 7 for the Cardinals on Friday night, hes off the World Series roster entirely after severely bruising his right pinky finger in Game 6. Adron Chambers replaces him on the roster, while Lance Berkman  fresh off his three-hit, three-R.B.I. night with four runs scored  will bat cleanup again Thursday night.

title: A Family of Italian Twins That Took a Different Approach
description: ASK a well-informed rider to name the venerable motorcycle maker whose gutsy air-cooled V-twins are a longstanding source of national pride and you might get this surprising, but correct, answer: Moto Guzzi.

title: A Greek Politician Who Pushed Back Against Perks
description: ATHENS

title: To Ban or Not to Ban Cellphones? Mixed Signals
Tempers Flare at Birthplace of Arab Spring After Some Tunisian Votes Are Nullified
description: Protesters angered by a local outcome in Tunisias first free election burned a central government building on Friday in the impoverished town of Sidi Bouzid, which is widely regarded as the birthplace of the Arab Spring.

title: TimesCast | Greeks Question Debt Deal
description: October 28, 2011 - Greeks celebrate their sovereignty, while questioning their dependence on Europe for a financial bailout.

title: Book Review Podcast: Frank Rich Discusses the Career of Pauline Kael
description: In Sundays Book Review, Frank Rich reviews two books that chronicle the life and career of the contentious film critic Pauline Kael: Pauline Kael: A Life in the Dark by Brian Kellow and The Age of Movies: Selected Writings of Pauline Kael, edited by Sanford Schwartz.

title: Another Flap Over an Alleged Romney Flip
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Just days after Mitt Romney came under attack for seeming to waver on antiunion rules in Ohio, the former governor of Massachusetts drew scrutiny yet again for alleged shape-shifting. The issue of the moment? Climate change.

title: Reassessing the Year Punk Broke
description: Remembering the year punk broke.

title: Sonic Tattoos, Gingerly Reconsidered
description: IN 1991, the year Nirvanas breakthrough album Nevermind (DGC) was released, the artist Andrew Kuo was a 13-year-old alternative rock superfanof bands like Nirvana,Fugazi and Dinosaur Jr.A year later he became obsessed with the film 1991: The Year Punk Broke, which documented Sonic Youths 1991 tour of Europe and features backstage antics fromthe likes of Thurston Moore andKim Gordon of Sonic Youth,Kurt Cobain and Dave Grohl of Nirvana,and Courtney Love.

title: Staging, Ever More Virtual
description: FOR the longest time, if brokers wanted to stage an apartment to sell, they needed to buy or rent furnishings, wall covering, carpets and other interior decorations. Then, a few years ago, advances in computer rendering gave them a simple and cheap way to hire a virtual staging company to render those items into a photograph of an empty room.

title: Five-Ku: Halloween Horror-Flick Haikus
description: First rule: When in aSlasher film, teens, dont sign upFor camp called Camp Blood.

title: Old World in a Big City
description: When Mary Theresa McCombe was growing up in Crestwood, a tidy 415-acre pocket of well-tended colonials, Tudors and Victorian single-family homes in a leafy neighborhood just west of the Bronx River in Yonkers, she often tarried on her way to and from school to admire one particularly stately Tudor perched on a double lot.

title: Customs Tuned to the Times
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Aftermarket Fluctuations
description: The Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show may lack the glitz of the boom years, but its still the place to search for the auto industrys next big thing.

title: Whats in Store | Carhartt Work in Progress

title: Selling Pieces of Law Firms to Investors
description: Imagine an afternoon trip to a Wal-Mart: You pick up socks, a flat-screen television and a microwave meal. After checking out, you stop in the photo studio at the front of the store for a family portrait, and then shift one booth over to a lawyer, who drafts your will or real estate contract.

title: Thrilling Series Game Scores a Ratings Victory
description: One of the most memorable World Series games ever played lifted baseballs biggest attraction to a dominant ratings victory on Thursday night, the first time this match-up was able to crush (almost) all comers.

title: Nelson Schwartz on the European financial crisis, Gretchen Morgenson on the foreclosure talks, Jim Collins and David Gillen on luck and business, and Christina Romer on Ben Bernankes chance for a Volcker moment.
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Nelson Schwartz on the European financial crisis, Gretchen Morgenson on the foreclosure talks, Jim Collins and David Gillen on luck and business, and Christina Romer on Ben Bernankes chance for a Volcker moment.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 28
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the opening of the first casino in New York City, a record-breaking gift for the High Line, and haunted tours through the State Capitol.

title: Dead Sea Scrolls in Times Square
description: The history surrounding the Dead Sea Scrolls is the subject of an understated new exhibition at Discovery Times Square.

title: 500 Words About the Common Application
description: A look at how we transformed an article about the Common Application to match the word limit that students face when composing their personal statements.

title: A Young Bassist, a Young Pianist, Two Sets: So Similar, and Yet So Different
description: Derrick Hodge, a 32-year-old bassist, and Aaron Parks, a 28-year-old pianist, share a wide-open view of music making, an agenda of unfolding possibility. They both come out of jazz and still basically belong to it, though their output reflects whole-body immersion in R&B, gospel and hip-hop (Mr. Hodge); classically tempered indie rock (Mr. Parks); and atmospheric film music (both). For a handful of years they both worked in a band led by the trumpeter Terence Blanchard, an important mentor for dozens of musicians their age. But their aesthetic differences were what stood out at 92YTriBeCa on Wednesday night as each led his own band.

title: Elastic Experimentalists With a Sense of Rhythm
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  During the making of FAR, the choreographer Wayne McGregor was surrounded by eight cameras and multiple cognitive scientists. As with previous works, Mr. McGregor invited scientists into his process and let them analyze his copious notebooks.

title: Continuing to Play With the Tension Between Formality and Wildness
description: Two rows of delicate filament light bulbs encased in glass globes lined the entryways Thursday night at the Kitchen. They called to mind the lights in the Metropolitan Opera House that rise to signal a shows imminent start.

title: A Thai Restaurant Standby Comes Home
description: A FAVORITE offering in Thai restaurants, usually as an appetizer, is tod mun, little fried fish cakes scented with kaffir lime leaf. These spicy fish cakes are good any time of year and make a fine snack with drinks, served with a little dipping sauce.

title: N.B.A. Talks Stall and More Games Are Canceled
description: Talks sputtered, games disappeared and frustrations simmered anew Friday afternoon when N.B.A. owners and players moved to the precipice of a deal, then squandered the moment. Any hope for a full season died when the negotiations did.

title: The Scrolls as a Start, Not an End
description: Dont expect to see the glittering marvels of King Tuts tomb. Few artifacts at the provocative new exhibition at Discovery Times Square The Dead Sea Scrolls: Life and Faith in Biblical Times  will inspire aesthetic wonder. Pottery, silver coins, iron arrowheads, limestone pitchers, scraps of parchment  such are the seemingly mundane yields of many archaeological excavations, and they are prevalent here as well.

title: Kaffir Lime and Other Citrus Pleasures
description: What would we do without citrus fruits? Our cooking would be dull without them. But unless we live in temperate climates, for the most part we depend on their availability to be shipped from citrus-growing zones. So much for locavore leanings: sometimes we just need stuff from elsewhere. We need to be able to add a big squeeze of lime, or the grated zest of lemon or orange, to so many dishes, sweet or savory.

title: Chic in Review | Thumbs Up for the Biebers Up Do
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Good Divorce
description: I NEVER wanted to get divorced. My parents split had been like an antipersonnel bomb, ripping everyone to pieces. So for 16 years, I stayed married.

title: The Past Brought Into the Light: Breaking Down a U2 Breakthrough, Chord by Chord
description: Artists windy chatter about their creative angst rarely makes interesting listening for anyone but hard-core fans, and theres a fair amount of it in From the Sky Down, a documentary by Davis Guggenheim about U2. But the film, showing Saturday night on Showtime, has a few segments that get beyond platitudes.

title: Colombian-Style Chicken, Short Rib and Potato Stew
description: Adapted from Ana Jovancicevic

title: From Colombia, the Ultimate One-Pot Meal
description: LAST spring, I had an elaborate Colombian dish called ajiaco at my friend Anas dinner party.

title: Bargain Hunters, Hold That Click
description: ON Gilt.com, where shoppers vie for limited-time discounts on designer brands, a Kate Spade cabana-stripe medium tote bag was recently $169, plus $5.95 shipping. That same day, the bag was on KateSpade.com for $130 with free shipping  about $45 cheaper.

title: And About That Corn
description: Corn season is waning, so if you cant find decent ears of corn to make the Colombian chicken, short rib, and potato stew featured in A Good Appetite, feel free to substitute frozen corn. Ive seen it sold on the cob in large supermarkets, and that is ideal here. But if you can find only kernels, just use about a cup of them in place of the cobs, stirring them in during the last few minutes of cooking. Also something to note: The corn used in Colombia, Ive read, has larger kernels and is less sweet than what we typically get. But the sweet corn tastes wonderful, authenticity aside.

title: One Wheel in the Future, One in the Past
description: Moto Guzzis current array of niche motorcycles are a throwback to the Italian makers rich history.

title: Herman Cain Stumps in  Alabama
description: HOMEWOOD, Ala.  Herman Cain steered his unconventional presidential campaign on Friday to Alabama, where he submitted paperwork to appear on the ballot in the March 13 primary  a date deep into the race when all but the strongest candidates presumably will have fallen out.

title: The Debate Over Routine Mammograms
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviewing the Chrysler 200 Convertible
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett reviews the 2011 Chrysler 200 convertible, a car that shares a nameplate but no body panels with its sedan sibling, reviewed by John Pearley Huffman.

title: A Young Auctioneer Breaks Into the Gavel Clique
description: IN a dressing room at Cipriani 42nd Street on a weekday evening not long ago, a young floppy-haired auctioneer named C K Swett was circling the room, reciting a nearly unintelligible stream of words to himself. Hey well all right sir here we go there and what are ya gonna give for em, I have a 600 dollar down here now 10 and now 25 and now 35 and now there 50 now 60 will ya give me 60 now 75, 75 another 85 dollars another buy em there, he said in a jumbled patter, barely pausing for breath.

title: Analyzing Steve Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Anne Bonney and Joseph Kearns Goodwin
description: VICTORIA BONNEY was enduring a forgettable date in September 2009 when a close friend texted her, foretelling her fate.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 42
description: With snow in the forecast and Zuccotti Park newly bereft of gas generators protesters are stocking up on Mylar sleeping bags and bike generators. [City Room, Dawn Hoag via Twitter, Young Manhattanite]

title: Leaving Bach in the Past, a Violinist Turns to Schumann, Franck and Bartok
description: With so much unaccompanied violin music of Bach on New York stages in recent days  Gidon Kremer played the Chaconne last Saturday and Jennifer Koh the six sonatas and partitas on Sunday  Christian Tetzlaff might have felt like the odd man out at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening. Mr. Tetzlaff devoted his recital to sonatas by Schumann, Franck and Bartok. But when it comes to Bach, he has been there and done that: two years ago he played all the unaccompanied violin works in a stunning marathon recital at the 92nd Street Y.

title: Transcript of Red Bulls Conference Call
description: The Red Bulls decided not to hold a training session Friday, but will be training in Saturdays predicted winter storm before playing the Los Angeles Galaxy in the first game of a home-and-home M.L.S. playoff series Sunday at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J.

title: Sitting on the High Line, Watching the Actors Go By
description: Last Sunday evening in Chelsea, a man robed like an Arab sheik crossed 10th Avenue while gently swinging a blue suitcase. On the opposite corner stood another man who appeared to be a Hasidic Jew, ringlets dangling under his black hat. Just as they were inches apart, the suitcase popped open  and out poured packets of condoms by the dozen. The two scrambled to scoop them up, with the help of passers-by who were plainly stifling laughter.

title: Undocumented Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: This Sunday: Excuse Me While I Get Fitted for a Hazmat Suit
description: If you look at our cover this week and think maybe you have enough worries in your life without adding anthrax back to the list, I completely understand. I feel that way myself sometimes. But I urge you to at least read the first section of Wil Hyltons story about the state of bioterrorism preparedness  its only 400 words  and Ill be surprised if you dont feel compelled to keep going. Yes, youll be a little freaked. Maybe a lot freaked. But Wils reporting isnt just about the nightmarish scenarios that could befall us. Its about what exactly the U.S. government has been up to since the anthrax attacks in the wake of 9/11, and the shocking extent to which we have wasted precious time and billions of dollars on poorly defined policy objectives and bureaucratic logjams. This is not merely bad news. This an expos that ought to inspire a rethinking of the entire program.

title: From Sneakers to Point Shoes, a Parade of Styles and Movement
description: At every performance of the annual Fall for Dance Festival at City Center the atmosphere is terrific. The theaters crowded, anticipations high, and the stylistic diversity of each program is marvelous. On Thursday, at this years first performance, many of us were also discovering happily just how many features of the recently reopened theater have been altered and refreshed. What remains is the immediacy of rapport between stage and auditorium: City Center remains an exciting dance house.

title: Officials at St. Pauls Cathedral in London Move to Evict Protesters Camped Outside
description: LONDON  Officials at St. Pauls Cathedral said Friday that they would go to court to force the removal of hundreds of protesters who have camped outside the cathedral for two weeks, demonstrating against economic inequality and corporate greed.

title: Ackman Takes a Ride on the Canadian Pacific Railway
description: The billionaire hedge fund manager William A. Ackman has been working on the railroad  in particular, the Canadian Pacific Railway.

title: A 7-Year-Old With a Very Developed Sense of Self
description: A fundamental problem with the new Fox cartoon Allen Gregory  though not the biggest one  is that its never clear what the show is satirizing. The title character is nominally a privileged 7-year-old horrified at the prospect of attending a public elementary school, but hes drawn as a boutonniere-wearing dandy and talks like a supremely egotistical talent agent. Hes a little bit Stewie from Family Guy, a little bit Ari Gold from Entourage, a little bit Frasier and Niles Crane, a little bit Mr. Magoo.

title: Exercise in Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Tries to Lure Chinese Cash to Back Rescue of Euro
description: PARIS  A day after European leaders unveiled their latest plan to save the euro, top officials opened talks with China in an effort to lure tens of billions of dollars in additional cash, giving China perhaps its biggest opportunity yet to exercise financial clout in the Western world.

description: Indictments from among those handed down to 16 New York Police Department members over ticket fixing and other charges.

title: Officers Jeer at Arraignment of 16 Colleagues in Ticket-Fixing Investigation
description: A three-year investigation into the polices habit of fixing traffic and parking tickets in the Bronx ended in the unsealing of indictments on Friday and a stunning display of vitriol by hundreds of off-duty officers, who converged on the courthouse to applaud their accused colleagues and denounce their prosecution.

description: Live coverage and analysis of Game 7 of the World Series from Pat Borzi and other Times reporters and editors in St. Louis and beyond.

title: Theyre Not the Supremes, but They Know the Tunes
description: When you go to one of those shows that seem to exist only to be marketed to a certain age or ethnic group (like Menopause: The Musical or My Mothers Italian, My Fathers Jewish, & Im in Therapy!), your expectations may not be particularly high. But Dorothy Marcics Sistas: The Musical, now playing at St. Lukes Theater, is a sweet and sassy if slightly rickety little show.

title: After Waging a Seesaw Battle, France Wins the Senior Bowl
description: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands  At the world team championships here on Friday, France defeated U.S.A.-2 to win the dOrsi Senior Bowl by 165 international match points to 160.3. Third place went to Poland.

title: Cigarettes Are Enlisted to Test Ways of Quitting
description: When a truck recently delivered 45,000 cartons of cigarettes to a research company in North Carolina, it was a turning point in the governments war on smoking.

title: Groupon Weighs Raising I.P.O. Price
description: It appears investors are flocking to Groupons forthcoming initial public offering like customers to one of the daily deal giants coupons.

title: For Cain, Reverse Is a Prominent Gear
description: HOMEWOOD, Ala.  Ask Americans what they know about Herman Cain and, of course, there is his 9-9-9 tax plan, made memorable through constant repetition.

title: West Virginias Palace of Gold
description: Alfred, N.Y.

title: The Cain Enigma
description: Sometimes life resembles fiction. Other times it resembles Star Trek.

title: Little-Girl Time and Big-Boy Sports
description: David Kaplan is in the enviable position of running a museum that is not just thriving, but expanding by popular demand: the Childrens Museum for the Arts tripled in size when it moved to its new home on Charlton Street in SoHo on Oct. 1. Mr. Kaplan, 50, the museums executive director, lives in Chelsea with his wife, Elaine Lacognata, 40, a singer-songwriter; their daughter, Marae, 5; and an aquarium of tropical fish. He spends Sunday mornings roaming with Marae; in the afternoons, he blows off steam by boxing or playing basketball.  ROBIN FINN

title: Pattersons Response to His Appeal Dismissal, and Other Case Documents
description: Despite a recommendation by the Texas Board of Pardons and Parole that Kelsey Patterson be spared due to severe mentally illness, he was executed for a double murder in 2004.

title: College Football All  Day  Long
description: If youre at the game or on the couch and in need of real college football analysis or even some wisecracks  or have some of your own to share  Paul Myerberg and The Times Jer Longman will be live-blogging all day on Saturday. Join the party and impress your friends.

title: Bloggingheads: Tax the Poor!
description: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Rich Lowry of National Review debate raising taxes on the bottom half.

title: A Former Leader Returns With a Signature Piece
description: Kurt Masurs 11-year tenure as the New York Philharmonics music director was often turbulent. There were tensions between him and the players caused by differences in the ways that old-school European conductors and modern American orchestra players think about a music directors power and prerogatives. But when Mr. Masur left New York, in 2002, the Philharmonic sounded vastly better than it had when he took it over from Zubin Mehta, in 1991. And whatever grievances the players might have had in the 1990s, they respond well to him when he returns as a guest (with the title music director emeritus).

title: Students and Teachers Are Furious Over High School Scheduling Mess
Excerpt: 'Allen Gregory'
description: Jonah Hill stars as a 7-year-old sophisticate in the new Fox animated series.

title: What a Family Faces After a Murder: The Terrible Mechanics of the First Week
description: There is a house on 91st Avenue in Woodhaven, Queens, that, with Halloween approaching, has fake yellow crime-scene tape strung across its porch. It reads, in spooky script, Caution: Enter if you dare.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: Gifts Galore

title: Bill Cunningham | Tricked Out
description: Two weeks ago, more than 100,000 young people got an early start on Halloween at ComicCon at the Javits Center.

title: Yankees Extend Radio Contract With WCBS
description: ST. LOUIS  The Yankees extended their contract with the radio station WCBS 880 to broadcast their games through the 2012 season, meaning that the announcers John Sterling and Suzyn Waldman will most likely come back in their same roles.

title: What the Costumes Reveal
description: On Friday, the law firm of Steven J. Baum threw a Halloween party. The firm, which is located near Buffalo, is what is commonly referred to as a foreclosure mill firm, meaning it represents banks and mortgage servicers as they attempt to foreclose on homeowners and evict them from their homes. Steven J. Baum is, in fact, the largest such firm in New York; it represents virtually all the giant mortgage lenders, including Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Wells Fargo.

title: Bank of America Rethinking Debit Card Fee
description: After setting off a firestorm of criticism from consumers, Capitol Hill and the White House, Bank of America is rethinking elements of its plan to charge customers $5 a month to use their debit cards.

title: Set in Their Ways, but Still Very Flexible
description: DOMINIQUE MARTINET, 67, loves the noise surrounding her apartment in Manhattan, the roar of the buses, the conversations just begging to be overheard, the street-corner strains of music.

title: 40 Killed Across Syria in Deadliest Friday Demonstrations Since May
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces killed at least 40 people on Friday during antigovernment demonstrations across the country, according to human rights activists, as the government of President Bashar al-Assad intensified a brutal military crackdown that has failed over eight months to extinguish a popular uprising.

title: Are the Candidates in the Top 1 Percent?
description: All presidential candidates must fill out a form declaring their finances. The form asks how many assets and income sources the candidate has within certain ranges. Here are the ranges of each candidates declared assets and income compared with a threshold that represents whether they are within the top 1 percent of earners.

title: Car Bomb in Aden Kills Yemeni Counterterrorism Chief
description: TAIZ, Yemen  The head of counterterrorism in the southern port city of Aden was killed Friday after a car bomb exploded beneath his vehicle, according to a senior security official.

title: One Nation, Innumerate
description: Via Brian Beutler, Politico has part of George Wills forthcoming attack on Romney:

title: Mexico: 20 Killed in Shootouts
description: Twenty people were killed Friday in multiple shootouts in two states, law enforcement officials said. In Michoacn, 14 bodies were found in three different locations. Of these, 10 people died in the city of Ptzcuaro after a confrontation with soldiers patrolling the area. Michoacn has been beset by violence in recent years, much of it attributed to the Familia drug cartel, and recently the cartels turf war with a splinter group called the Knights Templar. In the state of Sinaloa, a confrontation between members of an organized crime gang on a highway left six people dead, three of them unarmed civilians.

title: Fresh Food and Vintage Movies
description: Monday nights can feel slow in New York, as many spots take a day of rest after the busy weekend. But at La Gazzetta, the lively trattoria on the ground floor of Villa Pacri in the meatpacking district on Gansevoort Street at Ninth Avenue, it is a different story. On Mondays, it draws a crowd of regulars from the neighborhood, couples on first dates and families, for Cinema Italiano, its weekly screenings of classics like To Kill a Mockingbird and The Godfather  a hipper dinner theater for the downtown set  and for a menu offering Italian snacks, pastas and entrees. Last week, as the original Casino Royale with Peter Sellers and David Niven played in the background, a couple from London on their way to Buffalo and Toronto mixed business and pleasure.

title: Seligs Not Worried About the Mets
description: ST. LOUIS  Commissioner Bud Selig said the Mets, who borrowed $25 million from Major League Baseball after last season, still had not paid back the loan. But Selig said he was not worried about getting the money back.

title: Italy: Emergency Declared in Flood Zones
description: The Italian government declared a state of emergency on Friday in areas struck by flooding and mud slides earlier this week, and allocated $92 million to assist residents there.
