Torrential rains and flash floods on Tuesday and Wednesday killed at least seven people and left hundreds homeless in coastal areas of Tuscany and Liguria, including villages of Cinque Terre, Unesco World Heritage sites. Rescue and clean-up efforts continued Friday, but were hampered by inaccessible roads and disrupted electricity, water and gas.

title: Savings Rate Is Dropping, and Experts Are Puzzled
description: When the recession began, Americans began to save more of their money, prompting predictions that their financial habits might be changing permanently.

title: Iceland Videos
description: The IMF now has videos of the whole thing posted.

title: Victories and Questions Pile Up for Paterno
description: Penn State is in the midst of what could be a memorable season. The Nittany Lions are atop the Big Ten standings. And Joe Paterno is on the verge of setting the record for coaching victories in Division I college football.

title: The Court and the Next President
description: The Republican presidential hopefuls have been saying alarming things about the federal courts.

title: Live From Moscow: Its Friday Night at the Bolshoi, Friday Morning in New York
description: The Russians take their gala concerts seriously. That, at least, seemed to be the case when the Bolshoi Theater celebrated its reopening in Moscow after a huge renovation, on Friday evening, with a program seen in a live HD broadcast at Big Cinemas Manhattan on the Upper East Side, on Friday morning.

title: Study Finds Slight Decline in Veterans Using Shelters
description: Homeless veterans are most likely to be middle-aged white men with a disability. Younger veterans are more than twice as likely to be homeless than nonveterans in the same age group. And California has the most homeless veterans of any state, accounting for about a quarter of the nations total.

title: Reads and Reactions
description: In this edition: a lot of Herman Cain and overly confident punditry, some crowded estimates and two more endorsed ideas about newspaper endorsements.

title: For Their Own Good
description: The case for vaccinating all preteens against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cancer keeps getting stronger. After a thorough review of the evidence, an influential federal advisory committee recommended that boys ages 11 and 12 should routinely be vaccinated against the human papillomavirus, or HPV, echoing a 2006 recommendation for vaccinating girls of that age.

title: Death Row in Pennsylvania
description: Pennsylvania ranks high among states that impose death sentences and low among those that carry them out: 208 men and women are on death row, but no one has been executed since 1999; only three people have been executed since the penalty was reinstated in 1976.

title: Friday Night Music
description: Still loving this album:

title: Not Just Another Wind Farm
description: At the center of a newly opened wind farm in central West Virginia is the largest battery installation attached to the power grid in the continental United States.

title: America, Renewed
description: On Friday, a brilliant morning sun piercing their eyes, 125 Americans-to-be got ready to take the citizenship oath on Liberty Island.

title: Despite Attention to Abuses, Disability Filings at the L.I.R.R. Remain High
description: More than half of the Long Island Rail Road workers who retired last year applied for federal disability benefits, a rate far higher than the national average, even as federal officials and prosecutors tried to stem a chronic pattern of abuse of the public benefits system by the railroads retirees.

title: In Florida Battle, Casino Cash vs. Disney Image
description: MIAMI  The battle for Floridas tourism soul has been joined.

title: Riveting Series Caps a Scintillating Season
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Batteries at a Wind Farm Help Control Output
description: ELKINS, W.Va.  Another wind farm opened on another windy ridge in West Virginia this week, 61 turbines stretched across 12 miles, generating up to 98 megawatts of electricity. But the novel element is a cluster of big steel boxes in the middle, the largest battery installation attached to the power grid in the continental United States.

title: Man Accused in 78 Newark Killings Goes on Trial
description: NEWARK  The boys worked for the handyman, but they were working him, too. They helped him with odd jobs around town, riding in the back of his green pickup with Evans and Son painted on the side. He paid them in small amounts of cash, or a sack of White Castle hamburgers, and sometimes, in marijuana.

title: Fixated on What He Fixes
description: Peter Guggenheim has worked so long at Stuart Electronics that his feet have worn holes through two layers of tile and an inch of plywood, down to the floorboards behind the counter.

title: Leader Picked for Review of U.S. Loans on Energy
description: WASHINGTON  The White House directed a well-known businessman on Friday to conduct an independent review of government loans to energy companies, as House Republicans announced they would consider subpoenaing records related to a 2009 loan to a California manufacturer of solar-energy equipment that is now bankrupt.

title: Were New Yorkers Always Seen as Fast-Talking and Rude?
description: Born This Way?

title: Lottery Numbers
Animation Gives an Edge to Streaming Services
description: One of the most popular options on Hulu, ranking alongside mainstream TV hits like Modern Family and Glee, is an animated series about an adolescent ninja and his pink-haired love interest battling a mysterious organization.

title: William A. Niskanen, a Blunt Libertarian Economist, Dies at 78
description: William A. Niskanen, an economist who was dismissed by the Ford Motor Company after bluntly opposing the companys embrace of trade protection, and who later served as a member of President Ronald Reagans Council of Economic Advisers, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 78.

title: Convert Straddles Worlds of Islam and Hip-Hop
description: He was a 15-year-old white kid with Dad a diagnosed schizophrenic, rapist and racial separatist and Mom fresh off her second divorce, Michael Muhammad Knight writes in his 2006 memoir, Blue-Eyed Devil: A Road Odyssey Through Islamic America. At home in Rochester, he listened to a lot of Public Enemy and read The Autobiography of Malcolm X and by 16 had a huge portrait of Ayatollah Khomeini on his bedroom wall.

title: Joy in Russia as a Symbol of the Arts Reopens
description: MOSCOW  The interior of the newly restored Bolshoi Theater was resplendent with sable and dcolletage and claret-colored damask on Friday, as Russias new aristocrats leaned out from their balconies with opera glasses, hoping for a glimpse into the czars box, where the president was sitting.

title: Nostalgia and Drama in Bucks Game 6 Call
description: When Joe Buck punctuated the Cardinals game-ending home run in Game 6 of the World Series on Thursday night with the same line his father, Jack, used to call Kirby Pucketts home run at the end of Game 6 of the 1991 World Series  We will see you tomorrow night  it seemed as if the moment had been scripted in broadcasting heaven.

title: Corrections: October 29
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Dark Days for a Team Adrift
description: Outside the stadium where the Miami Dolphins play, a bronze statue of Don Shula shows him being carried off the field on the shoulders of his players. It is a tribute to a team of a much different era, when the Dolphins had the N.F.L.s only perfect season and their defense was so good that it did not have to spend a week arguing about why it could not stop a goal-line run that everybody knew was coming.

title: In Romneys Backyard, Perry Highlights Abortion
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas came to what is essentially Mitt Romneys home turf Friday and attacked him during a dinner speech for his position on abortion.

title: Romney Fields Friendly Questions in New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Just hours before Gov. Rick Perry of Texas addressed a Republican dinner across town on Friday, Mitt Romney fielded questions from a largely friendly crowd here, offering up his opinion on matters as diverse as the price of gas and the Occupy Wall Street movement.

title: YouTube Plans to Make Big Bet on New Online Channels
description: YouTube, making an expensive bet on original content, is planning to create dozens of channels featuring comedians, sports stars, musicians and other entertainers, the company said on Friday.

title: Saturday: Producer of Shooting Stars
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Its one thing for someone to think that we are immature. Its another thing entirely for someone to say it in a crossword puzzle, and thats what Barry C. Silk seems to be doing. Not once but twice Mr. Silk admonishes us to ACT ONES AGE and that it would be nice if we GREW UP.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 8s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: What a Gentleman Wears to Receive an Award
description: When Wyatt Workman, the 8-year-old winner of an award for his work on ocean conservation (he raised nearly $4,000), was too bashful to come onstage at GQ magazines Gentlemens Ball, it was hand-delivered. The actor Josh Lucas leapt from the stage and presented it to the child, who was frozen in the audience on Wednesday night.

title: Americas Exploding Pipe Dream
description: We are slowly  and painfully  being forced to realize that we are no longer the America of our imaginations. Our greatness was not enshrined. Being a world leader is less about destiny than focused determination, and it is there that we have faltered.

title: Sports Medicine Said to Overuse M.R.I.s
description: Dr. James Andrews, a widely known sports medicine orthopedist in Gulf Breeze, Fla., wanted to test his suspicion that M.R.I.s, the scans given to almost every injured athlete or casual exerciser, might be a bit misleading. So he scanned the shoulders of 31 perfectly healthy professional baseball pitchers.

title: The $16 Muffin That Wasnt
description: WASHINGTON  The office of the Justice Department inspector general on Friday retracted its much publicized claim that the agency had spent $16 per breakfast muffin at a conference. And it expressed regret for the significant negative publicity for the department and for the hotel that hosted the meeting that resulted from the erroneous finding in a report last month.

title: Storing With Style
description: A neo-Gothic tower on Second Avenue houses an unusual storage system, still in use after more than 80 years.

title: Storing the Stuff of Dreams
description: IT sounds like something out of a dime novel, or maybe a Nicolas Cage film. Behind the mute facade of a largely windowless neo-Gothic tower lies an ingenious system of steel vaults traveling on rails. Within those armored containers, which have been in continuous use since the Jazz Age, are stored some of New York Citys most precious objects and, presumably, a good number of its darkest secrets.

title: Berkman Hits in Clutch, and at the Microphone
description: ST. LOUIS  Lance Berkman entered the news conference room at Busch Stadium first, about half an hour after one of the most memorable games in World Series history. Berkman took two questions before David Freese, the No. 1 star of the night, bounced in and took a seat next to him on the platform.

title: For a Gallery at the Edge, Fame Is Born Tuesday
description: MARNI Kotak would not give birth in just any art gallery.

title: Waiting to Play, and to Redeem His Name
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Giants completed their dramatic victory over the Buffalo Bills this month, Jimmy Kennedy watched on television, pumping his fist while churning his legs on an elliptical machine at a gym near Denver.

title: Presidential Candidates? Few Are the 99 Percent
description: Occupy Wall Street protesters have touched a nerve with their slogan, We are the 99 percent. It has focused attention on the ground gained by the rich even as a brutal economy has pushed the typical American family backward. Economic inequality may or may not become a central issue in the presidential race, but the candidates have at least one reason to hope it does not.

title: Bringing the Torah to Life on Painted Nails
description: HARTSDALE, N.Y.

title: Western Companies See Prospects for Business in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  The guns in Libya have barely quieted, and NATOs military assistance to the rebellion that toppled Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi will not end officially until Monday. But a new invasion force is already plotting its own landing on the shores of Tripoli.

title: Underdog Turns Heads at the Top in Spain
description: VALENCIA, Spain The team is known as Levante UD and since 1939 it has spent only 10 percent of its history in La Liga, Spains top soccer league.

title: Closing for a Spell, Just to Prove Its Ours
description: ANY day is a fine day for visiting the garden courtyard of Lever House, that midcentury modernist Mad Men masterpiece that was beautifully rejuvenated a decade ago. Any day, that is, but one.

title: In Rubble-Strewn Sitra, Faces of the Young Foretell a Grim Future for Bahrain
description: SITRA, Bahrain  Sometimes a name suggests a condition. There was Beirut a generation ago, Baghdad more recently. In Bahrain, a Persian Gulf state so polarized that truth itself is a matter of interpretation, it is Sitra. Here, the faces of young men foretell a future for the country that looks like the rubble-strewn and violent streets of this town.

title: Virus in Pacific Salmon Raises Worries About Industry
description: Advocates for wild salmon said Friday that a deadly virus had been detected again in a Pacific salmon in British Columbia, but it was not clear if it would prove lethal to the fish population.

title: Yankees Stay With WCBS on Radio
description: The Yankees have extended their contract with the radio station WCBS 880 to broadcast their games through the 2012 season, meaning that the announcers John Sterling and Suzyn Waldman will most likely come back in their same roles.

title: Congressmen Say Union May Be Stalling on H.G.H.
description: The chairman and the ranking member of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, in a letter about the failure to begin testing for human growth hormone sent to the N.F.L. and the players union Friday, said it appears that the players union may be using stall tactics to avoid complying with the collective bargaining agreement.

title: Easy to Use, or Steal, but Inching Out of Reach
description: Among his various legacies, Steve Jobs, whose memorial continues with the arrival of the iPhone 4S, left us with a tangible and resonant symbol of our economic frictions: an easily brandished, easily taken device that in its sleek design and intuitive simplicity flaunts the relative effortlessness of affluent, knowledge-class living. The have-nots, particularly teenagers, covet and seek what, by now, the haves assume as birthright and dependency.

title: Where the 1 Percent Fit in the Hierarchy of Income
description: Chart of the hierarchy of income in the United States.

title: Telling the Story of 41 Years on the Run
description: CASAS NOVAS, Portugal  George Wright, the fugitive murderer who was captured in Portugal last month, 39 years after hijacking a jetliner and demanding a $1 million ransom, said he figured authorities in the United States had given up the chase long ago. But, he said, he never stopped worrying that they would come knocking.

title: California: Official Arrested
description: The state finance director, Ana Matosantos, was arrested early Friday and accused of driving drunk after the police saw her swerving near the Capitol. Ms. Matosantos offered her resignation to Gov. Jerry Brown, but he did not accept it and she reported to work. My decision to drive last night was reckless and irresponsible, she said in a statement.

title: Texas Manager Stands By the Closer Who Let It Slip Away
description: ST. LOUIS  Texas Manager Ron Washington said his team seemed relaxed and normal Friday afternoon, the day after twice failing to get the final strike to finish off the World Series in Game 6. Washington described the disappointment in that 10-9 loss in 11 innings as taking a blow to the gut.

title: Cuban Food, Authentic and Light
description: WHEN I first started working in Manhattan, in the 1980s, I became acquainted with the cheap but absolutely delicious Cuban food that was then ubiquitous on a strip of Ninth Avenue in Chelsea. It was an exciting culinary experience  a window into an unfamiliar culture and a taste awakening. One dish in particular satisfied me every time: picadillo, that basic beef hash made Cuban-style, with tomatoes, green olives and raisins.

title: Changes to Rules Help Ease Pressure on Amateurs
description: After the English amateur Tom Lewis burst onto the golf scene with a share of the first-round lead at the British Open in July, rumors swirled that dollar signs were dancing in his eyes and that he would jump to the professional ranks while his endorsement earnings potential was hot.

title: All the Way Back, the Cardinals Win the World Series
description: ST. LOUIS  When the St. Louis Cardinals were down to their apparent final strike of the season, in both the ninth and 10th innings of Game 6 on Thursday night, Manager Tony La Russa told his players in the dugout not to forget to thank the fans for their support amid what was looking like a crushing season-ending loss.

title: Iraq: Baghdad Bomb Toll Rises
description: The death toll from twin bombings on Thursday in a Shiite neighborhood of Baghdad rose on Friday to 36 killed and 78 wounded, according to an official at the Ministry of Interior. Initially, on Thursday evening, officials put the number of deaths at 12, but many who were hurt later succumbed to their wounds. Among the dead were several police officers and soldiers.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 11 OKLAHOMA AT NO. 10 KANSAS STATE3:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

title: A Neighborhood Pub, Channeling Ireland
description: ITS barely 7 oclock on a Saturday evening and the throttle is wide open at Thatcher McGhees Irish Pub and Eatery in Pompton Lakes. The large square bar is packed two deep with knots of sports fans, young couples and off-duty mechanics talking about the days work. A burly patron who could easily be a finalist in a Jeff Lebowksi lookalike contest is well into a plate of bangers and mash, next to a heavily tattooed fellow picking his way through his Thatch fries, an unholy concoction featuring three cheeses, bacon and ranch dressing, which seems to be a house favorite.

title: World Series Replay: Game 7
description: The St. Louis Cardinals win the World Series, beating the Texas Rangers, 6-2.

title: Rev. Dean Brackley, 65, Dies; Served in El Salvador
description: The Rev. Dean Brackley belonged to an order of priests, the Jesuits, sometimes referred to as Gods Marines, because of a 16th-century founders military background and because of their long tradition of intellectual rigor as teachers and missionaries.

title: Howard Wolpe, Backer of 86 Anti-Apartheid Act, Dies at 71
description: Howard E. Wolpe, a former congressman who played a crucial role in passing legislation that imposed economic sanctions on South Africa in the 1980s, helping to bring an end to apartheid while overcoming two vetoes by President Ronald Reagan, died Tuesday at his home in Saugatuck, Mich. He was 71.

title: For Restaurant Chains, Some Far-Off Links
description: DRIFTWOOD benches, surfboards and paintings of pelicans evoke the Florida coast at Hurricane Grill and Wings in Syosset; steel-drum music plays on the sound system.

title: Final Delights Before the Frost
description: The air may be a bit nippier, but it is not too late to enjoy the fruits of the fall harvest at local farms. At this time of year that means apples (and apple cider), along with pumpkins, squashes, gourds  and pies. These three orchards are representative of what is available at many farms around the state.

title: 2 Coaches Diverging on Game of Life
description: Sometimes a costume says it all. In Richard Dressers Rounding Third, the final offering of the Penguin Rep Theater season, the opening scene depicts two men meeting face to face for the first time. One, wearing horn-rimmed glasses and a tweed sport jacket over a V-neck sweater, looks natty. The other, in well-worn jeans and a T-shirt emblazoned with Local Sports Legend, could not be scruffier. Charlotte Palmer-Lanes textbook-clear outfits tell you right off the bat that Mr. Dressers comic meditation on Little League baseball is going to center on an odd couple.

title: The World This Week, Part One
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: The World This Week, Part Two
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: At Liverpool, the Statistics Sometimes Lie
description: Liverpool fans well recall just how deflated Anfield seemed when a League Two side, Northampton, sent the Reds crashing out of the Carling Cup at the first opportunity last September.

title: A Palm-Studded Outpost of 1940s Hollywood
description: There are plenty of musicals with clever lyrics. Some offer clever books. A handful even manage clever melodies. But City of Angels, which won six Tonys in 1990, is the rarity that has all three. And it demands clever costumes, clever sets and clever staging as well.

title: Goyas Dark Etchings From a Past Full of Horrors
description: One of the advantages of art history is that it provides a sense of perspective. If you think weve got it bad, with our financial crisis, wars and natural disasters, just look at Spain in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. A brilliant, sobering and visionary window onto that world is provided by Los Caprichos (The Caprices), a series of 80 etchings by Francisco Jos de Goya y Lucientes (1746-1828), currently on view at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor.

title: A Classical Myth With Contemporary Style
description: Marina Carrs intense, incisive new play, Phaedra Backwards, at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, is based on a myth that, while not exactly simple, is straightforward enough.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Police on Thursday arrested two militants from the militant organization Lashkar-e-Taiba for twin blasts that occurred in Baramulla and Srinagar in August. The detainees, identified as residents of the Sopore district, are charged with killing two paramilitary personnel and a civilian in the Baramulla town and injuring 11 pedestrians in Srinagar (Kashmir Live).

title: Freese Is Most Valuable, and Most Improbable
description: ST. LOUIS  Waves of red awaited David Freese as he headed toward yet another postgame interview. A major league official jogged alongside Freese, carrying the World Series most valuable player trophy Freese had just won, the main reason ESPN wanted to talk to him.

title: Qantas Fleet Grounded for Second Day
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Qantas Airways, Australias national carrier, kept its worldwide fleet grounded for a second day on Sunday as government officials and business and labor leaders said they were working to end a dispute between the airline and its employees that has left at least 80,000 passengers stranded.

title: Muppets, Warhol and Rebirth: Lady Gaga Holds Court in India
description: Performance art is my life. The idea is to create a fantasy that is so great that when we are together, it feels very real. So said Lady Gaga at a news conference in New Delhi, and so she has.With 15 million followers on Twitter, the most in the world, and 44 million likes on Facebook, the 25-year-old Grammy-winning artist, has redefined what it means to be popular.

title: 12 Americans Die as Blast Hits Bus in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 12 Americans were killed when a Taliban suicide car bomber attacked an armored shuttle bus in Kabul on Saturday, military officials said.

title: What You Thought About Why I Left India
description: India Inks recent first-person essay, Why I Left India (Again) unleashed an explosion of comment and discussion on our pages, on Facebook, Twitter and outside blogs. It also inspired a fictional parody, dinner party arguments in Manhattan, an Asia Society round up, and a psychological analysis from a mental health professional.

title: The Weekend Word: Second Look
description: Todays Times

title: New Track, Old Story:  Vettel Scores 13th Pole Position this Season
description: NEW DELHI  Sebastian Vettel continued his domination of qualifying sessions this year by scoring his 13th pole position of the season at the inaugural Indian Grand Prix outside New Delhi on Saturday. Vettel joins Alain Prost and Ayrton Senna in the record books with the second largest number of pole positions in a season. Nigel Mansell holds the record of 14 pole positions, which he achieved in 1992 at Williams. With two races left in the season, Vettel has a chance to beat the record.

title: New Track, Old Story:  Vettel Scores 13th Pole Position this Season
description: NEW DELHI  Sebastian Vettel continued his domination of qualifying sessions this year by scoring his 13th pole position of the season at the inaugural Indian Grand Prix outside New Delhi on Saturday. Vettel joins Alain Prost and Ayrton Senna in the record books with the second largest number of pole positions in a season. Nigel Mansell holds the record of 14 pole positions, which he achieved in 1992 at Williams. With two races left in the season, Vettel has a chance to beat the record.

title: For Texas, the Moment Slipped Away, Twice
description: St. Louis

title: Urban Forager | Reishi, the Leathery Healer
description: Its difficult these days to walk around the city without finding fungi growing in planters, on wood mulch, or at the base of trees, so I wasnt surprised to discover a beautiful cluster of red-shellacked reishi mushrooms growing fan-like at the base of a tree at the College of Staten Island.

title: Kelly Clarkson, a Pop Star Proud in Her Own Skin
description: THE other night, Danielle Travali, 25, was listening to Kelly Clarksons new album, Stronger. Ms. Travali has fought her brigade of demons and then some, describing herself as an eating-disorders survivor.

title: Denial In Depth
description: Columbia Journalism Review has a takedown of a study from American Enterprise Institute purporting to show that inequality hasnt increased, after all. Whats striking is the way AEI doesnt even resort to the usual practice of concocting misleading numbers; it just flat-out lies about what various other peoples research, like Robert Gordons work, actually says.

title: Falling Short In Europe (Again)
description: Kash Mansori is unhappy with the state of the Italian bond market just days after the supposed big rescue. Indeed, the Panzerfaust has fallen far short; Italy is having to roll over its debt at levels that are unsustainable, and the unraveling of the euro is definitely still on.

title: A Fourth Jewel for the Crown, Found in November
description: For decades, all those competing at the highest levels of North American racing have commenced each new year with their sights set on winning the same three races  the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes. Victories in these classics significantly raise the stature of horses, jockeys, trainers and owners alike and have a lasting impact on ones legacy, often tipping the scales in ones favor when its time to be considered for the Hall of Fame.

title: Can Breakfast Replace Family Dinner?
description: Can the family breakfast serve the same purpose as the family dinner?

title: Receiver Learns Roles, but Hasnt Found One
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Over the past two seasons, Ramses Barden has been Hakeem Nicks. He has also been Mario Manningham, Steve Smith and, on occasion, Domenik Hixon.

title: Occupy Protests Test the Mayor of Oakland
description: When Jean Quan was an undergraduate, she once sat for 10 hours inside Sproul Hall at the University of California, Berkeley, demanding better treatment for minority students. As a community activist, she helped unionize hospital workers and organized parents in a poor neighborhood of West Oakland.

title: For Rangers Fans, the Promised Land Was Two Strikes and a Few Inches Away
description: By the time the last out was made, Rangers fans knew what was coming. They had felt the tide shift in the late innings of Game 6, which will surely go down as one of the most torturous losses in World Series history  not one, but two blown chances to win the championship on a single pitch.

title: Variety: A Wartime Diagramless
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert! Todays Diagramless is 17 squares wide by 17 squares deep with regular crossword symmetry. The entry for 1-Across begins in the sixth square of the first row.

title: Live Analysis: Closing Down October, Looking to November
description: Paul Myerberg and The Times Jere Longman will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can alsofollow Paul on Twitterfor additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: Someone Ought to Make a Movie
description: ST. LOUIS  Carpe diem.

title: Path May Be Untraditional, but the Tar Heels Goal Is the Same
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  North Carolina basketball traditionalists apparently have an issue with their Tar Heels. Not the team. The uniforms.

title: Heavy Autumn Snowstorm Barrels Across Northeast
description: October, said the calendar. Before Halloween. And the 2.5 million trees occupying New York Citys open spaces confirmed it was fall  not winter  with glorious canopies of leaves stretching along their boughs.

title: Life Without Manning Leads to Thoughts of Life Beyond Him
description: It has long been a truism in sports: there is perhaps no player more important in any team game than the quarterback.

title: Big Brown Carries the Burden of His Owners
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Big Brown is having a good autumn. His first crop of yearlings, a handsome bunch, has been selling crisply. The horsemen here in the bluegrass in advance of this weeks 28th Breeders Cup have been buzzing about what they have seen from Big Browns babies in the sales ring. The big bay is in Australia, mating with a full book of 130 mares, and being paid nicely to do so: $27,500 a date.

title: Militants Strike at Troops at Base in Somali Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Islamist militants mounted heavy attacks against African Union and Somali troops in Mogadishu on Saturday. At least a dozen people were killed, witnesses said, although there were conflicting reports on the number of casualties.

title: Israeli Drone Strike Kills Militants in Southern Gaza
description: GAZA  Israeli airstrikes killed seven Palestinian members of Islamic Jihads armed wing in southern Gaza on Saturday, according to the militant group, and Gaza militants fired salvos of rockets at cities in southern Israel, killing one Israeli man and wounding at least two others in a sudden escalation of cross-border violence.

title: Ideas for Spreading Quake-Resistant Building Methods
description: Design for Disaster

title: Occupy Movement, After Legal Victories, Faces Weather
description: Continuing a week of crackdowns across the country, 26 Occupy Nashville protesters were arrested early Saturday, the second such roundup, for trespassing. And for the second night running, a judge dismissed the protesters arrest warrants, according to an official for the Tennessee Highway Patrol.

title: Kyrgyzstan Votes for a President, Feeling the Pull of Russia
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  When Russias prime minister, Vladimir V. Putin, unveiled a plan this month to form a new alliance of former Soviet countries called the Eurasian Union, some of them cringed at the specter of some kind of U.S.S.R. version 2.0.

title: In a Big Company, Make Everyone an Entrepreneur
description: This interview with  Lynn Blodgett, president and C.E.O. of ACS, a Xerox company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: 30 Seconds With Mark Messier
description: Mark Messier is best known around New York as the captain of the Rangers when they won the Stanley Cup in 1994, their first championship in 54 years. But next Sunday, he will trade skates for running shoes and hit the streets for the New York City Marathon. Messier, 50, will represent the New York Police and Fire Widows and Childrens Benefit Fund and Tomorrows Childrens Fund in the race.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Whats Luck Got to Do With It?
description: BETTER to be lucky than good, the adage goes.

title: Podcast: European Debt, Settlement Talks, Fed Policy and Jim Collins
description: European leaders reached agreement this week on a far-reaching package aimed at resolving the Greek debt problem, recapitalizing vulnerable banks and bolstering the euro zones financial rescue fund. Stock markets around the world rallied on the news.

title: A Conversation With Ariel Schulman
description: Ariel Schulman, the director of the box office smash Paranormal 3, takes more questions.

title: Free Agent Outlook: Pujols, Sabathia and Reyes Stand Above the Rest
description: With the World Series over, the hot-stove season begins in earnest as each team sets its sights on contending next year. This free-agent class, though not particularly deep, has an incredibly high end that includes the best hitter and two of the best pitchers in the majors.

title: When the City Was a House of Horrors
description: The late 1970s and early 1980s  when buildings were burning, fiscal crises were raging and the Dead Boys were playing at CBGB  were a macabre time in New York Citys history, a period when it could be said that the city resembled a haunted house.

title: A Deal That Wouldnt Sting
description: AFTER months of back and forth, a deal that is supposed to punish large financial institutions for foreclosure misconduct may be nigh.

title: Dear Ben: Its Time for Your Volcker Moment
description: IN October 1979, inflation was running at more than 10 percent a year, and the Federal Reserves gradual interest rate increases werent solving the problem. So Paul Volcker, the Fed chairman, dramatically changed how monetary policy was conducted. Today, an equally intractable unemployment crisis demands that Ben S. Bernanke, the current Fed chairman, stage a quiet revolution of his own.

title: For Kurds in Turkey, a Countrys Conflict Rends Families
description: SIRNAK, Turkey  Portraits of Mevlude Gungens two eldest children hang just above the television, the only piece of furniture in her spare living room. On a recent day, the set was tuned to the station run by a Kurdish militant group, bringing her news of the conflict that has haunted her country  and her family  for years.

title: More Thoughts On Weaponized Keynesianism
description: Let me follow up a bit on the sudden discovery by Republicans that cuts in government spending cost jobs and drive up the unemployment rate  as long as the spending is on destruction rather than construction. Oh, and thanks to commenters for reminding me of Barney Franks coinage, weaponized Keynesianism.

title: Ugandans May Get a Game Yet
description: When the team from Kampala, Uganda, was denied visas and was unable to play in the Little League World Series last July, the filmmaker Jay Shapiro found himself adding a heart-rending chapter to the documentary he was filming about the team, and doing so in a sea of sympathy. All kinds of people, from children offering to donate their baseball mitts to major league players, contacted him to ask the same thing: what can I do?

title: Can Super Mario Save the Day for Europe?
description: FRANKFURT

title: Hinting at an End to a Curb on Polygamy, Interim Libyan Leader Stirs Anger
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  It was just a passing reference to marriage in a leaders soberly delivered speech, but all week it has unsettled women here as well as allies abroad.

title: Its 3-D, High Definition and in Your Face
description: PEOPLE who want to enjoy the eye-popping effects of 3-D movies at home, far from the multiplex, usually do so on a 3-D television set.

title: In Colorado, a Power Struggle With the Power Company
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Many Americans these days, from the huddled masses of Occupy Wall Street to the coifed confines of the presidential campaign, are talking about the future of capitalism.

title: Commercials, by Multiple Choice
description: ON a television set, 10 feet away, commercials are often irritating.

title: The Slogans Stop Here
description: EXPRESSING your own views is challenging enough. Describing someone elses opinions without talking to them first opens the door to serious trouble.

title: Mets Name a First-Base Coach
description: The Mets continued revamping their coaching staff on Saturday, naming Tom Goodwin their first-base coach. Goodwin, 43, was the minor league outfield and base-running coordinator for the Boston Red Sox for the last three seasons.

title: Bringing the Haves and Have-Nots Together for Curry and Compassion
description: As the evening light dimmed, Shrawan Nepali greeted each person who stood in a long line waiting for his food: a woman with her butterscotch-colored cocker spaniel, a poet poring over a mystery book, art students, commuters, a homeless woman with crimson sneakers and men wearing black hoods to guard against the cold and conversation.

title: The Mystery of the $25,000 Phone Bill
description: THE Haggler has been traveling recently, and that can mean only one thing: a column that opens with a rant about traveling. Our subject this time is hotel doors, the kind that go ka-boom when they close.

title: Comedian Is Serious, Mostly, as Candidate
description: MIAMI BEACH  Wearing a black suit and tie with neon-pink laces on his kicks, the man in the video struggles up Ocean Drive, past the Art Deco hotels and the hangovers they house. He pulls a trolley freighted with two voting machines  the ones that hung those chads long ago and made election infamy.

title: China Reshuffles Top Leadership at Financial Regulators
description: SHANGHAI  China reshuffled the leadership of three of its financial regulatory agencies on Saturday, one of the first steps in what is expected to be a major leadership change at the top of the Communist Party next year.

title: Arsenal Sends Chelsea to 2nd League Loss in Row
description: Robin van Persie scored a hat trick to lead Arsenal to a 5-3 win over Chelsea on Saturday in the English Premier League, while first-place Manchester City beat Wolverhampton, 3-1.

title: One Role, With 10,000 Variations
description: ASK people to describe a typical day at work and some will say its impossible  each day is different. But there are other jobs where people do the same thing every day, like driving the same bus route, or performing the same role in a play year after year. Ive played the psychiatrist Margaret Brent in Perfect Crime, an off-Broadway play, for almost 25 years, ever since it opened.

title: Former Leader of Brazil Is Said to Have Throat Cancer
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils former president, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, has throat cancer and will begin chemotherapy soon, his hospital said Saturday in a statement.

title: A King of Kosher
description: I WAS born in Casablanca when Morocco was still a French protectorate. The humid climate was not good for my asthma, so when I was 7 my parents sent me to a home for children in a French mountain village where the air was healthier. My parents visited when they could and I went home during holidays, but the separation was traumatic for all of us. I lived there for three years and it cured my asthma.

title: Dolphins at Giants: Matchup to Watch
description: Dolphins (0-6) at Giants (4-2), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Considering When It Might Be Best Not to Know About Cancer
description: After decades in which cancer screening was promoted as an unmitigated good, as the best  perhaps only  way for people to protect themselves from the ravages of a frightening disease, a pronounced shift is under way.

title: Medical Marijuana Dispensary in Oakland Is Focus of Federal Government
description: Richard Lee, the leader of the marijuana legalization movement in California, does not appear to be intimidated by the federal governments crackdown on medical marijuana dispensaries.

title: October Surprise: White Snow on Green Leaves
description: Heres the view from my front porch of a rare sight in late October in the Hudson Valley: maple foliage thats still green because of a warm September and covered in white flakes from a pre-Halloween snowstorm.

title: Los Cenzontles Mexican Arts Center
description: Tucked between a laundry and a discount grocery in a strip mall, Los Cenzontles Mexican Arts Center  a nonprofit organization founded in 1994 by the musician Eugene Rodriguez  offers classes in Mexican dance, music and art for children of all ages. The rhythmic beat of stomping feet echoes into the parking lot.  LOUISE RAFKIN

title: Snow Comes Early to East Coast
description: A storm moving up the East Coast threatened to pull down power lines and dump up to a foot of snow in some areas.

title: Letters: Volcker and the Money Market Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: South Sudan Turns Toward British Heritage
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The new nation of South Sudan has expressed a desire to join the Commonwealth, a group composed mainly of former British colonies, and said that it would change the language used in schools from Arabic to English. The two actions further cement its pivot from the Arab world of northern Africa toward the largely Anglophone east.

title: Bob Beaumont, Who Popularized Electric Cars, Dies at 79
description: Bob Beaumont, who thought every home should have an affordable electric vehicle in its driveway and sold more than 2,000 of them, the tiny, trapezoidal creation known as the CitiCar, decades before General Motors and Nissan came up with their own versions, died on Monday at his home in Columbia, Md. He was 79.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, October 30
description: For frequent Sunday show viewers, this should sound familiar: The struggling economy and the 2012 presidential race are both on the menu this week.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 2 Amid Turkish Crackdown on Kurds
description: ANKARA, Turkey  A female suicide bomber killed two other people and wounded 20 on Saturday in Bingol, a predominantly Kurdish town in Turkeys east, as the army continued a major offensive against Kurdish separatists in the region.

title: Pizzas and Pessimism
description: BEING surprised by something nutty from Herman Cains presidential campaign is like balking at an autopsy in a CSI episode: certain things go with the territory. Still, you had to pause and peel your jaw off the ground after watching an Internet ad for Cain that prompted considerable conversation last week.

title: What Tax Dollars Cant Buy
description: OVER the last 30 years, the U.S. economy has generated more large fortunes and more stress for the middle class. While the rich have grown extraordinarily rich, median wages have barely increased, the costs of health care and higher education have jumped, and socioeconomic mobility has lagged behind that of other developed nations. Americans have never begrudged the wealthy their success, as long as they had a chance to rise higher than their parents, and perhaps get rich themselves. But our era of diminished expectations is putting that in doubt.

title: Did You Hear the One About the Bankers?
description: CITIGROUP is lucky that Muammar el-Qaddafi was killed when he was. The Libyan leaders death diverted attention from a lethal article involving Citigroup that deserved more attention because it helps to explain why many average Americans have expressed support for the Occupy Wall Street movement. The news was that Citigroup had to pay a $285 million fine to settle a case in which, with one hand, Citibank sold a package of toxic mortgage-backed securities to unsuspecting customers  securities that it knew were likely to go bust  and, with the other hand, shorted the same securities  that is, bet millions of dollars that they would go bust.

title: Addicted to Exercise?
description: FOR decades, scientists have studied areas deep within the brain that seem associated with pleasure and addiction.

title: The Bloated Nuclear Weapons Budget
description: Twenty years after the end of the cold war, the United States still has about 2,500 nuclear weapons deployed and 2,600 more as backup. The Obama administration, in an attempt to mollify Congressional Republicans, has also committed to modernizing an already hugely expensive complex of nuclear labs and production facilities. Altogether, these and other nuclear-related programs could cost $600 billion or more over the next decade. The country does not need to maintain this large an arsenal. It should not be spending so much to do it, especially when Congress is considering deep cuts in vital domestic programs.

title: After Liberation, Nowhere to Run
description: Tripoli, Libya

title: The Genius of Jobs
description: ONE of the questions I wrestled with when writing about Steve Jobs was how smart he was. On the surface, this should not have been much of an issue. Youd assume the obvious answer was: he was really, really smart. Maybe even worth three or four reallys. After all, he was the most innovative and successful business leader of our era and embodied the Silicon Valley dream writ large: he created a start-up in his parents garage and built it into the worlds most valuable company.

title: The Arab Intellectuals Who Didnt Roar
description: IN mid-June, the Syrian poet known as Adonis, one of the Arab worlds most renowned literary figures, addressed an open letter to the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad. The stage was set for one of those moments, familiar from revolutions past, in which an intellectual hero confronts an oppressive ruler and eloquently voices the grievances of a nation.

title: Falling Crime, Teeming Prisons
description: Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, has a smart proposal to create a bipartisan commission to review the nations troubled criminal justice system and offer recommendations for reform. The National Criminal Justice Commission Act would be a valuable first step toward reducing crime as well as punishment. Unfortunately, Senate Republicans derailed the bill recently, with some falsely claiming that it would encroach on states rights.

title: You Want to Track Me? Here You Go, F.B.I.
description: ON June 19, 2002, I ran into a bit of a problem that turned my life upside down. It happened at the Detroit airport as I was entering the country. I realized something wasnt right when the immigration agent at United States Customs slid my passport through the reader, then froze. Is there something wrong? I asked. He was still frozen. After a few moments, he said, Follow me, please, and I ended up at the Immigration and Naturalization Services airport office.

title: A Pilgrims Progress
description: I NEEDED to save myself, says Annie Leibovitz, explaining what motivated her new book of photographs, Pilgrimage. I needed to remind myself of what I like to do, what I can do.

title: Our Unpaid, Extra Shadow Work
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Twitterology: A New Science?
description: DENIZENS of the Twitter-verse, please be advised: Whether you are a Libyan celebrating the demise of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a New Zealand office worker sleepily starting your day or a California teenager trying out the latest slang, your words are being analyzed.

title: Gracias, Pero No Gracias
description: There are almost 12 million potential Hispanic voters in the United States. And both parties say they are eager to court their votes. So one has to wonder why the Republican presidential contenders would miss the chance to debate before the largest possible audience of Spanish-language television viewers.

title: Wall Street Protesters Hit the Bulls-Eye
description: Occupiers of Zuccotti Park and other sites around the country have been criticized for the fuzziness of their goals. Their complaint that the privileged few in the top 1 percent are getting a disproportionate share of the nations prosperity, however, is spot on. And Wall Streeters are taking a bigger and bigger chunk of that income.

title: Wait Wait... Dont Tell Me
description: NPRs Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait

title: Ariel Schulman
description: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

title: The Times Gives Them Space, but Who Pays Them?
description: PEOPLE dont just argue about what is written on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. They argue about who is doing the writing and why.

title: Jumping Jacks and Lobs at a City Budget Parade
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Managing Mental Illness in a High-Powered Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Dialogue: Using Technology to Teach
description: In schools and in homes, teachers and parents wrestle with the role of technology in childrens lives. Our readers weigh in.

title: The Shadow Republican Party
description: Outside organizations are a growing presence in the Republican Party, recruiting top strategists and donors from the traditional party structure.

title: Outside Groups Eclipsing G.O.P. as Hub of Campaigns
description: About once a month, a dozen or so of the countrys most influential Republicans meet in a bare-walled conference room in Washington to discuss how to make further gains in the Congressional elections next year and defeat President Obama.

title: The Latest in  Brain Research on Addiction
description: We in the pundit world probably dont pay enough attention to science, and in Sundays column I make a too-rare foray in that direction. I write about new research, based on brain scans, on addiction and happiness. One lesson is that sugary foods can constitute an addiction  but so can running, and also generosity. Read the column and post your thoughts!

title: Why Our Candidates Disappoint Us
description: Atlanta

title: Sunday: Hollywood From Right to Left
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Right off the bat I knew I would like this one. For one thing, its the brainchild of two constructors I find very entertaining, Andrea Carla Michaels and Patrick Blindauer. Its also about Hollywood movies. Now thats entertainment.

title: As Fall Veto Session Begins, Lawmakers Question Quinns Ability to Lead
description: With each green light that blinked last week on the General Assembly voting boards approving electricity legislation, Gov. Pat Quinns influence with lawmakers seemed to fade.

title: Speechmaking Call and Response at Alabama Straw Poll
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Maybe youve heard: there was another obscure straw poll held in America, and a legion of well-organized Ron Paul supporters turned out.

title: Jailing Fewer Would Trim County Costs, Official Says
description: In times of austerity, it can be very difficult for elected officials to advance any significant agenda items while also balancing a budget. But the Cook County Board of Commissioners president, Toni Preckwinkle, is trying to do just that.

title: Letters: Around the Globe, Economic Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Aggressive Strategy Pays Off at Womens Grand Prix Event
description: Heres a striking fact about the game: There is only one woman ranked among the worlds top 100 players.

title: State Finds a Way to Make Weatherization Work
description: For conservative opponents of the federal stimulus package, the beleaguered Weatherization Assistance Program has been an easy target. Texas component of the Obama administrations green jobs initiative has also been plagued by well-documented problems and criticisms, and the disdain of Texas Republican leadership, including Gov. Rick Perry.

title: Day After Day, Her Voice Takes Listeners to the Stars
description: SAN ANTONIO  On a clear, cool night in the early 1960s, a father drove his young, pajama-clad daughter to one of the T-head piers on Corpus Christi Bay to marvel at an object in the sky.

title: Enforcement Is Next Task for Law on Wage Theft
description: HOUSTON  For two years, Diego Gala, a Mexican immigrant in the country illegally, worked five days a week cleaning a private school for less than minimum wage. His employer refused to pay him overtime even when he was forced to work on the weekends. Mr. Gala did not speak up, fearing deportation if he reported his boss.

title: Drilling Debate in Cooperstown, N.Y., Is Personal
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  The letter that arrived in Kim Jastremskis mailbox on County Highway 52 suggested that she stop protesting the possibility of natural gas drilling. It seemed more of a threat than a request.

title: U.S. Planning Troop Buildup in Gulf After Exit From Iraq
description: MacDILL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla.  The Obama administration plans to bolster the American military presence in the Persian Gulf after it withdraws the remaining troops from Iraq this year, according to officials and diplomats. That repositioning could include new combat forces in Kuwait able to respond to a collapse of security in Iraq or a military confrontation with Iran.

title: Looks Like Salzburg
description: First, it was Tropical Storm Irene that forced the postponement on Aug. 28 of the Red Bulls game against the Los Angeles Galaxy.

title: Indian Middle Class Finds Its Political Voice
description: The wealthier India has become, the more politically disillusioned many of the middle-class beneficiaries have grown.

title: College Football Replay: Oct. 30
description: Rain and snow soaked the East Coast, and a storm of touchdowns showered the rest of the country, with blowouts for Florida State, Michigan and Oklahoma.

title: Protests Awaken a Goliath in India
description: DWARKA, India  Shubhrangshu Barman Roy and his childhood friends are among the winners in Indias economic rise. They have earned graduate degrees, started small companies and settled into Indias expanding middle class. They sometimes take vacations together and meet for dinners or parties, maybe to celebrate a new baby or a new business deal.

title: Soggy Trick-or-Treaters Visit White House
description: If his Halloween candy didnt deter the egg throwers that President Obama feared, the weather would have.

title: Up by 3 Goals, Rangers Find a Way to Lose Again
description: It looked as if Coach John Tortorellas experiment was working. He broke up the tandem of Marian Gaborik and the $60 million free agent brought in to ignite him, Brad Richards, and the Rangers had a three-goal lead over Ottawa with just 11 minutes to play Saturday afternoon.

title: Cain and Romney Top Iowa Poll
description: WASHINGTON  Two months before the first votes are to be cast in the Republican presidential nominating contest, Herman Cain and Mitt Romney have the strongest support among party activists who plan to participate in the Iowa caucuses, according to a poll released on Saturday evening.

title: A Tattoo Parlor Prepares to Depart the Chelsea Hotel
description: The tattoo parlor on the ground floor of the Chelsea Hotel was nearly empty on Saturday afternoon, and Ivan Arte, a worker there, said he had only one scheduled appointment, a man coming in to get a half-sleeve dragon with flowers.

title: Pujols Not Ready to Look Forward
description: ST. LOUIS  When Albert Pujols came to bat in the seventh inning of Game 6 of the World Series on Thursday night, the St. Louis Cardinals were losing and on the brink of elimination, and Pujols had not had a hit since his three home runs in Game 3.

title: With the Big East Teetering, Rutgers Stumbles
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  The snow-globe conditions for West Virginias 41-31 victory over Rutgers on Saturday afternoon provided a fitting backdrop for two Big East programs caught in the disorienting swirl of conference realignment.

title: N.B.A. Deal Is Tantalizingly Close, but Last Hurdle Is a Big One
description: The new N.B.A. labor deal is practically done. You wouldnt know it from the headlines, the dour news conferences or the apocalyptic rhetoric spilling from league officials. But the deal, in practical terms, is about 95 percent complete.

title: Sports Replay, Oct. 29
description: A look at the day in sports across the world, from Formula One racing in India to the Pan American Games in Mexico.

title: Corrections: October 30
description: SPORTS

title: Yanks Pick Up Options for Cano and Swisher
description: The Yankees exercised their one-year, $10.25 million option on right fielder Nick Swishers contract Saturday. They also picked up the $14 million option on Robinson Canos contract.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Days Best in College Football
description: KEVIN DECKER The New Hampshire quarterback had 335 yards of total offense and scored the go-ahead touchdown to lead host New Hampshire over Rhode Island, 31-24. Decker led an efficient six-play, 68-yard drive in the third quarter, erasing a 3-point deficit with a 1-yard touchdown run. He finished 14 of 21 for 257 yards.

title: Top 25 Roundup: Oklahoma Rolls, Stanford Escapes
description: 1. L.S.U. (8-0) did not play

title: Samantha Halpern, Michael Marsh
description: Samantha Blake Halpern, a daughter of Cheryl B. Halpern and Ronald A. Halpern of Niskayuna, N.Y., was married Saturday evening in New York to Dr. Michael Anthony Marsh, the son of Dominique Lorraine Marsh and David A. Marsh of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Steven Blane officiated at the New York Palace Hotel.

title: Anne Lumelleau, James Mormile
description: Anne Franklin Lumelleau and James Brien Mormile were married Saturday by Msgr. Robert OConnor at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York.

title: Olivia Schramm, Conor Grew
description: Olivia Patricia Schramm and Conor Patrick Grew were married Saturday at the Church of St. Monica in Berwyn, Pa. The Rev. William A. Trader, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Yu, John Song
description: Jennifer Sochung Yu, a daughter of Mun J. Yu and Jin S. Yu of Leawood, Kan., was married Saturday afternoon in Stevensville, Md., to John Joo Hwan Song, a son of Jaimin W. Song and Yangsoon Song of Baltimore. The Rev. John Kim, a Presbyterian minister, led a nondenominational ceremony at the Chesapeake Bay Beach Club.

title: Danielle Ingwer, Gregg Cohen
description: Danielle Brooke Ingwer, a daughter of Sherri J. Ingwer and Kenneth D. Ingwer of Armonk, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Gregg Howard Cohen, the son of Carol L. Cohen and Michael S. Cohen of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Joanna Samuels officiated at Gotham Hall, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Tina Pelikan and Claire Stefani
description: Tina Ann Emily Pelikan and Claire Jeanne Stefani were married Saturday at Bar Six, a restaurant in New York. Carl Pritzkat, a friend of the couple who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

title: Danielle Goldstein, Tal Masserman
description: Dr. Danielle Sarah Goldstein and Dr. Tal Ethan Masserman were married Saturday evening in an outdoor ceremony at the Westin Kierland Resort in Scottsdale, Ariz. Rabbi Mari Chernow officiated.

title: Carolyn Goldberg, Philip Butler
description: Dr. Carolyn Graham Goldberg, the daughter of Lynn G. Goldberg and Thomas D. Goldberg of Westport, Conn., was married Saturday to Dr. Philip Johannes Butler, a son of Elisabeth N. Butler and Dr. Thomas C. Butler of Dominica, the West Indies. Mary A. Richardson, an Anguilla justice of the peace, officiated at Cap Juluca, a resort in Maundays Bay on Anguilla, in the British West Indies.

title: Miki Litmanovitz, Jacob Heller
description: Miki Litmanovitz and Jacob Mattathias Heller were married Friday in San Jose, Calif. Ben Miyaji, a deputy marriage commissioner at the Santa Clara County Office of the Clerk-Recorder, officiated.

title: Hannah Foster, Jack Eaves
description: Lt. j.g. Hannah Foster and Lt. j.g. Jack Eaves were married Thursday by Justice Elena Kagan in her chambers at the United States Supreme Court in Washington.

title: Katherine Kamp, Joseph Collins Jr.
description: Katherine Elizabeth Kamp and Joseph Jameson Collins Jr. were married Saturday at the Fourth Presbyterian Church of Chicago. The Rev. Adam H. Fronczek, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Ann-Elizabeth Ostrager, Jon Daniels
description: Ann-Elizabeth Ostrager and Jon Asher Daniels were married Saturday evening at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

title: Daniel Layman and Eric Miller
description: Daniel Richard Layman and Eric Lawrence Miller were married Saturday afternoon in Lawrence, N.Y. Donald J. Buchalter, the village justice of Lawrence, officiated at the home of Mr. Millers sister and brother-in-law, Jane and Michael Groothuis.

title: Jennifer Miller, Jason Feifer
description: Jennifer Lillian Miller and Jason Bradley Feifer were married Saturday evening at the Fairmont Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Mindy Portnoy officiated with the assistance of Rabbi David Shneyer.

title: Samantha Freeman, Oran Ebel
description: Samantha Elizabeth Freeman and Oran Michael Ebel are to be married on Sunday by Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Sheila Chithran, Sandeep Ramesh
description: Sheila Jean Chithran and Sandeep Ramesh were married Saturday afternoon in New York. The Rev. Peter E. Fink performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church, where he is the associate pastor. In the evening, Pandit Krishna Bhat Varanasi, a Hindu priest, led a ceremony at Cipriani Wall Street.

title: Lauren Fadeley and Francis Veyette
description: Lauren Fadeley and Francis Veyette, dancers with the Pennsylvania Ballet in Philadelphia, were married Saturday evening at Minorca by the Sea, a condominium complex in New Smyrna Beach, Fla. Jonathan H. Stiles, a friend of the couple from the ballet company who became a Church of Spiritual Humanism minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Porcia Bradford and J C Love III
description: Dr. Porcia Therese Bradford and J C Love III were married Saturday evening at the St. Jude Catholic Church in Montgomery, Ala. The Rev. Paul McQuillen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Megan Ferguson, Nico Evers-Swindell
description: Megan Louise Ferguson and Nico Thomas Evers-Swindell, actors in Los Angeles, were married Saturday at the home of the brides parents, Sharon Maxwell-Ferguson and Howell Lykes Ferguson of Thomasville, Ga. The Rev. Frederick A. Buechner, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Caissie Levy, David Reiser
description: Caissie Shira Levy, the daughter of Lisa Levy and Dr. Mark Levy of Hamilton, Ontario, is to be married Sunday evening to David Aaron Reiser, a son of Linda Reiser and Dr. Robert A. Reiser of Tallahassee, Fla. Rabbi Stanley J. Garfein is to officiate at the Soho Beach House in Miami Beach, with Daniel H. Reiser, the brother of the bridegroom and a rabbinical student, taking part.

title: Kari Hirsch, Benjamin Cohen
description: Kari Drazel Hirsch, the daughter of Dena P. Hirsch and Mark S. Hirsch of New York, was married there Saturday evening to Benjamin Jacob Cohen, a son of Leslie J. Cohen and Mitchell H. Cohen of Boston. Rabbi Dr. Elliot J. Cosgrove officiated at the Jumeirah Essex House hotel, with Cantor Azi Schwartz assisting.

title: Jennifer Lane, John Spaith
description: Jennifer Marie Lane and John Chadwell Spaith were married Saturday at the Homer United Methodist Church in Homer, Ill. The Rev. John Wuestneck, a Presbyterian minister, performed a nondenominational Christian ceremony.

title: Courtney Silverman, Justin Weg
description: Courtney Blair Silverman and Justin Scott Weg were married Saturday at Capitale, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik officiated.

title: Elizabeth Feldmeier, Mark Vieyra
description: Elizabeth Morris Feldmeier, a daughter of Arlene Garbett Feldmeier and Harvey Feldmeier II of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married Saturday evening to Mark Bernard Vieyra, the son of Katherine Raab Vieyra and Daniel I. Vieyra of Tallmadge, Ohio. Rabbi Hayyim J. Angel performed the ceremony at Congregation Shearith Israel in Manhattan.

title: Jeri Milhauser, Michael Stagner
description: Jeri Lee Milhauser and Dr. Michael James Stagner were married Saturday evening at the brides apartment in New York. Justice Jane S. Solomon of State Supreme Court in New York officiated.

title: Building Collapse Kills Construction Worker
description: A construction worker was killed after a building he was working in collapsed and buried him under six feet of rubble in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon, the police said.

title: New Dreams for Field
description: DYERSVILLE, Iowa  Mike Dollar had a faraway look as he watched his wife, Laura, hit baseballs to their son, Jesse, who fielded them at shortstop in an Atlanta Braves T-shirt. Abby, their daughter, played catcher. The sun was bright, the sky was clear and the cornstalks were waving in the breeze.

title: Stanford and Luck Pull Out a Victory
description: LOS ANGELES  Stanfords perfect season was on the brink of ruin against U.S.C. on Saturday night because of a rare mistake by its impeccable quarterback Andrew Luck. With a little over three minutes to play in the fourth quarter, Luck threw a pass that cornerback Nickell Robey intercepted and returned 32 yards to put the Trojans ahead, 34-27.

title: Metro Pucks Weekly: Blown Leads, a Controversial Call and a Lot of Losses
description: Our weekly review of the performances of the three local N.H.L. teams.

title: Newswallah: Longreads Edition
description: A look at some of the long-form journalism we have been reading this week.

title: Two Masters Explored in Roman Show
description: The exhibition Filippino Lippi and Sandro Botticelli in Florence in the 1400s, showing at the Scuderie del Quirinale (Via XXIV Maggio 16; english.scuderiequirinale.it) through Jan. 15, follows the lives and works of those two painters, with particular emphasis on Lippis career, style and innovations. More than 40 of his works are juxtaposed with those of other masters, mainly Botticelli, whose supporting role in the exhibition serves to illuminate the character of the junior master.

title: Occupy Protesters Regroup After Mass Arrests
description: DENVER  Protesters in Denver and Nashville regrouped on Sunday, a day after dozens of arrests at demonstrations inspired by Occupy Wall Street in both cities.

title: Qantas Flights to Resume After Grounding
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Qantas Airways was expected to resume flying Monday after a government tribunal ordered the airline to lift its grounding of the entire fleet over the weekend, which stranded thousands around the world.

title: Breeders Cup Memories, From the First Break Out of the Gate
description: I was at Hollywood Park on Nov. 10, 1984, for the inaugural running of the Breeders Cup. My dad and I had been going to races in Southern California for just over a decade by that time, and we rarely missed a feature race on a weekend at any of the areas major tracks, so there was no way we were missing the first Breeders Cup.

title: Floodwalls Keep Bangkok Dry but Provinces Angry
description: BANGKOK  Shielded by hundreds of thousands of sandbags piled shoulder high along the citys outskirts, most of Bangkok remained dry on Sunday, allaying fears for now that the massive metropolis would be swamped by monsoon floodwaters.

title: Channel Surfing: Fires of Faith, Part 3
description: Its perhaps the most beloved (and, for many, most sacred) book ever published in the West, but oh, the birth pangs. BYUtv has been exploring the creation of the King James Bible in Fires of Faith, a well-made three-part documentary (also viewable on the channels Web site) that concludes Sunday night.

title: A Volcker Moment Indeed (Slightly Wonkish)
description: Christina Romer calls on Ben Bernanke to adopt a nominal GDP target, and suggests that he consider himself in a position comparable to that of Paul Volcker  where Volcker took drastic action to fight inflation, Bernanke should do likewise to fight unemployment.

title: Social Security Bait And Switch, A Continuing Series
description: Dean Baker is angry at the Washington Post for spreading disinformation about Social Security. Hes right, of course  and its shocking that a well-known fallacy is the subject of a news analysis that purports to inform readers.

title: A Sisters Eulogy for Steve Jobs
description: I grew up as an only child, with a single mother. Because we were poor and because I knew my father had emigrated from Syria, I imagined he looked like Omar Sharif. I hoped he would be rich and kind and would come into our lives (and our not yet furnished apartment) and help us. Later, after Id met my father, I tried to believe hed changed his number and left no forwarding address because he was an idealistic revolutionary, plotting a new world for the Arab people.

title: Committing to Debates, Perry Plays Down the Issue
description: Even as Rick Perry admits he has struggled during televised debates against the polished Mitt Romney and other G.O.P. candidates, the Texas governor maintains he could handle President Obama, a man he has acknowledged to be a very good debater.

title: Cain Gets Tough Treatment for Videos Cigarette Scene
description: WASHINGTON  Had Herman Cain known he would be running into a human buzzsaw named Bob Schieffer on Sunday, he might have had second thoughts about including a now infamous scene at the end of his new campaign video that shows his chief of staff, Mark Block, coolly smoking a cigarette.

title: Puss in Boots Leads at Weekend Box Office
description: DreamWorks Animations Puss in Boots, a spin-off of that studios Shrek franchise, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in an estimated $34 million. An unusually heavy autumn snowstorm in the Northeast may have kept some potential ticket buyers at home: Hollywood had been expecting a total closer to $40 million. But Puss in Boots, which cost about $130 million to make and was distributed by Paramount Pictures, received strong critical reviews and an A-minus from audiences in exit polls, opening up the possibility of solid sales in weekends ahead.

title: Storm Leaves More Than 2 Million Without Power
description: Millions of people across the Northeast found themselves without power on Sunday after an unusual autumn storm dumped record amounts of snow.

title: India Wins, as Vettel Leads From Start to Finish
description: NEW DELHI  Proving both the world and its own skeptics wrong, India staged its first Formula One race on Sunday in what has been hailed as a success for a country with a tarnished reputation for hosting international sporting events.

title: India Wins, as Vettel Leads From Start to Finish
description: NEW DELHI  Proving both the world and its own skeptics wrong, India staged its first Formula One race on Sunday in what has been hailed as a success for a country with a tarnished reputation for hosting international sporting events.

title: Obama Adviser Unloads on Romney
description: David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama and one of the chief architects of his 2008 victory, accused Mitt Romney of trimming his views for political gain and lacking the conviction needed to hold high office. The comments were unusual for their harsh assessment of Mr. Romneys politics and his character at this early stage of the campaign and for the fact that they came from an official serving in the White House rather than in Mr. Obamas Chicago-based re-election campaign.

title: Tested Again and Again, Cain Takes Comfort in His Rise in the Polls
description: HOMEWOOD, Ala.  For Herman Cain, these have been the sweet days.

title: She Lives
description: A correspondents daughter will be trick-or-treating as the confidence fairy:

title: Starting Lineups: Red Bulls vs. Los Angeles Galaxy
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Starting lineups for the first leg of Major League Soccers Western Conference semifinal between the Red Bulls and the Los Angeles Galaxy:

title: Russian Aide Says Issues With Georgia on Joining Trade Group May Be Settled Soon
description: MOSCOW  A top adviser to President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia said Sunday that the handful of outstanding issues necessary for Russia to join the World Trade Organization could be resolved in a matter of hours, suggesting that a deal was imminent after 18 years of stop-and-go negotiations.

title: Supreme Court to Weigh Effects of Bad Plea Advice
description: WASHINGTON  Anthony Cooper shot a woman in Detroit in 2003 and then received laughably bad legal advice. Because all four of his bullets had struck the victim below her waist, his lawyer said, Mr. Cooper could not be convicted of assault with intent to murder.

title: A Comical Analysis of Sports Childish Side
description: Whats the worst way a day can end for a diligent Manhattan worker bee? Youve logged some late hours at your desk, pushing through a project or getting ready for that big meeting in the morning. You hop the 11 p.m. train for your suburban castle, looking forward to winding down on the ride.

title: Pet Lovers, Pathologized
description: In a 1991 interview titled Eating Well, Jacques Derrida wonders whether a head of state (chef dEtat) could gain office by declaring himself or herself a vegetarian. He concludes, The chief (chef) must be an eater of flesh.

title: In East Harlem, Keep Out Signs Apply to Renters
description: East Harlem has been undergoing a resurgence for two decades, yet the neighborhood is still pockmarked with four- or five-story walk-ups where the ground-floor stores are bustling and the apartments above are devoid of life. Their windows are boarded up, blocked up or just drearily empty, torn curtains testifying to no ones having lived there for years.

title: Nebraska Seeks a Say on the Route of a Pipeline
description: With a federal decision anticipated soon on whether an oil pipeline will be allowed to run from Canada through the nations midsection, lawmakers in Nebraska are being summoned on Tuesday to an unexpected legislative session over the issue, which has stirred up a level of rancor that few had predicted.

title: After a Week Off, a Day on Edge
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  This was supposed to be the final trip to the breakfast buffet for the Giants, a last loll on the beach for a team that opened this season facing a slew of lesser opponents, then spent the past month playing three home games (and enjoying a bye week) before entering what should be the toughest stretch of schedule in the league.

title: Tapping Beethoven to Lift a Radio Stations Profile
description: BEETHOVEN is a giant of classical music. For an offbeat effort on behalf of a classical music station, he is becoming an Obey Giant.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Attacks on Foreigners in Capital Get Afghan Factions Message Across
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Every bomb, they say, has a return address.

title: A Filmmaker Wants to Help Others Use Product Placement
description: LOS ANGELES  Hes not selling out, hes buying in, says the slogan for POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold, Morgan Spurlocks whimsical documentary about product placement in movies and television shows.

title: CNN Is Said to Be Revamping Its Morning Lineup
description: CNN, which remodeled its afternoon and evening schedule earlier this year, is now on the verge of remaking its morning schedule.

title: European Doom Loop
description: For once  and I almost never say this  I think Dean Baker is being a bit too hard here. The Draghi piece was mainly a profile, and Im willing to cut a bit of slack on the macro analysis.

title: Seeing Tantrums as Distress, Not Defiance
description: When I describe the process I went through to get my 3-year-old into preschool to non-New Yorkers, they look at me as if I was wearing an astronaut suit to a dinner party. Eight interviews? Eight tours? Eight applications? For a kid who still has trouble drinking out of a cup? Absurd.

title: For a Free-Form Radio Conference, a Kindred Spirit
description: It would be hard to overstate the level of preposterousness that surrounds Jon Gnarr, the punk rocker-turned-comedic actor-turned mayor of Reykjavik, Iceland. Mr. Gnarr was elected in 2010 after he formed a quasi-satirical political party, the Best Party; his campaign promises included putting a polar bear in the city zoo and offering free towels in the swimming pools  as well as a promise to break all his campaign promises.

title: Monday: A Halloween Puzzle With Bite
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Happy Halloween, everybody! Have you all purchased your candy to dole out to trick-or-treaters? Anyone dressing up in costume for the holiday? Here on the East Coast, were having a very snowy Halloween, and if I was going to dress up, it would most likely be as a Resentful Homeowner Who Is Getting Really Tired of Shoveling Her Walkway. On the other hand, Im hoping there will be lots of chocolate left over to make it worth my while. Theres always a silver lining, am I right?

title: Advertising Companies Fret Over a Digital Talent Gap
description: When the Ad:tech advertising technology conference hits New York next week, marketers, advertising agencies and recruiters may spend less time listening to the panelists and more time working the floor to find new employees.

title: What Was Rafa Marquez Thinking?
description: The Red Bulls 1-0 loss to the Galaxy on Sunday ended with the teams pushing and shoving at midfield after the Red Bulls Rafael Marquez threw the ball at a Galaxy player after the final whistle. Moments later, Marquez and defender Stephen Keel were flat on their backs, with Keel apparently bloodied in the melee.

title: Huntsman Video Takes On Romney Backflips
