description: The campaign of Jon M. Huntsman Jr. on Sunday released a Web video titled Backflip, which highlights what it calls some of Mitt Romneys flips on issues like abortion, gun control and the Ohio proposal to curb the bargaining power of unions.

title: Love and Eros in Motion Among the Deities
description: Do we watch dance in terms of form or expression? As shapes, rhythms and beauty or as meanings, stories and significance? Actually, theres no either/or about it. Dancing is both/and: both a metric, spatial pattern and a profoundly human act at the same time. Yet it always takes me aback to see how drastically Indian classical dance often sets up an apparent dichotomy. That bit was about angles and meters, this bit is about character, emotion and story. But one dancer performs both. By commuting between the two aspects, she demonstrates contrasting planes of existence.

title: Jersey Shore Arrives in Academia. Discuss.
description: CHICAGO  When Deena Cortese was added to the cast of Jersey Shore in Season 3, she was nervous that she wouldnt be welcome, that she wouldnt be able to forge a place for herself in a group with well-established social dynamics.

title: Titans Clash Over a Mere Cadenza
description: Artistic differences. Its the euphemism of choice to save face and explain away unpleasant disputes among performers. The phrase pops up all the time in the arts, but in truth it describes nothing.

title: Comedy Troupe Delivers Its Second New York Baby
description: Taking her first tour on Friday night of the completed Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, known as U.C.B.East for short, in the East Village, Amy Poehler examined its renovated 124-seat performance space, its twin lobbies on Third Street and Avenue A and its momentarily immaculate bathrooms, so clean you could improvise off them, she said.

title: Race Across Time to Stop Assassin and Fall in Love
description: Stephen Kings latest magnum opus, 11/22/63, finds a way to revisit and even revise the events surrounding the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The books front cover depicts a newspaper account of Kennedys death in Dallas on that date. Its rear cover presents the opposite outcome, with the president and first lady looking happy and unscathed.

title: For Home Entertainment Releases, a Rare Bright Spot
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods troubled home entertainment business is moving in an unaccustomed direction: Up.

title: Bartok at Home, With a Touch of the Mischievous
description: Many of the artists chosen by Carnegie Hall to present a series of Perspectives concerts have brought in colleagues from diverse international cultures to share the programs and expand, well, the perspective.

title: Someday His Horse Will Come (and Win)
description: A low-key mockumentary set in the world of horse racing, And Theyre Off ... has its moments but not quite enough to carry it across the finish line. (Racing puns stop now.) Though some of the sports stars  like the trainers Doug ONeill and Bob Baffert, he of the white moptop and dark shades  make cameo appearances and acquit themselves decently, the movie is more interested in down-and-out dreamers than in Kentucky Derby or Breeders Cup winners.

title: Tides of Trance Meld Divine Echoes of South Asia and Africa
description: A trans-Islamic jam session, blending ecstatic trance music from Pakistan and Morocco, was the finale of the concert Saturday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Arts Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. The Pakistani group Qawal Najmuddin Saifuddin & Brothers  making its New York City debut  and the New York group of Moroccan Gnawa musicians, Hassan Hakmoun and Friends, shared a double bill, and then performed together. The concert marked the opening of the museums dazzling New Galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia.

title: Not Business as Usual for Visiting Minnesotans
description: It was high time the Minnesota Orchestra and its Finnish music director, Osmo Vanska, brought something else to Carnegie Hall. For five concerts in a row in previous visits an ensemble known to be adventurous in Minneapolis played only Beethoven and Sibelius: great composers, to be sure, and in sterling performances, Sibelius in particular being a Vanska specialty. But still.

title: Waiting, Waiting and Waiting Some More for a Kill Order
description: Torturous drips of water, screeching metal doors, muffled offstage voices, gurgling toilets.

title: Remembering Sounds That Coltrane Built
description: In remaking the music from John Coltranes 1961 record Africa/Brass, as Reggie Workman did on Friday at Rose Theater, the first step is filling its dimensions. Its not just that you have to fill it with loudness, though you do: the album has a huge cumulative sound. You have to fill it with people, presence and purpose, and you have to justify its repetitiveness. You have to honor pieces of music that seem to want to go on forever.

title: A Store of Images, From a Time When Cut and Paste Meant Just That
description: LONDON

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review Chinglish
description: NYTimes.com readers had mixed to positive reactions to Chinglish, David Henry Hwangs new comedy about Chinese-American relations (and relationships) that opened on Broadway last week. Some found the shows approach to linguistic and cultural confusion humorous; others thought that it had a one-note plot and that the jokes failed to land. (In his review for The New York Times, Ben Brantley called Chinglish a sporadically funny play laid out with the frame-by-frame exactness of a comic strip.)

title: Calling for Avon to Make a Change
description: A good look in the mirror might help Avons management. Andrea Jung, the chief executive of the $8 billion cosmetics company, has twice failed to turn it around. Never mind the federal investigation into possible wrongdoing that was disclosed last week; Avons performance even before then had been dismal.

title: For the Academys New Chief, a Balancing Act
description: LOS ANGELES  Bette Davis, the first female president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, held the job for two months before quitting in frustration. That was in 1941.

title: With New Ad, Perry Looks to Better His Standing in Iowa
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is intensifying his advertising push in Iowa, with the second television commercial of his campaign set to broadcast Monday in hopes of elevating him back into the top tier of Republican presidential candidates.

title: Ruby Cohn, Writer and Expert on Beckett, Dies at 89
description: Ruby Cohn, a theater scholar who espied the genius of Samuel Beckett early on in Paris and became a leading authority on his work as well as his friend, died on Oct. 18 in Oakland, Calif. She was 89 and lived until recently in San Francisco.

title: Robert A. Pritzker Dies at 85; Led Family Business
description: Robert A. Pritzker, an industrial engineer and philanthropist who ran one of Americas largest private companies, died Thursday in Chicago. He was 85.

title: Dutch Hosts Are Winners of Bermuda Bowl
description: VELDHOVEN, the Netherlands  At the world team championships here on Saturday, much to the delight of hundreds of spectators, the Bermuda Bowl was won by the host nation. In the 128-board final Sjoert Brink, Bas Drijver, Bauke Muller, Simon de Wijs, Ricco van Prooijen and Louk Verhees Jr., with Eric Laurant the nonplaying captain, defeated U.S.A.-2: Daniel Zagorin, Kevin Bathurst, Joe Grue, Justin Lall, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge, with Curtis Cheek the nonplaying captain. The final score was 300 international match points to 255. Italy was third.

title: Comedy Tonight
description: Photos of the new Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in the East Village.

title: Riding the Cain Train Through Alabama
description: Herman Cain says his two-day visit to Alabama, when all the other Republican candidates are in New Hampshire or Iowa, is a sign of unconventional boldness.

title: A Law Misused for Political Ends
description: Washington

title: American Songbook Slate Lands Top Stage Talent
description: Lincoln Center is to announce on Monday the 2012 season of its American Songbook series, a typically eclectic lineup that is to feature several Tony Award winners, a group of celebrated pop composers and a solo acoustic set by Thurston Moore, the Sonic Youth co-founder. The concert series, which is scheduled to run from Jan. 11 through Feb. 11 at the Allen Room of Frederick P. Rose Hall, is to include Mr. Moore (Feb. 2); Elaine Paige , the British musical theater actress (Feb. 10); and a performance by Lin-Manuel Miranda previewing his new work, The Hamilton Mixtape (Jan. 11). The lineup is also to include the Broadway stars LaChanze (Jan. 19), Michael Cerveris (Jan. 21) and Laura Benanti (Feb 11).

title: Buffering the Grand Canyon
description: Houston

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: In Living Color to Return on Fox
description: In Living Color, the sketch comedy series that introduced America to the Wayans brothers 20 years ago, is being resurrected for Fox by one of the brothers. The network said on Friday that Keenen Ivory Wayans, left, was set to host and produce two half-hour specials in the mold of In Living Color, which was shown between 1990 and 1994. The shows will appear on Fox next spring and could serve as test episodes for a full series. The programs will have new cast members and musical performances. Mr. Wayans and one of his brothers, Damon, were standouts on the original series, which also featured performers who were not well known at the time, including David Alan Grier, Jennifer Lopez, Jim Carrey and Jamie Foxx.

title: Studied: The Dropout vs. the Graduate
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Says Artists Have Higher Salaries
description: Artists in America constitute a tiny portion of the nations work force, but they tend to be more entrepreneurial, better educated and, with a median salary of $43,230, better paid than the average worker by nearly $4,000, according to a survey released Friday by the National Endowment for the Arts. Nearly 2.1 million Americans  1.4 percent of the total work force  fit into the 11 occupations that the government counts under the artist heading. That includes comics and movie stars, set designers and floral designers. Six in 10 have college degrees, compared with 1 in 3 over all, and 1 out of 3 are self-employed (3.5 times more likely than the average worker). But can you make a living? Mom and Dad want to know. No problem if you become a movie star, concert master or architect (whose median annual salary is $63,000). But the median income drops to $30,000 or less in acting, photography, music or dance. When was the last time your waiter was a part-time actor?

title: Trailblazing States on Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching Skills to Youths
description: To the Editor:

title: Controlling Fertility
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepperidge Farm Rolls, a Click Away
description: Consumers who want to make sure they dont miss any items on their holiday food shopping lists may want to pay attention to a new ad campaign by Pepperidge Farm.

title: Support for Early Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Chicago purchasing managers index for October (Monday); the I.S.M. manufacturing index for October and construction spending for September (Tuesday); ADP employment for October (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, third-quarter productivity, the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for September, and factory orders for August (Thursday); and unemployment for October (Friday).

title: Role of Small Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost of a Horse
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Shift Seen in Rally in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An antigovernment rally in Lahore, led by the former cricket star Imran Khan, attracted a huge crowd estimated at more than 100,000 people on Sunday evening. The rally represented what supporters and some political analysts said was Mr. Khans emergence as a serious challenger to the governing Pakistan Peoples Party and its longtime rival, the Pakistan Muslim League-N.

title: Postcard From L.S.U.: Few Speak Coachs Language
description: Known for his daring, and sometimes puzzling, strategy on the field, Louisiana State Coach Les Miles has also managed to keep fans and reporters alike entertained with his singular vocabulary.

title: A New Ad Race, but the Vehicles Are Retreads
description: WASHINGTONIn Mitt Romneys telling, Gov.Rick Perry made Texas a wasteland. Under the words Unemployment Has Doubled, a tumbleweed rolls across a barren highway.

title: Airport in Yemen Is Hit by Shells as Attacks in the Capital Widen
description: SANA, Yemen  For the first time since fighting broke out here in the Yemeni capital, Sana International Airport came under direct attack on Sunday night, in a possible move by opposition forces to escalate the conflict with the government.

title: Former Adviser to White House Is Likely to Seek Rangels Seat
description: He survived an ethics investigation and a humiliating censure vote on the floor of the House. He endured a brutal re-election battle. Now Representative Charles B. Rangel may face yet another tough challenge to his dwindling power and stature.

title: Postcard From Alabama: A Pattern Always in Fashion
description: In Tuscaloosa, Ala., there are three things that reign supreme: Crimson Tide football, Bear Bryant and houndstooth.

title: MF Global Said to Be in Deal Talks With Interactive Brokers
description: 7:51 a.m. | Updated Shares in MF Global Holdings were halted for trading early on Monday, as the brokerage prepared to file for bankruptcy protection and sell some of its assets to the Interactive Brokers Group, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Yankees Make Offer to Keep Sabathia From Opting Out
description: The Yankees made their formal offer to C. C. Sabathia this weekend in an effort to keep him from opting out of his contract, said a person with knowledge of the situation, who asked not to be identified because he was not at liberty to speak publicly about a continuing negotiation.

title: Road Runners Manifesto: More Than Marathoners
description: For decades, most people have known the New York Road Runners as the organizer of the New York City Marathon, and rightly so. The event draws 45,000 runners from all over the world, attracts more than 2 million spectators and is broadcast internationally.

title: In a Standardized Era, a Creative School Is Forced to Be More So
description: DURHAM, N.H.  Every spring, Linda Rief, who is in her 25th year of teaching English at Oyster River Middle School, has eighth graders do a semester-long genre project. They pick a subject area like mysteries, read masters like Agatha Christie, study the writers craftsmanship (Explain how the author foreshadows doom), then draft their own.

title: After Attacks, Efforts to Restore Truce Between Israel and Groups in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Cross-border tensions between Israel and Gaza simmered on Sunday as Egyptian efforts to restore an informal cease-fire began to take effect after a deadly round of Israeli airstrikes and Palestinian rocket attacks on Saturday.

title: Fighting Over Online Sex Ads
description: What if the price of having a vital, well-financed string of newspapers included rare, but inevitable, sexual predation of minors?

title: B.C.S. Standings Await Shake-Up After SEC Showdown
description: Consider the release of this weeks B.C.S. standings the calm before the storm. There was little activity of note, other than Stanford passing Boise State to move to No. 4 and Houston jumping up to 13.

title: Making a PBS Show, and Its Ads Too
description: The makers of America in Primetime, a four-week documentary series on PBS that began Sunday, produced more than the show itself: they also produced underwriting spots for Unilevers Dove brand that are helping to pay for the program.

title: Hopes for Peace as Kyrgyzstan Votes for New President
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The people of this strategically important Central Asian nation voted in a presidential election on Sunday, seeking an end to years of political turmoil, though some fear the vote could expose the regional and ethnic divisions that nearly tore the country apart last year.

title: Stanford Gains in Title Talk With Victory Over U.S.C.
description: Few have a better perspective of the different modern eras of Stanford football than the political science professor Condoleezza Rice. Along with her better known titles of secretary of state and national security adviser, Rice has been a member of Stanfords faculty since 1981.

title: A Steady Arm Lifts a Shaky Team
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Interview: Ruth Madoff
description: Audio and transcripts from an interview with Ruth Madoff recorded by The Timess Diana B. Henriques in October 2011.

title: Madoffs Aim to Write Their Own Future
description: She stayed, and it cost her more than she ever imagined.

title: Report Cites Womens Claims of Inappropriate Acts by Cain
description: 9:07 p.m. | Updated Two women who worked with Herman Cain at the National Restaurant Association in the 1990s complained of sexually suggestive behavior by him and later took financial payments before leaving the organization, according to a report by Politico on Sunday night.

title: Concerns Are Raised About Genetically Engineered Mosquitoes
description: These mosquitoes are genetically engineered to kill  their own children.

title: 409 Wins? The Coach Who Has Paterno Beat
description: Joe Paterno continues to make history.

title: New Faces and a Contentious Revival
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Business has never been slower at Mina Bridal, which sells billowing taffeta ballroom dresses in colors like hot pink and electric blue for quinceaeras, the traditional 15th birthday celebration for Mexican girls.

title: Joining the Fight in Somalia
description: More than 20 Somali-Americans have gone to Somalia to enlist in the Shabaab, an Islamist group battling the country's government.

title: American Identified as Bomber in Attack on African Union in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The voice in the recording sounds unmistakably familiar  the tenor, the colloquialisms  a boy who grew up in America.

title: With Generators Gone, Wall Street Protesters Try Bicycle Power
description: Rita Moreira, a visitor from Brazil, was walking past Zuccotti Park around noon on Sunday when she stopped to gaze at a man drinking a cup of coffee and pedaling a stationary bicycle connected to several wires.

title: As Meeting Approaches, Fed Panel Is Divided on Direction
description: WASHINGTON  When the Federal Reserves policy-making committee meets on Tuesday and Wednesday, 5 of the 10 voting members will arrive in open disagreement with the chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, about the direction of monetary policy. Three conservative members say the Fed has already done too much. Two liberals say the Fed needs to do much more.

title: Steelers Suddenly Look Young Again
description: PITTSBURGH  Impressions are formed quickly in the N.F.L., and the book on the Pittsburgh Steelers ever since their blowout loss in the season opener was simple: the defending A.F.C. champions had grown old, their defense was not up to its usual standards, and injuries were limiting the team to a season a notch below the leagues elite.

title: Cable Is Holding Web TV at Bay, Earnings Show
description: This time a year ago, the television industry was rife with worry about so-called cord-cutting  people dropping cable subscriptions in favor of watching TV over the Internet.

title: Red Bulls Lose to Galaxy and Then Lose Marquez
description: HARRISON, N.J.  If the Red Bulls have been adept at anything this season, it has been at making things difficult.

title: The Light in a Dark Harbor
description: The mid-autumn dusk of Oct. 31, 1861 cloaked Bostons island-studded harbor as the revolving beacon atop Boston Light began to glow. The beams radiating from the lighthouses bold white pillar sparkled in the enfeebled eyes of the men huddled aboard the steamer the State of Maine, making its way slowly toward the military prison at Fort Warren, an island garrison near the harbors outer edge.

title: Perry Presses for Second Look From Early Voters
description: WASHINGTON  With time running short before the first votes are cast in the Republican presidential contest, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is urgently trying to convince voters that his candidacy warrants a second look. He is retooling his campaign with a newly emphatic anti-Washington message and steering the race into a sharper ideological contrast with Mitt Romney.

title: You Can Take Your Fingers Out of Your Ears: Quieter Taxi TV
description: In a city filled with blaring ambient noise, the back seat of a taxi serves as a poor refuge: from the moment the meter starts running, so does Taxi TV.

title: In Central Park, Snow That Collected on Still-Leafy Branches Fells Even Hardy Trees
description: The storm struck trees of all ages and sizes in Central Park: oaks and elms outside the boathouse, birches and dogwoods near Belvedere Castle, magnolias and mulberries beside the obelisk.

title: Once a Fill-In Keeper, Now a Winning Scorer
description: HARRISON, N.J.

title: U.S. Seeks Aid From Pakistan in Peace Effort
description: WASHINGTON  Just a month after accusing Pakistans spy agency of secretly supporting the Haqqani terrorist network, which has mounted attacks on Americans, the Obama administration is now relying on the same intelligence service to help organize and kick-start reconciliation talks aimed at ending the war in Afghanistan.

title: Lottery Numbers
Rachael Ray Magazine Counts One Issue as Two
description: The November issue of Every Day With Rachael Ray is a bounty of Thanksgiving goodness: 322 ideas, 121 recipes and 40-plus bonus pages.

title: Elite Marathoner Is Right at Home on the Streets of New York
description: Most mornings, Buzunesh Deba does as thousands of other running-mad New Yorkers do: she jumps out of bed, laces her sneakers and heads to the park.

title: Cleaning Up After Nature Plays a Trick
description: It was a storm of record consequence, disrupting large swaths of the Northeast in ways large and small: towns were buried in dense snowfalls, closing down streets, schools and even, in some cases, Halloween celebrations.

title: Once Again, Fast Female Is the Horse to Beat in the Breeders Cup Classic
description: For the third year in a row, the Breeders Cup Classics Big Horse is a she, and this she goes by the name of Havre de Grace. A daughter of Saint Liam, Havre de Grace is the likely morning-line favorite for the 28th running of the Classic, North Americas richest race, on the strength of victories in five of six starts in 2011, including a convincing thumping of the boys in the Woodward Stakes.

title: Woman Killed and Brother Hurt After Leaving Van Amid Pileup
description: A brother and sister who had just emerged from their vehicle after an accident on the Cross Bronx Expressway early Sunday were struck by another car and thrown over a barrier, plunging 75 feet to the ground below, the authorities said.

title: A Perfect Storm for Tree Damage
description: Though the snowfall might have been relatively mild by winter standards, the snow became suspended on leaves, pulling down branches and, in some cases, entire trees.

title: Boyhood Reminiscences Curdle Into Family Drama
description: A playwright battles his demons not on the therapists couch but on the page and the stage in The Atmosphere of Memory, a new play by David Bar Katz at the Bank Street Theater. The odds are definitely stacked in favor of the demons, Im afraid, when we learn that the lead role in the writers memory play is being portrayed by his own mother, a well-known actress and twinkly-eyed narcissist, and the rehearsals are regularly invaded by his estranged father, who belittles and mocks the enterprise with lip-smacking viciousness.

title: Religion at the Ballot Box
Soldiers Death Raises Suspicions in Chinatown
description: Friends and relatives crowd into Su Zhen Chens small apartment in an East Village housing project, bearing food and solace for her and her husband. A community leader sometimes shows up to pay respects, or a military official arrives with papers to sign. Adults gather in the cramped living room for hushed chats in Chinese as children do homework at the kitchen table. For Ms. Chen, these are welcome distractions.

title: Flat Taxes and Angry Voters
description: By wide margins, Americans are now telling pollsters they want a tax system that raises more money and is more fair by asking the rich to pay more. They are connecting the dots between the lavish high-end tax cuts of the past decade and todays serious problems  including widening inequality and mounting deficits  and demanding change. The Republican presidential candidates arent listening.

title: Marshall Eats His Words, and Giants Thank Their Lucky Stars
description: A capsule look at the Giants 20-17 win over the Dolphins on Sunday:

title: A Duty of Effective Counsel
description: The vast majority of criminal cases are resolved by plea bargains: 94 percent in state courts, 97 percent in federal. For defendants, accepting a prosecutors plea deal is less risky than going to trial and possibly being convicted on a more serious charge with a stiffer sentence.

title: Ever More Homeless Families
description: An increase in poverty and rising rents produced a spike in homelessness among families in recent years. With the economy still weak and 14 million people out of work, the situation is bound to get worse.

title: The $350 Honk
description: For years, it has been illegal in New York City to use any claxon installed on a motor vehicle except in an emergency or, unfortunately, as one of those irritating car alarms. The fine for unnecessary horn-blowing is steep  $350 per summons  although very few tickets are given out, which may explain the din.

title: Occupy Protest at St. Pauls Cathedral in London Divides Church
description: LONDON  In a city where demonstrations of every kind are part of the daily syncopation, there has rarely been any with quite the same potential for amplifying the protesters cause as the one that has settled in recently on the historic forecourt of St. Pauls Cathedral, setting off a painful crisis of conscience for the Church of England .

title: Bombs, Bridges and Jobs
description: A few years back Representative Barney Frank coined an apt phrase for many of his colleagues: weaponized Keynesians, defined as those who believe that the government does not create jobs when it funds the building of bridges or important research or retrains workers, but when it builds airplanes that are never going to be used in combat, that is of course economic salvation.

title: Beyond Occupy
description: NEW DELHI

title: Most City Parks Earn Solid Marks, With Some Lagging
description: On their new report cards, New York Citys large parks turn out to be solid performers, earning a respectable B average. The grades, to be given out on Monday in a new study from New Yorkers for Parks, an independent advocacy group, nevertheless show some room for improvement, including the maintenance of drinking fountains and lawns.

title: New Yorks Halloween Spirit, and Other NYTimes.com Reader Tales
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Reinventing Post Offices in a Digital World
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  The Deutsche Post office across from the train station here offers DVDs, umbrellas, phone cards and toys  with the processing of mail appearing nearly an afterthought. And the facility housing it is not a post office at all. Deutsche Post occupies a corner space in a bank.

title: Perry Displays Varied Stance Toward Crime
description: AUSTIN  By the spring of 2004, when Rick Perry had been governor for over three years, the Texas Board of Pardons and Parole had yet to recommend to him that a single death row inmate be spared.

title: Milestones: Rick Perry
description: An interactive timeline of Gov. Rick Perrys life and career.

title: A Tax Bracket Divided Over a Plan to Pay More
description: DENVER  At a wine-and-cheese reception in his office here, Terry M. Barr, president of Samson Oil and Gas, made a pitch to industry executives to donate to the Republican Party of Colorado so that they could defeat President Obama and elect more Republicans at the federal, state and local levels.

title: Giants Replay: Week 8
description: The Giants escaped with a victory after struggling against the winless Miami Dolphins.

title: In Dallas Area, 4 Attacks Linked by Victims Sorority Membership
description: DALLAS  She called it her Delta plate: a silver license-plate frame reading Delta Sigma Theta in red letters across the bottom. Every car she owned since joining the black sorority in 1976 had one, but no more. A few nights ago, she watched her husband remove the plate with a screwdriver.

title: Sports Replay 10/30
description: The day in sports, from a victory celebration in St. Louis, to the conclusion of the Pan American Games, to action from Week 8 of the N.F.L.

title: Corrections: October 31
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Japan Acts Alone to Weaken Its Currency

title: Mining Salt From the Sea
description: One of the magical aspects of running a business is how it eventually taps into everything you know, or thought you knew. Maybe thats why you got into that particular business in the first place, without ever knowing about this secret synergy. Southfork Kitchen has drawn upon just about every experience or interest I have ever had, both obvious and all but forgotten, from music to design, food to entertainment, media to human interaction (oy, those human interactions!). More than a string of nouns, it is nearly a summation of a life.

title: Good Wife Watch: Its All About Connections
description: A rare occurrence on Affairs of State, the seasons sixth episode of The Good Wife on Sunday night: Alicia Florrick was unequivocally on the wrong side of the case. She and the new associate, Caitlin, defended a Taiwanese student who was a suspect in a rape and murder aboard a party boat. The story seemed to revolve around the question of diplomatic immunity (in this case, the lack thereof), but that was a MacGuffin. In the final minutes we and Alicia discovered that she had been defending the killer.

title: Postal Services Adapt
description: Postal services in Germany and other European nations have reinvented themselves over the past decade. The United States Postal Service, facing insolvency, is now looking toward Europe for new operating models.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
description: India successfully hosted its first-ever Grand Prix on Sunday, in front of a 95,000 strong crowd at the Buddh International Circuit outside New Delhi. National dailies were united Monday in their praise for the flawlessly executed event (Times of India), which has dispelled myths(CNN-IBN) about Indias ability to host high-end sporting events after the debacle of the Commonwealth Games. I honestly cannot wait to come back to India, said the two-time world champion Sebastian Vettel, echoing the sentiments of other Formula One drivers whose time in India has left an indelible mark on them (Indian Express). Good tracks these F1 fellows are used to but friendly, open people proved to be Indias greatest ambassadors, according to the Hindustan Times.

title: Oct. 31, 1984 | Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi Assassinated
description: On Oct. 31, 1984, Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated near her residence by two vengeance-seeking Sikh security guards. The men were angry at Gandhis authorization of a military attack on a revered Sikh temple in Amritsar five months earlier.Gandhi, the daughter of Indian independence leader and first Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, first acceded to prime minister in 1966. Her New York Times obituary described her as strong-willed, autocratic and determined to govern an almost ungovernable nation that seemed always in strife and a decisivesome said dictatorialleader.

title: Antique Cars on Display, and on the Road, in London
description: Two hundred years ago it was illegal to drive over four miles per hour on the streets of England, and cars had to be preceded by a man on foot waving a red flag. Luckily, in 1896, the speed limit was raised to 14 miles per hour and cars no longer had to have someone walk ahead of them  the red flag requirement having been eliminated in 1878. In the fall of 1896, motorists celebrated their newfound freedom by driving an Emancipation Run from London to the seaside town of Sussex. Today, a re-enactment of the event, now called the Brighton Veteran Car Run, takes place annually with a procession of pre-1905 cars driving from London to Brighton, about 60 miles away, this year from Nov. 4 to 6.

title: Who Is Your Role Model?
description: People choose their own role modelsfrom older siblings to favorite teachers and even people they have never met. The late Steve Jobs, co-founder and former C.E.O. of Apple, has repeatedly been called a role model in the outpouring of grief since his death in early October. Do you have a role model? If so, does this persons behavior guide you to make the right choices in your life now? Is your role model someone you aspire to be like when you get older?

title: Big Countries Are Sought to Help Fight in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Kenya and Somalia on Monday called for other nations to help in their fight against Islamist insurgents, as an aid organization said that five civilians were killed and more than 50 wounded when a military aircraft hunting the militants struck a displaced-persons camp in southern Somalia.

title: As News Animations Go Mainstream, Taiwanese Pioneers Try Playing It Straight

Muammar el-Qaddafi, as news organizations struggled to put the raw, graphic footage showing his last minutes alive into context, a Taiwanese animation studio famous for its fanciful recreations of news events suddenly found itself competing with CNN. In Atlanta as in Taipei, animators were asked to illustrate what reportedly happened in Libya that day just before Colonel Qaddafi was captured and the cameras started rolling.

At 4-3, the Jets are a game behind, and if they can win both, they will be in no worse than a tie for first place in the division. The Jets would have the tiebreaker advantage over both teams.

Posthumous Amy Winehouse Album Will Be Released in December
description: An album of material recorded by Amy Winehouse before she died, including new tracks as well as reworked versions of songs made popular by her and other artists, will be released on Dec. 5, an announcement on her Web site said Monday. The album, called Lioness: Hidden Treasures, will be released by Island Records, which released her two previous albums, Frank and Back to Black, and will contain 12 tracks Ms. Winehouse recorded between 2002 and 2008, including covers of Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow and The Girl From Ipanema. Other songs include a slower-tempo version of Ms. Winehouses hit Valerie and a new composition called Between the Cheats that Ms. Winehouse planned to include on a possible follow-up to Back to Black.

title: The Long Good Buy
description: After 24 years in the same rent-controlled apartment that I had used as my office (but absolutely not as a mortuary or dental practice, which everyone knows is against code, if youre reading this, L.A. Housing Department), I got the heave-ho when the owners informed me that they needed the place for family. Having been in this one spot for so long, I actually began to look forward to moving, exploring a new part of town, and even gave some mild thought to deaccessioning some pieces I had collected over the years. On my first day of packing, however, I found a New Yorker cartoon that helped me make up my mind. It showed an old man lying on his deathbed. Looking up at a visitor, he says, I should have bought more crap.

It took until Week 8, but we got a clash of powerhouses in the Patriots-Steelers game and a hint that the Eagles might be rounding into a juggernaut to remind us that A) the football gods are not just going to hand a second straight Super Bowl trophy to Green Bay, and B) not every coach dreams of penciling Andrew Luck into next years lineup.

I still consider Obamas failure to appoint someone from EPI to a senior position one of his biggest mistakes; he really needed someone who would speak up for workers and a view of economics not tinged by financial-sector connections.

title: Beau Bridges Succeeds John Larroquette in How to Succeed on Broadway
description: Why should Jeff Bridges be the only sibling in that Hollywood family who has all the fun? While his younger brother gets to cut a country record (and endure endless references to his role in The Big Lebowski), the equally Dude-like Beau Bridges will soon be putting his own musical talents to use in the current Broadway revival of How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, its publicity representatives said on Monday. Mr. Bridges, whose credits include the films Norma Rae and The Fabulous Baker Boys, will take over the role of the corporate big shot J. B. Biggley in How to Succeed on Jan. 3 for a run that is scheduled to end on July 1. He inherits the role from John Larroquette, the Night Court and Boston Legal star who won a Tony Award for his performance in the musical earlier this year.

title: Can You Have a Good Divorce?
description: I was utterly taken with Susan Gregory Thomass article on The Good Divorce in the Sunday Styles section. My parents are rounding the bend on 61 years of marriage, but I well remember the nuclear effect that divorce had on my best friends life. Her parents split when she was 11. They went on to poison every holiday, every birthday, every milestone event for decades. The first time I can recall them ever being in a (large) room together without tearing it down was at my friends wedding, when we were 30.

title: How John Jay Got Its Name (but Not Who Suggested It)
description: It was originally dubbed the College of Police Science in 1965, but students considered the acronym (COPS) undignified. A contest was held to find a better name (the prize, half a gallon of Scotch). Theodore Roosevelt was rejected because he was already memorialized in other institutions. Objections were mustered to Felix Frankfurter  the name, some said, invited ridicule.

Sony Pictures Television said on Monday that it will produce the as-yet-untitled show with Flavor Unit Entertainment, the production company of Queen Latifah and Shakim Compere, and Overbrook Entertainment, the company of James Lassiter and Will Smith (who in 1991 gave Queen Latifah one of her earliest screen appearances on his sitcom The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air).

title: Public Universities Seeking Out-of-State Students
description: In an article published on Sunday in The Chronicle of Higher Education, Eric Hoover and Josh Keller reported that public universities are escalating their recruitment of out-of-state students  students who not only bring geographic diversity to campus, but also pay higher tuition rates and improve a schools bottom line. That finding echoes the results of a recent Inside Higher Ed survey that concluded that more universities are seeking students based on their ability to pay.

title: Creep Show | Sue de Beers Haunt Room
description: The New York artist Sue de Beer has long established herself as an aesthetic interlocutor of teens and the occult, so Halloween provides an apt occasion for her to unveil a new work. De Beers practice first took root through domestically appointed video installations that channeled deep, dark, suburban, subcultural angst. She has steadily drifted toward explorations of the paranormal, conjuring Puritan New England for her 2007 horror film, The Quickening, and more recently  and more minimally  evoking the inherent eeriness of spaces through structures inspired by Brion Gysins Dream Machine or corporate entities like the Seagram Building. Haunt Room, which opened over the weekend on the 14th Street passageway of the High Line, is a 15-foot-wide frosted plexiglass tetradecagon outfitted with powerful infrasound speakers that pump low-frequency tones outside the range of human hearing. According to experiments conducted by Goldsmiths College, these vibrations are capable, in theory, of producing a haunted feeling  or at the very least the perception of strange smells and physiological hallucinations like dizziness. Visitors may enter and judge for themselves how easily their sensory perceptions are smeared. This is a New York haunted house' de Beer says. New York City architecture doesnt have gabled roofs or spooky parlors. It has office buildings, apartment buildings. And the only empty buildings here are either condemned or in the financial district.

title: Lifelong Death Sentences
description: WASHINGTON In 1978, when he was 27, Manuel Valle killed a police officer in Coral Gables, Fla. In September, when he was 61, Mr. Valle was put to death for his crime.

title: Fairy-Tale Shows Capture Viewers
description: It appears that the viewing public has fallen under the spell of not one but two fairy-tale-centric dramas. Once Upon a Time on ABC on Sunday night held on to its impressive premiere numbers: it fell slightly in total viewers to 11.64 million, but retained 100 percent of its premiere 18-to-49-year-old audience. Two nights earlier, despite competing against Game 7 of the World Series, the premiere of NBCs Grimm was sampled by 6.5 million total viewers. It was also the highest-rated Friday nonsports telecast in the 18-to-49 category from any network since Dec. 31, 2010.

description: Last weeks App Smart column pointed out a few apps that help find specialty coffee shops when youre in an unfamiliar area, but for a lot of people, a more pressing task is just completing a coffee run smoothly.

description: October 31, 2011 | Herman Cain pitches his tax plan and denies reports of sexual harassment.

title: In Skadden, MF Global Turns to Familiar Faces for Bankruptcy Filing
description: As MF Global filed for bankruptcy on Monday, it used lawyers who know some of its operations rather well  since they helped sell them six years ago.

title: Whether Humble or Glorious: Telling Stories of Human History Through Objects
description: In Stuff That Defines Us, Carol Vogel writes:

title: TimesCast | U.S. Seeks Pakistan's Help
description: October 31, 2011  The U.S. asks Pakistans spy agency to help set up peace talks in Afghanistan, weeks after accusing the same agency of supporting terrorism.

title: Safety: Car Crashes Pose Greater Risk for Women
description: Women driving cars are much more likely than male drivers to be seriously injured in a crash, even when both groups wear seat belts, according to a new report.

title: Patterns: Study Suggests Obesity Hinders Flu Vaccine
description: A new study suggests that overweight people benefit less from the flu vaccine than those of normal weight, and the heavier they are, the lower their immune response to the shot over time.

title: In a Willets Pt. Junkyard, Soccer Claims Eminent Domain
description: They call it Mad Max Stadium, a cleared-out junkyard enclosed by tall walls of corrugated metal.

title: Lights Out! Uh-Huh! Flash! Flash! Flash!
description: The recent shock of a pre-Halloween winter storm has left many people without power. Next time, those in the dark may want to check out a new product called Mr. Beams.

title: Critics Picks Video: Detour
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Edgar G. Ulmers low-budget film Detour (1945). The film stars Tom Neal as a struggling musician whos hitchhiking his way through California when he meets a femme fatale, played by Ann Savage.

title: London Protests Lead 2nd Church Official to Resign
description: Protests in Londons financial district prompted another resignation Monday as the dean of St. Pauls Cathedral, the Right Rev. Graeme Knowles, announced his intention to step down.

title: FX Adds Another Chapter to American Horror Story
description: Well chalk it up to pure coincidence and nothing more sinister that FX waited until Monday  Halloween  to announce that it is ordering a second season of its macabre series American Horror Story from creators Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk. The show, which stars Dylan McDermott and Connie Britton as a struggling married couple living in a haunted Los Angeles mansion where people cant seem to stop dying, has been a hit for the cable network, drawing nearly 3.2 million viewers for its Oct. 5 debut and averaging about 2.8 million for each new installment. FX said that, through four episodes, American Horror Story was on track to become the highest-rated first season of any series it has broadcast, surpassing Mr. Murphys plastic-surgery drama Nip/Tuck, which began in 2003. The second season of American Horror Story will run 13 episodes; no debut was immediately announced, though it will likely run in the fall, at which point well know whether its more or less terrifying than Charlie Sheens new FX series, Anger Management.

title: Comparing Airplane Boarding Methods
description: Animations displaying the speed of different boarding strategies.

title: Most Annoying Airline Delays Might Just Be in the Boarding
description: Its the common tale of woe for many travelers waiting to board a plane. First the airline has to go through a long list of passengers who have priority: First- and business-class passengers, frequent fliers, elite card holders, uniformed members of the military, families with children, those who hold credit cards affiliated with the airlines, passengers who paid for priority seats.

title: A.C. Grayling
description: The philosopher A.C. Grayling on meaninglessness and making meaning.

title: I Dont Think Thor Needs To Worry About Competition
description: From Business Insider:

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 45
description: Even within a square block, room for tension: a look at the geographical divide within Zuccotti Park between Occupy Wall Streets true believers on the east side and some less committed hangers-on and troublemakers on the west side. [Daily News]

title: The Get | Ronnie Kirsch Clutches
description: Ronnie Kirschs polymer clay clutches stood out among the piles of diamonds and silk pajamas at Bergdorf Goodmans holiday preview. It was refreshing to see such a colorful clutch after a season of so many neutral handbags. Right on time for springs pop fluorescents, the stripes are actually made of clay, then set in an oven like pottery. Kirsch, who holds a bachelors in fine arts from the Rhode Island School of Design and worked in the design departments of Cartier and the Tiffany & Company before starting her own collection, treats the bags as she would works of art. We recommend doing the same.

title: Its Official: Mets Citi Field to Shrink
description: Citi Field, the nearly $800 million stadium built by and for the Mets, was the realization of a family dream, constructed with government financial backing and the support of two mayors. The stadium, with its Ebbets Field touches, was an ode to the past. With its Shake Shack burgers and lobster rolls, it was also a bold bid to cash in on pricey ballpark amenities.

title: DeLong On Central Banking
description: Just read the whole thing  its short. Brad gives us an important history lesson, showing that the lender of last resort function has always been an essential part of a central banks job, and that the Bank of England played that role when necessary even though it lacked proper legal authority.

title: TimesCast | Qaddafi's Hometown In Rubble
description: October 31, 2011 - On the ground in Surt, Libya, Colonel Qaddafi's hometown and the site of his last stand.

title: Behind New Yorks Pension Changes, a Quest for Higher Returns
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New Yorks comptroller, John C. Liu, should perhaps call their ambitious plan to revamp the citys five public-employee retirement funds No Pension Plan Left Behind.

title: John Maus, Hearing Gregorian Plainchant in New Wave
A Lehman Brothers, in Miniature
description: MF Global Holdings and one of its United States subsidiaries filed for Chapter 11 protection on Monday.

title: Fighting the Overprotective Impulse
description: I dont mean to rub it in for those of you in the Northeast (O.K., maybe a little), but Sunday was gorgeous in Berkeley, Calif.: balmy, blue sky and, touch wood, steady ground. My husband and daughter and I took advantage by indulging in a stack of pancakes at an outdoor cafe. She got itchy as Steven and I lingered over coffee and the Sunday paper (why is it that kids wolf their food down when you want to lounge and are impossibly pokey when you dont?) and she asked me if she could go to the bookstore. The store was down the block, around the corner and across one high-traffic street that had a crosswalk but no stop sign or light.I glanced at Steven, hoping for a clue about how to respond.

title: Kardashian Divorce Forces the E! Network to Scramble
description: One of the biggest stars on the E! network, Kim Kardashian, said Monday that she was separating from her husband, Kris Humphries, 72 days after an extravagant, literally made-for-television wedding. Ms. Kardashian cited irreconcilable differences, but some of her fans and detractors sensed a business decision. Ms. Kardashian, after all, had earned millions of dollars by selling the television rights to her Aug. 20 wedding to E!, which has shown Kardashian family reality shows for several years. E! made the most of it, premiering Kims Fairytale Wedding: A Kardashian Event on Oct. 9 and 10 and replaying it almost every day since then.

title: Anxieties Stir as Greece Plans Referendum on Latest Europe Aid Deal
description: ATHENS  In a surprise move that jolted Europe and put his political future in play, Prime Minister George A. Papandreou announced Monday that his government would hold a referendum on a new aid package for Greece, putting austerity measures  and potentially membership in the euro zone  to a popular vote for the first time.

title: Broncos Should See What They Have in Tebow
description: Almost a week after Halloween, Dr. Frankenstein will come to the N.F.L., rolling out quarterback experiments in Oakland and in Denver that originated at opposite starting points but hoped to yield the same result: passing play effective enough to resuscitate a franchise.

title: An Interview With A.C. Grayling
description: This video is part of a weekly series of interviews with contemporary thinkers and philosophers on questions that matter.

title: Qaddafis Canarsie Pen Pal
description: To say Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was a special pen pal of Louis Schlamowitz would be stretching the truth.

title: Super PAC Plans Pro-Perry Advertising in South Carolina
description: 4:57 p.m. | Updated A new Super PAC called Make Us Great Again plans to begin at least $100,000 in advertising over the next 10 days on behalf of Rick Perry in the key state of South Carolina, where campaign analysts say Mr. Perry must perform well in the January primary to have any real shot at the GOP presidential nomination, according to a rival campaign and local television industry officials.

title: Some Help Getting Reimbursed for OTC Drugs
description: New I.R.S. rules that went into effect this year, as part of the Affordable Care Act, made it harder for consumers to have non-prescription medicines reimbursed from health-care flexible spending accounts.

title: Do Nice Doctors Make Better Doctors?
description: In an effort to improve the doctor-patient relationship, many medical schools are now filtering out candidates who lack communication skills. Breeding nice doctors, it seems, is becoming something of a trend. But in an essay in todays New York Times, Dr. Lisa Rosenbaum asks whether selecting future doctors based on their interpersonal skills could backfire:

title: Schedule Released for 12 Presidential Debates
description: There is light at the end of the debate tunnel: There will be only four debates next fall during the general election campaign.

title: From One Maternity Ward, a Growing World
description: Demographers disagree, and the United States Census Bureau says the milestone will not be reached for four months yet.

title: Cain Faces Allegations, and Now, the Possible Repercussions
description: The political impact of the accusations leveled against Herman Cain is difficult to assess in the early hours after they surfaced. But the allegations  and the reactions to them  have the potential to reshape the dynamics of the Republican presidential contest.

title: Tunisia Summons Arafat Widow in Corruption Inquiry
description: The Tunisian government has issued a warrant for the widow of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat in connection with a corruption investigation, the Tunisian state-run news agency reported on Monday.

title: A Hoarders Collection Goes Up for Sale
description: While Lee Roy Hartung may have lacked focus as a collector, he still left behind an extensive collection of cars, motorcycles and memorabilia, which is being auctioned this week in Glenview, Ill.

title: Kardashianomics
description: There are lots of reasons why marriage can be a good financial investment, including that marriage correlates with higher lifetime earnings. But of course for one (soon to be former) celebrity couple  Kim Kardashian and Kris Humphries  the payoff is much quicker, without that whole till-death-do-we-part commitment.

title: Beauty Spots
description: FRESHLY VEGAN Level Naturals is a new vegan skin-care collection from Los Angeles that includes soaps, body "butters and exfoliating body polish. The products are made using natural ingredients like peppermint, lemon verbena and grapefruit bergamot.

description: A soccer tournament played in the Iron Triangle, a surreal land of junkyards and auto shops in Willets Point, Queens.

title: A New Variation in Boarding an Airplane
description: Since checked-bag fees have become ubiquitous, more passengers now carry bags onto the plane. This can result in lines while boarding. In a new seating procedure being used by American Airlines, passengers are grouped randomly, so that their seats are scattered throughout the plane.

title: A Gym at the Inn
description: Rochelle Jacobs has been working out at Exhale, the mind and body spa, two to three times a week for the last nine years. She says she is so dedicated to her gym that she picks her hotels based on their fitness offerings.

title: Mississippis Ambiguous Personhood Amendment
description: ON Nov. 8, Mississippi voters will be asked to decide on a proposed amendment to the state constitution, which would define as a person every human being from the moment of fertilization, cloning, or the functional equivalent thereof.

title: Turkey: Sandblasting Jeans for Distressed Look Proved Harmful for Textile Workers
description: Sandblasting new blue jeans to make them look distressed killed a number of young Turkish textile workers before the practice was outlawed, a new study has found.

title: U.N. Says 7 Billion Now Share the World
description: Feeling claustrophobic? Youre not alone. According to United Nations demographers, 6,999,999,999 other Earthlings potentially felt the same way on Monday when the worlds population topped seven billion. But if youd rather go by the United States Census Bureaus projections, youve got some breathing room. The bureau estimates that even with the worlds population increasing by 215,120 a day, it wont reach seven billion for about four months.

title: City Nixes New Museums Group Soaking Sessions
description: Everybody into the pool! will no longer work so well as a catchphrase for the New Museums career survey of the adventurous work of the Belgium-born artist Carsten Hller, which opened last week. As one of its showstoppers, the exhibition includes a giant sensory deprivation tank created by Mr. Hller, in which museumgoers are invited to disrobe and lie in heavily salted water with a few friends or strangers to achieve a kind of out-of-body experience.

title: Better Batteries: Not Just for Cars Anymore
description: As I wrote in Saturdays paper, energy storage will be critical to making wind power more useful. Some wind farms are forced to dump a substantial portion of their production because they churn out megawatts in the middle of the night, when there is very little demand for it. At such times, some grid operators even charge generators for making power rather than paying them for it.

title: A Reminder on Maintaining Bone Health
description: Is fear, ignorance or procrastination putting you at risk of a devastating bone fracture?

title: 7 Billion and Beyond
description: Get ready to hear about a woman with 11 children who is part of a success story related to population trends.

title: Lost in Space
description: Q. Science-fiction films often depict people being killed by going out an airlock into space. What would that be like?

title: Another Question, This Time Financial, for Herman Cain
description: Early in his candidacy, Herman Cain may have accepted tens of thousands of dollars in goods and services for his campaign from a tax-exempt organization founded by his top aide, documents from the organization show, raising the prospect of serious violations of tax and election law by both Mr. Cains campaign and the organization.

title: Halloween Is Once Again Meredith Whitneys Day
description: The cat is out of the bag.

description: As MF Global filed for bankruptcy on Monday, much of the attention has focused on the Wall Street firms chief executive, Jon S. Corzine, the former New Jersey governor and onetime head of Goldman Sachs.

description: GLENVIEW, Ill.  Lee Roy Hartung may have lacked focus as a collector, but one rule always guided him.

title: New Mummy Insights, No Dissecting Needed
description: Without resorting to intrusive tools, scientists have used X-rays and CT scans to reveal new information about a 2,000-year-old Egyptian mummy.

title: Finding a Way Through the Chatter
description: OVER the years, Ive traveled well over one million miles for business. I approach every flight with a good attitude and roll with whatever happens.

title: Welcome
description: Welcome to Latitude, a new blog from the International Herald Tribunes opinion department.

title: A Peek at the Taxi of Tomorrow
description: The Taxi of Tomorrow  the oblong Nissan minivan unveiled with great fanfare by the city this spring  is a few steps closer to becoming the Taxi of Today. And the public is being invited to take a peek.

title: DirecTV and News Corp. Avert Channel Blackout
description: 6:30 p.m. | Updated |  Representatives for DirecTV and News Corporation said Monday evening that they had averted a looming blackout of regional sports networks, FX and other Fox-owned cable channels.

title: Global Population Reaches 7 Billion, or Doesnt
description: An effort by the United Nations to draw attention to the fact that the global population is now or soon will be 7 billion sowed confusion on Monday, as some news organizations, anxious to put a human face on the estimate, searched the globe for a newborn to anoint the seven billionth person, conflating a projection with an exact count.

title: The Ideas Behind a Move to Occupy London
description: The Occupy London movement does not yet have concrete aims, but it does appear to have some deep, and eclectic, philosophical underpinnings.

title: Welcome
description: If you dont know my name, you probably know my work. Im the editorial page editor of The New York Times, which means Im in charge of the papers opinion sections in print and online  editorials, Op-Eds, letters to the editor and Sunday Review. I head the editorial board, the 19 people who produce the unsigned editorials you can read on our site and in our paper every day. Those articles represent the institutional voice of the board, the editor and the publisher  not, and I cant say this often enough even if Republican politicians refuse to believe it, the Times newsroom.

title: A Toad-Eat-Toad World, and Other Tales of Animal Cannibals
description: When Richard Shine, a biologist at the University of Sydney in Australia, first heard the mystery of the missing eggs, he feared it was another case of what might be called invasive toadkill. He and his colleagues were studying the cane toad, Rhinella marina, a big, warty, sludge-colored Latin American amphibian that was brought to the continent years ago in an ill-fated effort at beetle control.

title: In Sex Harassment Cases, How Much Would an Executive Know?
description: UPDATE: 6:32. Despite Mr. Cains earlier statements that he was unaware of any settlements, he later provided details about one settlement to several interviewers.

title: Thanksgiving Side Dishes, Part 1: Winter Squash
description: Im already thinking about Thanksgiving and the side dishes I want to make this year. If the number of people who signed up for the Healthy Thanksgiving Side Dishes class I taught at Vail Restaurant Month in Colorado a few weeks ago is an indication, Im not the only one.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand, Russia and Washington.

title: It Is Designed to Break Your Heart
description: Last Thursday, just before the sixth game of the World Series, ESPNs Jayson Stark wrote a piece about the Texas Rangers relationship to their local sports fans, suggesting that the teams recent success and potential title might be finally earning them a place in the hearts of Dallass football-mad faithful. Despite their long World Series drought, Stark noted, the Rangers had never inspired the same kind of undying passion as frustrated franchises like the Cubs or Indians or pre-2004 Red Sox: Instead of agonizing over their baseball nines inability to win it all, the Dallas-Fort Worth fan base mainly just ignored them. But a Rangers victory over the Saint Louis Cardinals, he suggested, might change all that: If these Rangers find a way to win just one more time, life in Texas may never be the same all-Cowboys-all-the-time universe again.

title: A Nursing Home Shrinks Until It Feels Like a Home
description: Toni Davis spent much of her childhood roaming the corridors of a nursing home in West Orange, N.J., where her mother was the director. Even now she recalls the pleas of the residents there: Please help me, please take me home with you, theyd beg, Ms. Davis said. I remember asking my mom, Why cant we take them home for dinner for just one night?"

title: Steve Jobss Cancer Choices
description: Did Steve Jobs doom himself by delaying conventional medical treatment?

title: In Some Cases, Even Bad Bacteria May Be Good
description: THE HYPOTHESIS

title: The Flavor of Apples and a Sip of Fall
description: IN apple season, it doesnt take long for me to make the leap from fruit to cider to Calvados, which distills apples down to their elemental character in brandy form.

description: To the Editor:

title: Treating Childhood (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: 60 Minutes Draws Viewers With the Madoffs
description: Interest in the first interview with the wife and son of Bernard L. Madoff lifted 60 Minutes to an unusually strong ratings performance Sunday night.

title: For a Giant Single-Celled Organism, Home Is the Deepest Address on the Planet
description: Researchers returning from an expedition to the Mariana Trench in the western Pacific, the deepest part of the oceans, say it is home to single-celled organisms more than four inches long.

title: Europes Debt Crisis Stymies Financial Overhaul
description: LONDON  As the Continent grapples with the sovereign debt crisis, financial regulatory revision in Europe has been put on the back burner, with some rules delayed until at least 2013.

title: Hugh Jackmans Show Earns More Than $1.2 Million
description: Hugh Jackmans new concert on Broadway set a house record at the Broadhurst Theater, earning more than of $1.2 million last week, a result of the producers decision to charge exorbitant prices for tickets to Mr. Jackmans first return to Broadway as a singer since his Tony Award-winning performance in The Boy from Oz eight years ago. The previous record at the Broadhurst was about $1.18 million set by a production of Merchant of Venice starring Al Pacino during the week between Christmas and New Years Day last season.

title: Unveiling the Attributes of the Divine
description: Over the past decade New Yorkers have caught tantalizing glimpses of the Indian dancer Shantala Shivalingappa at the Fall for Dance Festival and in several works by Pina Bausch. On Sunday, however, the World Music Institute gave us a whole evening of Ms. Shivalingappa, at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts. One evening was hardly enough.

title: Passion de Jeanne dArc
description: Charles Hazlewood conducting a new score for the 1928 film Passion de Jeanne dArc at Alice Tully Hall, part of Lincoln Centers White Light Festival. (Video courtesy of Lincoln Center.)

title: HarperCollins Acquires Religious Book Publisher
description: HarperCollins Publishers said on Monday that it would acquire Thomas Nelson, a publisher based in Nashville, bolstering the companys strength in the market for inspirational and religious books.

title: Rich Get Biggest Break in Perry Tax Plan, Study Finds
description: Gov. Rick Perrys proposal for an opt-in flat tax would primarily benefit the wealthiest Americans, according to a new analysis from the Tax Policy Center, a nonpartisan research organization. Compared with current tax policy, the plan would most likely reduce federal tax revenue by $570 billion, or about 15 percent.

title: In a Blending of Cultures, Politics Pushed Aside
description: In his lucid and haunting works, the composer Toru Takemitsu synthesized the sounds of his native Japan with the techniques of Western modernism. Speaking from the stage of the 92nd Street Y on Thursday evening, the English violinist Daniel Hope summed up this cosmopolitan style: So far, and yet very near.

title: Joan of Arcs Suffering, This Time With Sound
description: Silent films have always had a devoted constituency among history-minded cinema enthusiasts, and aficionados of the form will tell you that directors and actors cultivated an artistry in those dialogue-free movies that was lost when talkies displaced them. For more casual viewers, public screenings are relatively hard to come by. These days they are most likely to be seen as part of a musical performance. Composers, it turns out, are doing more to keep these classics in public view than film societies.

title: The Sea That Gives, and Takes Away
description: It is a sign of the skill, range and taste of the Czech-born choreographer Dusan Tynek that a new dance of his will often recall the work of a great choreographer, a different one each time. That same trait is what keeps Mr. Tynek from advancing out of the artistic category of promising. The first section of his new Widows Walk, performed on Friday as part of his companys two-week season at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, could have been made by Martha Graham.

title: A Point Guards Nightmare Descent Into Drugs
description: Heroin and painkillers play a larger role than basketball in Unguarded, an ESPN documentary on Tuesday night. I come in here and tell you my nightmare, the onetime star Chris Herren, long past his glory days, tells a gym full of high school students, and thats the function of the film as well. Unlike the students, we dont have to listen to him, but its a pretty good story; even if sports arent your thing, you might find it worth hanging around the gym for an hour and a half.

title: Uncle Mo Is Favorite in Breeders Cup Classic
description: 11:25 a.m. | Updated Prayer for Relief has developed a fever and will not race in the Classic, bringing the field to 12.

title: A Fast-Rising Opera Star in a Solo Setting
description: In Friedrich Rckerts poem I Am Lost to the World, the narrator sighs that the world has heard nothing from me for so long,/That it may very well believe that I am dead.

title: Does Anyone Have a Grip on the Democrats?
description: Hundreds of readers commented on Matt Bais article Does Anyone Have a Grip on the G.O.P.?

title: Lessons From a Halloween Costume
description: A year ago I made the seemingly mundane choice to let my son choose his costume for Halloween. He chose Daphne from Scooby Doo. A few parents at his preschool disapproved, I wrote a blog post about it,  and in the blink of an eye, the post set off a national discussion about gender identity, bullying and a parents role in both issues.

title: Prior Experience and Presidential Greatness
description: There is no shortage of claims about what qualifies a candidate to be president. Military service, owning a business, serving in a legislature, serving in an executive position  all of these and more are cited routinely.

title: Staying Cool After a Slog With a Sleigh Isnt Easy
description: Arctic reindeer have thick fur coats that help them survive frigid winters. But they also need to cool off in the winter when their bodies grow warm from running.

title: The Dirty Tackle (Beckham)? The Dirty Team (New York)? Or Is It Just Red Bulls vs. Galaxy?
description: After Sundays 1-0 Galaxy victory over the Red Bulls in the opener of their two-game, total-goals M.L.S. playoff series, Landon Donovan of Los Angeles ripped into the home team for their dirty play. Video below.

title: For a Basso Profundo, a New Literary Tune
description: Alan Hollinghurst, whose new book, The Strangers Child, is just out, does not immediately seem like the kind of writer whose first novel included what amounts to a field guide to the variety of male genitalia. There are only so many ways one can describe a penis, he told British Esquire not long ago, and I think Ive covered most of them.

title: Readers Choice Words on Fees for Hotel Wi-Fi
description: AS someone who is derided by relatives and friends for not knowing how to text on a cellphone, I approach the task of evaluating technology as warily as a man wading into the Everglades with a pork chop tied around his neck.

title: Breaking a Long Silence on Population Control
description: Major American environmental groups have dodged the subject of population control for decades, wary of getting caught up in the bruising politics of reproductive health.

title: The Jazz Chameleon, in All His Colors
description: Chick Corea, the ebullient and eternally youthful pianist, bandleader and composer, turned 70 this year. Being a jazz musician, hes bound by custom to celebrate this mile marker on the bandstand, aglow in retrospection. Had there been a corporate-sponsored jazz festival in New York this summer, he probably would have headlined Carnegie Hall sometime around his birthday, on June 12. Instead hes taking over the Blue Note for most of November, beginning on Tuesday: two sets a night, in 10 different configurations, with collaborators old and new. Its the more fitting option by far.

title: Improviser With a Touch of I Love Lucy
description: Do you remember the mirror routine between Lucille Ball and Harpo Marx in the I Love Lucy show? A homage to a scene in the Marx Brothers film Duck Soup, it features Lucy dressed as Harpo. When she finds herself face to face with the real thing  typical Lucy  she must pretend that she is his reflection and mimics his every move. Its comedy gold.

title: Lumire | Closin Up the Ritz
description: The marble fountain sang. The waiters moved with elegance and grace. The sun softened the sharp edges of the late October afternoon. The outdoor terrace at the Ritz was open for tea. It could have been perfect.

title: Luring a New Headmaster With a $3.8 Million Town House
description: The buyer was looking for a town house in Brooklyn. It needed living space for a family of five and entertaining space for crowds in the dozens. It had to be within walking distance of Pierrepont Street  ruling out Park Slope  but outside of Brooklyn Heights, with its higher price tags.

title: In Israel, Press Freedom Is Under Attack
description: Tel Aviv

title: Movement Smooth as Silk
description: On Saturday night, the Fall for Dance Festival fell right into winter. Unfortunately, the second program, presented at City Center, turned out to be less eventful than the weather. Is it so wrong to want more out of a festival that, lets face it, has the honor of introducing new audiences to dance? At least there are more programs on the way.

title: Plans for an Open Pit Mine Meet Resistance in Bulgaria
description: A proposed gold mine in southeastern Bulgaria has been mired in controversy from the beginning, but this year the government provisionally granted the company a go-ahead, overriding the fierce opposition of the community.

title: Jane the Impaler and a Ghastly Halloween Tradition
description: There is a three-story house of fading red brick in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that gets a bit spooky looking at Halloween, with a rusty fence of iron spikes that only adds to the ominous look.

title: New iPhone Faces Battery Complaints
description: The introduction of a new iPhone wouldnt be complete without at least one baffling technical problem ticking off customers. The iPhone 4S hasnt disappointed in that regard.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,807 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Syria Accused of Kidnapping 4 in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Lebanese police have accused Syria of orchestrating the kidnapping of Syrian dissidents in Lebanon, a country that has served as a haven for them since the uprising against the government of President Bashar al-Assad began nearly eight months ago.

title: Attendance Records in the House
description: Eighteen members of the House have missed more than 10 percent of the 814 votes held so far this year.

title: The Road Ahead for Occupy Wall Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooper Union Looks at Charging Tuition
description: Facing serious financial trouble in a weak economy, Cooper Union, the New York City college founded in 1859 to provide free education for the working class, may begin charging undergraduate tuition for the first time in more than a century, its president said Monday.

title: Justices Hear Arguments in Faulty-Lawyer Cases
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments Monday in two cases concerning what should be done when criminal defendants pass up favorable plea bargains based on unprofessional work by their lawyers.
